This marks a cumulative 6 percentage point cut in 2015, as the bank may revise down its output forecast. The move aims to balance risks and stabilize the economy.

site_title: Volcano erupts on suspected MH370 wreckage island
summary: A volcano erupted on the Indian Ocean island of Reunion, where a piece of plane wing believed to be from missing Malaysia flight MH370 was found. The government banned access to the Piton de la Fournaise volcano, including helicopter visits, after the eruption. The discovery of the plane wing sparked renewed interest in the search for MH370, which disappeared in 2014. The volcano's eruption has raised concerns about the safety of the island, but officials have not confirmed any connection between the volcano and the plane wreckage.

site_title: China to raise US$160b in bonds to build infrastructure: sources
summary: China plans to raise $160 billion in bonds to fund infrastructure projects over the next few years, aiming to stabilize the economy and avoid a hard landing. The funds will primarily be used for large city infrastructure projects and poverty-alleviation initiatives, with the first tranche to be issued in about a month. This move comes as China's economy slows, with urban investment growth hitting a 14-year low. The plan is part of a broader strategy to boost infrastructure spending and shift the economy towards a more consumer-driven model.

site_title: China mulls forcing Tencent, Alibaba to offer rivals' online payment services
summary: China proposed new regulations that could force major Internet companies, including Alibaba, Tencent, and Baidu, to offer rivals' online payment services. The move aims to regulate China's rapidly-changing Internet sector and promote customer choice. The regulations, posted by the People's Bank of China, would require payment institutions to respect customers' right to choose and not force them to use a particular service. This could shift the balance of power in China's online payment industry, potentially favoring rivals of dominant players like Alipay. The central bank is seeking external opinions on the draft proposals.

site_title: Greek retail sales rose 4.2% in May
summary: Greek retail sales increased 4.2% in May compared to the same period last year, following a five-month rise in consumer spending. This modest recovery comes after a six-year recession, with the economy expected to deepen into recession by the end of the year. Retail sales declined by 40% from 2009-2014 due to austerity policies and record unemployment.

site_title: India seeks US$4b spending boost, almost half for state banks
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley seeks parliament's approval to increase the spending budget by US$4 billion, with almost half allocated to state banks to inject extra capital to combat bad loans. The government aims to meet Basel III regulatory requirements and revive investment in the country's third-largest economy. The additional capital infusion is part of a robust recapitalisation plan, but some analysts express disappointment at the amount, citing the need for more capital to help state-run banks grow.

site_title: Soilbuild Construction's Q2 profit up 5% to S$5.5m
summary: SoilBuild Construction's Q2 net profit rose 5% to S$5.51 million, driven by 21% revenue growth to S$81.63 million. The company attributed the increase to progressive revenue contributions from projects like Jalan Lam Huat and Xin Ming Hua. An interim dividend of 0.5 cents per share was declared. The group's order book stands at S$748.6 million, expected to be completed within the next 24 months.

site_title: Malaysia's anti-graft authorities deny charge sheet against PM Najib
summary: Malaysia's Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) has denied the existence of a draft charge sheet against Prime Minister Najib Razak, stating their investigation into SRC International has not been completed. The denial comes after Sarawak Report published a draft charge sheet allegedly drafted by former Attorney General Tan Sri Abdul Gani Patail. The MACC claims the report was not sent to the Attorney-General Chambers, and the investigation is ongoing.

site_title: Greek PM defends Varoufakis over Grexit 'defence plan'
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras defended his former finance minister Yanis Varoufakis over a 'defence plan' against a potential Grexit, stating that Varoufakis did not prepare plans to take Greece out of the euro. Tsipras acknowledged Varoufakis may have made mistakes, but said he was not liable for prosecution. The Supreme Court has forwarded the case to parliament, where a decision on formal charges will be made. Tsipras is trying to regain control of his Syriza party, which has been divided over the austerity measures in the new bailout.

images.alt_text: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras on Friday defended his former finance minister Yanis Varoufakis over a Grexit 'defence plan' that has led to lawsuits against the maverick economist.

site_title: Singapore is second-largest backer of Kickstarter travel jacket that has gone viral
summary: Singapore residents have backed a multi-feature travel jacket project on Kickstarter, making it the second-largest contributor, with over US$3.2 million raised in just three weeks. The project, Baubax, aims to become one of Kickstarter's most-funded campaigns since its launch in 2009, with funding set to close on September 4. The project has garnered significant attention, with over US$2.7 million initially raised and a projected total of US$3.7 million.

site_title: Noble Group battles falling markets as short-selling hits new pitch
summary: Noble Group's shares have plummeted 16% to a 6-1/2-year low as short-selling hits new highs, with investors losing confidence in the commodity trader's prospects. Weaker commodity prices and allegations of asset inflation have contributed to the decline. Noble's credit ratings have weakened, and its bonds have fallen in value, with Standard & Poor's cutting its outlook to negative last month. The company is due to report its earnings on August 13, and investors are monitoring the short interest, which has risen to 12.01% on July 29.

site_title: Greek stock market aims to reopen on Monday: regulator
summary: Greece's stock market aims to reopen on Monday following a five-week shutdown, pending a finance ministry decree detailing new trading rules. The Athens Stock Exchange (ASE) was closed on June 29 due to government-imposed restrictions on withdrawals and foreign transfers. Traders and exchange officials are optimistic about a reopening, despite technical glitches at local banks and concerns about capital outflows. The European Central Bank has approved a plan allowing foreign investors to operate normally, but with limits for local investors. A decision from the finance ministry is expected to confirm the reopening on Monday.

images.alt_text: Greece's stock market aims to reopen on Monday following a five-week shutdown but is still awaiting a finance ministry decree detailing new trading rules, the Greek securities regulator's chairman told Reuters on Friday.

site_title: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust posts 8.7% rise in Q1 DPU
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) reported an 8.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.696 Singapore cents in Q1 2015, driven by higher rents and strong leasing demand. Gross revenue rose 19.1% to S$75.9 million and net property income jumped 18.7% to S$62.4 million. The Reit's acquisition of Sandhill Plaza in Shanghai is expected to contribute to distributable income in subsequent quarters.

site_title: Samsung drops US$10b in market value on stalling S6 sales
summary: Samsung Electronics Co. saw its US$10 billion market value drop in July due to sluggish sales of its Galaxy S6 smartphones, which missed estimates and prompted the company's biggest share decline in four months. The stock fell 6.6% this month, with global smartphone market share falling over 3 percentage points amid tougher competition from Chinese vendors. Samsung will cut prices for its S6 and S6 Edge models to maintain sales growth and has over $43 billion in cash. The company also plans to add middle- and low-end models and cut spending in the phone division.

site_title: China's Sinopec in major shakeup of overseas unit: sources
summary: China's Sinopec Group is relocating nearly 40% of its staff in its global exploration and production unit back to its headquarters, citing a need to cut costs and boost efficiency. The move is part of a broader effort to refocus on core investments and reduce non-core assets. The relocation, which will affect 160 staff, is expected to be completed by the end of 2015. The company is also re-assessing its investment strategy to identify key target zones, prioritizing regions with similar geology and investment climates.

site_title: Asian petchem makers stick to naphtha as glut cuts demand for LPG
summary: Asian petrochemical makers have stuck to naphtha as a supply glut reduces the incentive to switch to liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), with naphtha prices falling due to oversupply. The glut, caused by European and Mediterranean naphtha cargoes, has narrowed the naphtha-to-LPG price difference, limiting buyers' incentive to switch. However, US exports of LPG are expected to increase next year, potentially reversing the trend and making LPG more economical for crackers.

site_title: Euro-area inflation remains at 0.2% as core rate increases
summary: Euro-area inflation remains steady at 0.2% in July, unchanged from June, as core inflation unexpectedly accelerated to 1% - the fastest in 15 months. The European Central Bank faces a challenge to stimulate price growth below its 2% goal. Unemployment remains at 11.1%, and economic confidence reached a four-year high, but data shows a mixed picture for the euro-area economy. The ECB expects inflation to remain low before accelerating to 1.5% in 2016, with the economy growing 1.5% this year and 1.9% in 2016.

site_title: LTA hands over Bulim Bus Depot to Tower Transit Singapore
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has handed over the Bulim Bus Depot to Tower Transit Singapore, which will operate 26 bus services from mid-2016. The depot, spanning 10 hectares, will be fitted out and staffed by Tower Transit, which was awarded the Bulim Bus Package under the new bus contracting model. The transition will be carried out in three stages to minimize inconvenience to commuters, with LTA handing over buses for deployment closer to the implementation date.

site_title: Swiss franc jumps as SNB's record loss fuels intervention doubts
summary: The Swiss franc surged to a one-week high against the euro, reaching 1.0551 per euro, after the Swiss National Bank reported a record loss of 50.1 billion francs (US$52 billion) in the first half of 2015. This loss fueled doubts about the bank's ability to curb gains in the currency, which strengthened against all 31 of its most-traded peers for a fourth straight day. The franc's advance is attributed to investors' concerns that the Swiss National Bank will abandon its efforts to defend the exchange rate, leading to a short-term surge.

site_title: Commodities extend rout as dollar holds gains, Asian shares rise
summary: Commodities continue their worst monthly slump since 2011, with the Bloomberg Commodity Index falling 0.3% and crude oil sinking 1.3%. The US dollar is expected to gain 2.6% this month, driven by rising bets on a US interest rate hike in September. Asian shares rose 0.5%, while European equities were little changed. Emerging markets have been hit hard, with developing-nation stocks heading for their worst month since 2012 and currencies slumping 8% this year.

site_title: Ex-Fukushima execs to be charged over nuclear accident
summary: A Japanese judicial review panel has ruled that three former executives from Tokyo Electric Power, the operator of the Fukushima nuclear plant, should be indicted over the 2011 accident. The executives, Tsunehisa Katsumata, Sakae Muto, and Ichiro Takekuro, will face a criminal trial under Japanese law, despite prosecutors previously declining to press charges. The decision is seen as a victory for campaigners who have demanded accountability for the disaster, which forced tens of thousands from their homes and has had lasting psychological impacts. A trial is expected to be held.

site_title: Oil falls after Opec comments imply no supply cut
summary: Oil prices fell after Opec's secretary-general stated there would be no production cuts, despite a global oversupply. Benchmark North Sea Brent crude dropped 50 cents to $52.81 a barrel, while US light crude fell 60 cents to $47.92 a barrel. Opec's production exceeds demand, with a surplus of 3 million barrels per day, contributing to the decline. Analysts predict further price drops, with some suggesting it may be time to sell into the market.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell on Friday as concern over global oversupply intensified after the head of oil producers' cartel Opec indicated there would be no cuts in production despite a huge global oversupply

site_title: Japan June crude imports fall to 26-year low; oil sales up 1%
summary: Japan's crude imports fell to a 26-year low in June, totaling 2.94 million barrels per day, according to the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry. Total oil product sales rose 0.8% to 2.8 million barrels per day, driven by increased naphtha demand. This marks the fifth consecutive month of rising naphtha sales, reflecting robust ethylene production. Japan's gas station closures have increased by 22% over the last decade, with forecasts indicating further decline.

site_title: India court asks Nestle, food safety regulator to retest Maggi noodles: TV
summary: India's Bombay High court has asked Nestle India and the country's food safety regulator to retest Maggi noodles after a regulator found excess lead in a sample in May. Nestle withdrew the brand from Indian stores last month and challenged the findings in court. The next hearing is set for August 3. This is the latest development in a decade-long food scare in India.

site_title: Lloyds takes US$2.2b provision, clouding dividend prospects
summary: Lloyds Banking Group Plc took a larger-than-expected US$2.2 billion provision for improperly sold loan insurance, threatening its dividend plans. The provision, 400 million pounds higher than estimates, pushed the total set aside to a record 13.4 billion pounds. First-half pretax profit rose 38% to 1.2 billion pounds, missing analyst estimates. The bank will consider special payouts or share buybacks, and its shares fell 0.6% to 85.49 pence.

site_title: US spied on Japan government, companies: WikiLeaks
summary: The US spied on senior Japanese politicians and major companies, including Mitsubishi, from at least 2006, according to WikiLeaks. The list of at least 35 targets includes government officials, ministries, and senior advisers. The spying allegedly occurred during the first administration of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. The revelation raises concerns about the extent of US surveillance in Japan.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close 0.56% higher
summary: Hong Kong shares closed 0.56% higher on Friday, ending a weak week on a positive note. The Hang Seng index rose 138.30 points to 24,636.28, driven by dealers brushing off losses in mainland Chinese markets and a lackluster lead from Wall Street. The index saw turnover of HK$77.73 billion.

site_title: Update: Uber to invest US$1b in India to expand services
summary: Uber Technologies Inc plans to invest US$1 billion in India over the next nine months to expand its services, improve operations, and develop new products. The investment aims to attain 1 million rides daily in India, with the company currently recording 200,000 trips daily. Uber sees tremendous potential in the Indian market and has been working to improve its services after a ban in New Delhi was revoked following the alleged rape of an Uber driver. The company aims to grow exponentially in India, alongside its priority market China.

site_title: Noble Group extends worst rout since 1999 amid SGX warning
summary: Noble Group Ltd plummeted 12% to 46 Singapore cents, its largest monthly drop in 16 years, amid a slump in commodity prices. The Singapore Stock Exchange warned investors to exercise caution due to "unusual trading activities." Noble has rejected criticism of its accounting and hired PricewaterhouseCoopers to review practices. The company has bought back its stock, but analysts say the impact on liquidity and financial leverage is limited. The larger issue is if confidence is affected, potentially impacting the company's credit position.

site_title: Japanese firm to mature whisky in space
summary: A Japanese firm, Suntory, plans to send whisky samples to the International Space Station to test the effects of zero-gravity on its flavor. The whisky will be stored for at least a year and analyzed upon return to assess any changes. The goal is to create a mellow flavor, but commercial applications are not being considered at this time. This experiment follows a surge in Japanese whisky demand after a period drama and a top-rated whisky publication.

site_title: Tsipras survives for now as Greek rebels try to stop rescue plan
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has survived a challenge to his premiership, but the Syriza party's hard-left fringe has brought early elections into view. After 12 hours of talks, the central committee decided to hold an emergency congress in September to vote on Tsipras' plan to accept a strings-attached bailout from international creditors. The move has sparked a rift within the party, with leaders opposing the plan, but Tsipras is set to rely on opposition parties' support to approve the measures.

site_title: Strong franc leaves Swiss central bank with record first-half loss
summary: The Swiss National Bank reported a record first-half loss of 50.1 billion francs due to the strong franc's surge against the euro after the currency cap was dropped. The loss means the bank will need a massive profit in the second half to pay out a dividend to shareholders, including the federal government and Swiss cantons, which is crucial for the country's budget. The bank's profits have been a sensitive topic since it paid no dividend in 2013.

site_title: Hong Kong regulator fines State Bank of India for antimoney laundering failures
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has fined State Bank of India's Hong Kong branch HK$7.5 million for breaching antimoney laundering and counter terrorist financing rules between 2012 and 2013. The bank failed to perform due diligence on 28 corporate customers and verify whether customers were politically exposed persons. As part of the penalty, State Bank of India must submit an independent report outlining remedial actions to address internal control failures, marking one of the first times a bank has been disciplined by the HKMA for such breaches.

site_title: Confidence grows that plane wreckage is from MH370
summary: Authorities are increasingly confident that a 2-meter long piece of wreckage found on an Indian Ocean island is from Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, which vanished 16 months ago. The wreckage is expected to be sent to France for analysis, with experts believing it is a Boeing 777 flaperon, a wing part. The discovery raises hopes of solving the mystery and provides tangible proof the plane went down in the Indian Ocean, consistent with the currents and movements previously suspected.

site_title: Japan says TPP is not a place to negotiate currencies
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso dismissed the idea of negotiating currency manipulation in the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free trade talks, stating it's not a suitable topic for the forum. The US proposal to discuss currency questions was met with skepticism by Japan and other countries, which fear it could hamper trade liberalization efforts. Japan's economy minister, Akira Amari, echoed concerns that currency debates should not be addressed in free trade talks, which are seen as unrelated to currency policy.

site_title: As China stocks crash, this top-ranked fund steps in to buy
summary: China's Shanghai stocks plummeted 8.5% on Monday, the largest decline in eight years, but some top fund managers remain optimistic, citing buying-on-dip opportunities and government support. Eight of 13 surveyed fund managers plan to increase holdings of yuan-denominated shares, while five maintain their positions. Despite volatility, some investors see value in the Chinese market, particularly in large companies that will benefit from government stimulus and reform efforts. Fund managers believe the market is undervalued relative to Hong Kong, and they plan to add to quality growth names.

site_title: Greek PM defends "emergency" plan for potential eurozone exit
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has confirmed that his government prepared contingency plans in case Greece leaves the eurozone, calling it a "responsible government" obligation. Former Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis had secretly prepared to hack into citizens' tax codes to create a parallel payment system. Tsipras' move comes amid concerns about the country's economic future, but he emphasized that Greece is committed to staying in the eurozone. The plans are seen as a precautionary measure, but Varoufakis' actions have raised eyebrows, sparking debate about the government's preparedness for a potential Grexit.

site_title: ANZ Bank fires trader over messages amid benchmark probe
summary: ANZ Bank fired a trader over inappropriate messages uncovered during a probe into possible manipulation of Australia's interest-rate benchmark. The employee was one of seven suspended in November and dismissed after a code of conduct review found evidence of "inappropriate electronic communication." The Australian Securities & Investments Commission is still investigating the setting of the bank bill swap rate, and regulators worldwide have led to billions of dollars in fines for rigging interest-rate benchmarks. The dismissal sends a message that "transgressions will not be tolerated" by banks and regulators.

site_title: Thai central bank consumption index up 0.9% month-on-month in June
summary: Thailand's central bank reported a current account surplus of $893 million in June, following a $2.13 billion surplus in May. The Bank of Thailand's private consumption index rose 0.9% month-on-month, while the investment index increased 0.2%. Exports slipped 8.9% from a year earlier, after a 5.5% drop in May.

site_title: Myanmar conglomerate asks Singapore court to enforce F&N brewery stake sale
summary: Myanma Economic Holdings Ltd (MEHL) has asked Singapore's High Court to enforce the transfer of its 55% stake in Myanmar Brewery to the Myanmar firm by August 20. MEHL plans to pay F&N $407 million (500 billion kyat) for the stake, while F&N estimates its value at $560 million based on a 2013 exchange rate. MEHL won an arbitration case in 2013, and F&N claims MEHL has breached its obligations by refusing to complete the sale in US dollars. The court will decide on the matter.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise; first monthly gain in 5 months
summary: Australian shares rose 0.52% on Friday, marking the first monthly gain in 5 months, driven by higher yielding financial sector stocks and improved risk appetites. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 29.677 points to 5,699.200, its third straight day of gains. New Zealand's NZX 50 index also rose 0.49% for its third straight day of gains.

site_title: Airbus aims to double A350 output in 2016, sees A380 sales soon
summary: Airbus aims to deliver 30 A350 jets in 2016, doubling its 2015 production target of 15. The company also plans to break even on A380 sales this year, despite delivering fewer than planned. Airbus is focusing on ramping up its newest passenger jet and has made progress in addressing communication issues with European governments regarding the A400M transporter plane. The company is also considering increasing A320-family production, but is being cautious. Meanwhile, talks to sell defense and space assets will accelerate in the second half of the year.

site_title: China: Shares post worst monthly loss in 6 years despite govt support steps
summary: China's stock markets posted their worst monthly loss in nearly six years, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 1.1% to 3,664.0 points. The decline follows a savage correction in mid-June, where the market slumped 30% after more than doubling in a year. The government has rolled out support measures, including buying shares and providing funding to investors, to stabilize the market. Despite these efforts, the market remains volatile, with investors sensitive to weekend announcements and weekend market closures.

site_title: China makes FX rules ready for foreigners to trade its commodity futures
summary: China has made foreign exchange regulations ready for foreigners to trade its commodity futures, allowing them to transfer either foreign currency or yuan funds. Foreign investors, particularly institutional investors, will help develop the sector and bring international practices. As of August 1, foreign commodity futures trading or brokerage firms can open special accounts in designated China-based banks, with funds to be used only for trading and reported to the State Administration of Foreign Exchange. The Shanghai Futures Exchange's crude oil futures will be the first contract open to overseas players, with other domestic futures contracts to be announced later.

site_title: Hot stock update: Noble dives deeper, risks being booted out of the blue-chip STI
summary: NOBLE Group shares plummeted 15% to S$0.44, their lowest close since November 2008, amid speculation that the commodities group could be dropped from the blue-chip Straits Times Index. The stock has lost over 60% of its market value since mid-February, following criticism of its accounting practices. A review in September may determine Noble's fate, with analysts warning that a decline in market value could lead to deletion from the index. The Singapore Exchange has also warned investors to exercise caution when trading Noble's shares due to "unusual trading activities."

site_title: Indonesia central bank says will keep tight monetary policy stance
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, will maintain its tight monetary policy stance amid global uncertainty, Governor Agus Martowardojo announced. The bank has kept its key interest rate at 7.50% since February, with Deputy Director Yoga Affandi stating there should be room to loosen policy after the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates. The decision aims to remain vigilant on developments and maintain stability in the economy.

site_title: China: Stocks fall at market open
summary: China stocks fell 1.0% to 3,777.15 points and 1.4% to 3,655.67 points at market open on Friday, July 31, 2015. The CSI300 index futures for August also dropped 0.3% to 3,668.4 points. The decline was attributed to a lack of significant economic data releases.

site_title: Ringgit extends monthly losses as 1MDB scandal hurts sentiment
summary: Malaysia's ringgit dropped for a third consecutive month, reaching a 16-year low due to a 1MDB scandal and negative investor sentiment. The currency weakened 0.2% on Friday and 1.4% this month, with forward contracts signaling further weakness towards 4 dollars per ringgit. The decline in investor confidence has led to a surge in demand for government bonds, with the 10-year yield rising 7 basis points to 4.09% and the 5-year yield dropping 2 points to 3.62%. Foreign-exchange reserves have declined to their lowest level since 2009.

site_title: Olympics: Final 2022 Games showdown for Beijing, Almaty
summary: China's Beijing and Kazakhstan's Almaty are in a final showdown to host the 2022 Winter Olympics, with 85 IOC members set to vote on the winner. Beijing, favored due to its economic and political weight, promised a "fantastic" Games, while Almaty emphasized its "winter wonderland" and athlete-centered approach. China's President Xi Jinping assured the world of a successful event, while Almaty's bid highlighted its smaller-scale, locally-hosted approach. The winner will be announced later on Friday, with Beijing expected to secure the hosting rights.

site_title: China says needs to ensure economic risks don't trigger social risks
summary: China's state planner warned that slowing economic growth poses a risk to social stability, emphasizing the need to prevent economic risks from escalating into social unrest. The government aims to keep unemployment low, a priority for stability, but acknowledges the challenges in doing so as the economy grinds towards a 25-year low. The National Development and Reform Commission suggested improving the social security system to mitigate risks and promote structural transformation in the labor market, particularly in regions heavily reliant on polluting industries.

site_title: Action Asia may be suspended after public float falls on planned delisting
summary: Action Asia Limited, a consumer electronics manufacturer, may face suspension from trading on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after its public float fell below the required 10%. The company plans to delist from SGX and has received 90.19% of issued shares in an exit offer, set to close on Aug 14.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.30%
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.30% higher on Friday, defying lacklustre Japanese economic data, amid anticipation of company earnings results. The Nikkei 225 index rose 62.41 points to 20,585.24, while the Topix index gained 0.75% to 1,659.52. Investors awaited key earnings reports on the busiest day of Japan's earnings season.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks ended higher on Thursday, in line with a broad rally across Asia following upbeat US data while a weaker yen provided support to Japanese exporters.

site_title: German retail sales post biggest first-half increase in 20 years
summary: German retail sales posted a 2.5% increase in real terms from January to June, the largest first-half increase in 20 years, driven by strong private consumption. Annual retail sales rose 5.1% and household spending is expected to boost the economy. However, monthly retail sales dropped 2.3% in real terms, below forecast. Strong employment and morale among German shoppers, combined with cheap oil, are expected to fuel private consumption. The data bodes well for Germany's economic growth this year.

site_title: China says former senior police chief suspected of murder
summary: China's anti-graft watchdog accused former police chief Zhao Liping of suspected murder, bribery, and illegal firearm possession. Zhao, who led police in Inner Mongolia from 2005-2010, was detained after a woman's murder in March. He was also accused of adultery. Zhao was expelled from the party, his illicit gains seized, and will be prosecuted. This move is part of President Xi Jinping's efforts to root out corruption within the party.

site_title: Indonesia central bank sees July inflation at 7.13% y-o-y
summary: Indonesia's central bank expects July inflation to ease to 7.13% y-o-y, down from 7.26% in June. Governor Agus Martowardojo attributed the slight decrease to the holiday season. Consumer prices are predicted to rise 0.8% on a monthly basis. The bank will monitor food supply and distribution to prevent higher prices due to the El Nino weather pattern.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets inch up at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Friday, driven by healthy US growth data and anticipation of eurozone inflation and jobs data. The FTSE 100 index in London increased 0.23%, while the CAC 40 in Paris rose 0.34%. The DAX 30 in Frankfurt also climbed 0.13%. The US Commerce Department reported a 2.3% annual expansion rate in the April-June period, the strongest since 2014. Investors await the release of eurozone data, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: Seoul: Shares erase early loss to close higher; won edges down
summary: Seoul shares ended the day 0.6% higher, erasing an early loss, as foreign investors bought a net 162.86 billion won worth of KOSPI shares. However, the KOSPI fell 2.1% for the month, its largest monthly loss in seven months, and 0.8% for the week. The won was down 0.1% at 1,170.0 per dollar, marking its sharpest monthly loss since September 2011.

site_title: Singapore June bank lending at 5-month high on construction loans
summary: Singapore's total bank lending in June reached a five-month high, driven by a 5.0% increase in housing and bridging loans to S$180.3 billion. Loans to the building and construction sector also rose, contributing to the growth. This marked a 1.5% increase from the same period last year, with loans to non-Singapore Asian currencies decreasing to S$554.5 billion. The total bank lending stood at S$606.8 billion, the highest since January.

site_title: Hot stock: UOB leads tumble among Singapore banking stocks
summary: UOB shares plummeted 4.10% to S$21.99 after reporting weaker-than-expected second-quarter earnings, missing analyst estimates. The bank's net profit fell 5.7% to S$762 million. Rivals DBS and OCBC also fell, with DBS down 3.28% and OCBC down 0.78%. The decline was attributed to lower treasury and investment income, and was part of a wider market downturn influenced by the Chinese stock market.

site_title: Shell Japan deal signals further refiner consolidation
summary: Shell Japan deal signals further refiner consolidation in Japan as Idemitsu Kosan Co agrees to purchase most of Royal Dutch Shell's stake in Showa Shell Sekiyu KK, potentially creating a company with about a third of the domestic gasoline market. The move could lead to industry consolidation, with Japan's refineries facing declining demand and unstable refinery margin trends. The deal follows existing consolidation efforts, such as TonenGeneral Sekiyu KK's merger with Cosmo Oil Co. The government has urged industry consolidation to address declining demand and export competitiveness.

site_title: Singapore manufacturers looking less optimistic about H2 2015: EDB survey
summary: Manufacturers in Singapore are less optimistic about the second half of 2015, according to a quarterly EDB survey. 16% of firms expect improved business conditions, while 14% expect deterioration, resulting in a 2% net weighted balance. The biomedical cluster is the most optimistic, while the chemical and transport engineering clusters have a gloomier outlook, particularly the marine and offshore engineering segment due to low oil prices.

site_title: China stock regulator restricts 24 trading accounts for suspected irregularities
summary: China's securities regulator restricted 24 trading accounts for suspected irregularities, including abnormal bids and bid cancellations that may have affected share prices or influenced investment decisions. The regulator is also investigating automated trading strategies in Shanghai and Shenzhen exchanges to analyze their impact on the stock market. This move is part of China's efforts to rescue its stock market, which has plummeted 35% in less than four weeks.

site_title: Australia 'increasingly confident debris from MH370': search chief
summary: Australian authorities are "increasingly confident" that debris found on the French island of La Reunion is from missing flight MH370. The two-metre piece of wreckage, believed to be a flaperon from a Boeing 777, is expected to arrive in France for analysis. Formal identification is possible within 24 hours, with investigators working to confirm its origin. The discovery comes as the search for MH370, which vanished in 2014 with 239 people on board, continues despite a massive search effort.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly up, dollar edges lower
summary: Asian stocks advanced on Friday, driven by the US economy's strong growth data, while the dollar edged lower. Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney rose, but Shanghai slipped 2.10% as the market struggles to recover from a recent sell-off. The US Commerce Department reported the world's top economy expanded at an annual rate of 2.3% in the April-June period, the strongest rate since 2014. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates as soon as September, supporting the dollar's advance.

site_title: Singapore services firms maintain optimism levels from a quarter ago
summary: Singapore services firms maintain optimism levels, with a net weighted balance of 2% expecting better business conditions for the second half of 2015, comparable to a quarter ago. However, this is lower than the 13% recorded last year. The food & beverage services sector, with a 21% net weighted balance, has the brightest prospects, while the accommodation industry expects a boost from the upcoming Formula One night race and year-end holiday period. Real estate and wholesale trade sectors have negative outlooks due to government measures.

images.alt_text: Firms in Singapore's services sector remain as upbeat about their short-term business prospects as they were a quarter ago.

site_title: Australia plays down MH370 luggage link
summary: Australian search chiefs for the missing MH370 flight played down the discovery of a suitcase on the French island of La Reunion, which sparked speculation about a possible link to the missing plane. The suitcase was found near plane wreckage, but experts believe it is unlikely to be from the doomed flight, citing a lack of indication of prolonged exposure to water. The Australian Transport Safety Bureau will examine the suitcase, but its findings are considered inconclusive at this point.

images.alt_text: Australian MH370 search chiefs on Friday played down any link between part of a bag discovered on the French island of La Reunion and the doomed flight.

site_title: BOJ does not have a "Kuroda line" to stop yen weakening: sources
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda never intended to set a "Kuroda line" to stop the yen from weakening, sources say. Kuroda's comments in parliament sparked a yen rally, but he prefers a weaker currency to a sharp bounce. The BOJ prefers moderate yen declines, which help exports and aid the economy's 2% inflation target. The governor's previous experience with a strong yen during his diplomatic role has made him cautious of sharp yen rises, and a weak yen also helps the BOJ achieve its inflation goal.

site_title: Families of MH370 victims renew talk of compensation after debris find
summary: Families of MH370 victims are renewing efforts to seek compensation after debris from the missing Malaysia Airlines flight was found on a remote island in the Indian Ocean. The 2-2.5 meter long wing surface, identified as a Boeing 777 part, has raised hopes that other useful debris could turn up, allowing investigators to examine patterns of destruction. Families, mostly Chinese, are considering suing Malaysian Airlines, Boeing, and other parties, potentially leading to millions of dollars in compensation. A two-year statute of limitations is set to expire in March 2016.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 2.43 points to 1,702.35. The market saw 38.82 million lots traded worth RM11.85 million, with 86 gainers and 50 losers.

site_title: Gold heads for longest weekly losing streak in 16 years
summary: Gold prices plummeted to near 5-1/2-year lows, marking its longest weekly losing streak in 16 years, as upbeat US economic data strengthened expectations for a near-term interest rate hike. The July 20 selloff saw gold drop 3% and has since lost 7.5% for the month, with spot gold falling 0.3% to $1,084.60 an ounce. The US Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates in September is seen as a major factor contributing to gold's decline, with investors favoring non-interest bearing assets.

site_title: Oil prices dip as Opec official says no cuts planned
summary: Oil prices dropped on Thursday, with US West Texas Intermediate falling 27 cents to $48.52 a barrel and European benchmark Brent oil shedding seven cents to $53.31 a barrel. Opec's Secretary General, Abdullah El-Badri, stated that the cartel has no plans to cut petroleum production, citing a meeting in December and June. The market is expected to shift into a "quieter choppy consolidation mode" as it works off a short-term oversold condition, pending fresh fundamental news.

site_title: Oil prices down in Asia
summary: Oil prices declined in Asia, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling 36 cents to $48.16 a barrel and Brent crude shedding 29 cents to $53.02 a barrel. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) indicated it will not cut output, citing current high output levels and a stronger dollar. Analysts say Opec is defending its market share against US shale oil competition. The US economy's expansion and expected Federal Reserve interest rate hike also contribute to downward pressure on prices.

images.alt_text: Oil prices extended their decline in Asia Friday after the Opec cartel indicated that current lofty output levels will remain, while a stronger dollar is also causing downward pressure.

site_title: Airbus Group profits up 34% in first half 2015
summary: Airbus Group reported a 34% increase in net profits to 1.5 billion euros for the first half of 2015, driven by the sale of its Dassault Aviation stake. The sale offset a 290 million euro charge related to the Airbus A400M military transporter programme, which suffered a setback after a test flight crash in May. The program's costs were partially offset by a 748 million euro gain from the Dassault Aviation sale.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble tumbles a further 13%
summary: Noble Group's shares plummeted 13% on Friday, following a 12% decline the previous day, amid concerns over trading practices. The Singapore Exchange requested Noble to explain the unusual trading. The company has spent S$131 million on a share buyback, its largest since 2014. Noble's stock has lost about half its value since February, when Iceberg Research criticized the firm's accounting practices. The company has rejected the criticism and hired PricewaterhouseCoopers to review its practices.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down on poor GDP growth reading
summary: Taiwan's stocks plummeted 0.6% on Friday after the government reported a dismal 0.64% GDP growth in the second quarter, significantly lower than the expected 2.67%. The main TAIEX index fell to 8,600.38, while the electronics subindex sank 0.3% and the financials subindex lost 0.9%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$31.549 per US dollar.

site_title: Singapore shares open 1.1% down on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.09% to 3,214.03 points, with 108 million shares traded worth S$283.3 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 69 to 61, and stocks like OCBC, UOB, and Global Logistic Properties were among the most actively traded.

site_title: Uber to invest US$1 billion in India: FT
summary: Uber is investing US$1 billion in India, aiming to reach 1 million daily rides by March 2016. The move brings its investment in India on par with that in China. Uber is expanding its service beyond 18 cities and sees a 40% monthly growth rate. The company has also launched an auto leasing subsidiary to sign up more drivers. This investment comes after a Delhi court revoked a government ban on Uber, clearing the way for the company to operate in the capital city and reapply for a license.

site_title: Taiwan Q2 GDP up 0.64%, sharply lower than forecast
summary: Taiwan's economy grew 0.64% in Q2, lower than forecasted 2.67%, due to decreased sales of key technology products to China and other major markets. This marks a sharp decline from the 3.37% annual growth in the first quarter. The export-driven economy is expected to face further challenges in the coming months.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.62% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.62% in the opening exchanges on July 31, 2015, following a broad Asian advance. The Hang Seng Index added 152.95 points to 24,650.93, despite a tepid lead from Wall Street. Investors brushed off concerns about US-EU tariffs, with the city's benchmark index in line with regional gains.

site_title: Japan consumer inflation tepid, spending down in June
summary: Japan's inflation remained low in June, with core inflation at 0.1% year-on-year, short of the Bank of Japan's 2.0% target. Household spending dropped 2.0% in June, a surprise after a 4.8% increase in May, due to lower fuel prices and the impact of a sales tax hike last year. Economists expect the Bank of Japan to ease monetary policy to stimulate growth.

site_title: In rural China, shoppers go online - with a little help
summary: Alibaba Group is investing heavily in rural e-commerce in China, aiming to tap into a market twice the size of the US. Despite the potential, few are making money yet, with the company teaching local "partners" how to shop online and set up service centers in their villages. Over 1,000 applicants have been trained, and Alibaba plans to establish more than 100,000 rural service centers. However, challenges remain, including lack of rural infrastructure and skepticism from local residents, with some struggling to compete with e-commerce giants.

site_title: Ringgit reaches 16-year low as 1MDB scandal hurts sentiment
summary: Malaysia's ringgit reached a 16-year low due to investor sentiment hurt by the 1MDB scandal, with the currency dropping 1.2% to 3.8168 a dollar in July. The scandal led to demand for government bonds and a decline in foreign-exchange reserves. The central bank discouraged transactions that would result in selling the ringgit, and forward contracts signal further weakness. The 10-year yield rose seven basis points to 4.09% and the five-year yield dropped three to 3.61% in July.

site_title: Pacific trade negotiators chase elusive final deal amid tough talks
summary: Pacific trade negotiators are nearing a final deal for the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a free trade pact aiming to cut trade barriers for 40% of the world economy. However, outstanding issues remain, including dairy exports and monopoly periods for biologic drugs, with the US pushing for 12 years and Australia and other countries seeking 5. The deal's fate is uncertain, with some officials expressing frustration over the negotiations' progress, while others stress their efforts to close the deal by the end of the week.

site_title: Facebook ready to test Internet-beaming drones
summary: Facebook is set to begin testing its high-altitude drone, Aquila, designed to provide internet access to remote locations. The solar-powered drone, with a wingspan similar to a Boeing 737, can remain aloft for three months and beam internet service from altitudes of 18,000 to 27,000m. Facebook aims to accelerate the development of internet infrastructure through its Connectivity Lab, but will not become an internet operator or carrier, instead providing technology to other partners.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust completes Hyderabad IT building acquisition
summary: Ascendas India Trust has completed the acquisition of multi-tenanted IT building aVance 3 in Hyderabad for 2.94 billion rupees (S$63 million). The building has a 94% leasing commitment and increases the trust's total floor area to 8.8 million sq ft, deepening its presence in Hyderabad. This acquisition is expected to support the trust's income growth.

site_title: Plane debris to be probed in France as MH370 enigma swirls
summary: A piece of plane debris, identified as a flaperon from a Boeing 777, has washed up on the French island of La Reunion, sparking hopes it may be linked to missing flight MH370. The 2m long flaperon, sent to France for investigation, has been compared to hundreds of photos and blueprints and matches the missing plane's wing part. Scientists say ocean currents could have carried debris from the plane to the island, with several plausible scenarios proposed. Malaysian authorities have confirmed the debris is "very likely" from a Boeing 777, but the origin remains uncertain, fueling continued speculation and emotional turmoil for relatives of the missing passengers.

site_title: UOB's Q2 net profit falls 5.7% on weaker treasury and investment income
summary: UOB Group reported a 5.7% decline in Q2 net profit to S$762 million, mainly due to weaker treasury and investment income. Total income grew 2.2% to S$1.93 billion, while net interest income rose 7.9% to S$1.21 billion. Fee and commission income increased 13.4% to S$465 million. The bank declared an interim cash dividend of 35 cents per ordinary share, citing higher staff costs and IT expenses. Gross loans grew 4.8% to S$202 billion, while deposits rose 11.7% to S$241 billion.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down 0.08% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.08% lower on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 16.28 points to 20,506.55. Household spending in Japan dropped 2.0% year-on-year in June, and core inflation rose 0.1%, short of the Bank of Japan's target of 2.0%. The dollar lost steam after a report on US growth confirmed the economy is expanding at a moderate rate.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, UOB, GLP, NOL, SMRT
summary: OCBC reported a 14% increase in net profit to S$1.05 billion for the second quarter of 2015, driven by new highs in net interest income and non-interest income. UOB's net profit fell 5.7% to S$762 million due to lower treasury and investment income. GLP's earnings rose 49.4% to US$268.1 million due to joint ventures and higher asset values. NOL returned to profit with a net profit of US$889.5 million, mostly from the sale of its logistics arm. SMRT's first quarter net profit slipped 10% to S$20.13 million due to losses from rail operations.

site_title: L'Oreal confident for 2015 after first-half sales, profit shine
summary: L'Oreal reported a 8.5% increase in net profit and a 14.7% surge in sales for the first half of 2015, driven by positive currency effects and growth across all divisions. Chairman and CEO Jean-Paul Agon attributed the strong results to innovation, e-commerce growth, and the roll-out of recently acquired brands. The company projects an acceleration in growth in the second half and a year of significant growth in both sales and profits.

images.alt_text: The world's largest cosmetics company L'Oreal on Thursday confirmed a "significant growth" in results for 2015 after posting an 8.5 percent jump in net profit in the first half of the year.

site_title: Facebook Q2 revenue, profit top Wall St forecasts
summary: Facebook reported Q2 revenue ($4.04 billion) and profit ($719 million) exceeding Wall Street forecasts, with 1.49 billion monthly users and 65% daily check-ins. However, total costs rose 82% from a year ago, shrinking profit margins. The company's stock initially dropped 5% before recovering. Facebook's strong growth in advertising revenue and expansion into Instagram and WhatsApp continue to impress investors.

site_title: Global economic woes dent strong UK consumer sentiment: GfK
summary: British consumer morale eased in July, falling to +4 from +7 in June, due to concerns about Greece and the global economy. Household spending remained weak, and Britons were more pessimistic about the general economic situation over the next year, with the index measuring this fell to -1 in July. The underlying message is strong, according to GfK, despite a dip in morale. Rising wages and zero inflation have increased consumers' disposable income, but global uncertainty and the potential Grexit meltdown have weighed on Britons' outlook.

images.alt_text: British consumer morale eased in July as concerns about Greece and the global economy weighed on Britons' outlook for the economic situation over the next year, a survey showed on Friday.

site_title: Apple to unveil next Apple TV version in September
summary: Apple plans to unveil its next-generation Apple TV set-top box in September, featuring a slimmer chassis, a new remote with touch-pad input, and support for Siri voice control. The device will also have increased on-board storage and a new operating system, along with its own App Store and software development kit for app developers. This marks the first refresh of the Apple TV since 2013, with the company initially expected to unveil the device in June at its Worldwide Developers Conference.

site_title: Trump leads Republicans but Democrats thump him: poll
summary: US billionaire Donald Trump leads the Republican field in the 2016 presidential race with 20% support, but Hillary Clinton and other Democrats outperform him in head-to-head matchups. Clinton leads with 55% support among Democratic voters, while Trump trails her by significant margins in hypothetical matchups. Trump's negatives are high, with 30% of Republicans saying they would not support him, but he remains a dominant force in the Republican field.

site_title: Home is where the kale is
summary: Urban farmer Donald Tan, a 49-year-old Singaporean, has successfully grown vegetables in his HDB corridor garden for 13 years. Despite the lack of space, Tan has cultivated a variety of edible plants, including kale, using a microclimate approach to overcome the limitations. His family enjoys the fresh produce, and his story has inspired others to take up urban farming, as seen in the documentary "Growing Roots." Tan's experience showcases the potential of growing one's own food in small spaces, encouraging others to adopt a similar approach.

images.alt_text: A former IT manager, Donald Tan is also a full-time team member of Edible Garden City, a company which promotes growing natural produce in Singapore. He says: "My wife Rachel doesn't really partake in the maintenance of the plants, but she harvests them for cooking. She enjoys the cooking part, and I enjoy the planting and eating part. So it's a great partnership."

site_title: Indofood Agri's Q2 earnings plummet 99%
summary: Indofood Agri's Q2 earnings dropped 99.1% to 2.06 billion rupiah, primarily due to a 3.4% increase in revenue offset by higher cost of sales. The decline in crude palm oil prices, mainly due to weak global demand and higher soybean supplies, contributed to the earnings drop. Despite this, the company expects demand for basic commodities like palm oil to grow, driven by growing consumer markets and a rising middle class.

site_title: GLP Q1 profits grow 49% to US$268 million
summary: GLP's Q1 profits rose 49% to US$268.1 million, driven by increased asset values and joint venture results. Revenue grew 12.3% to US$190.2 million. The company attributed the growth to development projects in China and higher rents, but partially offset by the sale of Japanese properties and the weakening Japanese yen. CEO Ming Z Mei stated that the company has made a solid start to FY16, despite macroeconomic uncertainties, and lowered development targets in China for FY16 to reflect increased uncertainty.

site_title: Google rejects French demand over global right to be forgotten
summary: Google has rejected a French demand to globally apply the "right to be forgotten" ruling, which allows users to request removal of personal information from search results. The ruling, made by the European Court of Justice in 2014, was sought by France's national data protection authority to be applied globally. Google stated that the right to be forgotten is only applicable in Europe, citing concerns about "serious chilling effects" on the web and a "race to the bottom" in internet regulation.

site_title: Shell culling 6,500 jobs, raising spending cuts to weather low oil prices
summary: Royal Dutch Shell plans to cut 6,500 jobs this year and reduce capital investment to $30 billion due to extended low oil prices. The company aims to boost its balance sheet through asset disposals, including a $1.4 billion sale of a Japanese refinery stake, and its proposed $70 billion acquisition of BG Group. Shell expects to complete the BG deal by early 2016 and generate pre-tax benefits of $2.5 billion per year starting in 2018.

site_title: Greek PM's Syriza party to hold congress in September
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' hard-left Syriza party has agreed to hold an emergency congress in September to determine the government's strategy and preserve party unity amid a deepening rift over the new international bailout. The congress comes after over 30 Syriza lawmakers refused to vote for reforms, prompting Tsipras to rely on opposition MPs to pass the measures. The vote was seen as a sign of the party's growing divisions, with more than a dozen central committee members resigning.

site_title: Jobs back on growth path in the second quarter
summary: Singapore's job market showed signs of recovery in the second quarter, with overall employment up 15,700 and the jobless rate at 2.0% in June. The services sector added 11,400 jobs and the construction sector added 7,800 jobs. However, manufacturing jobs continued to decline, and economists expect job growth to ease for the full year, with private-sector economists predicting around 20,000-25,000 jobs needed annually to prevent the jobless rate from rising.

site_title: US: Dow Jones falls on weak P&G results; Nasdaq up
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 5.41 points to 17,745.98, dragged down by weak Procter & Gamble results, while the Nasdaq rose 17.05 to 5,128.59. Mondelez raised its forecast after better-than-expected earnings, and other Nasdaq names like Amazon and Netflix gained. US GDP expanded at a 2.3% annual rate in the April-June period, slightly below the consensus estimate.

site_title: Dollar rises for 3rd day helped by US GDP report
summary: The US dollar rose for a third consecutive day, increasing 0.4% to $1.0931 per euro and 0.13% to 124.15 yen, following the release of a report showing the US economy grew at a 2.3% annual pace in the second quarter. The positive economic data supports expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike before the end of the year, but not a rapid acceleration of rate increases. Analysts see a high probability of a September increase in the federal funds rate.

site_title: Tourism boom drives Japan to turn offices into hotels
summary: Japan is experiencing a tourism boom, with visitor arrivals expected to beat last year's record of 13.4 million, and the government aims to attract 20 million visitors by 2020. However, the influx of tourists is squeezing existing accommodation supply, with only 7,600 new rooms scheduled for the next three years. To address this, developers are converting old office buildings into hotels with tiny but stylish rooms that can rent for under $30 a night, offering a cheaper alternative to traditional hotels.

site_title: OCBC's Q2 net profit up 14% to a record S$1.05 billion
summary: OCBC Bank reported a record Q2 net profit of S$1.05 billion, a 14% increase from last year. The bank's robust performance was driven by higher net interest income and non-interest income. Key overseas markets contributed 102% and 21% growth in pre-tax contributions, while customer loans rose 18% to S$210 billion. Non-interest income rose 10% to a new high, driven by fee and commission income growth. An interim dividend of 18 cents per share was declared for the first half of 2015.

site_title: Opportunities in insurance, wealth management
summary: The Zurich University of Applied Sciences (ZHAW) School of Management and Law has expressed interest in establishing a hub presence in Singapore, exploring opportunities in insurance and wealth management. A recent visit by ZHAW's head of business development Markus Braun and head of the Centre for Risk and Insurance Daniel Greber aimed to explore potential partnerships with Singaporean institutions. The Swiss university has already established student exchange programs with over 140 universities worldwide, including NTU's Nanyang Business School, and is considering launching a Masters of Advanced Science in Insurance Management product in Singapore.

site_title: Lim Kay Tong steals the show in 1965
summary: Veteran Singaporean actor Lim Kay Tong shines in the 2015 film "1965," playing the late founding Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew. Despite the film's flaws, including a tedious plot and underdeveloped characters, Lim's nuanced performance brings depth to the role. The film explores the tumultuous years of Konfrontasi, set against the backdrop of pre-separation Singapore. Director Randy Ang and Daniel Yun's decision to steer clear of hagiography is praised, but the film misses an opportunity to delve deeper into Lee's story.

site_title: Pathways to reconcile claims over South China Sea isles
summary: The Permanent Court of Arbitration in The Hague held its first hearings on the Philippines' dispute with China over the South China Sea, despite China's refusal to participate. The tribunal considered China's communications as a "plea" that the Philippines' submissions fall outside its jurisdiction, and promised to rule on the issue soon. The US has asserted that both parties must abide by the tribunal's decision, which could lead to a major blow to China if it rules in favor of the Philippines. The tribunal's ruling could also embolden other countries, such as Vietnam, to develop resources in their exclusive economic zones.

site_title: Second quarter GDP gains speed on consumer spending
summary: US economic growth accelerated in the second quarter with a 2.3% annual rate, driven by a surge in consumer spending and a firmer housing market. Business spending on equipment and structures fell, but the energy sector's decline may be slowing. The Federal Reserve's assessment of the economy as "moderately expanding" leaves room for a possible interest rate hike in September.

site_title: Will the real Indian inflation rate please stand up?
summary: India's central bank, Reserve Bank of India (RBI), faces a debate over its policy target due to a record discrepancy between the Consumer Price Index (CPI) and Wholesale Price Index (WPI). CPI shows consumer prices rising 5.4% in June, while WPI indicates wholesale prices falling 2.4%. This divergence has clouded the outlook for interest rates, with some economists calling for rate cuts and others advocating for maintaining the current rate of 7.25%. The RBI's governor, Raghuram Rajan, has defended the shift to a CPI target, aiming to align producer and consumer inflation.

site_title: On being human
summary: A $1 million US festival, "On Being Human," explores the human condition with 11 international performances. The festival features collaborations, such as a restaged production of "The Metamorphosis" and a joint performance between Melbourne and Taipei arts groups. Taiwanese art group "The Delusion Of Home" uses photographs of dilapidated houses to discuss human beings and the environment through a performance that incorporates interviews with local residents. The festival aims to facilitate cultural interaction and exchange of worldviews and arts aesthetics.

site_title: Taking steps to enhance financial cooperation
summary: Switzerland and Singapore have strengthened their financial cooperation through regular dialogue. In April, senior officials from both countries met to discuss global economic and financial market developments, as well as international regulatory reforms. The dialogue builds on previous visits by high-level officials, including Singapore President Tony Tan's visit to Switzerland in May last year and Swiss Finance Minister Eveline Widmer-Schlumpf's visit to Singapore in February. The two countries aim to enhance their cooperation on issues such as international financial forums, banking, insurance, and capital markets.

site_title: JLL floats changes in S'pore's property sector in next 50 years
summary: JLL's head of research, Chua Yang Liang, has raised questions about the future of Singapore's property sector, citing slowing immigration, low fertility rates, and high home ownership. He suggests the government may need to reconsider the role of the Housing & Development Board (HDB), potentially allowing private developers to take over some of its functions. JLL also proposes greater flexibility in zoning and intensity of usage for Government Land Sale (GLS) sites, and encourages public participation in conservation efforts, potentially through incentivizing the sale of development rights for unused plot ratios.

images.alt_text: Chris Fossick, JLL managing director for Singapore and South-east Asia, and Darren Soh, the photographer commissioned to shoot the 50 landmark buildings in the coffee table book 50 Stories

site_title: An epic Swiss road trip
summary: Switzerland Tourism has launched the Grand Tour of Switzerland, an epic road trip that showcases the country's diversity and attractions. The 12-part itinerary features 44 highlights and additional tips for tourists, highlighting Switzerland's beautiful countryside. The round trip is available starting this summer, allowing visitors to combine and select various pieces of the Swiss tourism mosaic.

site_title: US$ at week's peak after Fed tiptoes towards rate move
summary: The US dollar reached its highest level this week after the Federal Reserve hinted at a potential interest rate hike in September, reinvigorating dollar-betting analysts. The dollar index rose 0.4% to 97.320, while the euro fell to $1.0950, its lowest since last Friday. The Fed's statement gave no clear indication on timing, but encouraged those expecting a September rate rise. This move is expected to lead to further falls in commodities prices and currencies linked to them, particularly the Canadian and Norwegian crowns.

site_title: UN: India will be most populous nation sooner than thought
summary: The United Nations has revised its population forecast, predicting that India's population will surpass China's by 2022, rather than 2028. India's population is expected to reach 1.5 billion by 2030 and 1.7 billion by 2050, while China's population is expected to remain relatively stable until the 2030s. The world's population is projected to reach 9.7 billion by 2050 and 11.2 billion by the end of the century, with significant growth in high-fertility countries like Africa and large populations in countries like the US and Indonesia.

images.alt_text: The United Nations reported on Wednesday that India's population will probably surpass China's by 2022, not 2028.

site_title: NTUC FairPrice brings back 'Made in Singapore' fair (Amended)
summary: NTUC FairPrice is hosting its fourth "Made in Singapore" fair to support local small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through its SME Suppliers Support & Development Programme (SSDP). The fair, which runs until August 5, offers discounts of up to 40% and features cooking demonstrations using locally farmed produce. The programme aims to help local SMEs ease cash flow pressures, reduce business costs, and promote their products. Over 270 SMEs have benefited from the programme since its introduction in 2009.

images.alt_text: Mr Seah Kian Peng, Chief Executive Officer, NTUC FairPrice and Guest of Honour, Mr Lee Yi Shyan, Senior Minister of State, Ministry of Trade and Industry and Ministry of National Development at NTUC's 4th annual "Made in Singapore" Fair at FairPrice Xtra, JEM, on July 30, 2015.

site_title: Why having more women in corporate leadership is vital
summary: Having more women in corporate leadership is crucial for companies, as it brings balance and diversity of thought to teams. Studies show that companies with women in leadership positions tend to outperform those with all-male leadership. However, progress has been slow, with female executives decreasing from 27% to 23% in the last year. Despite this, AIG has taken steps to foster diversity and inclusion, resulting in over half of its leadership team being women. Companies need to capitalize on women as a source of competitive advantage to benefit from their unique leadership styles.

site_title: A pulse on today's urgencies
summary: Singapore's arts festival showcases contemporary art in the region, retaining its reputation as a leader. This year's programming features cross-genre works, such as the merger of visual films and music, and an "urgent" perspective on issues like Taiwan's views on China. The festival encourages artists to stretch their creativity with 12 Singapore commissions, honoring legends like Goh Lay Kuan and examining their work internationally. Director Ong Keng Sen aims to present works that fit the festival's themes and aims, focusing on emerging and urgent issues.

images.alt_text: Baritone Matthias Goerne will sing Franz Schubert's 1828 song cycle Winterreise against a backdrop of images by William Kentridge.
Singapore's arts festival

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: STAMFORD Land Corporation reported a 273% surge in net profit to S$12.69 million in the first quarter, driven by a 15.5% increase in revenue to S$64.72 million. Earnings per share rose to 1.47 cents. The hotel segment faces challenges due to the closure of Stamford Grand North Ryde and a declining Australian dollar, but the company expects stable performances from its remaining seven hotels.

site_title: UK's Labour Party flirts with its most socialist leader in 30 years
summary: The UK's Labour Party is on track to elect its most socialist leader in 30 years, with Jeremy Corbyn leading the pack. Corbyn's anti-austerity platform, which includes nationalising the railways and increasing income tax, has gained significant support from trade unions and constituency groups. His radical socialist agenda has sparked concerns that it may lead to Labour's downfall, with some pundits warning that it plays into the hands of the Conservatives. Corbyn's rise comes as the anti-austerity movement gains momentum globally, following the success of Syriza in Greece and Podemos in Spain.

site_title: Learning from each other
summary: Singapore is exploring Switzerland's vocational and apprenticeship schemes, and lifelong learning programs. A delegation from Singapore's Ministry of Education visited Switzerland in January to study the country's educational and career guidance systems. The trip aimed to understand how Switzerland creates a flexible and fluid system of education and training for working adults. Singapore's Institute of Technical Education also visited vocational schools in Switzerland to identify potential partners for new diploma programs. The country is keen to learn from Switzerland's successful vocational education and apprenticeship schemes, which blend academic and practical learning.

site_title: These are the most vermin-filled cities in the US
summary: US Census Bureau data from 2013 reveals the most vermin-filled cities in the US. New York tops the list with the highest cumulative score for rats, while Detroit ranks as the city with the fewest reported mice, rats, or cockroaches. Mice are more likely found in colder, Northern cities, while warmer climates contribute to a higher rat and cockroach population. Houses and apartments built in the last four years are less likely to be visited by vermin. The data is limited to 25 metropolitan areas, excluding cities like Dallas, Los Angeles, and San Francisco.

site_title: Singapore firms tap Guangdong knowledge drive
summary: Singapore firms signed 14 Memoranda of Understanding with Guangdong to boost collaboration during the 7th Singapore-Guangdong Collaboration Council meeting. The deals include partnerships in intellectual property, services, and education, with companies such as Equation Summit, Dentalthon Medtech, and Jean Yip expanding their presence in Guangdong. The Singapore Centre @ SSGKC was officially opened, offering integrated business services and plug-and-play workstations, and Singapore's investments in Guangdong rose 27% to US$1.27 billion in 2014.

site_title: Exchanges of mutual benefit
summary: Switzerland and Singapore have strengthened their ties in various areas, including finance, education, research, and security. The Swiss Finance Minister, Evelyn Widmer-Schlumpf, visited Singapore in February to deepen relations in finance and tax issues. Swiss Minister of Foreign Affairs, Didier Burkhalter, participated in the 14th Shangri-La Dialogue in May, highlighting the importance of confidence-building measures and multilateral cooperation. Other officials, including Federal Councillor Doris Leuthard, have also visited Singapore to discuss research, clean technologies, and vocational training. The two countries have also explored opportunities for collaboration in areas such as lifelong learning, skills-based education, and counter-terrorism efforts.

site_title: SMRT's Q1 profit slides 10%
summary: SMRT Corp's net profit fell 10% to S$20.13 million in Q1, dragged down by losses from its rail operations. Revenue rose 7.8% to S$320.3 million, driven by broad-based growth across segments. Operating expenses increased 10.1% due to higher staff costs, depreciation, and maintenance. The company expects operating expenses to rise further as it strengthens rail reliability. SMRT is making progress in talks with the government on a new rail financing network, but the rail business remains a challenge.

site_title: Close connection
summary: Switzerland's Federal Councillor Doris Leuthard emphasized the strong and growing relations between Switzerland and Singapore, citing their shared approaches to success despite cultural and political differences. Both nations face similar challenges, including limited natural resources and aging populations, and must be adaptive, innovative, and productive to outperform. Sustainability and innovation are key to their long-term development, and both countries are world leaders in research and development. Strong networking and data hubs are also crucial for economic opportunities, with Singapore being the largest trading partner of Switzerland in South-east Asia and Switzerland being a significant investor in the Republic.

site_title: Boeing mulls moving some work abroad over Ex-Im uncertainty
summary: Boeing Chairman Jim McNerney stated that the company is considering moving "key pieces" of its operations abroad due to uncertainty about the future of the Export-Import Bank. Boeing is exploring countries that offer export credits, amid growing frustration over US Congress's inability to compromise on issues like sequestration and export financing. McNerney expressed frustration that lawmakers are prioritizing politics over supporting US jobs. Boeing has employed 165,000 people and will continue to fight for reauthorisation of the trade bank, but is exploring alternative options.

site_title: A date with the classic Bordeaux
summary: A vertical tasting of Château Latour, a Premier Cru Classe wine from Bordeaux, was conducted, featuring seven vintages from 1961 to 1996. The 1961 vintage was particularly impressive, showcasing a classic Pauillac bouquet and a long finish. The tasting also highlighted the wine's consistency and longevity, with the 1995 vintage being the best-performing and best-drinking of the series. The wine's history, which has been shaped by its ownership by prominent figures, was also discussed. The tasting provided a good overview of the wine's character and pedigree, making it a benchmark for Bordeaux.

site_title: Three Jardine firms post lower H1 earnings
summary: Three Jardine Matheson Group companies - Mandarin Oriental, Hongkong Land, and Dairy Farm - reported lower earnings for the first half of 2015. Mandarin Oriental's net profit fell 29% to US$32.4 million, while Hongkong Land's net profit decreased 9% to US$513 million. Dairy Farm's net profit dropped 18% to US$192 million. The companies cited softer demand in Hong Kong and Paris, renovations, and exchange rate fluctuations as contributing factors to the decline in earnings.

site_title: Philippine malls are much more than just places to shop
summary: In the Philippines, malls have become the new gathering places for communities, replacing traditional public squares. With over 153 malls in Manila and spreading to rural areas, they offer a range of facilities, including dining, entertainment, and places of worship. Malls have also taken on roles such as housing government offices, hosting community events, and providing services like child-care centers and chapels. This shift has come at the expense of green spaces, with many parks deteriorating due to neglect and poor urban planning. Experts attribute this trend to the country's rapid urbanization and the appeal of malls as safer and more convenient alternatives to streets.

images.alt_text: A mass wedding taking place inside a mall in Manila. With their expanded roles as venues for Catholic mass, Zumba workouts and marriages, Philippine malls are taking on a more important role at the heart of communities.

site_title: Credit Suisse rides on wealth momentum of the Asia-Pacific
summary: Credit Suisse aims to grow its investment banking business in the Asia-Pacific region, which currently contributes significantly to the bank's overall profits. The bank's CEO, Helman Sitohang, plans to target entrepreneurs in the region, positioning Credit Suisse as the "entrepreneurs' bank of Asia." The bank will focus on mid-sized deals linked to Asian entrepreneurs' business operations, rather than cross-selling other products, and has seen strong growth in its private banking arm and investment banking business in the region.

site_title: NZ dairy farmers hit as China demand dries up
summary: New Zealand dairy farmers are facing a severe crisis due to China's reduced demand for imported milk powder, with shipments down 65% in the first five months of 2015. The country supplies two-thirds of the world's whole milk powder and is heavily reliant on China as its biggest customer. As a result, farm-gate milk prices have plummeted, making most farms unprofitable this season. Fonterra Cooperative Group Ltd has slashed its payment to farmers to NZ$4.40 per kg of milk solids, and rival Open Country Dairy Ltd forecasts a payment of NZ$3.65 to NZ$3.95.

site_title: New rules require auditors to highlight issues like valuations
summary: Singapore's Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) and Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (Isca) have introduced new rules requiring auditors to highlight significant issues like valuations in audit reports. The "key audit matters" (KAM) section will be introduced for Singapore-listed companies, requiring auditors to disclose significant audit-related issues beyond their usual "pass/fail" audit opinion. This change aims to boost transparency for investors and may lead companies to reevaluate valuations, particularly in sectors with intangible assets.

images.alt_text: Noble's auditors are Ernst & Young in Hong Kong, where regulators have not said yet that they will require a KAM section.

site_title: CAO Q2 revenue dives; profit up
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a 0.24% year-on-year rise in net profit to US$17.79 million for Q2, despite a 35.8% slump in revenue to US$2.52 billion. Gross profit decreased 17.6% to US$9.21 million, but operating profit rose 6.9% to US$5.09 million. The company attributed the results to lower oil prices and a slight fall in cost of sales and expenses.
