CAO expects the oil trading environment to remain challenging for the rest of the year due to macroeconomic weakness and geopolitical instability.

site_title: Enduring, special economic ties
summary: Switzerland and Singapore have strong economic ties, with Switzerland's presence in Singapore dating back to colonial times. Swiss companies, such as Novartis, have established themselves in the country, and trade between the two nations has grown significantly, with bilateral trade increasing from 1.5 billion Swiss Francs in 1995 to 4.637 billion Swiss Francs in 2014. The Swiss government initially recognized Singapore as a new state in 1965, and diplomatic ties were established two years later. Today, Singapore is Switzerland's most important trade partner in the ASEAN region, and both countries continue to learn from each other's success stories.

images.alt_text: The old Singapore Diethelm office building at Market Street. Swiss trading firms like Diethelm, Keller and Zuellig were already active in Asia during colonial times.

site_title: Different approaches to common problems
summary: Switzerland and Singapore, two small nations, are exploring mutual exchanges and discussions to learn from each other on addressing common issues like immigration and labor. A seminar held in Zurich and Singapore focused on migration and integration, governance, and urban planning. The two countries have differing approaches to social integration, with Singapore implementing top-down solutions and Switzerland adopting bottom-up approaches. The seminar concluded that both methods have value, with Singapore's solutions providing predictability and long-term planning, while Switzerland's approach secures consensus and empowers citizens.

site_title: Disneyland Paris denies price discrimination claim
summary: Disneyland Paris denies allegations of price discrimination, stating prices are the same everywhere in the European Union apart from exchange rates and special offers. The European Commission launched a probe into the park's pricing practices after receiving complaints of unequal treatment of customers from different countries. According to Disneyland Paris, prices vary due to different special offers available in each country, such as packages including meals or free transport. The park's vice-president, Julien Kauffmann, emphasized that prices are not fundamentally different and can be compared across countries.

images.alt_text: "Our prices are strictly the same everywhere in the European Union, apart from exchange rates," Disneyland Paris vice-president Julien Kauffmann says, adding that the only other variations concern special offers.

site_title: The deep humanity of The Lower Depths
summary: Mandarin theatre company Nine Years Theatre presents "The Lower Depths", a Russian proletarian drama about a group of poor people living in a dosshouse, transposed to a makeshift setting. The play follows the lives of seven characters, including a potmender, an actor, and a prostitute, as they find hope and empowerment through a wise and empathetic beggar. Despite some issues with set and costume design, the ensemble cast delivers strong performances, with standout roles from Johnny Ng and Koh Wan Ching. The play runs at the Drama Centre Black Box until August 2.

site_title: Spring launches Human Capital Movement, shines spotlight on SMEs' HR capabilities
summary: Singapore's Human Capital Movement launches to help Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) improve their human resource management and talent management. A pilot run of a diagnostic tool found SMEs score an average of 2.05, indicating a need for improvement. The initiative aims to attract and retain talent in industries deemed "not sexy" by promoting good HR practices and employer branding. Volunteer HR directors will engage SME bosses and HR managers, while progressive SMEs will be supported to increase student engagement activities.

site_title: Tuan Sing's Q2 profit surges on strong property, hotel segments
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings reported a 92% surge in Q2 net profit to S$22.3 million, driven by a 197% increase in property segment revenue to S$220.6 million. Revenue more than doubled to S$194.1 million, with the group reviewing its China strategy due to subdued activities. The company expects to derive the bulk of its revenue from completed residential projects.

site_title: Growing from strength to strength
summary: C&H Group, a Singapore-based company, is celebrating its 25th anniversary next year. Founded by Albert Lu in 1991, the company has evolved into a successful real estate business with two subsidiaries, C&H Realty and C&H Properties. Despite changes in ownership, the company remains committed to its core values of care, honesty, reliability, and law-abiding behavior. Under CEO Philip Chan, C&H Group continues to grow, with plans to re-launch its franchise scheme and enhance its online platform to support its agents.

site_title: An arts bonanza!
summary: Three arts festivals in Singapore, Penang, and Taipei are set to take place in August, featuring nearly 200 performances. The festivals aim to showcase each city's unique identity, with Singapore's Sifa focusing on specialization, Penang's GTF leveraging its World Heritage status, and Taipei's TAF highlighting young, emerging artists. International collaborations and co-creations are also key aspects, with the festivals seeking to build bridges and foster cultural diversity. Despite smaller budgets, the festivals are expected to bring a buzz to the region, with a wide range of shows and events available to arts enthusiasts.

images.alt_text: A scene from Taiwan Dreams by Taiwan's Creative Society Theatre Group, which is on the programme of the Singapore International Festival of Arts.
One of the many photographs of dilapidated buildings featured in The Delusion of Home, part of the Taipei Arts Festival.
Performers in 100% Penang, a show in the George Town Festival featuring 100 Penangites on stage in a performance devised by Germany's Rimini Protokoll.

site_title: IE S'pore ties up with big boys to help SMEs go online globally
summary: Singapore has partnered with Amazon, T-mall, and Lelong to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) list their products globally, reducing costs for S'pore firms. The partnerships aim to enable more companies to enter the e-commerce market, leveraging existing customer bases and waiving or lowering set-up charges. The move is part of IE Singapore's efforts to support SMEs in the process of going online globally, with over 30 local companies already in talks with Amazon for product listing. The partnerships are expected to boost Singapore's e-commerce market, which is forecast to grow from S$1.1 billion in 2010 to S$4.4 billion this year.

site_title: Modi faces US$200b power dilemma in India
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's plan to expand clean energy by $200 billion faces a challenge as state electricity distributors struggle with losses, partly due to selling power below cost to keep energy affordable. The distributors, reliant on loans and subsidies, are hesitant to invest in solar and wind energy, and many are unable to afford cheaper conventional power, raising questions about their ability to buy costlier renewable energy. This poses a key risk for investors such as SoftBank's Masayoshi Son, who have vowed major solar investment in India.

site_title: A tribute to Penang folk
summary: The George Town Festival (GTF) in Penang is celebrating its sixth year with a focus on the local community. The festival features a new food program, "Culinary Roots & Communities," and a visual arts show, "Totem," which highlights the island's heritage and traditional costumes. The festival also includes a showcase of South-east Asia's musicians using bamboo instruments. This year, GTF expands to the mainland with the Butterworth Fringe Festival, solidifying its presence in the state. The festival aims to give the community a platform and celebrate its unique spirit.

site_title: Samsung's Q2 profit falls 8% as mobile unit's earnings slump
summary: Samsung Electronics posted an 8% fall in Q2 net profit to 5.75 trillion won (S$6.7 billion) due to less-than-stellar sales in its mobile unit. The company attributed the decline to a slump in mobile earnings and announced flexible pricing for its new flagship smartphone. The result slightly missed analyst estimates.

site_title: DBS places out its first covered bonds from Singapore
summary: DBS Bank has successfully issued the first Singaporean benchmark in offshore covered bonds with a $1 billion three-year offering, marking a new asset class for the country. The transaction provides pricing guidance for South Korea's first statutory covered bond, expected to be issued by Kookmin Bank in the coming months. This move sets the stage for Asian banks to access international investors during challenging markets.

site_title: A party to celebrate all things Swiss
summary: The Swiss Club in Singapore will host its annual party to celebrate Switzerland's National Day on August 1, marking a long-held tradition of over 100 years. The event will feature Swiss cuisine, live music, and lampions, as well as the launch of Swatch's Gruezi ALL! Collection and Sistem51 Collection. Swiss Ambassador Thomas Kupfer will be present, and a national day address by the President of the Swiss Confederation will be broadcast. The event, expected to attract over 700 attendees, will offer Swiss-style cuisine, live music, and great prizes, celebrating "Swiss style" at the oldest Swiss club in Singapore.

site_title: Noble plunge leads to SGX 'caution' call
summary: Noble Group's shares plummeted to a seven-year low of 50.5 Singapore cents on Thursday, closing at 52 cents down 11.9% from the previous day. The Singapore Exchange issued a "trade with caution" notice after Noble replied that it was unaware of the reason behind the unusual price fall, prompting the third "caution" query in six months.

site_title: Innovation, technology take centre-stage
summary: Switzerland's economic success is attributed to its propensity for innovation, cutting-edge technologies, and a highly educated workforce. The country excels in Information and Communications Technology (ICT), Clean Technology, and Financial Technology (fintech), with top-class specialists and a thriving startup and spin-off scene. International corporations such as IBM and Google have set up operations near Swiss universities, and the country is ranked sixth worldwide for ICT patents per capita. Switzerland's respect for the environment and business-friendly climate have facilitated the growth of the cleantech industry, while its innovative fintech sector is expected to continue to grow, driven by fintech startup investments tripling last year.

site_title: City buzz
summary:
Here are summaries of the three articles:

1. Dom Perignon is launching its Vintage 2005 champagne with special dinners at eight restaurants in Singapore, featuring unique menus and curated access to the limited vintage. Prices vary, with a six-course dinner at Fat Cow starting at S$188++.

2. Lewin Terrace restaurant is celebrating Singapore's birthday with its LT50 cocktail menu, offering 11 spice-inspired cocktails and a lacquer box of Japanese bar bites. The menu is priced at S$150 for a basic two-pax picnic without theme.

3. The Private Museum is showcasing Chua Ek Kay's lesser-known art collection featuring artworks by well-known artists and friends, including a landscape painting by Huang Binhong. The exhibition allows viewers a glimpse into Chua's artistic influences and inspirations.

site_title: Investigators scramble to analyse wreckage for link to missing plane
summary: A piece of wreckage from the missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, believed to be a Boeing 777 wing component, has been found on the French island of La Reunion in the Indian Ocean. The US official confirmed the part number, and Boeing identified it as coming from a B777. Malaysian authorities are verifying the discovery, and experts believe it could have drifted from the area where the plane was last seen. The discovery has sparked hope for closure for the families of the 239 people who disappeared, but authorities caution against jumping to conclusions.

site_title: NOL achieves turnaround in Q2
summary: Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) achieved a turnaround in the second quarter, posting a pre-tax profit despite its liner business facing a pre-tax loss. The group's overall profit was US$889.5 million, driven by gains from the sale of its logistics arm APL Logistics. Revenue fell 24% year-on-year, and freight rates tumbled 17% due to overcapacity and weak trade growth. NOL aims to return its liner arm to profitability by focusing on cost competitiveness, yield optimization, and service reliability.

site_title: Ezion sells S$120m notes at 3.65%
summary: Ezion Holdings, an offshore oil and gas provider, sold S$120 million five-year bonds at 3.65% with backing from DBS Bank's innovative structure. The issue received S$1.5 billion in orders, 12.5 times oversubscribed, despite the slump in oil prices. The structure works like a bank guarantee, reducing the interest rate on the bonds and seemingly defanging the risk for investors.

site_title: El Nino set to generate first global sugar supply deficit in 6 years
summary: El Nino, a weather pattern causing droughts in Asia and heavy rains in South America, is expected to generate the first global sugar supply deficit in six years. Thailand and India, top sugar producers, are threatened by droughts, which may lead to a shortage of 9.7 million tonnes in India and a reduced crop in Thailand. This could result in a rebound in sugar prices, with some analysts predicting a global price increase in the upcoming season.

site_title: Pacific trading partners stuck on medicine monopoly periods
summary: Pacific trading partners are deadlocked over intellectual property protections, including monopoly periods for next-generation drugs. Japanese Economy Minister Akira Amari said talks are ongoing, with the US demanding 12-year data protection and Australia pushing for five years. The dispute could increase the cost of state-subsidised medicines and delay cheaper alternatives. Other issues, such as dairy market access and currency manipulation, are also being discussed. Officials are seeking a solution to prevent unfair export advantages.

site_title: Big year for the Matterhorn
summary: The village of Zermatt, Switzerland, is celebrating the 150th anniversary of the first successful ascent of the iconic Matterhorn mountain in 1865. The mountain, known as the "King of the Alps," was conquered by Englishman Edward Whymper and his team, who climbed via the Hörnligrat ridge. The event marks a significant milestone in the history of mountaineering and will be celebrated with various events in Zermatt. The Matterhorn remains a popular destination for hikers and climbers, with over 3,500 people attempting to summit the peak each year, and an estimated 500 climbers dying on the mountain between 1865 and 2011.

images.alt_text: The Matterhorn has a magical attraction - for day-trippers who love the view and for Alpinists who love a challenge and dream of climbing the peak at least once.

The Matterhorn has a magical attraction - for day-trippers who love the view and for Alpinists who love a challenge and dream of climbing the peak at least once. (Above) The group that made it to the top first

site_title: Deutsche Bank warns legal charges threaten its recovery
summary: Deutsche Bank's new CEO, John Cryan, has warned that the bank's turnaround is at risk due to heavy legal charges, which have gobbled up revenue. Cryan stated that the current performance is "nowhere good enough" and that the status quo is not an option. Despite a second-quarter net profit of 818 million euros, the bank's recovery is threatened by these challenges, prompting investors to expect significant changes under Cryan's leadership.

site_title: The LKY Musical: tight, pacy, engaging
summary: A new musical, "The LKY Musical," by Metropolitan Productions, tells the story of former Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew through a tightly-paced and well-engineered production. The show, set in the years leading up to Singapore's independence, condenses a lot of history with surprising ease and clarity. The cast delivers strong performances, particularly Adrian Pang as Lee Kuan Yew, while the music, composed by Dick Lee, is melodic but not memorable. The show runs at Marina Bay Sands until August 16, with tickets available from SGD 58 to SGD 150.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Japfa Ltd shares rose to S$0.35 on July 30, with a target price of S$0.46. The company warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, mirroring a similar operating loss in H1. Meanwhile, global markets were influenced by tariff threats, with oil prices rising over 2%. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case.

site_title: Steelmakers hard hit by China slowdown, falling prices
summary: Steelmakers worldwide face challenges due to China's slowdown, leading to lower prices and record exports. Japan's Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal Corp forecast its first drop in full-year earnings in three years, citing reduced output and declining profit. The company's first-quarter net profit rose 51% due to a weaker yen and one-time gain, but revenue and operating profit slipped. Global steel prices have fallen 33% due to increased Chinese exports, with the US price of hot-rolled coil reaching a 10-year low.

site_title: Islamic banks urged to go digital for reach
summary: Islamic banks are urged to adopt digital banking to increase their reach and compete with rival banks. Malaysian lender Hong Leong Islamic Bank introduced an app for mobile payments, while Maybank Islamic Bank Bhd offers mobile payment and fund transfers. The potential for Islamic finance growth is vast, with social media users in Muslim-majority regions expected to outpace the global average. However, digital adoption is slow, and experts warn that it will take time for people to become comfortable with digital transactions. The global Islamic debt market saw a 24% decline in 2015, but experts forecast Shariah-compliant assets to reach $3.4 trillion by 2018.

site_title: As tech industry booms, workers turn to coding for lucrative career change
summary: The tech industry's boom is driving a surge in workers seeking lucrative career changes through coding, with many transitioning from non-tech jobs. The industry's high demand for skilled workers, particularly software engineers and data scientists, is outpacing job openings in other fields. Companies like Google and Facebook are competing for top talent, while the federal government has launched the TechHire initiative to train workers for in-demand tech jobs. Coding schools like Galvanize and Hack Reactor are graduating thousands of students, with a 98% job placement rate, offering a pathway to high-paying careers in the tech industry.

site_title: Networking platform for Swiss
summary: The Swiss Association of Singapore (SAS) is a non-profit association for Swiss nationals and friends of Switzerland, offering over 60 social and recreational events annually. Founded in 2006, the association provides a platform for members to connect, integrate with the local community, and participate in activities such as language courses, sports events, and cultural events. With a committee of eight volunteers, the association offers a range of activities, including tours, cooking classes, and family events, in English, representing all major language regions in Switzerland. Membership is open to Swiss citizens and foreigners with an interest in Switzerland.

images.alt_text: Activities organised range from tours of historic parts of Singapore, jazz evenings and cooking classes to family events such as the Easter picnic (above) or the Santa Claus afternoon at the ambassador's residence

site_title: The challenge of timing the US interest rate hike
summary: The Federal Reserve's decision not to raise interest rates at its latest meeting has raised concerns about the timing of future rate hikes. Despite a strong labor market and rising expectations, the Fed's policymakers emphasized that the economy wasn't ready for a "take-off" that would require higher interest rates. The unemployment rate has dropped to 5.3%, but inflation remains moderate at 0.2% over the past 12 months. The Fed is expected to consider raising interest rates in its next meeting in December, but many uncertainties remain, including developments in the global economy and the potential for deflationary pressures.

site_title: S Korea's Big 3 shipbuilders in deep water with deep-sea oil rigs
summary: South Korea's three largest shipbuilders, Hyundai Heavy Industries, Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering Co, and Samsung Heavy Industries Co, reported a combined operating loss of 4.8 trillion won (S$5.6 billion) in the second quarter, exceeding analysts' expectations. The losses stem from their foray into deep-sea oil rigs, which proved more costly and competitive than anticipated. Shares of Samsung Heavy fell 10% and Daewoo Shipbuilding declined 2%, while Hyundai Heavy rose 0.7%.

site_title: Cuba: transforming a revolution
summary: Cuba and the US are moving towards normalizing relations, 6 decades after Fidel Castro led an army into Havana. The US has already relaxed travel restrictions, and the Cuban government plans to unify its currency system before 2016. Normalization could bring benefits, including increased tourism and foreign investment, with the US community of Cuban Americans playing a key role. However, barriers remain, including the US embargo and Cuba's dual-currency system, which could ease tourist transactions but reduce Cuban salaries. The process will be gradual, with President Obama leaving office in January 2017 and President Castro retiring in 2018.

site_title: Agent Ethan Hunt is back in familiar territory
summary: Tom Cruise reprises his role as Ethan Hunt in Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation, the fifth installment of the series. Cruise performs his own stunts, including a high-risk opening scene, and is up against a shadowy organization called The Syndicate led by Solomon Lane. The film features exotic locales, complex set-ups, and jaw-dropping action sequences. Hunt teams up with new ally Ilsa Faust, played by Rebecca Ferguson, as they navigate a deadly game of cat-and-mouse across multiple locations. The film is a thrilling addition to the Mission: Impossible franchise.

site_title: China's little secret: a thriving, free market in shares
summary: China's New Third Board (NTB), a small stock exchange in Beijing, is thriving despite the chaos in the nation's main stock markets. Since its launch in 2012, the NTB has seen a surge in new listings, with 362 companies listing since July 3, and 2,922 companies now listed. The NTB has attracted professional investors and has been driven by market forces, with the government intervening minimally. This has enabled companies such as Evergrande Real Estate to access the market, and has raised over 30.3 billion yuan in funding for small and medium-sized tech companies.

site_title: Fed rate hike ruled out for Sept; turmoil not expected when it happens
summary: The Federal Reserve ruled out a September interest rate hike, effectively pushing it to December or later. Despite warning signs, the market has not fully priced in the rate increase, with Treasury yields remaining near record lows. Stocks initially reacted positively, but later gave back gains, with the Nasdaq Composite turning negative. Analysts predict a "measured pace" of rate hikes, with subdued Treasury volatility, and warn that sectors such as utilities and retail may be negatively impacted by the rate hikes.

site_title: Depression's advocates
summary: A 2015 article discusses the Greek debt crisis and its impact on the global economy. The author argues that policymakers in the eurozone repeated the mistakes of the 1930s, including austerity measures that exacerbated the crisis. Using Iceland as a counterexample, the author estimates that Greece's GDP is 75% lower than it would have been if it had exited the eurozone in 2010. The article concludes that the EU's insistence on austerity reflects a conceptual framework that underestimates the gravity of the situation, and that the centre-left parties in Europe lack a strategy for changing the rules and addressing the crisis.

site_title: China visitors fuel a boom in demand for tour buses in Japan
summary: China's surge in tourism to Japan is driving a boom in demand for tour buses, with Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus Corp and Hino Motors Ltd seeing a significant increase in orders. The number of foreign visitors, led by Chinese arrivals, rose 46% to over 9 million in the first six months, with Chinese visitors doubling to over 2 million. This has put pressure on the Japanese car industry, with Toyota, Nissan, and Honda experiencing declines in domestic passenger car sales. The surge in tourism is attributed to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's policies, which have weakened the yen.

site_title: Promises that are not delivered
summary: A film adaptation of Gustave Flaubert's novel Madame Bovary, directed by Sophie Barthes, stars Mia Wasikowska as the titular character. The movie depicts Emma's world in a style faithful to the classic novel, exploring themes of unfulfilled desires and the consequences of reckless spending. Despite impressive production values, the film's slow-burning pace and lack of emotional payoff leave viewers questioning whether life has more to offer than its mundane reality. The film's conclusion mirrors Emma's tragic fate, leaving audiences with a sense of despair.

site_title: Toshiba fraud a deafening wake-up call for better corp governance in Japan
summary: A panel of external lawyers and accountants found Toshiba systematically overstated operating profits by $1.2 billion over several years, marking the biggest scandal since the Olympus fiasco in 2011. The company's corporate governance was found wanting, with a lack of financial expertise on its audit committee and a culture of unquestioning loyalty to top management. Despite being a pioneer of corporate governance in Japan, Toshiba's financial irregularities came just over a month after a new corporate governance code took effect. Eight top executives resigned, and the company promised measures to stem irregularities, including hiring more independent directors.

site_title: Stars come out in force for Sing50
summary: Top performers Stefanie Sun, Lang Lang, and Apl.de.ap will headline Sing50, a mega-concert celebrating local music in Singapore. The event, sponsored by Mapletree Investments, Resorts World Sentosa, and Zurich Insurance, will take place next Friday. Stefanie Sun will perform with an orchestra, marking her first collaboration with one, while Lang Lang will lead 50 pianists playing on Steinway-designed pianos. Apl.de.ap will guest star, leading a contingent of rappers in performing classic local rap numbers. The concert aims to showcase local talents and pay tribute to pioneering Singapore artists.

site_title: Samudera Shipping's Q2 profit sinks 26%
summary: Samudera Shipping Line reported a Q2 net profit of US$3.11 million, down 26% year-over-year, due to lower revenue from its container shipping and bulk & tanker business segments. Revenue declined 16.1% to US$81.3 million. Operating conditions for both industries are expected to remain challenging in the near to medium term. The company's earnings per share decreased to 0.58 US cents, down from 0.78 US cents last year.

site_title: Google fails to overturn Microsoft's US$14.5m jury victory
summary: Google failed to overturn a $14.5 million jury verdict won by Microsoft in a patent royalty dispute over Xbox game players and Windows operating systems. The US Court of Appeals in San Francisco refused to set aside findings that Google breached contracts requiring fair licensing of industry-standard patents. This case is part of the global debate on patent royalties and fair compensation for industry-standard patents.

site_title: Unexpected Q2 profit boosts chance of early RBS share sale
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) posted an unexpected Q2 profit of £293 million, up 27% from the previous year, driven by write-backs on problem loans. The bank's shares rose 3.3% ahead of its first share sale, which could kick off in the next few days or September, as part of the UK government's plan to sell at least 75% of its 78% stake over the next five years. The sale is seen as a milestone in Britain's recovery since the 2007-2009 financial crisis.

site_title: Step aside, here come Europe's hot economies: Spain and Ireland
summary: Spain's economy grew 1% in the first quarter, reaching an annual rate of 3.1%, while Ireland's economy grew 6.5% in the first quarter, a rate more typical of emerging markets. These growth rates surpass the overall 1% eurozone growth and Germany's 1.1%. The improvements come after Spain and Ireland received EU aid to support their struggling banks, which were affected by housing bubbles.

site_title: IMF board says Fund cannot join Greece bailout talks now: FT
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has decided it cannot officially join Greece's bailout talks until the country agrees to comprehensive reforms. IMF staff have determined that Greece is disqualified for any bailout due to high debt levels and poor reform record. The IMF can participate in negotiations, but a decision on further bailout will likely take months, possibly into 2016, and raises questions about its involvement in eurozone efforts.

site_title: Broadway Industrial sees higher Q2 profit, lifted by other income
summary: Broadway Industrial Group posted a net profit of S$4.56 million for Q2, up from S$301,000 last year, driven by higher other income from unrealised mark-to-market fair-value gains on financial derivatives. Revenue slipped 12.3% year-over-year to S$149.27 million. Earnings per share increased to 0.97 cent from 0.07 cent previously.

site_title: Start-up British brokers get lift from market volatility
summary: A surge in market volatility is encouraging a new generation of stockbrokers to set up shop in London, Europe's biggest financial centre. Despite tough competition and thin commissions, the UK remains the hub of choice, with 40 new securities and futures companies approved by the FCA regulator so far in 2015. Low-cost broker DEGIRO has expanded British trading operations, and new firms are emerging to capitalize on the increased demand for trading services, with many citing the opportunity to offer wealth-management services alongside share-dealing.

site_title: Ocean currents may trace origins of MH370 debris
summary: Scientists suggest that ocean currents in the Indian Ocean may have transported debris from the missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 to the French island of La Reunion. Two possible scenarios involve the South Equatorial Current or the Gyre, which could have carried debris past La Reunion. By analyzing satellite images of surface currents, experts aim to define the likely crash zone and potentially locate the aircraft's black box.

site_title: Dollar gains as US growth supports rate-hike view
summary: The US dollar rose to its highest in a week against a basket of currencies as the government reported 2.3% gross domestic product growth in the second quarter, exceeding analyst expectations. This data supports the expectation that the US Federal Reserve will raise interest rates as early as September. The dollar index rose 0.6% to 97.545, while the euro fell 0.5% to US$1.0925. Analysts see the rate hike as a possibility, but some caution that Greece's debt woes and China's financial turmoil may force the Fed to postpone a rate hike.

site_title: Shares retreat amid cautious trading
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.05% to 3,249.52, following losses in the Chinese market and dismissing overnight US Wall Street gains. The benchmark index dropped 34.48 points due to a "non-event" from the US Federal Reserve's meeting. Expectations for a September interest rate hike remain intact, with most pundits predicting a rate lift-off.

site_title: Germany's Schaeuble wants to rebalance EU Commission's role
summary: Germany's finance minister, Wolfgang Schaeuble, is pushing for a rebalance in the European Commission's role, seeking to correct the balance between its political function and regulatory powers. He wants to transfer certain responsibilities, such as competition and single market rule enforcement, to independent authorities. This move aims to maintain the Commission's neutrality and address concerns over its handling of budget discipline rules. Schaeuble's proposal is part of a broader discussion on the Commission's role, which will be further debated by EU finance ministers in September.

site_title: Ringgit hovers near financial crisis peg as troubles mount
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia has been using its reserves to protect the ringgit from the 1MDB scandal, causing currency reserves to fall US$5 billion in two weeks. This move may cost Malaysia more than a potential bailout for 1MDB, which has accumulated US$11 billion in debt. The central bank has taken an iron-fisted approach to prevent the ringgit's value from dropping, but this could lead to long-term economic consequences.

images.alt_text: Since early July, the ringgit has remained close to 3.8 to the US dollar.

site_title: Interest in ETFs rising among Asia-Pac investors: Deutsche study
summary: Deutsche Asset & Wealth Management (AWM) reported a 16% rise in ETF assets under management (AUM) in the Asia-Pacific region to US$234 billion between January and May. Nearly 93% of these assets are invested in equity ETFs, with 70% of investors having invested in ETFs, up from 55% five years ago. Globally, ETFs have seen a 7% rise in investments to US$2.82 trillion. The survey also found that 53% of investors are aware of the tax disadvantage of US-listed ETFs and 31% favour Asian-listed ETFs due to parallel trading hours.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb on earnings, Fed
summary: European stock markets rose on Thursday driven by company updates and the US Federal Reserve's positive outlook for the economy. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.57%, while the CAC 40 in Paris rose 0.58% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 gained 0.40%. The euro fell to $1.0916, but the dollar advanced after the Fed upgraded its outlook on the US economy. Asian markets also rose, tracking the New York rally.

site_title: Jet debris said to be from aircraft type used for Flight 370
summary: A wing component found on Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean is confirmed to be from a Boeing 777, similar to the aircraft that disappeared in March 2014's Malaysia Airlines Flight 370. The US official, who wished to remain anonymous, confirmed the identification through a part number and photos. The component is being taken to France for further examination by Malaysian authorities and others. While it's unclear if the component came from Flight 370, no other Boeing 777s are known to have crashed in the Indian Ocean.

site_title: Facebook spending on messaging, wearables seen fuelling growth
summary: Facebook's focus on messaging services and virtual reality headsets has boosted long-term growth expectations, with 20 of 50 brokerages raising their price targets. Despite a 1.6% drop in the stock price, analysts see investments in Instagram, Facebook Messenger, and WhatsApp as driving long-term growth. The company's monthly active users increased 13% to 1.49 billion, but ad revenue growth is expected to slow for the rest of the year. Analysts believe the investments will optimize the user experience and drive financial gains in the long term.

site_title: Swissport airport services sold to China's HNA for US$2.8b
summary: Swissport International, a global airport ground handling and cargo company, has been sold to China's HNA Group for 2.7 billion Swiss francs (approximately $2.8 billion USD). The deal is expected to be finalized by the end of the year, following approval by competition authorities and the Chinese government. Swissport employs around 60,000 people in 48 countries and generates annual revenues of approximately three billion Swiss francs. The acquisition confirms Swissport's strategic value as the worldwide leader in the airport services market, with HNA aiming to expand its presence in underpenetrated Asian markets.

site_title: PM Tsipras seeks ruling party members' referendum on Greek bailout on Sunday
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is calling for a party referendum on Sunday on whether Greece has any alternative to accepting a tough bailout, amid a deepening crisis within his Syriza party. The proposal, which would be a vote by party members rather than the general public, aims to address the divisions between those who support the bailout and those who oppose it. The move is seen as a challenge to far-left rebels threatening to split the party, and could potentially derail talks with European and International Monetary Fund lenders on a new aid package.

site_title: Consumer comfort in US drops most in five months on finances
summary: US consumer confidence fell to 40.5 in the week ended July 26, the lowest level since November, as households' attitudes about finances and the economy deteriorated. The Bloomberg Consumer Comfort Index declined 1.6 points from the previous week, with personal finances gauge dropping to 54.9 and the economy gauge falling to an eight-month low of 30.4. Sentiment worsened across income brackets, except for those earning $40,000-$50,000, which saw a slight improvement. A sustained boost in employment and wage growth is needed to lift consumer spirits.

site_title: Update: Debris part number said to be from same model as missing jet
summary: A Boeing 777 wing component, identified as a flaperon, has been found on Reunion Island, confirming its origin from the same model as the missing Malaysian Air plane Flight 370. The part will be examined in France under Malaysian supervision. Investigators believe someone on board intentionally disabled tracking devices, but no conclusive evidence has been found to prove the component came from the missing plane. The search for Flight 370 continues, with no trace of the plane despite deep-sea sonar scans of a large area.

site_title: Roxy gears up for launch of overseas projects
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings, a Singapore property group, plans to launch two overseas residential projects by year-end. The projects, in Kuala Lumpur and Brisbane, will feature over 700 and 400 apartments, respectively, along with small retail components. The company's second-quarter net profit dropped 43% to S$13.05 million.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of Trilive, a 222-unit condominium by local developers Roxy-Pacific Holdings in Kovan. Property and hotel group Roxy-Pacific Holdings, which has posted a 43 per cent year-on-year drop in second- quarter net profit to S$13.05 million, is getting ready to launch two overseas residential projects by year-end, its executive chairman and CEO, Teo Hong Lim, told BT.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty, with investors weighing tariffs, sanctions, and market outlook. US stocks edged down from records due to tariff threats, while Europe's stocks fell due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for the second half of the year. London's Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case worth 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Global stock markets can deliver robust returns despite FX swings: study
summary: A study by the Cass Business School, the Bank of England, and City University Hong Kong found that global stock markets can deliver robust returns despite fluctuations in foreign exchange rates. The study analyzed data from over 40 stock markets and observed a negligible impact of exchange rate movements on returns, averaging 12% per year. The study suggests that investors can earn significant returns by allocating funds across global stock markets, despite currency swings, and that predicting exchange rate movements is not useful for predicting stock market returns.

site_title: Global Premium Hotels posts lower Q2 profit as costs edge upwards
summary: Global Premium Hotels reported a 17.2% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$3.16 million for the second quarter, driven by increased administrative expenses and finance costs. Revenue rose 3.2% to S$14.98 million, while earnings per share fell to 0.3 cents. The company attributed the decline to a 4.1% year-on-year drop in international tourist arrivals and new hotel supply entering the market, leading to lower occupancy rates and revenue.

site_title: Stamford Land reports sharp rise in Q1 profit
summary: STAMFORD Land Corporation reported a 275% surge in Q1 net profit to S$12.69 million, driven by a 15.5% rise in revenue to S$64.72 million. Earnings per share rose to 1.47 cents. The hotel segment remains challenging due to the closure of Stamford Grand North Ryde and a declining Australian dollar, but the company expects stable performances from its remaining seven hotels and revenue growth from the opening of La Boca in Q2/Q3 FY2016.

site_title: US: Stocks dip on mixed earnings
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 39.18 points, the S&P 500 down 5.39, and the Nasdaq Composite Index down 13.38. Mixed earnings from companies like Procter & Gamble and Mondelez International contributed to the decline. The Commerce Department reported US GDP expanded at a 2.3% annual rate in the April-June period, slightly below the 2.5% consensus estimate.

site_title: US trade deficit in goods widened in June to US$62.3b
summary: The US trade deficit in goods widened to $62.3 billion in June, up from $59.7 billion in May. This marks the first time the Commerce Department has released advance data on monthly international trade, which will allow it to estimate quarterly GDP. The data will be released monthly, four to seven days before the more complete report on international trade, including services.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians carry Macy's Inc. shopping bags in San Francisco, California, on Jan 22, 2015.

site_title: NYC property market still hot even as private equity exits
summary: The NYC property market remains hot despite private equity firms exiting the market, with institutional investors and real estate investment trusts taking their place. These new investors are buying renovated Class A buildings in Midtown South, driven by the area's growth as a hub for tech, advertising, and media companies. The market's resilience is attributed to strong demand from other investors, which has alleviated concerns about a market peak.

site_title: Riddle of missing flight MH370 has confounded experts
summary: Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 vanished on March 8, 2014, without a trace, killing 239 people. The Boeing 777 changed course an hour after takeoff, and its main communication systems shut down. Despite extensive searches by 26 countries covering 4.5 million square kilometers, no wreckage was found. The Australian Transport Safety Bureau suggests a possible explanation: a sudden fall in oxygen levels rendering the crew and passengers unconscious, causing the plane to continue flying on autopilot until fuel ran out.

site_title: US jobless claims increase, but still near cycle lows
summary: US jobless claims rose 12,000 to 267,000 for the week ended July 25, still near cycle lows. This marks the lowest level since November 1973. The four-week moving average of claims fell to 274,750. The number of people receiving benefits after an initial week of aid increased to 2.26 million. Despite the increase, the data suggests the jobs market is gaining steam.

site_title: Opec does not expect prices to fall further: SecGen
summary: Opec's Secretary-General Abdullah al-Badri stated that global oil prices are unlikely to fall further due to growing demand. He also announced that Opec does not plan to cut oil output and will not hold any extraordinary meetings before December.

site_title: Zuckerberg to Wall Street: Be patient, big things take time
summary: Mark Zuckerberg urged investors to be patient, saying "big things take time" after Facebook's second-quarter revenue beat analyst estimates. Despite questions about the potential for WhatsApp, Instagram, and Messenger to generate billions of dollars, Zuckerberg focused on expanding their communities, with 700 million, 800 million, and 300 million users, respectively. Facebook's core business continues to perform well, with sales rising 39% to $4.04 billion. Zuckerberg emphasized that the company is taking a long-term approach to monetization, citing its successful introduction of ads on Facebook as an example.

site_title: Russia, Opec see possibility of oil market stabilising in 2016
summary: Russia and Opec see a possibility of the oil market becoming more balanced and stable in 2016, according to a joint statement. Russian Energy Minister Alexander Novak and OPEC Secretary-General Abdullah al-Badri met in Moscow, planning to meet in Vienna in the second half of 2016. Novak predicted global oil demand growth of 1.2-1.3 million barrels per day in 2015. This suggests a potential shift towards market stability, with officials from Russia and Opec working together to address the ongoing oil market challenges.

site_title: China to step up targeted control amid slowdown, Xinhua says
summary: China will step up targeted macro policy control to support its economy amid slowdown, according to an official news agency report. The politburo will keep liquidity at an "appropriate" level to serve the real economy and make "pre-emptive" adjustments to economic policies. China's economy has shown signs of stabilization after the government cut interest rates four times since November and relaxed rules for local government financing, but faces downward pressure due to stock market swings and a manufacturing gauge falling to a 15-month low in July.

site_title: Luggage piece found on French island near plane debris
summary: A piece of luggage was found on the French island of La Reunion, near plane debris believed to be from missing flight MH370. The luggage fragment includes a closed zip and is thought to be a part of a plane wing. Malaysian authorities, led by Prime Minister Najib Razak, are studying the debris and sending the wing component to Toulouse for further examination. The discovery has fueled speculation that the debris may be from MH370, which vanished on March 8, 2013, with 239 people on board.

site_title: Olympics: Beijing and Almaty make final pitch for for 2022 votes
summary: Beijing and Almaty, the last two cities vying for the 2022 Winter Olympics, made their final pitches to the International Olympic Committee (IOC) in Kuala Lumpur on July 30, 2015. China's strong favourites, Beijing and Almaty have made their cases despite Beijing's lack of natural snow and Almaty's compact Games plan. The IOC will vote on Friday, with 86 members deciding the host city, in what is the smallest contest for a Winter Olympics in four decades.

site_title: Opec chief says oil cartel 'not ready' to cut production
summary: Opec Secretary-General Abdullah El-Badri stated that the oil cartel is not planning to cut production, despite a recent fall in crude prices and concerns about the potential addition of Iranian oil to the market. The 30 million barrels a day production level remains unchanged. El-Badri welcomed the lifting of sanctions on Iran, saying the organization can accommodate any increased volumes. Opec and Russia expressed a "more balanced situation on the oil market and its stabilisation" in 2016, amid a global supply glut.

site_title: US 2nd-quarter GDP gains speed on consumer spending
summary: US economic growth accelerated in the second quarter with a 2.3% annual rate, driven by consumer spending that rose at a 2.9% rate. This offset the drag from soft business spending on equipment, which fell at a 4.1% rate. The Federal Reserve's assessment of a moderately expanding economy left the door open for a possible interest rate hike in September, the first rise since 2006.

site_title: Europe is hot spot as industrial deals are applauded
summary: The European industrial sector is experiencing a surge in dealmaking, with US$266 billion in purchases announced so far this year, surpassing previous records. American companies are taking advantage of the strong US dollar and large amounts of cash stockpiled overseas to acquire European industrial companies, with US takeovers of European industrial companies reaching an annual high of US$40 billion. Experts say that European companies, which have been through a turnaround, offer better value and opportunities for margin improvement, making them attractive targets for US buyers.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: Singapore's employment grew at a "moderate pace" in Q2, with layoffs continuing to fall. Auditor reporting standards will be enhanced from 2017, providing more transparency. Noble Group, Asia's largest commodity trading firm, fell to a 7-year-low due to weakening demand and buybacks. Singapore Airlines released seven A350 jet orders back to Airbus. The Straits Times Index closed 34.48 points lower, 1.05% down, at 3,249.52.

site_title: Malaysia's parliamentary probe into 1MDB to continue
summary: Malaysia's parliamentary probe into 1MDB, a state investment company embroiled in corruption allegations, will continue despite the departure of several committee members. The probe's chairman and deputy chairman will be appointed in Parliament, and the next sitting is scheduled for October. Committee member Datuk Abdul Aziz Sheikh Fadzir stated that the probe will continue to pursue the matter, regardless of his potential departure from the committee.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental's profit for first half of 2015 slumps 29%
summary: Mandarin Oriental International reported a 29% drop in net profit to US$32.4 million for the first half of 2015, citing softer demand in Hong Kong and Paris, as well as renovation impacts. Combined hotel revenue fell 5% to US$640.9 million. The group expects challenging conditions to influence its full-year performance, with an unchanged interim dividend of two US cents per share.

site_title: Rovio's Angry Birds are back in a sequel to save the company
summary: Finnish game maker Rovio launched Angry Birds 2, a sequel to the most downloaded mobile game series of all time, to revive its declining profits. The game's visuals and gameplay have been overhauled, and it's also working on a 3D feature film set for release in May 2016. The company aims to boost earnings, which slumped to 10 million euros in 2015, down from 36.5 million euros in 2013. Rovio has also cut 110 jobs and shut down its game development unit in Finland to address the decline.

site_title: JPMorgan drops to No 10 in JD Power mortgage-servicer ranking
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. dropped to 10th place in JD Power's annual survey of customer satisfaction for mortgage-servicing companies, behind Wells Fargo, Bank of America, and Quicken Loans. The bank earned a score of 730, down from 782 in 2014. JPMorgan has been investing in mortgage servicing and has the highest rating in the Treasury Department's assessment of mortgage servicers participating in foreclosure-avoidance programs. The survey results come amid increased regulatory scrutiny and a crackdown on default servicing, which may have contributed to the decline.

site_title: Bill Gross says Fed recognizing zero per cent rates causing harm to US
summary: Bill Gross, a prominent bond investor, stated that the Federal Reserve is recognizing the negative consequences of ultra-low interest rates, including the misallocation of funds and increased risk of corporate defaults. Gross argued that low rates have enabled companies to engage in stock buybacks rather than investing in the real economy, and that this has led to the proliferation of "zombie" corporations. He warned that prolonged low interest rates may have severe consequences, including financial market mispricing and solvency issues for insurance companies and pension funds.

site_title: Clarkson and "Top Gear" presenters sign with Amazon for new car show
summary: Jeremy Clarkson, fired from BBC's "Top Gear" in March, has signed a deal with Amazon to present a new motoring show alongside Richard Hammond and James May. The three-year, three-season series will be available on Amazon Prime, following Clarkson's departure from the BBC. Clarkson was sacked after physically attacking a production staff member and had previously been on a final warning over racist language allegations. The show's details have not been disclosed.

site_title: Tuan Sing's Q2 profit surges 92%
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings reported a 92% surge in Q2 net profit to S$22.3 million, driven by higher contributions from property and hotel investment segments. Revenue more than doubled to S$194.1 million, with the property segment contributing 63% of revenue and 79% of profit after tax. This marks a 98% increase in first-half net profit to S$38.2 million.

site_title: ECB's money-printing working though deflation, growth threats persist
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) quantitative easing program, launched in March, is showing promise in warding off deflation, with lending to non-financial corporations turning positive for the first time in three years. Consumer price growth remains below the ECB's target of 2%, but market measures of inflation expectations have risen sharply since the program's launch. The ECB now expects to normalize monetary policy in 2019, a year later than previously seen, and growth prospects for the eurozone remain modest, with the International Monetary Fund warning that more money printing may be needed.

site_title: 'A weird thing on the shore' sparks MH370 speculation
summary: A piece of plane wreckage, believed to be from a wing, was discovered on a French island in the Indian Ocean, sparking speculation that it could be from missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370. The debris, found by a group of cleaners, was initially thought to be a normal find but quickly drew international attention as investigators confirmed it could be from the missing plane. Malaysian experts have been sent to the island, but authorities urge caution in drawing conclusions about the origin of the wing.

site_title: Shell to "take a good look" at North Sea after BG deal
summary: Royal Dutch Shell plans to sell $30 billion of North Sea assets in the next two years following its acquisition of BG Group. CEO Ben van Beurden stated that Shell will "take a good look" at the ageing North Sea basin to restructure and bring it back to its most advantaged core. The move comes as production in the North Sea has declined since the 1990s peak, and Shell faces high cost structures and a high tax regime. Shell will assess its portfolio to identify the strongest assets and ensure a strong core after the BG deal.

site_title: Indian Ocean debris almost certainly from a Boeing 777: Malaysia
summary: Malaysia is "almost certain" that debris found on Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean is from a Boeing 777, which could be from missing Flight MH370. The debris, a flaperon, was found washed up on the island east of Madagascar and has a number stamped on it that may help verify its origin. If confirmed, investigators will try to retrace the debris drift back to where it could have come from, but the discovery may not provide precise information about the aircraft's final resting place.

site_title: Private banks say Asia debt shielded from panic in China, Greece
summary: Asian debt has shielded investors from panic amid global market volatility, particularly in China and Greece. Local investors and private banks have contributed to this resilience, with 75% of dollar notes sold over the past 12 months bought by investors in the region. This "home bias" has reduced the impact of negative news on Asian corporate dollar bonds, which have risen 0.8% despite European government bonds slumping 2.2%. The region's strong economic growth and stable currencies have also attracted investors, making Asian bonds a "safe haven" of sorts.

site_title: Asian investors warm to exchange-traded funds: study
summary: Asian investors are warming up to exchange-traded funds (ETFs), with assets under management in the Asia-Pacific region rising 16% to $234 billion between January and May. Nearly 93% of assets are invested in equity ETFs, with 70% of investors having invested in ETFs, up from 55% five years ago. Globally, $2.82 trillion is invested in exchange-traded products, with Deutsche Asset & Wealth Management's passive investment platform managing $118 billion in assets. Awareness of tax disadvantages and parallel trading hours are driving investor preference for Asian-listed ETFs.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Neptune Orient Lines back in the black in Q2
summary: Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) reported a net profit of US$889.5 million in the second quarter, driven largely by the sale of its logistics arm, APL Logistics. Excluding the gain on the disposal, net profit would have been around US$3 million. Revenue declined 24% to US$1.55 billion, and the company reported a loss per share from continuing operations. Despite this, net asset value per share increased to US$1.02, up from US$0.67 the previous year.

site_title: SingCert: Beware of major Android flaw that could lock users out of smartphones
summary: A major Android operating system flaw allows hackers to take control of users' smartphones by sending a malicious MMS. The Singapore Computer Emergency Response Team (SingCert) has issued a security advisory warning users to be cautious when downloading media files from unknown sources. This vulnerability can potentially lock users out of their devices, making it essential for users to exercise caution when receiving MMS.

site_title: Oil prices set to recover but oversupply will cap gains: poll
summary: Oil prices are expected to recover from six-month lows, averaging $60.60 a barrel in 2015 and $69 in 2016, according to a Reuters poll of 30 industry analysts. A global supply glut and strong dollar will cap price gains, but rising demand from emerging markets and lower production costs for some oil producers will help prices recover. Benchmark Brent hit a low of $52.28 a barrel, but is forecast to climb further in 2016.

site_title: Hongkong Land's H1 profit down 9% on higher tax charges
summary: Hongkong Land reported a 9% drop in its first-half net profit to US$513 million due to higher tax charges. Operating results were marginally higher, while underlying net profit fell 3% to US$419 million. Revenue rose 50% to US$905 million, driven by property sales. The company expects earnings from its residential business to be lower in the second half due to fewer completions. An interim dividend of six US cents per share was declared, unchanged from the prior year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.93 points to close at 1,699.92 on Thursday, driven by gains of 383 stocks while 401 stocks declined. The index saw trading of 1.62 billion lots worth RM1.58 billion.

site_title: EU 'very much regrets' Russian veto of UN MH17 resolution
summary: The European Union expressed regret over Russia's veto of a UN resolution establishing a tribunal to prosecute those responsible for downing Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 over Ukraine in 2014. The veto occurred during a UN Security Council meeting, preventing the adoption of the resolution. European Commission spokeswoman Maja Kocijancic described the veto as a "setback." The EU had been pushing for accountability for the downing of the plane, which killed all 298 people on board.

site_title: Malaysia's Khazanah to set up London office
summary: Malaysia's state investor Khazanah Nasional Bhd plans to set up a London office this year, aiming to deepen its presence in developed markets and evaluate opportunities in technology-enabled sectors in Europe. The office, to be operational by the third quarter of 2015, will be Khazanah's fourth regional office globally, following existing locations in Beijing, Mumbai, San Francisco, and Istanbul.

site_title: Greek PM calls party congress on bailout in September
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has proposed holding an emergency party congress in September to determine government strategy amid opposition to a tough EU-IMF bailout deal. The proposal comes as a sizeable minority of Syriza members, including former cabinet members, have refused to vote for reforms needed for a three-year bailout. If the congress is not held, the bailout ratification plan will be put to a party referendum on Sunday, raising the prospect of a split within the party. Tsipras emphasized the need for unity among Syriza members.

images.alt_text: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, under fire from his Syriza party comrades over an unpopular EU-IMF bailout, on Thursday proposed holding an emergency party congress in September to determine government strategy.

site_title: US must wait for EU hedge fund "passports": EU watchdog
summary: The European Securities and Markets Authority (Esma) has stated that US hedge funds should wait for a decision on EU "passports" before being allowed to operate across the 28-country European Union. Esma has not yet reached a view on US hedge funds, citing concerns over competition, regulatory issues, and insufficient evidence. In contrast, hedge funds from Guernsey, Jersey, and Switzerland have been deemed eligible for EU passports. A decision on US hedge funds will be made after Esma assesses other non-EU states, including Singapore and Hong Kong, to avoid market impact.

site_title: China's little secret: a thriving, free market in shares
summary: China's New Third Board (NTB), a small stock exchange, is thriving despite the chaos on the nation's main stock markets. Since its launch in 2012, the NTB has seen a significant increase in listings, with 362 companies since July 3, including major developers like Evergrande Real Estate. The NTB has been market-driven, with minimal government intervention, allowing companies to access the market and sustain their businesses. The NTB has raised a combined 30.3 billion yuan for 577 companies this year, more than double the amount raised in 2014.

site_title: Update: Plane debris 'very likely' from a Boeing 777: Malaysian PM
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has confirmed that plane debris found on the French island of La Reunion is "very likely" to be from a Boeing 777, possibly from missing flight MH370. The debris, identified as a wing component, has sparked hopes of determining the fate of the 239 people on board. The object will be shipped to Toulouse for examination by France's civil aviation authority. Najib urged against premature speculation, promising the families of the lost to find the truth and provide closure. The location of the debris aligns with drift analysis from the Malaysian investigation team.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific's Q2 earnings down 43%
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a 43% year-on-year drop in Q2 net profit to S$13.05 million, with revenue falling 9% to S$93.72 million. Earnings per share decreased to 1.09 cents, but net asset value per share rose to 36.89 cents. The company's first-half net profit rose 58% to S$59.5 million. Roxy-Pacific's executive chairman, Teo Hong Lim, plans to expand the company's footprint in existing markets and new geographies.

site_title: Air India staff arrested over people smuggling operation
summary: Indian police have arrested two Air India employees and two suspected traffickers over a people smuggling operation at New Delhi airport targeting Nepalese quake victims. Twenty-eight women, mostly from Nepal's earthquake-affected areas, were identified and rescued, with their travel documents found to have been forged. The operation involved paying $90 per person for the forged documents, and the women were allegedly promised jobs in Gulf countries. The arrests were made after a group of seven Nepalese women were found with their travel documents stamped without clearing immigration control.

site_title: Dairy Farm's H1 profit down 18% due to margin pressures
summary: Dairy Farm International Holdings reported a 18% drop in net profit to US$192 million for the first six months of 2015 due to margin pressures in its food businesses and disappointing trading in its Guardian business in Malaysia. Sales rose 27% to US$8.01 billion, driven by contributions from recent investments in supermarkets in China and Macau. Adverse exchange rates also impacted the company's results.

site_title: Asia-Pacific crude-narrowing brent, Dubai gap supports
summary: The Asia-Pacific crude market received support from a narrowing Brent-Dubai premium, with the gap dropping to $0.66 a barrel, its lowest level since July 17. The reduced spread makes regional oil more attractive to Asian refiners. Deals were reported in Japan, India, and Malaysia, while Indonesia's Pertamina offered crude for loading in a tender. Additionally, Royal Dutch Shell plans to axe 6,500 jobs and step up spending cuts due to lower oil prices.

site_title: French authorities ruling nothing out over Reunion plane debris
summary: French authorities have ruled out no hypothesis regarding the origin of plane debris found on Reunion island, despite a Malaysian minister's claim it was from missing flight MH370. The Malaysian Airlines Boeing 777 vanished in March 2014 with 239 passengers and crew. The Reunion prefecture and French Justice Ministry stated that the debris's origin remains unidentified, leaving all possibilities open.

site_title: Singapore shares close 34.5 points lower on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares closed 34.48 points lower, or 1.05%, at 3,249.52 on Thursday, with 2.13 billion shares changing hands. Losers outpaced gainers 283 to 152. The decline followed a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with no specific reason given for the drop.

site_title: GM's South Korea workers approve wage deal, avoid strike
summary: GM's South Korea workers approved a wage deal, averting a strike for the second year. The deal includes an 83,000 won wage increase and 10.5 million won bonuses. The agreement also involves the production of next-generation Chevrolet Malibu sedans on a second production line, likely ending speculation of reduced production at the Bupyeong plant. The union's partial strike did not affect production volume, and the company aims to achieve record sales in 2015.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close 0.49% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 0.49% lower on Thursday, with the Hang Seng index easing 121.47 points to 24,497.98, amid concerns about the mainland market and a late sell-off in Shanghai. This follows a second successive rise on Wall Street.

site_title: SMRT's Q1 profit down 10% to S$20m
summary: SMRT Corporation's net profit for the first quarter ended June 30, 2015, declined 10% to S$20.13 million due to losses from its rail operations. Revenue rose 7.8% to S$320.3 million. Despite this, the company remains a significant player in Singapore's public transportation sector, operating trains, buses, and taxis.

site_title: China search engine Baidu plans US$1.0b share buy-back
summary: China's search engine Baidu plans a US$1.0 billion share buy-back program over the next 12 months following disappointing second-quarter results, which sent shares plummeting. The company reported a profit of 3.66 billion yuan, slightly up from the same period last year but below forecasts. This move is aimed at returning value to shareholders and bolstering investor confidence.

site_title: ECB says oil prices a drag on inflation but a boost to growth
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) stated that falling oil prices will support Europe's economic recovery but exert downward pressure on inflation. The bank's asset buying program aims to boost inflation from anaemic levels. Despite low current prices, the bank predicts a further increase in oil prices by the end of the year and in 2016 and 2017, aligning with its target inflation rate of just under 2%.

images.alt_text: Falling oil prices will continue to support Europe's economic recovery but also exert a downward pressure on inflation, the European Central Bank said on Thursday, a potential headache for the bank as it tries to boost prices from anaemic levels.

site_title: German unemployment unexpectedly rises as economic risks mount
summary: German unemployment unexpectedly rose for a second month in July, increasing 9,000 to 2.8 million, with the unemployment rate remaining at 6.4%. This signals economic uncertainty surrounding Greece and the euro. Despite this, business confidence rebounded after Greece received a third bailout, preventing a default. The German economy is expected to recover, with strong factory orders in April and May suggesting a revival.

site_title: China Aviation Oil reports flat profit for Q2
summary: China Aviation Oil reported a flat profit of US$17.79 million in Q2, up 0.24% from the year-ago period. Revenue declined 36% to US$2.52 billion, while gross profit rose to US$9.21 million. The company's net profit for the first half of the year was 14.1% lower year-over-year at US$32.14 million. CAO plans to expand its global trading network and aviation marketing business to more airports outside China.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank denies rumours of governor's resignation
summary: Malaysia's central bank has denied rumors that its governor, Zeti Akhtar Aziz, has resigned. A spokeswoman for the bank stated that the rumors are "not true." This comes after speculation in local media and financial markets, but the central bank has not provided any further information on the matter.

site_title: Malaysia police say fire at headquarters destroyed waste paper, not secret documents
summary: Malaysian police have clarified that a fire at the country's headquarters on the 10th floor destroyed only waste paper, not secret documents related to ongoing investigations. According to Federal criminal investigation department director Comm Datuk Seri Mohmad Salleh, the fire only occurred in the outer corridor and involved old, unused papers such as application forms and book files.

site_title: Nokia's shares up in Helsinki on strong growth in networks
summary: Nokia's shares rose 7.5% in Helsinki after the company announced strong growth in its network equipment business in the second quarter, with group sales increasing 9% to 3.2 billion euros. The company reported an operating profit of 508 million euros, almost doubling from last year. Despite speculation about a potential sale of its HERE mapping unit, Nokia's CEO Rajeev Suri stated the company's goal is to find the best solution for shareholders, employees, and customers. Nokia expects to finalize its 15.6 billion euro Alcatel-Lucent acquisition by mid-2016.

site_title: Indonesia to sell first Samurai bonds without JBIC support
summary: Indonesia begins marketing its first Samurai bonds without Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC) support, marking a significant step in the country's efforts to diversify its funding sources. The 10-year fixed bonds will be marketed at 126bp-127bp, while the 3 and 5-year tranches will be sold at 85bp-90bp and 108bp-115bp over yen offer-side swaps, respectively. The notes are expected to score ratings of Baa3 and BBB-, similar to the sovereign. This move follows other sovereigns, such as Mexico, in graduating from JBIC guarantees.

site_title: UK fund firm Schroders tops forecasts on strong inflows
summary: Schroders, the UK's largest listed asset manager, posted a 17% pretax profit increase in the first half, beating forecasts, driven by strong demand for fixed-income products amid low interest rates. Net inflows of £8.8 billion, up from £4.8 billion last year, and total assets under management rose 14% to £309.9 billion. However, the company gave a cautious outlook due to increased market volatility and uncertainty in the eurozone and China, which may impact investor demand.

site_title: Hong Kong securities regulator fines Nomura Hong Kong for disclosure failings
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission fined Nomura Hong Kong HK$4.5 million for failing to promptly report trading misconduct by a staff member who falsified his position to conceal a US$3.3 million loss. The bank waited over two weeks to alert the regulator and also failed to voluntarily hand over a preliminary internal report. Nomura sent the staff member back to Japan before the alert was made. The SFC code of conduct requires firms to immediately alert the regulator in the event of material breaches.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's securities regulator has fined Japanese bank Nomura US$4.5 million (S$823,321) for failing to promptly report trading misconduct by a staff member who falsified his position in a bid to conceal a loss of US$3.3 million.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall as Samsung Electronics tumbles; won down
summary: Seoul shares fell 0.9% on Thursday due to disappointing results from Samsung Electronics, which tumbled 3.8% to an eight-month low. The company offered a downbeat outlook for the third quarter, contributing to the market's decline. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 2,019.03 points.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the open on Thursday, driven by company updates and investor assessments of the US Federal Reserve's economic outlook. London's FTSE 100 gained 0.64%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 advanced 0.83%, and Paris' CAC 40 climbed 0.63%. Asian markets also followed the rally in New York, with the dollar rising after the Fed upgraded its outlook on the US economy.

site_title: Oil set for biggest monthly loss this year even as supplies fall
summary: Oil is poised for its largest monthly loss this year, despite a recent decrease in US crude stockpiles, as global market concerns over oversupply persist. US oil production fell to its lowest level in over two months, and Royal Dutch Shell is preparing for a "prolonged downturn" by cutting thousands of jobs. The global market remains bearish, with OPEC pumping record volumes and Chinese fuel demand concerns.

site_title: Ezion sells innovative five-year notes backed by DBS at 3.65%
summary: Ezion Holdings sold S$120 million 5-year bonds at 3.65% backed by a DBS Bank structure, with orders reaching S$1.5 billion. The innovative structure, which uses DBS's credit facilities as a guarantee, reduced the interest rate by about 3%. The bonds, due August 5, 2020, will be fully backed by a committed funding facility provided by DBS, making the risk less apparent. This deal is seen as a sign of Ezion's resilience despite the slump in oil prices.

site_title: Indonesia readies US$1b loan against Fed rate volatility
summary: Indonesia received a $1.17 billion loan commitment from the World Bank and two other lenders to diversify funding sources ahead of potential US interest rate rises. The loan aims to bridge the budget shortfall this year, which Indonesia forecasts at 2.2% of GDP. The move follows Indonesia's decision to seek foreign loans rather than increase bond sales to cover the budget deficit, amid a depreciating rupiah and concerns over global market volatility.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise again on iron ore prices, China optimism
summary: Australian shares rose for the second consecutive day, driven by increasing iron ore prices and stabilizing Chinese equity markets, lifting investor confidence. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed 0.81% to close at 5,669.500.

site_title: MH370 relatives' emotional rollercoaster after wreckage link
summary: Relatives of Malaysia Airlines MH370 passengers expressed mixed emotions after reports emerged that a piece of the missing jet may have been found in the French Indian Ocean island of La Reunion. A two-meter long wing piece was discovered on a beach, raising hopes it could be from the Boeing 777 plane that vanished in 2014. Many relatives expressed a desire for closure and hoped those on board might still be alive, while others questioned the reports and criticized Malaysia's handling of the disaster.

site_title: Noble Group falls to 7-year-low on commodity slide amid buybacks
summary: Noble Group Ltd, Asia's largest commodity trading firm, plummeted to a 7-year low of 52 Singapore cents amid concerns about weakening demand for raw materials and its significant stock buybacks. The company has spent $131 million on 11 buybacks since last month, increasing its stake to 2.8%. This move has drawn criticism and attracted short-sellers, further depressing the stock price.

site_title: Swiss leading indicator hits 11-month high in July
summary: Switzerland's leading economic indicator rebounded to an 11-month high in July, reaching 99.8 points, surpassing estimates. The indicator, which measures economic activity, rose after the Swiss franc strengthened and the country's economy adjusted to the currency's sharp increase. The rebound suggests the economy is getting back on track, but economists caution that it's not yet in 'normal mode.' Brighter outlooks in prime costs, exporters' expectations, and the manufacturing sector contributed to the increase.

site_title: Dollar up on Fed rate talk, Asia markets mostly rise
summary: The US dollar strengthened against Asian currencies following the Federal Reserve's upgraded outlook on the US economy, sparking speculation of a potential interest rate hike in September. Asian markets, including Tokyo and Sydney, rose, while oil prices remained under pressure. The dollar's gain was partly driven by a Wall Street rally, with top firms like Nintendo reporting strong earnings.

site_title: China: Stocks fall as banks check equities exposure
summary: China's stocks fell 2.9% as banks investigated their exposure to the stock market through wealth management products and loans collateralized with stocks. The CSI300 index dropped to 3,815.41, while the Shanghai Composite Index slid 2.2% to 3,705.73. The China Securities Journal reported that unidentified bank officials were checking their exposure. This move is seen as a response to concerns over the stability of the financial system.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 1.08%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.08% on Thursday, driven by a weaker yen and a rally on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index gained 219.92 points to 20,522.83, while the Topix index rose 0.81% to 1,647.21. The Federal Reserve's upbeat assessment of the US economy also contributed to the gains.

site_title: S Korea Fifa hopeful slams 'cannibal' Blatter and stooge Platini
summary: South Korean billionaire Chung Mong-Joon has announced his candidacy for the FIFA presidency, calling Sepp Blatter a corrupt "cannibal" and Michel Platini an untrustworthy stooge.
