Chung, a former FIFA vice president, vows to make the governing body globally representative and transparent if elected. He faces stiff competition from Platini, who has the backing of four regional confederations, and will formally announce his candidacy next week. Chung has pledged to serve only one four-year term and aims to eliminate corruption within FIFA.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Sembmarine, SGX, SIA, Frasers Hospitality Trust
summary: Singtel sold its 30% stake in Abacus Travel Systems for $3 million. Sembcorp Marine reported a 17% decline in 2Q earnings to $109.23 million, while Singapore Exchange rose 24.5% in 4Q net profit to $96.22 million. Singapore Airlines' net profit jumped to $91.2 million in 1Q, driven by lower losses from associated companies. Frasers Hospitality Trust announced a 0.65% higher DPU of 1.56 Singapore cents for its 3Q.

site_title: Gold falls to near 5-1/2-year low as dollar rises on Sept Fed hike view
summary: Gold prices fell to a near 5-1/2 year low, dropping 1% to $1,084.46 an ounce, amid a strong US dollar and expectations of a September interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The dollar's rise made dollar-priced gold more costly for buyers using other currencies. Analysts predict further falls before and after the interest rate hike, with some seeing a substantially higher growth rate in US economic data as a factor in the Fed's decision.

site_title: Uber launches car leasing unit, makes entry into financial services
summary: Uber has launched its own auto leasing subsidiary, marking its entry into the financial services sector. The pilot project aims to provide drivers with more flexibility, allowing them to return vehicles with two weeks' notice and limited additional costs. Uber has partnered with Banco Santander's US lending unit earlier, but the partnership ended earlier this year. The move follows the US Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's oversight of non-bank auto lenders. Uber's leasing subsidiary will hold leases on its books during the pilot program, but the company will not be a party to any lease between a driver and the subsidiary.

site_title: Update: Shell to cut 6,500 jobs, reduce investment by US$7b
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc plans to cut 6,500 jobs and reduce capital investment by US$7 billion due to a "prolonged downturn" in the oil market. The company's second-quarter profit dropped to US$3.8 billion, beating analyst estimates. Shell expects oil prices to rise to US$90 a barrel by 2018, justifying its US$70 billion bid for BG Group Plc. The company's dividend commitment remains unchanged, with at least US$1.88 per share paid in 2016. The slump in oil prices has forced Shell to scale down its refinery businesses to strengthen its balance sheet.

site_title: DBS prices first covered bond from Singapore
summary: DBS Bank successfully priced its first Singaporean benchmark in offshore covered bonds, a USD1bn 3-year offering, at 37bp over mid-swaps. The deal attracted USD1.37bn in orders and marked a new asset class for Singapore, providing pricing guidance for South Korea's first statutory covered bond. The transaction reflects the banks' ability to tap global markets and access steady investor bases, particularly during challenging markets.

site_title: Sony's April-June profits more than triple to US$664m
summary: Sony's April-June net profit more than tripled to US$664 million, exceeding expectations. The company logged a quarterly net profit of 82.4 billion yen and operating profit jumped 38.8% to 96.9 billion yen. Sales were flat, edging down 0.1% to 1.8 trillion yen. Sony's full-year forecast remains unchanged, indicating a successful recovery from corporate restructuring efforts, including layoffs and asset sales.

images.alt_text: Sony said Thursday its April-June net profit more than tripled to US$664 million and kept its full-year forecast unchanged, as the company emerges from a painful corporate restructuring that included layoffs and asset sales.

site_title: Australia PM slams 'outrageous' Russian MH17 veto
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott criticized Russia's veto of a UN resolution to establish a tribunal to try those responsible for the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17. Eleven Security Council members voted in favor, while Russia and three others abstained or vetoed. Abbott called the veto "outrageous" and said it reinforced concerns Russia is protecting perpetrators. Countries including Australia, Britain, France, and the US blame pro-Russian separatists and Russia for the downing, which killed 298 people, including 38 Australians.

site_title: Australia says aircraft wreckage 'very important development'
summary: Australia's Transport and Infrastructure Minister Warren Truss says the discovery of a two-metre aircraft wreckage, possibly from a wing part, on the French island of La Reunion is a "very important development" in the search for MH370. The wreckage could have floated from the most likely impact zone in the southern Indian Ocean, approximately 4,000 kilometres away. Authorities believe it's feasible debris could have reached La Reunion, but the search strategy remains unchanged. The discovery provides closure for families of the 239 people on board, presumed dead.

site_title: Update: SGX issues trading query for Noble shares
summary: Noble Group Ltd's shares plummeted 14% on the Singapore bourse, prompting a trading query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX). This is the third query issued to Noble in six months, following a critical accounting report and short-seller claims of inflated assets. The company denies any new information, but a third-party review of its accounting practices is underway. The SGX advises shareholders to exercise caution and will investigate possible transgressions to maintain a fair market.

images.alt_text: The Singapore bourse asked Noble Group if it was aware of any reason for the sharp movement in its stock price, after the commodity trader's shares slumped nearly 12 per cent to a six-and-a-half year low on Thursday.

site_title: Shell cuts 2015 capex again to face oil downturn
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has reduced its 2015 capital investment to $30 billion, a 20% decrease from last year, due to the ongoing oil price downturn. The company expects its operating costs to fall by $4 billion, or 10%, in 2015 as part of a cost-cutting drive. Additionally, Shell plans to sell $30 billion worth of assets between 2016 and 2018, in addition to $20 billion in disposals for 2014 and 2015 combined, to boost its balance sheet.

images.alt_text: Royal Dutch Shell said on Thursday it will further reduce 2015 capital investment to US$30 billion, down by 20 per cent from a year ago as it expects the downturn in oil prices to "last for several years." Shell earlier this year cut its capital expenditure, or capex, to US$33 billion from around US$35 billion in 2014.

site_title: Accor eyes higher 2015 profit despite Brazil, France
summary: Accor, Europe's largest hotel group, forecasts 2015 operating profit of between 650 million to 680 million euros, a 8-10% increase from 2014, despite economic challenges in France and Brazil. The company's restructuring efforts are paying off, with first-half operating profit rising 8% like-for-like to 263 million euros. CEO Sebastien Bazin's reorganization started two years ago is expected to continue improving the company's performance.

images.alt_text: Accor, Europe's largest hotel group, on Thursday predicted its operating profit would rise further this year as restructuring efforts continue to pay off and despite still challenging economic conditions in France and Brazil.

site_title: Enhanced auditor reporting standards to provide more transparency from 2017 (Amended)
summary: The Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (ISCA) and Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) announced enhanced auditor reporting standards starting from 2017. Auditors will be required to provide more transparent reports, including key audit matters, and communicate these beyond a traditional pass or fail audit opinion. This change aims to provide deeper insights for investors and stakeholders, enhancing the quality and usefulness of auditor reports for listed companies.

site_title: Singapore Airlines releases seven A350 jet orders back to Airbus
summary: Singapore Airlines has agreed to return seven of its A350-900 jet orders to Airbus, reducing its total A350 orders to 63. The airline has also brought forward deliveries of some A350s and extended leases on A330-300s to meet its fleet renewal and growth plans. This move comes as the airline reported a first-quarter net profit of S$91.2 million, with operating profit increasing to S$108 million due to lower fuel costs and revenue from the sale of production slots.

site_title: South Korea central bank sees recovering consumption, modest inflation
summary: South Korea's central bank expects modest inflation to continue due to tepid consumption and weak global oil prices. The Bank of Korea sees upside risks from potential oil price hikes and fresh produce price spikes, but downward risks from the Iran nuclear agreement and lower utility costs. Domestic consumption is expected to recover, with exports rising slowly, narrowing the output gap in the second half of the year. Inflation is forecast to reach 0.9% this year and 1.8% in 2016, remaining below the central bank's target band of 2.5-3.5%.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly higher after Wall St gains
summary: Asian markets mostly rose Thursday, following a second straight rally in New York. The US dollar strengthened after the Federal Reserve upgraded its outlook on the US economy, while oil prices edged up. Tokyo jumped 1.05%, Hong Kong added 0.77%, and Shanghai rose 0.10%. Seoul dropped 0.73% due to Samsung's disappointing earnings. The Fed's statement suggested a possible rate hike in September, lifting the dollar and boosting markets.

site_title: BOJ's Ishida warns of stimulus costs, future imbalances
summary: Bank of Japan board member Koji Ishida warns of potential risks from the central bank's massive stimulus program, citing the risk of overheating the economy and creating financial imbalances. Despite Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's dismissal of such concerns, Ishida advises caution, emphasizing the need to monitor the situation from a long-term perspective. Ishida's comments contrast with Kuroda's focus on near-term benefits of the stimulus program, highlighting the differing views within the BOJ on the potential risks associated with its aggressive money printing.

site_title: Deutsche Bank quarterly performance overshadowed by legal costs
summary: Deutsche Bank reported a 34% increase in pretax profit to 1.2 billion euros in the second quarter, but warned that challenges remain due to high litigation costs and a need to pare its balance sheet. The company's new CEO, John Cryan, stated that the bank may not reach its 2020 performance targets if litigation charges continue at the same pace. Litigation charges of 1.2 billion euros and high costs burden the bank's bottom line, with Cryan citing an "unacceptably high level of costs" and a need for a more efficient balance sheet.

site_title: Eat, pray, shop: Philippine malls become the new town plazas
summary: Philippine malls are becoming the new town plazas, offering more than just shopping and dining. Teenagers like Jamie Gamboa prefer malls as they provide entertainment options, such as ice cream shops and venues for activities like Zumba workouts. Experts say malls are expanding their roles in communities, hosting events like Catholic mass and weddings. This shift reflects a changing need for community spaces, as traditional parks and museums are not often revisited. As a result, malls are becoming essential gathering places for locals.

site_title: Singapore appoints new representatives to Denmark, Jordan, Chile, Papua New Guinea
summary: Singapore has appointed new non-resident ambassadors to Denmark, Jordan, Chile, and a non-resident high commissioner to Papua New Guinea. Karan Singh Thakral will represent Singapore in Denmark, Shamsher Zaman in Jordan, Chong Siak Ching in Chile, and Chaly Mah Chee Kheong in Papua New Guinea. The appointments are part of Singapore's diplomatic efforts, with the new representatives bringing various professional backgrounds and expertise to their respective roles.

site_title: China's Baidu to buy back US$1b shares after investor selldown
summary: Baidu Inc, China's largest internet search engine company, plans to buy back $1 billion worth of shares after its stock price dropped 14% following a weak earnings report. The repurchase will be funded from existing cash and will take place over the next 12 months. The move aims to demonstrate confidence in the company's online-to-offline services, which are eroding its core search business margins.

images.alt_text: For more than a decade, Baidu's Robin Li has been the top provider of search services for China's Internet population. Now he wants to help them get laundry delivered, book a doctor's appointment or hire a chef to cook in their homes.

site_title: China: Stocks down open lower after rally
summary: China's Shanghai stocks opened lower, easing 0.41% in the first few minutes of trade on Thursday, after a 3.03% rally in the previous session. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 15.38 points to 3,773.79, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.49% to 2,188.00. The decline followed a strong performance in the previous session.

site_title: Singapore's employment grows at 'moderate pace' in Q2: MOM
summary: Singapore's employment grew at a "moderate pace" in Q2, with 15,700 new jobs added, mostly in construction and services. Unemployment rates edged up to 2% among residents and citizens, similar to last year's trend. Layoffs fell for a second consecutive quarter, with 3,100 workers made redundant, down from 3,500 in the first quarter. Overall employment growth moderated compared to a year ago.

site_title: Investigators scramble to analyse wreckage for MH370 link
summary: Aviation investigators are analyzing a 2m long piece of plane wreckage found on the French Indian Ocean island of Le Reunion, which may be linked to missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370. The object, appearing to be part of a wing, has sparked hopes that the mystery could be solved, but authorities warn against jumping to conclusions. French, Malaysian, and Australian authorities are investigating the object's origin, and a team of experts is expected to complete verification in two days. The discovery has fueled excitement, but also tempered it with the fact that no physical evidence has been found, and many questions remain unanswered about the plane's disappearance.

site_title: China investigates former vice-minister of environmental protection
summary: China's former vice-minister of environmental protection, Zhang Lijun, is under investigation for "severe disciplinary and law violations" following a reprimand of the environment ministry for interference in environmental impact assessments. This comes as part of President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption campaign, which has led to the downfall of numerous senior officials. The investigation highlights the sensitive topic of environmental degradation in China, with thousands of protests annually over pollution concerns. No further details have been provided by the Communist Party's anti-corruption agency.

site_title: Russia vetoes UN resolution on MH17 tribunal
summary: Russia vetoed a UN Security Council resolution to set up a tribunal to try those responsible for shooting down Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, which killed 298 people in 2014. The resolution was supported by 11 council members, but Russia's veto was backed by China, Angola, and Venezuela. Western powers and the victims' countries condemned the veto, with US Ambassador Samantha Power saying it would not silence efforts to seek international justice. The veto compounds the atrocity, with Australia's Foreign Minister Julie Bishop vowing to continue pursuing accountability for the perpetrators.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 0.73% after Fed meet
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.73% higher, following a positive lead from Wall Street and a stable dollar. Japan's factory output expanded 0.8% month-on-month in June, and Nintendo shares soared 7.32% after the company swung to a US$67 million net profit. However, Panasonic shares fell 7.35% due to a decline in operating profit. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also rose, with the dollar holding steady after the Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates near zero.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines says 'premature' to speculate on wreckage
summary: Malaysia Airlines has cautioned against speculating on the origin of a 2m long piece of wreckage found on the French island of La Reunion, which may be from missing flight MH370. The wreckage, possibly from a wing part, was discovered on a beach and authorities are working to verify its origin. Malaysian Transport Minister Liow Tiong Lai has sent a team to examine the find, and experts are awaiting confirmation before determining whether the part belongs to MH370. The discovery has sparked mixed emotions among next of kin of the missing passengers.

images.alt_text: Malaysia Airlines cautioned on Thursday that it was "premature" to speculate on whether aircraft wreckage found in the Indian Ocean was from missing flight MH370, as authorities scrambled to verify the origin of the debris.

site_title: Samsung Electronics Q2 profit down 4%, hurt by supply shortage for key phone
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 4% decline in Q2 operating profit to 6.9 trillion won, as expected, due to a supply shortage for the S6 edge phone's curved screen. The mobile division's profit fell to 2.76 trillion won from 4.42 trillion won a year earlier. Analysts attribute the shortage to the difficulty in manufacturing the curved screen, which affected demand for the device.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd said on Thursday its April-June operating profit fell 4 percent from a year earlier, in line with its earnings guidance, hurt by a supply shortage for one of its main smartphone models.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust reported a 0.65% higher DPU of 1.56 Singapore cents for its third quarter, despite lower gross revenue and net property income. The Reit's Japanese properties outperformed forecasts due to strong occupancies and revenue growth. Blumont Group warned of Q2 net losses due to fair value readjustments of its investments. Windsor Holdings changed its corporate name and sold subsidiaries, improving its balance sheet. China Minzhong Food Corp reported a 34% year-on-year decline in net profit, while TEE International swung into profit with a 92% surge in revenue.

site_title: Japan factory output up 0.8% month-on-month in June
summary: Japan's factory output increased 0.8% month-on-month in June, reversing a 2.1% drop in May. This beat economists' median forecast of a 0.3% increase. Industry projections indicate 0.5% growth in July and 2.7% in August. The better-than-expected data suggests the economy is showing signs of recovery, after a brief recession in 2014.

site_title: Singapore shares open little changed on Thursday
summary: The Singapore market opened little changed on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index slipping 2.13 points or 0.06% to 3,281.87. The US Federal Reserve kept its benchmark interest rate at near-zero percent after a two-day policy meeting, with US stocks gaining on Wednesday. 97.5 million shares worth S$74.8 million changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 91 to 42.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.65 points to 1,697.34. The market saw 148 gains and 65 losses, with a total volume of 69.26 million lots worth RM25.86 million.

site_title: Citigroup sees China securing oil market clout as imports climb
summary: Citigroup predicts China will secure oil market clout due to increasing imports and government reforms. China regained the top spot as the world's largest oil importer last month, and its imports are forecast to grow 7.1% this year. The country's independent teapot refineries will gain access to imported crude oil, and the potential start of an oil futures contract in Shanghai will further increase its importance. China may become a net exporter of petroleum products in 2016 for the first time in over a decade.

images.alt_text: As the global oil market grapples with a price slump and a supply glut, Citigroup Inc predicts China will exert the strongest pull on the international flow of crude.

site_title: Federal Reserve holds key US interest rate unchanged
summary: The Federal Reserve kept its benchmark federal funds interest rate at near-zero percent, as expected, at its latest meeting. The US economy has expanded moderately, with the jobs market strengthening, but business investment and exports remain soft. Inflation remains below the Fed's target, with core consumer prices rising to 1.8 percent year-over-year. The Fed is waiting to see more data before deciding on a rate hike, with a potential increase possible by the end of the year, according to Fed Chair Janet Yellen.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.82% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.82% in opening exchanges on Thursday, following a rally on Wall Street and investor returns after a sell-off at the start of the week. The Hang Seng Index added 202.97 points to 24,822.42. This increase comes amidst global market fluctuations, with the US and EU focusing on trade talks and investors reacting to new Trump threats.

site_title: SIA's Q1 earnings soar to S$91.2m on lower fuel costs
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a net profit of S$91.2 million for the first quarter of 2016, up from S$34.8 million in the same period last year, driven by lower fuel costs. Revenue fell 3.2% to S$3.57 billion, mainly due to competition and cut-throat fares. Operating profit rose to S$111.4 million, and earnings per share increased to 7.8 cents. Despite lower cargo revenue, the airline attributed the improvement to lower fuel costs and hedging losses.

site_title: Noble Group's buybacks near biggest acquisition in four years
summary: Noble Group, Asia's largest commodity trader, has spent S$131 million on its own shares, building up a 2.8% stake since last month. The buybacks, which began on June 12, come amid a 50% decline in the company's stock value since February, sparked by criticism of its accounting practices. Noble has rejected the criticism and hired a new auditor, but analysts warn that the aggressive buybacks could negatively impact the share price due to concerns over a potential downgrade of the company's credit rating.

site_title: Apple, Samsung lose ground in shrinking tablet market
summary: Tablet sales fell in the second quarter of 2015, with total sales reaching 44.7 million units, down 7% from the previous year and 3.9% from the prior quarter. Market leaders Apple and Samsung lost ground to other vendors, marking a third consecutive quarter of declining year-over-year sales. This decline was attributed to the saturation of the market and increased competition from emerging players.

site_title: Google adds 20 languages to instant translation app
summary: Google has added 20 new languages to its instant translation app, bringing the total to 27 languages that can be read and translated without an internet connection. The app now also offers faster and smoother voice translation, allowing it to interpret street signs, ingredient lists, and other texts. The new languages include Bulgarian, Croatian, and Ukrainian, among others. The updates utilize artificial intelligence to recognize letters and words, helping to break down language barriers and improve communication.

site_title: US: Stocks gain as Fed keeps rates low
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday after the Federal Reserve kept its benchmark interest rate at near-zero percent, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 121.12 points (0.69%) to 17,751.39. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also advanced, with the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index rising 22.53 (0.44%) to 5,111.73. The gains were attributed to a rally in Chinese stocks, a rise in oil prices, and the launch of Windows 10 by Microsoft.

site_title: Tourism boom drives Japan to convert offices into hotels
summary: Japan is experiencing a tourism boom, with record 13.4 million visitors in 2014 and a target to attract 20 million by 2020. The surge in tourists is straining Tokyo's existing 100,000 hotel rooms, prompting developers to convert offices into hotels to increase lodging options. The government aims to capitalize on the trend to boost the economy.

site_title: Greek PM threatens snap vote over party rebels' opposition to bailout
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has threatened to call an early election if hardliners in his party continue to resist a new bailout deal worth up to 86 billion euros. The European Central Bank has left its emergency credit lifeline unchanged, supporting Greece's struggling banks and economy. Experts from the ECB, EU, and IMF discussed the new bailout in Athens, with Tsipras warning of early elections if the deal is not accepted. The bailout deal is part of a three-year agreement aimed at providing debt relief to Greece.

site_title: September? December? Fed's not saying
summary: The Federal Reserve is delaying a decision on raising interest rates for the first time in nine years, with no clear timeline provided. The Fed's statement noted continued labor market improvement, but traders are focused on when the second rate increase will occur, with futures showing a more gradual pace than forecasted. The median forecast for the benchmark rate is 0.625% by year-end, rising to 1.625% in 2016, with markets not pricing in a second rate increase until June 2016.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve needs a little longer to decide when to raise interest rates for the first time in nine years. The bond market is more interested in when the second increase will be.

site_title: Microsoft gears for turnaround with Windows 10 rollout
summary: Microsoft launched its Windows 10 operating system, aiming to reshape the tech giant and move ahead in mobile computing and emerging technologies. The new system, available as a free upgrade, includes features such as voice, pen, and gesture input, as well as integration with the Cortana virtual assistant. Microsoft hopes to gain traction in mobile, where it lags behind Google Android and Apple iOS, and in emerging technologies like the "Internet of Things." The company faces a tough task in catching up with its competitors, but analysts see potential for growth in enterprise tablet purchases and the Internet of Things market.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler sued in Canada following recent vehicle recalls
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) was sued in Canada by the law firm Merchant Law Group for $4 billion in damages related to recent vehicle recalls. The lawsuit, filed in the Superior Court in Montreal, seeks class action status and plans to file claims in courts across Ontario, British Columbia, Saskatchewan, and Nova Scotia. A FCA spokeswoman stated the company has not been served and would not comment until reviewing the allegations.

site_title: Dollar rises as Fed keeps interest rates on hold
summary: The US dollar rose 0.6% to $1.0990 against the euro and 0.2% to 123.91 yen after the Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged but signaled a potential rate hike in the coming months. Analysts believe the Fed may raise rates in September if the US job market remains strong. The decision was seen as relatively upbeat on the economy, giving the Fed room to adjust its policy based on incoming data.

site_title: Little by little, Germans look beyond cash to shop
summary: Germans are gradually shifting away from cash payments, with over half of private purchases being paid in cash, despite nearly all having debit cards. A mistrust of credit and concerns over security and privacy are major factors. Younger consumers are more likely to use electronic payment methods, with 20% of 14- to 29-year-olds already paying with smartphones. Retailers like Lidl and Aldi have started accepting credit cards, and the European Union has passed a regulation capping fees on payments. The trend is expected to continue, with cash covering less than half of payments in the medium term.

images.alt_text: Security and privacy are high priorities among Germans, who tend to be conservative consumers with a strong aversion to debt. The trauma from 1920s-era hyperinflation still colours the national thinking.

site_title: Russian banks turn to HK to refinance debts of companies
summary: Russian banks are turning to Hong Kong to refinance debts of companies due to US and European sanctions. Russian corporates face difficulties issuing US dollar bonds, with yields on yuan-denominated bonds reaching 8.04% for VTB Bank JSC. Gazprombank, Russia's third-largest lender, is applying for licenses to offer securities services in Hong Kong. Chinese banks have helped Russian companies access funding despite sanctions, with yuan-denominated bonds being a viable alternative. Higher borrowing costs are expected, but closer ties between Russia and China are helping.

site_title: Bank of England may toughen stress tests as economy picks up
summary: The Bank of England may adopt a more dynamic approach to stress testing the financial system, using scenarios of varying severity to assess the resilience of the system as the economy cycles through growth and busts. Deputy Governor Jon Cunliffe said this approach would help regulators better understand potential risks and address them proactively. The move comes as the financial system continues to evolve, with asset management growing to a similar size to commercial banking, and regulators seeking to broaden their view of potential crises.

site_title: Malaysia sends team to see if Reunion debris is from MH370 flight
summary: Malaysia has sent a team to Reunion Island to determine if debris found may be from missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, which vanished in 2014. The Boeing 777, carrying 239 passengers, is believed to have crashed in the Indian Ocean. Malaysian Transport Minister Liow Tiong Lai has sent a team to verify the wreckage, with further inspection needed to confirm its origin. This development comes as search efforts led by Australia continue to focus on the southern Indian Ocean. The incident remains one of the biggest mysteries in aviation history.

site_title: Facebook profit dips as expenses bite into revenue
summary: Facebook reported a 9% drop in quarterly profit to $715 million, despite a 39% surge in revenue to $4.04 billion, driven by mobile advertising gains. The company's user base reached 1.5 billion, with mobile active users rising to 1.31 billion. Expenses, including stock compensation for WhatsApp's acquisition, increased 82% to $1.17 billion. Facebook shares dipped 2.2% after-hours, despite beating market expectations, and analysts expect the company's advertising business to continue growing.

images.alt_text: Facebook reported a dip in its quarterly profit Wednesday but said revenues surged on mobile advertising gains, as its user base neared 1.5 billion.

site_title: StanChart warms its durian-loving clients' hearts
summary: Standard Chartered Bank in Singapore has hosted its annual durian feast, welcoming over 1,000 clients to a two-day event featuring three premium durian varieties and other fruits. The event, which serves over 2,000 kg of durian, is seen as a unique opportunity for the bank to engage with its durian-loving clients. The head of commercial clients, Kenneth Tham, stated that the event is a chance to share the joy of a bountiful harvest of the king of fruits, and to create a memorable experience for clients.

site_title: LVMH fashion and leather Q2 sales beat forecasts
summary: LVMH's fashion and leather division reported a 10% rise in Q2 sales, beating forecasts, driven by strong trading in Europe, Japan, and the US. Total sales rose 6% on a like-for-like basis to 16.7 billion euros. The company attributed the growth to a shift of business to other geographies, including Japan and Western Europe, as Chinese tourists reduced spending in mainland China, Hong Kong, and Macau.

site_title: Brazil investment grade rating is at risk, warns S&P
summary: Brazil's investment-grade rating is at risk, according to a warning from Standard & Poor's, which could downgrade the country's rating to junk by 12-18 months. The warning comes amid concerns over corruption investigations, economic growth, and implementation of austerity measures. Brazil's Finance Minister Joaquim Levy's efforts to win back investor confidence have been unsuccessful, and market participants now expect the country to lose its investment grade by the end of 2016. The Brazilian real has slid 2% against the dollar, its weakest in over 12 years.

site_title: Desperate migrants try to cross Channel to Britain from Calais
summary: A large group of migrants attempted to cross the English Channel from Calais to Britain overnight, with at least 2,100 efforts reported, resulting in 1,900 being turned back, 200 arrests, and 6 injuries. The migrants, mainly Afghans, Ethiopians, Eritreans, Syrians, and Sudanese, aim to seek asylum or protection in Britain, often due to family ties or language skills. The surge in migrant attempts has worsened the situation in Calais, with over 3,000 migrants now living in squalid camps.

images.alt_text: Migrants who successfully crossed the Eurotunnel terminal on Tuesday walking on the side of the railroad in Frethun, northern France, as they try to board a shuttle freight train to Britain.

site_title: Raffles Medical Group first in Asia to join Mayo Clinic Care Network
summary: Raffles Medical Group, a Singapore-based integrated private healthcare provider, has become the first in Asia to join the US-based Mayo Clinic Care Network. The partnership allows Raffles Medical to access Mayo Clinic's resources, including electronic consultations, online clinical reference materials, and expertise in quality management. The collaboration, announced on July 29, 2015, will not affect the operations of either organization, with Raffles Medical's services available only at its Singapore clinics and hospital. The partnership aims to bring high-quality patient care to the region.

site_title: Denmark takes steps to avoid property market overheating
summary: Denmark's financial regulator is investigating banks to ensure they are not lending borrowers more than they can afford, amid concerns of an overheated property market. The Danish Financial Supervisory Authority is reviewing lending policies and urging banks to adopt sound practices, particularly steering away from interest-only and adjustable-rate products. The country's households, with a high gross debt load, are relying on fixed-rate loans to stem interest risk exposure, and apartment prices are at their highest since 2006. The regulator aims to prevent a repeat of the 2008 housing bubble.

site_title: India's SpiceJet in talks with Boeing, Airbus to buy 100 jets
summary: India's budget carrier SpiceJet is in talks with Boeing and Airbus to purchase over 100 single-aisle jets worth approximately $11 billion at list prices. The deal, if signed, would be SpiceJet's largest-ever plane order. The airline's shares rose 5.6% after it posted its second consecutive quarterly profit, marking a turnaround from financial troubles last year. SpiceJet chairman Ajay Singh is considering investments in the form of new shares or debt to support the order, which could be signed during the current financial year.

site_title: Gold price plunge comes amid loss of appeal
summary: Gold prices have plummeted amid a loss of appeal, with prices expected to drop to US$984 an ounce by January, the lowest since 2009. The metal has lost its charisma, and sentiment plays a significant role in the bullion market. Speculators are shorting gold for the first time since 2006, and holders of exchange-traded products are selling at the fastest pace in four months. Analysts predict further losses, with some forecasting prices below US$1,000. The decline is attributed to mounting speculation on US interest rates and the strengthening dollar.

images.alt_text: An improving US economy has spurred a shift in sentiment, driving bullion into a bear market in April 2013.

site_title: SGX profit jumps 24% in Q4 on robust derivatives showing
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 24% jump in net profit to S$96.2 million in Q4 2015, driven by its derivatives business, which saw a 64% increase in revenue. The exchange's securities market transformation appears to be making progress, with retail investors' trading in Straits Times Index (STI) stocks increasing by 9% to 45,330. Despite a 4% drop in securities daily average traded value, the derivatives business accounted for 38% of group revenue, driven by strong performances in China A50 and iron ore contracts.

site_title: Govt-to-govt cooperation now crucial in fighting cyber threats
summary: Singapore's government has acknowledged the need for government-to-government cooperation in fighting cyber threats, citing the country's vulnerability to targeted attacks. The Cyber Security Agency (CSA) has been established to oversee the nation's cyber defense, and collaborations with international partners, such as the UK, have been initiated to share threat intelligence and best practices. Experts emphasize the importance of cooperation in tackling the increasingly sophisticated and frequent cyber threats, which are no longer limited to monetary losses but can also cause harm to governments and countries.

site_title: SingPost Q1 profit up 15.8% at S$46.6m
summary: SingPost reported a 15.8% increase in net profit to S$46.6 million for the first quarter ended June 30, driven by revenue growth in eCommerce and logistics. Revenue rose 20.7% to S$254.6 million, while total expenses climbed 24.9% to S$222.7 million. The company declared an interim quarterly dividend of 1.5 cents per share. CEO Wolfgang Baier attributed the results to partnerships and M&As, including a new arrangement with Alibaba to create an end-to-end logistics platform.

site_title: Ageing population, insurance seen raising US health spending
summary: US healthcare spending is projected to rise by 5.8% annually from 2015 to 2024, outpacing overall economic growth, driven by an ageing population and increased insurance coverage under Obamacare. Health spending will account for 19.6% of GDP in 2024, up from 17.7% last year. The insured share of the population is expected to climb to 92.4% by 2024, with Medicare beneficiaries projected to reach 70.3 million and Medicaid members reaching 78.1 million. The effectiveness of the Affordable Care Act's spending control provisions remains uncertain.

site_title: Penalty on Fiat Chrysler makes merger search tougher
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) has been hit with a record US$105 million penalty for delaying the handling of safety defects in the US. The penalty, including an estimated US$7.5 billion to buy back defective vehicles, may deter potential merger partners from joining CEO Sergio Marchionne's call for a merger. The settlement is expected to have a minimal impact on FCA's financial results, but tarnishes the image of Fiat Chrysler cars and trucks, making a merger less likely.

site_title: India a safe haven in emerging-market storm, says IIF
summary: India's emerging-market assets have proven to be a safe haven in turbulent fund flows, with global fund managers increasing allocations to Indian equities despite net outflows from other emerging markets. India's portfolio weightings for equities reached an all-time high of over 9% in July, while emerging-market funds excluding China saw net outflows of $2.3 billion. Meanwhile, there has been a "flight-to-quality" in flows to advanced economy markets, with significant investments in US stocks and euro-area equities.

site_title: Why economists have trouble explaining bubbles
summary: Economists are reevaluating the "rational expectations" theory, which posits that people make correct guesses about the future economy. However, recent studies suggest that human psychology may lead to systematic errors in expectations, potentially explaining financial bubbles and crashes. Researchers have found that people with overly optimistic expectations for their incomes were more likely to overpay for houses before the 2008 housing crash. This challenges the long-held assumption that people make rational decisions based on correct expectations, and could lead to a fundamental shift in the field of economics.

site_title: BOE chief begins countdown to central bank's data overload
summary: The Bank of England's (BOE) chief, Mark Carney, is set to release a massive amount of data on August 6, dubbed "Super Thursday," in a single day, including policy decisions, minutes of meeting, officials' votes, and new economic forecasts. This unprecedented move aims to provide immediate explanations for the central bank's thinking and reduce speculation between publications. The data release coincides with a potential shift in interest rates, with some economists forecasting a rate hike in August. The format is expected to increase market fluctuations, but potentially reduce longer-term volatility.

site_title: CDLHT eyes Australia Japan and NZ for more acquisitions
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) is exploring acquisitions in Australia, Japan, and New Zealand. Despite a 10% drop in Q2 distribution per stapled security, the company remains well-positioned for acquisitions, with a gearing ratio of 32% and debt headroom of $322 million. CDLHT's Singapore hotels experienced a 4.4% year-on-year drop in revenue per available room, while its Australian hotels saw a 10.6% decline due to the weaker Australian dollar. In contrast, the company's two Japan hotels achieved 29.1% year-on-year revenue growth.

site_title: Twitter CEO's candour stops share price rise but wins plaudits
summary: Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey's first earnings call with investors as head of a public company was met with mixed reactions. Despite exceeding revenue expectations, the stock price declined 11% after Dorsey spoke candidly about Twitter's shortcomings, including its struggles to grow its audience and align the company around its strategy. Analysts praised Dorsey's honesty, saying it helped build trust with investors, but noted that the call was a test for the young CEO, who also runs Square Inc. and is rumored to be a potential permanent CEO of Twitter.

site_title: A$, C$ inch lower ahead of Fed statement
summary: The US dollar and euro were steady against other major currencies, while the Canadian and Australian dollar declined 0.2-0.3% ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy statement. Oil prices fell, and traders await the Fed's potential impact on interest rates and commodity prices. Analysts expect broad dollar strength against commodity currencies, citing macroeconomic risks, particularly out of China. The Fed's statement may reduce expectations of a rate rise in September, and the dollar may rise against emerging market currencies.

site_title: New Adelaide mall boosts Starhill's quarterly results (Amended)
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 3.2% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.29 cents for the April-June 2015 quarter, driven by its recent acquisition of Myer Centre Adelaide. The trust's three-month revenue rose 6.9% to S$51.8 million, while net property income (NPI) increased 5.5% to S$41.3 million. CEO Ho Sing attributed the growth to improving mall quality and tenant mix. The Reit plans to expand its portfolio overseas, particularly in Australia, but is cautious about acquiring assets due to high prices.

site_title: GIC posts 4.9% real return in past 20 years; sees tougher times ahead
summary: The Government Investment Corporation (GIC) of Singapore has reported an annualized real return of 4.9% over the past 20 years, surpassing its 20-year real return of 4.1% in 2014. However, the sovereign wealth fund's chief investment officer warns that volatile markets could chip away at its returns in the next 5-10 years, potentially leading to short-term losses. Fundamentals have not kept up with the sharp rise in asset prices, and GIC attributes its lower return to its conservative policy of keeping a large part of its portfolio in cash.

images.alt_text: GIC group chief investment officer Lim Chow Kiat says GIC is now more engaged with its partners and investee companies, and is working more closely with external managers.

site_title: Smooth piste for Beijing's 2022 Winter Games bid
summary: China has emerged as the frontrunner to host the 2022 Winter Olympics, with the International Olympic Committee (IOC) set to make a decision on Friday. Beijing's bid is seen as a significant moment for China, which hosted the 2008 Summer Olympics, and has been touted as a key opportunity to promote the country's winter sports development. Despite concerns over costs, China's government is confident in its ability to deliver the games, citing its national sports lottery and existing infrastructure. The bid team has also emphasized the importance of promoting winter sports in China, with a goal of encouraging 300 million people into the sport.

images.alt_text: China says it is keeping the budget for the 2022 Winter Olympics down by using 11 venues from the 2008 Games, including the Bird's Nest stadium.

site_title: P&G names Taylor to CEO job; Lafley to be exec chairman
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has announced that David Taylor will succeed current CEO A.G. Lafley as CEO on November 1, with Lafley staying on as executive chairman. Taylor, a 35-year veteran of the company, will also take on the president role. Lafley's succession plan is expected to follow the previously announced exit of 43 beauty brands to Coty Inc. for $12.5 billion. P&G's sales are projected to decline 8% this year, and Taylor will face challenges in competing with upstarts and convincing customers to pay a premium for P&G brands.

site_title: China stock rout may delay govt's push for 'bond connect' scheme
summary: China's stock market slump may delay the launch of a "bond connect" scheme, which aims to connect the country's $5 trillion bond market with overseas investors. The delay is due to regulatory concerns and the need to put a floor under China's unruly stock markets. Officials have been wary of pushing new initiatives until they have resolved the crisis. A bond connect scheme would require a more complicated undertaking, including working out how debt products can be traded on an exchange-type set-up. A launch in 2017 is now considered more likely due to the numerous obstacles to overcome.

site_title: Emaar IPO flop dashes Egypt's hopes of property market turnaround
summary: Egypt's Emaar Properties IPO, touted as a key to rebuilding investor confidence in the country's property market, has failed after a 7.4% decline in its first three weeks of trading. The IPO was expected to be a catalyst for the market's turnaround, but investors were deterred by a valuation that didn't reflect the dim outlook for high-end home demand. The IPO's failure may complicate the government's efforts to attract $40 billion in investment for low- and middle-income housing projects.

site_title: Jane Birkin asks Hermes to take her name off iconic crocodile-skin handbag
summary: British singer Jane Birkin has asked luxury brand Hermes to remove her name from its iconic crocodile-skin handbag due to the "cruel" methods used to make the accessory. Birkin, 68, has requested Hermes to "debaptise" the Birkin Croco until better practices are implemented. This comes after PETA exposed alleged cruelty on crocodile farms in Texas to Zimbabwe, where reptiles are allegedly crammed into pits and killed while still conscious.

images.alt_text: The bag named after Jane Birkin is a symbol of wealth and is much- loved by celebrities.

site_title: China's stock-market rescue puts spotlight on central bankers' exit strategy
summary: China's stock market experienced its largest drop since 2007 due to speculation that central bankers were scaling back stimulus. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.7% on Tuesday before rebounding on Wednesday. China's central bank pledged to stabilize the market, but the challenge of weaning investors off liquidity support remains. The move highlights the difficulties of implementing an exit strategy in a market dependent on official support, similar to the US Federal Reserve's experience with tapering stimulus.

site_title: Financial SMEs helping to boost Manhattan's office leasing market
summary: New York's office leasing market has seen a resurgence, driven by private equity and advisory firms, which now account for 26% of Manhattan's leasing space. This growth, combined with demand from technology, media, and advertising companies, has pushed up rents and created Manhattan's strongest office market since the 2008 crash. The vacancy rate in Midtown has fallen to 8.9%, with average rents rising 8% to $76.45 per square foot. Smaller financial firms are expanding, taking advantage of fewer regulations and more efficient office spaces.

site_title: Lone Star to buy UK property firm Quintain
summary: US private equity firm Lone Star has agreed to buy British property firm Quintain Estates and Development for £700 million (S$1.5 billion). The cash bid is 22% above Quintain's closing price, providing Lone Star with access to undeveloped land around London's Wembley Stadium. The acquisition will give Lone Star one of London's few remaining large-scale development opportunities.

site_title: Why the Greek deal will work
summary: A Greek bailout deal has created conditions for sustainable recovery, despite conventional wisdom suggesting it's a temporary fix. The agreement addresses eurozone flaws, allowing for monetary financing of government deficits and mutual support of debt burdens. With interest payments prioritized over electoral promises, Greece can now support its debt burden without strict austerity measures. The deal also paves the way for structural reforms, such as privatisation, labor market, and pension reform, which are crucial for the Greek economy and the eurozone as a whole. A sustainable recovery in Greece is now possible, contrary to previous predictions of permanent depression.

site_title: Faulty third-rail insulator major factor in July 7 train breakdown
summary: A faulty third-rail insulator in a tunnel between Tanjong Pagar and Raffles Place caused a massive train breakdown on July 7, affecting 250,000 commuters. The insulator's weak resistance allowed electricity to flow to the ground, triggering the system's 64P safety mechanism. Investigations found mineral deposits with high chloride content on the insulator, reducing its effectiveness. To prevent similar incidents, SMRT is replacing third-rail insulators and installing data loggers at traction power substations, with plans to raise the 64P setting to 200V.

site_title: Asean has greater need for insurance to safeguard economic success
summary: ASEAN's rapid economic growth is hindered by low insurance penetration, with a 3.4% rate in 2013, compared to the global average. Insurance underpins economic development, reducing uninsured losses and taxpayers' contributions after disasters. Global insurers play a crucial role in stabilizing financial situations after catastrophes. However, protectionism in Latin America, Africa, and Asia-Pacific restricts insurers' ability to offer cross-border insurance, undermining economic development. To address this, Singapore's thriving reinsurance market aims to share expertise and promote free trade, with Lloyd's committing to partner with local markets to increase Asean's resilience to natural disasters.

site_title: Spain's Talgo hopes to bag high-speed train deals in India
summary: Spain's Talgo aims to secure high-speed train deals in India, capitalizing on the country's strained relationship with China. Talgo's CEO, Jose Maria Oriol Fabra, stated the company is open to partnerships and projects in India's railway modernization drive. Talgo plans to manufacture and export trains from India to compete with Chinese trains on price. The Indian government plans to invest $132 billion in its railway network by 2020, creating opportunities for foreign companies like Talgo.

site_title: Ford surprises with 44% Q2 profit jump
summary: Ford Motor Co. reported a 44% profit jump in the second quarter, driven by record-setting profit in North America and strong sales of sport utility vehicles and trucks. Despite a decline in F-150 pickup sales, Ford's earnings reached 47 US cents a share, exceeding Wall Street expectations. The company attributed the growth to its ability to turn sales into profit, with operating margin rising to 7.2%. Ford reaffirmed its estimate of pretax profits for 2015, which is expected to be between US$8.5 billion and US$9.5 billion.

site_title: China: Searching for a new equilibrium
summary: China's economy is poised for a moderated 6% GDP growth, driven by rising wages and consumption, which will offset the contraction of traditional sectors such as real estate and manufacturing. The country faces policy challenges, including managing risks and overcoming imbalances, but remains optimistic about its outlook. Key risks include a delicate balance of monetary policy, substantial debt, and potential stock market corrections. Despite these challenges, China appears to have adopted the correct strategy to avoid the "middle-income trap" and will continue to shift towards consumption, services, and higher value-added manufacturing.

site_title: Sing Investments & Finance posts marginal dip in Q2 profit
summary: Sing Investments & Finance reported a net profit of S$2.66 million for Q2 2015, down marginally from S$2.7 million in the previous year. Interest income and hiring charges rose 24.3% to S$15.49 million, while interest expense increased 51% to S$7.09 million. This led to an operating profit of S$4.05 million, 1.6% lower than the previous year. The company attributed the decline to a 13.8% rise in other operating expenses, largely due to higher staff costs.

site_title: 'Halo effect' dims as Indonesia consumer confidence slides: survey
summary: Indonesia's consumer confidence plummeted 25.8 points in the first half, the steepest decline in Asia, due to a slow pace of change following President Joko Widodo's election. The country's economy and stock market outlook worsened, with the Jakarta Composite Index slumping 9.8% and the rupiah losing 8% this year. Weak government spending and bureaucratic hurdles hinder business growth, contributing to the economic slowdown. The country's consumer confidence remains in the "optimistic" range, but the outlook has significantly deteriorated.

images.alt_text: Consumer spending, which accounts for more than half of the economy, remains moderate.

site_title: Pacific trade talks formally start; too early to predict an agreement
summary: US and 11 other Asia-Pacific nations have formally started four-day talks to hammer out a massive free-trade agreement, the Trans-Pacific Partnership. The talks, which began in Hawaii, aim to resolve issues such as drug patents and dairy exports, but could collapse due to disagreements over these and other contentious topics. The US and Japan, the two largest economies in the TPP, will need to jointly drive a resolution, but progress is uncertain, with some experts predicting a 50-50 chance of success.

site_title: Penny activity, Jardine block deal dominate
summary: Singapore stocks rose 2.91 points to 3,284, with Penny stocks dominating the day's activity, driven by Chinese money. Jardine Matheson's massive block trade distorted the market, while oil prices plummeted. Liftboat provider Ezion Holdings surged 6% after analysts praised its growth potential. Penny stocks like Stratech Group and CEFC International also gained ground, with some stocks experiencing record highs. The Straits Times Index awaits hints from the US Federal Reserve meeting on a potential September rate hike.

site_title: JLL confirms en bloc sale of Thong Sia to Sin Capital
summary: JLL confirmed a S$380 million deal for the collective sale of Thong Sia Building, a 26-storey mixed-use building in Singapore. The sale, the first this year and largest ever mixed-use collective sale, translates to S$2,430 per square foot. Sin Capital Group, a private investment group, purchased the building without plans for redevelopment or change of use. The sale is subject to approval by the Strata Titles Board and reflects the current market conditions.

site_title: Newspapers, cultural symbols shouldn't be traded like assets
summary: The sale of the Financial Times to Japan's Nikkei group has raised concerns about the commodification of national culture. The newspaper is perceived as a symbol of British values, and its sale to a Japanese entity may lead to a clash of editorial mores. The Nikkei's "Japanese way" of doing things may compromise the FT's editorial integrity, and the process of "rationalization" and cost-cutting may erode the newspaper's essential character. This transaction highlights the need for new thinking on newspaper ownership, as the trend of treating media as tradeable assets threatens the unique cultural values of publications.

site_title: GLP to acquire US$4.55 billion US logistics portfolio
summary: GLP, a global logistics provider, announced the acquisition of a US$4.55 billion logistics portfolio in the US, expanding its presence to 173 million sq ft and becoming the second largest logistics property player in the US within a year. The portfolio, comprising 58 million sq ft across 20 markets, will be injected into GLP's fund management platform by April 2016. The acquisition is expected to generate "compelling returns" for GLP, with a 5.6% cap rate and a smaller 10% equity stake generating returns within the first year.

site_title: Europe: Earnings, M&A spur second day of advances in European equities
summary: European stocks surged on their second day of gains, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index rising 1% to 393.88. Companies such as Bayer, PSA Peugeot Citroen, and GlaxoSmithKline reported better-than-estimated earnings, while deals activity intensified. The Stoxx 600 is on track for a 3.3% gain in July, and analysts expect M&A activity to continue, driven by high cash piles and a favorable financing environment.

site_title: Greek debt restructuring is inevitable, says IMF chief
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde says Greece's debt restructuring is inevitable, stating that an easing of debt terms is necessary for Greece's success. The IMF has teamed up with the EU and ECB to provide loans to Greece, but creditors are resisting the idea of debt restructuring. Lagarde also comments on other topics, including Ukraine's debt restructuring progress and China's yuan inclusion in the IMF's special drawing rights basket, but emphasizes that these issues won't impact the IMF's decision on Greece.

site_title: Chinese government looks to tourism to lift consumption
summary: China's government aims to boost domestic spending through tourism, following a year of stagnant economic growth. Regulations for tourism businesses will be relaxed, and loans will be extended to firms. The government targets 5.5 trillion yuan in domestic tourism spending by 2020, more than doubling the 2013 figure. This move seeks to energize the economy, which is expected to log its slowest growth in a quarter of a century.

site_title: AA Reit's turnaround after 5 years
summary: AA Reit, a Singapore-based industrial real estate investment trust (REIT), has turned around its fortunes after five years under new management. The REIT has switched its investment strategy and capital management practices, increasing debt on fixed interest rates and securing tenants before property acquisitions. Despite a painful past, including a recapitalization plan and a binding obligation to purchase a property, AA Reit has posted a distribution per unit of 2.75 cents, a 7.8% increase from last year, and a 10.7% growth in gross revenue. The REIT's stock price has also recovered, with a 1-cent gain to S$1.49.

site_title: GIC stepping up investments in real estate
summary: GIC, one of the largest real estate investors globally, is increasing its investments in the asset class to diversify its portfolio and hedge against inflation. Real estate offers both income from rent and value appreciation, with income returns being more stable. GIC has a substantial presence in emerging markets, especially in Asia, and employs over 200 people across nine offices on four continents. The firm's real estate portfolio consists of direct and indirect investments in over 40 countries, with the largest holdings in offices, retail, and residential sectors.

site_title: Indonesia regulator open to higher foreign stakes in banks
summary: Indonesia's Financial Services Authority is open to increasing foreign ownership stakes in local banks beyond 40%, with chairman Muliaman Hadad stating the regulator is "quite open" to more than 40% foreign ownership, depending on an investor's business plan. This move aims to tap international funds for trade and project finance, as the country seeks to drive banking consolidation and lift capital requirements. International banks have expressed interest in buying into Indonesian banks, particularly in corporate banking and smaller companies, as the country is home to 250 million people.

site_title: US junk bond buyers take big risk as private deals become the norm
summary: US junk bond buyers are taking on increased risk by investing in private deals, accounting for a record 60% of all sales in 2015, up from 40% last year. These private offerings exempt borrowers from US securities laws, raising concerns among credit analysts that investors are sacrificing safeguards for higher yields. Borrowers can now sell debt as "144a for life," allowing them to change terms without unanimous consent from bondholders, leaving investors potentially underinformed and vulnerable to changes.

site_title: S'pore-EU FTA ratification can catalyse Asean-EU pact: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the ratification of the Singapore-EU FTA could catalyze an Asean-EU pact, signaling the EU's openness to business with the region. Lee emphasized the importance of diversifying Europe's engagement with Asia beyond major economies like China and India. The EU-Singapore FTA, awaiting ratification, would also encourage other regional agreements, including the Asean-EU deal.

images.alt_text: Mr Cameron and Mr Lee at the Istana. The UK remains Singapore's second-largest investment destination globally after China.

site_title: Microsoft's back on track with Windows 10
summary: Microsoft's Windows 10 operating system is set to launch on Wednesday, marking a significant improvement over its predecessor Windows 8. The new system addresses criticisms of Windows 8, including the removal of the Start Menu, by reintroducing it as a hybrid feature. The launch also includes a new browser, Microsoft Edge, and the integration of Cortana, Microsoft's voice assistant. Windows 10 offers a balance between pleasing modern consumers and business users, making it a solid upgrade for most users, with a free upgrade available for a year.

site_title: Some Japan farmers see trade pact jolt as only way to survival
summary: Japanese farmers, who make up 1.7 million of the country's workforce, are bracing for a trade pact that could lead to increased imports of grains and meats, threatening their livelihoods. Many, like Kazushi Saito, believe the pact is necessary to rescue the struggling sector, which faces a declining population, falling rice consumption, and an aging farmer population. Others, like Shigeyoshi Ota, are worried about the impact on agriculture and the potential loss of public support. The government is under pressure to introduce measures to ease the burden on agriculture, but with Japan's debt already high, public support may be difficult to gain.

images.alt_text: A farmer planting saplings in a rice field in Satsumasendai, Kagoshima prefecture early this month. Agriculture accounted for just 1.2 per cent of Japanese GDP in 2013, while the number of farmers was 1.7 million in 2014 down from 2.2 million 10 years earlier.

site_title: Umno rift seen widening despite Muhyiddin sending mixed signals
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak has widened the rift within the dominant Umno party after sacking former Deputy Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin, who had demanded comprehensive answers to the 1MDB scandal. Muhyiddin, who was replaced as deputy prime minister and education minister, has played down suggestions of a vote of no-confidence against Najib, but his supporters may link up with former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. The public has backed Muhyiddin's demands, but analysts say it remains to be seen whether the "rebel camp" can stir up enough strife to loosen Najib's grip on the party.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Three brokerages, Maybank Kim Eng, k1 Ventures, and CIMB Research, have released updates on their stock holdings. Maybank Kim Eng raised its target price for Q&M Dental Group to S$1.05 due to expected growth from Aidite's new production lines and Aoxin's potential for expansion. k1 Ventures' investment in Knowledge Universe (KUH) is expected to generate dividends, while CIMB Research maintains an "add" rating for Parkway Life Reit due to its attractive dividend yield and resilience in the competitive S-Reit market. The brokerages also highlighted potential catalysts for growth, including acquisitions and capacity expansion.

site_title: Asia apps combine technology and tradition in dating game
summary: A growing number of dating apps in Asia are combining technology with traditional values, offering group dates or chaperone services to help singles meet safely. Apps like Peekawoo, Grouvly, and Paktor provide alternatives to one-on-one dating, which is often seen as taboo in some Asian cultures. These apps aim to reduce awkwardness and promote a more relaxed atmosphere, with some even allowing users to bring friends or chaperones to meet potential partners.

images.alt_text: Developers of smartphone dating app Paktor log in to their accounts to show their Paktor profiles at their office in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore set to blaze digital innovation trail for insurance in Asia
summary: Singapore is set to lead the digital innovation trail in the insurance industry in Asia through a partnership with UK insurer Aviva. The agreement, signed by the British government and Monetary Authority of Singapore, aims to develop new business models, products, and processes to meet consumers' risk management needs. Aviva, the first insurer to embark on a full digital transformation, plans to simplify insurance products and offer discounts to customers by pre-underwriting policies based on data gathered online. The partnership is expected to promote competition, lower costs, and easier access to insurance products.

site_title: CRCT's Q2 DPU rises 5.4% (Amended)
summary: Capitaland Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 5.4% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) for Q2, driven by strong renminbi against the Singapore dollar. Gross revenue grew 6.4% to S$54.26 million, while net property income rose 5.3% to S$36.04 million. Tenants' sales at multi-tenanted malls increased 17.8% year-on-year, and shopper traffic grew 2%. The Reit manager plans to upgrade and refresh tenant mixes, and increase appeal to shoppers to enhance unitholder value.

site_title: Oil prices cut losses, rally after US inventory data
summary: Oil prices reversed earlier losses and rose on Wednesday after US crude inventories fell by 4.2 million barrels, exceeding analysts' expectations. Crude stocks are at 459.68 million barrels, up 20% so far this year. Brent futures rose 52 cents to US$53.82 a barrel, while US crude for September delivery gained 82 cents to US$48.80 a barrel. Despite a mounting global surplus, the US stock data suggests the pace of inventory build-up may reverse, supporting oil prices.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals rise amid housing revival
summary: UK mortgage approvals rose to 66,582 in June, exceeding economists' forecasts, as cheap borrowing costs fueled demand for homes. Business lending declined £5.5 billion, the largest drop on record since 2011. Net mortgage lending was £2.6 billion, the highest since July 2008. The effective interest rate on new mortgages fell to 2.56%, the lowest on record. The housing market continues to show signs of momentum, with no anecdotal evidence explaining the drop in business lending.

site_title: Barclays to step up revamp, keep dividend flat: chairman
summary: Barclays chairman John McFarlane has pledged to step up the overhaul of the British lender, while keeping its dividend flat for the year. The bank set aside an additional £600 million to compensate customers for wrongly sold payment-protection insurance, bringing the total set aside to over £2 billion. Barclays will use the funds to settle probes into currency and benchmark rigging.

site_title: Goldman adds fuel to raging bear-bull copper fire
summary: Goldman Sachs has downgraded its copper forecast, predicting a 44% drop in 2018 prices and a historic low of $4,500 per tonne by the end of 2017. The firm attributes this to a bearish outlook on Chinese demand, citing a slowing growth story and a major deleveraging cycle. However, other analysts, including Bank of America and Bloomsbury Minerals Economics, remain bearish, while Standard Chartered and Citi are among those predicting higher prices. The disagreement highlights a polarized view among commodity analysts, with no consensus on copper's future price trajectory.

site_title: US crude stockpiles fall 4.2 million barrels in latest week: EIA
summary: US crude stockpiles decreased by 4.2 million barrels in the latest week, exceeding analyst expectations by 22 times. Gasoline stocks fell by 363,000 barrels, while distillate inventories rose by 2.6 million barrels. Refinery crude runs declined by 108,000 barrels per day, and crude imports fell by 396,000 barrels per day. These changes suggest a shift in market dynamics, potentially influenced by refinery utilization rates and global market trends.

site_title: Luxury hotels offering signature spirits as a unique experience
summary: Luxury hotels are offering unique signature spirits as part of their experiences. The Hamilton Princess and Beach Club in Bermuda will introduce "The Princess Rum" in partnership with Gosling's Rum. Other hotels, such as the Omni Mount Washington Resort and the Beverly Hills Hotel, are also offering private label spirits, including bourbon and gin. These exclusive liquors are available for guests to sample at the bar or take home as a memento. This trend allows hotels to provide a distinctive experience for their guests, with prices ranging from $23 to $65.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust reports 1.56 cent DPU for Q3
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust reported a 1.56 Singapore cent DPU for its Q3, beating forecasts by 0.65%. Gross revenue was 3% lower, while net property income declined 1.2%. Despite weaker markets, Japan, Australia, and UK properties outperformed forecasts due to strong occupancies and revenue growth. The Reit's first acquisition, Sofitel Sydney Wentworth, is expected to contribute positively to its portfolio.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: SGX new boss sets his sights on bringing in big IPOs
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) CEO Loh Boon Chye has announced that the 90-minute mid-day break for traders, which was scrapped by his predecessor Magnus Bocker, will not be reinstated. Chye cited the need for continuous trading to remain an international business and financial hub as the reason. He aims to bring in bigger Initial Public Offerings (IPOs) and has launched initiatives such as a direct listings framework with China and appointed a listing head in Beijing. Despite a decline in IPO sizes, Chye believes the market will recover and attract quality companies.

images.alt_text: Mr Loh aims to tap the network he has built in the region in his new job.

site_title: Greek stock market unlikely to reopen this week due to IT glitch
summary: Greece's stock market is unlikely to reopen this week due to technical issues at local banks, according to the Athens Stock Exchange. The market had been closed for nearly five weeks under European Central Bank (ECB) approval, with restrictions limiting local investors' use of bank deposits to buy securities. The stock exchange's spokeswoman stated that the Greek banks need to resolve IT issues before reopening, leaving the market's status uncertain for Thursday and potentially Friday.

site_title: Greek prosecutor to investigate reports on Varoufakis' "Plan B"
summary: A Greek prosecutor has launched an investigation into reports on former finance minister Yanis Varoufakis' "Plan B," which included hacking into tax codes and creating a parallel payment system in case Greece left the eurozone. The probe focuses on potential law violations, such as data protection breaches and duty breaches, rather than Varoufakis himself, who enjoys parliamentary immunity. Varoufakis has denied any wrongdoing, claiming the plan was a contingency measure to harm the government, while two separate lawsuits have been filed against him.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. Meanwhile, stocks in Europe and the US fell, with banks and healthcare sectors dragging down the market. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for the second half of the year. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Economist Sachs calls for pro-environment, equitable growth
summary: World-renowned economist Jeffrey Sachs predicts a worsening global climate outlook, calling for pro-environment, equitable growth. He endorses alternative energy sources and criticizes those denying climate change. Sachs' comments come as the world grapples with economic and environmental challenges, including rising US tariffs, slowing China's GDP growth, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month. Sachs' call for sustainable growth highlights the need for urgent action to address climate change and its far-reaching consequences.

site_title: MDA asks The Middle Ground website to register under class licensing scheme
summary: The Media Development Authority (MDA) in Singapore has asked sociopolitical site The Middle Ground to register under the class licensing scheme. Registration will not affect the site's content, similar to other registered sites like The Online Citizen and The Independent. This move aims to regulate online content and ensure compliance with Singapore's laws. The decision was made without specifying the reason for the registration request.

images.alt_text: The Media Development Authority today asked sociopolitical site The Middle Ground to register under the class licensing scheme.

site_title: UK June business lending plummets by most since records began 4 years ago
summary: UK business lending plummeted by 5.487 billion pounds in June, the largest decline since records began in 2011. Despite this, mortgage approvals rose to 66,582 and lending to consumers continued to rise strongly. Lending to small and medium-sized businesses increased by 353 million pounds. The UK economy remains reliant on household spending, and the housing market appears to be heating up again.

site_title: Private equity giants hit second-quarter wall as stocks hiccup
summary: Private equity giants Blackstone, Carlyle, and Apollo reported lower second-quarter profits as US stocks slipped for the first time since 2012. The three firms, managing $688 billion in assets, saw economic net income decline due to unrealized losses and reduced sales. Carlyle's profit dropped 24% due to losses in hedge funds and energy holdings, while Apollo's profit fell 25%. The decline in US stocks and reduced sales have made it challenging for the firms to match last year's earnings, with Carlyle's chief investment officer stating that high prices are preventing new investments.

site_title: US pending home sales dip in June
summary: US pending home sales fell to 110.3 in June, down from 112.3 in May, despite a 10th consecutive year-over-year increase of 8.2%. The decline was attributed to lower sales in the Midwest and South. The National Association of Realtors expects a solid pace of home sales this summer, with a forecast of a 6.5% increase in national median existing-home price to $221,900. Existing-home sales are also expected to rise 6.6% to 5.27 million, 25% below the 2005 peak.

site_title: Sembmarine Q2 profit dives 17%, interim dividend cut
summary: Sembcorp Marine, a Singapore-based rigbuilder, has cut its interim dividend payouts for the first time in seven years due to a slump in oil prices and project deferments. The company's Q2 net profit declined 17% to S$109.23 million, with earnings per share falling 17% to 5.23 Singapore cents. Revenue dropped 9.9% to S$1.21 billion, mainly due to lower revenue recognition from rig projects. Analysts attribute the decline to rig deferments and delays, with some expressing concerns about potential further deferments of drilling rigs.

site_title: Greece expects debt reduction after November: PM
summary: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras expects debt reduction from international creditors after a November assessment of reforms under its new bailout obligations. This reduction is contingent upon the successful implementation of reforms. Tsipras stated that the pledge for debt reduction will be made after the first review, set to take place in November.

site_title: Hounded by left, Tsipras vows 'thus far, no further'
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has vowed that his government will not implement reform measures beyond those agreed with lenders at a eurozone summit, amid a revolt within his left-wing Syriza party over the tougher terms. Tsipras faces a tough central committee session on Thursday, with many activists angry over his acceptance of the bailout terms. The decision comes after voters rejected similar terms in a July 5 referendum.

site_title: Greece's Tsipras, hounded by left, vows "thus far and no further"
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras vowed to implement agreed-upon bailout terms, rejecting calls from his left-wing party to go beyond the deal. Tsipras faces a tough central committee session amid pressure from creditors to include unpopular reforms.
