The European Commission has expressed satisfaction with the bailout talks, but critics, including former finance minister Yanis Varoufakis, continue to voice opposition. Tsipras warned that if he loses parliamentary support, he may call early elections, and suggested an emergency party congress could be held in September.

site_title: Twitter shares tumbles amid fresh doubts on growth
summary: Twitter shares plummeted 13% to $31.82, the lowest level in over a year, amid doubts over growth prospects. The company reported a 61% revenue jump to $502 million, but a sluggish increase in users, with its core user base growing by only 2 million. Active US users remained flat, sparking concerns about the platform's ability to drive daily engagement and usage. Analysts warn that Twitter's inability to break into the mass market and monetize its user growth may pose long-term challenges.

site_title: SIA's Q1 profit soars as losses from associate firms decline
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a net profit of S$91.2 million for Q1 2015, up from S$34.8 million last year, due to lower losses from associated companies. Revenue inched up 1.4% to S$3.73 billion, while operating profit rose to S$111.4 million. Shares of losses from joint ventures, however, increased to S$700,000. The airline expects yields to remain under pressure and expects fuel hedging losses in the July-September quarter.

site_title: Thailand to sign first phase of Dawei development next week
summary: Thailand will sign a $1.7 billion deal to develop the first phase of the Dawei Industrial Zone in Myanmar next week. The 250-sq-km deep-sea port and petrochemical hub will link Thailand's southern economic corridor and help the country enter the global supply chain. The first phase, spanning 27 square kilometers, will include a road construction project from Dawei to Kanchanaburi province. Italian Thai Development Pcl and Rojana Industrial Park will develop the project, which aims to upgrade Thailand into a developed nation.

site_title: IMF: China 'strong enough' to handle market turmoil
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde stated that China is "strong enough" to handle market turmoil, citing the country's resilient economy. Despite a 11% drop in the Shanghai stock exchange, China's stock market is up 80% from a year ago. Lagarde praised China's efforts to restrain steep daily falls and maintain liquidity, while noting the country's significant economic reforms. The turmoil is unlikely to disrupt China's efforts to include its renminbi in the IMF's special lending currency, the SDR.

site_title: GlaxoSmithKline beats profit forecasts despite Advair hit, lower margins
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) reported a 9% decline in core earnings per share in the second quarter, despite beating profit forecasts due to a hit from lower sales of lung drug Advair and lower profit margins. The company has undergone a business overhaul, including selling marketed cancer drugs and buying vaccines. GSK reiterated its forecast for a high-teens percentage decline in 2015 earnings and is under pressure to deliver a promised recovery. The company's research pipeline and HIV business were bright spots, with sales rising 6% to £5.9 billion.

site_title: Greece did not seek more funding from ECB on Wed: sources
summary: Greece did not request an increase in Emergency Liquidity Assistance (ELA) from the European Central Bank, indicating that banks are maintaining a cash buffer. The ECB's cap on ELA remains at around 91 billion euros. This development is seen as a positive sign for the Greek economy and domestic lenders. Capital controls, limiting withdrawals to 420 euros per week, may need to stay in place until a bailout package is finalized and banks receive their recapitalization funds, now scheduled for late August.

site_title: Lufthansa to offer business-class upgrades with economy bookings
summary: Lufthansa is introducing a new strategy to offer business-class upgrades to passengers who book economy class tickets, with customized offers via email, web page, and check-in. The airline aims to use data and technology to personalize the experience and create a sense of loyalty among frequent flyers. The move is part of Lufthansa's efforts to boost revenue as low-cost airlines and long-haul carriers compete for market share. The service will be rolled out for European flights starting from October, with the option to upgrade on long-haul flights as well.

site_title: Russia's Putin says opposes MH17 tribunal ahead of UN vote
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin expressed opposition to the creation of an international tribunal to prosecute those responsible for downing Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 in 2014. The tribunal is co-sponsored by the Netherlands and aims to hold pro-Russian separatists in east Ukraine accountable. Moscow denies involvement, and Putin's statement indicates potential blockage of UN moves on the proposal. A UN vote on the tribunal is set to take place, with Kiev and many Western countries accusing Russia of obstruction.

site_title: Outside auditors should check bank capital, UK industry body says
summary: A UK industry body, the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales, recommends that outside auditors check bank capital ratios to restore investor trust. The Bank of England's Prudential Regulation Authority asked the ICAEW to examine how independent scrutiny can work in practice. Currently, capital ratios are not fully audited, despite being a key measure of a bank's health. The ICAEW is launching a public consultation to explore how independent scrutiny can enhance the credibility of these ratios. This move aims to address concerns about the reliability of bank capital ratios.

site_title: Greek PM says may have to call early election
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras stated he may call an early election if he does not secure a parliamentary majority. He emphasized his preference for avoiding elections but acknowledged the need to proceed if necessary. This comes amid ongoing challenges facing Greece's government.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: Singapore's train breakdown on July 7, 2015, was caused by a weak electrical resistance in the third rail insulator. DBS Bank launched Singapore's first US dollar benchmark covered bond. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed support for an EU-Asean free trade agreement. Singapore and the UK signed an agreement to lead the digital revolution in Asian insurance. The local market closed 0.09% higher on Wednesday, awaiting US Federal Reserve meeting hints on rate hikes.

site_title: Iran oil minister hails new cooperation with Total: Shana
summary: Iran's Oil Minister Bijan Zanganeh announced a new chapter of cooperation with French energy company Total, aiming to develop Iranian oil fields. This cooperation was agreed upon after a meeting between Zanganeh and France's Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius in Tehran.

site_title: US: Wall St opens little changed ahead of Fed statement
summary: US stocks opened little changed on Wednesday ahead of the Federal Reserve statement, with the Dow Jones rising 18.7 points to 17,648.97, the S&P 500 gaining 2.97 points to 2,096.22, and the Nasdaq adding 10.58 points to 5,099.79. The moves were influenced by hopes that Beijing could stabilize its markets and come ahead of the Fed's statement.

site_title: Dutch PM appeals to Putin ahead of MH17 tribunal vote at UN
summary: Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte made an urgent appeal to Russian President Vladimir Putin ahead of a UN Security Council vote on a resolution to try those responsible for shooting down Malaysia Airlines flight MH17. The resolution, backed by Malaysia, the Netherlands, Australia, Ukraine, and Belgium, would establish an international tribunal. Russia remains opposed, favoring an ongoing Dutch-led investigation instead, and is likely to veto the resolution. Rutte addressed Russia's concerns, emphasizing the need for a tribunal before determining facts and charges to prevent politicization.

site_title: Prince Ali says "Platini is not good for Fifa"
summary: Prince Ali Bin Al Hussein criticized Michel Platini, a potential FIFA president candidate, saying he is "not good for football." The Jordanian prince, who lost the FIFA presidency to Sepp Blatter in May, believes FIFA needs new, independent leadership to stop the practice of back-room deals. Prince Ali plans to consult with football federations to determine what is best for the sport. He stated that football fans and players deserve better than the current leadership, which is engulfed in scandal.

site_title: Nestle India reports Q2 loss as noodle scare hits sales
summary: Nestle India reported a net loss of 644 million rupees in its Q2, down from a profit of 2.88 billion rupees last year, due to a 20% decline in sales following the Maggi noodle recall over safety concerns. The company faces a nationwide recall of 27,400 tonnes of noodles and has appealed against the ban in court. Nestle maintains the noodles are safe, but the reputational crisis has hit sales, with one-off costs of 4.52 billion rupees reported in the quarter.

site_title: Hermes to probe, punish 'cruelty' to crocs used for handbags
summary: Hermes is investigating claims of cruelty at farms supplying crocodile and alligator skins for its luxury handbags. Rights group PETA published disturbing images of animals living in cramped concrete pits before being "cruelly hacked" to death. Hermes said it imposes high standards on its partners and will punish any proven negligence. Singer Jane Birkin requested her name be removed from the iconic crocodile skin Birkin bag due to the allegations, but Hermes maintains their friendship and trust.

site_title: Singapore shares close 2.91 points higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 2.91 points to 3,284 on Wednesday, with the market finishing 0.09% higher. The US Federal Reserve meeting's hints of rate hikes in September contributed to the gains. About 1.98 billion shares changed hands, with Stratech Group being the most actively traded stock. Losers outnumbered gainers 230 to 184.

site_title: Oil prices fall in longest decline in a year
summary: Oil prices fell for the sixth consecutive day, their longest decline in a year, due to a global oversupply and a weaker dollar. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries produced more oil than demand in the second quarter, contributing to the decline. Oil prices rebounded slightly after US commercial crude stocks fell last week, but the inventory level of 462 million barrels remains high, indicating a significant oversupply.

site_title: Opec's rivals resisting price pain signal oil losses to Citi
summary: Oil supplies outside Opec are holding up despite falling prices, signaling a further decline in crude prices before global markets rebalance. Citigroup reports that production from Brazil, Russia, Canada, and the North Sea has increased this year, while Iran and Mexico may add to the surplus. Saudi Arabia's strategy to tackle a global glut by pressuring non-Opec supplies is proving ineffective, with Brent crude futures expected to fall to new lows. Investment cutbacks in oil and gas projects may eventually support Saudi Arabia's plan, but Iran's potential return to the market could derail it.

images.alt_text: Oil supplies outside Opec are holding up surprisingly well against collapsing prices, signaling crude has further to fall before global markets rebalance, according to Citigroup Inc.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 0.71 point to close at 1,698.99, ending lower. 1.36 billion lots valued at RM1.75 billion were traded, with 444 gains and 371 losses.

site_title: Singapore Exchange's Q4 profit jumps 24.3% to S$96.22m
summary: Singapore Exchange reported a 24.3% year-on-year rise in net profit to S$96.22 million for Q4 2015, driven by a 25% increase in revenue to S$215.61 million. The full-year net profit rose 8.8% to S$348.61 million. The board proposed a final dividend of 16 cents per share, payable on Oct 9.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks snap 3-day slide, support measures anticipated
summary: China stocks ended a three-day slide, recording their biggest daily gain in 1-1/2 weeks, with the CSI300 index rising 3.1% to 3,930.4. The Shanghai Composite Index gained 3.4% to 3,789.2 points. Analysts attribute the rebound to the market's rich liquidity and curbed short-selling ability. The possibility of a further rebound is seen as high, with some predicting the index could rise to 4,100 points, a level reached last Friday.

site_title: Going for Gold(man): UK bank analyst pay tops out at 71,000 pounds
summary: UK bank analysts can expect an average annual bonus of 20,000 pounds from Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, with Deutsche Bank paying the largest average salary excluding bonus at 56,000 pounds. The top three institutions, along with UBS, offer an average annual remuneration package of 71,000 pounds. Analysts can receive up to 28% of their income in bonuses, with associate and managing director figures reaching 42% and over 50%, respectively.

site_title: UK banks to hold extra capital buffer against stress, PRA says
summary: The Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) announced that UK banks will need to hold an extra capital buffer against stress, ensuring they meet minimum capital requirements. The PRA buffer will be imposed when a bank's risk management and governance is deemed "significantly weak." This assessment will be informed by stress tests and will only kick in when existing buffers are deemed insufficient. The extra requirement aims to enhance financial stability and continuity in the provision of key services. The PRA will use its discretion to set Pillar 2 requirements, capturing risks specific to each bank's business model.

images.alt_text: UK banks will need to have capital to cover losses that occur in situations of extreme stress, ensuring that they continue to meet minimum capital requirements, according to the Bank of England.

site_title: UK July retail sales growth slows, outlook weakens: CBI
summary: UK retail sales growth slowed in July, with the CBI distributive trades survey's retail sales balance falling to +21 from +29 in June. Clothing sales rose at the fastest annual rate since January, but food sales were flat and shoe sales fell. The outlook for August sales is also weak, with the index dropping to a two-year low of +13. Retailers are finding conditions challenging, despite a strong UK economy outlook.

site_title: Malaysian probe into fund scandal stalls after PM sacks deputy
summary: Malaysia's parliamentary investigation into 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) scandal has been put on hold after Prime Minister Najib Razak sacked his deputy, Muhyiddin Yassin, amid allegations of extensive graft. The investigation, led by Public Accounts Committee chairman Nur Jazlan Mohamed, will be halted until a new PAC line-up is announced in October. Najib has denied taking personal gain from the scandal, but opposition leaders are demanding answers and calling for British Prime Minister David Cameron to bring up the issue in talks with Najib. The move has widened cracks in the ruling party, with some leaders warning that it could threaten the UMNO's grip on politics.

images.alt_text: A Malaysian parliamentary investigation into a graft scandal at a state investment fund embroiling Prime Minister Najib Razak has been put on hold as cracks in the ruling party appeared to widen on Wednesday.

site_title: Microsoft launches much-awaited Windows
summary: Microsoft launched Windows 10 at midnight on July 29, 2015, as a free upgrade for users of Windows 7, 8.1, and Windows Phone 8.1. The new operating system aims to work across laptops, desktops, and smartphones, part of CEO Satya Nadella's strategy to regain market share in the tablets and mobile arena. Windows 10 will generate revenue through search and gaming capabilities, according to CFO Amy Hood.

site_title: Nokia launches virtual reality camera
summary: Nokia has unveiled a virtual reality camera, the first from its digital media solutions business, designed for 3D movies and games with virtual reality headsets. The spherical camera takes 360-degree video and audio with eight sensors and microphones. This is part of Nokia's restructuring efforts after selling its mobile phone business to Microsoft and its proposed acquisition of Alcatel-Lucent. Nokia plans to return to the phone business and sell its navigation business HERE. The company expects virtual reality experiences to enhance communication and storytelling.

site_title: Platini to stand for Fifa president: UEFA
summary: Michel Platini, UEFA president, has announced his candidacy for the presidency of FIFA, following weeks of speculation. Platini, a 60-year-old Frenchman, has been a vocal opponent of Sepp Blatter's regime, which has been marred by corruption scandals. Platini has the verbal support of four confederations and has called for reform of the governing body. Candidates must be confirmed by five member nations and cleared by the ethics committee to stand. The election is set for February 26, 2016.

site_title: Malaysia hits back at domestic critics of Pacific trade pact
summary: Malaysia's trade minister Mustapa Mohamed defended the country's participation in the Trans-Pacific Partnership, addressing concerns over the pact's impact on state-owned enterprises and policies favoring ethnic Malays. He emphasized the need for flexibility in managing these enterprises and maintaining bumiputra preferences in government procurement. Malaysia will scrap tariffs on goods, open new markets, and safeguard access to affordable medicines and rice. Failing to join the pact could result in lost foreign investment and a disadvantage in shaping trade rules, according to Mustapa.

site_title: Sing Investments & Finance reports 1.4% dip in Q2 profit
summary: Sing Investments & Finance reported a 1.4% dip in Q2 profit, with a net profit of S$2.66 million. Interest income and hiring charges increased 24.3%, while interest expense rose 51%. Net interest income and hiring charges were 8.2% higher. Income before operating expenses was 6.8% higher than the previous year.

site_title: Alibaba cloud unit sets sights on Amazon in US$1 billion global push
summary: Alibaba's cloud computing arm, Aliyun, is investing $1 billion over three years to challenge Amazon's lucrative Web Services division globally. The investment will establish new data centers in the Middle East, Singapore, Japan, and Europe, with partnerships with telecom and enterprise technology providers. Aliyun aims to overtake Amazon in four years, leveraging its technological maturity and existing customer base in China. With a market share of over 20% in China, Aliyun seeks to expand its presence and compete with Amazon, Microsoft, and IBM in the global cloud infrastructure market.

site_title: Japan set to trim budget by more than US$2b: IOC chief
summary: Japan is set to trim its Olympic budget by more than $2 billion after scrapping a proposed futuristic stadium. The International Olympic Committee (IOC) chief, Thomas Bach, stated that construction costs in Japan have significantly increased, leading to the decision. The Tokyo organisers have made $1.7 billion in savings and are now expected to spend around $2.8 billion on new venues. Japan plans to launch a new tender for a cheaper stadium, with the aim of completing construction early next year for the 2020 Games. The IOC will monitor the development of the new stadium to ensure it meets "state of the art" standards.

site_title: Japanese butter on the table in Pacific trade talks
summary: Japan is struggling with a severe butter shortage, prompting emergency imports to fill the gap, amid concerns over the country's protected agricultural sector. Critics say the issue highlights a broader problem with Japan's command economy approach, which prevents farmers from responding flexibly to demand. The shortage has sparked public protests and is a key sticking point in the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade talks, with the US and other Pacific Rim countries pushing for liberalization of Japan's agricultural market.

site_title: Panasonic quarterly net profit soars more than 50%
summary: Panasonic reported a 57% increase in net profit for the first quarter of 2025, primarily due to a tax accounting change. The company's earnings rose to 59.52 billion yen, while operating profit decreased by 7% to 76.56 billion yen. Sales remained flat at 1.86 trillion yen.

site_title: Procter & Gamble names new CEO
summary: Procter & Gamble has named David Taylor, 57, as its new CEO, replacing AG Lafley. Taylor, a 35-year veteran of the company, will lead the manufacturer of popular brands like Pampers and Gillette Razors. P&G is reducing product lines and selling off some products to competitors, with its net profit falling 17% to $2.2 billion in the last quarter. The company will publish its second-quarter results on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close 0.47% higher
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.47% to 24,619.45 on Wednesday, driven by a rally in US and European markets. This followed a three-day sell-off in Shanghai, which rebounded strongly. The Hang Seng index gained 115.51 points on a turnover of HK$115.27 billion.

site_title: Sembmarine posts 17% drop in Q2 earnings
summary: Sembcorp Marine reported a 17% year-on-year drop in net profit to S$109.23 million for the second quarter, with revenue falling 9.9% to S$1.21 billion. The drop was attributed to lower revenue recognition from rig projects. However, the company noted that higher revenue recognition from offshore and conversion projects, as well as ship-repair business, helped mitigate the decline. Earnings per share fell to 5.23 Singapore cents, and the group declared an interim dividend of four Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Hong Kong stock exchange to slash Stock Connect fees
summary: The Hong Kong stock exchange plans to slash fees for trading mainland China shares via Stock Connect, effective August 3, subject to approval from regulators. The new rates include reduced handling and transfer fees, with the transfer fee waived for six months. The move aims to boost trading volumes, which have declined following a sell-off in mainland China markets.

site_title: SpiceJet in talks with Boeing, Airbus for US$11 billion deal
summary: SpiceJet Ltd is in talks with Boeing Co and Airbus Group SE to purchase over 100 single-aisle jets worth around $11 billion at list prices. The deal, if signed, would be the airline's largest-ever plane order. SpiceJet Chairman Ajay Singh mentioned the possibility of a deal during the current financial year, with Airbus A320neo and Boeing 737 Max aircraft being considered. The airline's shares rose 5.6% following the announcement, marking its highest intraday level in two years.

site_title: Alibaba cloud unit sets sights on Amazon in US$1b global push
summary: Alibaba's Aliyun cloud computing unit is investing $1 billion to expand globally, targeting Amazon's lucrative Web Services division. The move aims to challenge Amazon's 28% global cloud infrastructure market share. Aliyun plans to set up data centers in the Middle East, Singapore, Japan, and Europe, and strike partnerships with telecom and enterprise technology providers. Alibaba's president, Simon Hu, predicts the company can overtake Amazon in four years, leveraging its technological maturity and market presence in China.

images.alt_text: China's Alibaba Group Holding Ltd said on Wednesday it would invest US$1 billion into its Aliyun cloud computing arm to challenge Amazon.com Inc's lucrative Web Services division, opening a global front in the battle between the two e-commerce giants.

site_title: NTUC pushes to better represent PMEs
summary: NTUC, Singapore's largest labour union, is establishing a new leadership group to better represent professionals, managers, and executives (PMEs) in the workforce. The move aims to increase the effectiveness of union leaders in recruiting, organizing, and engaging PMEs. This push is part of NTUC's efforts to expand its membership beyond blue-collar workers and become a more inclusive and representative union.

images.alt_text: Unions have always championed the interests of the working class, especially blue collar workers.

site_title: Indonesia regulator open to higher foreign stakes in local banks
summary: Indonesia's financial regulator is open to increasing foreign ownership in local banks, potentially above the current 40% limit. Chairman Muliaman Hadad stated the regulator is willing to consider higher stakes for investors who can demonstrate a business plan to support trade and project finance. International banks, including Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, have expressed interest in buying stakes in Indonesian lenders. The move aims to drive banking consolidation and tap international funds to support trade and project finance in the country.

site_title: Japan carrier ANA says quarterly profit more than doubles
summary: Japanese carrier ANA reported a net profit of US$68 million for the April-June quarter, more than doubling from the same period last year. The company's operating profit soared to 16.7 billion yen, driven by strong results in its international business due to a weak yen. ANA left its full-year forecast unchanged, expecting a net profit of 52 billion yen. Revenue increased 7.0% to 413.9 billion yen.

site_title: SMRT says it will not compromise safety as it identifies cause of July 7 massive rail disruption
summary: SMRT has identified the cause of the July 7 rail disruption: a contaminated third rail insulator. The Land Transport Authority confirmed that the insulator's contamination led to a power trip, causing the breakdown of the North-South and East-West lines. SMRT has stated it will not compromise safety in addressing the issue.

images.alt_text: Investigations have pinpointed the cause of the July 7 massive rail disruption to a third rail insulator that was contaminated, the Land Transport Authority said on Wednesday (July 29).

site_title: Ratification of EU-Singapore FTA would encourage EU-Asean trade deal: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that ratification of the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (FTA) would signal the EU's openness to business and encourage an EU-Asean trade deal. The agreement, which Singapore is the EU's largest commercial partner in Asean, has been awaiting ratification since last year's negotiations. Lee believes that a successful EU-Singapore FTA would pave the way for a potential Asean-EU deal, which would diversify Europe's engagement with Asia and tap into the region's growing middle class and resources.

site_title: German consumer morale steadies going into August
summary: German consumer morale has steadied ahead of August, remaining unchanged at 10.1 points. Higher income expectations offset concerns about the Greece debt deal's impact on the German economy. Business confidence rose in July, while household optimism about future income reached a 1990 high due to low inflation and strong pay hikes. However, shoppers feel less willing to make purchases due to waning optimism about the overall economic outlook. The steady consumer sentiment indicator contrasts with a weakening German economy, which grew 0.3% at the start of the year.

site_title: Chinese airport closed after arson attack aboard plane
summary: A Chinese airport was closed after an arson attack on a Shenzhen Airlines flight from Taizhou to Guangzhou, injuring two passengers. A man boarded the plane with a knife, lighter, and gasoline, setting fire to a curtain and newspapers in the first class cabin. The arsonist was restrained by passengers and crew before the plane landed. Authorities sacked two aviation officials and set up a blacklist for unruly air travelers. The airport was temporarily closed due to "severe safety risks."

site_title: Nintendo swings to profit in April-June, sales up 21%
summary: Nintendo reported a net profit of $67 million for the April-June period, reversing a loss of $9.92 billion a year earlier. The company attributed the profit to a jump in console sales and a weaker yen. Nintendo expects to book a net profit of $35 billion on $57 billion in sales for the fiscal year ending March 2016.

site_title: Greek stock market to stay shut Wednesday: securities regulator
summary: Greece's stock market remains closed on Wednesday due to a lack of a ministerial decree to resume trading. The Athens Stock Exchange has been shut since June 29, following the government's closure of banks and imposition of capital controls. The market may reopen on Wednesday or Thursday, pending approval from the ECB, according to the securities regulator.

site_title: Bank of England may toughen stress tests as economy rallies
summary: The Bank of England may adjust its stress tests to better reflect the cyclical nature of the economy, using more severe tests during economic booms and softer tests during downturns. Deputy Governor Jon Cunliffe said the current approach could be "countercyclically" adjusted to address risks in the financial system. This shift in approach comes as regulators examine potential crises outside the banking system, such as insurers and asset managers, and consider broader macroprudential regulation.

site_title: Europe: Shares climb at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the open on Wednesday, driven by strong earnings updates from companies. London's FTSE 100 gained 0.63% to 6,596.47 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.67% to 11,249.30 points. The CAC 40 in Paris advanced 0.58% to 5,006.01 points. The gains come ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy statement and amid US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Seoul: Shares erase gains to turn lower; won gains for 3rd session
summary: Seoul shares erased early gains, closing at 2,037.86 points, due to pharmaceutical shares' decline. Hanmi Pharma Co Ltd's 18.4% drop contributed to the slide. The South Korean won rose 0.6% to 1,158.4 ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy decision, marking its third consecutive gain.

site_title: Barclays says to speed up cost cutting, asset sales
summary: Barclays has announced plans to accelerate cost-cutting and asset sales under its new chairman, John McFarlane. The bank aims to cut costs to mid-50s of income and non-core assets to £20 billion by 2017. Following the departure of its CEO, Barclays reported a 12% increase in adjusted pretax profit to £1.85 billion in the second quarter, beating analyst forecasts. The bank also took an additional £850 million provision for UK customer compensation due to mis-sold insurance products.

site_title: Update: Weak resistance of third rail insulator 'root cause of July 7 train breakdown'
summary: The massive train breakdown on July 7, 2015, which affected 250,000 commuters, was caused by the weak electrical resistance of a third rail insulator. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) and SMRT Corp have determined that the intermittent tripping of the rail power system at multiple locations was due to this weak resistance. The incident was triggered by a confluence of factors, including water dripping onto the third rail cover near an insulator, which reduced the effectiveness of the insulator.

site_title: Update: Singapore to work with UK for secure cyberspace
summary: Singapore has signed a memorandum of understanding with the UK Cabinet Office to work together on securing their cyberspace. The agreement focuses on four key areas: enhancing responses to cybersecurity incidents, sharing best practices, and improving collaboration between computer emergency response teams. The partnership aims to strengthen cybersecurity measures and protect both countries' digital assets.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end 0.13% down
summary: Japanese stocks fell 0.13% on Wednesday, as tech firms took a hit, with factory robotics giant Fanuc plummeting over 10% after cutting its profit forecast. The Nikkei 225 index fell 25.98 points to 20,302.91, while the Topix index rose 0.27% to 1,633.94.

site_title: Rollercoaster China stock market has more room to drop
summary: China's volatile stock market has dropped 8.48% in the biggest decline in eight years, sparking concerns about the government's management and the economy's health. Analysts predict the market has more room to drop, with some expecting a 20% decline to 2,800 points. The government's intervention, including banning short-selling and setting up a war chest to buy stocks, is seen as a temporary measure to stabilize the market. However, the long-term impact of the government's exit from the market remains uncertain, with some warning of a potential "Great Depression" due to the market's volatility.

site_title: Nomura profit more than triples on brokerage commissions, fees
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc. reported a first-quarter profit of 68.7 billion yen, more than tripling from the previous year, driven by a surge in brokerage commissions and investment-banking fees. The company's strategy to encourage more people to invest their savings is paying off, with Japanese stocks in their fourth year of gains. Nomura's retail clients were tapped for a Toyota Motor Corp and Sony Corp IPO, and the firm is managing an IPO for Japan Post Holdings Co. Analysts expect the favorable stock market environment to benefit Nomura, with large deals incentivizing depositors to shift their cash into investments.

images.alt_text: Nomura Holdings Inc's first-quarter profit more than tripled as a surge in brokerage commissions and investment-banking fees outweighed a drop in trading income.

site_title: DBS opens books for first Singapore's covered bond
summary: DBS Bank launched Singapore's first US dollar benchmark covered bond, the Bayfront Covered Bonds, with an initial price guidance of 40bp over mid-swaps. The three-year issue is expected to score Aaa from Moody's and AAA from Fitch. DBS is the first Singaporean issuer to set up a covered bond programme, and the first from South-East Asia to sell covered bonds in the offshore market. The issue was marketed by DBS, Deutsche Bank, JP Morgan, and Societe Generale, with Barclays and Citigroup as bookrunners.

site_title: Virgin Australia whittles back annual loss with cost cuts
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd reported a narrowed annual net loss of A$93.8 million, down from A$261.8 million the previous year, due to cost cuts and limiting seat capacity to boost demand and fares. The airline ended a price war with Qantas Airways Ltd and is now focused on improving profitability. Virgin Australia's Tigerair Australia low-cost unit also narrowed its quarterly loss to A$9.8 million from A$25.8 million. Shares rose 0.6% following the announcement.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump most in two weeks on brighter China, US outlook
summary: Australian shares surged 0.7% to a 3% gain for the month, the largest since March, driven by a reprieve from the Chinese equities correction and an upbeat US economic outlook. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 39.5 points to 5,624.2. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index also rose 0.4% to 5,870.8. The rally was seen as investors seeking bargains after recent market volatility.

site_title: Indonesian airline Garuda swings to profit in H1, shares jump
summary: Indonesian airline Garuda Indonesia posted a net profit of $27.7 million for the first half of 2015, reversing a $203 million loss from the same period last year. The airline's shares rose 7.3% due to cost reductions, fuel and currency hedging, and a network restructuring. Garuda signed a $600 million agreement with GE Aviation to equip 50 planes, and aims to raise fuel hedging to 50% by the end of the year. The airline's CEO attributed the turnaround to cost reductions and fuel price declines.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down, flat panels drag
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.6% on Wednesday, led by a decline in flat panels, with Innolux Corp and AU Optronics Corp experiencing sharp drops due to caution on second-half business. The electronics subindex sank 0.7%, while the financials subindex lost 0.3%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$31.447 per US dollar. The decline follows a 0.3% gain in the previous session.

site_title: Gold wedged below US$1,100 ahead of Fed meeting outcome
summary: Gold prices rose to just below US$1,100 an ounce on Wednesday ahead of the US Federal Reserve's meeting, where investors expect more signals on the timing of an interest rate increase. The expected rate hike could happen as early as September, potentially pushing gold prices lower. Global gold demand shrank to its lowest since 2009 in the second quarter, and holdings of the largest gold-backed ETF were unchanged at 21.87 million ounces.

site_title: Slumping Macau calls in superheroes as graft fight hits casinos
summary: Macau, a Chinese enclave, is facing a slump in gaming revenue due to a corruption crackdown by President Xi Jinping, which has scared off high-spending VIP customers. The territory's casino owners, including billionaire Francis Lui, are battling stringent government regulations and expanding their operations in an effort to attract new customers. Despite this, Lui remains optimistic, citing China's consumer revolution and the potential for Macau to become a global entertainment hub. The city's gaming revenue plummeted 37% to $15.2 billion in the first half of the year, and some investors see opportunity in the situation, with Galaxy's shares jumping 3.8 percentage points to 22.2% of the market.

site_title: LG Electronics Q2 profit slumps 60% on weak TV, smartphone sales
summary: LG Electronics reported a 60% slump in Q2 profit to 244 billion won, its weakest three-month profit since 2013. The company's TV division suffered a quarterly operating loss, while its mobile communications division eked out a 0.2 billion won profit due to shrinking smartphone shipments. Analysts have slashed forecasts for the firm, citing weak global TV sales and emerging market currencies. LG expects to recover in the third quarter with new products and marketing initiatives, but its stock has touched its lowest level in over 12 years amid growing business concerns.

site_title: Key facts about the TPP trade alliance
summary: The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) is a proposed 12-country trade bloc covering 40% of the global economy, aiming to promote free trade, labor rights, and environmental protection. The US, Japan, Australia, and Canada are key players, with the Obama administration seeking to counter China's growing influence. Negotiations have been secretive and contentious, with concerns over patent protections, food safety, and investor rights. The pact's success depends on Japan's participation and the US's ability to address its critics, with potential benefits including expanded markets and economic growth, but also risks of watered-down regulations and sovereignty challenges.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks open 0.73% higher
summary: Chinese stocks opened 0.73% higher on Wednesday, rebounding from a 11% plunge in the past three sessions. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 26.82 points to 3,689.82, while the Shenzhen Composite Index added 1.31% to 2,139.39. Concerns over another market rout easing contributed to the rebound.

site_title: Oil prices fall on oversupply concerns, weaker dollar support
summary: Oil prices fell in Asian trade on Wednesday due to concerns over global oversupply, outweighing a likely larger-than-expected draw in US crude stocks and a weakening dollar. OPEC production figures showed members produced 3 million barrels more than daily demand in the second quarter, citing "glut" as a concern. Brent futures fell 14 cents to $53.16, while US crude dropped 12 cents to $47.86, amid anticipation of a US Federal Reserve meeting that could confirm a rise in interest rates.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.38% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.38% in the first few minutes of trading on Wednesday, following global market gains. The Hang Seng Index increased 93.72 points to 24,597.66. The move tracks gains across global markets after a sell-off at the start of the week.

site_title: Toshiba to cut interim CEO pay by 90% on accounting scandal
summary: Toshiba Corp announced a 90% cut in the monthly salary of interim CEO Masashi Muromachi for the next two months, following revelations of improper accounting. This includes a 50% cut on top of the existing 40% reduction. The company also plans to hire more independent directors and consider additional measures at an extraordinary shareholders' meeting in September.

images.alt_text: Toshiba Corp said it would slash its interim chief executive's monthly salary for the next two months by 90 per cent, including previously announced cuts, following revelations of improper accounting at the Japanese conglomerate.

site_title: New Zealand central bank says dairy slump could worsen
summary: New Zealand's central bank warned that a dairy slump could worsen, potentially forcing interest rates down. Reserve Bank of New Zealand Governor Graeme Wheeler cited high milk powder stockpiles, increased global milk supply, and trade diversion issues as factors contributing to downward pressure on dairy prices. The bank's monetary policy settings aim to stimulate the economy, with interest rates expected to fall to 2.5% by year's end. Dairy industry job losses have already begun, with Fonterra announcing 523 job cuts this month.

site_title: For dating apps in Asia, love by numbers or chaperone
summary: In Asia, dating apps are shifting from traditional one-on-one meetings to group dates or chaperone services, catering to the region's cultural preferences for close family ties and social etiquette. Apps like Peekawoo and Grouvly, popular in Hong Kong and the Philippines, organize group meetups, often with a chaperone, to facilitate social interactions. This approach allows users to meet new people in a more comfortable and familiar environment, reducing the stigma associated with meeting strangers in bars or one-on-one. The trend is seen as a sign of adaptability in the face of cultural differences, with users embracing group dates as a way to meet new people and potentially find love.

site_title: 'Halo effect' dims as Indonesia consumer confidence in tailspin
summary: Indonesia's consumer confidence plummeted 25.8 points in the first half of 2015, the steepest decline in Asia, according to a MasterCard survey. The country's economic slowdown, fueled by weak government spending and a stifling bureaucracy, has led to a cyclical downturn. Despite a moderate increase in motorbike sales, the outlook for the Indonesian stock market and currency have deteriorated, with the benchmark Jakarta Composite Index slumping 9.8% and the rupiah losing 8% this year.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts posts Q2 DPSS of 2.25 cents, down 10%
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a Q2 DPSS of 2.25 cents, down 10% from the same period last year. Gross revenue grew 3% to S$39 million, driven by newly acquired Japan hotels and revenue increases at Maldives resorts. Net property income rose 0.9% to S$31.6 million. Income available for distribution decreased 9.2% to S$24.6 million due to the exclusion of Japan hotel contributions and higher financing costs. Despite unfavorable market conditions, the company's geographically diversified portfolio generated stable hotel earnings.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher after strong showing in US
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 10.59 points to 3,291.68, driven by strong gains in US markets and a rebound in European stocks following positive corporate earnings. The market opened 0.32% higher with 90.2 million shares changing hands, with Singtel, CapitaLand, and DBS leading the gainers. Traders await the US Federal Reserve's policy announcement, which could signal an interest rate increase later this year.

site_title: Japan official quitting amid Tokyo 2020 stadium row
summary: Japan's director-general of the education ministry's sports and youth bureau, Kimito Kubo, is quitting amid public anger over the Tokyo 2020 Olympic stadium's $2.0 billion price tag, nearly doubling initial costs. Kubo's resignation is seen as him taking the blame for the controversy, which sparked calls for Education Minister Hakubun Shimomura to quit instead. The stadium's design has been scrapped, and a new bidding process is underway, with a new design expected within six months.

site_title: Japan's June retail sales rise 0.9% year on year
summary: Japan's retail sales increased 0.9% year-over-year in June, exceeding the median forecast of 0.5%. This is the first time retail sales have risen in six months, suggesting a slight recovery in the economy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares opens lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.55 points to 1,698.15. The market saw 30.03 million lots traded worth RM15.03 million, with 115 gainers and 77 losers.

site_title: Amazon wants air space for delivery drones
summary: Amazon is seeking to establish separate zones for commercial drones to deliver goods to customers, proposing 200-400 feet above ground and a 100-foot buffer zone. The zones would be managed by air traffic control systems and would require drones to meet technical standards. Amazon's Prime Air project aims to introduce 30-minute parcel delivery by drones, but the proposal comes amid concerns over safety and regulations. The company has been working on its technology in secret locations, including British Columbia, Canada, and is pushing for a faster resolution to US drone regulations.

site_title: Subaru's secret: Low-paid foreign workers power an export boom
summary: Subaru's US sales have nearly doubled in the past four years, driven by the success of its Forester SUV. However, the company's export boom is largely made possible by low-paid foreign workers, mostly from Asia and Africa, who are employed on short-term contracts at the automaker's suppliers in Japan. These workers face abusive labor practices, including low wages, long working hours, and lack of insurance. Subaru's parent company, Fuji Heavy Industries, denies direct involvement in supervising working conditions, but acknowledges that suppliers are responsible for labor practices. The company's reliance on foreign labor is a result of Japan's tight labor market and strict immigration policies.

images.alt_text: Subaru's U.S. sales have almost doubled in the past four years.

site_title: GLP acquires US$4.6b logistics portfolio in US, becomes second largest US logistics property player
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) is acquiring a US$4.55 billion logistics portfolio in the US, becoming the second largest logistics property player in the country. The portfolio, comprising 58 million square feet across 20 markets, will be injected into GLP's fund management platform upon completion by November 16. GLP will fully own the portfolio and pare its stake to 10% by April next year, generating "compelling returns". The deal expands GLP's US footprint by 173 million square feet and follows its entry into the US market in February.

site_title: Singapore inks pact with UK to lead digital revolution in Asian insurance
summary: Singapore has signed an agreement with the UK to lead the digital revolution in the Asian insurance industry. The collaboration, led by British insurer Aviva, aims to develop new business models, products, and processes to meet consumers' changing needs in the digital age. The partnership will also explore options to promote competition, lower costs, and minimize barriers to digital products and distribution. Additionally, it will support FinTech start-ups with expertise, resources, and facilities. The agreement was reached during British Prime Minister David Cameron's trade mission to South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Singapore is primed to lead the way in the digital revolution in the insurance industry in Asia.

site_title: SingPost's Q1 net profit up 15.8%, boosted by one-off gains
summary: SingPost reported a 15.8% increase in Q1 net profit to S$46.6 million, driven by one-off gains from the disposal of Novation Solutions and DataPost HK. Excluding these gains, underlying net profit rose 8% to S$40.3 million. Operating profit grew 14.5% to S$57.7 million, with underlying operating profit increasing 8.3% to S$51.4 million.

site_title: iFAST's Q2 earnings rise 25% to S$3.28m
summary: iFAST's net profit rose 24.6% to S$3.28 million in Q2, driven by 21.9% revenue growth to S$23.2 million. The company received regulatory approval to distribute bonds and ETFs in Singapore and entered into an agreement to acquire Winfield Securities Limited in Hong Kong. iFAST also applied for a China investment platform license and proposed an interim cash dividend of 0.68 cents per share. The firm's expansion into China and acquisition of Winfield Securities are pending regulatory approval.

site_title: Twitter shares dive on word of growth challenges
summary: Twitter shares plummeted after executives warned that the company's path to mainstream popularity would be a long one, despite reporting a 61% revenue jump to $502 million in the second quarter. Co-founder Jack Dorsey stated that Twitter will take time to build a service people love, citing the need to simplify the service and improve communication of its value. The company lost $137 million in the quarter and expects revenue to range from $545 million to $560 million in the current quarter.

images.alt_text: Twitter shares hit the slide on Tuesday as executives warned that the messaging service's path to mainstream popularity would be a long one.

site_title: Asia: Stocks up as China steadies, wary of Fed
summary: Asian shares rose on Wednesday, driven by hopes that China's markets will stabilize without economic damage, despite caution ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy decision. China's CSI300 index gained 0.6%, while the Shanghai Composite rose 0.7%. Japan's Nikkei fell 0.4%, while US stocks ended with gains, with the Dow up 1.09%. Investors remain wary of a market that plummeted 8% on Monday, and the Fed is expected to keep rates unchanged this week.

site_title: Amazon moves to fuel startups for its platform
summary: Amazon has launched the Amazon Launchpad program to support startups in launching and selling their products and services through its platform. The program provides assistance with brand development, marketing, inventory management, and global expansion. Amazon is working with over 25 venture capital firms and startup accelerators to bring startups into the program, which has already helped 200 products become available in the Amazon Launchpad store. The program aims to discover unique products and learn about the inspiration behind them.

site_title: US crude oil snaps 4-day losing streak, Brent slips
summary: US crude oil prices rose 59 cents to $47.98 per barrel, snapping a four-day losing streak, on Tuesday. Brent North Sea crude dropped 17 cents to $53.30 per barrel. The rebound is attributed to a normal market rebound after recent weak economic data and a Chinese stock market plunge. Analysts fear the turmoil in China's stock market will affect demand, citing an already bearish market due to global oversupply.

site_title: Facebook co-founder, Temasek invest in Asian tech startup
summary: Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin and Singapore's state-owned investment company Temasek Holdings Pte are among the main investors in Golden Gate Ventures Fund II LP, a venture capital fund focusing on technology companies in Southeast Asia. The fund has raised US$35 million and plans to invest in early-stage companies. Temasek is attracted to the fund's access to potential investments, while Saverin's involvement is seen as a local partner for the venture. The fund has previously invested in 20 Asian companies, including Singaporean online grocery firm RedMart Ltd.

site_title: AIMS AMP Reit's Q1 DPU up 7.8% to 2.75 cents
summary: AIMS AMP Reit reported a 7.8% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.75 Singapore cents for Q1, driven by a 10.7% growth in gross revenue to S$30.3 million. The trust secured 15 new and renewal leases, maintaining a high occupancy of 96.1%. However, it expressed a cautious outlook for the industrial market, citing cost sensitivity and potential short-term impacts on occupancy and rentals.

site_title: Vietnam's Q3 GDP growth seen slowing slightly to 6.42% y-o-y: newspaper
summary: Vietnam's economy is expected to grow 6.42% in the third quarter, slightly slower than the previous period. The forecast is based on a possible US dollar rate hike and geo-political tensions affecting exports. January-July exports rose 9.5% from last year, below the government's target of 10% and 14.5% in the same period last year. The slower growth is attributed to the export-driven economy, which may face challenges from the US Federal Reserve and European debt crisis.

site_title: Stocks to watch: GLP, CRCT, AA Reit, iFast, Japfa
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) acquired a US$4.55 billion logistics portfolio in the US, becoming the second largest logistics property player within a year. China Trust (CRCT) saw a 5.4% increase in DPU to 2.73 cents for the second quarter. AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) recorded a 7.8% increase in DPU to 2.75 Singapore cents. iFAST's net profit rose 24.6% to S$3.28 million, while Japfa's net profit plummeted 86% to US$2.96 million due to lower revenue and an asset disposal.

site_title: Dr Seuss back in stores with newly discovered children's book
summary: A new Dr. Seuss book, "What Pet Should I Get?", was discovered in 2013 and released in stores on July 28, 2015, 24 years after the author's death. The book features the brother and sister characters from "One Fish Two Fish Red Fish Blue Fish" and was likely written between 1958 and 1962. It is the second Dr. Seuss book to be published posthumously, with the author having worked on many unfinished ideas, referred to as the "bone pile".

site_title: CRCT reports 5.4% rise in Q2 DPU on higher net property income
summary: Capitaland Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 5.4% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for Q2 2015, reaching 2.73 cents. This is attributed to a 5.3% rise in net property income (NPI) to S$36.0 million. The DPU for the first-half of 2015 was 5.37 cents, a 7.6% increase from the previous year. Unitholders can expect to receive their DPU for H1 on September 22, 2015.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.48% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.48% higher on Wednesday, following a five-day losing streak in US markets. The Nikkei 225 index rose 96.80 points to 20,425.69. Investors await a US Federal Reserve policy announcement that could signal an interest rate increase later this year, while the dollar strengthened to 123.58 yen.

site_title: US newspapers see more bad news, as jobs decline
summary: US newspaper employment declined 10.4% in 2014 to 32,900, the lowest level since 1978, according to the American Society of News Editors. The decline was seen across all circulation ranges, with the exception of large-circulation newspapers (up 13.98%) and small ones (up 15.9%). The job losses occurred despite a growing economy, with Ken Doctor noting that daily newspapers have consistently lost staff in good and bad economic times, and that the industry may be halving its workforce by 2017.

site_title: CIMB exec's departure adds to clouds over sukuk sales
summary: Malaysia's sukuk market faces uncertainty following the resignation of CIMB Group Holdings Bhd's Islamic unit CEO, Badlisyah Abdul Ghani, amid a probe into 1Malaysia Development Bhd. Sukuk sales dropped 36% in 2015 to a five-year low due to political uncertainty, falling commodity prices, and a looming US interest-rate increase. CIMB Islamic will need to find a replacement, and analysts predict a challenging environment for issuers, with sales potentially reaching 70% of last year's total.

site_title: Intel and Micron memory chip tuned to data driven age
summary: Intel and Micron unveiled a new memory chip technology called 3D XPoint, which they claim can "revolutionize" computing devices and applications. The non-volatile memory is 1,000 times faster and 10 times denser than NAND flash, enabling quick access to massive data sets and enabling new applications. The technology is already in production and has the potential to enhance personal computing, such as faster social media interactions and more immersive video games. Examples of benefits include real-time data analysis in healthcare and faster fraud pattern detection in finance.

site_title: UK growth up marginally on stronger services, oil output surge
summary: The UK economy experienced a 0.7% increase in gross domestic product (GDP) in the second quarter, marking a 10th straight expansion, driven by stronger services and finance, and a surge in North Sea oil output. This growth is in line with forecasts, but the recovery remains lopsided, with the services industry accounting for most of the increase. The economy's growth is expected to continue, potentially leading to higher interest rates, but concerns remain about the economy's structural issues, including weak exports and business investment.

site_title: Google loosening its ties to Google Plus
summary: Google is phasing out Google Plus features and integrating them into other services, such as Google Photos, Google Hangouts, and YouTube, in an effort to simplify its offerings. The move aims to reduce clutter and meet the demand for standalone apps, as seen in the success of Twitter's separate Vine and Periscope services. Google Plus, launched in 2011, initially gained popularity but struggled to retain users due to its connection to other services, and the company now promises to continue adding new features to the platform.

site_title: To axe or not to axe the Ex-Im?
summary: US President Barack Obama is urging Congress to fund the Export-Import Bank (Ex-Im), citing its importance in expanding US exports and creating jobs. The bank, which provides taxpayer-backed loans and guarantees to foreign companies, has been criticized by some Republicans as "corporate welfare." However, most economists argue that the bank's assistance is necessary to compete with other countries, particularly China, which has implemented its own export financing programs. The Ex-Im's supporters claim that it supports around 164,000 jobs and has returned nearly $7 billion in fees in the last two decades.

site_title: Cameron urges UK companies to grab Asean opportunities
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron urged companies to seize business opportunities in South-east Asia, particularly in Singapore, during his first major trade visit since re-election. He also called on world leaders and foreign companies to share data to combat money laundering, citing the need for greater transparency in corporate ownership. Cameron aims to sign £750 million in trade and investment deals with South-east Asian nations this week, and plans to introduce a publicly accessible central registry listing British company owners starting next year.

site_title: Russian economy decline slows, but recovery elusive
summary: Russia's economy decline has slowed, with a 4.2% year-on-year decline in June, down from 4.8% in May. The decline is attributed to a huge devaluation of the rouble and heavy government spending on anti-crisis measures. Recovery prospects are uncertain, with forecasts ranging from 0.5% to 2.3% growth next year. Analysts note that the devaluation has boosted competitiveness, but the economy's long-term prospects are limited by chronic underinvestment and reliance on commodity exports.

site_title: Twitter posts quarterly loss as revenue climbs
summary: Twitter reported a quarterly loss of $137 million, despite a 61% increase in revenue to $502 million. The company saw 15% growth in monthly active users to 316 million. CEO Jack Dorsey expressed dissatisfaction with growth in audience, citing a need to improve monetization, execution, and communication. Dorsey, who also leads Square, forecasted revenue for the current quarter to range from $545 million to $560 million, and predicted $2.2 billion to $2.27 billion in full-year revenue.

site_title: China state planner upbeat on economy, watching volatile stock market
summary: China's top economic planner, Li Pumin, expressed optimism on the economy's second-half performance, despite volatility in the stock market. The economy reported a 7% growth rate in the first half, but policymakers are concerned about channeling money into the real economy and the impact of a stock market plunge. Li emphasized that fundamentals are stabilizing and the government is prepared to support the capital market. The central bank has cut interest rates three times this year, and further easing is expected.

site_title: Why China's latest stock market plunge is good news
summary: China's stock market plunged 8.5% on Monday, its largest one-day decline since 2007. Instead of being a cause for concern, this event may be a positive development for China's economy. The plunge highlights the need for rationality to return to mainland markets, rather than relying on government interventions. According to Henry Paulson, China's capital markets have lagged behind the US, and the best way to create a modern capital market is to adopt international standards of transparency and trust. China's Communist Party should focus on creating a vibrant market system, rather than trying to control it through heavy-handed manipulation.

site_title: Cost of betting on ETF drop at record high due to China stock rout
summary: US investors face a record-high cost to bet against the Deutsche X-trackers Harvest CSI 300 China A-Shares ETF, with a 40% annualized drop needed to break even. The ETF plummeted 9.2% to $39.16, amid China's 28% decline in the Shanghai Composite Index and record volatility. Investors withdrew $401 million from the fund in the past four weeks, as the government implements measures to stem a $4 trillion market loss. The cost to short the ETF has surged, making it nearly impossible to borrow shares, with some traders saying "it's not really borrowable".

site_title: South Korea declares end to Mers outbreak
summary: South Korea has declared the effective end to the Mers outbreak that killed 36 people, triggered widespread panic and economic disruption. The government has lifted quarantine measures and urged the public to resume normal daily activities. Although the country is not yet Mers-free according to World Health Organization standards, the declaration stops short of formal confirmation. The Mers outbreak had a significant impact on the national economy, with a 40% decline in foreign visitors and a sharp drop in sales for local businesses. A stimulus package was announced to support affected businesses.

site_title: Hedge-fund billionaires bet on London again
summary: Hedge-fund billionaires, including Steven Cohen and Ken Griffin, are betting on London, driving up demand for office space in Mayfair and other districts. The city's fund industry is experiencing a rebound, with Europe attracting $12.5 billion in hedge funds in the first half of the year. This growth contrasts with the decline of Europe's biggest banks and a shortage of skilled fund managers. London's larger hedge funds manage about a third as much as those in New York, which oversee about $1.1 trillion.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust reports higher Q1 earnings for unitholders
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust reported a 5.2% increase in net profit for unitholders in the first quarter of FY2016, reaching S$2.66 million, despite a 14.2% decline in revenue to S$114.39 million. Lower fuel costs contributed to the boost, but also hurt revenue. The trust's earnings per unit dropped to 0.11 Singapore cent due to a significant increase in the unit base. Net asset value per unit tripled to S$0.363, and gearing dropped to 37% as of June 30. The trust plans to continue looking for acquisition opportunities.

site_title: MAS sets up new Financial Centre Advisory Panel
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has established a 26-member Financial Centre Advisory Panel (FCAP) to advise on asset class strategies and cross-sectoral strategies. The panel, chaired by MAS managing director Ravi Menon, will enhance dialogue and growth of Singapore's financial centre. Members include industry leaders from banks, insurance, and asset management, and will study initiatives like SkillsFuture and FinTech to boost the sector's competitiveness. The two-year term panel aims to deepen MAS's partnership with the industry to address future trends and chart strategies for Singapore's financial centre.

site_title: EU probes Disneyland Paris for alleged price discrimination
summary: The European Union is investigating Disneyland Paris for alleged price discrimination against customers from certain countries, including Britain and Germany. The park is accused of charging higher prices to non-French visitors, with prices ranging from 1,346 to 2,447 euros. This breach of EU law on fair treatment of consumers may require France to ensure Disneyland Paris complies with EU fair trading laws. The case comes as part of the European Commission's crackdown on unfair treatment of consumers, with several US firms already facing investigations.

images.alt_text: The European Union said on Tuesday it is probing whether Disneyland Paris is overcharging customers from certain countries in breach of the bloc's laws.

site_title: China wealth fund plans to buy Australia office blocks
summary: China's sovereign wealth fund, China Investment Corp (CIC), plans to buy Australia's largest office block portfolio from Morgan Stanley for $1.82 billion. This deal comes as China seeks stable assets offshore amid economic turmoil at home. The purchase, worth $200 billion, is CIC's biggest Australian investment and highlights Beijing's interest in the country's commercial property market. The deal requires approval from Australia's Foreign Investment Review Board and bodes well for the Australian government's plans for large privatisation sales.

site_title: US: Stocks rise on earnings, oil bounce
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, snapping a five-day losing streak, driven by positive earnings from UPS and a rally in petroleum-linked stocks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 189.68 points, while the S&P 500 gained 25.61 points, as oil prices stabilized. Key gainers included Intel, Micron Technology, and Amgen, while ExxonMobil, Apache, and ConocoPhillips also saw significant gains. Investors await the US Federal Reserve's policy announcement on interest rates later this week.

site_title: Thailand cuts GDP forecast to 3% this year amid fall in exports
summary: Thailand's finance ministry cut its economic growth forecast to 3.0% for 2015, its third cut this year, due to weak exports and slow demand. The country's export sector, accounting for two-thirds of the economy, is expected to shrink 4.0% this year. Despite this, the government expects clearer public investment and stronger-than-expected tourism growth to drive economic growth. However, economists warn that achieving 3% growth may be difficult due to drought and declining industrial output.

site_title: Jane Birkin asks Hermes to take name off crocodile handbag
summary: British singer Jane Birkin has asked luxury brand Hermes to remove her name from its crocodile-skin handbag due to animal rights concerns over the "cruel" methods used to make the iconic accessory. Birkin, 68, has asked Hermes to "debabatize" the Birkin Croco until better practices are implemented. Animal rights group PETA has exposed alleged cruel treatment of crocodiles on farms, including being crammed into pits and hacked to death. Birkin's decision comes after PETA called on Hermes to stop using wildlife for their skins.

images.alt_text: British singer Jane Birkin has asked luxury manufacturer Hermes to remove her name from its crocodile-skin handbag after learning of the "cruel" methods used to make the iconic accessory.

site_title: More buys than sells by global funds
summary: Global mutual funds purchased more Singapore stocks than they sold in the three months to July 22, with a net buy of S$843.5 million compared to a net sell of S$804.1 million. In the finance stocks excluding Reits, there were net buys of S$334.8 million, led by DBS Group Holdings. UOB was the top stock sold, with a volume of S$132.2 million. The data is based on transactions from top five stocks and excludes alternative investors and sovereign wealth funds.

site_title: Lian Beng posts record results, boosted by fair-value gain
summary: Lian Beng Group posted record net profit and revenue for the full year ended May 31, 2015, with a 24% jump in net profit to S$108 million and a 9.4% increase in revenue to S$747 million. The group's fair-value gain on investment properties rose 40.6% to S$52.4 million, and its share of results from associates and joint ventures increased to S$43.6 million. Lian Beng is proposing a total dividend of S$0.03 per share, a record for the company, and aims to balance its project-based construction and property development business with recurring income.

site_title: No sci-fi joke: 'killer robots' strike fear into tech leaders
summary: Artificial intelligence experts have sounded the alarm over the potential for autonomous "killer robots" to fuel ethnic cleansing and an arms race. Over 1,000 technology leaders have signed an open letter warning that the development of autonomous weapons, which use AI to select targets without human intervention, could lead to a global arms race. The letter calls for a ban on offensive autonomous weapons beyond meaningful human control, citing concerns that such systems could be used by terrorists, dictators, or warlords to carry out ethnic cleansing.

site_title: Thong Sia Building sold for S$380m
summary: The Thong Sia Building in Singapore's District 9 has been sold to Sin Capital Partners for S$380 million, or S$2,431 per square foot. The deal secured approval from over 80% of owners and will be subject to Strata Titles Board approval. The property, comprising commercial and residential space, was initially offered for sale at a minimum reserve price of S$400 million but was reduced to S$380 million. Sin Capital plans to redevelop the site, which has a land area 7.236 times larger than its existing GFA.

site_title: Toyota surges ahead as No 1 brand in Singapore
summary: Toyota surged ahead as the top brand in Singapore, with 5,299 new Toyotas registered from January to June 2015. Mercedes-Benz followed with 3,137 units, while Honda and Mazda took the third and fourth spots. The surge in Toyota's popularity was attributed to a drop in COE premiums, which led to increased demand for the brand. Showrooms were busy, with some reporting a 50-100% increase in sales and orders. The new car registration data, released by the Land Transport Authority, now breaks down by body style, providing more detailed insights into the types of cars being registered.

images.alt_text: Buyers thronged car showrooms last weekend as COE premiums slid and the Land Transport Authority (LTA) unveiled a new way of listing new-car registrations, which showed Toyota and Mercedes-Benz leading the pack of most popular brands here.

site_title: Asian buyers expect bargains when Iran oil returns to market
summary: Asian oil buyers expect to benefit from Iran's return to the global market after the lifting of western sanctions. With Iran's oil minister signaling a focus on wooing Asian customers, refiners such as Hindustan Petroleum Corp in India and Formosa Petrochemical Corp in Taiwan may increase purchases from the Persian Gulf state. The deal could lead to another price war, benefiting buyers like China, which now has more pricing negotiation leverage. Iran aims to boost shipments by 500,000 barrels a day, but initial volumes may be limited, according to Goldman Sachs.

site_title: Choa Chu Kang EC site draws 11 bids
summary: A Singapore executive condominium (EC) site along Choa Chu Kang Avenue 5 attracted 11 bids, exceeding initial forecasts of 3-7 bids. The top bid of S$295 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr) from a Qingjian Realty-led consortium was 7% above the next highest offer. Most bidders priced the site below S$250 psf ppr, reflecting the challenges facing the EC market. Analysts attribute the strong turnout to expected increases in income ceilings for eligible buyers and the site's potential for affordability.

site_title: Malaysia lets ringgit fall below level that prompted dollar peg
summary: Malaysia allows the ringgit to trade below the dollar peg level set in 1998, citing insufficient international reserves. The currency has fallen 5.1% since January due to economic growth slowdown, political uncertainty, and US interest rate hikes. Standard & Poor's maintains Malaysia's credit rating at A-, with a "stable" outlook. Economists forecast the ringgit to weaken further, potentially reaching 3.86 by end-2015 and 4.05 by end-2016.

images.alt_text: Malaysian ringgit banknotes.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Japfa's net profit for the second quarter ended June 30, 2015, dropped 86% to US$2.96 million due to lower revenue and an absence of a one-off gain from asset disposal. Core profit after tax and minority interests fell to US$14.27 million. Sincap Group's subsidiary, Shandong Luneng Taishan Mining, has been accused of misappropriation, and Global Yellow Pages is expected to report a loss for FY2015 due to non-cash impairment charges. Choo Chiang Holdings' initial public offering was 2.3 times subscribed, raising S$10.65 million.

site_title: Freeport worst metal stock as rout blunts Indonesia boon
summary: Freeport-McMoran Inc plummeted 7.5% to $11.37, its largest selloff among major metal producers, due to slumping commodity prices. The company's shares have lost 25% since failing to provide a plan to withstand plummeting prices. Despite hopes for an agreement to extend a six-month export contract with Indonesia, copper prices slid to a six-year low, and Freeport's bonds soared in value, pushing yields to 7.7%. Analysts say the contract renewal is a positive sign, but the company's long-term work status in Indonesia remains uncertain.

site_title: One-time disposal gain lifts Great Eastern
summary: Great Eastern Holdings posted a 14% year-on-year rise in second-quarter net profit to S$277.7 million, driven by a S$119.9 million gain from the sale of part of its investment in New China Life. Gross premiums fell 8% to S$1.823 billion, and profit from insurance business plummeted 39% to S$139.1 million. An interim dividend of 10 Singapore cents per share will be paid on September 2. The company attributed the slow quarter in Singapore to anticipated interest rate rises.

site_title: S'pore junk bonds best performer in region
summary: Singapore's junk bonds have been the best performers in the region, with US dollar notes gaining 7.9% this year, driven by strong institutional demand from private banks and improved debt profiles of local companies. This contrasts with Indonesia, where high-yield notes gained 3.2% and the country's default tally reached over $3 billion. The resilience of Singapore's debt market is attributed to its AAA sovereign rating and the comfort of investing in a home market, despite economic weak spots, such as a 4.6% contraction in the second quarter.

site_title: China stocks 'to fall another 14%'
summary: China's Shanghai Composite Index is expected to decline by an additional 14% over the next three weeks, according to Tom DeMark, who predicted the gauge's bottom in 2013. The index has already plunged 8.5% on Monday, and DeMark's indicators suggest a trading pattern similar to the 1929 US crash. The market's recent rally, fueled by government intervention, is deemed artificial and unsustainable, with DeMark warning that the index could "unravel" quickly if it fails to hold at 3,200.

site_title: Dollar strengthens ahead of Fed policy statement
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro and yen ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy statement on Wednesday, which may provide insight into the Fed's plan to raise its benchmark federal funds rate this year. Investors are eagerly awaiting the statement, with Kathy Lien of BK Asset Management stating that the dollar's uneven price action is due to the uncertainty surrounding the Fed's decision.

images.alt_text: The dollar firmed against the euro and yen on Tuesday as the Federal Reserve opened a two-day meeting expected to leave unchanged zero-level interest rates.

site_title: Najib drops Muhyiddin as deputy prime minister, sacks A-G
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak dropped Deputy Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin and replaced him with Home Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi in a cabinet reshuffle. Najib also sacked the Attorney General and promoted the PAC chairman to Deputy Home Minister. The move is seen as an attempt to consolidate his position amid the 1MDB saga.

site_title: BP joins Total in writing off oil investments in Libya
summary: BP joins Total in writing off US$600 million in investments in Libya due to the four-year conflict, forcing the suspension of an oil exploration campaign. This charge contributed to BP's earnings falling short of analysts' estimates. The move comes three months after Total wrote off US$755 million from onshore assets, signaling uncertainty for other oil companies with investments in the country. Libya's oil industry has been in chaos since the 2011 rebellion, with militias attacking oil fields and terminals, resulting in reduced production of less than 400,000 barrels per day.

site_title: Sing Holdings' Q2 profit surges
summary: Sing Holdings reported a 590.5% leap in net profit for Q2 2015, reaching S$2.244 million, driven by higher revenue recognition from its development project. Revenue increased 482.5% to S$25.3 million, largely due to the progressive recognition of proceeds from the sale of units in Robin Residences. This significant increase in profit and revenue is attributed to the successful development project.

site_title: Best Buy to sell Apple Watch from August
summary: Best Buy will start selling the Apple Watch on August 7, becoming the first national retail chain to offer the device outside of Apple's own stores. Over 300 locations will carry the watch, including Best Buy's website, and 16 Apple Watch models will be available, including the Sport and Watch versions, as well as nearly 50 accessories. The watch's average selling price is around $500. This move is seen as a test for Apple to expand the watch's mass-market appeal, following its latest revenue forecast that missed expectations.

site_title: MAS likely to keep policy settings unchanged in October: analysts
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority is likely to keep its policy settings unchanged in October, according to a Reuters poll of 16 analysts. Most expect headline and core inflation to pick up next year, with forecasts ranging from 0.5% to 2% and 1-2% respectively.
