The MAS may consider easing policy if the official 2015 growth forecast is downgraded, but most analysts do not expect any further off-cycle changes this year.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit's Q2 DPU up 15.5%
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 15.5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the second quarter to 3.35 Singapore cents, driven by a 1.2% growth in gross revenue to S$25.65 million. The Reit's gearing remains healthy at 34.1%, and its debt maturity profile has been extended to 4.0 years. The company expects the Singapore hospital properties to register a 1% increase in minimum guaranteed rent.

site_title: Despite its flaws, Iran nuke deal helps America protect its interests
summary: The US-Iran nuclear deal has been criticized for allowing Iran to develop an "industrial strength" nuclear program, but it may still serve American interests by preventing Iran from developing a nuclear weapon. The deal's flaws include lifting economic sanctions, which could boost Iran's economy and military capabilities. However, without the deal, Iran may have accelerated its nuclear program, and the US may not have been willing to use military force to stop it. The agreement still allows the US to address regional concerns, such as Iran's backing for radical governments.

site_title: PBOC boosts capital of China's policy banks
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has injected $48 billion into China Development Bank Corp and $45 billion into Export-Import Bank of China to bolster lending capacity and support foreign projects. The move aims to sustain loan growth and help the commercial sector, particularly in light of faltering exports. The PBOC's actions also follow previous efforts to address local-government debt strains and a stock market selloff. The capital injection will mainly be used to finance China's "one belt, one road" strategy, with the funds denominated in dollars.

site_title: Self-radicalised S'porean placed on detention order
summary: A 51-year-old Singaporean man, Mustafa bin Sultan Ali, was arrested and placed on a two-year detention order under the Internal Security Act for attempting to join ISIS in Syria. He was radicalized online and planned to carry out terrorist attacks in Singapore. Mustafa left Singapore in May and was detained in Turkey before being deported back to Singapore in June. The government views his actions as a serious threat and will take decisive action against anyone engaging in terrorism.

site_title: US$ makes limited gains against yen
summary: The US dollar recovered slightly against the yen on Tuesday, rising to 123.68 yen, after a sharp plunge in Chinese stock markets hit risk sentiment. The euro also strengthened against the yen, while the dollar edged up to new six-year highs against the Thai baht and Indian rupees. Investors remain cautious ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, despite expectations of no interest rate hike, and await potential forward guidance.

site_title: Writer Susan Cain instigates a 'quiet revolution' of introverts
summary: Susan Cain, author of the bestselling book "Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking," has launched a "quiet revolution" to promote the strengths of introverts in the workplace. Cain's company, Quiet Revolution, offers educational programs and resources to help organizations better understand and support introverted employees. Cain's efforts have contributed to a shift in societal attitudes towards introversion, with many people now embracing their introverted nature. Cain's work has been endorsed by experts such as Amy JC Cuddy and Mike Erwin, who are working with organizations like NASA and Procter & Gamble to develop programs that support introverted leaders.

site_title: Facebook and Twitter Q2 results will show if ad investments are paying off
summary: Facebook and Twitter will report Q2 earnings this week, with analysts expecting the companies to deliver impressive results. Facebook is projected to report a 37% revenue increase and 47 cents profit per share, driven by its efforts to attract advertisers. Twitter is expected to boost revenue 54% to $481.7 million, with its user growth slowing. The companies' deals with Google and Doubleclick aim to increase ad revenue and improve monetization. Analysts expect Facebook to outperform Google's Q2 results, while Twitter's success will depend on its ability to monetize its inventory.

site_title: New York City's La Guardia Airport to be completely rebuilt
summary: New York City's La Guardia Airport will be completely rebuilt by 2021 at a cost of approximately $4 billion, replacing the dilapidated terminals and alleviating chronic passenger delays. The project aims to create an aesthetically pleasing, unified airport with improved taxiways, a rail link to a subway station, and a ferry service. The redevelopment will create 8,000 construction jobs and additional permanent positions, with a master plan that includes a grand entryway, new terminals, and expanded amenities. The project is seen as a major step towards modernizing New York City's airports and improving the nation's infrastructure.

site_title: Technology can keep Asean ahead in the game: top execs
summary: Asean can maintain its competitive edge in the global market by leveraging technology in manufacturing, say top executives. The region's flexibility and accessibility to technology will help it keep up with changing consumer demand. Vietnam, for example, is the third-largest adopter of Autodesk's cloud rendering product, while Kimberly-Clark Asia-Pacific president Achal Agarwal highlights the region's expertise in e-commerce and digital capabilities. To remain attractive as a collective entity, Asean needs to harmonize regulations and make its supply chain flexible across markets.

site_title: Jokowi to S'pore businesses: The early bird catches the worm
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo urged Singaporean businesses to invest in Indonesia, citing the country's potential for growth and the opportunity to reap big profits. He referenced the 1997/98 Asian financial crisis, when early investors saw significant returns on their investments. With Indonesia's economy expected to double in size, Widodo encouraged Singaporean businesses to invest early, despite some regulatory challenges. The two countries also agreed to strengthen ties in areas such as trade, defense, and tourism, and signed agreements on e-government, youth development, and sports.

images.alt_text: At a joint press conference, President Joko and PM Lee vowed to continue to strengthen the close ties between Indonesia and Singapore in the areas of the economy, defence and people-to-people relations. They also witnessed the inking of three agreements by officials at the Istana.

site_title: ADB boosts sovereign lending to aid Philippine economic development
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) plans to boost sovereign lending to the Philippines from $1.8 billion to $3 billion between 2016 and 2018 to support infrastructure projects, education, and job creation. The bank will focus on strengthening senior high school education, promoting deeper capital markets, and improving access to finance. ADB President Takehiko Nakao expressed support for the Philippine government's public-private partnership program, citing the country's recent growth and better governance. The move aims to fuel inclusive growth and address youth unemployment, with the ADB projecting a 6.4% economic growth this year.

images.alt_text: ADB president Takehiko Nakao (left) said the ADB was pleased with the progress Manila was making in its public-private partnership programme and pledged the bank's continued support. Philippine Finance Secretary Cesar Purisma said his country was "writing a comeback story of growth and better governance".

site_title: Slowdown in labour growth a boon for US workers
summary: A slowdown in labor-force growth in the US, China, and elsewhere is expected to give American workers more bargaining power, as companies will have to pay a premium to attract skilled workers. This trend is driven by declining birth rates and an aging population in many countries. As a result, companies will have to offer higher wages to retain talent, potentially leading to increased consumer spending and economic growth. The shift is seen as a boon for US workers, who may see their standard of living improve in the years ahead.

images.alt_text: In trucking, young drivers aren't joining fast enough to replace retirees, while federal regulations bar entry for those under 21. For the US as a whole, the labour force has grown just 1.6 per cent since the recession ended six years ago.

site_title: Kering's Gucci produces unexpected rebound in sales
summary: Gucci, Kering's flagship brand, reported a 4.6% rise in underlying second-quarter sales, exceeding expectations. The brand's sales rebound is attributed to strong demand from Chinese tourists in Japan and Western Europe, as well as discounted sales of previous designer collections in China. This marks a significant turnaround under new creative and management duo, CEO Marco Bizzarri and creative head Alessandro Michele, who took over at the start of the year. Gucci's sales were expected to decline by 2.5-3% in the quarter.

site_title: Global borrowers lapping up cheap euro bonds
summary: International companies are borrowing heavily from European bond markets, with a record 157 billion euros (S$236.7 billion) issued this year, surpassing previous records. The European Central Bank's stimulus program has driven down borrowing costs to a record 0.85% in March, attracting globally recognized firms like Time Warner Inc and lesser-known companies from China, Brazil, and Australia. US issuers have led the international charge, with companies like Berkshire Hathaway and Mondelez International raising record amounts from bonds due in 2025 or later.

site_title: Emerging stocks down for fifth straight day on China rout
summary: Emerging market stocks fell for a fifth consecutive day, led by a 6.1% drop in Zijin Mining Group Co. in Hong Kong. The Shanghai Composite Index slid 1.7% amid concerns over government intervention failing to stabilize equities. Russia's rouble weakened to a four-month low. The decline follows China's largest one-day selloff since 2007.

site_title: Pre-sales of London homes down by 27% in Q2
summary: London home pre-sales declined by 27% in Q2, with 5,109 units sold compared to 7,046 last year. High prices and a sale-tax increase on luxury homes have reduced demand. Developers are focusing on expensive areas, with average sale prices exceeding £1,000 per square foot. Demand remains strong in some areas, such as Canary Wharf, but overall, the slump is concerning for developers who rely on down-payment income to secure construction finance.

images.alt_text: Terraced houses in the Kensington and Chelsea borough of London. Developers are focusing on the most expensive areas like these, which have spurred the average sale price of brand-new properties in London past £1,000 a square foot for the first time.

site_title: Fresh off one deal, Allergan CEO Saunders sets his sights on more
summary: Allergan CEO Brent Saunders is set to use the $40.5 billion proceeds from the sale of its generics business to Teva Pharmaceutical Industries to make large acquisitions. This move comes after the company's recent $36 billion sale of its generics business, and Saunders aims to increase the size of existing drug businesses, expand into new therapy areas, and pursue larger deals. Analysts speculate potential targets may include Biogen, AbbVie, and Amgen, with Saunders indicating a focus on "transformational" mergers.

site_title: Index of big Shanghai, Shenzhen firms tumbles
summary: China's stock market experienced a volatile day, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 1.7% and the CSI300 index losing 0.2% despite regulatory efforts to stabilize the market. The decline was partly attributed to the central bank's decision to return funds borrowed from commercial banks to stabilize the market, which may have signaled a scaling back of support. The market's fragility has raised concerns about the long-term viability of Beijing's strategy of intervening in the market, and analysts predict further monetary easing could be in store.

site_title: Pfizer lifts 2015 forecast despite fall in Q2 earnings
summary: Pfizer reported a 9.8% dip in second-quarter earnings to $2.6 billion, down from the year-ago period. Despite this, the company boosted its 2015 forecast due to higher revenues from cancer drugs and global vaccines. The earnings fall was attributed to increased expenses and lower sales in some business segments. Pfizer's revised forecast now suggests a 1-2% increase in 2015 earnings per share.

site_title: Central Region condo prices ease the most from 2013 peak: index
summary: Singapore condo prices in the Central Region have eased the most from their 2013 peak, with a 12.7% drop based on National University of Singapore's June 2015 flash estimates. This was the worst showing among four index categories. Islandwide prices of small units slipped 1.1% in June, while the Non-Central Region subindex fell 1.6%. Experts forecast higher volatility in Non-Central Region prices and attribute the price drops to investors releasing empty shoebox units for resale.

site_title: BlackRock eyes private deals as banks shy away
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, is seeking private deals in energy and infrastructure projects in the US, Mexico, and Asia to attract yield-hungry clients. The company is trying to capitalize on banks' post-crisis regulatory constraints, aiming for more direct deals with more flexibility. BlackRock has raised $15.2 billion in commitments for such deals and is looking to expand into asset management technology, including a digital marketplace. The company's alternatives business, which generated 6.4% of total revenue, is expected to play a key role in its growth strategy.

site_title: Work on first US offshore wind farm underway
summary: The US has begun construction on its first offshore wind farm, the Block Island Wind Farm, located off Rhode Island. The project, developed by Deepwater Wind, will feature five turbines providing electricity for approximately 17,000 homes. Construction marks a significant step for the US offshore wind industry, which has faced challenges in recent years. If successful, the project could pave the way for larger, more extensive wind-energy projects along the East Coast, potentially generating 4,223 gigawatts of electricity.

site_title: MDA fines Singtel S$90,000 for TV disruption in February
summary: The Media Development Authority (MDA) fined Singtel S$90,000 for a TV disruption on February 3, 2015, that affected 11,000 subscribers across Singapore. Investigations revealed a hardware failure of a hard disk array controller as the root cause. This is the second time Singtel TV has "contravened the Quality of Service (QoS) condition of its Nationwide Subscription Television Service Licence" in two years, prompting the MDA to impose the fine.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: SIA Engineering's net profit fell 23% year-over-year to S$41.3 million due to lower heavy maintenance revenue. The company's engine centres continue to face challenges due to accelerated engine model retirements and lower utilisation rates. In contrast, Sheng Siong Group, a mass-market supermarket operator, has been initiated with a "buy" rating by Maybank Kim Eng Research, citing secular growth and potential market share gains. The company's target price is set at S$1.07, representing a 10% premium over its peer average.

site_title: India's potential still on investors' radar screen
summary: Foreign investors remain optimistic about India's potential, driven by its demographics and slower growth rate compared to China. Despite high inflation rates and a fractious democracy, India's population is expected to surpass China's within 10 years. The government, led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, has implemented structural reforms, such as increasing road construction and doubling coal production. Analysts predict India's GDP growth to rise to 15.6% in 2016, supporting high returns on equity and valuations. However, concerns over the ability to acquire land for development and high interest rates remain.

images.alt_text: India has "more than 20 countries within itself," says Mr Jain. "You can't go into one state and try and replicate what's happening in another state."

site_title: As Fed approaches rate hike, job growth shifts away from oil
summary: The US job market is shifting away from the oil industry, with recovery broadening across the country. Despite the oil boom, states such as Michigan and Florida are gaining momentum, while the six states with high oil production have seen combined employment fall for four months. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates in September, driven by a significant improvement in US labor markets, with employment growing faster than the working-age population in 46 states.

site_title: Fed expected to postpone rate hike despite being upbeat about economy
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to postpone interest rate hikes, despite being optimistic about the US economy. Policymakers want to see more positive economic data, including a tighter labor market and firmer inflation, before making a decision. This would mark the first rate hike since 2006. Analysts anticipate a potential rate hike in 2026, with Citigroup setting a target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: Beware of superstitions
summary: The International Monetary Fund warns Europe that to save the euro, Greece must create a fiscal union and forgive its debt, requiring rich European countries to contribute and Greece's debt to be written off. This poses a challenge for both sides, as Germany and other countries do not want to support Greece, while Greeks feel humiliated by their debt. The issue also highlights cultural differences within the euro zone, with northern countries being more fiscally responsible and southern countries more laid-back. This cultural divide is echoed in the establishment of new banks in Asia, such as the AIIB, which may face similar challenges in managing diverse cultural expectations.

site_title: A bull in a China shop
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 32.33 points, or 1%, to 3,281.09. Penny stocks with "China" in their names surged, with 2.3 billion shares worth S$1.37 billion changing hands. Despite larger mainland Chinese stocks slumping, Singaporean penny stocks with "China" tags ran wild. This contrasts with the larger Chinese market.

site_title: Major US markets calm despite adverse global events
summary: The US stock market has remained calm despite adverse global events, with major market indexes holding steady in a tight trading range. The S&P 500 index has barely budged this year, moving less than ever before, and the Dow Jones industrial average has been going nowhere since the end of last year. Individual stocks and sectors have been more active, with the Nasdaq composite index up 7.4% for the year and energy stocks down 13%. Experts attribute the calm market to investors waiting for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, which may delay global economic problems and benefit stocks.

site_title: Android flaw lets hackers break in with text message
summary: A flaw in the Android operating system allows hackers to take control of smartphones using a text message. Cybersecurity firm Zimperium discovered that attackers can remotely execute malicious code via a specially crafted media file delivered via MMS. This allows hackers to plunder contents without the owner's knowledge. Zimperium warned that attackers only need the mobile number to execute the code. The vulnerability poses a significant threat to Android users worldwide.

site_title: Vietnam's tycoons explore agribusiness ventures
summary: Vietnam's top industrialists are investing in the US$37 billion agriculture and seafood sector, seeking to capitalize on free trade pacts and expand overseas. Firms like steelmaker Hoa Phat Group and real-estate-to-retail billionaire Pham Nhat Vuong are venturing into animal feed, livestock, and farming, aiming to tap into growing demand for food and address global shortages. The government is promoting the sector, offering tax incentives and support for foreign operators, with Deputy Prime Minister Hoang Trung Hai stating that agriculture and rural development are key to industrialization and modernization.

site_title: Deutsche Bank exec put on leave after China fund probe: sources
summary: Deutsche Bank co-head of Asian corporate finance, Douglas Morton, has been put on leave after an internal investigation found evidence of fund transfers to the bank's Chinese joint venture, Zhong De Securities Co, without proper authorization. The compliance department had been increasing checks on China dealings since last year, amid global banks strengthening compliance operations following financial scandals. Zhong De recorded a loss of 17 million yuan in 2014, and the China Securities Regulatory Commission requires brokerages to meet minimum profit and revenue requirements before expanding their business.

site_title: Mitsui to offer build-to-suit properties for lease in M'sia
summary: Mitsui & Co Ltd has entered into a joint-venture agreement with Ascendas and UEM Sunrise Berhad to offer build-to-suit properties for lease in Nusajaya Tech Park, Iskandar Malaysia. The joint venture, Nusajaya Tech Park Sdn Bhd, aims to develop the site in phases over nine years. This move marks Mitsui's expansion into Malaysia's industrial sector, with the closest industrial site to the Malaysia-Singapore Second Link. The development is expected to cater to businesses seeking customized industrial spaces.

site_title: Market sirens lead China astray
summary: China's stock market has been propped up by the government after a 8.5% decline on July 27, with dark talk of "malicious shorting" adding to concerns about the market's stability. This move is seen as a challenge to the country's efforts to resist inflating asset prices, which has been a rare feat for most governments. The decision reflects the high price of being a free rider in the financial market, where China's authorities have struggled to balance market control with foreign investor concerns.

site_title: Progress needed on Doha to avoid 'dangerous situation': WTO
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) warns that a lack of progress in the Doha Round of trade negotiations by year's end could lead to a "dangerous situation". Despite a July 31 deadline to agree on a work plan, chief WTO spokesman Keith Rockwell expressed skepticism that the deadline will be met. Huge gaps remain among members, particularly among top economic powers, on key areas such as agricultural and industrial goods trade. Failure to make progress could result in a loss of will to continue the process, posing a threat to the WTO.

site_title: Singapore developer sentiment shows slight bump in Q2
summary: Singapore developers' market sentiment has shown a slight improvement in Q2, with the Current Sentiment Index rising to 3.9 from 3.8 in Q1. The Future Sentiment Index also edged up to 4, indicating optimism about the next six months. However, the Composite Sentiment Index remains weak, and the worst-performing sectors include prime residential and retail. Developers expect moderate increases in new residential launches or steady levels, with 52% forecasting a decrease in residential property prices. Excessive supply and global economic slowdown are potential risks to market sentiment.

site_title: Malaysia's Cagamas debuts on the Singapore dollar bond market
summary: Malaysia's state-backed mortgage lender Cagamas Bhd has debuted on the Singapore dollar bond market with a three-year Singapore dollar-denominated bond carrying an A3 issue rating by Moody's. The bond closed at a spread of 50 basis points over the corresponding Singapore swap offer rates. The debut marks Cagamas's entry into the Singapore dollar bond market under a US$2.5 billion conventional multi-currency medium term notes programme, with an initial offer size of up to S$100 million.

site_title: Service on North-East line resumes after 20-minute delay due to signalling fault
summary: Train service on the North-East line resumed after a 20-minute delay due to a signalling fault on Tuesday night. The delay affected both directions, with SBS Transit initially estimating an additional 15-minute travel time. Free bus services were provided during the delay. The service has now fully resumed, with no further disruptions reported.

images.alt_text: Train service on the North-East line was delayed in both directions for about 20 minutes on Tuesday night due to a signalling fault.

site_title: Brazil port's boom-to-bust story shows snapshot of an almost superpower
summary: Brazil's Santos port, a key gateway to the world, is experiencing a boom-to-bust story, mirroring the country's economic struggles. Exports from Santos have tumbled 20% in the first six months of 2015, and the city's real-estate prices are falling as entire buildings stand vacant. The decline is attributed to reduced investments from Petrobras, the state-owned oil company, and Brazil's worst recession in a quarter century. Local businesses that once thrived on Petrobras' investments are now closing or never opened, leaving a sense of unfulfilled promises and missed opportunities.

site_title: Korean shipyards left struggling as deep-sea strategy backfires
summary: South Korea's Big Three shipbuilders, Hyundai Heavy Industries, Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering, and Samsung Heavy Industries, are facing significant financial struggles due to a deep-sea strategy that backfired. The companies ventured into offshore oil rigs to avoid competition with China, but the strategy has led to high debt and potential billions of dollars in losses when they report earnings. Oil prices have plummeted, and the companies have struggled with technology and construction costs, leaving them with limited cash reserves. Analysts predict profits, but shares have been declining due to concerns about the companies' financial health.

site_title: Fragmentation impeding success of Asean Exchanges
summary: Asean Exchanges, launched in 2011, aims to increase regional cross-border trades, boost trading stability, and attract foreign funds. Despite initiatives, only three exchanges - SGX, Bursa Malaysia, and SET - are on board, and trading volumes have been low. The original plan to link up to seven exchanges by the end of 2015 is doubtful, and smaller exchanges are reluctant to join due to concerns about trade volumes and market integration. To succeed, the Asean Trading Link needs stronger support from other Asean countries, and full integration is hampered by settlement and currency differences. Harmonization of rules and policies is also essential, with some experts suggesting a leaf from Europe's MiFiD.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound as Melrose, Hikma rally amid takeovers
summary: European stocks rebounded from their worst five-day decline, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index adding 1.1% to 390.02. Deal activity increased, with Melrose Industries, Hikma Pharmaceuticals, and RSA Insurance Group surging after agreeing to sell or buying businesses. Other shares rose, including Kering SA, Drax Group, and Luxottica Group, after beating earnings projections. Analysts attribute the rebound to positive developments for the European economy, citing more mergers and acquisitions as a positive sign for corporate confidence.

site_title: USOC pulls Boston's bid for Olympics
summary: The US Olympic Committee (USOC) withdrew Boston's bid to host the 2024 Summer Games due to deep-seated skepticism among residents about footing the bill. Resistance to the proposed bid was deemed insurmountable, forcing the USOC to reconsider its options before the September 15 deadline. This decision raises questions about whether other major American cities will take on the risk of hosting the Olympics. Boston's withdrawal may impact the USOC's ability to propose a bid city by the deadline.

site_title: The Met attracts record number of visitors
summary: The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York has drawn a record 6.3 million visitors in the past year, the most since tracking began over 40 years ago. This marks the fourth consecutive year the museum has surpassed 6 million visitors, surpassing the National Gallery and the British Museum in London. The increase is attributed to strong international tourism, well-attended shows, and a seven-day-a-week schedule, with the highly popular China: Through the Looking Glass exhibition drawing over 350,000 visitors.

site_title: Oil's double dip here as lasting glut spurs BofA price cut
summary: Bank of America predicts a "double dip" in oil prices, with Brent and West Texas Intermediate (WTI) expected to fall to $50 and $45 a barrel, respectively. The supply glut is expected to persist for another 18 months, with a 1 million barrel daily deficit. A potential rebalancing of the market may come from a reduction in US shale output, but Iran's increased exports could exacerbate the oversupply. The bank maintains its 2016 projections of $62 and $57 a barrel for Brent and WTI, respectively.

site_title: India's No 4 state bank may take over steelmakers to recover debt
summary: India's fourth-largest state lender, Punjab National Bank (PNB), is considering taking control of heavily indebted steel companies to recover debt. The bank plans to change management and then sell stakes over the next two years. PNB holds nearly $4 billion in steel loans, a quarter of which are stressed. The move aims to address the issue of total bad loans, estimated to be at a decade-high of $49 billion, and is seen as a broader effort to revive the economy. The finance ministry is also considering a rescue package for steel companies.

site_title: US consumer confidence drops in July
summary: US consumer confidence declined in July, falling to 90.9, its lowest level since September 2014. The Conference Board's index, which measures attitudes towards the labor market, rose to 26.7, but still fell short of economists' forecast of 100.0. This marks a downward revision from the originally reported 101.4 in June. The weaker-than-expected reading may indicate ongoing concerns about the US economy.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty. Stocks in Europe and the US declined, with bank and healthcare sectors dragging down the market. US President Trump's tariff threats on Canada also weighed on Wall Street. In business news, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for the second half of the year. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and an Indonesian court detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Japfa's Q2 earnings plunge 86% to US$2.96m
summary: Japfa's Q2 earnings plummet 86% to US$2.96 million, down from US$16.5 million a year ago, due to lower revenue and the absence of a one-off asset disposal gain. Core Patmi fell to US$14.27 million, and revenue declined 8% to US$704.25 million, mainly due to Indonesian operations experiencing a decline in consumer demand. The company's six-month net profit dropped 71% to US$9.96 million.

site_title: Fall in non-underwriting income hits UOI's Q2 bottom line
summary: United Overseas Insurance (UOI) reported a 12.5% rise in second-quarter underwriting profit despite lower net earned premiums. Net profit tumbled 47.8% to S$5.09 million due to a 68.3% plunge in non-underwriting income. Gross premiums written fell 3.9% and net earned premiums dropped 4.7%. The company raised underwriting profit by 12.5% to S$3.33 million, driven by improved risk quality. UOI declared an interim dividend of three Singapore cents per share and expects the national economy slowdown to affect premium growth but not significantly impact underwriting profitability.

site_title: US home price growth stalls in May: S&P/Case-Shiller
summary: US single-family home prices in May rose 4.9% year-over-year, matching April's pace but falling short of forecasts. Economists had predicted a 5.6% increase. Denver, San Francisco, and Dallas experienced the largest year-over-year home appreciation, with 10.0%, 9.7%, and 8.4% increases, respectively. The plateau is attributed to first-time homebuyers being the "weak spot" in the market, according to S&P Dow Jones Indices chairman David Blitzer.

site_title: IMF says global growth still being held back by trade imbalances
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that global growth is being hindered by trade imbalances, particularly in countries with large current-account surpluses such as China and Germany. The IMF urges these countries to boost domestic demand to correct imbalances and mitigate financial instability. China is advised to adopt a flexible exchange rate and increase consumption, while the US should aim for a primary budget surplus of 1% of GDP. The IMF warns that inaction on excess imbalances could lead to a mediocre global outcome in terms of growth and stability.

site_title: BP less likely to be acquired after US$18.7b settlement: CEO
summary: BP CEO Bob Dudley stated that the company is less likely to be acquired after settling the US$18.7 billion claim over the 2010 Macondo oil spill. The settlement, which resulted in a significant charge to the company's second-quarter profit, has likely decreased BP's attractiveness to potential acquirers. The British government also warned it would oppose any takeover bid. Dudley's comments came amid increased merger and acquisition activity in the energy sector, but BP shares remain 35% below their pre-spill value.

site_title: India antitrust watchdog imposes US$66m penalty on Hyundai Motor
summary: India's Competition Commission of India (CCI) fined Hyundai Motor's local unit 4.2 billion Indian rupees for engaging in anti-competitive practices, including restricting access to spare parts and diagnostic tools. The CCI also found Mahindra Reva Electric Car Company and Premier Ltd in violation, but did not impose fines. The companies were restricting access to spare parts and diagnostic tools, making servicing and repairing cars more expensive for consumers. Hyundai was asked to deposit the penalty within 60 days and take corrective measures.

site_title: ECB approves Athens stock exchange reopening-bourse official
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) approved a plan to reopen the Athens Stock Exchange with restrictions on trading by local investors after a one-month shutdown. Trading will resume once the Greek finance ministry issues a ministerial decree. The ECB approved the plan, which includes restrictions for Greek investors, paving the way for a potential reopening as early as Wednesday.

site_title: Greece awaiting ECB consent to reopen stock market: sources
summary: Greece is awaiting European Central Bank (ECB) consent to reopen its Athens stock market, which has been shut since June 29. The exchange may reopen as early as Wednesday, depending on the ECB's response to two plans submitted by Greek regulators. The plans include one allowing unrestricted trading and another imposing restrictions on Greek investor trading to prevent capital flight. The shutdown was implemented to prevent bank collapses under mass withdrawals amid a debt crisis.

site_title: EU slams 'false' Varoufakis claims on Greece
summary: The EU sharply denied claims by Greece's ex-finance minister Yanis Varoufakis that creditors controlled the country's tax agency. Varoufakis alleged he had hacked into his ministry's computers due to the creditors' control. The EU's European Commission spokeswoman, Mina Andreeva, stated that the tax agency is a quasi-independent entity and that the creditors only provide technical assistance, not control it. The claims were made in a leaked conference call with London investors following Greece's referendum against creditor bailout terms.

site_title: IOC signs US$14b of deals in 17 months
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has signed US$14 billion in deals over 17 months, demonstrating its financial strength. The deals include 13 broadcast agreements, with a $7.65 billion contract with NBC to show the Olympics in the US until 2032, and partnerships with top sponsors Bridgestone, Toyota, and major technology companies. These deals are expected to provide a stable financial foundation for the Olympic movement, allowing the IOC to redistribute 90% of its revenues to support athletes and sports globally, equivalent to $3.25 million per day.

site_title: Facebook's ascent has investors betting on more gains
summary: Investors are betting on more gains for Facebook's stock after it reports earnings on Wednesday, despite weak results from other social media companies last quarter. The company's shares are up 20% this year, making it one of the largest S&P companies by market capitalization. Analysts expect strong mobile pricing and video ad strength to drive robust results. In contrast, investors are less prepared for potential selloffs in Twitter, LinkedIn, and Yelp, with low put-call open interest ratios.

site_title: Fed meets, expected to again postpone rate rise
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged at its two-day meeting, despite growing confidence in the US economy. Policymakers want to see more positive data on a tighter labor market and firmer inflation before raising rates. Fed Chair Janet Yellen has said she expects a rate increase by the end of the year, but key data has recently been closer to the Fed's target. The unemployment rate has fallen to 5.3% and inflation has picked up to 1.8%, but Yellen remains cautious due to persistent weakness in the labor market and slow wage growth.

site_title: US services sector growth picks up in July: Markit
summary: The US services sector expanded at a faster clip in July, with a preliminary Purchasing Managers Index reading of 55.2, beating expectations of 55. This represents the first time the index has surpassed 55 since April. New business growth accelerated, with a subindex measuring new business at service companies rising to 56.8, the highest since April, and employment components also edging higher. The sustained economic growth is expected to continue, with the labor market showing signs of another strong month of employment growth in July.

site_title: Veteran MP Inderjit Singh dismisses online chatter that he has quit the PAP
summary: Veteran MP Inderjit Singh has dismissed online chatter that he has quit the People's Action Party (PAP), stating he remains a member and will assist Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong in campaigning at the next general election. Singh, 55, announced his retirement from politics at the next election, but clarified his commitment to the party amidst reports on social media.

site_title: EU/IMF mission chiefs to arrive in Greece for bailout talks on Wednesday
summary: European Union and International Monetary Fund mission chiefs will arrive in Athens on Wednesday for talks on a third bailout program for Greece. Talks began on Monday and are expected to wrap up by Friday, with potential follow-up discussions over the weekend if necessary. Both sides aim to reach a deal as soon as possible, with the goal of keeping Greece afloat.

site_title: Britain seeks to stop foreign "dirty money" hiding in UK property market
summary: Britain is cracking down on foreign "dirty money" hiding in the UK's property market, with Prime Minister David Cameron announcing plans to expose owners of anonymous shell companies. The move aims to prevent corrupt money from being laundered through London's expensive properties. A central registry of land and properties owned by foreign firms will be set up, requiring details of who owns around 100,000 property titles. The measures aim to stop corrupt officials and organized criminals from using shell companies to invest stolen gains in London property.

site_title: UK should seize opportunities in Asean: British PM
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron emphasized the UK's opportunities in Southeast Asia during his first major trade visit since the general election. He urged world leaders and companies to tackle corruption, particularly through data sharing to combat money laundering. Cameron plans to establish a publicly accessible central registry showing who owns and controls British companies, aiming to increase corporate transparency. He also aims to make property ownership by foreign companies more transparent, particularly in London, to combat shell companies snapping up properties.

site_title: Choa Chu Kang executive condominium site draws 11 bids
summary: A 99-year-leasehold executive condominium site in Choa Chu Kang Avenue 5 attracted 11 bids for its development. The top bid was S$156.157 million from a partnership, while the lowest bid was S$108 million from Sim Lian Land and Centra One. The site can generate an estimated 490 EC units, a public-private housing hybrid. The top bid price was S$295.12 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr).

site_title: Update: Malaysian PM reshuffles cabinet, dumps deputy after 1MDB criticism
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak reshuffled his cabinet, sacking Deputy Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin and four other ministers amid criticism over the 1MDB graft scandal. The move aims to stifle questions about the scandal, which has debts of over $11 billion and is being investigated for financial mismanagement and graft. Najib replaced Attorney General Abdul Gani Patail with Mohamed Apandi Ali. The reshuffle has sparked concerns about Najib's credibility and the future of his ruling coalition.

site_title: Obama says time for world to 'change approach to Africa'
summary: US President Barack Obama said it's time for the world to change its approach to Africa, calling for more trade and economic partnerships that benefit the continent. In his address to the African Union, Obama stated that Africa has made significant progress and deserves to be recognized as such. He emphasized the need for partnerships that create jobs and build African capacity, rather than just extracting natural resources. The US is stepping up its business ties with Africa, with Obama seeking to counter China's growing influence on the continent.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher ahead of Fed meet
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting, with the Dow Jones rising 64.84 points to 17,505.43, the S&P 500 gaining 9.57 points to 2,077.21, and the Nasdaq composite adding 18.78 points to 5,058.56. The move is seen as a positive sign before the Fed meeting, which could provide insight into the timing of a potential interest rate hike.

site_title: MAS sets up 26-member Financial Centre Advisory Panel
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has established a 26-member Financial Centre Advisory Panel (FCAP) to enhance dialogue with the financial industry and boost growth in Singapore's financial centre. Chaired by MAS Managing Director Ravi Menon, the panel will provide advice on asset class strategies and cross-sectoral strategies. The two-year term members include industry leaders from Singapore Exchange, DBS Bank, Great Eastern Life Assurance, and Aberdeen Asset Management. The FCAP aims to deepen MAS's partnership with the industry to better anticipate trends and chart strategies for Singapore's financial centre.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary: Singapore property prices fell 0.3% in June, the first drop in four months, according to the NUS flash estimate. Real estate sentiment improved marginally in Q2, but remains weak. Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Indonesian President Joko Widodo reaffirmed their countries' close ties. A 51-year-old self-radicalised Singaporean man was placed under detention order for two years. The local market closed 1% down, with the Straits Times Index retreating 32.33 points to 3,281.09.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1% down on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.98% to 3,281.09 on Tuesday, with about 2.3 billion shares changing hands. The market declined despite a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with losers outnumbering gainers 303 to 155. The most actively traded stock, Chinese Global, dropped S$0.006 to S$0.057. The decline follows a 0.4% gain on Thursday, where investors maintained positivity despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Trapped in the market, China retail investors plot escape with government money
summary: China's retail investors are "trapped" in the market, holding onto losing positions and waiting for indexes to rise to sell, despite government efforts to stabilize the markets. This "tao lao" mentality, which means being captured by a lasso, highlights the risk for Beijing in sustaining a market turnaround. The government's measures, including share buying, have calmed markets for most of July, but a sudden drop of over 8% on Monday has raised concerns. Retail investors conduct 80% of trades, making it a long and hard grind for the government to stabilize markets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's stock market ended lower on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 10.06 points to close at 1,699.7. A total of 2.14 billion lots were traded, valued at RM2.25 billion, with 197 gains and 726 losses.

site_title: Real estate sentiment improves marginally in Q2: survey
summary: Real estate sentiment in Singapore improved marginally in Q2, according to a survey. The Current Sentiment Index rose to 3.9, from 3.8 in Q1, while the Future Sentiment Index increased to 4, indicating optimism for the next six months. The worst-performing sectors were prime residential, suburban residential, and prime retail. Risks to market sentiment include a global economic slowdown, rising inflation and interest rates, and excessive supply from new property launches.

site_title: United Overseas Insurance's Q2 profit plunges 47.8%
summary: United Overseas Insurance (UOI) reported a 47.8% year-on-year decline in Q2 net profit to S$5.09 million, with annualized earnings per share dropping to 33.29 cents. Gross premiums written decreased 3.9% and net earned premiums fell 4.7%. Despite a 12.5% rise in underwriting profit, non-underwriting income dropped 68.3% due to lower investment gains. The company expects the slowing national economy to impact premium growth, but expects underwriting profitability to remain resilient.

site_title: Philippines seeks approval for budget, Q2 spending to pick up
summary: The Philippine government has proposed a record 3 trillion peso budget for 2016, aiming to boost spending by 15.2% and fund a 29% increase in infrastructure spending. Budget Secretary Florencio Abad expects second-quarter spending to jump 12.4% from last year, reversing months of underspending. However, the government faces questions on meeting its spending goals, with an ambitious 7-8% GDP target and a budget shortfall of 309 billion pesos to be financed through borrowing.

site_title: Singapore's port authority calls for LNG bunkering proposals
summary: Singapore's Maritime Port Authority is seeking proposals for liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunkering supplies to support its shift away from fossil fuels and maintain its role as the world's top bunkering hub. The port authority aims to supply LNG fuel to ships by 2020 and is issuing licenses to gas sector suppliers. Applicants must submit proposals by September 30, detailing their bunkering supply model, LNG sources, and marketing plans. This move complements Singapore's push to profile itself as an LNG hub and follows the current 60 licensed bunker suppliers covering marine fuel oil and gasoil deliveries.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Q1 earnings rise 5.2%
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Q1 earnings rose 5.2% to S$2.66 million, despite a 14.2% decline in revenue to S$114.39 million due to lower town gas tariffs. Lower fuel costs also reduced expenses, contributing to the profit increase. The trust declared a DPU of 0.25 Singapore cent for the quarter, lower than the 0.82 Singapore cent DPU in Q1 2015. The trust's manager plans to continue looking for acquisition opportunities, following the recent purchase of a 51% stake in Keppel Merlimau Cogen for S$510 million.

site_title: Gucci, Burberry demand lower Hong Kong rents as market wilts
summary: Luxury brands Gucci and Burberry are demanding lower Hong Kong store rents due to the city's declining appeal to wealthy Chinese shoppers. Kering Chief Financial Officer Jean-Marc Duplaix warned that Gucci may close some stores if costs don't decrease. The market change has left many landlords unaware, according to Duplaix. This move comes as Hong Kong's property market continues to face challenges.

site_title: UK growth accelerates to 0.7% as services, oil surge
summary: The UK economy experienced a 0.7% growth in the second quarter, its 10th straight expansion, driven by services and finance, and a surge in North Sea oil output. This marks a rebound from a slowdown in the first quarter. The growth is considered lopsided, with manufacturing declining 0.3% and construction remaining unchanged. The pound rose following the data, but Bank of England Governor Mark Carney warned that record-low interest rates may soon end due to the economy's strong performance and government fiscal program.

site_title: Indonesia issues new export tax rates for palm oil: ministry
summary: Indonesia has issued a new regulation changing the calculation of export taxes for crude palm oil and other palm products. The tax revision aims to simplify the system, with amounts now expressed in dollars rather than a percentage of the price. The new tax rates range from $3 to $200 per tonne, in addition to a $50 US export levy, when palm oil prices exceed $750 per tonne. The move is intended to offset the costs exporters must pay.

site_title: Lian Beng posts record profit and revenue
summary: Lian Beng Group posted record net profit and revenue of S$108 million and S$747 million for the full year ended May 31, 2015, respectively. The company proposed a total dividend of S$0.03 per share, including a first and final dividend of S$0.01 per share and a special dividend of S$0.01 per share. This is the company's third record dividend payout. The growth is attributed to diversified revenue streams, with net profit rising 49.6% and revenue increasing 20.6% in the fourth quarter.

site_title: POSB offers free train, bus rides to select cardholders
summary: POSB is offering free train, bus rides on Fridays to select cardholders as part of Singapore's 50th birthday celebrations. Eligible cardholders can enjoy free rides on MRT, LRT, and buses until the end of 2015, with the first 50,000 cardholders and those linked with EZ-Reload expected to benefit. POSB will waive EZ-Reload transaction and ATM top-up fees, resulting in an average monthly savings of S$15 per commuter.

site_title: Global borrowers gorging on cheap euro bonds transform market
summary: International companies are borrowing heavily in the European bond market, with a record 157 billion euros issued in 2015. Foreign firms, including those from China and Brazil, are attracted to the region's suppressed borrowing costs due to the European Central Bank's 1.1 trillion-euro stimulus program. US issuers have led the international charge, eclipsing American firms' 2014 totals, and extending maturities to further globalize the market. This shift is expected to continue, with investors adapting to the changing market landscape.

site_title: BP falls into Q2 loss on oil spill charge, price slump
summary: BP reported a Q2 loss of $5.82 billion due to a $10.8 billion charge related to the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill and declining oil prices. The company's total pre-tax charge for the incident now stands at $54.6 billion. Underlying replacement cost profit fell 64% to $1.3 billion, missing market expectations. The company cited continued low oil and gas prices, reduced contributions from Rosneft, and one-off charges as contributing factors. CEO Bob Dudley emphasized the company's focus on efficiency, cost reduction, and capital discipline to position for a period of weaker prices.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close 0.62% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 0.62% higher on Tuesday, recovering from previous day's losses. The Hang Seng index rose 151.98 points to 24,503.94 on HK$115.27 billion in turnover. The gains came despite a sharp plunge in Shanghai, with traders brushing off US President Trump's new tariff threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: US$3b ADB lending boost to help end Philippines Muslim rebellion
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has agreed to lend approximately $3 billion to the Philippines over the next three years, supporting infrastructure development, education, and capital market reforms. The loan is a 66% increase from the initial $1.8 billion, with a focus on helping the government bring lasting peace and development to the Muslim south. The funding is aimed at rebuilding basic infrastructure, improving literacy levels, and creating jobs to combat poverty. The move follows a peace deal with the country's largest Muslim rebel group, which has claimed 120,000 lives since the early 1970s.

site_title: MDA fines Singtel S$90,000 for TV service disruption
summary: The Media Development Authority of Singapore (MDA) has fined Singtel S$90,000 for disrupting its TV service on February 3, 2015, affecting approximately 11,000 subscribers. The disruption lasted nearly two hours due to a hardware failure, prompting MDA to impose the fine as Singtel had previously contravened the Quality of Service condition of its licence twice in two years. The incident highlights the importance of reliable service and prompt response times in the telecommunications industry.

site_title: Warnings on cost rises were ignored: Japan stadium designers
summary: A Japanese stadium design firm, Zaha Hadid, blames the cost rise of the new Olympic stadium on ignored warnings about uncompetitive contractor selection and a two-stage tender process. The original design was scrapped after costs soared to $2.1 billion, nearly twice the original estimates. The firm claims that going back to the drawing board may worsen the situation, and it has offered its services to Japan as it reviews plans. The decision has damaged Japan's reputation for organisational prowess, and the government is set to begin construction early next year with a new design.

site_title: Passenger traffic at Changi Airport nearly flat for H1 2015
summary: Changi Airport saw nearly flat passenger traffic in the first half of 2015, with 26.6 million passengers, a 0.2% year-on-year increase. Aircraft take-offs and landings decreased by 1%, while cargo volume rose 0.2%. Bangkok regained its top spot as the busiest route, followed by Kuala Lumpur, Hong Kong, and Manila. Other cities, such as Colombo and Mumbai, also experienced double-digit growth.

site_title: Update: Malaysia PM Najib removes deputy after public sparring
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak removed his deputy, Muhyiddin Yassin, amid a public rift over the handling of financial probes into 1Malaysia Development Bhd, a debt-ridden state investment company. Najib cited the need for a unified team and welcomed debate, but criticized public airing of differences. He has denied taking money for personal gain and accused the probes as political sabotage. Ahmad Zahid Hamidi replaces Muhyiddin as home minister, and Mohamed Apandi Ali takes over as attorney general.

site_title: German "wisemen" say eurozone states should be able to go bankrupt
summary: Germany's "wisemen" panel recommends creating a sovereign insolvency mechanism for eurozone states to prevent future crises. The mechanism would allow creditors to bear losses if states go bankrupt, making the currency area's no bail-out clause credible. The council also suggests countries should be able to leave the eurozone as a last resort, but warns against "quick-win" policies that could destabilize the currency union. The proposal aims to make the eurozone more stable and ensure the cohesion of monetary union, but faces opposition from some countries, particularly Greece, which is struggling with debt crisis.

site_title: As Fed approaches rate hike, job growth shifts away from oil patch
summary: The US job market is shifting away from the oil patch, with broadening job growth across the country. A Reuters analysis shows that industries such as manufacturing in Michigan, construction in Florida, and tech in California are gaining momentum. This trend is likely to keep the Federal Reserve on track to raise interest rates in September, satisfying one of its key criteria: a significant improvement in US labor markets. Despite a decline in energy sector jobs in some states, other sectors are outpacing job growth, and wage pressures are building across the country.

site_title: Australia: Shares close slightly lower, NZ stocks dip on China woes
summary: Australian shares closed 0.1% lower on Tuesday, despite strength in energy and healthcare sectors, as worries about China's economy persisted. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5,584.7 points, on track for a 2.4% gain for the month. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.4%, while Chinese shares fluctuated amid efforts to prop up the stock market.

site_title: Seoul: Won, shares turn higher after China shares cut losses
summary: The South Korean won closed higher against the dollar on Tuesday, erasing earlier losses, following a risk-off sentiment easing after Chinese shares cut losses. The won rose 0.2% to 1,164.9 per dollar, driven by domestic exporters' demand for month-end settlement and profit-taking in the greenback. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) also turned slightly higher, closing at 2,039.10 points.

site_title: Malaysia PM replaces deputy, sacks AG amid scandal: state media
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak replaced Deputy Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin and sacked Attorney General Abdul Gani Patail amid a scandal over state-owned development company 1MDB. Najib has denied any wrongdoing, but the moves come as the scandal threatens his hold on office. The replacements and sacking follow criticism of Najib's handling of the scandal.

site_title: France's Hollande gambles on jobs growth for 2nd term bid
summary: French President Francois Hollande has announced that he will only consider running for a second term in 2017 if unemployment falls throughout 2016 and economic growth is sustained. Despite rising jobless claims to a new record of 3.55 million in June, Hollande believes the economy will expand fast enough in the second half of the year to halt the rise in unemployment. His comments have been criticized by opposition conservatives, who view his gamble as unworthy of a statesman.

images.alt_text: French President Francois Hollande, who has long pledged only run for a second term in office if unemployment was falling, has upped the stakes by saying that fall would have to be sustained throughout the year before the May 2017 vote.

site_title: Europe: Shares up, RSA and Melrose surge on M&A news
summary: European shares rose, rebounding from a five-session decline, driven by strong company results and mergers and acquisitions news. RSA Insurance Group surged 12.9% after Zurich Insurance weighed a bid, while Melrose jumped 15% after selling its Elster business for $7.03 billion. Kering's shares rose 5.6% after Gucci's underlying sales rebounded 4.6%. The FTSEurofirst 300 index gained 0.4% at 1,536.12 points, marking a two-week low.

site_title: Baidu taps US$12 billion to challenge Alibaba in consumer services
summary: Baidu Inc, China's largest search engine, plans to use its $12 billion in cash to challenge Alibaba in consumer services. CEO Robin Li aims to transform the company into a provider of local services, competing with Alibaba, Tencent, and Meituan. This move comes as Baidu missed earnings estimates and faces a slowing Chinese economy. The company will boost administrative spending 90% in the second half, citing a growing market for online-to-offline services worth $2.19 trillion. Analysts warn that this strategy may impact the company's bottom line, but Li is willing to invest billions to sustain growth.

images.alt_text: Robin Li wants to tap Baidu Inc's US$12 billion in cash and equivalents to reshape China's largest search engine company.

site_title: Malaysian media report Najib to drop deputy after 1MDB criticism
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has sacked his deputy, Muhyuddin Yassin, and four others in a cabinet reshuffle amid criticism over his handling of the 1MDB graft scandal. The state investment fund, which has debts of over $11 billion, is being investigated for financial mismanagement and graft. Najib told his officials to stop commenting on the scandal, citing it would erode government support, before making the changes. The reshuffle is seen as an attempt to address the growing criticism and maintain stability in the government.

site_title: MAS seen keeping monetary policy steady in Oct, small minority expect easing: Reuters poll
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is expected to maintain monetary policy steady in October, with a small minority anticipating easing, according to a Reuters poll. Analysts predict headline and core inflation to rise 0.5-2.0% and 1.0-2.0% in 2016, respectively. The MAS has reviewed its 2015 growth forecast of 2-4% and may ease policy if the forecast is downgraded by more than half a percentage point.

images.alt_text: Singapore's central bank will probably hold off from further monetary easing at its next policy review in October, a Reuters poll showed, with headline and core inflation expected to pick-up next year.

site_title: Hot stock: Golden Agri falls to lowest in six years
summary: Golden Agri-Resources, the world's second-largest palm oil firm, saw its shares fall to a six-year low of 35.5 Singapore cents due to lower palm oil futures prices. The decline began in early July, amid drier conditions in Indonesia due to El Nino, which is expected to impact production in 6-9 months. Despite some plantation stocks rising, Golden Agri's near-term outlook remains "somewhat muted".

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks down at close as China stock rout weighs
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.10% at close, recovering earlier losses, as Chinese shares rebounded after a day of heavy losses. The Nikkei 225 index closed down 21.21 points to 20,328.89, while the Topix index eased 0.52% to 1,629.46. This followed a record-breaking one-session loss in Chinese shares, the mainland market's heaviest in over eight years.

site_title: Dollar under pressure on China equity rout concerns
summary: The US dollar recovered slightly against the yen on Tuesday, but remains under pressure due to concerns over a sharp plunge in Chinese markets. Chinese stocks plummeted 8.48% on Monday, the largest drop in eight years, and continued to fall on Tuesday. This has led to increased risk aversion and yen buying, causing the dollar to tick up despite the losses. The euro was supported by upbeat German data, and investors are awaiting the Federal Reserve's policy meeting later Tuesday for guidance on future interest rate hikes.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise after bruising loss due to China falls
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.8% on Tuesday, recovering from a 2.41% fall in the previous session due to losses in Chinese markets. The tech and semiconductor sectors led the gains, with the electronics subindex rising 1.5%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$31.497 per US dollar. Gains were also seen in optoelectronics, led by AU Optronics Corp, which rose 4.57%.

site_title: Oil prices down in Asia as China stocks plunge weigh
summary: Oil prices dropped in Asia due to a 8.48% plunge in Chinese stocks, their largest fall in over eight years. This led to fears of an oversupply of oil, exacerbated by strong US and OPEC production. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell 43 cents to $46.96 and Brent crude lost 55 cents to $52.92. Analysts expect the turmoil in China's stock market to affect global demand, with the Chinese government's support measures being closely monitored.

site_title: Thailand cuts 2015 GDP forecast to 3%, admits exports will fall
summary: Thailand's finance ministry cut its economic growth forecast for 2015 to 3.0%, citing shrinking exports and weak domestic demand. This is the third time the forecast has been reduced this year, following a 0.8% cut in February and a 0.5% cut in May. The ministry now expects exports to fall 4.0% this year, down from a previous estimate of a 0.2% rise. The cut is attributed to slow external demand and a decline in factory output, with the industry ministry reporting a 8% drop in factory output in June.

site_title: Singapore property outlook to improve longer term, OCBC CEO says
summary: Singapore's property market is expected to improve in the long term, according to OCBC CEO Samuel Tsien. Despite the current economic contraction, Tsien sees attractive long-term prospects for the residential and commercial sectors. Office rents have decreased, and residential prices have fallen for seven quarters, but demand is expected to recover as the economy stabilizes. The government's measures, including higher real-estate taxes and stamp duties, are also seen as temporary curbs that will eventually lift. Tsien believes the demand for properties will be there in the long term, despite the current slowdown.

site_title: PM Lee, President Widodo reaffirm close Singapore-Indonesia ties
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Indonesian President Joko Widodo reaffirmed their countries' close ties during a meeting in Singapore. They pledged to work together in economy, defense, and people-to-people ties. The two countries have consistently been top trading partners and investors, with Singapore investing in Indonesia's special economic zone. Memorandums of understanding were signed for e-government and youth development, and a business-to-business platform was established to promote Singapore investments in Indonesia. The leaders also signed a Strategic Cooperation Agreement between their business federations.

site_title: China securities regulator says investigating share "dumping" after market dive
summary: China's securities regulator is investigating share "dumping" after the country's markets suffered their worst single-day plunge in over 8 years. The investigation comes after a 30% decline in Chinese markets from mid-June to early July, with a 25% rebound in recent weeks. The regulator has set up an inspection and enforcement force to examine clues about concentrated share dumping and has threatened to severely punish "malicious short sellers". The move aims to restore confidence in the market, which has been struggling to recover from a massive sell-off that shaved around $4 trillion from the country's net market capitalization.

site_title: Android flaw lets hackers break in with a text message
summary: A flaw in Android's Stagefright code, dubbed "Stagefright," allows hackers to take control of smartphones with a text message. Attackers can hide malicious code in video files, which will be executed even if the user never opens or reads the message. The vulnerability affects 95% of Android phones, or approximately 950 million devices. Google has applied patches to internal code, but updating Android software is controlled by hardware makers and carriers, leading to a lengthy update deployment process.

site_title: 51-year-old Singaporean placed under detention order
summary: A 51-year-old Singaporean man, Mustafa bin Sultan Ali, was arrested under the Internal Security Act and issued a two-year order of detention for attempting to join ISIS in Syria. Mustafa, who had been self-radicalised by online terrorist ideology, left Singapore in May and was detained in Turkey, then deported back to Singapore. He had planned to carry out ISIS-directed terrorist attacks in Singapore. The government views terrorism support seriously and will take firm action against those who engage in such activities. Mustafa's detention order runs from July 2015.

site_title: Gold not far from 5-1/2-year low as investors eye Fed
summary: Gold prices hovered near a 5-1/2-year low, influenced by investors' expectations of a US interest rate hike and weakening demand from China. The Federal Reserve's two-day meeting may signal a rate hike later this year, strengthening the dollar and diminishing gold's appeal. Spot gold rose 0.3% to $1,096.96 an ounce, but remains under pressure, with forecasts predicting a potential drop to $1,000/ounce before recovery.

site_title: Update: China state planner optimistic on economy, watching volatile stock market
summary: China's top economic planner, Li Pumin, expressed optimism on the economy's outlook for the second half of 2015, citing improved performance in the first half. However, he noted that growth momentum remains insufficient due to operational difficulties, fiscal revenue pressure, and job market concerns. The recent stock market volatility has fueled concerns, but policymakers are monitoring the situation closely. China's central bank has cut interest rates three times this year to support the economy, with further policy easing expected in the coming months.

site_title: All companies can e-file tax returns from this year: Iras
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) announced that all companies with annual revenue of over S$1 million can e-file tax returns starting this year. This marks an expansion of e-filing, which was initially introduced for small firms in 2012. The move is expected to reduce compliance costs and increase convenience for companies, with benefits including a 15-day extension for the deadline, automatic fill-up of certain fields, and an estimate of tax payable. The number of companies e-filing has increased by 10% annually, with 41% of small companies filing electronically last year.

site_title: Toshiba interim CEO Muromachi to stay on in role
summary: Toshiba Corp. has decided to propose interim President Masashi Muromachi as a more permanent CEO beyond September, following a slew of executives' resignations over the company's biggest accounting scandal in years. Muromachi, not implicated in the scandal, is considered a safe choice to lead the company through its turmoil. The decision was made by the company's appointments committee, which includes external directors, and is expected to be proposed at an extraordinary shareholders' meeting in September.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.34% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.34% lower on Tuesday, following a 3% slump in the previous session and a rout in mainland markets. The Hang Seng Index eased 82.06 points to 24,269.90. This dip comes amid concerns over US-EU trade tensions and the ongoing market volatility.

site_title: Credit Suisse sees 'extraordinary' steel exports from China
summary: Credit Suisse reports that China's steel exports have reached extraordinary levels, with 52.4 million metric tons in the first half of 2015, rivaling Japan's total crude-steel production. This surge in exports threatens to spark trade disputes, particularly in Asia, Europe, and the US, where Chinese steelmakers are increasing competition. The report suggests that Chinese steel demand may peak, prompting exports to rise or facilities to be scrapped. This has led to US Steel Corp and ArcelorMittal filing a case against imports of cold-rolled steel from China, including steel from other countries.

site_title: China economy still facing downward pressure: state planner
summary: China's top economic planning agency stated that the country's economy still faces downward pressure and growth momentum is insufficient. Despite a 7% growth rate for the first six months, concerns arise due to a stock market plunge since June. The central bank has cut interest rates three times this year to support the economy, which is headed for its poorest performance in a quarter of a century.

images.alt_text: China's economy still faces downward pressure and growth momentum is "insufficient", the country's top economic planning agency said on Tuesday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 0.22 points to 1,709.54. The market saw 115.53 million lots traded, worth RM97.68 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 172 to 80.

site_title: Sincap unit's ex-employee arrested in China for alleged fraud
summary: A former employee of Shandong Luneng Taishan Mining Co, a subsidiary of Chinese mining and commodity trading firm Sincap Group, has been arrested for allegedly misappropriating 1 million yuan (S$220,000) in 2009. Investigations are underway, and Sincap Group will provide shareholders with updates. The incident is the first reported case of alleged misappropriation by a former employee of the company.

site_title: Buildings damaged, one missing in Indonesian earthquake
summary: A magnitude 7.0 earthquake struck remote eastern Indonesia on Tuesday, causing damage to several buildings and leaving one person missing. The quake, which occurred at 6.41am local time, was felt strongly for four seconds and triggered minor damage to two houses, a hospital, and a warehouse in Kasonaweja city. Rescuers are trying to reach the area closest to the epicentre, which is inaccessible due to its remote location. No tsunami warning was issued, and both Indonesian authorities and the Pacific Tsunami Warning Center confirmed there was no threat of tsunami waves.

site_title: Singapore, Indonesia ink pacts to deepen ties
summary: Singapore and Indonesia signed two agreements to deepen bilateral ties during Indonesian President Joko Widodo's first state visit to Singapore. The memoranda of understanding (MoUs) cover e-government cooperation, including knowledge sharing and joint projects, as well as youth and sports development, which may involve joint training sessions. The agreements were signed by Singapore's Minister for Communications and Information and Indonesia's Minister of Administrative and Bureaucratic Reform, and Singapore's Minister for Culture, Community and Youth. The move aims to strengthen ties between the two countries.

images.alt_text: Singapore and Indonesia signed two agreements to further cooperation in electronic government or e-government and for youth and sports development aimed at strengthening bilateral ties.

site_title: Toyota falls behind VW in world's biggest automaker race
summary: Toyota has fallen behind Volkswagen in the world's largest automaker title, with Volkswagen selling 5.04 million vehicles worldwide between January and June, compared to Toyota's 5.02 million. US-based General Motors ranks third with 4.86 million sales. This marks a reversal of earlier figures, where Toyota was leading the pack.

images.alt_text: Toyota has fallen behind Volkswagen in the race for the world's biggest automaker title, figures showed Tuesday, as the German giant outsold its Japanese rival in the first half of the year.

site_title: China selloff ripples across Asia as equities drop; oil retreats
summary: Asian stocks retreated for a fifth day due to a deepening selloff in China, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index dropping 1.1% and the Shanghai Composite Index sinking 3.2%. Oil declined 0.7%, while New Zealand's currency rallied against the dollar. China's stock market plummeted 8-year lows amid speculation that government efforts to prop up shares are unsustainable, sparking concerns about the impact on the world's second-largest economy. Global stocks sank, with the S&P 500 falling 0.6% and European stocks declining 2.2%.

site_title: Prices of completed apartments, condos fall 0.3% in June: NUS index
summary: Singapore's completed non-landed private homes and condos experienced a 0.3% decline in June, according to the National University of Singapore's flash estimate. The Central Region sub-index rose 0.3%, while Non-Central Region fell 0.9%. Islandwide small apartments and condo units declined 1.1%. Year-on-year, the Central Region sub-index dropped 4.8%, the biggest decrease, followed by a 3.8% decline in small apartments. The Overall SRPI was 3.2% lower in June compared to the same month last year.

site_title: Asia: Stocks hit 3-week lows as China gloom spreads
summary: Asian stocks fell to three-week lows on July 28, as a deepening Chinese stock market rout eroded risk appetite, prompting investors to seek safe-haven assets like government bonds and the Japanese yen. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index dropped 0.8% to its lowest level since July 9, while Chinese shares fell 2-5% and broader regional markets moved in line with the mainland. The decline was driven by concerns over government support, with investors wary of further market volatility, and ahead of the US Federal Reserve's rate-setting meeting later this week.

site_title: Shanghai: Shares open down more than 4% after plunge
summary: China's Shanghai stock index plummeted 4.09% at the open on Tuesday, following a 8.48% drop the previous day, the largest single-day fall in eight years. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 152.42 points to 3,573.14, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 4.67% to 2,059.24. Despite a government vow to support the market, investors remain cautious amid concerns over the impact of US-EU trade tensions and global economic uncertainty.

site_title: RBS in talks for management buyout of Indian private banking arm
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) is in talks for a management buyout of its Indian private banking arm, valued at approximately $2.5 billion. The Edinburgh-based lender has signed a non-binding framework agreement with Sanctum Wealth Management, led by Shiv Gupta, a RBS managing director. This sale follows the exit of several global banks from India's private-wealth market in the past two years. RBS has agreed to sell its Coutts International private banking business to Union Bancaire Privee in March.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower after stocks fall in the US and Tokyo
summary: The Singapore market opened lower on Tuesday, following a retreat in US, Tokyo, and European stocks. The Straits Times Index fell 0.45% to 3,298.57 after the Shanghai stock exchange suffered its largest one-day drop in eight years. The US and Tokyo markets declined, with the US stocks edging down from records amid tariff threats. The decline was attributed to concerns over global economic growth.

site_title: After quick 8.5% crash, confusion reigns in Chinese stocks
summary: China's Shanghai Composite Index plummeted 8.5% on Monday, its largest one-day selloff since 1997, leaving investors and analysts confused about the reasons behind the sudden drop.
