Despite government intervention and support measures, the market's transparency and lack of clear communication have raised concerns among investors. The International Monetary Fund has urged China to unwind its support measures, allowing market forces to settle share prices. Analysts speculate that the government may be struggling to prop up overvalued shares, which could lead to further declines.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks end lower as Beijing renews support
summary: China stocks ended lower on Tuesday, despite Beijing's pledge to lend further support, as the CSI300 index fell 0.2% and the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.7%. The previous day's 8% drop raised concerns about financial stability. Chinese regulators said they would buy shares to stabilize the market, while the central bank injected 50 billion yuan into money markets. Analysts predict further monetary easing and see current consolidation as an attractive entry point for investors.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.79% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.79% lower on Tuesday, following a 8.48% drop in the Chinese stock market, sparking concerns about global economic growth. The Nikkei 225 index lost 161.53 points to 20,188.57. Global equity markets retreated, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 also declining. Key commodities, including oil and copper, fell. The drop in Tokyo's stock market mirrored concerns about the Chinese government's support measures for the market.

site_title: South Korea declares end of Mers outbreak: Yonhap
summary: South Korea has declared the end of the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) outbreak, which resulted in 36 deaths following the first diagnosis on May 20.

site_title: China central bank: will make monetary policy changes as needed
summary: China's central bank stated it will adjust monetary policies as needed to maintain liquidity in the second half of 2015, amid concerns over the country's economy. The factory sector contracted by 15 months in July, with shrinking orders depressing output. This follows a stock market crash in June and a preliminary private survey showing the worst-than-expected result. The central bank's actions aim to address the economic slowdown, which is expected to slow China's GDP growth and put pressure on policymakers.

site_title: London home presales slump as buyers deterred by prices, taxes
summary: London home presales plummeted 27% in the second quarter due to high prices and a sale-tax increase. Demand for luxury homes fell to 5,109 from 7,046 in the same period last year, with developers facing concerns over construction finance and affordability tests. Despite this, demand remains high for homes in certain areas, such as Canary Wharf, and developers are focusing on the most expensive neighborhoods. The average sale price of new properties in London surpassed 1,000 pounds per square foot for the first time.

site_title: World's top island property market to heat up on Indonesia rules
summary: The world's hottest island property market, Bali, is expected to heat up further with Indonesia's proposed rule changes allowing foreigners to directly own luxury apartments. The Indonesian government plans to revise rules within two to three months, with the aim of increasing demand from Asian buyers, particularly from China and Singapore. Currently, foreigners can only use local citizens as proxies or structure purchases as long-term leases. The changes are expected to boost demand and increase property prices, with Bali's prices surging 15% last year, and property prices in Jakarta also rising 11% in March.

site_title: Voter rolls certified and open for public inspection
summary: Singapore's voter rolls have been certified and are available for public inspection. A total of 2,460,977 electors are listed, and citizens can check their particulars online or at community centers. Non-voters who had their names removed due to not voting in a previous election can apply to have their names restored through various channels, with applications closing before the issue of the Writ of Election.

site_title: Great Eastern's Q2 net profit up, boosted by partial sale of interest in New China Life
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 14% increase in Q2 net profit to S$277.7 million, driven by a gain of S$119.9 million from the sale of part of its investment in New China Life. Operating profit for the quarter was 7% lower than the same period last year. The company also achieved S$203.9 million in total weighted new sales for Q2, 4% lower than a year ago. An interim tax-exempt dividend of 10 cents per share was declared for the financial year ending December 31, 2015.

site_title: Keeping calm: Malaysia lets ringgit fall below 1998-2005 peg
summary: Malaysia has allowed the ringgit to trade below its 1998-2005 peg of 3.80 per dollar, with the currency trading around 3.81 per dollar since July 6. Economists predict further decline due to weak energy prices, political uncertainty, and a possible US interest rate hike. The country's international reserves have dropped to near five-year lows, making intervention to shore up the currency less feasible. Experts warn that the ringgit will need to adjust to a new equilibrium, with forecasts suggesting a weakening to 3.86 by end-2015 and 4.05 by end-2016.

site_title: Oil prices slide after Shanghai stock market dives
summary: Oil prices slid for a fourth straight day, falling 75 cents to $47.39 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The decline was fueled by a 8.5% drop in Chinese shares, the largest one-day fall since 2007, sparking fears about reduced demand in the world's top energy consumer. Global benchmark Brent crude also dropped to $53.47 a barrel, with analysts attributing the decline to concerns about slowing economic growth in China and record production levels worldwide.

site_title: Euro gets boost from eurozone growth data
summary: The euro surged over 1% against the dollar, reaching a two-week high of US$1.1132, due to improved eurozone growth data. German business confidence rose, and lending in Europe picked up, signaling a cyclical recovery. The M1 measure of eurozone money supply also increased, indicating a pickup in incomes and private sector growth. Economists attribute the boost to low inflation and a surge in GDP growth, comparable to previous record business cycle upturns.

site_title: Trump gets US$21m for Park Avenue penthouse, 40% off list price
summary: Donald Trump sold his Park Avenue penthouse for $21 million, 40% off the original list price of $35 million. The 575 sq m, five-bedroom apartment took 676 days to sell. The sale price is in line with Manhattan's record-breaking average price of $1.87 million per unit. Trump's decision to lower the price and extend the sale period suggests that the market was out of sync, according to appraiser Jonathan Miller. The sale comes as Trump continues his presidential campaign.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump, the real estate mogul turned presidential candidate, sold a penthouse on Manhattan's Park Avenue for US$21 million, almost two years after listing the five- bedroom, seven-and-a-half-bath apartment for US$35 million.

site_title: Greek PM to take on party critics over unpopular bailout
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is set to face a party congress in September to address growing criticism over the unpopular EU-IMF bailout, which he was forced to accept after five months of negotiations. The bailout comes with new reforms and austerity measures, which have sparked a mutiny among lawmakers. Tsipras faces a challenge from eurosceptic wing leader Panagiotis Lafazanis, who controls around a third of the party, and analysts predict the government will not survive beyond autumn. A congress could see Lafazanis' faction emerge as Syriza's dominant force.

site_title: Black economy clouds Spain's recovery from crisis
summary: Spain's economic recovery is hindered by a significant black economy, where 1.7 million people, including 1 in 10 employees and 1 in 5 unemployed, earn undeclared income. The black economy is estimated to equal a quarter of Spain's GDP, or roughly €250 billion, and is strongest in sectors such as agriculture, construction, and tourism. Economists attribute the persistence of the black economy to a culture of tax avoidance and a lack of tax inspectors, as well as concerns that cracking down on it could lead to social unrest.

site_title: Singapore: STI continues slide on China jitters
summary: The Singapore market continued to slide on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) losing 0.88% or 29.15 points to 3,284.27. China jitters unsettled traders, affecting regional markets such as Hong Kong and Tokyo, which also fell. The Shanghai stock index dipped 4.09% despite a government vow to support the market.

site_title: Tech startup trying to catalogue every piece of artwork in existence
summary: A tech startup, Verisart, aims to create a digital catalogue of every artwork in existence by using blockchain technology. The platform, co-founded by Robert Norton, will allow artists to add their work to the database as they produce it, including metadata and provenance. The goal is to create a shoppable database that verifies authenticity, benefiting both artists and collectors. However, the project faces challenges, including voluntary participation from owners and the potential for bypassing traditional art market business models.

site_title: Gold slump not over as hedge funds go net-short for first time
summary: Hedge funds have raised their bearish wagers on gold to the highest level since 2006, sparking concerns that the gold slump may have further to run. Speculators increased their short positions to 121,238 contracts, while long holdings declined for a fourth week. Gold prices fell to a five-year low, and futures are poised for the biggest monthly loss in two years. Analysts predict prices could drop below $1,000, citing increased US interest rates and a strengthening dollar.

site_title: TPP critics fear trade deal favours big business over states
summary: Critics of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) fear the proposed investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) mechanism will favor big business over state interests and individual consumers, potentially exposing developing countries to huge liability claims and threatening their ability to introduce health and environmental laws. The mechanism would allow foreign companies to sue governments through international tribunals, a concern raised by experts and critics, including intellectual property expert Matthew Rimmer and former chief economist Tim Harcourt.

site_title: Indonesia tin smelters face export delays ahead of new rules
summary: Indonesian tin smelters are expected to face export delays ahead of new rules that come into effect on August 1, potentially leading to a price increase. The new regulations require refined tin producers to hold "clean and clear" certification, and many smelters have faced delays in receiving export approvals. This is expected to crimp supply out to August or September, but demand from the electronics sector remains sluggish, and Myanmar's ample supply is likely to offset the impact.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit's Q2 DPU up 15.6% to 3.35 cents
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 15.6% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.35 Singapore cents for the second quarter, driven by 1.2% growth in gross revenue to S$25.65 million. The Reit's gearing stood at 34.1% with "ample debt headroom" for growth. The healthcare sector remains resilient due to strong demand in Japan and a growing industry in the region. Parkway Life Reit plans to consolidate assets in Japan to generate operating synergies and cost savings.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Great Eastern, Parkway Life Reit, SIA Engineering, Aztech, Sincap
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 14% increase in net profit to S$277.77 million for the second quarter, driven by a gain from the sale of part of its investment in New China Life. Parkway Life Reit announced a 15.6% rise in distribution per unit to 3.35 cents, while SIA Engineering saw a 22.8% drop in net profit to S$41.3 million due to a restructuring gain. Aztech Group's net profit plummeted 44% to S$1 million, and Sincap Group's former employee was arrested in China for allegedly misappropriating S$220,000.

images.alt_text: Great Eastern Holdings on Tuesday morning said that its net profit for the second quarter rose 14 per cent from a year ago to S$277.77 million.

site_title: China fulfilling global ambitions - with loans and strings attached
summary: China is expanding its global footprint, investing heavily in countries such as Ecuador with loans and conditions attached. The country has pledged $11 billion to Ecuador and is building infrastructure, including a dam, oil refinery, and surveillance system. China's growing financial clout is seen as a shift in the world order, with the country's currency, renminbi, expected to become a global reserve currency. However, critics argue that China's terms favor the country, with steep interest rates and conditions that can leave recipient countries vulnerable to economic forces beyond their control.

site_title: Strong 7.0 earthquake strikes off Indonesia: USGS
summary: A 7.0 magnitude earthquake struck the Indonesian province of Papua on Monday, 250km west of the provincial capital Jayapura. The quake occurred at a depth of 52km and was deemed not to pose a threat of tsunami waves. The area's geography, with steep mountain ranges and rainforests, increases the risk of landslides. Indonesia is located on the Pacific "Ring of Fire," a region prone to seismic and volcanic activity.

site_title: Former Indian president A P J Kalam dies aged 83
summary: Former Indian President A.P.J. Kalam, a renowned scientist, died at 83 after collapsing during a lecture in Shillong. He served as India's 11th president from 2002 to 2007. The country declared a seven-day national mourning in his honor. Prime Minister Narendra Modi paid tribute to Kalam, describing him as a great scientist and inspiring individual. Kalam was known for his work on India's nuclear weapons program and was nicknamed "India's missile man." His body will be flown to New Delhi for burial.

site_title: Did Merkel pass out at opera intermission?
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel attended the opening night of the Bayreuth Festival, where a new production of Richard Wagner's opera Tristan and Isolde was met with praise from Merkel, but controversy surrounding conductor Christian Thielemann and soprano Evelyn Herlitzius. Merkel allegedly fainted during the intermission, but this was denied by government spokesman, with a broken chair possibly causing her to slip. The festival, known for its exclusive and hard-to-get tickets, has faced criticism for its changing aesthetic, with some calling it a loss of its traditional operatic style.

site_title: 'Third world' New York's LaGuardia airport to be rebuilt
summary: New York's LaGuardia Airport, once likened to a "third world country," will be rebuilt from the ground up with a $4 billion private-public partnership. Construction is set to begin in 2016, creating 8,000 new jobs. The new airport will be more modern, move closer to the Grand Central Parkway, and eventually connect to the rail network. Governor Andrew Cuomo and Vice-President Joe Biden announced the plan, citing the airport's slow and dated conditions. The project aims to improve the airport's infrastructure and meet growing passenger numbers, expected to reach 34 million by 2030.

site_title: Chinese firm Kuafu plans condo tower at NYC's Upper East Side
summary: Chinese investment firm Kuafu Properties LLC has signed a contract to buy a six-building site at East 60th Street in Manhattan's Upper East Side for $300 million. The company plans to demolish the existing buildings and add about 60,000 sq ft of retail space in its ground-up project. Kuafu, which means "beyond wealth" in Chinese, is the fourth Manhattan deal for the company, which is backed by Chinese state-owned companies and high-net-worth individuals. The purchase is expected to close in October, with Kuafu aiming to hire local executives and expand its offices.

site_title: Galaxy invests in Monaco casino company as Macau revenue falls
summary: Galaxy Entertainment Group Ltd has invested in Societe des Bains de Mer et du Cercle des Etrangers a Monaco (SBM), a Monaco casino and hotels operator, amid a decline in Macau's casino revenue. The investment, which includes a 5% stake, is seen as a strategic partnership. Macau's casino revenue has fallen to its lowest in over four years due to China's slowing economy and a graft crackdown, with analysts predicting a 30% plunge in gross gaming revenue this year. Galaxy's move follows a 5% stake acquisition by luxury goods maker LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SE.

site_title: Lighter-touch regulation is what China stock markets need
summary: China's stock markets suffered a sharp decline, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 8.5% and the Shenzhen Composite falling 7%. Despite the correction, the market is still up 15% year-to-date. The government's heavy-handed intervention, including direct purchases and restrictions on short selling, has created moral hazard and may undermine confidence in the market. Experts warn that the psychological impact of stock-market losses on households could be significant, particularly among those who did not buy shares. A more "hands-off" approach by the authorities may be a positive development, allowing the market to reach its own level.

site_title: What the FT takeover means for Japan and Asia
summary: The FT takeover by Japan's Nikkei media company for £844 million marks a significant shift in Asian influence over English-language international business media. While the takeover may not lead to a gradual rise in Asian dominance, it signals Japan's growing openness to the world. The acquisition is expected to boost the FT's coverage of Asia and introduce Nikkei's corporate journalism style, potentially leading to a more balanced approach. The move is part of Japan's efforts to revitalize its economy, promote its "Japanese story," and increase its global influence.

site_title: Selling a business: 3 key fundamentals
summary: Aspiring entrepreneurs should focus on three key fundamentals to sell their business effectively: getting their finances in order, ensuring compliance with Environmental, Social, and Governance processes, and avoiding informal sales approaches. A professionally run contested sales process can result in the best value for the vendor. This approach helps protect the business from reduced prices and ensures transparency during on-site inspections by prospective buyers.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse buys forex trading platform 360T for 725m euros
summary: Deutsche Boerse acquired the foreign exchange trading platform 360T for 725 million euros, beating CME Group in an auction. The deal aims to strengthen Deutsche Boerse's position as a leading global marketplace for multiple asset classes. 360T's founder Carlo Koelzer is credited with launching a new generation of forex platforms, and the company is now the third-largest platform in the industry. The acquisition is expected to be immediately accretive to cash earnings and bring double-digit million euro revenue synergies in the medium term.

site_title: Fresh GLC mergers 'likely to lift valuations'
summary: A Morgan Stanley report suggests that Singapore's government-linked companies (GLCs) may drive market valuations higher as they restructure and internationalize. GLCs are currently at a 20% premium to the MSCI Singapore index, and their market capitalization makes up over 50% of the index. The report predicts potential consolidation among GLCs, citing firms like Ascendas Reit and Sembcorp Marine, and expects them to evolve into globally competitive companies. Temasek Holdings may divest non-strategic GLCs and list assets, shifting focus from government to private enterprise.

site_title: US: Stocks dive under pressure from Chinese market
summary: US stocks declined on Monday due to a significant drop in the Chinese stock market, sparking concerns about global economic growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 127.94 points (0.73%) to 17,440.59, while the S&P 500 dropped 12.01 (0.58%) to 2,067.64 and the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 48.85 (0.96%) to 5,039.78. The decline was attributed to worries about the impact of the Chinese market's downturn on global economic growth and trade.

site_title: S&P 500 propped up by just 2 sectors shows bull market fatigue
summary: The US stock market, represented by the S&P 500, is showing signs of bull market fatigue as it relies on just two sectors - healthcare and retail - for its gains. This is the tightest clustering of sectors in over 15 years, with the two industries accounting for more than 22 times annual earnings. Investors are focusing on a limited number of companies, leading to concerns about market valuations and the potential for a correction.

site_title: Coming GE to be fought in different landscape
summary: Singapore is gearing up for its first general election without Lee Kuan Yew's presence, with the Electoral Boundaries Review Committee releasing a report on new electoral boundaries. Polling Day could occur as early as September, sparking debate about the timing. The ruling People's Action Party has worked on various issues, including transport, housing, and immigration, while the Workers' Party is expected to contest a total of five Group Representation Constituencies. New parties, including Singaporeans First and the People's Power Party, are also entering the scene, with the PAP unveiling its first new face, Joan Pereira.

site_title: On their way to making a big impact
summary: The Sing50 concert, celebrating local music in Singapore, is set to feature 1,064 choir singers and 150 instrumentalists. The grand finale, led by conductor Chan Tze Law and international star Lang Lang, will include performances by popular artists such as Stefanie Sun and JJ Lin. The event, organized by The Business Times and The Straits Times, aims to promote local music and raise funds for charity, with proceeds going to The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund.

site_title: Only 6 in 10 F&B businesses last beyond 5 years: study
summary: A study in Singapore found that only six in 10 F&B businesses last beyond 5 years, with nearly half of the 369 registered in 2011 closing down. The average business runs at an annual loss of 8%, taking an average of 2.5 years to recoup its initial investment. This highlights the challenges faced by entrepreneurs in the competitive Singaporean market.

site_title: Raffles Medical Group upbeat as it stays on growth path
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 2.2% year-on-year rise in second-quarter net profit to S$15.95 million, driven by gains in hospital services and healthcare services divisions. Revenue rose 7.2% to S$99.25 million. The group expects to complete several projects, including a medical centre in Shanghai, and is optimistic about future growth despite moderating healthcare demand.

images.alt_text: Dr Loo says that the group is "on track" with the planned completion of several projects.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Aztech Group's net profit dropped 45% to S$1 million in Q2 2015 due to lower gross margin contribution. CDL sold 185 units of The Brownstone EC at an average S$810/psf. Hoi Hup Realty bought a London commercial building for S$164 million. The SPDR Straits Times Index ETF announced a dividend distribution of S$0.049 per unit. Oxley Holdings' subsidiary sold 195 units at the Royal Wharf Development for S$160 million. Mount Elizabeth Hospital's CEO Joycelyn Ling died suddenly on July 26.

site_title: Light at the end of the tunnel for the Trans-Pacific Partnership
summary: US trade ministers from 12 countries in the Asia-Pacific region are in Hawaii for talks that could lead to the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) deal being settled on or before Friday. The proposed treaty aims to assure US security, political, and economic commitments to its 12 Asia-Pacific allies amid China's rising assertiveness. Passage of the Trade Promotion Authority (TPA) in the US Congress has enabled potential breakthroughs after five years of negotiations. A successful TPP deal could provide a $300 billion boost to the 12 countries by 2025 and reinforce US influence internationally, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: China property rebound sparks demand for bonds
summary: China's property market rebound has boosted demand for onshore bonds issued by developers, leading to lower borrowing costs. Longfor Properties Co sold 5-year AAA-rated notes at 3.93%, while Beijing Tian Heng Development Group issued AA-rated 5-year debt at 4.12%. Chinese bond investors are increasingly bullish on property debt, mirroring a surge in the Shanghai property stock index. Home sales jumped 13% in the first half, driven by reduced interest rates and eased property curbs, as developers issued a record 67.1 billion yuan of notes in the second quarter.

site_title: DBS's mortgage and insurance sales hit new highs in Q2
summary: DBS Group Holdings' consumer banking unit reported record-breaking mortgage and insurance sales in Q2, with profit before tax jumping 56% to S$336 million. Total income grew 27% and new mortgage bookings reached S$3 billion, a quarterly record. The bank's strong franchise and dominant position in Singapore allowed it to outperform rivals despite a sluggish property market. DBS's mortgage market share rose to 25.3% and total housing loans reached S$54.6 billion. The bank's bancassurance business also saw significant growth, with annual premium in the first half increasing by 32%.

site_title: ECB can now focus anew on euro-area economy
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is poised to shift its focus back to fostering economic recovery in the euro area, as reports indicate the economy is not performing as expected. Despite avoiding a Greek crisis, the ECB still needs to speed up growth and inflation. Three years after Mario Draghi's promise to "do whatever it takes" to maintain the union, the ECB's work is cut out to stimulate the economy. Growth and inflation are expected to remain sluggish, and the ECB's efforts will be crucial in addressing these challenges.

site_title: Whitney Houston's daughter Bobbi Kristina dead at 22
summary: Bobbi Kristina Brown, the 22-year-old daughter of Whitney Houston, has died six months after being found unconscious in a bathtub in her Atlanta home. She had been in a medically induced coma and was surrounded by loved ones before passing away. The cause of her death is linked to an apparent drug overdose, drawing parallels to her mother's 2012 death. Many fans and celebrities, including Oprah Winfrey and Missy Elliott, have sent messages of support for the family.

site_title: Ryanair to use summer profits to slash winter fares
summary: Ryanair raised its annual passenger growth target to 14% and plans to use summer profits to slash winter fares. The airline will also benefit from falling fuel prices. However, it disappointed investors by not boosting its profit guidance, citing it was "too early" in the year. As a result, Ryanair's share price fell 3%. The move aims to drive capacity and reduce fares, but investors were expecting a more optimistic outlook.

site_title: Noble accounting saga: It's the message that counts, not the messenger
summary: A writer, Mak Yuen Teen, responds to criticisms of Noble Group's accounting and corporate governance practices, stating that the message, not the messenger, should be the focus. He questions Christie Loh's motivation for criticizing Noble, as she did not provide evidence to refute the allegations. Mak argues that Noble's corporate governance issues, including a flawed board composition and remuneration practices, could have contributed to the accounting and valuation issues raised. He concludes that Noble's governance must fundamentally change to address these issues and prevent the company from failing in the long term.

site_title: Fortune Reit posts Q2 DPU of 11.75 HK cents
summary: Fortune Reit posted a 12.7% increase in income available for distribution to HK$221.5 million in Q2, driven by a 13.2% revenue increase and 12.8% net property income growth. A DPU of 11.75 HK cents was declared, up from 10.5 HK cents a year ago. The Reit also completed its first acquisition from an independent third party, Laguna Plaza, and disposed of Nob Hill Square. Portfolio occupancy was 97.3% as of June 30, with rental reversion of 22.1% recorded for renewals.

site_title: DBS beats expectations with 15% rise in Q2 profit
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported a 15% rise in Q2 profit to S$1.12 billion, exceeding analyst expectations. The bank's net interest margin and fee income reached new quarterly highs, driving first-half 2015 net profit to a record S$2.39 billion. DBS increased its interim dividend to 30 cents per share, citing confidence in earnings sustainability. Despite a regional economic slowdown, the bank's loan and business pipelines remain healthy, with loan growth of 9% in Q2.

images.alt_text: DBS Group Holdings announced better-than-expected second-quarter earnings due to improved margins, broad-based fee income growth and sales of more loans.

site_title: S&P keeps Malaysia's A- sovereign rating
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) maintained Malaysia's long-term foreign currency sovereign credit rating at A- with a "stable" outlook, despite allegations of graft involving 1MDB. S&P believes Malaysia's strong external position and diverse economy can absorb weakness in the oil and gas sector. The decision comes after Fitch Ratings revised its outlook to "stable" earlier this month, and is seen as positive for the government's efforts to manage its economy.

site_title: Euro hits two-week high versus weak US dollar
summary: The euro rose 1.2% to $1.1113 against the US dollar, its two-week high, after Germany's Ifo survey beat forecasts, painting an upbeat picture of Europe's largest economy. The US dollar fell 0.3% against the yen amid a drop in US shares and bond yields, and market focus shifts to this week's Federal Reserve policy meeting. Analysts expect the euro to remain volatile, with concerns over weaker commodity prices and inflation expectations.

site_title: China slowdown puts energy firms under pressure
summary: China's economic slowdown is putting energy firms under pressure, with companies from renewables to fossil fuels facing a record 200 billion yuan (S$44.1 billion) of debt repayment this quarter. Defaults are looming, with Haitong Securities warning of more defaults, and companies such as Tianwei Yingli New Energy Resources Co and Yaojie Coal & Electricity Group Co struggling with cash shortfalls. The country's green energy push has helped some companies access funding, but the sector is facing overcapacity and low demand, leading to downgrades and defaults.

site_title: Bank clean-up deal may delay lifting of Greek cash controls
summary: Greek banks are likely to keep broad cash controls in place for months due to a delayed injection of funds from Europe, which is also linked to a restructuring plan. Germany wants big depositors and bondholders to take a loss, but Greek officials prefer an initial amount of 10 billion euros without strings attached. This could delay a third bailout deal for Greece and worsen the country's economic situation, with cash controls choking the economy and borrowers' ability to repay loans.

site_title: Ageing infrastructure plagues busiest US rail corridor
summary: The US Northeast Corridor, a century-old rail sector, is plagued by ageing infrastructure, causing widespread train delays and disruptions. The busiest rail corridor, carrying 750,000 daily riders, is struggling to secure funding, with Amtrak and local transit agencies facing financial challenges. Delays are expected to worsen, with a single day's shutdown costing the country $100 million in added congestion. The need for replacement of critical infrastructure, including the Hudson River tunnels, is a top priority, but funding remains a significant issue.

images.alt_text: Trains must slow to 48 kph to pass through the Baltimore, Potomac tunnels in Maryland, which opened not long after the US Civil War.

site_title: Tsipras under pressure over covert Syriza drachma plan reports
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras faces pressure over reports that some members of his Syriza party wanted to raid central bank reserves and hack taxpayer accounts to prepare a return to the drachma. Former energy minister Panagiotis Lafazanis and former finance minister Yanis Varoufakis were reportedly behind the plans, which were allegedly considered by the government but ultimately rejected. Opposition parties have demanded an explanation, while Tsipras struggles to hold his divided party together. The plans, dubbed "Plan B," aimed to create a parallel payment system in case the banking system was closed down.

site_title: Cameron aims to seal £750m trade, investment deals with S-E Asia
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron aims to sign £750m trade and investment deals with South-east Asian nations during a four-day tour, starting in Indonesia. He seeks to boost the UK economy and tap into the region's growing market. The deals include £1 billion finance for Indonesia's infrastructure and £200m export contracts. Cameron also plans to discuss counter-terrorism cooperation with Indonesia and Malaysia, and raise the threat from Islamist extremism. The visit aims to strengthen the UK's ties with the region ahead of a potential Brexit referendum.

site_title: Luxury firms step up fight against fakes sold online
summary: Luxury brands are stepping up efforts to combat online sales of counterfeit and grey-market goods. Companies like Gucci owner Kering and Mulberry Group have sued e-commerce operators and use technology to take down links to websites selling fakes. The issue is exacerbated by social media, where nine out of 10 suspect links are found, and the rise of better-quality counterfeit products. The luxury industry is estimated to lose up to $82 billion in sales to intellectual property breaches this year.

site_title: Using algorithms to determine character
summary: Algorithms used by computers are increasingly being used to judge human character, with some experts viewing this as a positive development. While AI systems can analyze vast amounts of data, they can also learn to deceive and manipulate, posing a threat to their creators. Recent investments in AI-focused innovation hubs and research initiatives, such as NIE and Synapxe, aim to harness AI's capabilities for beneficial purposes, including education and healthcare. As AI technology advances, its role in evaluating human character will continue to be a topic of discussion.

site_title: Consequences of French weakness
summary: A proposed "temporary" Greek exit from the euro was narrowly averted in July 2015 negotiations, but Germany's stance on Greece remains unchanged, favoring economic discipline and austerity measures. This divergence in Franco-German relations signals new fragility in European cooperation, with France opposing Germany's views and small euro states from Central and Eastern Europe backing Germany. The situation could lead to a European coalition opposing German-style austerity, potentially weakening France's influence in the EU, and France's President Francois Hollande may seek a sharper profile against Germany ahead of his presidential election in 2017.

site_title: Teva agrees to buy Allergan's generic-drug unit for US$40.5b
summary: Teva Pharmaceuticals has agreed to buy Allergan's generic-drug unit for approximately US$40.5 billion, bolstering its position as the world's largest maker of generic drugs. The deal allows Teva to extricate itself from its pursuit of Mylan, ending a hostile bid for the company. The acquisition is part of a wave of mergers in the healthcare industry, with announced deals totaling over US$180 billion this year. Teva expects the transaction to close in the first quarter of 2016 and boost earnings per share.

site_title: Boosting brand image with uniforms
summary: Local designer Esther Tay, founder of uniform consultancy Esta, aims to change the perception of work uniforms by creating stylish yet functional attire. With over 20 years of experience in the industry, Tay has designed for major institutions such as Singapore Airlines and Maybank, and has seen firsthand the impact of uniforms on staff morale and brand image. Tay emphasizes that uniforms are not just about slapping a logo on fabric, but about dressing right and dressing well to affect staff's self-esteem and sense of purpose. She seeks to draw attention to the role uniforms play in customer service and encourages companies to prioritize staff attire.

site_title: Ex-banker takes on male-dominated Islamic industry
summary: A former Merrill Lynch banker, Samina Akram, is launching the first global Women in Islamic Finance Forum in London, aiming to empower women in the male-dominated Islamic banking industry. The event, attended by over 200 people, seeks to address the obstacles women face due to religious conservatism, restrictions on mixed-gender working environments, and stereotypes. The industry is expected to see significant growth in women's net worth in the GCC, with women's net worth projected to increase by 15% to $258 billion by 2023.

site_title: Toll to build S$228m logistics facility near future Tuas port
summary: Australian logistics giant Toll Group is investing S$228 million in a new high-tech logistics facility near the future Tuas port in Singapore. The 82-meter-tall facility, set to be completed in mid-2017, aims to use automation to reduce labor reliance and is part of the company's plans to upgrade existing facilities across the island. Toll expects to achieve a 35% productivity improvement in its warehouse operations at Toll City and is considering building more such hubs in Singapore.

site_title: Oil hits 4-month low on China stocks rout, supply glut
summary: Oil prices fell to a four-month low on Monday, dropping 97 cents to $53.65 a barrel, amid a steep Chinese stock market slump and evidence of a global supply glut. The decline was driven by concerns about China's economic health and the potential for reduced fuel demand. Global oil supplies are abundant, with major producers pumping more oil than needed, and oil market speculators have cut their bets on a longer-term rise in prices.

site_title: Office rentals in Japan slow to respond to monetary easing moves
summary: Office rentals in Tokyo have shown a slow response to the Bank of Japan's monetary easing measures over the past two years, with average rent rising 4.5% to 17,401 yen per tsubo in June. Analysts are divided on whether this indicates a lack of effectiveness of the stimulus or a healthy, sustainable rise. Some, like Jesper Koll, see the slow growth as a sign of a real recovery, while others, like Hirokazu Anai, believe it may be a warning sign of rising asset bubble risks.

site_title: Absence of restructuring gain contributes to lower Q1 profit for SIAEC
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) reported a net profit of S$41.3 million for Q1 2015, down 22.8% from the previous year, primarily due to a lack of restructuring gains. Excluding the gain, net profit would have fallen 13.4%. Revenue decreased 5.7% to S$277.3 million, and operating profit remained stable at S$20.9 million. The company aims to manage costs and strengthen competitiveness, seeking strategic partnerships and long-term growth opportunities.

site_title: Greece: Troika's harsh policies will not work
summary: A Greek crisis program imposed by the troika of the International Monetary Fund, European Central Bank, and European Commission is deemed unsustainable and ineffective by its author. The program demands harsh austerity measures, leading to high unemployment and further economic depression. Debt restructuring and structural reforms are needed, but the program's design is flawed, favoring special interests over the Greek public. The author believes the policies will not work, resulting in depression, unemployment, and inequality, and advocates for democratic persuasion over compulsion to achieve economic prosperity.

site_title: KLIA2 is still sinking, warns AirAsia CEO
summary: AirAsia CEO warns that KLIA2, a new budget passenger terminal in Kuala Lumpur, is still sinking due to cracks in the taxiway and water forming pools that planes must drive through. The defects pose potential safety risks and could cause flight delays, increasing wear and tear on planes. AirAsia has asked Malaysian authorities to fix the problems before passengers get hurt. The terminal's construction expenses have ballooned from RM1.7 billion to RM4 billion, amid concerns about Malaysia's aviation infrastructure following recent accidents, including the disappearance of MH370 and the shooting down of a plane over Ukraine.

site_title: Bullish wagers on Baidu surge ahead of Q2 earnings report
summary: Baidu Inc's shares have surged 9.9% in two weeks ahead of its Q2 earnings report, with bullish wagers surging and options implying a 8.5% one-day move. Analysts forecast further price gains due to rising mobile usage and market share expansion of its Groupon-like platform, Nuomi.com. Baidu's profits have topped estimates in all but two quarters since 2009, with 3/4 of analysts recommending buying the shares, which are forecast to appreciate 17% on average in the next 12 months.

site_title: Thai PM hints at September Cabinet reshuffle
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha hinted at a potential Cabinet reshuffle in September to address the country's slow economy, which has consistently missed growth targets since his military coup in 2014. The economy is heavily dependent on exports, which have declined, and domestic demand is slow due to factors like record household debt and drought. A reshuffle may not lead to immediate economic improvement, with Prayuth warning that the poor economy is due to multiple internal and external factors.

site_title: BCA leads push to make building design more user-friendly
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) in Singapore has tightened the criteria for the Universal Design (UD) Mark certification, raising the benchmark for building design's user-friendliness. The BCA has also launched a guide for age-friendly homes, aiming to encourage developers and architects to incorporate UD features. Minister Tan Chuan-Jin emphasized the importance of adopting UD in Singapore's built environment to create an inclusive society. The move is part of efforts to address the needs of an aging population and promote social sustainability.

site_title: Singapore eyes diagnostics market as growth driver
summary: Singapore aims to strengthen its diagnostics market, a high-growth segment, to drive innovation and commercialization. The country has seen a significant increase in medical research and clinical diagnostic instruments industry output, with over 2,000 employees and S$1.6 billion in revenue in 2013. Diagnostics now accounts for 2% of healthcare funding but guides 60% of healthcare decisions. Roche Diagnostics, a global leader, has expanded its Singapore office and training center, hiring 230 staff and providing expert training programs. The government supports the industry through initiatives like the Diagnostic Development Hub, aiming to accelerate the development of diagnostic devices and drive growth.

site_title: Redrawing boundaries
summary: Singapore is establishing a centre to promote sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific, while the government is also exploring opportunities to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging. Additionally, the government is providing up to S$100,000 in grants for businesses hit by tariffs. The country's employment rates for graduates are also showing improvement, with experts advising them to future-proof their careers ahead of potential crises. Meanwhile, a visit to the US by Deputy Prime Minister Gan is set to focus on trade talks, with the aim of strengthening economic ties.

site_title: Oil bulls' retreat at the fastest pace in three years
summary: US oil prices plummeted 20% from their June high, entering a bear market, as speculators lost confidence in a rally. The net-long position in West Texas Intermediate contracted 28% in the past week, with long positions at a two-year low and short holdings rising 25%. US output remains near a four-decade high, while Opec members pump at record rates, keeping the market oversupplied. Oil prices fell 5.1% to $50.36 a barrel, erasing over $100 billion in market value.

site_title: S&P cuts Viva Industrial Trust's rating to BB
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) lowered Viva Industrial Trust's corporate credit rating from BB+ to BB, citing the trust's "uncertain risk tolerance" and aggressive debt-funded acquisition plans. S&P expects Viva's leverage to weaken temporarily but rise as debt is drawn down to fund construction costs. The trust's gearing ratio has historically exceeded its long-term target of 35-40%. The downgrade may lead to higher borrowing costs and falling bond prices for debt holders.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: DBS Group's Q2 profit reached S$1.12 billion, slightly above consensus, driven by US dollar strength lifting loans. The bank's shares are trading at S$21.08, with a target price of S$21.70. CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) also reported Q2 results in line with estimates, but Citi Research remains cautious about the office segment outlook. CCT's shares are trading at S$1.48, with a target price of S$1.69, and are considered oversold.

site_title: OCBC's staff to get S$5m of SG50 gifts
summary: OCBC Bank is rewarding its 8,000 employees in Singapore with a S$5 million gift package to celebrate SG50. The package includes an OCBC SG50 Nets Flashpay card with S$100 preloaded credit, four complimentary tickets to Gardens by the Bay, and subsidized tickets to Universal Studios Singapore. Additionally, about 3,000 junior executives and unionized staff will receive 100 OCBC shares. The gift aims to encourage share ownership and recognize employees' contributions to the bank's success.

site_title: US monitorship move may be best chance of Fifa reform: lawyers
summary: US prosecutors may consider imposing a court-appointed monitor on FIFA to ensure the soccer organization's corruption-hit governance body cleans up its act, according to lawyers. Despite FIFA's decision to establish its own task force for reforms, critics say the organization is incapable of transforming from within. Leading sponsors and anti-corruption groups demand an independent reform commission, but the US Department of Justice has not indicated plans to impose a monitor, citing FIFA as a victim of corruption. A monitor could be installed through a settlement, plea deal, or judge-imposed mandate, but key steps must be taken for this to happen.

site_title: BoE survey shows FX volumes dipping after SNB shock
summary: The Bank of England's survey revealed a decline in average daily trading volumes in the currency markets, falling back from record highs in the six months to April after the Swiss National Bank's shock decision to scrap its franc cap. London's daily trading volume dropped 8% to US$2.48 trillion, with spot volumes decreasing 13% to US$973 billion. Despite this, the Chinese yuan saw increased activity, with USD/CNY trading rising 25% in April. Other major currency pairs, such as the euro/dollar pair, also showed signs of recovery.

site_title: Shunfu Ville poised for en bloc sale launch
summary: A large prime suburban condo redevelopment site in Singapore, Shunfu Ville, is poised for a collective sale after owners achieved the minimum consent level required. The site, located near Marymount MRT Station, has a balance lease term of 70 years and is expected to fetch more than S$700 million. The site can be developed into a 36-storey project with up to 1,280 units, and owners stand to receive a 50% premium over individual unit sales. The sale is expected to attract big boys and consortiums, with a breakeven cost for a new condo project estimated at around S$1,300-1,400 psf.

images.alt_text: A large prime suburban condo redevelopment site could come on the market soon through a collective sale.

site_title: Dissolution of Moulmein-Kallang GRC not disruptive: Lui Tuck Yew
summary: Singapore's Moulmein-Kallang Group Representation Constituency (GRC) is set to be dissolved, with its activists joining Tanjong Pagar GRC, according to Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew. The move is not expected to be disruptive, as activists have worked with the Tanjong Pagar team in the past. The dissolution is part of the Electoral Boundaries Review Committee's recommendations, which also affect Bishan-Toa Payoh, Holland-Bukit Timah, Jalan Besar, and other GRCs.

site_title: YCH Group sign MOU with WDA to tap SkillsFuture
summary: The YCH Group signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the Singapore Workforce Development Agency (WDA) to tap into the SkillsFuture initiative, aiming to become more manpower-lean and build a stronger Singaporean core. The company will encourage employees to utilize their SkillsFuture Credit for work skills-related courses and participate in the SkillsFuture Earn and Learn Programme. Minister for Manpower Lim Swee Say emphasized the importance of lean manpower, a strong Singaporean core, and a better quality foreign workforce, highlighting the need for companies to adopt useful technology and early implementation to become future-ready.

images.alt_text: TheYCH Group and the Singapore Workforce Development Agency (WDA) signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) on Monday morning to take advantage of the opportunities offered by SkillsFuture.

site_title: Netflix's DVD operation fuelling transformation
summary: Netflix's DVD-by-mail operation continues to be profitable despite the company's shift to a global streaming service. With over 65 million streaming members in 50 countries, the company plans to expand globally by 2017. The DVD division still generates hundreds of millions of dollars in profit each year, with 5.3 million subscribers, a significant decline from its peak of 20 million in 2010. Despite this, executives expect the DVD division to remain profitable, citing the need to maintain customer service and address rural Internet service issues.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler to pay record US$105m penalty
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV agreed to a record US$105 million penalty for delaying acting on safety defects in light trucks and cars. The company will buy back over 500,000 vehicles with defective suspension parts and hire an independent monitor. Owners of affected Jeeps can trade in for above-market value. The penalty is the largest imposed by the US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, which regulates the US car industry. Fiat Chrysler also agreed to spend at least US$20 million to meet NHTSA's performance requirements.

site_title: Gilead cash pile burns hole in investors' pockets
summary: Gilead Sciences Inc has been unusually quiet in the midst of the US$179 billion mergers and acquisitions period in the drug industry, despite holding a multibillion-dollar cash reserve. Analysts are urging the company to make strategic acquisitions to boost growth, citing the peak of its hepatitis C drug revenue and competition from other companies. Gilead's shares have risen sevenfold since 2010, but investors are growing anxious for the company's next move, with potential targets including Vertex Pharmaceuticals and Incyte Corp.

site_title: Europe: Shares post biggest five-day drop this year on China rout
summary: European stocks plummeted 2.2% to 385.91, marking their largest five-day drop this year, amid concerns over China's economy. Daimler, BMW, and UBS fell at least 2.6%, with auto-related companies and banks contributing to the decline. China's benchmark index tumbled 0.3% in June, fueling uncertainty about emerging markets. The Stoxx 600 has lost 5.1% over the past five days, surpassing the previous biggest drop this year.

site_title: STI down 39 pts amid big China decline
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore plummeted 39.23 points, or 1.2%, to 3,313.42 on Monday, amid a weak Shanghai market and concerns over the economy. The Shanghai Composite fell 8.5% to its worst single-session drop since 2007, dragging down markets across Asia, including Shenzhen, Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Japan. Market experts predict continuing turbulence due to weak macro numbers and highly geared investors, while penny stocks saw a surge in speculative interest.

site_title: Muhyiddin getting set to challenge Najib?
summary: Malaysian Deputy Premier Muhyiddin Yassin has distanced himself from Prime Minister Najib Razak amidst the 1MDB scandal, reiterating that Najib should explain the problems at the strategic development company. Analysts suggest Muhyiddin is gaining ground support, with former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's indirect endorsement believed to have motivated him. Muhyiddin has called for the auditor-general's report on 1MDB to be made public and urged the administration to list false reports in a suspended newspaper. Najib has told his officials to stop commenting on the scandal, but analysts believe he needs to provide strong answers to allegations to avoid losing support.

site_title: Singapore junk gains twice Indonesia as millionaires find haven
summary: Singapore's junk bond market has seen significant gains this year, with investors earning twice as much as in Indonesia, driven by strong institutional demand and improved credit profiles of local companies. The Singapore dollar index has risen 8.2% this year, outperforming regional peers, as investors seek a haven in a more developed market. Despite weak economic spots, including a manufacturing contraction, Singapore's debt market remains resilient, with the average one-year probability of default for junk-equivalent companies decreasing.

site_title: Delta to buy stake in China Eastern Airlines for US$450m
summary: Delta Air Lines is set to acquire a 3.55% stake in China Eastern Airlines for $450 million, strengthening their partnership serving the US and China. The deal depends on a final marketing agreement and board approval. Delta will also gain an observer seat on China Eastern's board. The partnership aims to create a profitable and enduring franchise between the two carriers, with world-class customer service. The agreement follows a long-standing relationship between the two airlines, which already operate codesharing flights on multiple routes.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector issues. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, with similar operating losses as in H1. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Echo Entertainment wants to use jewellery to track down world's top gamblers
summary: Echo Entertainment Group Ltd is partnering Chow Tai Fook Jewellery Group Ltd and Far East Consortium International Ltd to build a 1,100-room hotel and casino in Brisbane, Australia. The loyalty program will offer exclusive experiences to high-rollers who spend over HK$1 million a year, aiming to attract the world's top gamblers. The project is expected to generate A$22 billion in annual wagers by 2023 and cost around A$2 billion to build. The partnership is seen as a strategic move to tap into China's growing high-end market.

site_title: Shanghai stock market savaged by biggest sell-off in 8 years
summary: The Shanghai stock market suffered its largest daily percentage loss in eight years, with the benchmark index plummeting 8.5% on Monday, driven by dismal economic data and heightened expectations of an interest rate hike in the US. The sell-off also affected other regional markets, including Hong Kong and Singapore. Analysts attributed the rout to concerns that the Chinese government's support measures would be withdrawn, as well as a commodity slump and weak industrial profits. The market is expected to experience a correction, with some analysts warning that it may not have run its course yet.

site_title: EU steps up PR campaign to overcome US trade deal hostility
summary: The European Union is launching a public relations campaign to counter opposition to the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) deal with the US, following criticism of its lack of transparency and perceived negative impacts on health and consumer safety standards. EU officials are using social media, video clips, and fact sheets to address misconceptions about the deal, which aims to reduce tariffs and increase regulatory cooperation between the EU and US. Despite limited public support from EU governments, the EU is also engaging with university students and civil society groups to build support for the deal.

site_title: S&P keeps Malaysia's A- sovereign rating, outlook stable
summary: Standard & Poor's has maintained Malaysia's long-term foreign currency sovereign credit rating at A-, with a stable outlook, despite allegations of graft involving state fund 1MDB. The agency believes Malaysia's strong external position and diverse economy can absorb weakness in the oil and gas sector. This decision comes after Fitch Ratings also revised its outlook to stable earlier this month.

site_title: Goldman Sachs unit must pay US$1.8m for reporting failures: FINRA
summary: Goldman Sachs' clearing and execution unit must pay US$1.8 million for failing to report substantial details about its alternative trading system orders and sending inaccurate order data to Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA) for over eight years. The unit also lacked adequate controls to detect and prevent these violations. Goldman neither admitted to nor denied wrongdoing in the civil settlement with FINRA.

site_title: US upgrades Malaysia, Cuba in trafficking report
summary: The US has upgraded Malaysia to the "Tier 2 Watch List" in its annual human trafficking report, despite calls from lawmakers to keep the country on the list due to its failure to suppress trafficking. Cuba was also upgraded to the Tier 2 Watch List for the first time since 2003. The upgrades were based on Malaysia's efforts to strengthen anti-trafficking laws and increase trafficking investigations, but also noted declining trafficking convictions and conditions of forced labor and sex trafficking. The upgrades could pave the way for Malaysia's inclusion in the Trans Pacific Partnership.

site_title: US automakers leery as Pacific trade deal emerges
summary: US automakers and the US Auto Workers union are skeptical about the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a trade deal between 12 Pacific nations, due to concerns over closed markets and currency manipulation. The deal would create a massive market, but US automakers want protections against countries weakening their currency. The union is also pushing for renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) before entering another trade deal. The pact's success is uncertain, but it could create opportunities for growth in countries like Malaysia and Vietnam.

site_title: Indonesia, Freeport agree 6-month export permit extension
summary: Indonesia and Freeport-McMoRan reached a 6-month agreement allowing the US mining giant to export up to 775,000 tonnes of copper, a relief after the company's stock sank due to contract uncertainty. Freeport agreed to deposit the last $20 million installment into an escrow account for a copper smelting facility and may see its export tax lowered to 5% from 7.5%. The two sides continue to negotiate a contract extension, with Freeport committed to spending $15 billion on an underground expansion and a new smelter.

site_title: IMF says ECB may need to extend money-printing to get eurozone moving
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that the eurozone's recovery will be subdued over the medium term, with average potential growth of just 1% per year. The European Central Bank may need to extend its quantitative easing programme beyond its planned end in September 2016 to stimulate growth. The IMF also emphasized the need for structural reforms to improve labour markets and productivity, as well as cleaning up balance sheets at banks and implementing EU rules for a single services market.

images.alt_text: Eurozone growth will be subdued over the medium term and the European Central Bank may need to extend its money-printing programme for longer than planned, the International Monetary Fund said on Monday.

site_title: Asia-Europe container freight rates fell 22.8% last week
summary: Container freight rates from Asia to Northern Europe plummeted 22.8% last week, falling to $400 per 20-foot container. This marks the third consecutive week of decline, with rates down 24% to Mediterranean ports and 4.4% to US West Coast ports. Despite a year of fluctuations, the rates remain below the profitable range of $800-$1,000 per TEU, attributed to overcapacity and sluggish demand.

site_title: Imperium Crown acquires two residential properties in Japan
summary: IMPERIUM Crown's subsidiary One Room Mansion has acquired two residential properties in Tokyo for 1.76 billion yen (S$19.56 million) through a sales and purchase agreement with Godo Kaisha JFA. The acquisition aligns with the group's new core business of property investment and development, aiming to establish a portfolio of income-generating properties in Tokyo's urban areas. The deal is financed by internal funds and bank borrowings.

site_title: Najib urges patience on Malaysia probes as warns against discord
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak urged patience on investigations into the state investment company 1Malaysia Development Bhd, warning against infighting in the ruling party that could risk sowing voter discord. Najib called for calm after Deputy Premier Muhyiddin Yassin stepped up calls for answers over 1MDB's debt and government investments. Multiple probes are underway into 1MDB, with a task force making several detentions and a company owner released on bail. Najib has denied taking money for personal gain, but the premier's office warned against making statements that could cloud perceptions of the government and leaders.

site_title: Fifa choice for reform panel head rejects role after discussion
summary: Fifa's reform panel head, Domenico Scala, has rejected the role after discussions due to a lack of independence. Scala, an independent head of Fifa's audit and compliance body, had been under consideration for the added role. He would only consider leading the group if autonomy was guaranteed, but instead, panel members will be appointed by Fifa and regional bodies. The task force, due to make recommendations in September, will focus on nine proposals including term limits and publishing executive pay.

site_title: Oil bulls flee at fastest pace in three years as glut expands
summary: US oil futures plummeted 20% from their June high, entering a bear market, as speculators lost confidence in a rally. The net-long position in West Texas Intermediate contracted 28% in seven days, with long positions hitting a two-year low and short positions increasing 25%. US output remains near a four-decade high, and concerns over slowing Chinese growth and a stronger dollar contribute to the market's oversupply.

site_title: Britain, France see euro reform as possible "win-win"
summary: Britain and France agree that eurozone reforms could benefit both the UK and the EU, with Prime Minister David Cameron seeking assurances on the UK's influence in the EU before a 2017 referendum on membership. France and Germany propose strengthening the eurozone with its own budget, government, and parliament, which could be a "win-win" for both the UK and the EU. The UK seeks reforms to safeguard its financial position and protect its interests, while France is cautious about changes to EU labor and public health legislation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's stock market ended lower on Monday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropping 11 points to close at 1,709.76. A total of 2.22 billion lots valued at RM1.78 billion were traded, with 290 gains and 609 losses reported.

images.alt_text: Malaysian shares ended lower on Monday with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 11 points to close at 1,709.76.

site_title: New Greek bailout talks start, creditors seek more action
summary: Greece began new bailout talks with international creditors on Monday, with teams from the European Commission, European Central Bank, and International Monetary Fund in Athens. The lenders want to see more reforms implemented before disbursement of up to €86 billion in loans to keep Greece afloat. The Greek government has pushed through two packages of measures, and talks aim to conclude a Memorandum of Understanding by August 20. The creditors want a deal that includes debt relief and conditions to support the country's economy.

site_title: Greek bank deposits fell by 8 billion euros in June: ECB
summary: Greek bank deposits fell by 8 billion euros in June to 127.5 billion euros, a 6% decline, amid fears the country may fall out of the eurozone. This marks the lowest level of deposits since 2003. Following a temporary bank closure and imposition of capital controls on June 28, banks have reopened with a cap on cash withdrawals.

site_title: Oxley sells 195 Royal Wharf Development units for £75.1m
summary: OXLEY Holdings' subsidiary sold 195 units at Royal Wharf Development to L&Q PRS Co for £75.14m (S$160m). The units, slated for completion in 2018, are part of London's largest residential development. L&Q owns over 70,000 homes in London and the South East. This sale marks a significant forward sale for Oxley, with the company expected to benefit from the sale price. The transaction demonstrates the growing demand for London's prime residential projects.

site_title: Voter rolls certified, available for public inspection
summary: Singapore's voter rolls have been certified and are now available for public inspection. The voter rolls contain 2,460,977 electors, and citizens can check their particulars on the Elections Department website, at community centers, or at the Prinsep Link premises. Those living abroad can do so at the 10 Singapore overseas missions.

site_title: Aztech's Q2 profit falls 45% due to compressed margins
summary: Aztech Group reported a 45% decline in Q2 net profit to S$1 million due to lower gross margins from its marine and material supply segment. Revenue was 3.7% lower year-over-year at S$83.98 million. The company expects market uncertainty and currency volatility to continue affecting its performance, but remains cautiously optimistic for the next reporting period.

site_title: Eurozone lending improves in June
summary: Eurozone lending to households and firms improved slightly in June, growing 0.6% year-over-year, in line with expectations. Loans to private companies had previously been sluggish, but the trend has been improving since late 2014. The M3 measure of money circulating in the eurozone also grew 5.0% in June, indicating a potential economic recovery.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Monday
summary: Singapore's voter rolls are now certified and available for public inspection. DBS Group Holdings reported a surge in mortgage sales with new bookings at S$3 billion in Q2. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) announced no change to Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) rates for Q3. OCBC is giving its 8,000 staff a gift to celebrate Singapore's 50th birthday. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) set up a new FinTech & Innovation Group, effective August 1. The local market ended 1.17% lower on Monday.

site_title: SIAEC posts 22.8% drop in Q1 profit
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) reported a 22.8% drop in Q1 profit to S$41.3 million, primarily due to lower airframe component and overhaul revenue. Excluding a one-time gain, net profit would have fallen 13.4%. Revenue decreased 5.7% to S$277.3 million. The company attributed the decline to challenging market conditions, rising business costs, and increased competition. SIAEC emphasized efforts to manage costs and strengthen competitiveness, while expanding capabilities to handle new generation aircraft.

site_title: ECB says too early to predict inflation turning point
summary: The European Central Bank stated it's too early to predict a turning point in inflation, which is expected to gradually improve this year. The ECB's money printing scheme, aimed at boosting the economy and lifting inflation, will continue until September 2016. The bank raised its inflation forecast to 0.3% for this year and 1.5% for next year, indicating a gradual improvement. It remains uncertain when inflation will reach a turning point, requiring more data.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1.2% lower on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 39.23 points to 3,313.42, closing 1.17% lower on Monday. 26 of 30 component stocks retreated, led by local banks, with only three advancing. Losers outnumbered gainers 402 to 93. The most actively traded stock was Chinese Global, which surged 215% to S$0.063. The market's decline followed Shanghai's sharpest fall in a long while.

site_title: German business morale brightens in July as Greece situation improves
summary: Germany's business morale improved in July, rising to 108.0 from 107.4 in June, according to the Ifo business climate index. The improvement was attributed to the easing of the Greece situation, which lifted sentiment in the German economy. The survey of 7,000 firms showed a stronger business confidence, beating the Reuters consensus.

site_title: Toll Group plans S$228m logistics facility near future Tuas port
summary: Toll Group, an Australian logistics giant, plans a S$228 million logistics facility in Tuas, Singapore, set to be completed in mid-2017. The 100,000 sq m facility will utilize high-tech automation to reduce labor reliance, potentially reducing staffing needs by 40%. The project aims to capitalize on future container traffic from the upcoming Tuas seaport, 5 km away. Toll Global Logistics CEO Chris Pearce stated the company is in discussions with customers to sign them on, despite already employing 1,000 people in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore STI falls more than 1% on China woes
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell over 1% in mid-afternoon trade on Monday due to concerns over China's economic slowdown. The STI was down 37.73 points at 3,314.92. Blue chip stocks like SingTel, OCBC, and DBS were dragged down by the market's weaker sentiment. Despite a 15% gain in second-quarter profit, DBS's stock still fell over 1% to S$21.12 a share. Global equities ended on a weaker note last week, with China's flash PMI adding to worries about the Chinese economy's further weakness.

site_title: Indonesia's import duty hike to boost revenue by 800b rupiah: finance ministry official
summary: Indonesia has raised import duties on consumer goods, such as food and clothes, to boost domestic industry growth. The move is expected to generate an additional 800 billion rupiah in revenue in the second half of 2015. The finance ministry claims the tariff hike is not a protectionist measure, but rather an instrument to support domestic industry growth. The increase affects about 1% of all imports and is expected to have near-zero inflationary pressure, exempting trade pact partners such as other Southeast Asian nations.

site_title: No change to ERP rates for Q3: LTA
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) announced no change to Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) rates in the third quarter, following its quarterly review of traffic conditions. The next review will take place in November this year.

site_title: Chinese fund plans US$10b European deals after Philips
summary: Chinese investment firm GSR Capital plans to pursue European acquisitions worth up to $10 billion, targeting technology, clean energy, and pharmaceuticals sectors. The firm, led by Chairman Sonny Wu, aims to acquire top companies globally, leveraging China's growing market. GSR will raise a $5 billion global acquisition fund, seeking to increase cross-border deals by Chinese private-equity firms to $28.1 billion this year. The firm plans to partner with entrepreneurs to enter new areas, aiming to "change the industrial landscape" in China.

site_title: Ying Li acquires site in Chongqing for mixed-use project
summary: Ying Li International Real Estate has acquired a 199,773-square-metre land site in Jiangjin District, Chongqing, to develop the Ying Li International Hardware and Electrical Centre, a mixed-use property. The project will include a wholesale centre, retail shops, hotel, residential, e-commerce platform, and logistics centre, spanning 1.32 million sq m. Construction of Phase 1 has commenced and is expected to be completed next year, with over 800 prospective buyers registered and a sellable GFA of over 350,000 sq m. The development will proceed in at least three phases, driven by robust demand.

site_title: ICE delays Singapore platform launch to later this year
summary: Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) has delayed the launch of its Singapore platform to later this year due to China's opposition to using Chinese prices as references for certain futures contracts. The platform, ICE Futures Singapore and ICE Clear Singapore, will offer contracts such as one-kilogramme gold, "mini-Brent" crude oil, and renminbi futures. The launch was initially targeted for March but was pushed back after China's Zhengzhou Commodity Exchange complained about the use of its settlement prices as references.

site_title: India govt to consult on central bank on new monetary policy panel: Sinha
summary: India's junior finance minister Jayant Sinha stated the government will consult the central bank before forming a proposed interest rate-setting panel. The proposal, published by the finance ministry, aims to reduce the central bank's influence in setting interest rates. Sinha clarified that the government believes the Reserve Bank of India is capable of making independent decisions on monetary policy, contradicting the proposal's intention. The move is seen as a response to the central bank's growing independence.

site_title: US business capital spending gauge rebounds solidly in June
summary: US business capital spending gauge rebounded 0.9% in June, reversing two straight months of decline, after deep investment spending cuts in the energy sector weighed on factory activity. The increase follows data showing US energy firms added 21 oil rigs, marking the third increase over 33 weeks. Shipments of core capital goods slipped 0.1%, but durable goods orders, including aircraft and automobiles, rose 3.4% and 3.4%, respectively, driven by a surge in aircraft orders. The rebound suggests the energy spending rout may be ending.

site_title: US: Wall St dips at the open on China concerns
summary: US stocks declined on Monday after a sharp drop in Shanghai shares raised concerns over China's slowing growth. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.49% to 17,482.61, while the S&P 500 lost 0.37% to 2,071.97 and the Nasdaq composite dropped 0.69% to 5,053.37. The decline follows a record-breaking session on Friday, with investors weighing the impact of US-China trade tensions and the ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close down 3.09%
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed down 3.09% on Monday, following a decline in mainland China shares due to concerns about a slowdown in the world's second-largest economy. The Hang Seng index dropped 776.55 points to 24,351.96, with a turnover of HK$116.25 billion. This was largely attributed to the economic concerns and was not directly related to the US-EU trade talks or recent stock market records.

site_title: Australian dollar nears 6-year low against US dollar
summary: The Australian dollar has reached a 6-year low against the US dollar, trading at $0.7286, due to concerns about China and falling commodity prices. Investors are increasing their bearish positions, with the Aussie having skidded 5.5% this month, its largest monthly fall since October. The market views the Aussie as a proxy for Chinese growth, contributing to its weakness against the euro and sterling.

site_title: Thai PM Prayuth says may consider cabinet reshuffle
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha stated that he may consider a cabinet reshuffle after the current government's one-year working period ends in September or earlier. The reshuffle could involve changes to some cabinet members, according to Prayuth.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady at open
summary: European stocks held steady on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index adding 0.05% to 6,583.04 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 dropped 0.53% and Paris's CAC 40 slid 0.52%. The steady opening follows a poor Asian session, with investors weighing US-EU trade talks and hefty losses on Wall Street over the weekend.

site_title: Deep-sea plan fails, leaving Korean shipyards struggling
summary: South Korean shipyards, Hyundai Heavy Industries, Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering, and Samsung Heavy Industries, are struggling due to a failed deep-sea plan. The Big Three invested in offshore oil rigs to avoid direct competition with China, but technology and plummeting oil prices have led to significant debt and potential billions in losses. Analysts forecast profits, but shares have been declining. The industry faces a global slowdown and low freight rates, prompting the need for the companies to learn from their mistakes and increase technical competitiveness.

site_title: China stocks plunge, suffer biggest one-day loss since Feb 2007
summary: China's stocks plummeted, suffering their largest one-day loss in over eight years, as profit-taking and concerns over economic health led to a government-triggered rebound. The CSI300 index fell 8.6% and the Shanghai Composite Index lost 8.5%, their biggest drops since February 2007. The declines were attributed to fears of an end to Beijing's looser monetary policies.

site_title: Australia: Shares close higher as financials rebound
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to close at 5,589.9, rebounding from a choppy session. The S&P/ASX 200 index remains on track to post a monthly gain in July, despite falling each month since March. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index slipped 0.37%. The Australian market's gains were driven by property stocks and banks, following a significant fall last week.

site_title: Singapore Power to provide 200 free mobile phone charging stations for SG50
summary: Singapore Power is gifting 200 free mobile charging stations for SG50, to be rolled out in high-traffic locations island-wide.
