The stations will provide charging services for the public in hospitals, tertiary institutions, libraries, and supermarkets. The initiative aims to promote public convenience and accessibility during the country's 50th anniversary celebrations.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks down 5.22% in afternoon trade
summary: China's benchmark Shanghai stock index plummeted 5.22% in afternoon trade on Monday, driven by concerns over the economy. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 212.64 points to 3,858.27, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 4.54% to 2,217.34. Weak economic data, including a 0.3% year-on-year decline in major industrial firms' profits, and a preliminary PMI reading of 48.2, fueled investor uncertainty. Officials have introduced measures to prop up the market, but investors remain skeptical about a return to the bull market.

site_title: Oil down in Asia, hurt by Chinese factory slump
summary: Oil prices fell in Asia on Monday, hurt by a slump in China's manufacturing sector and a strong US dollar. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) fell 16 cents to $47.98 and Brent crude tumbled nine cents to $54.53. A weak Chinese manufacturing index and rising US oil production added to downward pressure on prices, while expectations of US interest rate hikes also contributed to the decline.

site_title: China's energy consumption up 0.7% in H1
summary: China's energy consumption rose 0.7% in the first half of 2015, with a decline in coal use offset by increases in oil, natural gas, and renewable power consumption. This marks a slowdown in annual growth due to economic downturn. Coal production fell 5.8% and fixed asset investment in the coal sector plummeted 12.8%. In contrast, crude oil output rose 2.1% and natural gas production increased 4.3%. The share of non-fossil-fuel energy in power generation reached 22.9%, up 3 percentage points from the same period in 2014.

site_title: MAS appoints ex-Citi banker to head new FinTech & Innovation Group from Aug
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has established a new FinTech & Innovation Group (FTIG) to promote the use of technology and innovation in the financial sector. Former Citi banker Sopnendu Mohanty has been appointed as Chief FinTech Officer to head FTIG, effective August 1, 2015. The group will focus on regulatory policies and development strategies to enhance efficiency and competitiveness in the financial sector while ensuring safety and security. MAS aims to create a Smart Financial Centre, where technology is applied pervasively to create new opportunities and improve people's lives.

site_title: Asia hedge fund start-ups see record first half
summary: Asian hedge fund start-ups raised a record $5.3 billion in the first half of 2015, more than double the amount raised in the same period last year. This surge is attributed to anchor investors and strategic backers, with 25 new Asia-focused hedge funds seeded in the period. Despite the impressive capital raising numbers, hedge fund managers in Hong Kong remain cautious due to volatile markets and challenging conditions, with many struggling to beat market indexes consistently. Macro strategy-focused funds were the most successful, garnering $4.2 billion.

site_title: Broker's take: Morgan Stanley 'overweight' on A-Reit, GLP, SGX, SIA and Singtel
summary: Morgan Stanley has placed an "overweight" rating on several government-linked companies (GLCs) in Singapore, including Ascendas Reit, Global Logistic Properties, Singapore Exchange, Singapore Airlines, and Singtel. Analysts Hozefa Topiwalla and Aarti Shah predict that restructuring, consolidation, and internationalization will drive re-rating of these companies over the next one to three years. They also suggest that Temasek Holdings may divest non-strategic GLCs to drive total returns. The analysts believe that private enterprise, not the government, is best positioned to exploit evolving market trends and technologies.

site_title: Roche Diagnostics opens new regional headquarters and training centre
summary: Roche Diagnostics has launched a new regional headquarters and training centre in Singapore, investing S$8.4 million. The facility, located at Aperia in Kallang, aims to enhance the company's diagnostics services across the Asia-Pacific region. The centre features a state-of-the-art training centre and a second-line technical support centre, supporting customers in the region. Roche Diagnostics, a leading in vitro diagnostics company, seeks to improve its services in detecting major diseases such as cancer and infectious diseases. The new centre is expected to provide better service to the healthcare space in the region.

site_title: China coal producer Shenhua plans US$1b wind farm IPO in HK
summary: China's largest coal producer, Shenhua Group, plans to list its wind farm assets in a Hong Kong IPO valued up to $1 billion, expected in the first half of 2016. The company has invited banks to pitch for the deal, but no mandates have been assigned. This move is seen as a strategic shift towards renewable energy.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close 0.95% lower on stronger yen
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.95% lower on Monday, July 27, 2015, due to a stronger yen as Japan's earnings season began. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 194.43 points to 20,350.10, while the Topix index eased 1.08% to 1,637.90. The decline was attributed to the yen's appreciation, which negatively impacted shares.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 9.41 points to 1,711.35. The market saw 166 losers compared to 124 gainers, with a total volume of 187.5 million lots worth RM72.4 million.

site_title: Fed policy meeting: is Yellen turning bullish?
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen may signal a shift towards raising interest rates, potentially as early as September, according to her recent statements. Despite a slowdown in US economic performance, Yellen expressed confidence in the economy, citing tentative signs of wage growth and potential improvement in the second half of the year. Analysts expect continued data on employment and inflation before a potential rate hike, but any signal from the Fed could be cautious due to ongoing market volatility.

site_title: UBS Q2 profit rises 53% on higher wealth management
summary: UBS Group AG reported a 53% increase in second-quarter profit to 1.21 billion Swiss francs (US$1.26 billion), beating analyst estimates. The bank's wealth management division saw a 200% surge in income, driven by lower costs. UBS plans to establish a group service company subsidiary in the third quarter. CEO Sergio Ermotti expressed satisfaction with the quarter, citing maintained momentum despite market challenges. The bank's Q2 results were released early to counter misinformation and address seasonal impacts in the third quarter.

site_title: Indian jeweller Rajesh Exports buys refiner Valcambi for US$400m
summary: Indian jeweller Rajesh Exports Ltd has acquired Valcambi, the world's largest gold refining company, in an all-cash deal worth US$400 million. The acquisition aims to secure raw material supplies at competitive prices, particularly for dore, a semi-pure alloy of gold and silver. Valcambi's world-class refining technology will help Rajesh Exports expand its refining capacity in India.

images.alt_text: Indian jewellery firm Rajesh Exports Ltd said on Monday it has bought Valcambi, the world's largest gold refining company, in an all-cash deal worth US$400 million as it looks to secure raw material supplies at competitive prices.

site_title: Whitney Houston's daughter Bobbi Kristina dies at 22
summary: Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Whitney Houston and Bobby Brown, has died at 22. She was found unresponsive in her bathtub on January 31 and died at a hospice in Georgia. The cause of death is linked to an apparent drug overdose, similar to her mother's death in 2012. The Houston family released a statement saying she is "finally at peace in the arms of God." Brown suffered significant brain function loss after her revival.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.88% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.88% in early trading on Monday, following a heavy sell-off on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index eased 221.73 points to 24,906.78. The decline comes amid concerns over US-EU trade tensions and global market uncertainty.

site_title: Draghi focuses on reviving economy with Greece on back seat
summary: Mario Draghi is shifting focus from Greece to reviving the euro area economy, as the currency bloc avoids losing a member and market upheaval. Despite the European Central Bank's quantitative easing program, consumer-price growth remains too low, and unemployment, particularly in southern Europe, remains high. The euro-area economy is expected to grow 1.5% this year, with inflation forecast to rise to 1.5% in 2016, but recovery remains uneven, with industrial production growth weakening in the last quarter.

site_title: China: Stocks lower in morning trade
summary: Chinese stocks fell on Monday, with the Shanghai Composite Index dropping 2.10% and the Shenzhen Composite Index sinking 1.94%. The decline was attributed to concerns over the health of the world's second-largest economy, following weak manufacturing data released last week.

site_title: Ringgit hits 17-year low on weak commodities, Fed caution
summary: Malaysia's ringgit hit a 17-year low of 3.8110 per dollar on Monday, driven by a global slump in commodity prices and concerns over sluggish exports. The currency eased 0.1% from its previous day's close. The decline comes as the country's international reserves fell to $100.5 billion, down from $105.5 billion as of June 30. The weak currency may prompt the U.S. Federal Reserve to take another step towards lifting interest rates, further affecting the country's economy.

site_title: Dearth of compliance expertise complicates Singapore's fight against unlawful money
summary: Singapore's fight against illicit funds has created a shortage of qualified compliance specialists, forcing banks to make stringent checks on clients, leading to longer turnaround times to open bank accounts. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has issued warnings and reprimands to financial institutions for deficiencies in anti-money laundering measures, with six banks fined penalties ranging from $1,000 to $700,000. The demand for experienced compliance officers has increased globally, with some banks launching "grow-your-own" training programmes to expand their talent pool, amid a fierce competition for talent.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.83% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.83% lower on Monday, influenced by a negative lead from Wall Street and a stronger yen. The Nikkei 225 index lost 170.48 points to 20,374.05. A strong yen is detrimental to Japanese exporters, making them less competitive abroad and decreasing profits upon repatriation. The dollar was at 123.74 yen, down from 123.81 yen in New York late Friday.

site_title: Asia markets sink after US losses, eyes on Fed meeting
summary: Asian markets declined Monday following a fourth consecutive US sell-off, with investors awaiting the Federal Reserve's policy meeting for interest rate guidance. The dollar remained weak after a disappointing US housing market report and oil prices fell due to a global supply glut. The Dow dropped 0.92%, the S&P 500 fell 1.07%, and the Nasdaq sank 1.12%. Analysts expect the Fed to raise rates in September or December, with investors seeking forward guidance.

site_title: A frosty welcome for Greece's hated creditors
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is set to meet with creditors from the International Monetary Fund, European Union, and European Central Bank, known as the "troika," to discuss a third bailout worth up to 86 billion euros. The talks come six months after a new government took power, vowing to confront the creditors and restore "dignity" to Greece. However, the cash is conditional on more economic reforms, which have been met with resistance from the public, who have expressed anger and frustration with the austerity measures. A referendum last month showed 61% of Greeks voted against more cash-for-austerity, highlighting the ongoing divisions within the country.

site_title: OCBC to spend S$5m on SG50 Gift for staff
summary: OCBC Bank is celebrating Singapore's 50th birthday by giving its 8,000 staff a SG50 Gift, valued at S$5 million. The gift includes an exclusive Nets Flashpay card with S$100 preloaded credit, four complimentary tickets to Gardens by the Bay and Universal Studios Singapore, and subsidized tickets to the latter. Additionally, 3,000 junior executives and unionized staff will receive 100 OCBC shares. The gift aims to encourage share ownership and reward employees for their contributions to the bank's success, with the goal of fostering a sense of national pride and unity.

site_title: KL's US$1b air terminal sinking, airline says
summary: Kuala Lumpur International Airport's new budget passenger terminal, klia2, is sinking, with cracks appearing in the taxiway and water forming pools that planes must drive through. The defects, caused by differential soil settlement, pose potential safety risks and could cause flight delays. AirAsia, the terminal's biggest user, has asked Malaysian authorities to fix the problems before passengers get hurt. The terminal's construction expenses ballooned from an initial estimate of $446 million to $4 billion, and experts say the issue highlights shortcomings in Malaysia's aviation infrastructure.

site_title: DBS' mortgage sales surge to new high, market share rises
summary: DBS Group Holdings has achieved a new high in mortgage sales, with S$3 billion in new bookings in Q2, exceeding the quarterly record. The bank's mortgage market share rose to 25.3% in May, its highest since 2010. Total housing loans increased to S$54.6 billion, while total gross customer loans rose 9% to S$284 billion. DBS expects full-year loan growth to be 5% and bancassurance sales to reach S$250 million this year.

site_title: Teva said to be close to buying generic drug unit of Allergan
summary: Teva Pharmaceuticals is in advanced talks to buy Allergan's generic drug division for approximately $45 billion. This deal would bolster Teva's market position and end its pursuit of Mylan. For Allergan, selling the generic business would be a change of course, having previously built its power through deals. The deal could be announced as early as Monday, pending ongoing negotiations.

site_title: BoJ's deputy chief warns of China slowdown impact on exports
summary: Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Hiroshi Nakaso warned that China's economic slowdown may negatively impact Japanese exports, which have been increasing but lacking momentum. The BOJ trimmed its economic growth forecast but maintained upbeat inflation projections. Meanwhile, the US Federal Reserve is expected to hike interest rates, potentially affecting global fund flows. The BOJ's decision not to expand monetary stimulus suggests policymakers are cautious about the potential economic impacts.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan deputy governor Hiroshi Nakaso said on Monday policymakers must be mindful of the potential negative impact that China's economic slowdown could have on Japanese exports.

site_title: Asian futures point to more losses as gold to oil extend drops
summary: Asian stock futures signal losses amid a selloff in commodities and a strengthening dollar, with oil and gold extending declines. Crude oil fell 0.1% to $48.10 a barrel, while gold dropped 0.2% to $1,096.93 an ounce. Futures on major Asian stock indexes, including the S&P/ASX 200 and the Hang Seng Index, also declined. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index rose, and investors are awaiting data on Chinese industrial company profits and the US Federal Reserve's meeting to gauge interest rate expectations.

site_title: British PM heads to Southeast Asia with trade, IS on agenda
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron begins a four-day visit to Southeast Asia, focusing on combating the Islamic State group and strengthening trade ties with Indonesia, Singapore, Vietnam, and Malaysia. He will discuss the "common enemy" of IS jihadists and offer expertise on counter-terrorism work. Cameron also aims to drum up trade opportunities in the region, accompanied by 30 British business leaders. The trip coincides with controversy in Malaysia, where Cameron will meet with Prime Minister Najib Razak amid allegations of corruption and money laundering.

site_title: Messaging platform Symphony seeks more funding
summary: Symphony Communication Services LLC, a secure instant messaging platform backed by Goldman Sachs, is seeking additional funding to value the startup at up to $1 billion. The Palo Alto-based company is approaching venture-capital funds and financial institutions to invest, with existing backers also soliciting additional funds. Symphony, which has received $66 million in investment from 14 finance institutions, aims to expand its user base among finance professionals who communicate securely through the platform. A deal for the funding is not imminent, with the company's board of directors now including former Thomson Reuters CEO Tom Glocer.

site_title: Singapore shares open 8.35 points lower on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 8.35 points or 0.25% to 3,344.3 at 9:02am on Monday, with 93.6 million shares changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 84 to 63. The most actively traded stocks included Global Logistic, Singapore Exchange, CapitaLand, and ComfortDelGro.

site_title: US airlines surge but plenty of challenges still lie ahead
summary: US airlines, including American Airlines, United Airlines, Delta Air Lines, and Southwest Airlines, have seen their profits surge by 30% in the second quarter due to lower fuel prices. Despite record profits, analysts question the industry's long-term profitability, citing challenges such as a strong US dollar, excess capacity on international routes, and a downward trend in revenue per passenger per mile. The US Justice Department is investigating some airlines over anti-competitive behavior, and market firm Trefis suggests that top airlines must increase domestic flights to defend their market share.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler agrees to record US agency fine over recalls
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV agreed to pay a record US$105 million to the US Department of Transportation after an investigation into delayed action on safety defects. The company must also buy back over half a million vehicles with defective suspension parts and hire an independent monitor. This is the largest penalty imposed by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, surpassing a US$70 million fine paid by Honda Motor Co last year.

site_title: Gold slump not over as speculators go net-short
summary: Gold prices may continue to fall as speculators increase their bearish bets, with futures in New York poised for the biggest monthly loss in two years. Hedge funds have swung into a net-short position for the first time, with long holdings declining for a fourth week. The decline is attributed to speculation of rising US interest rates, a strengthening dollar, and reduced Chinese demand. Analysts predict further price drops, with one fund manager stating that prices could drop significantly, potentially reaching a five-year low.

site_title: Buying flat, selling remains very low
summary: Singaporean companies reported minimal buyback activity in the fourth week of July, with nine firms posting 26 repurchases worth S$18.76 million. The buying activity was consistent with the previous week, while the selling among directors remained low. Significant purchases were made by Ryobi Kiso Holdings, Ezion Holdings, ISEC Healthcare Limited, Eurosports Global Limited, and Oxley Holdings. On the funds side, ARA Asset Management purchased shares, while Aberdeen Global sold its stake in Yanlord Land Group.

site_title: French farmers block routes from Spain, Germany
summary: French farmers blocked roads from Spain and Germany on Sunday, protesting a fall in food prices that has brought them to the brink of bankruptcy. Over 1,000 agricultural workers participated in the blockage, forcing 12 trucks to turn back at the border. In another incident, around 100 farmers ransacked dozens of trucks from Spain on a highway, threatening to unload meat and fruit destined for the French market. The protests come after a week of disruptions across France, with the government offering 600 million euros in tax relief and loan guarantees.

images.alt_text: French farmers blocked roads from Spain and Germany on Sunday to stop foreign products entering the country, the latest protest against a fall in food prices that has brought them to the brink of bankruptcy.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down, in line with regional bourses
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.5% to 8,720.26 on Monday, mirroring regional markets and US Wall Street ahead of a Federal Reserve rate meeting. Weak corporate earnings and a strong US dollar cast uncertainty, but no rate hike is expected this week. Chipmakers led declines, with Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Inc and Inotera Memories Inc falling 2.5% and 2.89% respectively. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$31.501 per US dollar.

site_title: 'Virtual vultures' game in Argentina for angry investors
summary: Argentina's President Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner's government is using a state-run amusement park to encourage children to take aim at virtual vultures, a reference to international creditors. The "Virtual Vultures" game, played on consoles, targets digital birds at hospitals, schools, and factories, with the goal of "recovered national sovereignty." The game is part of the government's efforts to battle with spurned creditors, including billionaire Paul Singer's Elliott Management, which refused restructuring terms. The game's message is clear: even children can play a role in the country's debt battle.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yoma, Raffles Medical, First Sponsor
summary: Three Singapore-listed stocks made significant announcements: Yoma Strategic Holdings reported a 78% increase in net profit to S$2.56 million, driven by revenue growth in its automotive segment. Raffles Medical Group's net profit rose 2.2% to S$15.9 million, with revenue growing 7.2%. First Sponsor Group, a Chinese property developer, achieved a net profit of S$7.62 million, despite uncertainty in the China property market, with its three core businesses seeing higher revenues.

site_title: Foreign investment in Arab states drops 8% last year
summary: Foreign investment in Arab states declined 8% last year, reaching $43.9 billion, down from $47.5 billion in 2014. The United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia received nearly half of the total funds, with the UAE attracting $10.1 billion and Saudi Arabia $8 billion. This marks a significant drop from the $66.2 billion in 2010, before the Arab Spring uprisings. The six energy-rich Gulf Cooperation Council states accounted for 49.7% of the Arab world's total FDI, while outflows of Arab investments into other countries dropped 10% to $33.4 billion.

site_title: China Railway Signal seeks up to US$1.8b in HK IPO
summary: China Railway Signal & Communication Corp, the world's largest train traffic control systems provider, is seeking up to $1.8 billion in a Hong Kong initial public offering. The company is selling 1.75 billion shares at HK$6.30 to HK$8 apiece. This deal aims to raise funds after China's stock market rout wiped out $4 trillion in value, with 16 cornerstone investors agreeing to buy more than half of the offering. It will add to Hong Kong's $18.5 billion in first-time share sales this year.

images.alt_text: China Railway Signal & Communication Corp, the world's biggest provider of train traffic control systems, is seeking to raise as much as US$1.8 billion from a Hong Kong initial public offering.

site_title: US Congress nowhere near a deal as highway fund deadline nears
summary: US Congress is struggling to reach a deal on a highway fund bill, with a July 31 deadline looming. The Senate has advanced a six-year plan, but House Republican leaders have declared it "dead on arrival." The House will need to consider a short-term extension, and the Highway Trust Fund is expected to run low by the end of the month. Failure to act could lead to 4,000 layoffs and reduced payments to states for road and bridge projects. The Obama administration supports a House package that allows for negotiations on a long-term bill.

site_title: Tokyo office rents crawl to 4-year high, new units on horizon
summary: Tokyo office rents have reached a 4-year high, with an average rent of 17,401 yen (US$191) per tsubo in June, a 4.8% increase from the previous year. However, the growth is seen as small and is expected to be capped by the imminent launch of new office towers, which will add over 1 million square meters of space to the market by 2019. Analysts attribute the slow growth to the government's stimulus policies and the loss of confidence in the property sector, with vacancy rates averaging 5.1% in June, higher than the 3% seen in the 2007 property investment peak.

site_title: Yoma's Q1 net profit up 78% to S$2.56m
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings reported a 78% increase in Q1 net profit to S$2.56 million, driven by growth in its automotive sales and a 31% rise in revenue to S$22.6 million. The company attributed this growth to the contribution of Convenience Prosperity Company, which sells tractors and farm equipment in Myanmar. Despite a decline in joint venture losses and a significant increase in share of losses from associated companies, Yoma's earnings per share rose to 0.15 Singapore cents. The company expects to secure financing for itself and its customers, particularly for its real estate business, in Myanmar.

site_title: Raffles Medical's Q2 net profit up 2.2%
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 2.2% increase in net profit to S$15.9 million for Q2 2015, driven by 7.2% revenue growth to S$99.3 million. Revenue from healthcare services rose 5.7% and hospital services increased 6.6%. Staff costs rose 9.4% to S$48.5 million, partly due to new recruitment. The company declared an interim dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents per share, to be paid on August 31, 2015.

site_title: Brazil bank carnage defies better profit forecast as stock rout worsens
summary: Brazil's biggest banks, Itau Unibanco and Banco Bradesco, are trading at the cheapest levels in three years despite analysts boosting their earnings estimates by 9% this year. The Ibovespa stock index slumped, with Itau's stock falling 8% and Bradesco's 7%, as concerns about borrowing costs and investment-grade status amid Brazil's recession worsen. Analysts warn that banks could suffer if Brazil loses its investment-grade status, citing a negative outlook from Moody's Investors Service. The real sank 2.1% to its lowest since 2003.

site_title: GE books US$2.5 billion in African orders from oil to locomotives
summary: General Electric (GE) has booked $2.5 billion in orders from sub-Saharan Africa over the past 11 months, exceeding its 2018 target. Orders include oil and gas equipment for Eni SpA in Ghana and locomotives for Angola. The company expects to deliver the orders over the next two years and plans to expand its footprint in Africa, seeking financing for projects worth at least $1.5 billion annually.

site_title: The case against Depression
summary: The article discusses whether the current economic environment is comparable to the pre-Depression era. The author argues that, despite similarities, the global economy is more resilient due to stronger banking systems, increased monetary accommodation, and a weaker link between the US and other countries. Unlike the 1920s, the US money supply is expanding, and other major central banks are engaging in quantitative easing. The author concludes that the implications for growth are less severe, and the world today is better equipped to respond to economic challenges, reducing the risk of another Great Depression.

site_title: Voters can expect candidates' introduction after National Day
summary: Singapore's ruling party, the People's Action Party (PAP), will formally introduce its candidates for the upcoming general election after National Day. Newcomers may be introduced by retiring MPs, ensuring a smooth transition. Potential candidates include Joan Pereira, Desmond Choo, and Cheng Li Hui, who will replace retiring MPs in various constituencies. The election is seen as a "watershed" one, marking the first GE since the demise of founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew.

site_title: Eurozone urged to drop debt-fuelled growth model
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) debt-fuelled growth model is being urged to be abandoned by the Bank for International Settlements (BIS). Jaime Caruana, BIS general manager, warns that ultra-low interest rates have led to speculation and could trigger another crash. The eurozone's massive debt burden weighs on growth, with debt ratios of other nations exceeding 130%. The ECB's quantitative easing has failed to boost growth, with the eurozone experiencing only 1% annualized growth since 2008. The BIS recommends a rebalancing of national and international policy frameworks to address slower-moving financial cycles and encourage productivity-enhancing reforms.

images.alt_text: The eurozone's massive debt burden continues to weigh on the region's growth and the Greece debacle is a warning of further dangers ahead.

site_title: Loan growth in focus for banks' Q2 results
summary: Singapore banks' second-quarter results will focus on loan growth and asset quality. Analysts expect a "multi-year low" of 3% loan growth this year due to the cooling property market and China. Despite concerns over asset quality, Nomura believes the banks' client base and risk profile are different from emerging market banks, making significant increases in non-performing loans unlikely. Moody's expects a stable outlook for the banking system, but notes declining bank profitability due to higher credit costs and slower loan growth.

site_title: Mafia and multinationals milk Italy's green energy boom
summary: Italy's green energy boom has attracted multinationals and mafia, with thousands of solar panels installed on farmland in Sardinia, despite concerns of corruption and job losses. Generous state subsidies have fueled the growth, but campaigners claim little of the profits have been reinvested locally, with many energy firms accused of making fraudulent claims. The Italian government has reduced subsidies, but the problems persist, with local communities fighting to protect their land and environment from exploitation.

site_title: Opposition parties declare contest areas
summary: Singapore opposition parties have declared contest areas for the upcoming General Election. The Workers' Party will contest 28 seats, including five GRCs and five Single Member Constituencies. The Democratic Progressive Party and Singaporeans First are targeting Tanjong Pagar GRC, while the Singapore Democratic Party is considering Bukit Batok SMC. Other parties, including the National Solidarity Party and Singapore People's Party, are also contesting various areas.

site_title: DBS Q2 net profit up 15 %, sees some uncertainty in H2
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported a 15% increase in second-quarter net profit to S$1.117 billion, exceeding analyst forecasts. The bank attributed the growth to an eight basis point rise in interest rate margin and healthy loan growth. DBS increased its first-half dividend to 30 cents a share from 28 cents a year ago. Despite a strong performance, the bank's second-half outlook is uncertain, but loan and business pipelines remain healthy.

images.alt_text: DBS Group Holdings, Singapore's biggest bank, on Monday posted a better-than-expected 15 per cent rise in second-quarter net profit, helped by an eight basis point jump in interest rate margin and healthy loan growth.

site_title: India's reforms target labour anarchy, but too late for some
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is set to introduce labour reforms aimed at reducing labour anarchy, but some businesses fear the changes will hike costs and make Indian garments less competitive. The proposed reforms will increase flexibility to hire and fire seasonal workers, but also extend the social security net, which could raise costs for firms like garment exporter Orient Craft. The changes are seen as a step towards making India a manufacturing hub, with Taiwan's Foxconn planning to set up 12 new factories and employ one million workers. However, some workers and unions fear the reforms will worsen conditions and push Indian businesses out of the global market.

site_title: Airbnb hires Blackstone's Laurence Tosi as CFO
summary: Airbnb has hired Laurence Tosi, former CFO of Blackstone Group LP, as its new CFO, filling a vacant position. Tosi brings expertise in hospitality and finance to the company, which is projecting $900 million in revenue this year. The hiring is seen as a precursor to an initial public offering, as it follows other Silicon Valley startups that have hired Wall Street talent, including Google and Twitter. Tosi's background in technology and finance makes him a good fit for the role, and his experience at Blackstone has helped the firm double its assets under management to $333 billion.

images.alt_text: Mr Tosi has been Blackstone's CFO since 2008 and has long been drawn to technology

site_title: But, I am only a sleeping director...
summary: Singapore's Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) has issued 10,000 summonses to "errant" directors each year for failing to comply with Companies Act requirements. To address this, Acra now offers a Directors Compliance Programme, which includes a half-day course to educate directors on their duties and responsibilities. The programme has seen over 160 directors attend since its launch in 2014. Repeat offenders face increased enforcement actions, including fines double the usual amount, and may also face reputational damage and potential disqualification.

site_title: GOME to buy US$1.45b retail assets from controlling shareholder
summary: Chinese home appliance retailer GOME Electrical Appliances Holding Ltd will acquire US$1.45 billion retail assets from its controlling shareholder Wong Kwong Yu, expanding its company-owned stores to 1,714 across 181 Chinese cities. The deal includes 578 existing stores, trademarked electrical appliance sales, and related consumer electronic product operations. Wong's stake in GOME will increase to 55.34% upon completion of the deal.

images.alt_text: Chinese home appliance retailer GOME Electrical Appliances Holding Ltd said it would buy retail assets from its controlling shareholder for HK$11.27 billion (US$1.45 billion), expanding its network of company-owned stores.

site_title: Barclays to boost Asian trade flows business
summary: Barclays is revamping its Asian trade flows business, hiring corporate bankers and relocating a key executive to Singapore. The bank plans to increase revenues in the region, driven by cross-border trade and investment between Asia and the UK, US, and Africa. Despite slowing growth in Asia, Barclays sees significant opportunities for its corporate banking business, which will focus on supporting Asian corporates and financial institutions in Europe, the Middle East, and Africa. The bank has established specific desks in India, China, and Japan to facilitate trade between these markets.

site_title: Technology, while not a fountain of youth, can make ageing safer
summary: Older adults are increasingly using technology to live safely and independently at home. Devices such as medical alert pendants, safety watches, and sensors can detect falls, medication reminders, and vital signs. These gadgets can help prevent serious illnesses and reduce hospital trips. Companies like Honor and CareLinx are connecting caregivers with older adults through in-home screens, while startups like AgeLab are developing smart home technology. Experts predict that technology will transform ageing in the next three to five years, enabling older adults to stay in their homes longer and more cheaply.

site_title: Grundfos has ambitious water technology plans in Asia
summary: Grundfos, a water pump manufacturer, plans to double its revenues in the Asia-Pacific region over the next five years. The company's regional headquarters in Singapore is a key part of this strategy, with the city-state establishing itself as a global water technology hub. As Singapore moves towards becoming a water self-sufficient nation, Grundfos aims to provide simpler and more cost-effective clean water treatment and desalination technology. The company has a presence in 22 countries in the Asia-Pacific and has reorganized its operations under four geographical clusters.

site_title: Toshiba scandal exposes Japan Inc's governance flaws
summary: A scandal at Toshiba has exposed Japan Inc's governance flaws, revealing a culture of collusion and poor external controls. The company's top executives pressured underlings to inflate profits by $1.2 billion since 2008, with a report finding senior managers complicit in the affair. Toshiba's rigid system of lifetime employment and loyalty to the company contributed to the scandal. The incident has led to the resignation of half the company's board, with experts warning that Japan's corporate traditions enabled the scheme and that similar problems exist in many other firms.

site_title: Largest US mall owner posts 22% jump in Q2 funds from operations
summary: Simon Property Group, the largest US mall owner, reported a 22% increase in second quarter funds from operations to $955.4 million, or $2.63 a share, driven by rising employment and a 22 cent share gain from securities sale. The company's full year forecast was also raised due to increased hiring. This growth is attributed to redevelopment efforts and joint ventures with retailers such as Sears Holdings and Hudson's Bay Co.

site_title: Singapore data centre operators eye China market
summary: Singapore's data centre market is experiencing robust growth, driven by high utilisation rates and a relatively lower power supply requirement. The country is emerging as an alternative gateway to China, with many co-location data centre service providers investing in building a China-Singapore footprint. The market is expected to reach US$1.2 billion in revenue by 2016, with 50 co-location service providers operating in the country. Local companies, such as Singtel and Equinix, are dominating the market, while international companies are also expanding their presence. The government's proactive policies and business-friendly environment have created a regional data centre hub, making Singapore an attractive location for international enterprises.

site_title: Critics of SGX should put things in perspective
summary: Critics of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) have made various demands for improvements, including boosting liquidity and scrapping the minimum trading price (MTP). However, it's essential to consider the task ahead in perspective. Liquidity has indeed dropped, but this is partly due to factors beyond SGX's control, such as monetary policy and the launch of the Hong Kong-Shanghai connect. Comparisons with Hong Kong and China are also unfair, as they enjoy a natural edge due to their geography. A more balanced approach is needed to address the market's challenges without being overly critical or reactive.

site_title: India aims to unlock value of its far-flung islands
summary: India's government aims to develop the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, a group of 556 islands, to promote tourism, trade, and military interests. However, this development plan poses a threat to the islands' pristine environment and the unique Jarawa tribe, which has lived on the islands for up to 55,000 years. Environmentalists and human rights groups warn that the plan could damage the tribes' cultural identity and put their way of life at risk. The government's push for development is seen as a collision course with these groups, who are concerned about the impact of tourism and infrastructure projects on the islands' fragile ecosystem.

site_title: National Day or election rally around the corner?
summary: The Singapore stock market has experienced a remarkable week of gains, with stocks like CEFC International and Qingmei posting significant percentage increases. However, experts warn that the momentum may soon slow down if interest flags or if the main drivers of the rally withdraw. The upcoming US Federal Open Market Committee meeting and the General Election in Singapore are expected to influence market sentiment, with the Fed potentially raising interest rates in September or December. Nomura predicts that elections will have a minimal impact on markets, as the macro environment will overshadow the outcome.

site_title: Two more schools to receive Sing50 baby grand pianos
summary: Two schools in Singapore, Canberra Primary and Yu Neng Primary, have received Steinway-designed Lang Lang baby grand pianos as part of the Sing50 Fund's "Adopt-A-Piano" initiative. The 50 pianos will debut at the Sing50 concert on Aug 7, where 50 pianists from across ages will perform simultaneously. The schools aim to promote Singapore's pop music heritage and enhance their arts, music, and aesthetics programs. This is the second and third school to benefit from the initiative, following Westwood Primary School, which was announced earlier this month.

site_title: Apollo seeking to raise US$3b for its new natural resources fund
summary: Apollo Global Management, a US$163 billion private equity firm, is seeking to raise up to US$3 billion for its new natural resources fund, Apollo Natural Resources II, LP. The fund aims to invest in energy, mining, and agriculture sectors in North America, taking advantage of fresh investment opportunities created by a slump in commodities prices. The fund will invest between US$100 million and US$300 million at a time, backing teams to make acquisitions or sell unloved assets, and is marketed to both institutional and retail investors.

site_title: Equipment reliability of Dreamliner leaves supplier with unsold spare parts
summary: Rockwell Collins, a supplier of cockpit displays for Boeing's 787 Dreamliner, is struggling with unsold spare parts due to the monitors being more reliable than expected. This has contributed to a 4% drop in air transport aftermarket sales. The company is adjusting its forecasts for other new jets, including the 737 Max and 777X, and plans to use the improved reliability to persuade operators of older Boeing models to upgrade to new equipment, taking advantage of depressed fuel prices.

site_title: Investors seek miners that can weather storm ahead
summary: Investors are scrutinizing mining companies' ability to weather the storm ahead, driven by a slump in metals prices and concerns over China's growth prospects. China accounts for half of global copper demand, 70% of iron ore consumption, and is seen growing at 7% this year, the slowest in a quarter of a century. Some miners, like Randgold Resources and Fresnillo, have been upgraded to "buy" by Citi, while others see opportunities for buying amid the market's wreckage, citing China's plans to boost infrastructure as a positive factor.

site_title: Striving for gender equality in Silicon Valley
summary: MARC Benioff, co-founder and CEO of Salesforce, launched the Women's Surge in 2013 to achieve 100% equality in pay and promotion for men and women. The initiative resulted in promotions for some women, but it wasn't until a review of 16,000 salaries revealed a significant pay gap that the company took action. Salesforce is now raising salaries of underpaid women, with the goal of achieving a more equitable workforce. The gender pay gap persists in Silicon Valley, with men earning up to 61% more than female peers, and companies like Google and Microsoft have been criticized for not doing enough to address the issue.

site_title: Total seeks buyer for half of Texas refinery
summary: Total SA is selling a 50% stake in its 225,000-barrels-per-day US refinery in Port Arthur, Texas, to a potential buyer, with investment bank Lazard advising on the deal. Total will remain the refinery's operator. The sale reflects the company's efforts to shift capital toward production and follows recent refinery sales by Exxon Mobil and Petroleos de Venezuela. The refinery's value is estimated to be around $188 million, and potential buyers include Canadian oil sands companies and PetroChina.

images.alt_text: Total has been trying to cut its exposure to refining since 2012, and plans to reduce its European refining and petrochemical capacity by 20 per cent by 2017.

site_title: Manulife FA in poaching row
summary: Manulife Financial Advisers (Manulife FA) is facing criticism from several industry players over its poaching practices and buyout packages offered to agents. The company has recruited 31 new representatives since its launch, exceeding its goal of doubling its advisers to 500 in one to two years. Industry players, including Zurich Life Insurance, Axa Singapore, and AIA Singapore, have expressed concerns that the aggressive recruitment tactics and buyout packages incentivize advisers to push Manulife products, rather than recommending the most suitable ones to clients.

site_title: OCBC, Great Eastern launch SG50 endowment plan
summary: OCBC Bank and Great Eastern have launched an SG50 five-year single premium endowment plan offering a guaranteed 2% annual payout. The plan, starting with a minimum premium of S$20,000, guarantees the total premium paid at maturity, providing the highest guaranteed returns in the market. Customers can choose between two payout options, with a total guaranteed amount of S$110,000 over five years.

site_title: Hedge funds set to lease record space in Mayfair, St James's
summary: Hedge funds and private equity firms are leasing a record amount of space in London's Mayfair and St James's neighborhoods this year, with alternative investment firms accounting for 29% of new office space rented in the area. This represents a 50% increase from last year and is driven by wealthy investors seeking to grow their business in a favorable economic environment. Property costs remain relatively low for hedge funds, with West End office rents at £120 per square foot, compared to £63.50 in the City of London.

site_title: Japan developer sells 10b yen of debt to individuals
summary: Tokyo Tatemono Co, a 119-year-old Japanese real estate company, has sold 10 billion yen (S$110 million) of debt to individuals in its first such offering in over a decade. The move follows strong sales of top-floor condominiums in Tokyo, with units selling for up to $3 million. The bonds, with a 0.59% coupon, offer a higher yield than fixed bank deposits, reflecting a favorable fundraising environment for the real estate sector. This is part of a trend of property developers seeking to access individual money as borrowing costs have plummeted under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's stimulus policies.

site_title: Weak China demand and stronger dollar drive down gold price
summary: Gold prices hit a multi-year low due to a stronger US dollar and weak Chinese demand, reaching its lowest point in nearly five and a half years at US$1,072.35 an ounce. Other precious metals such as silver and platinum also fell to their lowest levels in six years. Mining groups announced plans to cut staff by up to 12,000 due to weak metal prices. A stronger US currency makes dollar-denominated commodities more expensive for buyers using weaker currencies, denting demand and pulling prices lower.

site_title: Passing on wedding gifts, millennials prefer cash
summary: Millennials are shifting away from traditional wedding gifts, such as dinnerware and cookware, and instead opting for cash, home-repair gift cards, and lavish honeymoon experiences. Couples are registering with Simple Registry, which allows guests to contribute towards experiences like elephant camps, beach dinners, and snorkeling with whale sharks. Researchers attribute this trend to millennials' preference for experiences over material possessions, as well as their financial constraints and desire for independence. Etiquette experts agree that the new trend is acceptable as long as couples suggest and don't demand money.

site_title: Indonesia floats port expansion to boost economy
summary: Indonesia plans to expand its port network to boost its economy, with President Joko Widodo aiming to complete 24 ports by 2019. The New Priok port, set to be Indonesia's largest, is expected to handle 12.5 million containers a year, reducing transport costs and attracting foreign investment. However, experts warn that tackling bureaucracy and corruption will be crucial to the project's success, and the target date may be doubtful due to Indonesia's history of infrastructure delays.

site_title: Italian lender cuts exposure to Nomura as required by ECB
summary: Italian lender Monte dei Paschi di Siena has reduced its exposure to Japanese bank Nomura to within regulatory limits, as required by the European Central Bank. The bank had a 4.7 billion euro exposure to Nomura at the end of March, nearly half its total capital, but has since closed asset swap deals worth 500 million euros and completed a 3 billion euro capital increase. The exposure is linked to a loss-making derivative trade known as Alexandria, at the center of judicial investigations in Italy.

site_title: Job insecurities mar Spain's labour rebound
summary: Spain's job market is experiencing a labour rebound, with the unemployment rate falling to 22.4% but still affecting millions. However, short-term job contracts are exacerbating a two-tier labour market, leaving temporary workers in a precarious position. Many temporary workers, such as freelance property agent Eric Martin, are struggling to provide for their families due to low pay and lack of job security. The government acknowledges the issue, but critics argue that decades of abuse of temporary contracts by employers need to be addressed, and a one-contract-fits-all system should be introduced to provide better protection for workers.

site_title: Puerto Rico Electric Power investors to suffer interest loss under bondholder plan
summary: Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority (PREPA) investors face a 33% loss of interest income over eight years under a proposed debt restructuring plan. The plan, valued at $8.1 billion, would delay payments and give PREPA $2.5 billion to upgrade the utility's system. Under the proposal, interest payments from 2016 to 2023 would be reduced by $984 million, or 33%, affecting bondholders who purchased the securities at full value. The plan is part of Puerto Rico's efforts to address a $72 billion debt burden and avoid default.

site_title: Hungarian GP: Vettel wins for Bianchi and Ferrari on emotionally charged day
summary: Sebastian Vettel won the Hungarian Grand Prix for Ferrari, dedicating his victory to his late teammate Jules Bianchi. Vettel led from the start, dominating the race and drawing level with Ayrton Senna on the all-time win list. Red Bull's Daniil Kvyat finished second, and Vettel's emotional tribute to Bianchi, who died in a crash at the Japanese Grand Prix, was marked with a minute's silence before the race. Vettel's win marked Ferrari's first podium this year without a Mercedes driver, with Lewis Hamilton finishing sixth and enlarging his title advantage.

site_title: Blackstone unit buys 25 Manhattan apartment buildings: source
summary: Blackstone Group LP has agreed to buy 25 Manhattan apartment buildings in Chelsea and Upper East Side for approximately $700 million, its first purchase of rental housing in the borough. The 1,000-unit properties were built in the 1970s and '80s and will be owned by Blackstone with a majority stake.

site_title: Pearson in talks to sell 50% stake in The Economist
summary: Pearson is in talks to sell its 50% stake in The Economist to the remaining shareholders, including Italy's Agnelli family, which wants to increase its holding. The deal, which could take several weeks, comes after Pearson sold the Financial Times to Nikkei. The Agnelli family, a major shareholder in Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, is in talks to raise its stake to 4.72%. The sale would be a minority shareholding, and any changes to ownership would require the consent of the remaining shareholders and trustees.

site_title: When a giant sneezes
summary: China's recent stock market correction, rather than a crash, is unlikely to have significant consequences for the Chinese economy and businesses in the region. Key factors include the relatively small size of the stock market, the dominant role of bank financing in the economy, and limited exposure of foreign investors and households to the market. The correction is expected to have a limited impact, with the Shanghai Composite still up 100% from last year, and the government's efforts to stimulate the economy have shown positive effects.

site_title: Foreign insurers eyeing Iran cautiously following nuclear deal
summary: Western insurers are eyeing Iran as an attractive US$8 billion market following the country's nuclear deal with world powers. Eight out of 11 insurance and reinsurance specialists see Iran as an appealing market, particularly in the marine and energy sectors. However, uncertainty over when sanctions will be lifted means they are treating the country with caution, with some firms saying they won't start researching the market until sanctions are repealed. The process of rescinding sanctions could start around the end of this year, and Iran's large oil and gas sector, young educated population, and growing economy make it an attractive opportunity.

site_title: Brazil building execs accused in 'Carwash' graft scandal
summary: Brazilian federal prosecutors formally accused top builders Marcelo Odebrecht and Otavio Marques de Azevedo of corruption, money laundering, and forming a criminal organization in the country's largest corruption scandal, "Carwash". The accusations include bribery and embezzlement at state-run Petrobras, with losses of 6 billion reais. The executives deny any wrongdoing, while prosecutors seek restitution of 6.7 billion reais from Odebrecht and 486 million reais from Andrade Gutierrez.

site_title: US stocks could rebound this week on brighter economic data
summary: US stocks are poised for a rebound this week due to brighter economic data, including a 7% GDP growth rate in China's second quarter. The Federal Reserve's policy statement is also expected to provide a boost. Despite a sharp decline last week, US corporations have been beating Wall Street estimates, with 186 out of 186 companies surpassing average analyst targets. A positive Q2 GDP growth rate and a potential rate hike by the Fed are also expected to reassure investors.

site_title: Shareholding spread enough to enable operation of orderly market: CEFC
summary: CEFC International, a Singapore-based petrochemical and fuel oil trader, disclosed its shareholding data to the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after being queried about unusual trading activity. The company's controlling shareholder, Singapore Petrochemical & Energy Development Pte Ltd, holds 76.58% of the company's shares, with the public float at 23.42%. CEFC stated that its controlling shareholder has not sold or bought any shares since March 13 and that the company is in compliance with SGX listing rules. The query is the second within a week and the third in the past month.

site_title: Election should be 'soon', says Tan Chuan-Jin
summary: Singapore's next election is expected to take place soon, according to Social and Family Development Minister Tan Chuan-Jin. He and fellow MP Tin Pei Ling visited residents in MacPherson, a single-seat constituency set to be formed in the next election. The visit occurred before the Electoral Boundaries Review Committee's report was released on Friday.

site_title: The importance of setting realistic sales targets
summary: Insurance agents and financial advisers are often poached due to low basic salaries and high commission-based income. Buyout packages, which allow companies to recruit experienced advisers, can be lucrative but lack regulation, leading to concerns about competitiveness and ethics. Industry players acknowledge the need for fair-dealing practices and realistic sales targets to retain advisers and build trust with clients. Companies must set achievable targets to ensure long-term sustainability and avoid customer complaints, as building trust takes years to establish but can be lost in seconds.

site_title: Clinton proposes tax, buyback changes to encourage long-term growth
summary: Hillary Clinton proposed US corporate tax reforms, including a sliding scale for capital gains taxes, greater transparency for stock buybacks, and changes in executive compensation to encourage long-term economic growth. She criticized the US government for pouring subsidies into thriving industries and called for companies to counter "hit and run" activist shareholders. Clinton's tax policy aims to counter "quarterly capitalism" and promote long-term growth, but has been criticized by Republicans as outdated and favoring big-money donors.

site_title: Temasek chief executive officer Ho extends sabbatical to October
summary: Temasek Holdings Pte CEO Ho Ching is extending her six-month sabbatical, which she began in April, to October 2015. The decision was made due to her husband, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, undergoing prostate cancer surgery. Ho will continue to serve on the board and specific stewardship duties, with Lee Theng Kiat covering the normal course of business during her absence.

site_title: Two sides to the penny rally
summary: Singapore-listed penny stocks surged 13.9% on average between July 16 and 23, outpacing the rest of the market. The smallest 20% of stocks saw their daily turnover-to-market cap ratio rise by 0.5 percentage point, with prices also climbing. Analysts attribute the rally to speculation, with one saying it's a short-term phenomenon, while another hopes it may be the start of a sustained run. The broader market, however, faces concerns over a slowing economy and potential rerating amid disappointing earnings.

site_title: Greek bailout talks pushed back by a few days on logistics-official
summary: Greek bailout talks have been delayed by a couple of days due to logistical issues, with technical teams starting talks on Tuesday and mission chiefs arriving a day later. The delay is not due to political or diplomatic reasons, according to a finance ministry official. Greece is seeking a new bailout package worth up to 86 billion euros, with Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras struggling to contain a rebellion in his left-wing Syriza party. The country's debt is around 170% of GDP, and a debt relief is expected to be discussed.

site_title: Hedge funds in net-short position on gold for first time
summary: Hedge funds have taken a net-short position on gold for the first time since 2006, betting on a decline in gold prices. In the week ending July 21, 11,345 contracts were held in New York futures and options, with gold prices falling to their lowest since 2010. The decline is attributed to mounting speculation on US interest rate hikes, a stronger dollar, and reduced Chinese demand. Experts predict the worst is yet to come for gold, with prices potentially falling below $1,000 an ounce for the first time since 2009.

site_title: Britain may vote on EU membership in 2016: report
summary: Britain's Prime Minister David Cameron plans to hold a referendum on EU membership in June 2016, according to a report. Cameron has promised to renegotiate Britain's EU membership terms before the referendum, which he aims to hold by the end of 2017. The Conservative government will campaign in favor of remaining in the EU, pushing for reforms on welfare, powers for London, and opting out of closer integration. The decision comes amid recent turmoil in Greece and aims to avoid a political issue in 2017 French and German elections.

site_title: Powerful typhoon kills 11,000 farmed tuna in Japan: reports
summary: A powerful typhoon, Typhoon Nangka, has killed over 11,000 farmed bluefin tuna in Japan, causing $10 million in damage. The storm made landfall on July 16 and caused torrential rain and high waves, driving the tuna into a barrier. The loss is estimated at 1.29 billion yen ($14.3 million). The incident highlights the unsustainable pressure on the bluefin tuna species due to surging global demand, particularly for farmed tuna in Japan.

site_title: Another Great Depression in the making?
summary: A global economic downturn, similar to the Great Depression, is possible due to reliance on the US dollar, deflation, and lack of leadership. The US economy is experiencing weak growth, and the Federal Reserve is planning to hike interest rates, which could prompt global tightening. The world is heavily reliant on US capital loans and dollar liquidity, making it vulnerable to a slowdown. Overproduction and price collapse in commodities markets are also contributing to deflation, which can spread globally. The lack of global leadership and coordination to address these issues makes a potential economic downturn more likely.

site_title: Mr Bean's royal Cinderella tale
summary: Mr. Bean, a Singapore-based soya milk chain, has grown from a small stall to a 49-outlet chain over the past 20 years, with over 10 overseas outlets. Founder Loh Jwee Poh attributes the growth to a focus on quality and a homely culture, where employees and customers feel welcome. Despite a reduction in stores, sales have grown 2% over the last year, driven by centralising production and boosting productivity. Mr. Loh plans to expand globally, with a focus on Asian markets and convenience-driven products. The company is also open to listing on the stock market or being acquired.

site_title: Oil falls to lowest close since March, down a fourth week
summary: Oil prices fell to their lowest close since March, with Brent and US crude futures declining for a fourth straight week. Weak economic data from China, a rise in US oil drilling rigs, and a stronger US dollar contributed to the decline. US crude fell 21% from its June close, entering bear market territory, while Brent settled at its lowest close since March 19. The world's top oil companies are expected to report another drop in profits, leading to potential spending cuts.

site_title: Swing in style
summary: Puma has incorporated adaptive materials into its golf fashion, allowing golfers to maintain optimal body temperature during play. This technology aims to keep golfers cool without hindering their performance.

site_title: Masters of the game
summary: The Rolex brand has solidified its presence in golf through its association with organizations like the American Junior Golf Association. This has led to the brand becoming synonymous with golf. No other key information is available in the provided article.

site_title: Pearson in talks to sell The Economist share
summary: Pearson is in talks to sell its 50% stake in The Economist Group, owner of The Economist magazine, for £400 million. The sale comes after Pearson agreed to sell the Financial Times to Nikkei for £844 million. Other shareholders, including the Agnelli family, are in talks to increase their stake in The Economist. Any deal must be approved by the trustees of the Economist Group, who aim to preserve the magazine's editorial independence.

site_title: Workers' Party to contest in Marine Parade and MacPherson
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) announced plans to contest the Marine Parade Group Representation Council (GRC) and MacPherson Single Member Constituency (SMC) in the upcoming elections. WP secretary-general Low Thia Khiang confirmed the party's decision to contest these seats during a walkabout in Punggol East. The party has been actively working on the ground in Marine Parade GRC and Joo Chiat SMC, which will be absorbed into Marine Parade GRC.

site_title: US: Wall St slides to end rough week on macro, earnings concerns
summary: US stocks ended a rough week on Friday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq posting their largest weekly drops since March. Slowing global growth and concerns over macroeconomic indicators, including weaker-than-expected economic data from China and the euro zone, weighed on the market. Biogen's earnings report, which more than halved its revenue growth forecast, also contributed to the decline. However, Amazon's unexpected quarterly profit boosted the online retailer's market cap to $247 billion, making it the 10th-largest US company by market value.

site_title: Greece asks for fresh IMF aid in step closer to bailout
summary: Greece formally requested fresh IMF aid, taking a step closer to a third international bailout worth up to 86 billion euros. The Greek government has passed two laws enshrining austerity measures, and Finance Minister Euclid Tsakalotos wrote to Christine Lagarde that Greece is seeking a new loan. The IMF confirmed receipt of the request, with talks expected to discuss timing and modalities. Greece's existing aid program runs until early 2016, and the request comes amid delays in finalizing the package.

site_title: Keeping the ringgit below US$3.80
summary: The ringgit currency weakened past the six-year high of 3.80 against the US dollar due to investor loss of confidence in Malaysia's 1MDB situation. Despite strong Q1 GDP growth and low inflation, the BNM may consider measures to maintain the ringgit's strength, such as policy changes or interest rate adjustments. However, with interest rates already high and potential risks of inflation, alternative approaches like increasing demand for the ringgit may be considered. The BNM is likely to intervene if the ringgit weakens further, and investors can use non-deliverable forwards to take positions on the currency.

site_title: Secrecy around TPP trade deal fuels suspicions and worries
summary: US, Japan, and 10 other Pacific Rim countries are set to finalize the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal, despite secrecy surrounding the negotiations. The deal aims to create a new international framework for trade in services, investment, and intellectual property, with potential benefits of $295 billion in annual global income. Critics, however, express concerns that the agreement will primarily benefit corporations, not economies and people, with higher costs to consumers from increased protections for intellectual property. The deal's completion is under pressure from the US to finalize before the 2016 elections.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler US to recall vehicles to prevent hacking
summary: Fiat Chrysler US is recalling 1.4 million vehicles to install software that prevents hackers from remotely controlling engine, steering, and other systems. The recall comes after researchers demonstrated hacking into a Jeep Cherokee's engine using a wireless connection. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) will investigate whether the software upgrade is sufficient to protect consumers. The recall is seen as a major step in addressing cybersecurity concerns in the automotive industry, with experts warning of the risks of increasing connectivity to physical devices.

site_title: CEFC says shareholding spread sufficient to enable operation of an orderly market (Amended)
summary: CEFC International disclosed that its shareholding spread is sufficient to enable an orderly market, following requests from the Singapore Exchange due to unusual trading activities. The company's controlling shareholder, Singapore Petrochemical & Energy Development Pte Ltd, retains 76.58% of its shares. This move aims to alleviate concerns about market volatility and instability.

site_title: Focus turns to The Economist after FT sale
summary: The Economist Group, a 184-year-old British magazine, is at risk of changing ownership as its co-owner Pearson focuses on education. Pearson, which owns 50% of The Economist Group, has pledged to exit the news industry but retains control due to a series of wealthy families, including the Cadbury and Rothschild families, holding A shares with greater voting rights. Any change in ownership would require consensus among these A shareholders, who are unlikely to sell to Pearson. The group's profitability is estimated to be worth between 300-400 million pounds, and individual shareholders may need to raise cash to finance a potential deal.

site_title: Amazon passes Wal-Mart as biggest retailer by market value
summary: Amazon surpassed Wal-Mart as the world's biggest retailer by market value after a surprise second-quarter profit, with its stock rising 9.8% to $529.42. Amazon's market value reached $247.6 billion, surpassing Wal-Mart's $230.5 billion. Despite Wal-Mart's larger sales, Amazon has solidified its dominance in e-commerce, forcing the retailer to invest heavily in its web operations and online subscription service. Amazon's revenue grew 20% to $23.2 billion, exceeding analysts' average projection.

site_title: Professionalising management of the family business
summary: A well-established family governance framework is crucial for the success of family businesses, allowing them to navigate complex family dynamics and make effective decisions. This framework evolves through generations and adapts to changing circumstances. Key elements include setting clear roles, defining ownership and stewardship, and establishing a consistent decision-making process. A comprehensive framework also involves setting defined expectations, agreeing on family values, and utilizing non-family advisers for objectivity. Ultimately, there is no one-size-fits-all solution, and each family's unique circumstances require personalized advice from wealth structuring and family governance specialists.

site_title: Freedom vital for business, creativity: HK Chief Secretary
summary: Hong Kong Chief Secretary Carrie Lam emphasized the importance of freedom in nurturing creativity and entrepreneurship, stating it is central to the city's global competitiveness. The city retained its top spot as "The World's Freest Economy" in The Heritage Foundation's index. Lam highlighted the role of creative industries in Hong Kong's economy, citing a 9% annual growth rate, and announced plans to boost the West Kowloon Cultural District and provide financial support for local talent through the CreateSmart initiative.

site_title: China to allow wider yuan trading range
summary: China's State Council announced plans to allow the yuan to trade in a wider range against the US dollar, increasing flexibility and potentially allowing for depreciation. The move aims to support China's trade and boost exports. The yuan's trading band could be widened to 3%, and the PBOC may reduce its intervention in the existing band. This move is seen as a step towards China's goal of becoming a global reserve currency.

site_title: Anthem to buy Cigna, creating biggest US health insurer
summary: Anthem Inc. has agreed to buy Cigna Corp for approximately $54.2 billion, creating the largest US health insurer by membership. The deal, which is the health insurance industry's largest, comes after Aetna Inc's $37 billion acquisition of Humana Inc. The proposed merger aims to reduce costs and negotiate lower prices with doctors and hospitals. However, regulators and lawmakers have expressed concerns about the impact on competition and consumer access to healthcare, with several lawmakers and medical associations warning of potential price increases and limited access to providers.

site_title: Indonesian mining firms find it tough going
summary: Indonesian mining firms face significant challenges due to the country's mineral export ban, implemented in 2014. The ban has resulted in massive losses for the industry, with Indonesia's mining export revenue plummeting from $3.09 billion in 2013 to $1.92 billion in 2015. Many companies are struggling to build smelters, with high costs and weak infrastructure cited as major stumbling blocks. The government is now considering relaxing the ban, with top officials exploring legal possibilities. Despite the challenges, some companies remain optimistic about the long-term prospects for the industry, particularly for bauxite and aluminium.

site_title: FCOT raises S$142.1m from upsized private placement
summary: FRASERS Commercial Trust (FCOT) has raised S$142.1 million from an upsized private placement, with the net proceeds primarily used to finance the acquisition of a Melbourne office building and paying down existing debt. The trust intends to declare an "advanced distribution" of 0.7805 Singapore cents per unit to existing unitholders, with the payment expected on or around October 1, 2015.

site_title: Stepping into the spotlight
summary: Chef Andrew Walsh's solo venture, Cure, in Singapore's Keong Saik Road, offers a unique dining experience with a focus on sustainable, farm-to-table ingredients. The open kitchen allows guests to witness Walsh's culinary philosophy in action. The fixed dinner menu, priced from $75 to $115, features dishes such as bacon butter, sourdough bread, and scallops paired with pickled kohlrabi and pea cream. While some courses may be too safe, the restaurant's commitment to quality ingredients and hospitality shines through. With a rating of 7, Cure shows promise but needs to take more risks to truly stand out.

site_title: Ugly duckling refineries turning into swans
summary: Refineries in north-west Europe are experiencing a resurgence in profitability, with margins rising fivefold in the last quarter to the highest since 2003. The turnaround follows the decline of the oil boom, which tripled the cost of crude for processing since 2009. As a result, oil companies are shifting focus from drilling to refining, with Shell and BP reporting significant profits from trading and refining. The European refining industry is expected to cut capacity by 700,000 barrels a day, which may support margins and earnings for integrated oil companies.

site_title: Microsoft aims to reboot connections with Windows 10
summary: Microsoft is launching Windows 10, aiming to build lasting relationships with users and developers, offering the operating system for free as an upgrade to Windows 7 and 8.1 users. The goal is to have Windows 10 powering a billion devices by 2018, creating a massive audience for developers to create must-have apps. This move is seen as a shift from Microsoft's traditional packaged software sales to a more ongoing relationship with users, with the aim of increasing opportunities for the company to make money from online activities.
