summary: The International Monetary Fund warns that Japan's debt risks are unsustainable, potentially reaching triple the size of its economy by 2030, unless the government takes action to cut its budget. The IMF recommends rules to curb spending, limits on extra budgets, and independent assessments of its projections. Japan's reliance on optimistic economic assumptions risks harming confidence in its plan to put the budget into surplus by 2020. The IMF also suggests that the Bank of Japan should increase monetary stimulus and provide stronger guidance to markets.

site_title: Thai regulator to shake up mutual fund industry
summary: Thailand's Securities and Exchange Commission plans to introduce regulations by September to allow the launch of hedge funds and junk bond funds, a move expected to shake up the country's 3.5 trillion baht mutual fund industry. The goal is to encourage investors to keep funds onshore and reduce capital outflows, which were relaxed by the Bank of Thailand in April to weaken the baht. The move aims to provide higher yields to investors seeking riskier investment instruments.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.47% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.47% at the open on Friday, following a third straight loss on Wall Street and a regional sell-off. The Hang Seng Index eased 118.90 points to 25,279.95. The decline is attributed to a regional sell-off, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Ringgit forwards extend weekly losses as oil enters bear market
summary: Malaysia's Ringgit forwards declined for a fifth week, extending weekly losses, due to oil entering a bear market and eroding export earnings. The nation's foreign reserves fell to a five-year low, signaling potential central bank intervention to curb losses. Oil prices dropped 52% from 2014's high, putting pressure on Malaysia's current-account surplus, which accounts for 22% of government revenue. The decline in reserves and oil prices are contributing to investor sentiment, with the ringgit expected to remain under pressure.

images.alt_text: Ringgit forwards headed for this year's longest stretch of weekly declines as oil re-entered a bear market, eroding Malaysia's export earnings.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust raises S$142.1m from upsized placement
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) raised S$142.1 million from a private placement of 96 million new units at S$1.48 apiece, exceeding the top end of the price range. The trust plans to use the net proceeds, S$140.2 million, primarily to finance the acquisition of 357 Collins Street in Melbourne and pay down existing debt. The advanced distribution of 0.7805 Singapore cents per unit will be made to existing unitholders, excluding the new placement units, with a payment expected on or around Oct 1, 2015.

site_title: China: Shares slightly higher in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares rose slightly on Friday morning, following six previous sessions of gains, after the government launched market-boosting measures. The Shanghai Composite Index increased 0.02% to 4,124.75, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.36% to 2,361.16. This marks a slight reversal from the previous sessions, where shares gained for the sixth consecutive day. The gains are attributed to the government's efforts to boost the market.

site_title: AIA Singapore achieves a 19% growth in value of new business
summary: AIA Group's Singapore insurance unit reported a 19% increase in value of new business (VONB) to US$142 million for the six months ended May 31, 2015. Overall group VONB grew to US$959 million, with net operating profit rising 15% to US$1.6 billion. Despite a relatively flat industry environment, AIA's Singapore operations achieved strong results, with China becoming its second-largest market in terms of VONB.

site_title: Viva Industrial Trust's Q2 DPS jumps 7.3%
summary: Viva Industrial Trust reported a 7.3% increase in distribution per stapled security (DPS) for Q2, reaching 1.849 Singapore cents, driven by a 14.3% gain in distributable income to S$11.76 million. Net property income jumped 19.3% to S$12.2 million, while gross revenue expanded 17.1% to S$17.82 million. The trust's gearing has been reduced to 38.9%. CEO Wilson Ang attributed the results to the successful expansion of the portfolio through recent acquisitions.

site_title: China July factory activity falls to 15-mth low: Caixin flash PMI
summary: China's factory sector contracted by the most in 15 months in July, with the Caixin/Markit China Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 48.2, its lowest reading since April last year. Output in July dropped to 47.3, and new orders and export orders also fell. The contraction is expected to fuel speculation of further monetary policy easing to stimulate activity, with economists predicting a 25 basis point interest rate cut before the year-end. This would be the most aggressive easing cycle since the 2008 global financial crisis.

site_title: Singapore's June manufacturing output down 4.4%
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector contracted for the fifth consecutive month in June, with industrial output declining 4.4% year-on-year. The sector's decline was broad-based, with all clusters except chemicals experiencing contractions. The transport engineering cluster performed the worst, plummeting 17.5% year-on-year. Excluding biomedical manufacturing, output fell 4.6% month-on-month. The decline follows a 2.3% drop in May and a 9.1% fall in April.

images.alt_text: Singapore's manufacturing sector contracted for the fifth straight month in June, with industrial output down 4.4 per cent on a year-on-year basis due to broad-based declines in all clusters save chemicals.

site_title: Asia: Shares catch gloomy mood from Wall Street
summary: Asian shares fell on Friday, on track for a weekly loss, as Wall Street's gloomy mood spread. The dollar strengthened against the yen and euro, fueled by US jobless claims and interest rate expectations. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates later this year, supporting the greenback. In China, the manufacturing PMI is expected to show improvement, but fragile investor sentiment remains a concern. The benchmark US 10-year yield rose to 2.276%, while gold was steady but set for a weekly loss.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.39% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.39% on Friday, following consecutive US stock declines due to weak corporate earnings. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 80.32 points to 20,603.63. US stocks also declined, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.67%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.57% and 0.49%, respectively. The dollar rose slightly to 123.92 yen, while the euro edged up to US$1.0990 and 136.14 yen.

site_title: Nikkei bags FT for digital strategy, expansion of global readers
summary: Nikkei, Japan's largest financial news publisher, has acquired the Financial Times (FT) for $1.3 billion, marking a significant expansion of its global reach. The deal complements Nikkei's existing strengths in Japan and aims to bolster its emerging digital strategy. With the FT's 500-strong editorial team in 50+ locations worldwide, Nikkei seeks to increase its influence and strategic expertise, positioning itself for growth in the digital landscape. The acquisition is seen as a premium deal, surpassing recent newspaper purchases.

site_title: Private home prices, rents continue to fall in Q2, URA data show
summary: Singapore's private home prices and rents continued to fall in Q2, with the URA's private-home price index slipping 0.9% and rentals falling 1.1% compared to the previous quarter. Price declines were seen across all segments of the private residential property market, with landed properties shedding 1.0%. The vacancy rate of completed private residential units increased to 7.9% at the end of Q2. Despite this, developers sold 2,116 private homes and had 1,827 resale transactions in Q2, indicating some activity in the market.

site_title: Mylan foundation tries to block Teva takeover bid with poison pill
summary: An independent Dutch foundation linked to Mylan exercised a call option to buy 50% of the company, temporarily blocking a $40 billion Teva takeover bid citing potential job losses and reduced access to cheap generic medicines. Mylan's management is based in the Netherlands to reduce US tax liability, and the foundation claims to safeguard the company's "stakeholder interests." Teva has threatened to challenge the foundation's action in court, while analysts question the foundation's rationale for blocking the bid.

site_title: US probes banks in Fifa scandal: sources
summary: US regulators are investigating large banks including Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank, and HSBC over their handling of tainted funds in the FIFA corruption scandal. The Department of Justice and New York's Department of Financial Services are focusing on whether banks' internal controls failed to spot questionable payments by top FIFA officials. Other banks in the probes include Barclays, Standard Chartered, and Bank Hapoalim. Visa has expressed a lack of confidence in FIFA's leadership, calling for an independent commission to help reform the body.

site_title: Singapore office rents down 2.6% in Q2: URA
summary: Singapore's office rental prices rose 0.3% quarter-over-quarter in Q2, while the overall index decreased 2.6% compared to Q1. The amount of occupied office space increased by 38,000 sq m, while the stock of office space rose 8,000 sq m, resulting in a 9.8% vacancy rate at the end of Q2. Retail space prices fell 0.5% in Q2, with a 7.2% vacancy rate at the end of the quarter.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, SATS, Sheng Siong, OSIM
summary: Keppel Corp delayed the construction of a drillship and is working on financing for vessels for Sete Brasil. SATS reported a 14.5% year-on-year rise in net profit to S$49.6 million for the first quarter. Sheng Siong's net profit jumped 23.1% to S$13.6 million, with improved gross margin. OSIM International's net profit declined 24% to S$22.5 million, with revenue down 13% due to weak retail sentiment in Asia.

site_title: Singapore shares open 4.16 points higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 4.16 points to 3,360.53 on Friday, outperforming concerns over a commodity rout and Wall Street's decline. The blue-chip index gained an average unit price of S$1.05 per share, with 97.2 million shares changing hands. Global Logistic Properties led the gains, followed by Xpress Holdings and Foreland FabricTech. Gainers outnumbered losers 85 to 67, marking a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: US slaps sanctions on North Korea-linked shipping company
summary: The US imposed sanctions on Senat Shipping Company, a Singapore-based firm, and its president Leonard Lai, for allegedly supporting illicit arms imports into North Korea. The sanctions freeze US assets and prohibit transactions with the company and its president. This move targets a North Korean company already under sanctions for attempting to import arms into the country. The US aims to make it challenging for North Korea to continue its unlawful behavior by targeting those who support illicit arms transfers.

site_title: Caesars' parent faces bankruptcy after ruling
summary: US Bankruptcy Judge Benjamin Goldgar denied Caesars' request to stay four lawsuits by hedge fund creditors seeking up to $11 billion, sending Caesars' stock plummeting 41% to $4.76. The hedge funds allege Caesars guaranteed debts of Caesars Entertainment Operating Co, Inc. The company had sought to stay the lawsuits to reach a consensual overhaul of its $18 billion debt, but the judge's decision raises the risk of Caesars facing bankruptcy.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Brokers' take on two Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (REITs): 
- Hutchison Port Holdings Trust maintained "hold" with a target price of US$0.65 due to modest earnings improvement and subdued dividend payout.
- CapitaLand Mall Trust upgraded to "add" with a target price of S$2.37 after Q2 results met expectations, with improved shopper traffic and tenant sales expected in the second half.
- CIMB Research also upgraded CMT, citing a potential acquisition and redevelopment plan for Funan.

site_title: CapitaLand Commercial Trust's Q2 DPU up 0.5%
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a 0.5% year-over-year increase in Q2 distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.19 Singapore cents. Income available for distribution rose 0.5% to S$64.43 million, driven by rent increases and higher occupancy rates. Net property income grew 3.6% to S$53.86 million, while gross revenue increased 5% to S$69.11 million. The trust's portfolio occupancy rate reached 98% and monthly average office gross rent rose to S$8.88 per square foot. CCT's balance sheet remains robust with a gearing of 29.5%.

site_title: Zero-pollution buses emerge with backing from Silicon Valley
summary: Seattle is rolling out two all-electric buses made by Proterra Inc., backed by Silicon Valley and Warren Buffett, as part of a six-month trial. The buses, which can carry 120 passengers, will be charged from 95% renewable electricity, making them emissions-free. The trials in Seattle, Dallas, San Antonio, and Worcester, Massachusetts, show battery-powered buses can be quieter and cheaper than traditional diesel models, with significant fuel cost savings over their lifetime. Analysts predict that by 2020, 59% of the world's transit buses will be electric hybrids and 12% will be all-electric.

site_title: White House clears way for Shell to drill in Arctic
summary: The US government has cleared the way for Shell to start drilling in the Arctic Ocean this summer, despite environmental concerns. The Interior Department granted a permit allowing Shell to drill at the top of the seabed, but not to penetrate into oil reserves until a capping stack is deployed. Environmentalists fear a drilling accident could be devastating, citing the 2010 BP spill. The permit's safety restrictions may slow the pace of drilling, and Shell's nearest capping stack is currently en route to Oregon for repairs.

site_title: Visa joins Coke in call for independent body to reform Fifa
summary: Visa and Coca-Cola have joined forces to call for an independent commission to reform the way FIFA is run. The call comes after a series of corruption allegations and a US indictment of nine FIFA officials and five marketing executives in May. Visa CEO Charlie Scharf stated that FIFA's responses to the allegations were "wholly inadequate" and that the organization is not living up to its standards. Scharf emphasized the need for an independent commission to formulate reforms and stated that meaningful change cannot be made under FIFA's existing leadership.

site_title: Oil prices slide on concerns about ample supplies
summary: Oil prices dropped Thursday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling 74 cents to $48.45 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude falling 86 cents to $55.27 a barrel. Concerns about abundant global supplies, particularly from OPEC's record production levels, are cited as reasons for the decline. Analysts predict the market will remain supplied, with demand expected to pick up in the second half of the year, and prices unlikely to recover anytime soon.

site_title: BlackBerry prepared to move past smartphones, CEO Chen says
summary: BlackBerry CEO John Chen says the company may be forced to stop making smartphones if turnaround efforts fail, citing a 31% drop in smartphone revenue to $263 million in the latest quarter. Chen plans to focus on professionals and government workers, and possibly discontinue low-end devices, to bring the smartphone business back to profitability. The company has already outsourced manufacturing and is shifting focus to software sales, aiming to double revenue to $500 million. Chen believes the device business is not BlackBerry's "sweet spot" and that the company may exit the market if current efforts don't gain traction.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust's Q1 DPU up 3.1%
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust posted a 3.1% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.01 Singapore cents for its first quarter ended June 30, 2015. Gross revenue rose 1.6% to S$69.7 million, driven by portfolio properties and reduced operating expenses. VivoCity delivered a 3.8% year-on-year rise in gross revenue and 8.8% in net property income. The Reit's debt was fully refinanced, and the balance sheet was strengthened with longer tenor borrowings. Unitholders can expect to receive the distribution on Sept 4.

site_title: Rare kampung spirit caught on camera
summary: Documentary filmmakers Mark Chua and Mark Kwan capture the rare "kampung spirit" of Dakota Crescent, one of Singapore's oldest public housing estates, in their film Heartland. The 1958-built neighbourhood, set for redevelopment, showcases a strong sense of community and tradition among its residents, who have maintained a close-knit bond despite changes in their lives. The filmmakers highlight the efforts of residents, including Roger Neo, who continue to support and care for one another, and the area's unique architecture, which has become a nostalgic charm.

site_title: GM earnings surge on solid sales in US, China
summary: General Motors reported a quadrupling of quarterly earnings to $1.1 billion, driven by solid sales in the US and China. The company's North America region saw a 10.5% profit margin, its highest quarterly record, while GM International Operations in China saw a 10.8% increase. Despite a 3.7% dip in revenue, GM attributed the drop to the strong dollar. The company aims to reach a 10% profit margin in 2016, with plans to manage the Chinese market through cost cutting and boosting output of popular SUV models.

site_title: Reluctance to move on from the euro
summary: Economists have long warned that the European Monetary Union (EMU) was a flawed experiment, but many have been reluctant to admit its failure. Despite the eurozone's costly failures, economists have instead focused on reforming the existing system rather than abandoning it. However, the lack of progress in implementing reforms has led to increased skepticism and polarization, with the rise of anti-European parties. The author argues that it's time to accept the euro's failure and consider an end to the euro, rather than risking further damage to the European project.

site_title: US: Caterpillar, Amex earnings disappointments push stocks lower
summary: US stocks fell for a third straight day on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 119.09 points to 17,731.95, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declining. Disappointing earnings from Caterpillar, American Express, and others, including a 47% drop in Qualcomm's earnings, contributed to the decline. However, some stocks, such as Under Armour and General Motors, rose after reporting better-than-expected earnings. The market's valuation concerns and softness in key sectors, particularly in China, also weighed on investor sentiment.

site_title: Did Beijing overreact?
summary: China's recent intervention to halt a sharp sell-off in its stock markets may be seen as an overreaction by foreign investors, who remain skeptical about the country's commitment to market reforms. Despite a 30% drop in Shanghai's domestic A shares, the market has still shown resilience, with the index up 150% since the start of the bull market. The government's measures, including suspending trading in half of the market, have not convinced investors that Beijing is serious about reforms, which could harm its efforts to attract international capital and position the renminbi as a global currency.

site_title: S Korea growth slows as Mers dampens consumer spending
summary: South Korea's economy slowed in the second quarter due to the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) outbreak, which dampened consumer spending. GDP grew 0.3% from the previous quarter, below forecast, and expanded 2.2% from a year earlier. The Bank of Korea trimmed its growth forecast to 2.8% and warned of economic risks, including the Greek crisis and China's stock market. Exports have fallen every month this year, and private sector consumption fell 0.3% in the second quarter.

site_title: Dollar slips in profit taking
summary: The US dollar slipped in profit-taking after a strong week, with traders taking profits from its gains. Despite a report showing new US unemployment claims fell to a nearly 42-year low, the dollar's weakness was attributed to technical factors rather than fundamental changes in sentiment. The euro gained ground after Greece's parliament approved reform measures, but analysts warned the gains were a "relief rally" that may not last. The euro's appreciation is seen as a temporary reprieve, with the path ahead expected to be challenging for Greece and investors.

site_title: Amazon shares surge after surprise profit report
summary: Amazon's shares surged 17% after the company reported a surprise net profit of $92 million in the second quarter, driven by a 20% revenue increase to $23.18 billion. The Seattle-based e-commerce giant credited its diverse offerings, including Emmy-nominated TV shows and cloud computing services, for the results. Amazon Web Services saw an 80% revenue jump to $1.8 billion, and the company offered a better-than-expected outlook for the current quarter, predicting revenues of $23.3 billion to $25.5 billion.

site_title: Pearson sells Financial Times to Japan's Nikkei for £844m
summary: Pearson has sold its Financial Times to Japan's Nikkei for £844m in cash, marking a significant shift in the global media landscape. The sale includes the FT Group's digital assets, including FT.com, but excludes the FT's stake in The Economist Group and its London headquarters. Nikkei, the largest independent business media group in Asia, aims to leverage the FT's global reputation and digital presence to drive growth and success. The deal follows a period of restructuring and cost-cutting for Pearson, which will focus on its education division.

site_title: Value of F&N's Myanmar asset settled
summary: Frasers & Neaves (F&N) is set to sell its 55% stake in Myanmar Brewery to Myanma Economic Holdings, with a fair value estimate of S$549.2 million (500 billion kyat). However, Myanma Economic Holdings disputes F&N's valuation of US$560 million at 2013 exchange rates. The sale must be completed within a 30-day period ordered by an arbitral tribunal. The deal represents a significant improvement from Myanma's original offer of US$246 million in 2013.

site_title: MAS proposes tighter FI marketing controls
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed enhanced safeguards and controls for the sale of financial products by financial institutions (FIs) at public places and via third-party retailers. FIs will be required to notify MAS of their marketing and distribution activities and implement measures such as callbacks, mystery site visits, and tracking complaints. The proposals aim to balance flexibility with consumer protection, particularly for unsuitable product sales. MAS invites comments from interested parties by August 24.

site_title: Vietnam's name-and-shame corporate tax list gets quick success
summary: Vietnam has released a list of 600 companies that owe taxes overdue by over 121 days, with the goal of shaming them into paying up. The Ministry of Finance has vowed to freeze bank accounts and deduct past taxes. The public embarrassment led to 65 Hanoi-based companies paying their taxes, but the country still needs to find additional revenue to fund infrastructure projects and pay off public debt. The move is seen as a way to address the country's tax collection challenges, but more needs to be done to meet the government's funding needs.

site_title: Sensibly joining hands to confront a common danger
summary: The historic Iran nuclear deal, reached by major world powers including China, marked the Obama administration's biggest diplomatic achievement in six years. China, initially accused of proliferation activities, played a key role in negotiations, setting aside differences with the US to present a united front against Iran's nuclear ambitions. Despite differing views on arms restrictions, the deal successfully achieved both goals, paving the way for increased business opportunities between China and Iran, with China to play a key part in implementing the agreement, particularly in modifying the Arak heavy water reactor.

site_title: Maldives to allow foreigners to own land
summary: Maldives lawmakers have voted to allow foreign ownership of land for the first time, paving the way for foreign companies to own land in perpetuity after investing over $1 billion. The move has sparked concerns over a possible land grab, with opposition lawmakers fearing increased Chinese involvement in the atoll nation. The bill passed with 70 votes in favor and 14 against, and is expected to be ratified by the president. The move comes amid ongoing political unrest in the Maldives, where the country's former strongman leader is urging public debate on the constitutional amendment.

site_title: Hong Kong IPOs lift global cross-border listing activity
summary: US cross-border IPOs raised US$15.6 billion in the first half of 2015, a 75% increase from the previous year, driven by China companies listing in Hong Kong. This segment saw a 24% decline in global cross-border IPOs to US$20.6 billion. North America saw a decline in IPOs due to companies being cash-rich, while Europe, the Middle East, and Africa also experienced a decline. Despite this, Asia-Pacific is expected to promote stronger market environments, creating hubs for investment, particularly for emerging Chinese, Southeast Asian, and Indian companies.

images.alt_text: Money raised from global cross-border initial public offerings (IPO) - companies not listing on their domestic exchange - fell 24 per cent to US$20.6 billion in the first half of 2015 compared to a year ago.

site_title: Thailand at forefront of curbing alcohol consumption in Asia-Pacific
summary: Thailand is set to ban alcohol sales near universities and technical colleges, a move aimed at promoting a healthy lifestyle and tackling alcohol-related problems. The ban, to be implemented nationwide in late August, prohibits bars, clubs, and retailers from selling alcoholic beverages within a 300-metre radius of colleges. This measure follows similar policies introduced by other Asian countries, including Vietnam, the Philippines, and Indonesia, to curb alcohol consumption. The goal is to reduce underage drinking and related issues, such as sex. The ban will be enforced nationwide in late August.

site_title: Local artworks on the move
summary: Uber partners with ArtLoft to showcase five local artworks on 50 Singapore roads until August 9. The artworks were selected by Uber passengers who chose from promo codes linked to the artworks. ArtLoft will donate half of the sales proceeds from limited edition prints to The Business Times Budding Artists Fund. Uber will donate $1 for every ride taken in the art-on-the-move cars. The artworks, created by five local artists, will also be available for purchase online.

site_title: Trouble at the top of the food chain
summary: Singapore's food bloggers and social media influencers are raising concerns about ethics and credibility in the city-state's competitive food and beverage (F&B) industry. Restaurants are increasingly paying for meals and hosting events to secure positive reviews, creating a perceived conflict of interest. This practice has led to questions about the objectivity of reviews and the potential for bias. Industry experts and bloggers disagree on the issue, with some arguing that it's essential for restaurants to engage with social media and bloggers to stay relevant, while others claim that it compromises the credibility of reviews. The practice has sparked debate beyond Singapore, with similar issues raised in the UK's World's 50 Best Restaurants list.

site_title: Singapore June inflation mired in negative territory
summary: Singapore's inflation rate remained in negative territory for the eighth consecutive month in June, at -0.3%, driven by increases in services, food, and private road transport costs. Core inflation, which excludes accommodation and private road transport, rose to 0.2% and is expected to remain subdued. Headline inflation is forecast to ease further, potentially breaching the Monetary Authority of Singapore's forecast range, and is expected to come in at the lower end of the -0.5-to-0.5% forecast for 2015.

site_title: Why the drachma is history
summary: Greece's economic commentators, including those who support the country's EU membership, have long advocated for the country to return to its own currency, the drachma. However, this idea is met with widespread opposition from the Greek people, who have consistently expressed their desire to remain in the eurozone. A recent referendum saw 60% of voters reject creditors' packages while still affirming their commitment to Europe. The author argues that instead of telling Greeks to abandon the euro, economists should focus on implementing reforms to address the country's economic issues within the existing currency.

site_title: Robots not displacing workers yet
summary: Robots are not yet displacing workers in the supply chain, according to John Calverley, head of global thematic research at Standard Chartered Bank. While robots can automate certain tasks, they are still limited in what they can do and can be costly for smaller companies. Workers in low-cost countries like Cambodia and Vietnam remain attractive for manufacturing due to lower wages. Reshoring, or bringing manufacturing jobs back to the US, is also limited, with high-tech products and certain industries still outsourced. Robot development is likened to the early days of the Internet.

site_title: A simple trading strategy that reaps substantial gains in China market
summary: A simple trading strategy in China's stock market involves buying at the open and selling at the close, exploiting afternoon equity purchases by state-backed funds. Since July 8, this strategy has generated a 23% return on the Shanghai Composite Index, compared to 8% for a buy-and-hold approach. However, the strategy is limited to China's futures market due to the ban on same-day trading in domestic stock exchanges. Analysts warn that the strategy's effectiveness will diminish as more investors catch on, but the high returns may continue to attract traders.

site_title: Markit sees higher dividends from S'pore banks
summary: Markit predicts Singapore banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB will pay higher dividends this year, starting with DBS' 30 cents per share in Q2, a 7.1% increase from last year. OCBC may increase its interim and final dividend to 38 cents, while UOB could hike its final dividend to 80 cents. The banks' stable but incremental dividend payouts and expected earnings growth due to higher interest rates are driving the forecast.

site_title: Under the Tuscan sun
summary: A traveler reflects on their recent visits to Tuscany, Sicily, and Burgundy, finding the Italian regions to be pleasant despite the torrid summer temperatures. They discovered a lovely hotel in a castle, Pecille, and a small, inexpensive restaurant, Osteria Le Panzanelle, in the heart of Tuscany. The traveler praises the beautiful landscapes, longer days, and excellent wine, particularly Le Pergole Torte 2011 from Montevertine, a pioneering Super-Tuscan wine. They also appreciate the charm of Sicily, with its unspoiled towns and countryside.

site_title: Qualcomm may spin off chip business
summary: Qualcomm, a leading chipmaker, may consider spinning off its chip business as it delivers its third profit warning this year and announces plans to slash jobs and spending due to rising competition. The company will reduce costs by $1.4 billion, cut 4,500 staff, and boost capital returns to shareholders. Hedge fund Jana Partners is pushing for the spin-off, citing intense competition from MediaTek and small Chinese companies. Qualcomm faces a Chinese government investigation and has agreed to pay a $975 million fine for anti-competitive practices.

site_title: Suntec Reit's Q2 DPU, net property income up
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 10.3% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.5 Singapore cents for Q2, driven by a 19.6% rise in gross revenue to S$81.4 million and a 23.5% increase in net property income to S$56.9 million. The company secured 169,000 sq ft of office leases and maintained high occupancy rates, with 99% office occupancy and 95.1% retail occupancy as of June 30. Despite divesting Park Mall for S$411.8 million, Suntec Reit remains positive on its office portfolio's performance this year.

site_title: When the past can't be shaken off
summary: A theatre in Lasalle College of the Arts is haunted by ghosts of the past, reenacting scenes from Singapore's banned 1969 play "The Struggle" by Kuo Pao Kun. The play, about exploited workers, was banned by the Singapore government just before its premiere. The new production, "The Struggle: Years Later," weaves together snippets of the original play with documents and reminiscences, featuring a 67-year-old actor from the original production and the daughter of Kuo. The play tests the audience's patience with its slow pace and meandering narrative, but explores the impact of censorship on artists.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust launched a private placement to finance its Melbourne office building acquisition, offering 84-96 million new units at S$1.46-S$1.48 per unit. The placement's gross proceeds will be approximately S$142.1 million, with the option to upsize by up to 12 million units. Ezra Holdings' renounceable underwritten rights issue was oversubscribed at a 1.3 times subscription ratio, raising S$200 million. GLP closed new lease agreements totaling 81,000 square meters with Chinese companies in retail, e-commerce, and logistics.

site_title: Abenomics needs to be 'reloaded', says hard-hitting IMF report
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has released a report stating that Japan's economic policies, known as Abenomics, need to be "reloaded" to achieve its growth and inflation targets. The report urges the Bank of Japan to prioritize achieving a 2% inflation target in a stable manner. The IMF also recommends further structural reforms to lift growth, facilitate fiscal consolidation, and unburden monetary policy. The report projects a modest economic recovery in Japan, with growth stabilizing at around 0.7% over the medium term.

site_title: Another twisted tale from Allen's (ir)rational world
summary: Woody Allen's film "Irrational Man" explores themes of morality, existential choices, and the role of chance in a person's life. The movie follows Abe Lucas, a charismatic philosophy professor struggling with depression, who becomes infatuated with a student, Jill, and later plots the perfect murder after overhearing a conversation about a stranger's murder. The film raises questions about Abe's originality and warped value system, leaving the audience to ponder the consequences of a random act. Allen's signature wit and dialogue drive the narrative, but the film falls short of his usual high standards.

site_title: Cambridge Industrial's Q2 DPU down 2.1%
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust's Q2 DPU fell 2.1% to 1.225 Singapore cents, despite a 0.5% increase in distributable income to S$15.8 million. Higher property expenses and borrowings costs contributed to the decline. The trust's portfolio occupancy grew to 95.5% and rents rose 6.3% on average. Borrowing costs are "significantly insulated" against interest rate hikes, with 96.5% fixed for 3.5 years. The trust expects a lacklustre industrial market with a strong supply of space and high sub-letting rates.

site_title: City buzz
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

To celebrate SG50, the Esplanade Theatres by the Bay is hosting a contest where the winner and three loved ones can stay on stage for a night, enjoying a programme including traditional dance and a behind-the-scenes tour. The winner must submit a 15-second video wishing Singapore a happy birthday. Meanwhile, Print the Legend, a documentary on 3D printing, will have its Singapore premiere, featuring a tour of the National Design Centre. The LKY Musical, starring Adrian Pang and Sharon Au, and The Room, a notorious cult film, are also set to screen.

site_title: ANZ raises landlord mortgage rate amid regulatory crackdown
summary: ANZ has raised its mortgage rate for landlords by 27 basis points to 5.65% and 30 basis points for fixed rates, starting August 10, amid a regulatory crackdown on soaring home prices. This move reverses a trend where owner-occupiers received better rates than investors since 1997. The decision aims to temper the 43% surge in Sydney's home prices since 2012 and follows other lenders removing interest rate discounts on home loans for investors and reducing borrowing limits.

site_title: Penny stocks see rotational play
summary: Penny stocks dominated trading in Singapore on Thursday, with CEFC International and Noble Group among the top movers. Despite a subdued punt, the Straits Times Index closed 2.8 points lower, while Starland rose 21.6% after being queried by the Singapore Exchange. Nomura expects a reasonable Q2 for banks, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB forecast to grow by 9%, 2%, and 5% respectively. The analyst also notes that a general election may not be a major market catalyst, but the gradual uptick in interest rates could be more significant.

site_title: Noble hits 7-year low in intra-day trading
summary: Noble Group plummeted to a 7-year low in intra-day trading, closing at 63 Singapore cents, down 3.1% from the previous day. The decline came after Iceberg Research questioned the scope of a third-party review of Noble's governance framework, citing a lack of clarity on the review's objectives. The stock had previously lost 48% of its value since Iceberg's first criticism in February 2015. Ex-Temasek Holdings executive Michael Dee also expressed concerns about the review's conflict of interest and lack of transparency.

site_title: Tighter controls needed on spending by public sector agencies
summary: Singapore's Auditor-General's Office released its annual report, highlighting irregularities in public sector agencies' spending. The report found lapses in procurement, poor contract management, and lack of oversight. Notable errors were found in the People's Association, National Library Board, and Workforce Development Agency. The Auditor-General noted that while audits ensured proper accounting and management, more robust frameworks are needed to ensure accountability, particularly for repeat offenders. The report emphasizes the need for early intervention to prevent problems, especially when involving significant public funds and resources.

site_title: Iceberg does not deserve the legitimacy it is being given
summary: A columnist criticizes the legitimacy given to Iceberg, a mysterious entity involved in Noble's troubles, calling it "ignoble" and "not honourable in character or purpose." Iceberg is accused of backstabbing Noble, prejudging PwC's work, and disregarding shareholders. The columnist questions the motivations of writers who have given Iceberg attention, including Michael Dee and Associate Professor Mak Yuen Teen, and criticizes The Business Times for reporting on Iceberg's allegations without qualification.

site_title: Singapore's best musicians in one studio
summary: Singapore's biggest names in music gathered at Leo Studio for the historic Sing50 concert, set to take place on August 7 at the National Stadium. The event, organized by The Business Times and The Straits Times, features over 40 iconic musicians from across five decades, including JJ Lin, Dick Lee, and Stefanie Sun. The concert will showcase local music and talent, with young emerging singers and veterans performing together on stage. Proceeds from ticket sales will benefit local charities, with the adoption of Steinway pianos by schools promoting Singapore's musical legacy.

site_title: China's next 5-year plan beginning to take shape
summary: China's next 5-year plan is taking shape, with key topics including the role and structure of state-owned enterprises, oversight of energy prices, and a possible reduction in the 7% growth target to 6.8%. The plan aims to deliver on promises to ease state control over the economy, with President Xi Jinping championing a vision of becoming a "moderately well-off society" by 2020. The plan's draft is complete, and the government is seeking comments from local officials and experts, with challenges including limiting population growth, expanding social security, and reforming rural landholdings.

images.alt_text: Mr Xi has been meeting provincial party bosses in recent weeks to discuss the 2016-2020 plan.

site_title: Lee Yi Shyan to front SkillsFuture outreach to businesses
summary: Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Lee Yi Shyan will lead SkillsFuture's outreach to businesses, including industry associations and small and medium-sized enterprises. The goal is to ensure tie-ups with education and training providers. Lee, who has experience engaging multinational corporations and SMEs, will tackle the challenge of reaching out to businesses, which is a key aspect of the national movement to give Singaporeans the opportunities to develop to their fullest potential.

site_title: Sony turning to property for growth
summary: Sony Corp is venturing into real estate through a partnership with Yahoo Japan Corp, aiming to complement its financial arm. The Tokyo-based company plans to introduce a website by the end of the year to match property buyers and sellers, targeting a public listing in two to three years. Sony expects the property business to boost profit, as real estate transactions rely on loans, insurance, and financial consulting services it already offers. The company also bets on Japan's expanding home market, aiming to tap into a 20 trillion yen market by 2020.

site_title: Commodities outlook still grim this year, says World Bank
summary: The World Bank has released its quarterly Commodity Markets Outlook, forecasting a grim outlook for commodities in 2015 due to abundant supplies. Average prices for fuels like crude, natural gas, and coal are expected to tumble 39% from 2014, while metals and fertilizers will fall 12%. The forecast for oil prices is raised to $57 per barrel, but the bank warns that prices will likely remain weak in the medium-term due to large inventories and rising output from Opec members.

site_title: Greece faces recession warning as bailout talks set to reopen
summary: Greece is facing a recession warning as a think-tank report suggests the economy will contract by 2-2.5% this year, reversing a forecast of 1% growth. The report's findings come as Parliament approved a second bailout package, and formal negotiations with international lenders are set to begin in Athens. The Greek economy has been weakened by a six-year-long slump, with unemployment over 25% and national output cut by a quarter. The government faces a tough mix of tax hikes and spending cuts, and a renewed recession could test Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras's ability to push through reforms.

site_title: Indonesia to relax rules for luxury apartment sales
summary: Indonesia plans to introduce new rules allowing foreigners to own luxury apartments, with conditions such as size restrictions, to boost economic growth. The government aims to create jobs and boost spending power by attracting foreign retirees and buyers. Foreigners will be allowed to purchase luxury apartments, but not landed property. The new rules are expected to benefit developers and are modeled after Malaysia's approach, with coordination from the immigration and tax offices. The rules are set to take effect in two to three months.

site_title: BHP's 'four pillars' no buffer against weak commodity prices
summary: BHP Billiton, the world's largest miner, is facing a double-digit price slump for its 10 major commodities, including iron ore, copper, and petroleum products. Despite its diversified portfolio, the company's entire suite of products has fallen in price, with iron ore and copper experiencing significant declines. BHP's strategy of focusing on cost-cutting and squeezing value from its operations may not be enough to shield the company from the impact of weak commodity prices.

site_title: A heartfelt cinematic missive to Singapore
summary: Local filmmakers create anthology "7 Letters" to celebrate Singapore's 50th birthday, featuring seven short films showcasing individual styles that collectively tell a poignant story about the nation. The anthology, directed by seven local filmmakers, includes nostalgic segments, classic films inspired by Singapore's past, and contemporary stories that explore themes of home, family, and identity. The result is a powerful and heartfelt cinematic tribute to Singapore, highlighting the art of local filmmaking and its ability to tell unique and poignant stories.

images.alt_text: At the core of Cinema, Eric Khoo's contribution to 7 Letters, is a haunting song by Nadiah M Din, who plays a beautiful actress/spirit hunted by a group of jittery villagers.
Ray Tan Liang Yu plays the young boy in Royston Tan's Bunga Sayang.

site_title: SGX confirms Noble granted waiver regarding board composition
summary: SGX has confirmed that Noble Group was granted a waiver regarding board composition, citing that the objective of the Listing Rule 221 was met. Factors considered included board accessibility and the company's use of Singapore-based professional advisers. The waiver was granted after assessing compliance with the rule, which includes evaluating director residency and access to the board.

site_title: Spring Singapore CEO to move to private sector
summary: Spring Singapore's CEO Tan Kai Hoe will step down on July 31 to join the private sector after six years, during which he ramped up programs for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and strengthened partnerships between large organizations and SMEs. Under his leadership, the agency launched initiatives such as the SME Talent Programme and streamlined its programs to support SME growth. Deputy chief executive Ted Tan will take over as acting CEO from August 1. The Ministry of Trade and Industry extended its appreciation to Tan for his years of service and wished him well in his future endeavors.

images.alt_text: Mr Tan said that, for him, it has been most gratifying when SME bosses thanked Spring for helping them.

site_title: New Jersey Transit delays enter third day in a row
summary: New Jersey Transit riders faced their third consecutive day of delays due to electrical problems in century-old rail tunnels under the Hudson River. The disruptions, which began on Monday, caused hour-long delays and stranded tens of thousands of commuters. Federal transportation secretary Anthony Foxx called the lack of action to repair the tunnels "almost criminal." The issues are attributed to the deteriorating tunnels, which have been exacerbated by Hurricane Sandy, and the agency is trying to determine if ageing infrastructure or heat played a role. Governor Chris Christie is under criticism for his decision to halt construction of a new tunnel five years ago.

site_title: Grant Thornton launches HQ-funded S'pore office
summary: Grant Thornton, an audit and advisory services provider, launched its Singapore office, funded by the company itself for the first time. The office, which has 25 employees, aims to serve large international businesses in sectors such as energy, finance, and technology. CEO Peter Allen stated that the move is part of the company's expansion in the Asia-Pacific region, with plans to double staff by year's end. The firm expects to double its audit clients and grow advisory revenues, with a focus on multinational companies and referral work from the global network.

site_title: Investors stay away from gold as confidence shatters
summary: Gold prices fell to their lowest in five years on Monday, erasing half the gains from a 12-year bull rally, amid heavy fund liquidation and stop-loss selling. Investors are shifting away from gold, citing its underperformance despite positive news and a rise in US interest rates. Analysts say gold is overvalued compared to other assets, such as oil and copper, and is no longer a viable store of value or appreciating asset. The metal's recent retreat has led to a decrease in hedge fund expectations and a reduction in gold-backed exchange-traded fund holdings.

site_title: Pearson agrees to sell FT Group to Nikkei for US$1.3b
summary: Pearson Plc has agreed to sell its FT Group, including the Financial Times newspaper, to Nikkei Inc for 844 million pounds. The sale does not include Pearson's 50% stake in the Economist Group or certain London properties. Pearson CEO John Fallon cited the growth of mobile and social media as a driving factor, allowing the FT to succeed as part of a global digital news company. The sale is expected to focus on Pearson's education unit, which has been impacted by declining US college enrollments and falling textbook sales.

site_title: Lockheed's Sikorsky deal marks turning point for CEO
summary: Lockheed Martin Corp's CEO Marillyn Hewson has made a significant move by acquiring helicopter maker Sikorsky Aircraft in a deal worth $9 billion. This marks a turning point for Hewson, who has been steadily increasing her assertiveness since taking the CEO role in 2013. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to balance Lockheed's portfolio and diversify its revenue streams. However, industry executives caution that the deal may test Hewson's ability to execute and navigate the company's future challenges, including uncertain military sales and the integration of Sikorsky's services business.

site_title: A minority PM 'must be able to connect with Chinese and non-Chinese'
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong believes it's possible for a non-Chinese PM to lead the country, but the person must be able to connect with both the Chinese and non-Chinese populations. He notes that having some Chinese language skills is essential for any future PM, especially among younger Singaporeans who are more comfortable with Mandarin. Lee emphasizes the importance of maintaining a "Singapore core" with deep roots in the country, citing the need for a sense of unity and national identity.

site_title: O&M segment weighs on Keppel Q2 bottomline
summary: Keppel Corp, a Singaporean conglomerate, reported a 2.3% dip in Q2 net profit to S$396.72 million due to weakness in the offshore industry. The company's O&M segment weighed on the bottomline, with offshore and marine net profit falling 36% to S$173 million. However, the property arm and infrastructure division saw significant increases in earnings. Keppel is working to finance vessels for Sete Brasil and has delayed the construction of a drillship. Despite this, CEO Loh Chin Hua remains hopeful for the rig business, citing low oil prices and the potential for older rigs to be scrapped.

site_title: FinTech firm ApexPeak buys Dutch company
summary: APEXPEAK, a Singapore-based FinTech firm, has acquired ASYX, a Netherlands-based supply chain finance and collaboration solutions provider. ASYX offers a secure web-based platform serving local and global clients in 12 countries. The acquisition provides ASYX with long-term financial backing and ApexPeak with a state-of-the-art financial services platform. The deal aims to address the under-serviced SMEs in the APMEA region, providing them with quick and efficient access to working capital.

site_title: Brazil's Gol woos business fliers with rare onboard Wi-Fi
summary: Brazil's discount airline Gol is introducing Wi-Fi on domestic flights as part of its effort to attract corporate passengers, who tend to buy expensive last-minute tickets. The airline's average fare per kilometer is the lowest in Brazil, and the technology upgrade is expected to drive loyalty. Gol aims to debut the service in mid-2016, following a recent capital increase and investments in other amenities such as leather seats and GPS technology. The move is part of a broader effort to compete with other airlines and attract higher-paying passengers in Brazil's struggling economy.

images.alt_text: The Sao Paulo-based Gol also unveiled a new logo last week, has installed GPS technology to ease check-in and flight changes, and is adding leather seats that boast more legroom.

site_title: Euro jumps, kiwi rallies after central bank moves
summary: The euro jumped above $1.10 for the first time in a week, while the New Zealand dollar surged 1.5% after the country's central bank unexpectedly refused to cut interest rates. The dollar's momentum faded, raising doubts about its rally, which has surged almost 5% since mid-June. Analysts attribute the euro's gain to short-term bets being abandoned, and expect the euro to fall in a slow manner.

site_title: Sheng Siong's Q2 profit up 23.1%, muted outlook
summary: Sheng Siong Group reported a 23.1% increase in Q2 net profit to S$13.6 million, driven by improved gross margin due to better buying prices and efficiency gains. The company's central distribution centre at Mandai contributed to the increase. However, the outlook remains muted, with no specific guidance provided.

site_title: OSIM Q2 net down 24% in soft market
summary: OSIM International, a lifestyle products group, reported a 24% decline in net profit to S$22.5 million in its Q2 2015 results, due to weak retail sentiment in Asia. Revenue fell 13% to S$159.5 million, primarily due to a drop in sales from a smaller non-chair product. Despite this, chair sales increased, and the company plans to launch new products to sustain growth. The company's share price has lost half its value over the past year, primarily due to legal and investment costs, and a drop in Chinese consumer sentiment.

site_title: Financial Times: A reference point for global business
summary: The Financial Times, a global business newspaper, is for sale. Founded in 1888 as a four-page publication in London, it has maintained its unique salmon pink paper and free-market stance. With its digital and foreign editions, it serves as a leading international newspaper. The FT's founding motto was to cater to the "Honest Financier" and "Respectable Broker."

site_title: SATS posts 14.5% rise in Q1 earnings to S$49.6m
summary: SATS, a Singaporean groundhandler and food solutions provider, reported a 14.5% year-on-year rise in net profit to S$49.6 million for the first quarter ended June 30. Revenue fell 4.2% to S$416.9 million, mainly due to lower contributions from its food solutions business. Expenditure eased, contributing to an operating profit of S$44 million. The company attributed the growth to lower expenses and higher contributions from associates/joint ventures, despite intense competition in the Asian airline market.

site_title: CPI for Singapore households decreases 0.4% in H1
summary: The consumer price index (CPI) for Singapore households decreased 0.4% in the first half of 2015, contrasting with a 0.5% rise in the preceding six months. A decline was seen across all income groups, with the bottom 20% experiencing a 0.7% fall and the top 20% experiencing a 0.6% drop. Lower accommodation costs and electricity tariffs contributed to the decline, while moderate increases in food prices offset the effect. The CPI climbed 0.2% when imputed rentals were stripped out.

site_title: Doctor who?
summary: A Singaporean university, SUTD, has launched a new office focused on Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Digital Innovation to enhance Design AI skills in students. Meanwhile, a mining giant, BHP, has partnered with several companies, including Oracle and Grab, to create an AI Hub in Singapore. This hub aims to foster innovation in education technology and AI research. Additionally, Amazon Web Services and NIE have set up an AI-focused innovation hub for edtech research. These developments highlight the growing importance of AI in Singapore's business and education sectors.

site_title: China preparing 'California-style' scheme to promote green cars: Beijing Auto chairman
summary: China is preparing a "California-style" scheme to promote electric and hybrid vehicles, with the central government potentially implementing the policy in the first half of 2026. Beijing Automotive Group's chairman, Xu Heyi, stated that the scheme would give automakers credits for producing and selling "new energy" cars, with all-electric vehicles receiving the most credits. Consumers would receive credits redeemable for money based on electric driving distance, while those using gasoline would pay an additional fee. The policy aims to tackle vehicle emissions and meet increasingly aggressive fuel economy standards through 2020.

images.alt_text: China is preparing a new scheme to encourage auto makers and consumers to use electric and hybrid vehicles, learning lessons from California's efforts to promote a similar switch, the head of a major state-owned carmaker said on Thursday.

site_title: Intel's US$7b bond attracts over US$20b in investor demand
summary: Intel priced a $7 billion bond, attracting over $20 billion in investor demand. The bond, split into four tranches with maturities from 5 to 30 years, was priced with initial new issue concessions of 15-25 basis points. Despite market volatility, investors sought a deal that was smaller than initially expected, securing a decent premium. Lead managers Bank of America Merrill Lynch and Wells Fargo secured pricing from 15-25 basis points, leaving investors with a premium to Intel's own curve and competitors.

site_title: Collaborative platform for healthcare sector launched
summary: Singapore's Centre for Healthcare Assistive and Robotics Technology (Chart) has been officially launched by President Tony Tan Keng Yam at Changi General Hospital. Chart is a collaborative platform for healthcare professionals to work with academia, industry, and research institutions to develop healthcare solutions using robotics and assistive technologies. The platform will focus on five key areas: virtual hospitals, aged care, rehabilitation, process automation, and medical training. It will also serve as a shared platform for various healthcare clusters and aged-care providers, and will be a launchpad for the National Robotics Programme.

images.alt_text: CHART - or the Centre for Healthcare Assistive and Robotics Technology - was on Thursday officially opened by President Tony Tan Keng Yam at the Changi General Hospital (CGH).

site_title: Young 'uns see that reality can fall short
summary: Paper Towns, a coming-of-age film directed by Jake Schreier and written by Scott Neustadter and Michael H Weber, tells the story of Quentin, a nerdy high school senior who has a massive crush on Margo, a popular and rebellious girl. After Margo disappears, Quentin embarks on a cross-country quest to find her, discovering that reality often falls short of his dreams. The film, based on John Green's novel, explores themes of self-discovery and the importance of breaking out of one's comfort zone.

site_title: Q2 industrial space prices, rents soften on supply glut, weak output
summary: Singapore's industrial space prices and rents have softened in Q2, with prices down 0.9% and rents down 2.7% year-on-year, according to JTC data. The supply glut and weakening economy, exacerbated by the labor crunch, are attributed to the downward trend. Occupancy rates remained stable at 91%. The government has implemented supply-side and anti-speculative measures to ensure a stable market, with more industrial space expected to be added in the next two years. Analysts predict further price and rent declines, with some tenants preferring private land to avoid government restrictions.

site_title: Venture-backed firms take record US$32b in Q2, mostly in mega-deals
summary: Venture capital-backed firms globally raised a record $32.5 billion in Q2, mostly in mega-deals worth $100 million or more. This represents a 19% increase from Q1 2015, but the majority of funding went to 61 mega-rounds, accounting for half of all venture funding. The decline in deal volume to 1,819 deals for the third consecutive quarter was attributed to low interest rates driving investors to seek higher returns from private firms rather than public markets.

site_title: Consumer comfort in US declines to lowest level in five weeks
summary: US consumer confidence declined to a five-week low, reaching 42.4 in the period ended July 19, due to growing concerns about the economy. The Bloomberg Consumer Comfort Index has fallen throughout July, despite a 3.9-point advance in the last three weeks of June. Consumer sentiment about the current economy is at its second-lowest level since early December, with mixed economic reports including an eight-year high in existing-home sales and a decline in retail sales.

site_title: Housing market in Thai capital posts strong H1, but growth seen slowing
summary: The housing market in Bangkok experienced a 64% increase in new housing project values in the first half of 2015, driven by demand from wealthy buyers. However, growth is expected to slow in the second half due to fears of oversupply. The full-year 2015 growth is predicted at 30%, with cheap condominiums booming due to speculative purchases. Experts warn of potential bubbles in detached homes and cheaper condos, and unsold projects may be left behind as the economy continues to slow.

site_title: Greek public spending dives in first half of 2015
summary: Greek public spending decreased to 23.2 billion euros in the first half of 2015, down from 26 billion euros in the same period last year. State revenues also dropped to 21.8 billion euros, resulting in a budget surplus of 1.88 billion euros after debt repayments are removed. The government reduced spending in various areas, including hospitals and job centers, and tapped into reserves to pay wages and pensions. This development is likely to be welcomed by creditors, who are struggling to provide a rescue package for the struggling Greek economy.

site_title: Myanma Economic Holdings ready to buy F&N's stake in Myanmar Brewery for 500 billion kyat
summary: Myanma Economic Holdings is ready to purchase F&N's 55% stake in Myanmar Brewery for 500 billion kyat (approximately S$586 million), according to an independent valuation. The deal must be completed within 30 days. F&N disputes the valuation, citing a 2013 exchange rate, while Myanma Economic Holdings disagrees and is willing to proceed with the purchase. The sale is part of a dispute over F&N's breach of obligations under a joint venture agreement, which led to arbitration in 2013.

site_title: Europe: Stocks decline as energy drop outweighs Credit Suisse
summary: European stocks fell for a third day, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index sliding 0.5% to 398.1, as energy shares declined 1.4% despite better-than-expected results from Credit Suisse and Unilever. Oil approached a bear market, with BP and Tullow Oil falling 1.4% and 3.7% respectively. Meanwhile, Switzerland's benchmark SMI Index jumped 1% as Roche Holding AG and ABB Ltd. rose 1.6% and 1.7% after beating analyst estimates.

site_title: Sheng Siong Q2 profit jumps 23.1% amid intensifying competition
summary: Sheng Siong Group reported a 23.1% increase in net profit to S$13.6 million for the second quarter, driven by improved gross margin and sales mix. Revenue gained 4.3% to S$179 million, with 4% attributed to new store openings and 0.3% from comparable sales. However, the company acknowledges intensified competition and tepid demand, leading to declining sales at an older store and a planned store closure in 2016.

site_title: Culinary adventures
summary: Chef SR Bala is attempting to break two Guinness World Records at this year's Singapore Food Festival, including the Largest Cooking Vessel and the Largest Curry in the World. The 41-year-old Indian chef has enlisted the help of engineers, the Civil Defence Force, and the Public Utilities Board to prepare the 15-tonne vegetable curry. Meanwhile, Chef Violet Oon will be sharing Singaporean family recipes and cooking techniques in her workshops, highlighting the importance of traditional cooking methods and cultural heritage. The festival, which runs from July 30 to August 2, will also feature a range of local and international dishes.

site_title: India banks using offbeat ploys to tackle US$49b of bad debts
summary: India's state-owned banks are intensifying efforts to tackle a US$49 billion bad debt pile, with tactics including naming and shaming smaller borrowers and advertising seized assets at shopping malls. The banks are accelerating sales of seized assets and putting pressure on investors or executives at larger firms. Executives say they are focusing on getting court cases expedited and are stepping up efforts to recover loans. The move aims to accelerate economic recovery and get company owners to take more responsibility for their debts.

site_title: GLP inks new lease deals with 5 firms in China
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has signed new lease agreements totaling 81,000 square meters with five companies in China's retail, e-commerce, and third-party logistics industries. The agreements follow the growing demand for consumer goods in China, with e-commerce and third-party logistics facilities driving the need for modern logistics facilities in premium locations.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as GM rises, Caterpillar falls
summary: US stocks were mixed in early trading on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 6.71 points (0.04%) at 17,844.33. The S&P 500 rose 1.76 (0.08%) to 2,115.91, while the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 7.05 (0.15%) to 4,630.29. General Motors surged 6.5% after reporting a quadrupling of second-quarter earnings to $1.1 billion, while Caterpillar fell 2.2% after profit fell 29% and the company lowered its 2015 sales forecast.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims hit lowest level since 1973
summary: US initial jobless claims fell to 255,000 in the week through July 18, the lowest level in nearly 42 years. This decline supported the 5.3% unemployment rate, the lowest since April 2008. Economists note that summer jobs data can be volatile, but the claims data adds to signs of a tightening workforce.

site_title: IMF expects 'difficult' discussions on new Greek bailout
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) expects "difficult" discussions on a third EU-IMF bailout for Greece, worth up to 86 billion euros over three years. The IMF will only participate if the European Union, European Central Bank, and other creditors reduce Greece's debt burden to make its finances "sustainable." Representatives from the three parties are set to meet in Athens on Friday to begin talks. The IMF has conditioned its participation on specific, concrete commitments from the Europeans on debt relief. A successful bailout is seen as crucial for Greece's economic growth.

site_title: Goldman: It's totally unrealistic to expect China to consume more than half the world's copper
summary: Analysts at Goldman Sachs have slashed copper price expectations, forecasting a fall to US$5,670 this year and US$4,725 in 2016, citing China's economic slowdown as a key factor. China currently consumes half of the world's copper supply, but analysts believe it's unrealistic to expect the country to continue this trend. With China's economy rebalancing away from heavy investment, the copper intensity of the economy is likely to drop, making it a more bearish outlook for copper prices.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew had 'very deep influence' on me: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong reflects on the influence of his late father, Lee Kuan Yew, saying his passing led to an "enormous outpouring of sorrow" but ultimately strengthened the country's confidence. He notes that his father believed in strong leadership succession and allowing successors to pursue policies necessary for Singapore's progress. The younger Lee credits his father's influence on his own views on politics, culture, and world affairs, praising leaders such as Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia, and Chinese President Xi Jinping.

images.alt_text: There was an "enormous outpouring of sorrow" when Singapore's founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew died in March, but what should be noted is that the country emerged stronger as a result, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has told Time magazine.

site_title: Keppel Corp hoping for more rig replacements as Q2 earnings dip
summary: Keppel Corp reported weaker Q2 earnings, with net profit dipping 2.3% to S$396.72 million. Revenue fell 19.3% to S$2.56 billion, primarily due to the offshore and marine division. However, the company's property arm and infrastructure division saw significant increases in earnings. Keppel CEO Loh Chin Hua expects more oil companies to scrap their older rigs, potentially accelerating the replacement cycle and rebalancing the offshore market.

site_title: Nestle's US$2.3b India noodle mess perks up AIG to Allianz
summary: Nestle's India noodle dispute over lead contamination is boosting business for insurers, with local units of American International Group and Allianz SE reporting a significant surge in inquiries and product insurance sales. The Food Safety and Standards Authority of India ordered the recall of Maggi instant noodles, and Nestle is battling to get the ban overturned by court. Insurers are seeing a 10-fold jump in product insurance sales, with companies seeking protection from regulatory risks such as recalls.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust's Q1 DPU up 3.1%
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 3.1% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.01 cents for its Q1 2015, driven by a 1.6% increase in gross revenue. Property operating expenses declined by 9% and net property income rose 5% to S$54.3 million. The distribution will be paid on September 4, 2015, and unitholders can expect to close their transfer books and register on July 31, 2015.

site_title: Waning China demand means larger lead market surplus
summary: China's slower growth has led to a stronger-than-expected surplus in the global lead market this year, with a median forecast of 21,000 tonnes. This is due to weaker demand for electric bicycles and cars, which use lead in their batteries. China's lead consumption has fallen 3% in the first five months of 2015, and car sales have decreased by 2.3% from last year. Analysts expect China's lead exports to rise in the second half of 2015, contributing to a larger surplus.

site_title: Global CEOs who lack language skills get lost in translation
summary: Global CEOs who struggle with local languages, such as Anshu Jain at Deutsche Bank and Brady Dougan at Credit Suisse, risk losing investor confidence, despite language skills not being a direct job-killer. Many multinational European firms prioritize English, but local language skills are still crucial for connecting with shareholders, customers, and colleagues. CEOs are expected to reflect local culture, including language, to avoid cultural resentment. Despite this, multilingual CEOs are rare, with some firms expecting executives to speak at least two local languages in addition to English.

images.alt_text: Facing thousands of Deutsche Bank AG investors, many of them mutinous, Anshu Jain knew a lot was riding on his speech at the annual meeting of Germany's largest bank.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust launches private placement to raise S$142.1 million
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust has launched a private placement to raise S$142.1 million, with 84 million new units to be issued at a price of between S$1.46 and S$1.48 per unit. The placement will partially finance the acquisition of a Melbourne office building, with approximately S$122.7 million going towards the estimated total acquisition cost. Net proceeds are expected to be about S$140.2 million. The placement is being led by Barclays Bank, Citigroup, and DBS Bank.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: Singapore's inflation rate rose to -0.3% in June, up from -0.4% in May. Industrial prices fell 0.7% in Q2, and the consumer price index for households dropped 0.4% in the first half of the year. Visitor levels in Singapore remain low, despite being ranked as Lonely Planet's top 2015 destination. Former unionist Phey Yew Kok faces 28 additional charges, bringing the total to 34.

site_title: UK retail sales unexpectedly fall as food, furniture drop
summary: UK retail sales unexpectedly fell 0.2% in June, contrary to forecasts of a 0.4% increase. The decline was driven by drops in food, furniture, and sporting equipment sales. On an underlying basis, retail sales remained strong, with a 0.7% growth in the three months through June. The decline in retail sales may have contributed 0.04 percentage points to overall economic growth. Despite this, economists expect persistently low inflation and stronger wage growth to continue supporting consumer spending.

site_title: China share sales in Hong Kong lift global cross-border IPO statistics
summary: Global cross-border IPOs raised US$20.6 billion in the first half of 2015, a 24% decrease from last year. The Asia-Pacific region saw a 75% increase, driven by Chinese companies listing in Hong Kong, including Huatai Securities and GF Securities, which raised US$9.1 billion. Despite near-term volatility, the long-term outlook is optimistic, with exchanges promoting stronger market environments and creating investment hubs for emerging companies.

site_title: Update: Pearson in talks to sell Financial Times, Economist stake
summary: Pearson is in advanced talks to sell the FT Group, which owns the Financial Times newspaper and a stake in the Economist magazine, for as much as 1 billion pounds. The potential buyer is not identified, but could be media companies like Axel Springer SE or investors in Europe, the Middle East, and Asia. A sale would allow Pearson's CEO to focus on the education unit, which has been impacted by declining US college enrollments and falling textbook sales.

site_title: Lufthansa reshuffle lined up for September: Manager Magazin
summary: Lufthansa is set to discuss a management shake-up at a September board meeting, which could see a new structure implemented by 2020. The proposed three-pronged structure would separate hub airlines, Eurowings, and aviation maintenance and catering services. Swiss CEO Harry Hohmeister is expected to head Eurowings, while Lufthansa finance chief Simone Menne would oversee maintenance and catering. A new CEO for Lufthansa could be announced, but details remain unclear.

site_title: Venture funding for startups still surging
summary: Venture funding for startups surged to $32.5 billion in the past quarter, with over 1,800 companies receiving investment globally. The majority of funding went to tech firms, particularly internet and mobile communications startups, with an average investment of $74 million for late-stage firms. The number of billion-dollar startups, or "unicorns," also grew, with 24 created in the quarter. Experts attribute the boom to consumer demands for instant services and the availability of private venture capital, which allows companies to stay private and focus on long-term growth.

images.alt_text: Investors pumped some US$32.5 billion into more than 1,800 venture-backed companies around the world in the past quarter, amid feverish interest in tech startups, a survey showed on Thursday.

site_title: OSIM Q2 net profit drops 24% to S$22.5m
summary: OSIM International reported a 24% drop in Q2 net profit to S$22.5 million, down from S$29.5 million a year ago, and a 13% decrease in revenue to S$159.5 million. The company declared an unchanged interim dividend of two cents per share. Founder and CEO Ron Sim expressed concerns about the retail market slowdown but emphasized the need for new, innovative products to sustain the company. The stock closed unchanged near a 33-month low.

site_title: SATS Q1 profit up 14.5% at S$49.6m
summary: SATS, a groundhandler and food solutions provider, reported a 14.5% year-over-year increase in net profit to S$49.6 million for Q1 2015, despite a 4.2% drop in revenue. Lower expenses contributed to a S$44 million operating profit. The company attributed its growth to Asia's strong structural growth prospects despite intense competition in the airline industry.

site_title: Think-tank sees Greek economy falling into recession this year
summary: Greece's IOBE think-tank has revised its forecast, predicting the economy will contract by 2.0-2.5% this year, entering recession due to the impact of capital controls and banking holiday on consumption, investment, and exports. The economy had grown 0.7% last year, but slipped into contraction in the first quarter. The think-tank urges Greece to quickly wrap up a deal with lenders for a third bailout package to avoid further economic damage. The EU Commission had also forecast a 2-4% contraction this year.

site_title: Greece's creditors prepare to fly in for bailout talks
summary: Greece's creditors will meet in Athens on Friday to discuss a potential third bailout worth up to 86 billion euros over three years. The talks follow a recent bailout-for-reforms deal aimed at preventing Greece from leaving the eurozone. Greek lawmakers passed a bill on reforms needed for the talks to proceed. The negotiations are seen as crucial to prevent Greece from defaulting on its massive debts, and a successful outcome would provide relief to the country's struggling economy.

site_title: Lee Yi Shyan to lead SkillsFuture outreach to businesses
summary: Senior Minister of State Lee Yi Shyan will lead the outreach to industry associations and businesses to address SkillsFuture's challenge of reaching out to small and medium-sized enterprises. Lee has over 1,000 company engagements, and his role aims to ensure tie-ups with education and training providers. The initiative is part of SkillsFuture, a nationwide program to upgrade Singaporeans' skills for career progression. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman notes that while there is good early momentum, the journey is long and there is much work to be done.

site_title: US growth seen picking up; rate hike expected in Sept
summary: US economic growth is expected to pick up in the third quarter, allowing the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates in September. A Reuters poll of 81 economists forecasts 2.3% economic growth this year, with unemployment expected to average 4.9% in 2016 and 4.8% in 2017. The Fed's policy-setting committee meets next week, but many economists believe the economy is not yet ready for a rate hike due to concerns over a potential slowdown and tame inflation pressures. A September rate hike is seen as likely, with the midpoint of the federal funds rate expected to be 0.375% by the end of September.

site_title: Pearson has decided to sell FT, announcement due shortly: source
summary: Pearson, a British publisher, has decided to sell the Financial Times newspaper to a global digital news company.
