The decision comes after nearly 60 years of ownership, allowing Pearson to focus on its education strategy. A full announcement is expected shortly. Pearson's shares rose 1.9% following the Reuters report.

images.alt_text: British publisher Pearson has decided to sell the Financial Times newspaper to a global, digital news company, a person familiar with the deal said on Thursday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 7.09 points to 1,722.44, ending lower. The index saw 1.76 billion lots valued at RM1.69 billion trade, with 491 gains and 317 losses.

site_title: Singapore oil stocks surge adds to pressure for rate cuts
summary: Singapore oil stocks surged to their highest since 1999, with oil product inventories rising 6% to a four-year high. The supply glut, fueled by seasonally weak demand and mounting supplies, is expected to pressure refineries globally to cut rates. Diesel stocks rose particularly fast, with analysts estimating a 0.7 million barrels-per-day global run cut needed to balance supply worldwide. The surge in stocks is also attributed to traders storing products in landed tanks due to high freight rates.

site_title: Fast fall in baht could cause problems for economy: central bank
summary: Thailand's baht currency has fallen by 2% this week, prompting concerns from the central bank. Assistant Bank of Thailand Governor Chantavarn Sucharitakul stated that there is no sign of unusual speculative activity, but the central bank is closely monitoring the market. The baht stands at 34.74 against the dollar. A rapid decline in the currency could cause problems for the real economy, according to the central banker.

site_title: Greece to decide next week when stock exchange to open: source
summary: Greece will decide next week when the Athens stock exchange will reopen, following a four-week shutdown due to capital controls imposed last month. The stock exchange closed on June 29 after Greece rejected a cash-for-reforms deal and secured emergency funding for its banks. Talks with international creditors on a third bailout will start in Athens on Friday, aiming to conclude by August 20. The government targets a budget primary surplus of less than 1% of GDP for 2015.

site_title: Singapore's Hin Leong sells 2nd gasoline cargo this year
summary: Singaporean trading company Hin Leong sold its second gasoline cargo of the year, a 50,000-barrel shipment, in the cash market on July 23. The cargo was sold for July 26-30 loading to Vitol. This move is seen as a test of the market, with traders expecting Hin Leong to expand its gasoline trading. The company's entry into the market is expected to increase liquidity, benefiting the market.

site_title: Former unionist Phey Yew Kok faces 28 more charges
summary: Former unionist Phey Yew Kok faces 28 additional charges, bringing the total to 34. The charges include four counts of criminal breach of trust and two counts under the Trade Unions Act. Phey had absconded in 1980 and surrendered at the Singapore Embassy in Bangkok in June. He was brought back to Singapore the following day.

site_title: IMF warns Japan must avoid over-reliance on weak yen
summary: The International Monetary Fund warned Japan against relying too heavily on a weak yen to stimulate its economy. The IMF advises Japan to implement structural reforms, such as boosting labor market participation, to achieve its 2% inflation target. Over-reliance on yen depreciation could lead to economic instability. The IMF also notes that while inflation is expected to rise to 1.5% in the medium term, meeting the 2% target remains challenging.

images.alt_text: Premier Shinzo Abe's stimulus policies, dubbed "Abenomics,"consist of the three arrows of bold monetary stimulus, flexible fiscal policy and a strategy to boost Japan's growth potential.

site_title: Malaysia reserves drop to five-year low on sign of intervention
summary: Malaysia's foreign-exchange reserves dropped to a five-year low of US$100.5 billion as of July 15, signaling possible central bank intervention to stem the ringgit's decline. The currency has weakened to a 16-year low of 3.8130 a dollar, surpassing its pegged level of 3.8. Analysts forecast further weakness due to US interest rate hikes, exacerbating losses caused by plummeting oil prices and an investigation into state investment company 1Malaysia Development Bhd.

site_title: Barclays gunning for Asia's trade flows, hiring corporate bankers
summary: Barclays is revamping its corporate banking business in Asia, hiring bankers to tap into the region's lucrative trade flows. The bank, which previously scaled back its presence in Asia, plans to increase revenues significantly with hubs in Singapore, India, Hong Kong, and Japan. Alexander Harrison, appointed to lead the next phase of growth, will focus on supporting Asia-Pacific corporates with growth ambitions in Europe, the Middle East, and Africa. Despite slowing growth in Asia, Barclays sees significant opportunities for cross-selling services and increasing its presence in the region.

site_title: Noble Group drops to 6-year low on commodity rout, criticism
summary: Noble Group Ltd, Asia's largest commodity trader, plummeted to a 6-year low in Singapore due to a slump in resource prices and criticism of its accounting. The stock fell 3.1% to 63 Singapore cents, its lowest since 2009, amid a bear market in crude oil and gold. An anonymous group, Iceberg Research, continues to criticize Noble's accounting practices, despite the company's efforts to address the issues. Investors remain cautious until a review by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP is completed, with some predicting a sustained decline in commodity prices.

site_title: Suntec Reit posts 10.3% rise in Q2 DPU
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 10.3% year-on-year rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.5 Singapore cents for the second quarter ended June 30. Gross revenue grew 19.6% to S$81.4 million and net property income rose 23.5% to S$56.9 million. The retail space occupancy reached 95.1%, while office space occupancy stood at 99%. The Reit manager remains positive on office portfolio performance despite impending supply in 2016 and 2017.

site_title: Pearson confirms Reuters report on Financial Times sale talks
summary: Pearson confirms it's in advanced talks about selling the Financial Times newspaper to a "global, digital news company", following earlier speculation. The company has no certainty that discussions will lead to a transaction.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker as penny momentum slows
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed with a net loss of 2.8 points at 3,356.37, following a 13-point gain in the morning. Penny stocks dominated trading, with CEFC International not appearing in the top volume list. Property developer Starland was queried by the Singapore Exchange for a large rise, while commodities firm Noble Group dropped S$0.02 to S$0.63 on high volume. The slow momentum in penny stocks led to a subdued trading session, with turnover at S$1 billion.

site_title: Maldives to allow foreigners to own land
summary: The Maldives has voted to allow foreign ownership of land for the first time, with 70 lawmakers supporting the move and 14 opposing it. The new law would permit foreign investors who invest over $1 billion to own land in perpetuity, provided 70% of it is reclaimed from the Indian Ocean. The move has raised concerns over a possible landgrab in the honeymoon islands and potential Chinese involvement, amid a backdrop of ongoing political unrest in the country. The law has yet to be ratified by the president.

site_title: Mers outbreak smothers South Korea economic recovery in Q2
summary: South Korea's economy slowed in Q2, growing 0.3% due to consumer spending stifled by the MERS outbreak and exports failing to recover from a slump. The outbreak infected 186 people and resulted in 36 deaths. The government has announced a 22 trillion won stimulus package to support affected businesses. The tourism industry was severely impacted, with foreign visitor numbers plummeting 40% in June and 60% in the first two weeks of July. The Bank of Korea has cut its 2015 economic growth forecast for the third time this year, to 2.8%.

site_title: Gold sinking to US$800 in worst-case outlook at Morgan Stanley
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts gold may drop to US$800 an ounce under a worst-case scenario, driven by US interest rate hikes, China's stock market correction, and central bank reserve sales. The bank's forecast remains unchanged at US$1,050 an ounce for 2015. Gold prices have fallen to a 13-year low, with the Bloomberg Commodity Index reaching its lowest level since 2002.

site_title: Asian currency index declines to five-year low on slowing growth
summary: A measure of Asian currencies dropped to a five-year low due to slowing regional growth and a looming US interest-rate increase. South Korea's won fell 1.1% to a three-year low against the dollar, while Malaysia's ringgit and Thailand's baht also declined. Global funds cut their equity holdings in six Asian markets, citing weak growth fundamentals. The Bloomberg Commodity Index slid to its lowest close since 2002, weighing on raw-material exporters like Malaysia. Growth in China, the region's largest economy, is projected to slow to 7% this year.

site_title: Shanghai: Stock index rises for 6th day on reaffirmation of govt support
summary: China's Shanghai Composite index rose for the sixth consecutive session, with the CSI300 index up 2.3% and the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 2.4%. The market rally was led by blue chips and fueled by the government's reaffirmed support, with China Securities Finance Corp stating it would continue to support the market and deny selling shares in certain companies.

site_title: Former Toshiba auditor to step down from government panel: source
summary: Former Toshiba auditor Makoto Kubo plans to step down from a government accounting panel following an investigation into the company's book-keeping scandal. Kubo resigned as director and chairman of Toshiba's audit committee after investigators found the committee failed to function, contributing to "institutionalized" accounting irregularities. Kubo also submitted his resignation from the Financial Services Agency's accounting panel, which has been urging Japanese companies to adopt international accounting standards.

site_title: Central banks dump up to US$260b FX reserves in Q2: Citi
summary: Central banks globally dumped up to $260 billion of foreign exchange reserves in Q2, the largest drop in over a decade, as emerging markets faced capital outflows amid economic uncertainty. The decline was driven by a combination of factors, including investors rushing to exit emerging markets and central banks selling reserves to prevent currency devaluation. This move is particularly notable as it involves the same factors affecting China, which has also experienced a capital outflow, according to Citi.

site_title: CPI for S'pore households drops 0.4% in H1
summary: Singapore's consumer price index (CPI) for households dropped 0.4% in the first half of 2015, contrasting with a 0.5% rise in the previous six months. The decline was largely due to lower accommodation and electricity costs, but was partially offset by moderate increases in food prices. Stripping out imputed rentals, the CPI rose 0.2% in the first half of 2015, lower than the 0.9% rise in the previous year. The impact varied across household segments, with the bottom 20% experiencing a 0.7% decline and the top 20% a 0.6% decline.

site_title: Quick takes: Consumer prices fall for 8th consecutive month in June
summary: Singapore's inflation rate remained in negative territory in June, rising to -0.3% from -0.4% in May, due to increases in services, food, and private road transport costs. Economists predict the core inflation rate will narrowly avoid dipping into negative territory, but highlight downside risks due to the uncertain global environment. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is expected to maintain its current monetary stance, with no pressure to ease the appreciation rate of the SGD.

site_title: Spring CEO to step down on July 31, join private sector
summary: Tan Kai Hoe, CEO of Spring Singapore, will step down on July 31, 2015, to join the private sector. He was promoted to CEO in May 2013 and led the agency's SME transformation efforts. Deputy CEO Ted Tan will be acting CEO until a new CEO is appointed. Under Kai Hoe's leadership, Spring has sharpened its focus on SME transformation.

site_title: Asia: Shares slip on lacklustre data, dollar strong
summary: Asian shares slipped on Thursday, weighed down by lacklustre regional data and a strong dollar. South Korea's economy expanded at its weakest pace in six years, while Japan's export growth strengthened in June. Tokyo's Nikkei rose 0.4%, but Asian shares outside Japan fell 0.2% amid concerns about China's slowing economy. Despite this, capital flow trends suggest money managers are turning bullish on the region's growth prospects.

site_title: Credit Suisse Asia chief eyes expansion as regional profit doubles
summary: Credit Suisse Asia's Chief Executive, Helman Sitohang, said the bank is open to expanding its private banking business in the region, potentially through acquisitions or hiring. Asia is the world's fastest-growing private banking market, driven by China's growing economy, which created 1 million new millionaire households last year. The bank's pretax profit in the first half of the year doubled to 873 million Swiss francs. Sitohang acknowledged the challenge of hiring experienced private bankers in the region but cited training programs and external recruitment as solutions.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse Group's Asia chief on Thursday said the Swiss bank would consider raising headcount or buying a smaller peer to build up its private banking business, in a region where pretax profit doubled in the first half of this year.

site_title: Visitor levels down in Singapore, but analysts say may look up in H2
summary: Singapore's visitor levels have declined for 14 consecutive months, with year-on-year declines in visitors through May. Hotel room rates have also dropped for 10 straight months, with Marina Bay Sands posting its lowest average room rate since 2012. The decline is attributed to a stronger Singapore dollar, making the city a more expensive destination for tourists. Economists predict a potential recovery in the second half of the year, citing events such as the Formula One night race and islandwide retail sale.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close 0.46% higher
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.46% to 25,398.85 on Thursday, driven by a sixth consecutive rise in mainland markets, outweighing losses on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index gained 116.23 points on HK$79.82 billion in turnover.

site_title: China to allow more refiners to import crude oil: ministry
summary: China will allow more refiners to directly import crude oil, expanding the pool of companies that can apply for import licenses. Companies meeting environmental and capacity requirements can now apply for licenses, following a relaxation of Beijing's grip on the sector. Five firms have been granted preliminary approval for 25.8 million tonnes of crude, and they can now import the oil on their own rather than through state trading companies. This move is part of China's broader reform efforts to open the energy sector to more private participation and increase domestic oil refineries' access to crude feedstock.

site_title: ANZ bank raises interest rates on investor home loans
summary: ANZ bank has raised interest rates on investor home loans, effective Monday, with variable rates increasing by 0.27 percentage points to 5.65% and fixed rates rising by up to 0.30 percentage points. The move follows APRA's July 2016 deadline for banks to lift cash reserves and regulators' warnings on tighter mortgage standards to prevent a housing bubble. ANZ has also implemented stricter criteria for investor loans and reduced interest rate discounts. The lender aims to balance its lending between owner-occupied and investment lending.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close 0.44% higher on weak yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.44% on Thursday, driven by a weakening yen that boosted exporters, and falling oil prices that lifted airline shares. The Nikkei 225 index ended at 20,683.95, while the Topix index climbed 0.57% to 1,664.88.

site_title: Indonesia coal exports suffer most as Chinese demand falls
summary: Indonesia's coal exports suffered a 49% decline in the first half of 2015 due to China's reduced imports, which fell 38% from the previous year. This drop was attributed to China's tighter quality limits on seaborne coal and increased support for domestic miners. The decline in Chinese demand has left Indonesian coal exporters searching for alternative markets, with a glut of 5.2% expected to widen by 2018, according to Deutsche Bank AG.

site_title: Daimler Q2 operating profit jumps 54% defying China slowdown
summary: Daimler's second-quarter operating profit surged 54% to 3.8 billion euros, exceeding forecasts, as new luxury car model launches boosted Mercedes-Benz Cars division. Deliveries of Mercedes-Benz passenger cars rose 20% to 500,700 vehicles, with sales in China increasing 38.5% in the world's largest car market. The company's operating margin rose to 10.7%, up from 7.9% last year, defying a slowdown in car sales in China.

site_title: Australia: Shares close down as weak commodity prices weigh on market
summary: Australian shares fell 0.43% on Thursday, led by a 1.61% decline on Wednesday, due to weak commodity prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5590.300, with the materials sector taking a hit. This follows global commodity price declines, which affected the sector.

site_title: China: Stocks head for longest winning streak in two months
summary: China's stocks rose for a sixth day, pushing the Shanghai Composite Index toward its longest winning streak in two months, as speculation mounts that the government's support measures have stabilized equities. The benchmark index gained 1.7% to 4,092.20, driven by financial and material shares. The Shanghai index has risen 16% since July 8, rebounding from a month-long rout that wiped out nearly $4 trillion in market value.

site_title: Wal-Mart buys out China e-commerce firm Yihaodian in online push
summary: Wal-Mart has acquired a 49% stake in Chinese e-commerce firm Yihaodian.com, gaining full ownership and accelerating its online push in the country's growing market. The move comes as retailers face competition from online rivals and a slowing economy. With Yihaodian's local experience and Wal-Mart's global sourcing, the company aims to deliver low prices and boost coordination between physical and online stores. This acquisition is part of Wal-Mart's strategy to tap into China's younger generation and expand its online presence.

site_title: World Bank sees commodities headed for another bad year on glut
summary: The World Bank predicts commodities will decline in 2015 due to abundant supplies and weak demand. Oil prices are forecast to fall 39% from 2014, while natural gas and coal prices will tumble 36% and 17% respectively. Metals and fertiliser prices are expected to decline 12% and 5% on average. The bank attributes the decline to China's shift towards a services-oriented economy and policies to curb pollution. Despite a slightly improved forecast for oil prices, large inventories and rising output from OPEC members suggest prices will remain weak in the medium-term.

site_title: Industrial prices, rentals soften amid larger supply in Q2: JTC
summary: Industrial prices in Singapore fell 0.7% in Q2 compared to the previous quarter, and 0.9% year-over-year, due to increased supply of industrial land and space. Industrial rentals also decreased 0.7% quarter-over-quarter and 2.7% year-over-year. Occupancy rates rose 0.3 percentage points to 91% due to higher occupancies at business parks and warehouses. However, this is expected to be negatively impacted by a significant increase in supply, with 1.6 million sq m of industrial space expected to come onstream in the second half of 2015.

site_title: Japanese govt bonds steady, supported by BOJ buying operations
summary: Japanese government bonds remained steady, with the 30-year yield dropping to 1.390% as the Bank of Japan purchased 375 billion yen in JGBs. The BOJ's asset purchase program helped push the yield down to its lowest level in nearly three months. The benchmark 10-year JGB yield and 5-year yield remained flat, while the 1-year to 3-year zone saw a significant increase. The move is seen as supporting the Japanese economy, but the overall impact on the country's bond market remains steady.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise on earnings as dollar holds gains on Fed
summary: Europe's benchmark stock index rose 0.3% as Credit Suisse and Unilever reported better-than-estimated results. The dollar strengthened against emerging currencies, while the Shanghai Composite Index advanced 2.4%. European bonds rallied after Greece approved creditor-imposed reforms. The dollar's resurgence is undermining commodity prices, with the World Bank citing abundant supply and weakening global demand.

site_title: Linc Energy's divested Australian mine project runs into trouble
summary: Linc Energy's Australian coal-mine project, sold to Adani Mining in 2010, has faced trouble due to a budget restructure and delays in Queensland state government approvals. Adani has suspended two major contractors on its $10 billion Carmichael project, casting doubt on its prospects. Linc Energy sold the project's underlying asset for $500 million in cash, with the option to sell a royalty deed for $155 million, which Adani exercised in 2014, generating $133 million annually in revenue for Linc. The project's future is now uncertain.

site_title: Gold crawls off 5-year low, but downside risk seen intact
summary: Gold prices rose 0.5% to $1,098 an ounce, rebounding from a five-year low, as the dollar weakened. However, investors remain bearish, with holdings in the world's largest gold-backed ETF shrinking for a fifth day. The sell-off was exacerbated by large trading volumes on the Shanghai Gold Exchange and expectations of interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Despite this, some analysts believe gold may not collapse entirely due to quantitative easing by other central banks, such as the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan.

site_title: Indonesia raises import duty on consumer goods
summary: Indonesia has raised import duty on various consumer goods, including food, beverages, clothing, and condoms, to support local industry. The move took effect on July 23, 2015, following an evaluation of recent economic conditions. The aim is to boost domestic production and reduce reliance on imports.

site_title: Yellen has bond market in hand as volatility heads to 2015 low
summary: Janet Yellen, the Fed chair, has successfully calmed the bond market, with volatility at its lowest since 2015. Futures show a 74% chance of a rate hike by December, while a gauge of Treasury market volatility has declined to 72 basis points. Yellen expects to raise interest rates gradually, with economists predicting a 50% chance of a September liftoff. The benchmark US 10-year note yield remains unchanged at 2.32%.

site_title: CGH launches robotics centre to help develop new healthcare solutions
summary: Changi General Hospital (CGH) has launched the Centre for Healthcare Assistive and Robotics Technology (Chart), a collaborative platform to develop healthcare solutions using robotics and assistive technologies. The centre, supported by the Singapore Economic Development Board, will focus on five key domains: virtual hospitals, aged care, rehabilitation, process automation, and medical training. Chart features a design lab and a living lab, and will serve as a shared platform for healthcare clusters and aged-care providers. Partners include Hope Technik and Nanyang Technological University, with the goal of enhancing healthcare solutions through robotics technologies.

site_title: China: Shares up slightly in morning trade
summary: China's shares rose 0.18% in morning trade, driven by reports that the state-backed China Securities Finance Corp denied reducing its holdings in listed companies. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 7.22 points to 4,033.27, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 4.63 points to 2,292.61. This move comes as traders brush off new US President Trump's threats to extend stocks rally.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall on earnings woes; won sinks after Q2 GDP
summary: South Korean shares fell to a one-week low due to weak earnings from key sectors and a sharp decline in the won, which reached a fresh two-year low against the dollar. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) dropped 0.1% to 2,062.17 points, while the won fell 0.8% to 1,162.7 per dollar. The central bank estimated South Korea's economic growth during the past quarter to have slowed more than initially thought, further hurting the market sentiment.

site_title: Singapore inflation edges up to -0.3 per cent in June
summary: Singapore's inflation rate rose to -0.3% in June, up from -0.4% in May, driven by increases in services, food, and private road transport costs. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and transport costs, rose to 0.2% from 0.1%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry predict inflation will be -0.5-0.5% for the year, while core inflation is expected to be 0.5-1.5%. This is partly due to higher global oil prices and the effects of budgetary measures.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.86 points to 1729.570. Volume was 33.1 million lots worth RM16.9 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 99 to 69.

site_title: Hyundai Motor profit falls for sixth quarter on weak sales
summary: Hyundai Motor reported a 24% decline in quarterly net income to 1.7 trillion won (S$2.05 billion) due to weak sales in China and the US, the automaker's two largest markets. Quarterly sales fell amid intensified competition and a stronger won against the yen, which reduced Hyundai's competitiveness against rivals like Toyota Motor Corp. This marks the sixth consecutive quarter of declining profit for Hyundai, underscoring the challenges faced by the company in the global automotive market.

site_title: Indonesia central bank says rupiah's weakness is due to normal fluctuation
summary: Indonesia's central bank attributed the recent 17-year low in the rupiah to normal external fluctuations, citing the US dollar's rise due to strong home resales data. The rupiah eased 0.2% to 13,395 per dollar. Bank Indonesia's spokesman stated that the central bank is monitoring the foreign exchange market to smooth out volatility, indicating no significant change in domestic market conditions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.10% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.10% at the open on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 25.93 points to 25,308.55. The previous session saw a sell-off, but the market rebounded as traders brushed off new Trump threats. The gains were largely driven by the previous session's losses.

site_title: Indonesia will safeguard rupiah exchange rate: econ minister
summary: Indonesian Chief Economics Minister Sofyan Djalil stated the government will work with the central bank to safeguard the rupiah exchange rate according to fundamentals. The rupiah has declined 0.2% to 13,395 per dollar, its weakest since August 1998, but Djalil believes this is a normal fluctuation with minimal impact.

site_title: Singapore's richest get slightly less rich but more billionaires minted
summary: Singapore's 50 wealthiest individuals saw their combined net worth decrease by 32% from last year to US$6.4 billion, due to a slowdown in the property market, a weakened Singapore dollar, and a lackluster stock market. However, the number of billionaires increased to 28, with 22 new billionaires added. Robert and Philip Ng retained the top spot with a combined net worth of US$8.7 billion, while Goh Cheng Liang moved up four spots to third place with a net worth of US$6.9 billion.

site_title: Beijing's stock rescue has US$800 billion bark, small market bite
summary: China has committed $800 billion to rescue its stock markets, with $1.1 trillion in funds unleashed to calm a savage sell-off. However, the impact of the rescue has been modest, with the Shanghai Composite Index still 17% below its semi-official recovery target. Analysts question the effectiveness of the rescue, citing high valuations and the lack of support for fundamentals. The government's strategy to entice private money back to the market may ultimately impose a longer-term financial cost.

site_title: Adani says approval delays halt work on Australia coal project
summary: India's Adani Mining halted work on its $10 billion Carmichael coal mine in Australia due to delays in government approvals. The project, which aims to supply coal to India, could damage the Great Barrier Reef and contribute to global warming. Environmentalists, including Greenpeace, have campaigned against the mine, citing its potential impact on the reef and climate change. Despite signing up buyers for 70% of the mine's output, Adani cited government approval delays as the reason for the halt, with work to resume in early October.

site_title: Singapore shares open 9.12 points higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 9.12 points to 3,368.29, driven by a 0.3% increase in local market. About 204 million shares worth S$60.9 million were traded at an average unit price of S$0.30. Gainers outnumbered losers 91 to 59, with Sitra and Blumont being the most actively traded stocks. The market rally comes ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble tumbles to multi-year low after Iceberg casts doubts on third-party review
summary: Noble Group's stock plummeted to a five-year low after research outfit Iceberg Research cast doubts on the effectiveness of a third-party review of the company's governance framework. The stock lost 4.6% to S$0.620, amid heavy selling. Iceberg questioned the scope of the review, believing PricewaterhouseCoopers will focus on the valuation framework rather than the portfolio's valuation. This move has led to a 45% decline in the stock's value since Iceberg launched its attack in February 2015.

site_title: Australia business confidence, activity improve in Q2: survey
summary: Australian businesses reported improved confidence and activity in the second quarter, with a National Australia Bank survey finding a +4 index of business confidence and +4 of business conditions. This marked a turn in sentiment for sectors outside mining, which had been struggling due to weaker commodity prices. Respondents were optimistic about the pick-up extending over a three- and 12-month horizon, with investment plans remaining strong. The positive momentum was attributed to industries sensitive to low interest rates and the Australian dollar, rather than mining.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ascott Reit, Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Ascendas Reit
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (Ascott Reit) reported a 5% decline in distribution per unit to 2.09 Singapore cents for the second quarter. Frasers Centrepoint Trust saw a 0.5% increase in distribution per unit to 3.036 Singapore cents. Ascendas Reit posted a 5.5% rise in distribution per unit to 3.841 Singapore cents, driven by positive rental reversions and higher occupancies at its properties.

site_title: Euro firms after Greece passes bailout reforms
summary: Greece's parliament passed a bailout reforms bill, securing crucial funds from creditors. The euro traded higher against the dollar and yen, while the US dollar firmed against the yen due to strong US homes data. The vote is seen as a test of Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' authority, following a major rebellion in his party.

site_title: Credit Suisse second-quarter profit beats poll estimate
summary: Credit Suisse posted a second-quarter profit of 1.1 billion Swiss francs, beating analyst expectations of 783 million francs. The bank's net income more than doubled from a 700 million franc loss in the same quarter last year, driven by penalties from a 2014 settlement with US authorities. The strong earnings report comes as the bank continues to recover from past setbacks.

site_title: Oil prices mixed in Asia, WTI stays below US$50
summary: Oil prices were mixed in Asia, with WTI staying below US$50 a barrel, as concerns over a supply glut persisted. The US Department of Energy reported a 2.5 million barrel increase in commercial crude stockpiles, and US production remained near-record levels. Analysts attributed the rise to a strong US currency and Opec's record production levels, particularly from Iraq and Saudi Arabia. Oil prices may move lower, with March lows of US$42-$45 in the crosshairs, according to market strategist Bernard Aw.

images.alt_text: Crude's plunge keeps piling on the bad news for oil producers, who are having the worst start to a year on record. More than US$100 billion has been wiped off the 61-company Bloomberg World Oil & Gas Index this year as it plunged to the lowest since August 2004. It has dropped 5.6 per cent, making it the worst opening to the year since the index started in 2003. Thailand's PTT Pcl, Apache Corp and China Petroleum & Chemical Corp led the decline.

site_title: Hot stock: NauticAWT opens 75% higher in Catalist debut
summary: NauticAWT, an oil and gas engineering firm, made a strong debut on the Catalist exchange, opening 75% higher at S$0.35, exceeding its IPO price of S$0.20. The company's successful listing is seen as a platform for long-term growth, with plans for dividend payouts of 20% of net profit and capital expenditure. This marks the addition of another marine and offshore services sector company to the Catalist bourse, now featuring 62 such companies with a market value of over S$50 million.

site_title: Indian banks opt for offbeat tactics to tackle US$49b of bad debts
summary: Indian state-owned banks are intensifying efforts to tackle a US$49 billion mountain of bad debts, with aggressive campaigns to name and shame smaller borrowers and sell seized assets. Executives are receiving extra training, and banks are accelerating sales of seized assets, focusing on expedited court cases and fieldwork. Wins include Suzlon Energy selling its German unit for 1 billion euros and over two dozen lenders working together to find an investor for Electrosteel Steels Ltd. Gross bad loans at Indian banks rose to 3.1 trillion rupees, or 4.6% of total loans, as of end-March.

site_title: Greek parliament passes second crucial bailout bill
summary: Greek parliament passes a second bailout bill with over 170 MPs in favor, a majority of the 300-seat parliament. The bill includes civil justice reforms, a bank deposit protection scheme, and measures to shore up the banking system. This vote comes after a major rebellion by MPs in Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' Syriza party last week, but appears to have avoided another split within the party. The passage of the bill unlocks a potential €86 billion bailout package over three years, with Tsipras riding high in opinion polls.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust selling Tampines property to Keppel T&T for S$20m
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust is selling a 9,251 sqm light industrial property at 20 Tampines Street 92 to a Keppel joint venture for S$20m. The property, aged 19 years, is being sold due to outdated specifications and limited redevelopment potential. Keppel Data Centres plans to develop it into its fourth data centre in Singapore, with a gross floor area of 183,000 sqft. The sale is expected to recycle capital into better-quality logistics assets, according to the trust manager.

site_title: Indonesia rupiah hits 17-year low; intervention eyed
summary: The Indonesian rupiah reached a 17-year low of 13,395 per dollar, down 0.2% from its previous close, amid expectations of a US interest rate hike in September. Solid US housing data further fueled dollar strength. Bank Indonesia, the central bank, is watching the currency and may intervene to prop up the rupiah, which is the second-worst performing Asian currency this year. The government aims to keep the rupiah in an "acceptable range" that reflects the country's economic fundamentals.

images.alt_text: The Indonesian rupiah hit a fresh 17-year low on Thursday as solid US housing data added to expectations the Federal Reserve with hike interest rates as soon as September.

site_title: South Korea Q2 GDP more than halves from Q1, weaker than expected
summary: South Korea's Q2 GDP growth slowed to 0.3% in April-June, its weakest in two quarters, due to consumption being battered by the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome outbreak. Private consumption fell 0.3% and capital investment rose 0.4%. The economy expanded 2.2% year-over-year, below a median forecast of 2.3%. The sluggish growth is attributed to poor global demand and the impact of the MERS outbreak on tourism.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall; Apple suppliers down again
summary: Taiwan's main stock index fell 0.3% to 8,892.73, weighed down by Apple suppliers for the second day after the company's fourth-quarter revenue forecast missed estimates. Apple suppliers, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co and Largan Precision, declined 1% and 2.5% respectively. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$0.117 to T$31.235 per US dollar.

site_title: Tsipras urges Greek parliament to back crucial bailout bill
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras urged the parliament to pass a crucial bailout bill, which must be approved for Greece to unlock a 86 billion euro international bailout. The vote comes after a major rebellion by MPs in his leftist party Syriza last week, and comes as 6,000 protesters gathered outside parliament to protest against the cash-for-reforms deal. Tsipras said Greece must confront "new realities" and warned that the painful path does not stop here, as the country adapts to the bailout agreement.

site_title: Greek PM promises will not allow foreclosure of primary homes
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras pledged his government would not allow banks to seize primary residences of Greeks, promising lasting protection of primary homes. This comes ahead of a vote on a bill tightening foreclosure rules as part of a bailout agreement. Tsipras said his government was forced to accept reforms to avoid a Greek euro exit, and will now focus on political and anti-corruption reforms in the coming days.

site_title: New Zealand cuts interest rates again, flags more to come
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank cut interest rates for the second consecutive month, lowering the Official Cash Rate (OCR) to 3.0% from 3.25%. The decision aims to address "softening" growth and low inflation in the farm-reliant economy. Governor Graeme Wheeler warned that more easing may be necessary, citing a slowdown in dairy exports and construction activity. The move is expected to support economic growth, which is forecast to slow to 2.5% due to the decline in export prices.

site_title: Tim Cook's US$181b headache: Apple's cash held overseas
summary: Apple's cash reserves have surpassed $200 billion, with 89% held overseas, putting pressure on CEO Tim Cook to find a way to use the funds without incurring US taxes. The company's booming global revenue, particularly in China, has driven the increase. Apple is seeking to return more of its cash to investors, but its current system encourages companies to shift profits abroad, with over $2 trillion being stockpiled overseas by US companies. Cook has called for comprehensive tax reform and is already the largest taxpayer in the US.

site_title: UK car production up sharply in June as export demand surges
summary: British car production rose 5.4% in June, reaching 143,759 cars, with exports increasing 9.0% to 115,408. The first half of 2015 saw 793,642 cars produced, a 0.3% increase. Productivity among car producers has improved, with £100,000 in added value per employee in 2014. The industry's success is attributed to significant investment and a positive relationship with the government, essential for maintaining international competitiveness. This marks the strongest half-year performance since 2008.

site_title: Japan's June exports rise 9.5% year on year
summary: Japan's exports rose 9.5% in June from a year earlier, exceeding economists' expectations of a 10.0% annual increase. This marks the fastest pace of rise in five months, following a 2.4% year-on-year increase in May. Meanwhile, imports fell 2.9% in the year to June, leading to a trade balance deficit of 69.0 billion yen.

images.alt_text: Japan's exports rose 9.5 per cent in June from a year earlier, Ministry of Finance data showed on Thursday, in a sign overseas demand bounced back from a dip last month.

site_title: Software patch issued after hackers take over Jeep
summary: Fiat Chrysler released a software patch for some of its Internet-connected vehicles after hackers remotely commandeered a 2014 Jeep Cherokee as part of a demonstration of a vulnerability. The hackers, Charlie Miller and Chris Valasek, gained control of the vehicle's steering, brakes, radio, windshield wipers, and more. Fiat Chrysler claims no first-hand knowledge of the hack and released free software updates for affected vehicles. The updates are available on the UConnect website and are designed to improve security protection and reduce the risk of unauthorized access to vehicle systems.

site_title: Thousands protest as Greece votes on bailout bill
summary: Thousands of anti-austerity protesters gathered in Athens as lawmakers prepared to vote on a second bailout bill, which must pass for Greece to unlock a $128 billion international bailout. The vote poses a challenge to Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, who relied on opposition MPs to pass the law, which includes sweeping changes to taxes, pensions, and labor rules. Analysts say the debate will show whether Tsipras can avoid another split within his own party and head off the risk of early elections.

site_title: Dollar off lows, kiwi rallies on less dovish central bank stance
summary: The New Zealand dollar rallied after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand trimmed interest rates by 25 basis points, beating expectations of a 50-basis-point cut. The kiwi dollar rose to a peak of US$0.6654, moving away from a six-year low. The US dollar, meanwhile, edged up against the yen, while the euro inched down. The prospect of higher interest rates in the US and UK boosted the dollar's appeal, while the British pound also gained.

site_title: New York shelves effort to limit Uber growth
summary: New York City has shelved plans to cap Uber's growth, agreeing to a four-month study on the effect of ride-hailing services on traffic and pollution. The deal averts a potential showdown between Mayor Bill de Blasio and Uber, which had launched an aggressive ad campaign. The study will examine the impact of all for-hire vehicles on traffic congestion, with Uber agreeing to release additional data. The city will review the impact of all for-hire vehicles by the end of November.

site_title: Fraser & Neave's Myanmar Brewery stake worth over twice the bid price
summary: Fraser & Neave's (F&N) 55% stake in Myanmar Brewery is estimated to be worth US$560 million (S$763 million), more than double the original bid price of US$246 million (S$335 million). The valuation is attributed to the brewery's leading position in the Myanmar beer market, iconic brand, and distribution network. A sale of its stake could result in F&N losing a significant growth driver, but the company has earmarked funds for further investments. F&N shares closed 4 cents down at S$2.55 on the news.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.50% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.50% higher on Thursday, driven by a weakening yen that boosted exporter shares. The Nikkei 225 index rose 103.43 points to 20,697.10, despite US stocks falling on disappointing earnings from Apple and Microsoft. Japan's trade deficit narrowed last month as exports picked up, while oil prices fell due to higher crude stockpiles. The yen's weakness also made energy imports more expensive, but provided relief for Japan, which relies heavily on pricey energy imports.

site_title: Existing US home sales hit 8-year high in June
summary: US existing home sales reached an 8-year high in June, with a 3.2% increase to a 5.49 million annualized rate, according to the National Association of Realtors. Median home prices rose 6.5% to a record $236,400, while the number of properties on the market rose to 2.3 million. The housing market is expected to continue its recovery, but faster wage growth is needed to offset weakness elsewhere. The real estate agents' group projects sales will total 5.26 million this year, the most since 2007.

site_title: Greenback struggling after one-year rally
summary: The US dollar struggled on Wednesday, experiencing its biggest decline in a month, amid profit-taking and uncertainty over a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. Sterling rose almost half a percent on comments from Bank of England policymakers supporting higher interest rates. Despite a year of gains, the dollar's inability to trade above US$1.08 per euro since April raises concerns about its long-term prospects. Analysts remain bullish on the dollar, expecting a rate hike in September, but its rally appears to be running out of steam.

site_title: Google lets users map their steps
summary: Google has introduced a "Your Timeline" feature in Google Maps, allowing users to automatically map their steps and view histories of trips taken. The feature, enabled by geolocation on smartphones, lets users visualize their real-world routines and see where they spend their time. Users can control what information is shared and private, and edit or delete locations as needed. The feature is initially available on Android-powered mobile devices and desktop computers, with plans to expand to other platforms.

site_title: NYSE and Nasdaq bolster safeguards for critical closing auctions
summary: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) and Nasdaq Stock Market have agreed to back each other during malfunctions in their daily closing auctions, enhancing safeguards for the US$25 trillion stock market. If one exchange can't establish closing prices, the other will calculate them. The plan, which needs SEC approval, aims to prevent disruptions that can impact investors and the global market. The agreement follows a July 8 outage at the NYSE, which raised concerns about the lack of a backup plan. The exchanges will work together to strengthen the US equity markets.

site_title: Canadian dollar hits 10-year low; pound up on bullish BOE
summary: The Canadian dollar hit a 10-year low against the US greenback due to weaker growth prospects and the Bank of Canada's interest rate cut. The British pound gained strength on the Bank of England's bullish policy meeting minutes. The US dollar reached a 10-year high of C$1.3047, while the pound surpassed the US$1.56 level. Analysts expect the Bank of England to consider an interest rate hike before the end of the year. The Canadian economy has been weakened by the plunge in oil prices, while the US Federal Reserve is moving towards raising rates.

site_title: New York plans US$15 minimum wage at fast-food chains
summary: New York state is set to raise the minimum wage to $15 in the fast-food sector, a 71% increase from the current $8.75 an hour. The wage increase will be phased in, starting with New York City restaurants in 2018 and elsewhere in the state in 2021. The move is a key victory for workers' campaigns for liveable wages, with Governor Andrew Cuomo indicating he will follow the panel's recommendation. The decision is seen as a model for other states and cities, with Los Angeles and Seattle already passing similar wage increases.

site_title: Citigroup shuts Banamex USA, pays US$140m in fines
summary: Citigroup will shut its US branch of Mexican subsidiary Banamex due to inadequate anti-money laundering programs. The company will pay $140 million in fines and wind down operations, affecting 300 workers. Banamex USA had failed to correct weaknesses in its anti-money laundering program, despite a 2012 consent order. The closure is the result of new violations of federal bank secrecy and money laundering rules, with Citigroup focusing on reassigning employees to other roles.

site_title: US regulator mulling over plane safety amid soaring bird population
summary: US regulators are considering whether planes need to be built to withstand collisions with birds due to a significant increase in Canada goose and pelican populations. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is seeking public comment on new safety standards amid a record 10,856 bird strikes in 2013. The agency cites incidents such as the "Miracle on the Hudson" and a 2013 plane damaged by ducks, which cost $494,000 to repair. The FAA is also considering strengthening aircraft against birds in other ways and wants to know if planes should be designed to withstand heavier bird strikes.

site_title: Oil prices drop as US reports higher crude supplies
summary: US oil prices dropped by $1.67 to $49.19 a barrel, the lowest since April 2, after the US Department of Energy reported higher crude stockpiles. Commercial crude stockpiles rose by 2.5 million barrels, and supplies at the Cushing, Oklahoma hub increased by 800,000 barrels. The drop was attributed to a global supply glut and the strengthening dollar, which makes crude more costly for buyers using other currencies. Analysts expect the price drop to have a "psychological impact" leading to further selling.

site_title: COE premiums continue to fall
summary: COE premiums for passenger cars in Singapore have fallen for the second consecutive tender, with Category A decreasing by S$2,811 to S$55,889 and Cat B dropping by S$7,392 to S$58,109. This marks the lowest premiums in the first seven months of 2015. The expected rise in COE supply by up to 15% due to deregistration numbers is also expected to stabilize premiums in the coming weeks.

site_title: Remy Martin to export 'smart' cognac to China to stop fakes
summary: Remy Martin, a French cognac giant, is launching a "smart" cognac bottle in China to combat counterfeits. The bottle, sold in three major Chinese cities, features a chip in the cap that communicates with a smartphone app, allowing consumers to verify its authenticity and track its contents. This technology aims to address the significant issue of counterfeit cognac in China, where it is a major problem. The launch is part of Remy Martin's efforts to protect its brand in its key market, alongside the US.

images.alt_text: A bottle of "XO" (extra old) cognac is displayed at the Remy Martin distillery in Cognac, southwestern France.

site_title: Ascott Reit Q2 DPU falls 5%, revenue rises 12% to S$98.7m
summary: Ascott Residence Trust posted a 5% dip in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.09 Singapore cents for Q2 2015, with revenue rising 12% to S$98.7m. Excluding one-off items, DPU would have been 5% higher. The Reit's gross profit rose 6% to S$49.4m, driven by acquisitions in 2014. Ascott Reit is expanding its portfolio to nearly 11,800 units across 96 properties in 40 cities, with asset value reaching S$4.6 billion.

site_title: Qualcomm unveils cuts in jobs, spending
summary: Qualcomm, the world's largest mobile semiconductor manufacturer, is cutting 15% of its workforce, or around 4,650 employees, as part of a "right-sizing" plan to improve financial performance. The company aims to eliminate $1.4 billion in spending, including a $300 million reduction in annual share-based compensation grants. This move follows pressure from activist shareholder Jana Partners, which has called for a breakup of Qualcomm's patent division. The company has also posted a profit of $1.2 billion in the past quarter, down 47% from a year ago.

site_title: Greek bailout vote puts Syriza party rebellion to the test
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' leftist Syriza party faces a test as lawmakers vote on reforms required to start talks on an 86 billion euro rescue loan. The legislation, which includes rules for dealing with failed banks and speeding up the justice system, is expected to pass despite planned protests. The bill's passage will be closely monitored to see if Tsipras loses more support, with hardline Syriza lawmakers opposing the deal. The reforms are a condition for Greece to receive the bailout loan and kickstart negotiations, with talks set to begin this week.

site_title: Japan won't meet its fiscal discipline target in 2020
summary: Japan's government announced it will not meet its fiscal discipline target of returning to a primary budget surplus in fiscal 2020, citing a need to boost revenue and lower spending. The target is crucial for reducing Japan's high debt-to-GDP ratio. The Cabinet Office forecast a primary budget deficit of 6.2 trillion yen (1% of GDP) in fiscal 2020, short of the goal. This decision prioritizes economic growth over spending cuts, raising concerns about increasing the debt burden.

site_title: Cambridge Industrial Trust's DPU for Q2 down 2.1%
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust's (CIT) distribution per unit (DPU) for Q2 fell 2.1% to 1.225 Singapore cents, despite a 0.5% increase in distributable amount to S$15.79 million. Gross revenue rose 13.2% to S$27.81 million, and net property income increased 9.9% to S$21.6 million. The trust strengthened its capital structure through a medium-term note issuance and refinanced its S$250 million club loan. CIT's borrowing costs are now "significantly insulated" against interest-rate hikes, with 96.5% of its exposure fixed for 3.5 years.

images.alt_text: Panasonic Building is one of the properties owned by Cambridge Industrial Trust Management.

site_title: Harsh generosity of Germany's Angela Merkel
summary: Germany's Angela Merkel has been criticized for her handling of the Greek bailout package, which some argue is overly restrictive and fails to address Greece's economic needs. Merkel's stance on "Grexit" - Greece exiting the eurozone - is seen as too harsh, and observers argue that the current system favors Germany over other European countries. The article suggests that the eurozone's strict fiscal policies and lack of macroeconomic sovereignty have led to a situation where Greece is stuck in a cycle of debt and deflation, with little hope of economic recovery.

site_title: Nuns won't sell convent to Katy Perry
summary: Katy Perry's plan to turn a former convent into her home has hit a roadblock. Two elderly nuns, Sister Rita Callanan and Sister Catherine Rose Holzman, have challenged the authority of the archdiocese to sell the property, citing a unilateral change to the convent's bylaws. The sisters, who range in age from 77 to 88, oppose the sale to Perry, who has reportedly visited them and expressed interest in living on the property with her family. The archdiocese counters that the sale to restaurateur Dana Hollister is the best option.

site_title: Vard's Q2 earnings take a dive
summary: Vard Holdings, a Singapore-based shipbuilder, reported a 58.6% drop in Q2 net profit to 58 million Norwegian kroner, and a 64.3% decline in earnings to S$10 million, due to lower revenue and a decline in yard utilization. The company expects this trend to continue for the rest of 2015 and 2016. Vard has started cutting jobs and reducing its workforce, but remains optimistic about opportunities in specialized segments and plans to focus on research and developing new business.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as Apple, Microsoft tumble
summary: US stocks fell on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 69.42 points (0.39%) to 17,849.87. Apple's shares tumbled 4.3% due to disappointing earnings, while Microsoft fell 3.7% after reporting a loss of $3.19 billion. The Nasdaq Composite Index sank 36.35% to 5,171.77. Despite Apple's 38% increase in net income, revenue forecast fell shy of expectations, and analysts questioned the 47.5 million iPhones sold.

site_title: More Britons switching banks after launch of new rules
summary: New UK bank switching rules resulted in a 4% increase in customers switching accounts in the year to June, with 1.1 million switches, up from 1.06 million the previous year. The rules, introduced in 2013, allow for seamless account transfers within seven working days. 69% of Britons are now aware of the service, up from 58% at launch. Santander attracted the most new net accounts, while Halifax offered cash payments to new customers, and Barclays and NatWest lost the most customers. The Competition and Markets Authority is investigating the market for personal current accounts.

site_title: More job losses coming to US shale
summary: US shale oil industry faces significant challenges as oil prices remain below $50 per barrel, leading to rising debt and increasing risk of default. Despite a recent report showing job creation in the sector, analysts predict a downturn in the industry, with Goldman Sachs forecasting only 20-50 drilling rigs to return by the end of 2015. Companies are struggling to sustain operations with high drilling costs, and some small and medium producers may file for bankruptcy. Big operators like Exxon Mobil, Chevron, and ConocoPhillips may also start downsizing their workforce if oil prices remain low.

site_title: Seafacing bungalow on Sentosa offered via expression of interest
summary: A seafacing bungalow on Sentosa Cove is being offered via expression of interest with an asking price of S$25 million (S$2,325 psf) for its 10,754 sq ft land area. This would be the lowest price per square foot for a seafacing bungalow in the area since 2012. The property boasts high-quality finishes and features, including a swimming pool, jacuzzi, and titanium-coated plates. If sold, it would be the lowest price per square foot for a seafacing bungalow in Sentosa Cove.

site_title: Trump's run fuels his feud with Murdoch
summary: Donald Trump's presidential campaign has strained his relationship with media mogul Rupert Murdoch, who has publicly denounced Trump's comments on Mexican immigrants and his treatment of Senator John McCain. Murdoch's media outlets, including The Wall Street Journal and The New York Post, have published scathing editorials and headlines criticizing Trump. In contrast, Fox News has maintained a more neutral stance, but its host Bill O'Reilly has chided Trump for his remarks about McCain. Trump is now seeking to woo Roger Ailes, the CEO of Fox News, as a potential ally in his bid for the Republican nomination.

site_title: 2 in 5 Japan firms plan increased capital spending
summary: Japan firms plan to boost capital spending by 2 in 5, with 40% aiming to increase both overall and domestic spending. Rising demand and need to replace ageing equipment are the main reasons cited, with 40% of respondents citing these factors. However, 27% of respondents said domestic sales have fallen short of plans, and only 13% said sales have exceeded expectations. This suggests companies may face challenges in implementing their investment plans, but the survey offers a positive surprise to policymakers seeking increased business investment.

site_title: Foreign buyers snapping up Sydney skyscrapers
summary: Foreign buyers are investing record sums in Sydney's office market, attracted by higher yields. They now own nearly one in five downtown buildings, driven by the city's allure. This trend is part of a global property boom, with other cities experiencing similar demand.

site_title: MDIS to open third overseas campus
summary: Management Development Institute of Singapore (MDIS) is launching its third overseas campus in Chennai, India, in a joint venture with Vels Institute of Science, Technology and Advanced Studies (VELS). The campus will offer business and management programs, with construction scheduled to begin in July 2016. MDIS will hold a 51% share in the joint venture, with VELS holding the remainder. The campus is expected to support 1,500 to 2,000 students and will be operational by October 2015.

images.alt_text: MDIS courses are offered in collaboration with several universities from Australia, France, the United Kingdom and the United States.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ICH Gemini launched a US$110 million private equity fund in Singapore to invest in mid-sized companies. Deutsche Boerse won approval to operate a clearing house in Singapore, bringing it closer to opening a derivatives exchange in Asia. SATS acquired a 13% stake in MacroAsia Catering Services, increasing its total stake to 33%. The Singapore stock market has seen fluctuations, with oil prices rising over 2% and US stocks edging down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: Growing economy brings Spanish PM no joy
summary: Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy faces challenges in selling the country's economic growth to voters, despite a 22.5% unemployment rate, the lowest since 2011. The economy is growing, with over 500,000 jobs created annually, but Rajoy's party risks losing power due to electoral fragmentation. The government is pushing for tax cuts and cost reductions to boost consumer spending, but faces pressure from anti-austerity parties and criticism from the International Monetary Fund for structural labor market imbalances.

site_title: Harley fights back against cheap Asian bikes by curbing output
summary: Harley-Davidson has decided to restrain motorcycle production despite strong demand, citing the strong US dollar as a major factor. The company's revenue dropped 10% to $1.7 billion and profit slid 15% in the quarter ended June 28, with shipments of 85,172 bikes, a 8% decrease from the previous year. Harley's new CEO, Matthew Levatich, attributes the decline to Asian brands slashing prices in the US, which now buys 23% more yen than last year, giving foreign competitors an edge.

site_title: Winds blow aerial ash away, Bali airport reopens
summary: Bali's international airport reopened on July 22, 2015, after a three-day closure due to volcanic ash from Mount Raung. The airport had previously been closed twice in two weeks, causing flight cancellations and disrupting holiday plans. With winds shifting direction, the airport began operating at 3:30 pm local time, allowing PT Garuda Indonesia to reinstate 14 cancelled flights and Lion Group to resume operations. The reopening occurred during the peak holiday season for the resort island, which had seen over 200 million Muslims travel home for Eid.

site_title: The botched block trade that spoiled bankers' Mother's Day
summary: A rare Sunday e-mail from Blackstone Group LP invited banks to underwrite 90 million shares in Hilton Worldwide Holdings Inc at a US$2.7 billion stake, which unexpectedly headed southwards. Major banks were left stuck with the shares, resulting in a "botched block trade" that spoiled their Mother's Day celebrations. The unexpected move has led to significant losses for the banks involved, with the full extent of the losses yet to be determined.

site_title: AirAsia to resume Japan flights early next year
summary: AirAsia plans to resume flights to Japan early next year, starting with domestic and international routes from Chubu Centrair Airport. The airline had previously exited the market in 2013 due to a dispute with All Nippon Airways. AirAsia Japan will launch flights in spring 2016, aiming to crack the Japanese market controlled by ANA and Japan Airlines.

site_title: Singapore's consumer confidence slips again in July
summary: Singapore's consumer confidence index dropped 3 points in July to 126.4, marking a second consecutive month of decline. The decline is attributed to pessimistic economic indicators such as declining GDP growth, negative inflation, and rising interest rates. A survey found that 27% of respondents believe their families are better off financially than last year, down from 29%, while 33% expect to be better off in a year, down 3 percentage points. The number of respondents who consider it a bad time to buy major household items increased to 19%.

site_title: Banco de Brasil is world's cheapest bank after govt stake sale
summary: Banco de Brasil, Brazil's largest bank by assets, has become the world's cheapest bank after the government sold 1 million shares, reducing its stake to 80%. The bank's shares trade at 5 times forecast earnings, the lowest ratio among top 100 banks by market value. Analysts predict the bank's dividend yield of 7.5% in 2016, but warn of further declines due to the government's potential sale of more shares to finance its budget deficit.

site_title: Australia dry spell boosts beef export to all-time high
summary: Australia's severe drought has led to a record-high beef export to the US, with shipments increasing by over 70% in 2015. The drought has caused ranchers to cull cows at the fastest pace in over three decades, boosting beef exports to an all-time high. The US has become Australia's top export market, with most beef destined for burgers. The drought is expected to continue, potentially leading to more herd liquidation, and Australia's cattle cull may reach eight million for the third consecutive year.

site_title: Retail sector rents could ease in 2H (Amended)
summary: Retail sector rents in Singapore are expected to ease in the second half of 2015 due to department store closures and an increase in retail space supply. Knight Frank reports a 1-2% decline in prime retail rents this year, and average rents may fall by 3-5% in 2015. The supply of new retail space is expected to increase by 3.7 million sq ft from 2015 to 2019, with 1.1 million sq ft completed in 2018. Department store closures, such as Isetan and John Little, have led to vacant units and a shift towards short-term leases.

images.alt_text: Orchard Gateway.

site_title: STI falls, but penny stocks still in play
summary: Singapore share prices closed lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index down 12.24 points at 3,359.17, due to weaker markets across most of Asia. Asian markets were hit by cautious sentiment from US markets, where tech behemoths Microsoft and Apple reported weaker quarterly results. However, some penny stocks in Singapore saw strong trading activity, including Qingmei Group Holdings and Foreland Fabrictech Holdings. The debut of iX Biopharma on the Catalist board also saw gains, with its shares closing 10 cents higher at S$0.56.

site_title: FedEx orders 50 Boeing freighters in deal worth US$9.97b
summary: FedEx has signed a deal with Boeing to purchase 50 additional 767-300 freighters, valued at US$9.97 billion, allowing Boeing to extend its production line into the next decade. The order brings FedEx's total firm orders for 767Fs to 106 and aims to modernize its fleet, reducing structural costs and improving fuel efficiency. Despite a soft air cargo market, Boeing forecasts 4.7% annual growth in global air freight traffic over the next 20 years.

site_title: Halep eager to return to Singapore for WTA Finals
summary: Romanian tennis player Simona Halep is eager to return to Singapore for the upcoming BNP Paribas WTA Finals tournament. She had a successful debut at the event last year, finishing as the runner-up and praised the crowd support she received during her matches. Halep is currently the world No. 3 and is eyeing the prestigious Billie Jean King trophy. The tournament will feature the top eight singles players and doubles teams, with Serena Williams defending her title after winning the first three Grand Slams of 2015.

site_title: French govt pledges 600m euros in aid to protesting farmers
summary: The French government has pledged 600 million euros in aid to protesting farmers, who have blocked cities, roads, and tourist sites due to falling prices and increased competition. The aid package includes waiving 100 million euros in taxes, setting aside 500 million euros for debt relief, and guaranteeing 500 million euros in loans. Farmers blame supermarkets, distributors, and the food processing industry for keeping prices low, and protests have grown more violent over the past few days. The government has also acknowledged that around 22,000 farms are on the brink of bankruptcy, with a combined debt of 1 billion euros.

site_title: Gold continues to face downward pressure
summary: Gold prices fell for a seventh consecutive session, with a 0.8% drop to $1,094.20 an ounce, amid sustained downward pressure. The decline was exacerbated by a looming US interest rate hike and reduced demand outlook. Holdings in the SPDR Gold Trust dropped to 22.17 million ounces, its lowest since 2008. Experts predict further losses, with Goldman Sachs' Jeffrey Currie saying prices could fall below $1,000 an ounce for the first time since 2009.

site_title: A-Reit's Q1 DPU rises 5.5%
summary: A-Reit's Q1 DPU rose 5.5% to 3.841 Singapore cents driven by positive rental reversions and higher occupancies at its business space and industrial properties. Gross revenue increased 10.6% to S$180.5 million, while occupancy rates improved to 88.8% and 84.7% for the overall portfolio and multi-tenant buildings, respectively. The Reit manager has continued to reposition its assets, completing several enhancements and divesting underperforming properties.

site_title: Warburg Pincus to invest in India developer
summary: Warburg Pincus is investing approximately $284 million in Piramal Realty, a real estate developer backed by the Indian conglomerate Piramal Group. This is the firm's fifth investment in India in less than a year. Piramal Realty has 10 million square feet under development, valued at over $600 million, and plans to use the investment to acquire more properties around Mumbai. The move is seen as a significant expansion of Warburg Pincus's presence in the Indian real estate market.

site_title: 1MDB 'Tentacles'
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB scandal is attributed to weak corporate governance, leading to muddled financials. Helen Wong will retire as OCBC CEO, succeeded by Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Meanwhile, Citigroup sets a target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index by mid-2026 and Chinese banks struggle with consumer lending. MAS and PBOC will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, highlighting the need for financial regulation in the region. Tan Teck Long's appointment signals a shift in OCBC's leadership.

site_title: Citi told to pay US$770m over credit card practices
summary: Citi has been ordered to pay US$700 million in relief to borrowers for illegal credit card practices, including deceptive marketing and unnecessary fees. The US Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) has also fined Citi civil penalties of US$35 million. The settlement is the CFPB's 10th case against a major US bank, following similar fines on JPMorgan Chase & Co and Bank of America Corp. This brings Citi's total fines and settlements to over US$17 billion since the financial crisis, affecting about seven million customer accounts.

images.alt_text: About seven million customer accounts were affected by Citibank's "deceptive marketing" practices.

site_title: Tech world's biggest challenge: Finding the right talent
summary: The tech world's biggest challenge is finding the right talent, as rapid technological advancements disrupt traditional industries and create new ones. Companies struggle to balance technology and business acumen, with many struggling to embed digitization into every business unit. Traditional firms face difficulties attracting and retaining tech-savvy talent, while start-ups also face challenges as the talent pool becomes increasingly saturated. To succeed, companies must adapt their mindset and work culture to become more attractive to digital talent, and deploy them effectively to navigate the ever-changing landscape.

site_title: US$7 billion charge leads to largest loss ever for Microsoft
summary: Microsoft reported its largest loss ever, $3.2 billion, due to a $7.5 billion accounting charge from its Nokia acquisition. The charge led to a 40% decline in net income, despite strong growth in its cloud services business, Xbox games, and Surface tablets. Revenue fell 5% to $22.18 billion, but the company's overall revenue rose to $93.58 billion for the full year. Despite the challenges, Microsoft's shares fell only 4% in after-hours trading, with analysts praising the company's results and outlook for its new operating system, Windows 10.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust DPU up 0.5% in Q3
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) posted a 0.5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.036 cents for its third quarter ended June 30, 2015, driven by 15% higher distributable income to S$26.9 million. Gross revenue and net property income rose 14.3% and 12.8%, respectively, due to the addition of Changi City Point and step-up rents. Despite a 5.3% average rent increase, negative rent reversion at one store and a struggling Bedok Point mall impacted occupancy, which fell to 96.5% from 98.5% last year.

site_title: Security researchers find a way to hack cars
summary: Security researchers Charlie Miller and Chris Valasek have found a way to hack hundreds of thousands of cars remotely, using a vulnerability in a Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) car stereo head unit. They demonstrated this at the Black Hat and Def Con conferences, showing they could control vehicles' speed, lights, and brakes from the internet. The discovery is part of a new chapter in vulnerabilities and attacks on the Internet of Things, affecting 14 carmakers that account for 80% of the worldwide auto market. FCA has released a patch to fix the issue.

site_title: China's rising influence over Indian Ocean
summary: China's rising influence in the Indian Ocean is driven by its long-term policy to contain India, according to the country's stable government. China's One Belt, One Road project and its all-weather alliance with Pakistan are key examples. The two nations are actively working together to bring the Afghan government and Taliban to the negotiating table for the first time, demonstrating China's growing strategic interests in the region.

site_title: US real estate firm buys 2 Moscow office buildings
summary: US real estate firm Hines has acquired two Moscow office buildings, Metropolis Office Buildings I and III, jointly with Czech billionaire Petr Kellner's PPF Group. The acquisition provides over 56,000 square feet of Class A offices with almost full occupancy by 40 prime tenants. Hines already owns over a dozen properties in Moscow and St Petersburg, and the purchase was made despite Russia's economy entering its first recession in six years due to oil price decline and sanctions.

site_title: After its market intervention, Beijing faces other challenges
summary: Beijing's market intervention to curb a stockmarket crash has created new challenges for the Chinese government. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 32.1% in one month, prompting the government to cut interest rates, allow pension funds to increase equity allocations, and directly buy shares. Critics argue the measures leave the government holding a massive equity position and send the wrong message about market interference. Unwinding the government's positions will be difficult, and repairing its reputation is crucial to restoring investor confidence. Beijing must balance propping up the market with allowing it to discover prices freely.

site_title: Japan slams China for rigs in disputed waters
summary: China has installed 16 drilling rigs near its disputed maritime border with Japan, Japan's government said. The rigs are located in an area where both countries' exclusive economic zones overlap, and Japan claims it is a unilateral development by China, violating a 2008 agreement to jointly develop the area. Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary described the move as "extremely deplorable" and accused China of "raising concerns among the international community." The move is the latest in a long-standing row over gas fields and maritime claims between the two countries.

site_title: Russia faces extended recession if oil prices fail to recover
summary: Russia's recession may stretch into 2016 due to the latest downturn in the world oil market, with crude prices failing to recover. The country's economy, heavily reliant on oil, may contract for a third year in 2017 if oil remains at $40. The government has already cut budget outlays by 10% and dipped into sovereign wealth funds, and is now facing pressure to finance a potential shortfall. Experts predict a 2-year economic contraction if oil prices remain below $60.

site_title: Thai condo developers wary about second-half outlook
summary: Thai condo developers are cautious about the second-half outlook due to a sluggish economy and unfavorable market sentiment. A recent stock market slump may hit demand for high-priced condos, with some buyers reluctant to buy if the SET falls to 1,400. The industry expects a record high in condo transfers, but developers should monitor demand and household debt, with some limiting purchases to two to four units per name to prevent speculation.

site_title: Brooklyn's hotel boom causing concern
summary: Brooklyn is experiencing a hotel boom with at least 32 new properties planned or under construction, raising concerns about demand and supply. Despite Brooklyn's rising popularity, occupancies and rates are declining, with average occupancy rates falling to 76.8% and average room rates dropping to $155.71 in the first five months of the year. Experts say Brooklyn's status as a cheaper alternative to Manhattan may not be enough to attract most corporate travelers or tourists, and the borough's lack of offices relative to Manhattan may hinder its ability to become a major hotel market.

images.alt_text: The average hotel occupancy rate in Brooklyn fell 1 percentage point in the first five months to 76.8 per cent, while average room rates slipped 2.9 per cent to US$155.71, according to STR Inc.

site_title: Tiger slashes Q1 loss; eyes profit for full year
summary: Tiger Airways narrowed its first-quarter net loss to S$1.68 million, down from S$65.22 million a year ago, due to lower fuel costs and turnaround efforts. The budget carrier clocked a group operating profit of S$552,000, despite a 2% year-on-year decline in revenue. Tiger Airways aims to return to full-year profitability and plans to expand in China, where it launched a store on Qunar.com in April. Fuel costs are expected to be lower in the second half of the year, leading to improved performance.

site_title: Global energy costs to decline despite oil price rise: World Bank
summary: The World Bank predicts global energy costs will decline by 39% in 2015, despite a 17% rise in oil prices. China's economy rebalancing will drive global energy demand, while India's consumption of industrial commodities will also play a significant role. Energy prices rose 12% in the second quarter, with oil prices forecast to average $57 per barrel.
