The report also notes that natural gas and coal prices are expected to decline, and metals prices are projected to average 16% below 2014 levels.

site_title: Australia inflation stays restrained, no bar to rate cuts
summary: Australia's inflation rate rose 0.7% in the second quarter, exceeding expectations, but remained within the Reserve Bank of Australia's target range of 2-3%. Core inflation, excluding petrol prices, rose 0.6% for the quarter, supporting further interest rate cuts if needed. The annual pace of inflation is now within the target range for five consecutive years, a "goldilocks" scenario that allows for rate cuts without deflation risks.

site_title: HPH Trust posts 8.5% rise in earnings for Q2
summary: HPH Trust reported an 8.5% year-on-year rise in net profit to HK$399.9 million for Q2, driven by higher revenue and lower operating costs. Revenue climbed 2.1% to HK$3.13 billion, while earnings per unit rose 4.59 HK cents. However, the company's six-month net profit fell 26.1% to HK$685.7 million, and recommended a DPU of 15.7 HK cents per unit. Management remains cautious on volume outlook for the remainder of the year due to weak EU market.

site_title: Asset management doyen Rothenberg dies at 69
summary: James F. Rothenberg, chairman of Capital Group, a leading asset management company, died from a heart attack at 69 while on vacation in the US. Rothenberg spent 45 years at Capital Group, overseeing $1.4 trillion in assets and was a strong advocate for "active" investment management. He also served as chairman of Harvard Management Co, where he invested the university's $36 billion endowment. Rothenberg's unique approach to investing, which emphasized the importance of multiple managers and a case-by-case approach, yielded one of the best long-term track records in the industry.

site_title: Qoo10 bags US$82m in Series A funding by SPH and investors
summary: Qoo10, a Pan-Asian e-commerce platform, has secured US$82.1 million in Series A funding led by Singapore Press Holdings and eBay. The investment will be used to grow the company and expand its presence in Malaysia, Hong Kong, and China. Qoo10, which operates in Singapore, Japan, Indonesia, Malaysia, Hong Kong, and China, has 17.6 million users and achieved US$408 million in gross merchandise volume last year. The funding will also enable collaboration opportunities on content, marketplace, retail, advertising, and classifieds with SPH.

site_title: Vegas touch charms gamblers of swamp country
summary: The Golden Nugget Hotel & Casino in Lake Charles, Louisiana, is drawing gamblers with its luxurious amenities and offerings, including seven restaurants, five bars, and a pool open until 2:30am. The casino's success has boosted riverboat casino revenue by 19.3% to $179 million in May, making it the best month since legalization in 1991. The Nugget's success is attributed to its "first-class product for the everyman" and has proven that regional casinos can grow the market, with MGM Resorts International taking note.

site_title: Numbers 'too embarrassing' to show fuelled Toshiba scandal
summary: Toshiba faces a major accounting scandal, with the company admitting to at least $1.2 billion in earnings corrections over six years. The scandal involved the company inflating profits by selling PC parts to Taiwanese contract manufacturers at a higher price, with executives under pressure to achieve profit goals. Former president Atsutoshi Nishida and two successors resigned amid the scandal, with the company taking steps to create a new culture and regain stakeholder trust. No charges have been filed, but Toshiba is taking the findings seriously.

site_title: Green light for CIT's US$3.4b OneWest acquisition
summary: US regulators have approved CIT Group's US$3.4 billion acquisition of OneWest Bank, resulting in a combined business called CIT Bank. The merger, one of the largest in the banking industry since the 2008 credit crisis, has been delayed for almost a year due to concerns about creating another too-big-to-fail lender. The acquisition is expected to have a significant impact on the banking industry, marking one of the biggest deals since the crisis.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust Q2 DPU rises 0.7%
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust reported a 0.7% increase in second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.71 Singapore cents, driven by a 0.7% rise in distributable income. The Reit's gross revenue fell 2.9% to S$159.6 million due to lower revenue from IMM Building and occupancies at JCube and Clarke Quay. Despite softening retail scene, CMT is focusing on sustaining DPU growth and has taken steps to optimise its portfolio, including reconfiguring Block C at Clarke Quay and acquiring Bedok Mall.

site_title: Yahoo declines as sales forecast falls below analysts' estimates
summary: Yahoo Inc. declined in extended trading after reporting sales forecast below analysts' estimates for the third quarter, with revenue expected to be $1 billion to $1.04 billion. This falls short of the average analyst estimate of $1.07 billion. CEO Marissa Mayer's turnaround effort is still in progress, with mobile, social features, and video investments showing 60% sales growth. Profit per share was 16 cents, below the average analyst projection of 19 cents.

site_title: Keppel unit inks US$684m LNG carrier conversion contract
summary: Keppel Corp's unit, Keppel Shipyard, has secured a US$684 million contract to convert a liquefied natural gas (LNG) carrier, the Gandria vessel, into a floating liquefaction facility for London-based Golar LNG. This is the third conversion contract awarded to Keppel Shipyard from Golar and marks the exercise of the second of two options. The converted facility is expected to be delivered in about 31 months and will reduce the cost and time required to monetize and deliver offshore gas to market, according to Keppel Offshore & Marine managing director Michael Chia.

site_title: Israeli link found in JPMorgan hacking and 'pump-and-dump' scheme arrests
summary: A grand jury indictment in Manhattan federal court has revealed a complex securities fraud scheme involving at least five stocks manipulated in 2011 and 2012. The scheme, known as a "pump-and-dump" operation, involved promoting stocks through spam campaigns, with perpetrators secretly selling their own holdings to earn millions in illegal profits. Four people, including two Israelis and a US citizen, have been charged with the scheme, while two others remain at large. The investigation is believed to have ties to the 2014 JPMorgan hack, although no direct connection has been made.

site_title: 'Weak corporate governance' cause of 1MDB's muddled financials
summary: The Public Accounts Committee (PAC) in Malaysia is investigating 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB), a state-owned firm, due to "weak corporate governance" that led to muddled financials. Chairman Nur Jazlan Mohamed blames top executives, directors, and auditors for the firm's financial situation, which has sparked a national scandal. The 13-member committee, comprising both ruling and opposition members, has already hauled up several officials, including the Ministry of Finance permanent secretary and KPMG auditors, for questioning. Jho Low, a key figure in the 1MDB controversy, is set to be questioned in September.

site_title: Contract workers at JFK, LaGuardia airports to go on strike
summary: Contract workers at New York's LaGuardia and John F Kennedy International Airports, including security officers, baggage handlers, and wheelchair attendants, have unanimously voted to go on strike starting Wednesday night due to wage and benefit disputes. The strike, which will affect over 35,000 Delta Airlines customers, aims to pressure airlines and the Port Authority to improve working conditions and pay. The union, Service Employees International Union 32BJ, claims that non-union contract workers have been mistreated and pressured to join the company without fair representation. The Port Authority has pledged to work to avoid disruptions to airline operations.

site_title: Taiwan's South China Sea Peace Initiative is timely
summary: Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou has introduced the South China Sea Peace Initiative, a policy calling for all parties to shelve sovereignty disputes, exercise restraint, and resolve disputes peacefully. The initiative, which mirrors Taiwan's 2012 East China Sea plan, aims to establish a code of conduct, respect the UN Charter and Convention on the Law of the Sea, and jointly develop resources. The proposal comes amid escalating tensions in the region, with countries such as China and the US vying for influence. Taiwan hopes the initiative will be accepted and acted upon, promoting peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Weakened yen prompts Toyota to delay Lexus production in China
summary: Toyota plans to delay building its Lexus brand in China for at least several years due to the weakened yen and slowing China car market. It will continue producing cars in Japan, which is now cheaper, and aims to strengthen the Lexus brand in China before investing in a new assembly line. This decision comes as other Japanese manufacturers, such as Nissan and Canon, are also reconsidering exporting from Japan due to the yen's stability above 100-to-the-dollar level.

images.alt_text: New Lexus cars being checked in a plant in southern Japan. Toyota executives say the company will make the premium brand in China some day, but for now, it will focus on manufacturing and exporting the marque from home base.

site_title: Going overseas the solution to China's supply glut
summary: China's severe industrial overcapacity is expected to be solved by shifting production facilities abroad, where demand still has potential to grow. According to an official at the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, China's efforts to boost economic cooperation along the "One Belt, One Road" route will provide opportunities for industries to shift production overseas. The country aims to tackle overcapacity in sectors such as coal, cement, and glassmaking, but loss-making aluminium smelters are unlikely to invest in overseas capacity due to economic and infrastructure challenges.

site_title: Strong first-day trading for iX Biopharma
summary: iX Biopharma, a specialty pharmaceutical company, made a strong trading debut on the Singapore Exchange Catalist board, with shares closing 21.7% up at S$0.56, surpassing its IPO price of S$0.46. The company's therapies for pain management and male erectile dysfunction have strong commercialization potential, driving investor interest. Analysts attribute the firm trading debut to the healthcare sector's demand and the company's low public float. This marks the second healthcare company to list in less than two months, following Singapore O&G's debut in June.

site_title: ECB hikes emergency liquidity for Greek banks: report
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) increased its emergency liquidity for Greece's struggling banks by 900 million euros, following a new bailout agreement between Greece and its eurozone partners. The decision came as the debt-mired country's parliament debated a crucial reform package. The ECB had previously tightened conditions for the Emergency Liquidity Assistance (ELA) program, but the new deal requires Greece to pass market-oriented laws, paving the way for a three-year bailout worth up to 86 billion euros.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has set up China Logistics Fund II (CLF II) with a potential assets under management (AUM) of US$7 billion, expanding its fund management platform. This move is expected to raise fee income and impact earnings from FY 2018 onwards. GLP retained its "add" rating with a target price of S$3.31. Meanwhile, Sinarmas Land acquired a prime commercial property in London for S$551.3 million, and Qian Hu's Q2 2015 net profit fell 96% due to forex losses, leading to lower earnings estimates.

images.alt_text: A property in the eastern city of Urayasu that belongs to Global Logistic Properties.

site_title: Thailand needs to restructure its economy with investment
summary: Thailand's economy faces challenges due to low private investment, with exports and domestic demand still sluggish. The military-led government has accelerated infrastructure plans and approved private investment in key sectors. The next central bank governor, Veerathai Santiprabhob, warns that if investment does not improve, the workforce will face problems and exports will struggle to compete. Despite this, Deputy Prime Minister Pridiyathorn Devakula predicts the economy will grow by around 3% this year due to increased private and government investment and a rebound in tourism.

site_title: ST Telemedia invests S$36.9m in JV with StarHub
summary: ST Telemedia has invested S$36.9 million in a joint-venture (JV) partnership with StarHub, acquiring a 70% stake in Shine Systems Assets Pte Ltd. StarHub will retain a 30% stake. This partnership aims to enhance content delivery and digital services for the company.

site_title: Oil falls on swelling US crude stocks, weak shares
summary: US crude oil stocks rose unexpectedly by 2.5 million barrels, contributing to a decline in oil prices. Oil for September delivery fell to a contract low of $49.67 a barrel, down 86 cents. The rise in crude stocks, driven by a strong rebound in imports, has left Opec members unimpressed by the price drop, with some indicating they will not adjust production to maintain market share. Global supply glut concerns persist, with China's diesel exports expected to reach a record high and Saudi Arabia increasing diesel exports.

site_title: US: Wall St falls after Apple results disappoint
summary: US stocks fell in early trading on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq composite down 1% after disappointing results from technology giants, including Apple, which reported lower-than-expected revenue for the fourth quarter. Apple's shares slumped 6.7% to $121.99. Microsoft and Yahoo also fell due to weak earnings reports. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 were down 0.12% and 0.26% respectively, as commodities prices continued to decline.

site_title: Shaken investors to stay away from gold as confidence shatters
summary: Investors are shifting away from gold due to its failure to perform during expected price increases and recent volatility, particularly a Monday price plunge. Despite a 12-year bull rally, gold prices have largely underperformed, erasing half of its gains since 2011. Experts attribute gold's poor performance to the emergence of the US dollar as a safe-haven asset, reduced expectations of gold price rises, and its relatively high value compared to other assets. As a result, gold is no longer seen as a viable investment option for many investors.

site_title: Popularity of alcoholic root beer growing in US
summary: Hard root beer, a sweeter alternative to traditional beer, is gaining popularity in the US, particularly among craft breweries seeking a competitive edge. Not Your Father's Root Beer, brewed by Small Town Brewery in Illinois, has received an enviable rating of 94 out of 100 on Beer Advocate, making it a sought-after product. The brew's success is attributed to its nostalgic appeal and complementary flavor profile when mixed with bourbon, capitalizing on the trend of sweeter cocktails.

site_title: ST Telemedia invests S$36.9m in StarHub's unit
summary: ST Telemedia invests S$36.9 million in StarHub's unit, acquiring a 70% stake in Shine Systems Assets Pte Ltd, a subsidiary for a state-of-the-art telecommunications, media and data centre facility. StarHub retains 30%. The joint venture aims to develop MediaHub as a convergence hub for its fixed, mobile and pay TV networks, leveraging its location at Mediapolis@one-north. The companies commit to further investments to build and develop the facility, which is expected to be a key hub for emerging media technologies and content.

site_title: Picasso, Warhol, Monet still hot at cool auctions
summary: Global art auctions cooled by 5.8% to $8.1 billion in the first half of 2015, despite weak sales in China, the UK, France, and Germany. However, prices soared for high-value transactions dominated by works by Pablo Picasso, Claude Monet, and Andy Warhol. Sales haven't declined since 2013, with a record $2.7 billion sold in May in New York. The US ranked first, with $3.4 billion in sales, while China declined 32% to $1.5 billion. The top 10 artists sold over $2 billion worth of works, with Picasso leading the list at $441 million.

site_title: US existing home sales near 8-1/2-year high
summary: US existing home sales rose 3.2% to an annual rate of 5.49 million units in June, the highest level in nearly 8-1/2 years, according to the National Association of Realtors. This marks the biggest gain in eight years, with sales on track to record their largest increase since 2007. The strong housing reports indicate the economy remains on firmer footing despite recent retail sales and job growth slowdowns, driven by a tightening labor market and rising wages.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: Singapore's COE premiums for passenger cars fell further in the second July tender, while consumer confidence in the country slid for the second consecutive month. Meanwhile, Keppel Corporation secured a US$684 million contract to convert an LNG carrier. The Straits Times Index closed 12.24 points lower at 3,359.17. International news includes Vietnam's surprise at US Trump's tariff announcement, the Asian garment industry's concern over higher US tariffs, and China's GDP growth expected to slow.

site_title: Europe: Stocks stumble on China, US technology woes
summary: European stocks declined on Wednesday, with the mining sector hit by concerns over China and disappointing earnings figures from US technology giants Apple, Yahoo, and Microsoft. The FTSE 100 index fell 1.50%, while the CAC 40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX 30 also dropped. The euro slid to $1.0890, and London-listed mining companies like Anglo American, BHP Billiton, and Rio Tinto plummeted. The tech sector was also affected, with Apple's shares falling 5.2% after missing earnings expectations.

site_title: Loans to China's property developers down slightly in Q2
summary: China's property developers took 4.88 trillion yuan (S$1.07 trillion) in loans by the end of June, a 20.9% annual increase, but slower than a 24.1% rise in March. Mortgage growth accelerated to 17.8% from 17.6% in the previous quarter. The government's efforts to revive the housing market are showing signs of progress, with property sales measured by floor space rising 16% from a year earlier. However, banks remain cautious about bad debts and have not passed on policy steps to home buyers.

site_title: US plans to seize properties of allegedly corrupt sports executives in FIFA case
summary: US authorities plan to seize properties owned by allegedly corrupt FIFA officials and sports marketing executives, valued between $70,000 and $1 million. The 13 properties include a 1.1-hectare estate in Georgia, a high-rise apartment on a Miami island, and eight rental units in Miami. The government aims to recover tainted money and assets linked to bribery, fraud, and money laundering. The seizures are part of a federal indictment filed in May, which also accused FIFA officials and sports marketing executives of bribery, fraud, and money laundering.

site_title: Analysts as upbeat as ever on Apple; Investors not so much
summary: Analysts remain optimistic about Apple's future prospects despite investors knocking billions off the company's market value. Only one analyst downgraded its rating, while 11 maintained a "buy" or "hold" rating. Analysts point to emerging markets, such as China and India, as key drivers of growth and the potential for the iPhone 6s refresh cycle to benefit the company. The median target price is US$150, and Apple's stock trades at a discount to tech peers, with a current price-to-earnings multiple of 13.7.

site_title: Taxpayers could lose billions as US students escape loans
summary: The US government may forgive trillions of dollars in student loans owed by students who attended now-defunct for-profit colleges, including Corinthian Colleges Inc, Education Management Corp, and ITT Educational Services Inc. Dozens of borrowers are protesting outside a financial aid officers' gathering in New Orleans, seeking loan cancellations under federal law. The situation has sparked debate about fairness and personal responsibility, with some arguing that taxpayers should not be responsible for the debt. If successful, the push for loan cancellations could be unprecedented in US history.

site_title: Opec sees oil drop as short-term, expects stronger demand: delegates
summary: OPEC delegates expect a short-term drop in oil prices, citing stronger global economic growth and higher demand. Despite a 10% decline in Brent crude in July, OPEC will maintain its production target of 30 million barrels per day, aiming to defend market share. Saudi Arabia led the policy shift, supported by Gulf allies, with some countries potentially renewing calls for supply cuts following the price drop.

site_title: Amazon expands local services marketplace in US cities
summary: Amazon is expanding its local services marketplace in 15 US cities, offering services such as plumbing and TV installation. The platform now has over 15 million unique services, and customers can select services and see recommended local contractors and pricing. The company screens service providers and charges a 10-20% referral fee. Amazon aims to add more services and locations, potentially expanding beyond home services to other areas.

site_title: Greece bailout deal by mid-August: EU's Moscovici
summary: Greece and its EU-IMF creditors aim to finalize a third bailout deal by mid-August, with the European Central Bank expecting a 3.2 billion euro loan repayment on August 20. The talks will detail the bailout's timeline and reforms in return for enacted budget targets. EU Economic Affairs Commissioner Pierre Moscovici set the deadline, despite Greece's embattled Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras facing opposition from a fifth of his Syriza party MPs over reforms. The deal is crucial to avoid default and maintain access to financial aid.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Wednesday, closing at 1,729.53 after a 6.66-point decline. 1.66 billion lots were traded, with 403 gains and 409 losses.

site_title: Boeing profit hit by tanker charge
summary: Boeing reported a 33% fall in quarterly profit to $1.11 billion, or $1.59 per share, due to a $536 million charge related to its KC-46A tanker program. Core earnings fell to $1.62 per share from $2.42. Revenue rose 11% to $24.54 billion. The company cut its 2015 earnings forecast to $7.70-$7.90 per share, down from $8.20-$8.40 per share. Commercial aircraft deliveries rose 9% to 197.

site_title: HSBC to agree sale of Turkish unit to ING for around US$750m: sources
summary: HSBC is set to agree to sell its Turkish unit to ING Group for around $700-$750 million, according to sources. ING was one of three banks to submit a non-binding bid in May, alongside Arab Banking Corp and BNP Paribas. HSBC declined to comment on the matter.

images.alt_text: HSBC is set to agree to sell its Turkish business to Dutch lender ING Group for around US$700-US$750 million in the next few days, two people familiar with the matter told Reuters on Wednesday.

site_title: Ascott Reit Q2 DPU dips 5%
summary: Ascott Residence Trust reported a 5% dip in DPU to 2.09 Singapore cents for Q2 2015, excluding one-off items. Revenue rose 12% to S$98.7 million, driven by properties acquired in 2014, and gross profit increased 6% to S$49.4 million. This contrasts with a 5% higher DPU without one-off items, indicating a mixed performance for the Reit.

site_title: BlackBerry to buy messaging alerts firm AtHoc to expand software base
summary: BlackBerry Ltd is acquiring privately-held messaging alerts firm AtHoc for undisclosed terms, expected to close by November. AtHoc's services are used by top clients such as the US Department of Defense and blue-chip companies, providing secure, networked crisis communications. The deal aims to broaden BlackBerry's software base and generate revenue from its BBM messaging service, with AtHoc's services to be enhanced with BBM's richer content offerings. This is part of BlackBerry's strategy to pivot to software and acquire companies for targeted revenue growth.

images.alt_text: BlackBerry Ltd said on Wednesday it is buying privately-held AtHoc, a provider of secure, networked crisis communications, as it moves to broaden its software offering and generate revenue from its BBM messaging service.

site_title: SATS boosts stake in MacroAsia Catering Services to 33%
summary: SATS is acquiring a 13% stake in MacroAsia Catering Services (MACS), increasing its total stake to 33%, for PHP 168.8 million. The deal is expected to be completed on or about August 31, pending government approvals. SATS aims to strengthen its partnership with MAC and grow MACS' food business in the Philippines. MacroAsia Corp will retain 67% ownership of MACS.

site_title: NTUC plans more help for low-wage workers without pay or annual increments
summary: NTUC plans to launch a salary relief assistance scheme for low-wage workers earning S$1,900 and below, providing a one-off payment to those whose employers go bankrupt. The labour movement is in talks with the Manpower Ministry to implement the scheme, which aims to support workers without pay or annual increments. The initiative is a response to the struggles of low-wage workers in Singapore, who often face financial difficulties due to inadequate pay and lack of job security.

site_title: US crude inventories soar above five-year seasonal average: EIA
summary: US crude inventories rose 2.5 million barrels last week, surpassing the five-year seasonal average, according to the Energy Information Administration. Crude stocks at the Cushing, Oklahoma delivery hub increased by 813,000 barrels. Gasoline stocks fell by 1.7 million barrels, while distillate inventories rose by 235,000 barrels. Refinery crude runs rose by 45,000 barrels per day, with refinery utilization rates increasing by 0.2 percentage points. The total inventories stood at 463.89 million barrels, over 100 million barrels above the seasonal average.

images.alt_text: US crude stocks fell more than expected last week, while gasoline stocks increased and distillate inventories fell, data from the Energy Information Administration showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Bali airport reopens after third closure due to volcano ash
summary: Bali's international airport reopened after a third closure due to volcanic ash from Mount Raung. The airport, closed for three days through July 11 and again in the early part of July 12, resumed operations after a wind shift carried the ash away from the island. 14 canceled flights were reinstated, and several airlines resumed operations. The closure disrupted the peak holiday season, with over 200 million Indonesians traveling home for Eid. Authorities will continue to monitor the situation, posing a threat to Bali's economy, which relies heavily on tourism.

site_title: Loans to Chinese property developers cooled slightly in Q2
summary: Bank lending to Chinese property developers cooled slightly in Q2, with a 20.9% annual increase, but remained high. Mortgage lending rose 17.8% from a year earlier, indicating a nascent recovery in the housing market. Despite government efforts to revive the market, banks are cautious about bad debts and haven't passed on policy measures such as interest rate cuts. Improved home sales, with a 16% increase in property sales measured by floor space, suggest that recent government moves are gaining traction.

site_title: Standard Chartered must raise up to US$10 billion, Mizuho says
summary: Standard Chartered may need to raise up to $10 billion from investors to comply with stricter regulations, offset bad-loan charges, and invest for growth, according to Mizuho Securities Asia. The bank's CEO, Bill Winters, may opt to sell $5 billion to $10 billion of new shares to boost the bank's common equity Tier 1 ratio to 11% and offset estimated bad-loan charges of $824 million next year. A rights issue is expected, with analysts predicting a dilutive effect on the bank's share price, potentially leading to a 12-15% increase in share dilution.

site_title: Gold seen going back to boring by chart watchers at Commerzbank
summary: Gold prices are expected to pause after a relentless stretch of losses, according to Commerzbank AG. After falling almost every day this month, gold futures are near a five-year low, but analysts expect a support level to hold prices for a few weeks. Commerzbank analyst Karen Jones believes the market selloff has ended and investors should "get out of their shorts," but predicts a trade between $1,050 and $1,130 within the next few weeks.

site_title: HPH Trust reports 8.5% rise in Q2 profit
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPH Trust) reported an 8.5% year-over-year increase in Q2 profit to HK$399.9 million, driven by higher revenue and lower operating costs. The company's six-month net profit fell 26.1% to HK$685.7 million. Despite the encouraging Q2 results, management remains cautious on the volume outlook for the remainder of the year, citing the depressed EU market. HPH Trust recommended a dividend of 15.7 HK cents per unit for the first six months.

site_title: 'Brexit' fears haunt London's roaring trade in euros
summary: London's dominance in the $5.3 trillion foreign exchange market could wane if Britain leaves the European Union, with some investors fearing a shift to Asia and other European capitals. The city's ability to trade euros and dollars could decline, with the eurozone's 19 members potentially vying for the lost trade. A "Brexit" would require significant infrastructure changes, but over the long term, foreign exchange trading is likely to shift to the US and Asia, according to experts. Britain's allies warn that leaving the EU would be foolhardy, while opponents argue that London would thrive outside the bloc.

site_title: European banks face capital hit from second-quarter bond selloff
summary: European banks are likely to face capital hits from the second-quarter bond selloff, with Italian and Spanish banks hit hardest. The damage is expected to be significant, with Italian banks incurring unrealized losses of over 1 billion euros on European government bonds. Banks in Spain, such as CaixaBank and Santander, also suffered losses, with CaixaBank losing 328 million euros. While the losses are not expected to be severe enough to force banks to sell shares, they will still squeeze capital under post-crisis rules.

site_title: A-Reit marks 5.5% rise in Q1 DPU
summary: A-Reit reported a 5.5% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.841 Singapore cents for the Q1 fiscal year, driven by positive rental reversions and higher occupancies at its business space and industrial properties. Gross revenue rose 10.6% year-over-year to S$180.5 million. Occupancy rates for the overall portfolio and multi-tenant buildings improved to 88.8% and 84.7%, respectively, with positive rental reversion achieved across all segments of the portfolio.

site_title: Giosis bags US$82.1m in Series A funding
summary: Singapore-based e-commerce platform Qoo10, owned by Giosis, secured US$82.1 million in Series A funding led by Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) and participated by eBay and other investors. Qoo10 operates six e-commerce marketplaces across Asia, with 17.6 million registered users, and recorded US$408 million in gross merchandise volume (GMV) last year. The funding will be used to expand the company in Malaysia, Hong Kong, and China, and accelerate growth. Qoo10's Singapore platform is the best performer, with 1.8 million registered users and US$182 million in GMV in 2014.

site_title: Car COE prices tumble further
summary: COE premiums for passenger cars dropped in the second July tender, with Category A slipping to S$55,889, the lowest this year. Category B fell to S$58,109, and Category E dropped to S$60,101, also the lowest this year. Motorcycle COE prices also decreased, with a drop of S$196 to S$6,312. The declines were attributed to slowing car bookings, which have been impacted by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Rocket Internet says 'proven winners' revenue tripled in Q1
summary: Rocket Internet's "proven winners" portfolio saw average weighted net revenue growth of 217% in Q1. The portfolio's value increased by 2.3 billion euros since its October IPO. The company plans to start four new companies this year, bringing its total to 10.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse gets go ahead for Singapore clearing business
summary: Deutsche Boerse AG has received final approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore to operate a clearinghouse in the city-state, paving the way for the launch of a derivatives exchange in Asia. Eurex Clearing Asia will clear equity, bond, and currency futures, while Eurex Exchange Asia will list contracts on German government debt and foreign-exchange futures. The new exchange is expected to open in the second quarter of 2016, allowing global banks to trade continuously across Asian and European hours.

site_title: Gold falls to near 5-year low as bearish view holds
summary: Gold prices fell to a near 5-year low, dropping 0.7% to $1,093.60 an ounce, as the bearish view persists. The decline is attributed to the looming hike in US interest rates, which dents gold's appeal as an investment. Physical demand has been sluggish, and holdings in the SPDR Gold Trust, the world's largest gold-backed ETF, fell to 22.17 million ounces, the lowest since 2008. Experts predict further losses, with some predicting a price target of $1,000.

site_title: Bank of England minutes show 'a number' of rate-setters edging towards hike
summary: The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) voted unanimously to keep interest rates at a record low of 0.5% in July, citing the uncertainty surrounding Greece's debt stand-off and volatility in China's financial markets. However, "a number" of policymakers were edging closer to a rate hike, with some arguing that the economic recovery can withstand a rate increase. The BoE's decision comes despite predictions that the MPC would remain united in keeping rates unchanged, and may signal the end of unity among rate-setters in August.

images.alt_text: Bank of England policymakers voted unanimously to keep interest rates on hold earlier this month but there were signs that more of them were edging closer to pushing for a first hike since before the financial crisis.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks close up 0.21%
summary: China's Shanghai stock index closed up 0.21% on Wednesday, reaching 4,026.05, despite profit-taking after surpassing the 4,000-point level. The Shenzhen Composite Index rose 1.01% to 2,287.98. The gains came despite ongoing market volatility, with US-EU trade tensions and global economic concerns.

site_title: Japan Post, Nomura, Sumitomo Mitsui to set up investment trust
summary: Japan Post, Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Bank, and Nomura Securities have agreed to set up a joint venture to sell investment trusts, starting from next February. The joint venture will be held 50% by Japan Post, 30% by Sumitomo Mitsui, and 20% by Nomura. This move is part of Japan Post's existing efforts to sell investment trust products at post offices, with the new venture aiming to expand the offerings.

site_title: Japan to cut discretionary spending by 10 pct in FY 2016 budget: source
summary: Japan's government plans to cut discretionary spending in the fiscal 2016 budget by 10 percent, reducing it to 13.2 trillion yen, as part of efforts to improve public finances. The government also aims to earmark 30 percent of its 2016 budget for growth policy measures, worth 4 trillion yen, and cap welfare spending gains at 670 billion yen. These measures are part of the government's efforts to address its public finances.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower on Wednesday, tracing Asian markets
summary: Singapore share prices closed lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index down 12.24 points at 3,359.17, following Asian markets. Top losers included Singapore Airlines and DBS Group. Trading volume was 2.79 billion shares worth S$952 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 261 to 191.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall 1.19% on US sell-off, stronger yen
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 1.19% on Wednesday, following a US sell-off and a stronger yen. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 248.30 points to 20,593.67, while the Topix index fell 1.11% to 1,655.37. The declines came despite a near 18-year high for the Nikkei 225 on Tuesday. The weaker yen and concerns over US-EU trade talks weighed on exporters, contributing to the market downturn.

site_title: Australia: Stocks drop 1.61% after 6 days of gains
summary: Australian shares dropped 1.61% on Wednesday, snapping a six-day winning streak, after investors took profits. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 5,614.60, its lowest close in six weeks. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.86% to 5,927.75. The decline was attributed to broad-based losses, with no specific sector or company causing the drop.

site_title: DAP lawmaker Tony Pua barred from leaving Malaysia
summary: DAP lawmaker Tony Pua has been barred from leaving Malaysia after being stopped at KLIA2 airport on Wednesday. He was attempting to fly to Indonesia. The reason for the ban is not specified. Pua is a member of the opposition Democratic Action Party. The incident occurred on July 22, 2015.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close 0.99% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 0.99% lower on Wednesday, following a recent uptick and tracking losses in New York. The Hang Seng Index decreased 253.81 points to 25,282.62 on HK$81.73 billion in turnover. This decline follows a period of gains in Hong Kong equities.

site_title: NYC's hotel onslaught brings glut of rooms to booming Brooklyn
summary: Brooklyn is experiencing a surge in hotel construction, with at least 32 new properties planned or under construction, a record for the area. However, this influx of supply may lead to declining occupancies and rates, as seen in Manhattan, where new supply is also increasing. Brooklyn's average occupancy rate fell 1 percentage point to 76.8% in the first five months of the year, while average room rates slipped 2.9% to $155.71. Experts say that Brooklyn's appeal is mainly to domestic visitors and those looking for a local experience, but it may not be enough to attract most corporate travelers or tourists from overseas.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's DPU up 0.5% at 3.036 cents
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust posted a 0.5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.036 Singapore cents for its third quarter ended June 30, 2015, driven by a 14.3% year-on-year rise in gross revenue to S$47.1 million. Net property income rose 12.8% to S$32.9 million, attributed to the addition of Changi City Point and higher rental income. Distributable income for the quarter was S$26.9 million, a 15% increase from the same period last year.

site_title: Dollar's retreat supports Asia currencies, ringgit near 2-week high
summary: Emerging Asian currencies rebounded as the US dollar retreated, with the Malaysian ringgit reaching a near two-week high. However, analysts warn that this strength may be short-lived due to expected higher US interest rates. The South Korean won and Indonesian rupiah also gained, but the rupiah edged closer to a 17-year low. Despite negative headlines, investors see the ringgit's weakness as a potential buying opportunity, and the won's gains are seen as a temporary rebound.

site_title: UAE to scrap fuel subsidies from August
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) will scrap fuel subsidies on petrol and diesel from August, cutting spending as low crude prices hit revenues. The move aims to save billions of dollars a year and will set pump prices based on world prices, adjusted monthly. The UAE has been spending $29 billion annually on subsidies, and the decision is expected to reduce fuel consumption and encourage the use of environmentally friendly transport alternatives.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall in early deals, led lower by ARM
summary: European shares dropped 0.5% in early trading on Wednesday, led by chip designer ARM's 4.1% decline after Apple's disappointing quarterly earnings results. ARM posted a 32% profit rise, but traders cited the company's reliance on Apple. EasyJet, Europe's second-biggest budget carrier, jumped 4.4% on guidance to annual profit growth of up to 14%. The FTSEurofirst 300 index fell to 1,589.06 points.

site_title: VW's Audi to replace China chief amid accelerating sales decline
summary: Volkswagen's Audi division is replacing the head of its Chinese operations, Dietmar Voggenreiter, who will step down at the end of the year. Voggenreiter led Audi's business in China since 2009 but has seen a 5.8% decline in sales in June. Joachim Wedler, currently overseeing Audi's model line strategy, will take over the role. The move comes as Audi reviews its 2015 target of delivering 600,000 cars in China, which has slowed due to the sales decline. The reason for the reshuffle remains unclear.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen's Audi division will replace the head of its Chinese operations as the luxury carmaker grapples with an accelerating sales decline in its key market.

site_title: 4th Singapore mobile - no major short-term impact: Fitch
summary: Fitch Ratings predicts a limited short-term impact from the entry of a fourth mobile network operator in Singapore, citing high spectrum costs and saturated market penetration rates. The new entrant will face significant capital investment costs and large cash burn, limiting its ability to compete aggressively in terms of pricing. While a conducive competitive environment could lead to market share growth over the longer term, Fitch expects the new operator to struggle, citing precedents such as Virgin Mobile's exit in 2001 and MyRepublic's failure to achieve significant market share.

site_title: Apple faces old question of what's next after record profit
summary: Apple reported its best-ever fiscal third-quarter profit, with net income reaching $10.7 billion, but its shares fell 6% due to missing analyst projections. iPhone sales rose 35% to 47.5 million units, but missed forecasts, while smartwatch sales were lower than expected. The company expects continued growth in the fourth quarter, but analysts question what's next for the company after a record-breaking profit. Apple's CEO, Tim Cook, said the iPhone has "a lot of legs" and that 73% of old iPhone owners haven't upgraded, a bullish sign for future growth.

site_title: Japan govt says won't meet FY 2020 fiscal discipline targets
summary: Japan's government announced it will not meet its fiscal discipline target of returning to a primary budget surplus in fiscal 2020, citing a need to boost revenue and lower spending to address a high debt-to-GDP ratio. The forecasted primary budget deficit for fiscal 2020 is 6.2 trillion yen, or 1.0% of GDP, better than a previous forecast but still short of the goal. The government is prioritizing economic growth over budget discipline, raising concerns about the debt burden.

site_title: ICH Gemini launches private equity fund in Singapore
summary: ICH Gemini, a boutique fund manager, has launched a private equity fund in Singapore with at least US$110 million in capital. The fund will invest in mid-sized companies at growing or mezzanine stages, focusing on sectors such as infrastructure, consumer discretionary, and healthcare. Anchor sponsor Ren Yuanlin has committed US$100 million, while the remaining US$10 million come from ICH Gemini's other two major sponsors. The fund aims to provide access to China's booming capital markets and offer exit strategies via public listing or trade sale.

site_title: UK households bring forward rate hike expectations after Carney hint
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney's hint of higher interest rates has led to a surge in expectations among UK households, with 44% of respondents believing tighter monetary policy is imminent. This is a significant increase from 31% before Carney's speech and 24% in June. The expectation of rate hikes has been driven by Carney's statement that a decision on the first increase in Bank Rate since the financial crisis could come into sharper relief around the turn of this year.

site_title: Microsoft drops after largest quarterly loss on Nokia charge
summary: Microsoft reported its largest quarterly loss, $3.2 billion, due to a $7.5 billion writedown from its failed Nokia purchase. Revenue fell 5.1% to $22.2 billion, and the company cut 7,800 jobs. Despite cloud-computing growth, Windows sales to PC makers and corporate customers declined. The company expects the US dollar to continue affecting revenue, but expects improving results in the mobile business. Microsoft's new Windows 10 operating system is set to be released on July 29, with CEO Satya Nadella expecting it to restore growth to the Windows business.

site_title: Two bank accounts related to 1MDB probe frozen: Singapore police statement
summary: Singapore police have frozen two bank accounts related to the 1MDB investigation, which is linked to financial mismanagement and graft in Malaysia. The accounts are part of an ongoing probe into the Malaysian sovereign fund, which has been linked to US$700 million in deposits into Prime Minister Najib Razak's personal accounts. Najib has denied taking any money for personal gain, and 1MDB has denied transferring funds to him. The investigation is ongoing, and the identities of the bank and accounts have not been disclosed.

site_title: AirAsia says re-starting Japan flights early next year
summary: AirAsia plans to restart flights in Japan early next year, after exiting the market following a joint venture collapse with All Nippon Airways in 2013. AirAsia Japan will launch domestic and international routes from Chubu Centrair Airport, starting Spring 2016. The airline aims to crack Japan's market, controlled by ANA and Japan Airlines, with a new alliance involving Japanese firms such as Rakuten.

site_title: Toshiba risks penalty for raising US$8 billion on false profit
summary: Toshiba Corp. issued $8 billion in stocks and bonds using inflated earnings statements, putting the company at risk of regulatory fines and investor lawsuits. The company's president, Hisao Tanaka, resigned following a third-party panel's findings that executives were involved in systematic overstating of profits. Toshiba's actions, described as "fraudulent," violate the Financial Instruments and Exchange Act, according to professor Etsuro Kuronuma.

site_title: Toshiba sells 4.6% stake in Finland's Kone for US$946m
summary: Toshiba sold a 4.6% stake in Finnish elevator maker Kone Oyj for approximately US$946m. The sale, completed just hours after the announcement, is expected to generate a pre-tax profit of about 113 billion yen (S$1.24 billion) for Toshiba in the current business year. The sale comes amid Toshiba's efforts to divest assets following revelations of accounting irregularities, which led to the resignation of several senior officials.

site_title: Some creditors of Indonesia's Bumi ask court to overrule debt moratorium
summary: Some creditors of Indonesian coal miner PT Bumi Resources Tbk have applied to a Singapore court to overrule a debt moratorium granted to the company's subsidiaries, Bumi Capital, Bumi Investment, and Enercoal Resources. The moratorium, which was granted until October 24, was intended to facilitate debt restructuring talks. The creditors are seeking to "set aside" the moratorium, which could complicate the restructuring process. The hearing is scheduled for September 3. Bumi Resources is struggling to service its debt due to low coal prices.

site_title: Singapore consumer confidence falls for second consecutive month
summary: Singapore's consumer confidence index fell to 126.4 in July, marking the second consecutive monthly decline. The drop was attributed to decreased certainty about family financial prospects and global economic turmoil. Only 27% of respondents believed their families were financially better off in July compared to 29% in June. The decline may signal softer domestic demand and a broader slowdown if it persists.

site_title: Tiger Airways narrows Q1 2016 loss due to absence of Tigerair Mandala loss
summary: Tiger Airways reported a narrower net loss of S$1.7 million for Q1 2016, compared to a net loss of S$65.2 million in the same period last year due to the absence of shutdown costs and losses related to Tigerair Mandala. The loss per share narrowed to 0.07 Singapore cents, down from 5.87 cents in the previous year. The company attributed the improvement to reduced associate losses and lower shutdown costs.

site_title: STB looks for agency to integrate its creative, digital and production services
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) plans to integrate its creative, digital, and production services through a combined agency pitch in August 2015. The agency will be awarded a two-year contract with an option to extend for up to three years. STB is seeking a global network agency that can provide holistic and strategic solutions, following criticism of its 2014 video campaign. The current contracts for creative agency J. Walter Thompson, digital and production agency Mirum, and media agency MEC will end in March 2016 and March 2017, respectively.

site_title: Enviro-Hub to spend S$290m to acquire company-linked vehicles (Amended)
summary: Enviro-Hub Holdings plans to spend S$290.1 million to acquire company-linked vehicles, increasing its stake in the group from nearly 40% to about 69.5% through a series of acquisitions. The group aims to expand its property business by expanding its portfolio of investment and development properties. Enviro-Hub will issue 2.85 billion new shares and set off a shareholder loan to pay for the acquisitions, and plans to consolidate its shares 6:1 after the deal is completed. Trading in Enviro-Hub shares was halted due to the announcement.

site_title: Indonesia has started collecting palm oil export levy: govt
summary: Indonesia began collecting a palm oil export levy on Thursday, with the aim of adding 4.5 trillion rupiah (S$458.7 million) to state coffers this year. The levy requires exporters to pay US$50 per tonne for crude palm oil shipments and US$30 for processed palm oil products. The government received 21 billion rupiah in payments on the first day of collection.

site_title: Yahoo! declines as sales forecast below analysts' estimates
summary: Yahoo! shares fell 2.7% in German trading after the company forecast third-quarter revenue below analysts' estimates, at $1 billion to $1.04 billion. This marks a setback for CEO Marissa Mayer's turnaround effort, which aims to return the web portal to sustainable growth through investments in mobile, social features, and video. Despite a 60% growth in sales in these new areas, analysts say the signs of recovery are still tentative, with RBC Capital Markets' Mark Mahaney stating that the fundamentals are not conclusive.

site_title: Lonza first-half profit beats estimates, prompting asset review
summary: Lonza Group, the world's largest custom maker of drug-ingredients, reported a 7.9% gain in core earnings to 260 million Swiss francs in the first half of the year, beating analyst estimates. The company will review its portfolio to boost profitability further, with CEO Richard Ridinger stating that it may consolidate activities at certain sites and focus on more profitable products and services. Lonza reiterated a full-year forecast for flat sales and core Ebit of at least 5% at constant exchange rates.

site_title: Oil prices resume decline on supply glut worries
summary: Oil prices declined in Asia, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling 70 cents to $50.16 a barrel and Brent crude tumbling 53 cents to $56.51 a barrel. The supply glut remains a concern, with analysts warning of further weakness. The US Energy Information Agency report, due to be released, will be closely monitored, but the supply glut issue is expected to persist. The return of Iranian oil to the market following a nuclear deal has also added to pressure on prices, which have tumbled from over $100 a barrel in June last year.

site_title: China's industrial sector still faces significant downward pressure
summary: China's industrial sector continues to face downward pressure, requiring "arduous efforts" to stabilize the economy. Despite a five-month high in factory output growth of 6.8% in June, firms in some industries struggle to make profits. The Ministry of Industry and Information Technology emphasized the need for significant reforms to address the sector's challenges.

site_title: Yellen's gradual policy path backed by slumping inflation view
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's plan for gradual interest rate hikes is gaining traction amid a slump in investors' inflation expectations. The 10-year break-even rate fell to 1.83 percentage points, the lowest close since June 1, and the spread between two- and 30-year yields held near its narrowest in over a month. This suggests Yellen's preference for a gradual tightening cycle may be the preferred path for monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Janet Yellen's emphasis on a gradual path to higher US interest rates is getting support from a slump in investors' inflation expectations.

site_title: Volcano forces fresh shutdown of Bali airport
summary: Bali's Ngurah Rai airport was closed for the third time this month due to volcanic ash from Mount Raung, forcing flight cancellations and stranding tourists during peak holiday season. The Indonesian transport ministry warned it was uncertain when the airport would reopen. Ash from Raung had previously closed the airport twice in July, cancelling or delaying nearly 900 flights and creating a backlog. The shutdown affects both domestic and international flights, with Australian airlines Virgin Australia and Jetstar cancelling flights to and from Bali.

site_title: US Fed raps China Construction Bank over money laundering
summary: The Federal Reserve has taken enforcement action against China Construction Bank (CCB), the US's first action against one of China's four largest state-owned banks. The bank must submit plans for anti-money laundering controls, customer due diligence, and suspicious transaction spotting within 60 days. The Fed did not impose a fine or sanctions, and the bank did not disclose the problems it was facing. This is the first enforcement action by the Fed against CCB, following a trend of tough US policies against banks failing to enforce compliance.

site_title: Yellen's gradual policy path backed by slumping inflation view
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's gradual approach to raising interest rates is gaining traction amid a slump in inflation expectations. The 10-year break-even rate fell to 1.83 percentage points, its lowest close since June 1. This decrease in inflation expectations has reduced pressure on the Fed to tighten monetary policy, with the benchmark 10-year note yield remaining steady at 2.33%. Experts, including Westpac's Damien McColough, see Yellen's approach as a "re-normalisation of rates" rather than a tightening cycle.

site_title: Asia: Markets slip after Wall Street losses
summary: Asian markets declined on Wednesday following a negative lead from Wall Street, with tech firms linked to Apple retreating after disappointing earnings. The Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq fell, sparking concerns about the upcoming US earnings season. Asian markets, including Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Seoul, also declined, with Tokyo losing 1.23% and Hong Kong shedding 0.89%. The euro held steady despite recent sell-offs, and investors are watching the Greek bailout process for further progress.

site_title: Greece to vote on second bailout bill in test for Tsipras
summary: Greek lawmakers will vote on a second bailout bill, which includes measures to guarantee bank deposits and civil justice reforms. The bill, less contentious than the previous one, aims to secure Athens' third international bailout. Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' authority is being tested after a major parliamentary rebellion last week, with opposition MPs supporting the law to pass. A positive vote will pave the way for Greece to receive its third bailout, but the outcome remains uncertain.

site_title: Shanghai: Shares down 0.53% in morning trade
summary: China's benchmark Shanghai stock index fell 0.53% on Wednesday morning, after breaking above the 4,000-point level. The Shanghai Composite Index slid 21.24 points to 3,996.43. In contrast, the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.07%. The decline was attributed to investors taking profits after the market's recent surge.

site_title: FedEx orders 50 Boeing freighters in deal worth US$9.97b at list prices
summary: FedEx Express ordered 50 additional Boeing 767-300 freighters worth $9.97 billion at list prices, with options for another 50. The deal will be delivered between 2018-2023, bringing FedEx's firm orders for 767Fs to 106. This is the single-largest order for 767s in history, allowing Boeing to extend production into the next decade.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on profit taking
summary: Australian shares fell 1% on Wednesday, ending a 6-day winning streak, due to profit-taking by investors. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped to 5,646.8, with losses in information technology, healthcare, and natural resources sectors. BHP Billiton's profit warning weighed on the market, while gold miners rose 1.7% after metal prices stabilized. The benchmark index is still up 3.5% for the month, but investors remain cautious ahead of the corporate earnings season.

site_title: Seoul: Shares set for biggest fall in 2 weeks; won rebounds
summary: South Korean shares plummeted 0.9% to 2,065.95 points, marking their sharpest daily percentage drop in two weeks, as investor risk-taking decreased following soft US earnings announcements. This decline follows a similar trend seen in US stock markets.

site_title: The most wonderful time of the year for a Fed liftoff isn't December
summary: Federal Reserve officials are considering delaying a rate hike until September or October to avoid year-end market thinness, which could exacerbate volatility. The Fed's benchmark rate is expected to rise in September, with 76% of economists predicting a move at the September meeting, according to a Bloomberg survey. A sharp rate increase could hurt the economy and complicate liftoff, and officials prefer to move on a meeting with a press conference to maintain transparency. The Fed is also concerned about the potential impact on consumer confidence and the economy during the key retail sales season.

site_title: Australia's RBA says rate cuts on table, but sees risks
summary: Australia's Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) Governor Glenn Stevens stated that interest rate cuts remain on the table, but warned of risks associated with excessive borrowing. The RBA has already cut rates to an all-time low of 2.0% and is considering further action due to benign inflation. Stevens cautioned against encouraging a return to borrowing binge in the early 2000s, which could threaten future economic stability. The Australian dollar has hit a six-year low, and Stevens hopes it will continue to be lower to offset a downturn in mining investment and commodity prices.

site_title: Dollar rally takes a breather, uptrend seen intact
summary: The US dollar experienced a brief decline on Wednesday, falling to 97.314, after a four-week uptrend. The drop was attributed to a retreat in equity markets and lower US front-end yields. Analysts at BNP Paribas expect the dollar to rebound due to the Federal Reserve's planned interest rate hike later this year. The decline was a temporary setback, with commodity currencies such as the Australian and Canadian dollars gaining strength.

site_title: LG Electronics shares surge on speculation of Google stake buy
summary: LG Electronics shares surged 14.5% on speculation that Google may acquire a stake in the company. The company's spokesman denied any involvement, calling the market talk "complete speculation." As of 0254 GMT, shares were trading 6% higher compared to a 1% decline for the broader market.

images.alt_text: Shares of South Korea's LG Electronics Inc surged in morning trade on Wednesday, rising as much as 14.5 per cent at one point on market speculation that Google Inc will acquire a stake in the consumer electronics maker.

site_title: Indonesia central bank governor says sees July inflation at 0.46-0.6% m-o-m
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor, Agus Martowardojo, expects July inflation to be 0.46-0.6% month-on-month, with the annual rate potentially dipping below 7%. This follows a 7.26% inflation rate in June. Martowardojo also hinted at easing macroprudential policies, which could offer economic benefits from the fourth quarter. The rupiah is seen as undervalued, but the central bank is not actively managing its value.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, Mapletree Industrial Trust, Stratech
summary: Noble Group faced doubts over its accounting practices after Iceberg Research fired another criticism. Mapletree Industrial Trust posted an 8.8% jump in distribution per unit to 2.73 Singapore cents for the first quarter. Stratech Group secured its first commercial US contract for its airfield surveillance system at Miami International Airport.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust's Q2 DPU up despite lower property income
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust's Q2 distribution per unit (DPU) rose 0.7% to 2.71 Singapore cents, despite lower net property income of 4% to S$109.5 million. Gross revenue fell 2.9% to S$159.6 million. The trust's portfolio occupancy remained at 96.4% due to refurbishment initiatives and reconfiguration work at some malls. Unitholders will receive their Q2 DPU on Aug 28.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.88% lower
summary: Tokyo shares opened 0.88% lower on Wednesday, following a negative lead from Wall Street. The Dow Jones Industrial Average tumbled 1.00%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.43% and 0.21%, respectively. A firmer yen also contributed to the decline. In Tokyo, Toshiba shares rose 1.9% after the company's president and seven executives resigned over a $1.2 billion accounting scandal. The dollar was at 123.88 yen, slightly up from its New York value.

site_title: Oil steady near US$50 amid signs US crude supply glut persisting
summary: US oil futures traded near $50 a barrel amid signs the US crude supply glut will persist. Inventories rose by 2.3 million barrels, and supplies are expected to remain above the five-year average. The global surplus is prolonged due to Iran's plans to restore output after its nuclear accord. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude dipped below $50 a barrel for the first time since April. Oil prices have fallen 5.1% this year, with Brent gaining 0.7% to $57.04 a barrel.

site_title: Australian core consumer prices rise 0.6%, matching forecasts
summary: Australian core consumer prices rose 0.6% in the latest quarter, matching economists' forecasts, and sent the currency higher. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep interest rates on hold, as policymakers seek to maintain 24 years of growth. The data, attributed to a drop in the Aussie dollar and rebound in petrol prices, supports the central bank's decision to leave the cash rate at 2%. The outcome is consistent with the Reserve Bank of Australia's current stance, according to chief economists.

site_title: US, Israel make arrests related to JPMorgan hack: reports
summary: US and Israeli authorities arrested four individuals, including Israeli nationals Gery Shalon and Ziv Orenstein, and US citizens Joshua Samuel Aaron and Anthony Murgio, in connection with various fraud schemes linked to last summer's JPMorgan data breach. The breach compromised 83 million accounts, making it one of the largest in history. The charges include a stock manipulation scheme and operating an unlicensed bitcoin exchange. US investigators initially ruled out Russian involvement in the hack, and instead focused on other activities involving the hackers.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.77 points to 3,372.18 on Wednesday, largely unchanged from the previous day, despite weakness on Wall Street. Oil prices rebounded, contributing to the gain. About 187 million shares changed hands, with Qingmei being the most actively traded, rising by S$0.013 to S$0.047. Losers outnumbered gainers 77 to 73.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.53% lower
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.53% in the first few minutes of trade, following an Asia-wide sell-off and losses on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index eased 134.64 points to 25,401.79. The decline is in line with other markets, including Europe and the US, where stocks are down due to bank and healthcare sector concerns, as well as US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.07 points to 1731.12. The trading volume reached 30.73 million lots worth RM31.65 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 94 to 72.

site_title: Vard Holdings' Q2 earnings plunge 58.6%
summary: Vard Holdings, a shipyard company, reported a 58.6% year-over-year decline in Q2 earnings to 58 million Norwegian kroner (approximately $10 million in Singapore dollars) due to a slowdown in activity caused by the slump in crude oil prices.

site_title: James Rothenberg of Capital Group dies at 69 of heart attack
summary: James Rothenberg, 69, chairman of Capital Group Co and Harvard Management Co, has died of a heart attack. Rothenberg oversaw Capital Group's growth into a leading investment company, but the firm lost its top mutual fund title to an index fund. He remained a defender of active fund management, stating there can be a significant advantage to it. Rothenberg, a Harvard graduate, had a legacy extending beyond Capital Group, to Harvard's endowment, which he managed as treasurer from 2004 to 2014.

site_title: Tech rally unravelling with Apple poised for US$50 billion slump
summary: Apple's stock slumped 6.7% after disappointing earnings reports, potentially wiping over $50 billion from its market value. The tech rally, which had reached an all-time high just days prior, was derailed by poor results from Microsoft and Yahoo. Analysts had expected a 13% profit increase in the second quarter, but earnings weakness across the board led to a 2.4% gain instead. The slump also raised concerns about demand for Apple's iPhone, which missed analyst projections.

site_title: iX Biopharma opens 7.6% higher in Catalist debut
summary: iX Biopharma, a specialty pharmaceutical firm, made its Catalist debut on Wednesday, opening 7.6% higher at S$0.0495, above its IPO price of S$0.46. The company drew strong interest, with an oversubscription of nearly 25 times and fully subscribed placement shares raising S$29.7 million. The listing increases the number of healthcare companies on the Singapore Exchange to 31, with a combined market capitalization of over S$38 billion.

site_title: Yahoo swings to loss as revenues rise
summary: Yahoo swung to a $22 million loss in the second quarter, but revenue grew 15% to $1.24 billion, driven by investments in mobile, video, and native advertising. CEO Marissa Mayer credited the growth to "Mavens," a new emerging area for Yahoo. The company's stake in Alibaba is set to be spun off into a separate company by the end of the year, with potential tax implications. Mayer expressed optimism about mobile search and innovation in search, communications, and digital content.

site_title: S&P raises Greece rating by two notches on bailout talks with creditors
summary: Standard & Poor's upgraded Greece's sovereign credit rating to CCC+ from CCC-, citing improved liquidity and a stable outlook. The upgrade comes after euro zone finance ministers agreed to start negotiations with Greece on a third bailout. The possibility of Greece leaving the single currency union is less than 50%, according to S&P. This is the first upgrade for Greece since a last-minute deal with lenders last week allowed for bridge financing and bailout talks.

site_title: US: IBM, United Tech drag Dow; Apple results weigh on futures
summary: US stocks closed lower on Tuesday, with the Dow falling 1% due to declines in IBM and United Technologies, which contributed 118 points to the drop. IBM's shares fell 5.9% after its revenue dropped for the 13th consecutive quarter, while United Technologies cut its full-year profit outlook for the third time this year. Tech companies Apple, Microsoft, and Yahoo also fell after their quarterly results, pushing stock futures lower.

site_title: Greek PM Tsipras rallies Syriza backing before bailout vote
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras rallied his Syriza party on Tuesday ahead of a vote on the second package of measures demanded by international creditors to open talks on a new bailout deal. The package, which includes tax hikes, market reforms, and spending cuts, is expected to pass with the support of pro-European opposition parties. Tsipras warned party hardliners that ignoring the package would undermine the party's support among ordinary Greeks, who want to remain in the eurozone. The vote comes after a revolt by 39 Syriza lawmakers last week, and officials from the creditor institutions are due to meet with the government on Friday.

site_title: Microsoft posts US$3.2b loss as it writes down Nokia phone business
summary: Microsoft reported a US$3.2 billion quarterly net loss due to a US$7.5 billion charge related to its Nokia phone business. Demand for its Windows operating system fell 22% and 21% in the quarter and year-earlier quarter, respectively. Revenue from its commercial cloud business rose 96%, driven by Office 365 and Azure. The company added 3 million subscribers to Office 365, bringing the total to 15.2 million. Microsoft also cut 7,800 jobs, mainly in the phone hardware business.

site_title: South Korea takes steps to better manage growing household debt
summary: South Korea has introduced measures to mitigate household debt, aiming to lift the amortized loan ratio to 45% by the end of 2017. The goal was initially set at 40% but has been revised. The government will strengthen funding for the Korea Housing Finance Corporation to help local lenders and require lenders to improve loan screening practices. The move comes as South Korea struggles with a fragile economy and heavy household debt, which has been cited as a major weak spot in the financial system.

images.alt_text: South Korea unveiled on Wednesday a modest set of measures aimed at mitigating risks from the heavy and growing household debt burden, but promised to continue with broad policies designed to support economic growth.

site_title: Greenback slips after five-week high against yen
summary: The US dollar slipped against other currencies after reaching a five-week high against the yen and a three-month peak against a basket of currencies, due to renewed expectations of rising US interest rates. The euro rose 0.4% to US$1.0864, while commodity-linked currencies like the Canadian, New Zealand, and Australian dollars remained stable. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to raise rates in September, which may impact the US economy and global markets.

site_title: Doing well amid market turbulence
summary: Asia's private banking business continues to thrive amid market turbulence, with major players posting strong results in the first quarter of 2015. China minted a new billionaire almost every week, and the Asian ultra-high net worth market is expected to surpass the US in five years. UBS, Credit Suisse, and other banks reported robust profits and net new money inflows, with DBS Bank and Bank of Singapore also posting double-digit gains. Despite market volatility, experts recommend staying invested in European equities, with some banks favoring eurozone stocks and others maintaining a neutral weighting on global equities.

site_title: Apple profit jumps but shares slip
summary: Apple reported a 38% increase in quarterly profit to $10.7 billion, driven by iPhone sales that rose 59% year-over-year. However, the company fell short of analyst expectations, and shares dropped 6% in after-hours trading. iPhone sales reached 47.5 million, with sales in Greater China more than doubling to $13 billion. The Apple Watch, launched in April, is not seen as a mainstream hit, with orders plummeting 90% since its debut. Despite this, some analysts predict it will be a top-selling product during the holiday season.

images.alt_text: Apple on Tuesday reported that its quarterly profit leapt 38 per cent to US$10.7 billion on surging iPhone sales, but fell short of analysts' expectations.

site_title: Hackers threaten to leak data of 37m clients of cheating website
summary: Hackers threaten to leak data of 37 million AshleyMadison.com clients, including credit card info, nude photos, and sexual fantasies, unless the dating website catering to cheating spouses is taken down. The hackers, known as The Impact Team, claim they have taken over the site's systems and are demanding payment to stop the leak. AshleyMadison.com's parent company, Avid Life Media, has confirmed the breach and secured the site, but not before hackers leaked snippets of the compromised data online.

site_title: S&P cut its rating on Shell after big BG merger
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) cut its rating on Royal Dutch Shell Plc to 'AA minus' from 'AA', citing weaker financial risk profile due to soft oil prices and substantial capital expenditures. The rating agency considers the company's outlook negative due to the large BG Group Plc acquisition, which could be finalized in the future. S&P's rating may be revised to stable if the acquisition doesn't proceed, but could be lowered further if it does. The company's long-term and short-term ratings have been removed from CreditWatch.

site_title: JPMorgan is US$12.5b short of Fed surcharge
summary: The Federal Reserve has imposed extra capital requirements on the top 8 US banks, totaling US$200 billion, to mitigate the danger of their failure. JPMorgan Chase & Co is short US$12.5 billion, but the bank has reduced its non-operating deposits and trading assets. The requirements, ranging from 1% to 4.5% of risk-weighted assets, will be phased in from 2016 to 2019. The Fed aims to ensure these banks maintain enough capital to prevent system-wide harm.

site_title: Keppel unit bags US$684m LNG carrier conversion contract
summary: Keppel Shipyard has signed a US$684 million contract to convert an LNG carrier into a Golar floating liquefaction facility. The conversion work, expected to take 31 months, will be done for Golar Gandria, a subsidiary of Golar LNG. This marks the exercise of the second of two options awarded to Keppel Shipyard for a similar conversion. Full construction activities will start after a notice to proceed is issued in 2016.

site_title: New rules aim to uncover real owners of NY properties
summary: New York City has implemented new disclosure requirements for shell companies buying or selling luxury properties, aiming to uncover the real owners of high-end real estate sales. The rules, which went into effect in May, require the names of all members of a shell company to be disclosed to the city, with the goal of identifying those who may be avoiding city income taxes by claiming non-residency. The changes are intended to increase transparency and make it harder for criminals to hide their purchases of luxury real estate through shell companies, but some industry players have questioned the necessity and burden of the new requirements.

site_title: Spring to buy 21 Airbus planes for 12.45b yuan
summary: Chinese budget carrier Spring Airlines plans to buy 21 Airbus A320 planes for 12.45 billion yuan (S$2.7 billion), citing growth in international and domestic air travel. The purchase will be funded in part through a private placement of shares to raise 4.5 billion yuan.

site_title: Container shipping is in a bad place
summary: Container shipping faces a toxic mix of overcapacity, weak demand, and aggressive pricing, threatening industry profitability for the rest of 2015. Drewry estimates average global freight rates will decline at their fastest pace since 2011, with some lines expected to be in the red by the end of 2015. The consultant attributes the decline to the need for radical action to address overcapacity, but notes that carriers cannot "address over-capacity" due to regulatory restrictions.

site_title: The changing face of billionaire wealth
summary: Billionaires' wealth dynamics are shifting significantly, with the number of self-made billionaires increasing from under half in 1995 to two-thirds today. The proportion of self-made entrepreneurial billionaires has accumulated 75% of the $4.7 trillion increase in wealth. Asia is now home to 36% of entrepreneurial billionaires, with billionaire wealth in Asia expected to surpass that in the US by 2025. The average age of a billionaire in Asia is 57, a decade younger than their Western counterparts, and intergenerational transfer is becoming more complex, with a greater emphasis on succession planning.

site_title: China slump being felt in world's biggest firms
summary: China's market slump, which wiped out nearly $4 trillion in market value, is affecting corporate earnings worldwide. Companies such as Remy Cointreau, Yum! Brands, Burberry, and Kumba Iron Ore are feeling the impact, with sales and profits declining in China. The International Monetary Fund predicts China's economy will expand at its slowest rate since 1990, posing a risk to global growth. Despite this, some investors and companies, like Investec and Netflix, are optimistic about a rebound in business due to China's demographics and market-friendly policies.

site_title: GET.com to build up website, launches credit card deals app
summary: Singapore-based personal finance-comparison startup GET.com launched its new all-in-one credit card deal app, GETdeals, on Tuesday. The app features over 2,300 credit card deals from major Singapore banks and automatically displays up-to-date card offers based on proximity to users. GET.com plans to expand into other markets and is considering a business model that allows banks to access consumer data. The company earns income mainly from its comparison website, with the app not generating direct revenue. GET.com aims to leverage technology to provide value to consumers in the digital banking space.

site_title: Lessons for Europe from Asia's post-crisis repairs
summary: European leaders can learn from Asia's post-crisis repairs, particularly in addressing structural reform over austerity.
