The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,696.6, its highest level since June 2. Banking stocks led the rally, with National Australia Bank and Westpac Bank rising 1.2% and 0.9% respectively. Resources stocks, including BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, fell 1.1% and 1.5% due to weak gold prices.

site_title: Japan demands China halt oil exploration in part of East China Sea
summary: Japan has demanded China halt construction of oil-and-gas exploration platforms in the East China Sea, near disputed waters claimed by both nations, citing concerns that Chinese drills could tap into Japanese territory. The demand was added to Japan's annual defense review after criticism from hawkish party members. China has resumed exploration in the area, which includes gas fields that overlap Japan's median line, and has started building new platforms on the Chinese side of the median line.

site_title: MAS continues fight against money laundering, terrorism financing
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) continues to combat money laundering and terrorism financing with significant resources. In 2014/15, MAS conducted 74 AML/CFT inspections, issued 9 warnings and reprimands, and imposed financial penalties on 6 financial institutions. While controls were generally in place, MAS identified areas for improvement, including inadequate implementation of updated policies and failure to review suspicious transaction parameters. MAS plans to inspect higher-risk sectors, including money changers and remittance agents, to strengthen its efforts against transnational crime.

site_title: Malaysia's stock index price feed disrupted for almost an hour
summary: Malaysia's benchmark stock index, FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI, was frozen for almost an hour due to a malfunctioning price feed from Bursa Malaysia Bhd. The incident occurred at 10:38 am and resumed at 11:32 am. Despite the freeze, individual stocks continued to trade. The cause of the disruption is currently under investigation.

site_title: Fed rate rise view underpins dollar as Aussie falls on RBA
summary: The US dollar rose to its strongest level in three months as the Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates this year, driving demand for the currency. Australia's dollar fell 0.2% to 73.58 US cents, while the yen dropped to a one-month low after minutes from the Bank of Japan's policy board meeting showed some members expect a temporary slowdown in the nation's recovery. New Zealand's dollar climbed 0.6% to 66.04 US cents after Finance Minister Bill English said dairy prices may recover at the end of 2015.

site_title: Malaysia arrests man to help with high-level probe into 1MDB
summary: Malaysian authorities have arrested Jerome Lee, believed to be the first person to aid a high-level probe into 1MDB, a scandal-hit state investor. Lee was picked up by the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) as he was about to leave for Taiwan. He was given a four-day remand, but his lawyer claims the arrest breached his basic rights. The arrest is part of a high-level probe into 1MDB, which has been embroiled in corruption scandals.

site_title: Shanghai: Shares fall sharply in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares fell sharply on Tuesday, with the Shanghai Composite Index dropping 1.64% to 3,926.55 and the Shenzhen Composite Index losing 1.91% to 2,187.66. Investors became cautious as the market approached the 4,000-point level. The decline was attributed to concerns over market volatility and the impact of US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: US dollar picks up on interest rate hike speculation
summary: The US dollar rose against the yen to a five-week high of 124.38 yen due to speculation that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates this year. The dollar's rise is also attributed to the Bank of Japan's and European Central Bank's efforts to boost their economies, which has pushed down the value of the yen and euro. Fed chief Janet Yellen's comments last week, stating a rate hike before 2016, fueled the dollar-buying trend. Investors are closely monitoring the Fed's decision, which could have a positive impact on the dollar.

images.alt_text: The dollar rose against the yen Tuesday as investors buy the unit on hopes that the Federal Reserve will raise US interest rates this year.

site_title: China's FDI up 8% in Jan-June on M&A: govt
summary: China's foreign direct investment (FDI) rose 8% in the first half of 2015, reaching US$68.41 billion, driven by a sharp increase in mergers and acquisitions. M&A activity more than quadrupled in value, with foreign mergers and acquisitions accounting for 19.3% of total FDI. Investment from the European Union rose 13.7%, while investment from Japan fell 16.3%. Hong Kong remained the largest investor in China, accounting for US$50.69 billion. The growth in FDI was driven by increasing land prices and costs in China, with many companies investing in the country through mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: MAS and MTI reviewing 2015 growth forecast
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) are reviewing the 2015 growth forecast, taking into account weaker output in the first half and supporting factors in the second half. MAS managing director Ravi Menon expects Singapore's growth to expand at a moderate pace of 2-4% in 2015, in line with its medium-term potential. The global economy is expected to grow modestly, with China's growth moderating and the US Fed hiking interest rates. Inflation forecasts remain unchanged, with headline inflation averaging -0.5 to 0.5% and core inflation at 0.5 to 1.5%.

site_title: South Korea tourism struggles to recover from Mers crisis
summary: South Korea's tourism industry is struggling to recover from the Mers crisis, with visitor numbers plummeting 41% in June compared to the same period last year. The outbreak claimed 36 lives and triggered widespread panic, resulting in a potential revenue loss of up to $10 billion. Officials are launching promotional campaigns and waiving visa fees to attract tourists back, with the mayor of Seoul set to travel to China to persuade Chinese tourists to visit. The country's K-pop industry is also being used to promote tourism.

site_title: Singapore Savings Bonds will be issued on Oct 1, 2015
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced that Singapore Savings Bonds will be issued on October 1, 2015. Interested investors can apply starting September 1, with no need to rush for the first issuance. The MAS expects to issue $2 billion to $4 billion worth of bonds in 2015, with a cap of $100,000 per individual investor and $50,000 per issue. The introduction of Singapore Savings Bonds is expected to have a low impact on the banking sector.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said on Tuesday that the Singapore Savings Bonds will be issued on Oct 1, 2015.

site_title: New Brics bank opens for business: Xinhua
summary: The new Brics bank, a multilateral lender, officially opened for business in Shanghai, China, on July 21, 2015. The bank, established by Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, aims to challenge the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, dominated by the US. With an estimated capital of $100 billion, the bank represents 40% of the world's population. China is also leading the setup of the Asian Infrastructure Development Bank, with Beijing as its headquarters.

site_title: Asia: Shares mixed, dollar pushes higher
summary: Asian shares were mixed on Tuesday, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rising 0.43% and Hong Kong's index up 0.23%, while Chinese shares fell 1.64% and 1.91% before recovering. A weak yen and falling commodity prices, including crude oil below $50 a barrel, raised concerns about global growth. The US dollar traded near a five-week high against the yen, and investors are watching the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions.

site_title: IBM revenue falls for 13th straight quarter; shares dip
summary: IBM's revenue fell for the 13th consecutive quarter, missing analyst estimates, as it continues to shed low-margin businesses and focus on high-growth areas like security software and cloud services. Revenue from strategic imperatives rose 20%, but was offset by divestitures. The company's shares fell 5% in after-market trading, and it expects third-quarter revenue to remain flat. Consolidated net income dropped to $3.45 billion, but excluding items, IBM beat analyst estimates with $3.84 per share.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up 0.34% in morning trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.34% in early trade on Tuesday, following gains on Wall Street where the Nasdaq finished at a third straight record high. The Hang Seng Index added 85.52 points to 25,490.33.

site_title: Oil prices fall further on strong dollar, WTI below US$50
summary: Oil prices fell further in Asia, with US crude dropping below US$50 a barrel, due to a strong US dollar and expectations of increased Iranian crude supply. The US dollar strengthened after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hinted at a potential interest rate hike later this year, making oil more expensive and reducing demand. WTI fell 16 cents to US$49.99, while Brent crude dropped 11 cents to US$56.54 a barrel. The market is also concerned about the return of Iranian oil, which is expected to be introduced by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell further in Asia Tuesday, with US crude falling below US$50 a barrel as demand for the dollar-priced commodity takes a hit from a strong US currency, analysts said.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.85 points to 1725.43. The market saw 35.83 million lots traded worth RM11.86 million, with 99 gainers outnumbering 56 losers. The market reaction was largely unaffected by global market fluctuations, with traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: China's Spring to buy 21 Airbus planes for US$2.04b
summary: Chinese budget carrier Spring Airlines plans to buy 21 Airbus A320 planes for 12.45 billion yuan (S$2.8 billion), citing growing demand in China's domestic and international aviation market. The purchase will be funded in part through a private placement of shares to raise 4.5 billion yuan. This move comes as China's economy continues to grow, with the country's GDP expanding 7.4% last year. Spring Airlines' shares rose after the company reported a 46.43% year-on-year jump in net profit for the first quarter.

site_title: Hot stock: Foreland FabricTech surges despite SGX warning
summary: Foreland FabricTech, a Chinese textile supplier, surged by up to 100% on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) despite a "trade with caution" warning from the exchange. The company's shares jumped from 2.8 cents to 5.6 cents before slipping to 5 cents. The unusual trading volume, exceeding the daily limit, prompted an SGX query. The price surges follow a change of control at the company, with its executive chairman selling a significant stake to raise funds.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.1 per cent up on Tuesday
summary: The Singapore stock market opened 0.1% higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 3.44 points to 3,376.92. The muted advance followed a flat finish on Wall Street overnight. Trading volume was high, with 176 million shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 88 to 54, with New Silkroutes being the most actively traded stock. The Singapore Exchange issued a "trade with caution" warning on Foreland FabriTech due to a substantial increase in traded volume.

site_title: MAS posts sharply lower profit due to currency effects
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reported a net profit of S$281 million for the year ended March 31, 2015, down from S$15.8 billion in 2013/14 due to currency effects. The Singapore dollar strengthened against the euro and yen, offsetting translation gains, while weakening against the US dollar. MAS's total expenditure rose 31.2% to S$1.2 billion, driven by higher investment and interest expenses. The official foreign reserves (OFR) generated a S$1.2 billion gain, with investment gains stripping out currency translation effects at S$10.4 billion.

site_title: Some BOJ policymakers fret stimulus effects diminishing: minutes
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers expressed concerns that the effects of the bank's massive stimulus programme might be diminishing, according to minutes from its June policy meeting. A few board members noted that long-term interest rates had risen to 0.5-0.6%, which could impact the programme's effectiveness. Despite this, the BOJ agreed that the underlying trend in inflation would continue to improve, driven by the output gap and long-term inflation expectations. The bank has maintained its stimulus since October last year to prevent deflation.

site_title: Toshiba shares jump 6% after accounting probe
summary: Toshiba shares surged 6% after a team of investigators found the company had "systematically" inflated profits over several years. The firm's top managers will resign to take responsibility. The Tokyo Stock Exchange reported shares reaching 398.6 yen, up 5.78% from the opening bell. The shares hovered at 390.0 yen, up 3.50%, amid reports of impending resignations.

site_title: Japan business mood subdued on uncertainty over China: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japan's business confidence remains subdued, with a Reuters poll showing manufacturers' and service sector morale staying muted over the next three months. The country's economic outlook is uncertain due to worries about China's economy, which is on track to grow at its slowest pace in over two decades. Data from the past few weeks has shown weakening shipments and output, but solid capital expenditure. The Bank of Japan trimmed its growth forecast but held off on fresh stimulus, citing an expected pick-up in consumption to accelerate inflation toward its 2% target next year.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks inch up, but poor export order data weighs
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.1% to 8,986.32, despite poor export order data for a third straight month in June. The electronics subindex rose 0.2%, while Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. added 0.7%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$31.200 per US dollar. Investors remained cautious, with tech exporters trading flat.

site_title: Oil extends drop amid commodity selloff; most Asian futures rise
summary: Crude oil prices extended their decline for a fifth day, falling 0.3% to $50 a barrel, amid a commodities rout fueled by dollar gains. Gold prices slid 0.8% to $1,097.50 an ounce, reaching a five-year low. Investors' focus on US monetary policy and interest rate hikes has driven the dollar's strength, negatively impacting precious metals and oil prices. Asian index futures rose, while US stock futures declined.

site_title: Hot stock: Frasers Commercial Trust flat despite reporting a 7.3% increase in DPU
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a 7.3% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.35 Singapore cents for its third quarter ended June 30, 2015. Net property income rose 6.1% to S$24.3 million, driven by better performances of Alexandra Technopark and 55 Market Street. Analysts maintain a "buy" rating on FCOT, citing its resilience in a volatile market and unique position in the Singapore office Reit market.

site_title: GLP to set up US$7b fund to expand logistics facilities in China
summary: Singapore-listed Global Logistic Properties (GLP) plans to set up a US$7 billion fund to expand its logistics facilities in China, with US$3.7 billion of equity already committed. The fund, CLF II, will develop 13 million square meters of facilities and focus on modern warehouse spaces with computerized tracking systems. GLP aims to invest at least 30% more in China in the current financial year, with existing customers accounting for two-thirds of new storage facilities. The company operates in 36 Chinese cities and has 11.8 million square meters of completed logistics space.

site_title: Update: GLP sets up US$7 billion China fund to develop logistics infrastructure
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has established a US$7 billion fund to develop modern logistics facilities in China, with US$3.7 billion of equity committed. The fund aims to develop 13 million square meters of logistics space over four years, starting land acquisition later this year and construction in April 2016. This marks GLP's second China-focused logistics infrastructure fund, following a US$3 billion fund launched in 2013. The fund is expected to drive higher risk-adjusted returns for the company.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open 0.58% higher after Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo shares opened 0.58% higher on Tuesday, tracking gains on Wall Street due to solid corporate earnings, a weaker yen, and oil price boosts. The Nikkei index rose 114.57 points to 20,765.49. Toshiba shares surged 5.78% after company investigators confirmed systematic profit inflation over several years. The dollar strengthened to 124.35 yen, while the euro slightly increased to 134.65 yen.

site_title: Oil prices dips below US$50 on ample supply, strong dollar
summary: Oil prices fell below US$50 a barrel on Monday as ample supply and a strengthening dollar combined to pressure prices. US crude futures dropped 74 cents to settle at US$50.15, while Brent September crude fell 45 cents to settle at US$56.65. A stronger dollar makes crude more expensive for investors using other currencies, and rising US interest rates are expected to curb liquidity, adding to price pressures. Refinery operations are set to slow in the second half of the year, reducing demand for crude oil.

images.alt_text: Oil futures fell on Monday and US crude slipped below US$50 a barrel intraday as ample supply, the prospect of more Iranian crude for export and a strengthening dollar combined to pressure prices.

site_title: I've come full circle on the wisdom of a common currency
summary: The author, a former economics editor, has changed his mind about the euro, now believing it's not a concept suitable for all European nations. He initially held skepticism in the 1970s, influenced by Peter Jay's warnings of potential problems, including Greece's current economic struggles. The euro's limitations, such as Greece's inability to devalue its currency, have become apparent. The author now advocates for a more gradual approach to economic integration, with a focus on compensating countries that lose from lack of exchange rate flexibility.

site_title: Funeral services provider eyeing Singapore real estate agency business
summary: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments (APS), a Catalist-listed funeral services provider, plans to shift focus to the Singapore real estate agency business. The company proposes buying Global Alliance Property, a brokerage with about 800 agents, for S$2.75 million. APS aims to make real estate its core business, moving away from funeral parlours and columbariums in Malaysia. The move will be sought after shareholders' approval at an extraordinary general meeting. APS has been working on a S$500 million reverse takeover deal involving Armenian miner Coeur Gold Armenia, which has been delayed due to the miner's restructuring.

images.alt_text: Catalist-listed funeral services provider Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments (APS) has changed course again. This time round, it wants to move into an industry that some might say is nearly as moribund at present - becoming a Singapore real estate agent.

site_title: Stocks to watch: M1, Keppel Reit, Cache Logistics Trust, First Reit
summary: M1's net profit for the second quarter rose 1% year-over-year to S$44.3 million, while its revenue increased 15.5% to S$276.8 million. Keppel Reit's DPU fell 9.5% to 1.72 Singapore cents due to an enlarged base. Cache Logistics Trust reported a 0.3% dip in DPU to 2.14 Singapore cents, despite a 5.4% decrease in net property income. First Reit's DPU rose 3.5% to 2.07 Singapore cents due to contributions from new acquisitions and a universal healthcare scheme in Indonesia.

site_title: Qualcomm may consider breakup: WSJ
summary: Qualcomm may consider a breakup of the company, including spinning off its chip business from its patent-licensing business, amid pressure from hedge fund Jana Partners. The San Diego-based chipmaker is also expected to return more cash to shareholders. Qualcomm's shares rose 3.2% in after-hours trading following reports of potential layoffs. The company's plans are in flux, and a formal announcement is not guaranteed.

site_title: Taylor Swift to sell clothing line designed for Chinese shoppers
summary: Taylor Swift is teaming up with JD.com Inc to sell a new fashion line designed specifically for Chinese shoppers. The clothing line will be available on JD.com's website in August ahead of Swift's "1989" tour visit to Shanghai in November. JD.com is looking to expand its clothing business and woo US brands, eschewing knockoff merchandise common in Chinese marketplaces. This partnership aims to help JD.com surpass Alibaba Group Holding, the No 1 e-commerce company in China.

site_title: Frasers Australand CEO quits
summary: Frasers Australand CEO Bob Johnston has resigned, effective six months after the company's parent group, Frasers Centrepoint Limited, acquired Australand in August 2014. The board accepted his resignation without disclosing the reason. Johnston will be succeeded by Rod Fehring, current general manager of the residential division. Despite the change, Frasers Australand is "well-positioned for growth," according to CEO Lim Ee Seng, who also serves on the Frasers Australand board.

site_title: Blatter confirms Fifa exit as favourite Platini mulls options
summary: Sepp Blatter has confirmed he will step down as FIFA president on February 26, amid scandal-tainted corruption allegations. Michel Platini is favored to succeed him, having been lobbied by regional governing body members. FIFA's leaders have proposed reforms, including enhanced background checks and term limits, but Transparency International has criticized them as insufficient to address corruption. A task force will present its findings to the board in September, with any changes to be ratified by FIFA's full membership in February.

site_title: M&S veteran closer to top job as he is moved to flagship division
summary: Steve Rowe, a Marks & Spencer (M&S) veteran, has been promoted to head of the company's general merchandise division, a significant step up from his previous role running the food business. This move could potentially boost his chances of succeeding Marc Bolland as chief executive. Rowe has delivered 23 consecutive quarters of underlying sales growth in the food division, but faces the challenge of replicating this success in the general merchandise division, which spans clothing, shoes, and homeware.

site_title: Greece's euro exit back on the agenda next year, economists say
summary: Greece's euro exit may be back on the agenda next year, according to a Bloomberg survey of 34 economists, with 71% predicting Greece will be forced out of the euro region by the end of 2016. Despite Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' efforts to secure a third bailout, economists question the package's size, citing concerns over debt restructuring and austerity measures. The European creditors' refusal to firm up their commitment to debt relief has fueled doubts about Greece's ability to stabilize its finances, with some economists warning that the package will never be big enough without debt relief.

site_title: Gold rout sends global miners lower; S&P 500 tops closing record
summary: A gold rout sent global miners lower, with bullion falling 2.1% to $1,108 an ounce, its lowest in over five years. The Bloomberg Commodity Index hit a 2002 low, while emerging markets' MSCI Index fell 0.8%. The prospect of higher US interest rates and a stronger dollar led to the decline, overshadowing better-than-forecast corporate earnings. The S&P 500 edged past its closing record, while technology shares advanced.

site_title: Germany, Iran pledge to revive economic ties after long freeze
summary: Germany and Iran have pledged to revive their economic ties after a 13-year freeze, with Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel signaling a ministerial-level meeting on a dormant economic commission in Tehran next year. The move comes after a landmark nuclear deal, which may lead to the lifting of Western economic sanctions. German industry representatives are keen to re-enter the Iranian market, particularly in the energy sector, with exports potentially quadrupling to 10 billion euros within a few years.

site_title: Why buy gold baffles investors as top forecaster sees more pain
summary: Gold prices hit a five-year low, with futures falling 2.1% to $1,107.90 an ounce. Top forecaster Barnabas Gan predicts gold will reach $1,050 an ounce by December, a 5.2% drop. Investors are bailing on gold due to a decline in safe-haven demand, rising interest rates, and decreased need for a store of value. Money managers are holding the smallest net-bullish bet on gold since 2006, with some forecasters cutting year-end estimates.

site_title: China's state-owned company profits edge down in H1: finance ministry
summary: China's non-financial state-owned companies reported a 0.1% decline in profits to 1.23 trillion yuan (S$271.1 billion) in the first half of the year, down from a year earlier. Revenue dropped 6% to 21.8 trillion yuan. The finance ministry noted that profits have been down all year, but have been improving since January-February, when they were 21.5% lower than a year ago. Certain sectors, such as transport and electronics, enjoyed "considerable" profits, while others, like nonferrous metals, posted losses.

site_title: 158 Cecil Street being sold for S$240m
summary: Alpha Investment Partners, the fund management arm of Keppel Land, sold 158 Cecil Street to a company linked to low-profile Singaporean investor Denis Jen for S$240 million, or about S$2,100 per square foot. The 14-storey building has a balance lease term of around 65 years and has received several accolades, including the top prize at the 2011 Skyrise Greenery Awards. The sale comes after a company controlled by Mr Jen was granted an option to purchase the property last month, with several other parties previously considering the asset.

site_title: Airbnb overhauls service for business travellers
summary: Airbnb has overhauled its service for business travelers, introducing a revamped Airbnb for Business with a central billing system and a dashboard for HR representatives to track employee spending. The new system aims to simplify the process of managing expenses and tracking employee stays. The move is part of Airbnb's effort to attract corporate customers, with the company already serving 250 companies. The revamped service will help streamline the process of compiling travel expenses and reduce manual efforts, such as sending invoices and creating custom coupon codes.

site_title: Singapore's last Russian bond seller has just left the island
summary: Singapore's last Russian bond seller, VTB Bank JSC, has left the island after repaying a $400 million note without replacing the debt. This marks the first time in five years a Russian issuer hasn't had a Singapore dollar bond outstanding, following US and European sanctions on Russia. The exit is seen as a result of market apprehension about doing business with Russian entities, with Singapore's local corporate bond sales running at less than half of 2012's record high.

site_title: Airbus plans to offer new version of A380 by 2025: CEO
summary: Airbus plans to introduce a new version of its A380, dubbed the "A380 neo type," between 2020 and 2025. CEO Fabrice Bregier stated that the airline will likely choose just one engine type, rather than two, as with the current model. The improved A380 will be available for service by 2025, although no decision has been made on new engines. This move aims to modernize the A380, a popular long-haul aircraft.

site_title: ST Engineering chief on medical leave after mild stroke
summary: ST Engineering's president and CEO, Tan Pheng Hock, is on medical leave after suffering a mild stroke. He is expected to be out for about four weeks as his condition is reviewed by doctors. Deputy CEOs Lee Fook Sun and Vincent Chong will cover his executive duties and responsibilities during his absence. Tan, who has been with the company since 1981, is the longest-serving CEO of ST Engineering, which provides solutions and services in aerospace, electronics, and other sectors, earning revenues of $6.54 billion in FY2014.

site_title: Obama picks University of Michigan economist Dominguez for Fed post
summary: President Barack Obama has chosen University of Michigan economist Kathryn Dominguez to fill the final open seat on the Federal Reserve Board of Governors. Dominguez, a research associate at the National Bureau of Economic Research, brings expertise in international economics and foreign exchange rates. The addition of Dominguez and former community banker Allan Landon will bring the Fed Board to full strength, just as Fed Chair Janet Yellen is expected to begin lifting short-term interest rates for the first time since 2006.

site_title: Clinton's capital gains tax plan aims at long-term investment
summary: Hillary Clinton's proposed capital gains tax plan aims to foster long-term investment by taxing short-term investments at higher rates. The plan would create a sliding rate scale based on investment length, with profits from short-term investments taxed at regular income rates and those from long-term investments taxed at a rate of at least 28%. The plan is expected to raise tax revenue, but some experts question its effectiveness in altering investment behavior. Clinton will provide more details about the plan in a speech later this week.

images.alt_text: US presidential contender Hillary Clinton's proposed plan to overhaul capital gains taxes aims to foster long-term growth by taxing some short-term investments at higher rates, an aide for her campaign said on Monday.

site_title: Smithsonian embraces crowdfunding to preserve lunar spacesuit
summary: The Smithsonian Air and Space Museum has launched a Kickstarter campaign to raise $500,000 for the restoration of Neil Armstrong's lunar spacesuit. The project, "Reboot the Suit," has already raised nearly $100,000 within hours of its launch. The campaign must be fully funded by August 19, and pledges will only be collected after this date. This marks the first time a Smithsonian museum has used crowdfunding to preserve its artifacts.

site_title: Applying fixed EC does not give parallel-import cars an advantage
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore clarified that parallel-imported cars do not have an advantage due to the application of a fixed Evolution Coefficient (EC) in testing their carbon emissions. The fixed EC is used to compare emissions values of production vehicles to those of vehicles that have been run in, but it does not provide an advantage to parallel importers. Parallel importers do not have access to reports on emissions tests conducted by manufacturers and are subject to strict conditions and rigorous checks to ensure the vehicles have not been tampered with or run in.

site_title: US 'strongly condemns' Turkey terror attack
summary: The US has strongly condemned a terrorist attack in Turkey that killed at least 30 people and wounded 104. The attack, blamed on the Islamic State group, occurred at a cultural center in Suruc, near the Syrian border. Turkish authorities have cracked down on IS networks and beefed up its border security. The White House has also expressed skepticism about reports of the Islamic State using chemical weapons against Kurdish forces in Syria and Iraq.

images.alt_text: The White House condemned an apparent suicide bombing in Turkey Monday that killed at least 30 people and was blamed on Islamic State.

site_title: Lockheed to buy United Tech's Sikorsky for over US$8b: sources
summary: Lockheed Martin Corp has agreed to buy United Technologies Corp's Sikorsky Aircraft for over $8 billion, cementing Lockheed's dominance in the defense industry and expanding its overseas sales. The deal, set to be announced Monday, will add the iconic Black Hawk helicopters to Lockheed's product line and make the company less reliant on the F-35 fighter jet business. The acquisition, valued at over $8 billion, is Lockheed's largest since buying Martin Marietta Corp for $10 billion two decades ago.

site_title: US sets capital surcharges for largest 8 banks
summary: The US Federal Reserve set capital surcharges for the country's eight largest banks, including Bank of America, Wells Fargo, and Goldman Sachs. Only JPMorgan Chase is below the new capital threshold, requiring an additional $12.5 billion by 2019. The new rules aim to reel in "too-big-to-fail" institutions, following the 2008 economic crisis.

site_title: Malaysia sukuk premium shields returns imperiled by ringgit loss
summary: Malaysia's ringgit sukuk returns outperformed Islamic dollar debt this year, with 2.5% and 3.3% yields for 2016 and 2021 securities, respectively. The sukuk premium over global counterparts exceeded 200 basis points. Despite a weaker ringgit forecasted to decline another 1.1% by Dec 31, global funds have increased holdings of Malaysian government bonds to a record in June. The ringgit's losses were exacerbated by a decline in oil exports and an investigation into state investment finances, but investors have shrugged off these concerns.

site_title: Russia submits alternative UN resolution on MH17
summary: Russia has submitted an alternative UN resolution to the Security Council, opposing the creation of a tribunal to prosecute those responsible for the downing of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 in 2014. The draft resolution, which Russia claims is not in the UN charter, instead calls for a full, thorough, and independent international investigation led by the International Civil Aviation Organization. The Netherlands, Malaysia, and other countries are working together to create an international tribunal under Chapter 7 of the UN charter. A vote on the resolution is expected in the middle of next week.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends flat as commodities weigh
summary: US stocks ended flat on Monday as a better-than-expected start to corporate earnings season boosted investor confidence, despite a drop in commodities. The Nasdaq Composite reached its third straight record close, driven by tech gains, while the S&P 500 is less than 3 points from its record close. Gold and copper prices plummeted, and oil prices fell due to a growing glut in refined products. The dollar index rose 0.17% to a three-month high, and 70% of companies have reported earnings above analyst expectations.

site_title: Europe's impossible dream
summary: Europe's economy is struggling, with Greece experiencing a slump worse than the Great Depression, Spain facing 22% unemployment, and Finland, Denmark, and the Netherlands also experiencing economic depression. The single currency, introduced 25 years ago, has caused huge problems, despite warnings from economists. The EU's elite ignored economic arithmetic and history, prioritizing a unified currency as a symbol of unity. The policy response to economic strains has been to impose austerity on debtor nations, which has failed to achieve debt reduction and has caused deep recessions. The EU's response to the crisis is mired in ideas that don't work, making it hard to find a solution, and Greece's exit from the euro may be necessary.

site_title: Europe markets continue to rise as Greek banks re-open
summary: European stock markets continued their upward trend on Monday following the European Central Bank's 900 million euro loan to Greek banks, enabling them to reopen. Greek banks repaid 6.25 billion euros owed to the ECB and IMF, using a 7 billion euro loan granted by the EU. However, analysts say there is still a long way to go for Greece to meet negotiation terms for the 86 billion euro bailout, and a general election is likely in September or October. Capital controls remain in place, with restrictions on cash withdrawals and wire transfers.

site_title: Polish video game The Witcher enchants world
summary: Polish video game "The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" has sold four million copies worldwide, with the entire series selling eight million copies since its release in 2007. The game's success is attributed to Eastern European sensibility and creativity, according to CD Projekt Red co-founder Marcin Iwinski. The game's open world and realistic dialogue have been praised, and it has been mentioned by US President Barack Obama as an example of Poland's place in the global economy. The country's video-game industry is one of the biggest in Europe, with over 500 independent studios producing games annually.

site_title: No charge for Windows 10 upgrade
summary: Microsoft will release Windows 10, its latest operating system, for free, marking a significant shift in the company's pricing strategy. The move is seen as a response to the growing popularity of free software and services from competitors like Google and Apple. The new operating system will include a virtual assistant, regular updates, and a revamped Start menu, and is expected to generate significant revenue from advertising, app sales, and licensing deals with corporate customers. Analysts predict the move will boost adoption and create new opportunities for developers, but may also lead to a decline in revenue from Windows upgrades.

site_title: Singaporeans expect inflation to rise in medium and long term: survey
summary: Singaporeans now expect inflation to rise to 3.35% in a year, up from 3.05% in March, due to domestic price pressures and a tighter labor market. The expectation is higher than the historical average of 3.99% and the current median one-year-ahead headline inflation rate of 3.14%. Despite global factors pointing to a downward correction, Singaporeans are anxious about the global economy and expect a gradual increase in interest rates.

site_title: No new target for job cuts at Barclays: sources
summary: Barclays has set no new targets for job cuts beyond the 19,000 redundancies announced last year, despite reports of plans to cut over 30,000 staff within two years. The move follows the departure of CEO Antony Jenkins, who was fired due to underperformance. New leadership is expected to accelerate cost-cutting measures to address the bank's underperformance and hit a target to double its share price. Barclays' workforce could be reduced to below 100,000 by the end of 2017, with potential job cuts in middle and back office operations.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing needs intelligent ecosystem and mindset to compete
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector faces significant challenges to remain competitive, despite its highly educated population and well-connected infrastructure. The need for an intelligent manufacturing ecosystem and mindset is crucial to overcome obstacles such as labor costs, raw material costs, and quality requirements. Singapore must differentiate itself through flexible and agile manufacturing, coupled with high-quality production, and adopt Industry 4.0 solutions to support rapidly shifting manufacturing operations. A fundamental mindset change is required to perceive productivity, monitoring, and production control, and an ecosystem of expert solutions must evolve to support Singapore's manufacturing sector.

site_title: China's Hony Capital keen to explore Reits listings on SGX
summary: China's Hony Capital, a major private equity firm, is exploring ways to work with the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in securitization products, particularly Real Estate Investment Trusts (Reits). Hony Capital's CEO, John Zhao, plans to initiate talks with SGX to discuss securitization opportunities with Chinese companies holding real estate assets. Despite China's complex tax regime, SGX is open to discussing potential collaborations, with its CEO noting the need for controlled market opening and the importance of international centers like Singapore and Hong Kong.

site_title: US will need to reassure its Gulf Arab allies on Iran deal
summary: The US nuclear deal with Iran faces significant challenges as Gulf Arab allies express concerns over the agreement. Despite US President Barack Obama's vow to veto any legislation opposing the deal, opposition from Republicans and some Democrats is gaining pace. Saudi Arabia and other Sunni Gulf monarchies are particularly annoyed, as the deal could increase Iran's influence in global oil markets, threatening their economic interests. The US needs to reassure its allies of continued military and geopolitical support to prevent potential damage to the economy and its role as a global reserve currency.

images.alt_text: Whatever the spin doctors say, the road ahead for the nuclear agreement between the six world powers and Iran will be convoluted.

site_title: China can maintain 7% growth: Tung Chee Hwa
summary: China's economy is expected to maintain 7% growth despite a slowdown, according to Tung Chee Hwa, vice-chairman of China's top political advisory body. This is attributed to growing consumption, urbanization, and new jobs in the service sector. China's disposable income grew 9% in the first half of the year, driving growth in final consumption, which now accounts for 60% of GDP. Despite concerns over job creation and economic slowdown, China is on track to create 10 million jobs annually, according to Tung Chee Hwa.

site_title: EU envoy sees renewed investor interest in SEA
summary: European Union envoy Michael Pulch says investors are re-examining South-east Asia as cheaper and more stable markets amid the Greek crisis and China's stock market rout. The EU is the largest investor in the region, with a free-trade agreement expected to be signed with the Association of South-east Asian Nations in the "medium term". Despite global trade growth slowing, the region's economies may benefit from companies looking for alternative markets. Pulch highlights maritime transport and aviation as areas for expansion, while economists see long-term opportunities in South-east Asia as China's growth slows.

images.alt_text: Mr Pulch says trade flows will increase further under an FTA that the EU expects to sign with Asean in the medium term

site_title: NOL shares surge on talk of potential sale
summary: Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) shares surged 10.3% to a 7-week high on July 20, 2015, amid speculation of a potential sale of the loss-making shipping liner. Despite NOL's announcement that it has not made any decision on a sale, analysts welcomed the possibility of a divestment, citing the company's reduced strategic value. Temasek Holdings, NOL's parent company, has a 67% stake in the company, and analysts believe it may be willing to sell its stake for a higher valuation.

site_title: Plans to subject rogue retailers to personal injunctions
summary: Singapore plans to subject rogue retailers to personal injunctions, in addition to shop closures, as part of a review of the Consumer Protection (Fair Trading) Act. The proposed changes aim to strengthen the Act and deter unfair retail practices. Under the new measures, retailers must inform consumers of injunction orders, even if they close their shop and operate under a new name. An agency within the Ministry of Trade and Industry will be established to investigate and enforce compliance, with the Consumers Association of Singapore remaining the first line for consumer complaints.

site_title: US and Cuba end Cold War, restore ties, re-establish embassies
summary: US and Cuba have ended the Cold War and restored diplomatic ties, re-establishing embassies in both countries. The historic gesture marks the end of decades of enmity and comes after the US acknowledged its failed policy of isolating Cuba. Diplomatic relations were re-established at midnight, with the Cuban flag raised at the US State Department, and the US and Cuba will hold talks on Monday to discuss issues such as human rights and compensation for seized American property. The normalization of ties is seen as a significant step towards a more constructive engagement between the two countries.

site_title: Quest by 'rageful guy' to pry out US government secrets
summary: Reporter Jason Leopold, a "pretty rageful guy", has released 20,000 pages of US government documents, many of which led to explosive news stories, while working for Vice News.

site_title: Could revolution follow Greek crisis?
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras reshuffled his government to remove MPs who opposed the bailout deal, but the country remains in economic intensive care. EU leaders warn of ideological contagion from the Greek crisis, with Donald Tusk citing the rise of radical groups on both left and right. The crisis has sparked global unrest, with millions taking to the streets and administrations collapsing in various countries. Despite economic recovery prospects, drivers such as social media and youth unemployment will continue to fuel protest and uprising.

images.alt_text: Opportunity structures have been swept away for too many, leading to a "lost generation", especially in Greece where youth unemployment has peaked at more than 50 per cent.

site_title: Port-shots
summary: Singapore's container port faces a productivity question, as it struggles to maintain efficiency and competitiveness. Meanwhile, London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Tesla launches its formal entry into India with a Mumbai event, while expanding its robotaxi services to California and Arizona. FedEx partners a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries in commercial areas, and Delta Air Lines offers an upbeat outlook on travel demand, lifting its shares. Japan's carmakers cut export prices to the US to offset the impact of tariffs.

site_title: London home prices keep rising on strong demand
summary: London home prices continue to rise, with asking prices for homes with two bedrooms surging 1.1% to £449,766, according to Rightmove Plc. The UK housing shortage, exacerbated by record-low borrowing costs, is driving upward pressure on house prices across the country. The government's recent budget cut a mortgage-payment tax break for landlords, potentially easing affordability concerns. Despite a 0.9% drop in top-end London prices, the lower-end sector remains in high demand, with prices up 7.8% from last year.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ST Engineering secured S$424 million worth of contracts in Q2, including S$285 million in advanced electronics and infocomm technology contracts. Global Logistic Properties leased 475,000 square feet to a leading retailer in Greater Chicago for distribution expansion. HLH Group's subsidiary in Cambodia signed a deal to buy equipment worth US$2.23 million to process cassava starch. The Stratech Group received an in-principle approval from SGX to be removed from the watch-list.

site_title: Cache's Q2 DPU down 0.3%
summary: Cache Logistics Trust reported a 0.3% dip in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.14 Singapore cents for its Q2 2015, due to a larger base of units compared to last year. Income available for distribution rose 0.3% to S$16.8 million, while net property income fell 5.4% to S$18.5 million. The trust attributed the decline to a soft rental market and increased vacancy. Despite this, Cache expects stable cash flow from its 10-year lease with DHL Supply Chain Singapore, starting January 2016.

site_title: Court issues arrest warrant for former mining mogul
summary: An Australian court issued an arrest warrant for former mining billionaire Nathan Tinkler, who failed to appear for questioning about the collapse of his thoroughbred racing and breeding business, Patinack Farm. The liquidator is seeking to recover A$5 million owed by creditors. Tinkler, who moved to Singapore, had been summoned to give evidence, but Judge Steve Roder agreed to the arrest warrant citing contempt of court. The case is investigating the circumstances of Patinack Farm's collapse three years ago.

site_title: Rare chicks go into hiding as bird flu hits Iowa
summary: A deadly bird flu outbreak in Iowa has prompted the relocation of rare, genetically valuable chicks to a safe location in Texas. The outbreak, which has killed over 48 million chickens and turkeys since December, has led to a halt in US poultry imports to China and limited trade restrictions from other countries. The rare breeds, some dating back to the early 1900s, are considered irreplaceable and may take years to rebuild if they were lost.

site_title: Shrinking China trade likely to curb S'pore, HK banks' profits
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong banks' profits may be curbed as China's trade finance shrinks by 20% due to the slowing Chinese economy and slump in commodity prices. Trade loans in the two financial hubs have fallen to a two-year low of US$110.6 billion, raising concerns about lower earnings growth for banks such as Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp and global lenders like Standard Chartered Plc and HSBC Holdings Plc. The decline in trade finance could result in a small negative impact on banks' overall profits, mainly due to thin net interest margins from this business.

site_title: HLH focuses on Cambodia market in bid to raise profits
summary: HLH Group, a Singapore-based agriculture and property company, is shifting focus to Cambodia to boost profits. The company posted a net profit of S$0.89 million last year, after two consecutive years of losses. It announced a US$2.23 million deal to purchase agricultural equipment in Cambodia and plans to develop over 3,000 residential units in Phnom Penh, Siem Reap, and Sihanoukville. The company sees enormous growth potential in Cambodia's young and upwardly mobile population, and is confident that its new businesses will deliver positive value to shareholders and provide long-term sustainable growth.

site_title: MLT's DPU for Q1 dips 2.6% on higher property expenses
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust's (MLT) first-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) dropped 2.6% to 1.85 Singapore cents due to higher property expenses. Gross revenue rose 5% to S$85.1 million, while net property income gained 3.1% to S$71.1 million. The Reit attributes the decline to increased costs from property conversions and weaker yen. Despite this, the Reit remains optimistic, expecting to achieve maximum portfolio occupancy and pursue accretive acquisitions.

site_title: Keppel Reit's Q2 DPU down 9.5%
summary: Keppel Reit reported a 9.5% year-on-year drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.72 Singapore cents in Q2 2015, due to an enlarged unit base. However, distributable income rose 3% to S$54.8m. Net property income slipped 11.4% to S$34.7m, mainly due to the absence of income from the divested Prudential Tower. The Reit has completed refinancing requirements and started early refinancing for loans due in 2017, aiming to use the funds for minor portfolio improvements.

site_title: China tops IMF list with US$5.3t in global energy subsidies
summary: China tops the International Monetary Fund's list of global energy subsidies with estimated $5.3 trillion in support, equivalent to 6.5% of the world's GDP. China leads in dollar terms, while Ukraine contributes 6.4% of GDP and Qatar 6.3% per capita, according to the IMF report released on July 17.

site_title: Aussie banks told to boost mortgage capital
summary: Australia's top four banks will increase their mortgage capital by at least 25% from July 1, 2016, to ensure the financial system can cope with a potential downturn in the housing market. The increase, worth around A$12 billion, will be implemented by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority to boost the banks' capital. The move aims to enhance the resilience of the financial system, but may lead to higher mortgage rates for customers.

site_title: Lynas in supply talks with car, turbine makers to boost output
summary: Lynas Corp, a rare earths producer, is in supply talks with car and turbine makers to boost output at its Malaysia plant, currently operating at 75% capacity. Lynas aims to reach full production of 22,000 tonnes, citing growing demand for energy-efficient cars and wind turbines. The company is seeking to recapitalize and has discussions with debt holders, with repayments due in June 2016.

site_title: US$ firm in Asia with focus on Fed rate hike timing
summary: The US dollar strengthened in Asia on Monday, reaching a three-month high against the euro, amid concerns about Greece's debt crisis subsiding. The euro fell to US$1.0827, while the yen rose to 124.17 Japanese yen. Analysts attributed the dollar's rise to the US Federal Reserve's focus on interest rate hikes, with the Fed's chair Janet Yellen sticking to her forecast of a rate increase later this year.

site_title: China on an outbound investment spree
summary: China is poised to become the world's largest outbound direct investor, surpassing the US, with a growth rate of 20% per year. The "Third Wave" of China's outbound direct investment (ODI) focuses on high-tech and services sectors in developed economies, driven by the central government's encouragement of domestic companies to invest overseas. China's ODI reached $116 billion last year, with a surge in M&A deals, particularly in real estate and consumer goods. The trend is expected to continue, with private investors playing a key role, and the renminbi-denominated deals set to play a bigger role in overseas mergers and expansions.

site_title: Acronis to set up major R&D hub in Singapore
summary: Acronis, a data protection company, plans to establish a major research and development (R&D) hub in Singapore. The centre, expected to be one of the largest in the country, will partner with various research institutes under A*Star and employ around 120-150 researchers. The company aims to spend S$50 million over five years on the R&D centre, focusing on areas like data storage, security, and cloud services. Acronis hopes to develop new products catering to local needs, such as Singapore's Smart Nation ambitions, and collaborate with other research institutions to improve IT efficiency levels among local small and medium-sized enterprises.

images.alt_text: Acronis, which provides back-up, disaster recovery and other data protection services, will open a research and development (R&D) centre in Singapore.

site_title: CAG, Xiamen Airlines sign air services MOU
summary: Changi Airport Group (CAG) and Xiamen Airlines have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to boost connectivity and passenger traffic between Singapore and China. The agreement, valid until March 2018, aims to increase air services between the two countries, including new secondary and third-tier cities in China. Xiamen Airlines, the fourth largest Chinese city for Changi, operates 28 weekly services to seven Chinese cities, with a 9% compounded annual growth rate in passenger traffic since 2009. The partnership aims to improve the travel experience for passengers and leverage Singapore as a hub for transit and transfer traffic.

site_title: M1 posts earnings of S$44.3m for Q2
summary: M1 Ltd reported a net profit of S$44.3 million in Q2, with an operating revenue growth of 15.5% to S$276.8 million. The telco's six-month net profit was up 3.8% at S$90 million, with operating revenue increasing 19.1% to S$571.7 million. M1 added 12,000 postpaid customers and 6,000 fibre customers, bringing its mobile customer base to 1.88 million and fibre base to 114,000. The company declared an interim dividend of 7.0 cents per share.

site_title: Charter extensions worth up to US$458m buoy Vallianz shares
summary: Vallianz Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore vessel owner, has extended charter contracts for 19 vessels in the Middle East worth up to US$458 million. The deals, which run until June 2018, have boosted the company's order book to a record high of nearly US$1 billion. However, charter rates for the vessels have been cut by 10% on average, less than industry cuts. The stock price surged 15.4% to S$0.06, its highest level since 2014, but remains below its pre-slump price of S$0.133.

site_title: Pearson exploring sale of Financial Times: Bloomberg
summary: Pearson is exploring the sale of the Financial Times newspaper after receiving interest from potential buyers. A sale may value the business at up to 1 billion pounds (S$2.2 billion). Pearson is sounding out possible bidders and has not commented on the matter. The news comes as the company considers strategic options for its publications business.

site_title: Let it roll
summary: Coffee Bandits, a specialty coffee food truck in Singapore, has been operating since August 2014. Founded by Cheryl Ong and Jessica Chow, the duo aimed to provide good coffee to working people on the outskirts of Singapore. After facing licensing hurdles, they eventually secured certification from the National Environment Agency and Land Transport Authority. The truck has become a regular fixture at light industrial estates and offices, serving a mix of coffee and pulled pork sandwiches. Despite the challenges, the business has improved, covering operational costs, and the owners plan to focus on event catering and expanding their operations.

site_title: Gold prices dive 4% to five-year low
summary: Gold prices plummeted 4% to a five-year low due to increased sales in top consumer China, with a record 3.3 million lots or 33 tonnes traded on a Shanghai physical contract. This suggests China is shunning bullion, leading to a decline in gold prices.

site_title: Germany eyes Iran business but Israel tops differences
summary: Germany's economy minister Sigmar Gabriel led a delegation to Iran to discuss business opportunities, but emphasized that Israel must be included in any discussions on Middle East security. Gabriel stated that Germany values its friendship with Iran, but also prioritizes the security of Israel and supports the Palestinians' right to their own state. The talks also highlighted differences in human rights, women's rights, and corruption, with Gabriel expressing concerns about Iran's ranking as one of the most corrupt countries in the world.

site_title: Echo wins Brisbane casino resort bid
summary: Echo Entertainment Group Ltd won the bid to develop a Brisbane casino resort, beating Crown Resorts Ltd, in a consortium with Chow Tai Fook Enterprises Ltd and Far East Consortium International Ltd. The A$2 billion project aims to capitalize on growing casino spending in Australia despite a 36% decline in Macau's gambling revenues. Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk called the development a "premium tourist destination" that will change Brisbane's CBD.

site_title: Hedge funds dump crude oil as Iran deal may prolong glut
summary: Hedge funds significantly reduced their bullish bets on crude oil, cutting their net-long position by 15% in the week ended July 14, according to US Commodity Futures Trading Commission data. This comes as an agreement over Iran's nuclear program may prolong a global supply glut, potentially increasing oil production from Saudi Arabia and Iraq. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) is pumping the most in almost three years, and Iran may be able to increase exports as soon as December if it complies with the terms of its nuclear accord.

site_title: US shoppers using mobile devices in-store to browse, research
summary: US shoppers are using mobile devices in-store to browse and research products, but not to make purchases. Retailers are adapting their strategies to boost in-store sales, with some investing in mobile apps and WiFi networks to enhance the shopping experience. Examples include GameStop's mobile app, Kohl's in-store mode, and Target's relaunched app with features like shopping lists and interactive store maps. Despite the growth in mobile traffic, online sales remain relatively low, and technology startups are exploring new ways to facilitate in-store purchases, such as one-click "buy" buttons on social media platforms.

site_title: Statoil to leave trans-Adriatic gas pipeline project
summary: Norway's Statoil is selling its 20% stake in the Trans Adriatic Gas Pipeline (TAP) project, which will transport 16 billion cubic meters of gas from Azerbaijan to Europe by the end of the decade. The stake is expected to be bought by multiple companies, with Italian gas infrastructure company Snam previously expressing interest in taking a 20% stake. The sale is seen as a strategic move to reduce Statoil's presence in the project, which is part of the larger Shah Deniz II field in the Caspian Sea.

site_title: Fifa to hold election for Blatter's replacement in Feb
summary: FIFA will hold an election on February 26 to replace embattled President Joseph "Sepp" Blatter, who has promised to step down by early next year. The election comes after the US Justice Department alleges corruption, and the governing body's board has discussed changes to prevent similar practices. Michel Platini, a former Blatter ally, is considered a favorite to win the top spot, while other potential challengers, including Chung Mong-Joon and Prince Ali bin al-Hussein, have not made public statements. The scandal has led to internal reforms and calls for outside oversight, with FIFA's sponsors and former officials calling for a third-party commission to reform the organization.

site_title: SPH in a strong position to tackle media challenges
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) is well-positioned to tackle the media industry's challenges, according to its chairman Lee Boon Yang. The company has set up a digital division to drive growth in the digital space, and its adjacent businesses have seen growth. SPH has also made strategic investments and partnerships to enhance its business. The company's print products have demonstrated resilience and adaptability, and it continues to redefine its core media business. SPH has awarded 31 scholarships to students, including 11 bond-free Lim Kim San Memorial Scholarships to students from modest family backgrounds.

site_title: Singapore's container port faces a productivity question
summary: Singapore's container port, one of the busiest in the world, appears to be lagging behind regional rivals in efficiency, according to fresh data from the OECD ITF. The port moved an average of 66 containers per hour per ship in 2014, compared to 81 at Malaysia's Tanjung Pelepas and 167 at China's Shanghai. Analysts caution that the numbers may not be representative, citing complexity in Singapore's operations and the type of traffic it handles. The port is expected to improve productivity with the upcoming terminal at Tuas, and service quality remains a crucial factor in port competitiveness.

site_title: Julius Baer still has cash to make purchases after settling tax probe
summary: Julius Baer Group, Switzerland's third-largest wealth manager, is expected to have sufficient cash to make acquisitions after settling a four-year US tax probe with a $350 million payment. The bank has set aside $1 billion in excess capital, which could be used to fund deals in Switzerland, Asia, and London. Julius Baer's CEO, Boris Collardi, has expressed his desire to acquire rivals, citing the bank's excellent track record of getting good prices and integrating assets efficiently. Analysts estimate the bank has the potential to acquire businesses twice the size of Coutts International.

site_title: 50 pianists working hard at playing in sync
summary: The Sing50 concert, led by Lang Lang, will feature 50 pianists playing Steinway-designed baby grand pianos at the National Stadium on Aug 7. The pianists, including 10-year-old Bryzlyn Sin from Perth, will play a selection of Singapore's best-loved songs from the past 50 years. Rehearsals have been challenging, with the biggest challenge being synchronizing their interpretations of the songs. The concert is part of Singapore's 50th anniversary celebrations and will be followed by the adoption of the pianos by schools to teach the country's musical heritage.

site_title: How to keep businesses fit for sale
summary: Business owners should prepare their companies for sale by creating a mindset that allows the business to run independently. This includes creating intellectual property that belongs to the business, managing contractual relationships with employees and suppliers, and keeping employment contracts formal. A business fit for sale is a pleasure to own, and preparing for sale now can maximize value. By adopting these strategies, owners can free themselves from day-to-day operations and focus on strategy, driving performance and business value. This mindset allows for a smoother transition when the time is right.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) is reinitiated with a "buy" rating by RHB Research Institute Singapore. The Reit's exposure to defensive subsectors like Grade B office and hi-spec industrial spaces provides stability, with a forecast yield of 6.8% in 2016. Organic growth via higher-than-expected rental reversion and the rejuvenation of China Square Central are long-term catalysts. In contrast, Singapore Airlines (SIA) maintains a "hold" rating, citing stagnant demand and the need for further industry consolidation to improve its outlook.

site_title: Raising funds, creating entrepreneurs
summary: The Spirit of Enterprise (SOE) Fundraising Golf Challenge 2015 will be held at Sentosa Golf Club on July 30, aiming to raise an additional S$130,000 for the organization. Founded in 2002, SOE cultivates an entrepreneurial culture in Singapore, recognizing local entrepreneurs and inspiring young students to become entrepreneurs through various programs. The event is expected to add to the organization's total fundraising of around S$230,000 since its inception in 2011.

images.alt_text: The SOE Fundraising Golf Challenge aims to raise S$130,000 this year.

site_title: Stratech gets SGX nod for removal from watch-list
summary: Stratech Group, a technology-based surveillance and transportation systems supplier, received in-principal approval from Singapore Exchange to be removed from the watch-list, effective July 20, 2015. The counter closed 5% up at 4.2 Singapore cents following its application on July 14. This move comes after the company's shares were traded 42 million times worth S$1.8 million on Monday.

site_title: Penny stock CEFC's rise draws attention
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 20.03 points to 3,373.48, driven by the 80% surge in shares of penny stock CEFC International. The firm's share price rose from S$0.03 to S$0.18, with 127.5 million shares traded. The STI's gain took it 8 points into the black for the year, after six weeks of losses. Other penny stocks, such as Sino Construction and Polaris, also saw increased interest. The rise in the STI was attributed to programme buying ahead of a firm session on Wall Street, and the receding worries surrounding Greece.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close higher
summary: Europe's main markets closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE 100 rising 0.20% to 6,788.69 points, the CAC 40 increasing 0.35% to 5,142.49 points, and the DAX 30 rising 0.53% to 11,735.72 points. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks.

site_title: First Reit's Q2 DPU rises 3.5%
summary: First Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) for the second quarter rose 3.5% to 2.07 Singapore cents, driven by new acquisitions and Indonesian and Singapore properties. Distributable income and net property income increased 7.2% and 8.3% respectively. The trust's gearing remains healthy at 32.9%, and it expects demand for healthcare services to remain strong despite Indonesia's economic slowdown. First Reit's rentals in Indonesia are denominated in Singapore dollars, making it unaffected by the rupiah's depreciation.

site_title: Toshiba bosses responsible for overstating profits by US$1.2b: panel
summary: Toshiba's top executives were responsible for inflating profits by $1.2 billion over six fiscal years, according to an independent panel. The plan was uncovered after securities regulators investigated accounting irregularities in Toshiba's balance sheet. The conglomerate hired an outside team of investigators to look into the matter. The findings are a stinging indictment of one of Japan's best-known firms, Toshiba.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Monday
summary: Singaporeans expect inflation to rise to 3.35% in a year, despite lower oil prices and a slowdown in China, according to a quarterly survey. US authorities are investigating a Singapore asset manager in an offshore tax evasion crackdown. ST Engineering's CEO, Tan Pheng Hock, is on medical leave after suffering a mild stroke. Singapore stocks finished higher, led by penny stock CEFC International, which surged 80% in a single trading session.

site_title: ST Electronics wins S$424m contracts in Q2 2015
summary: ST Electronics secured S$424 million worth of contracts in Q2 2015, with S$285 million for advanced electronics and infocomm technology projects and S$84 million for satellite communications equipment. These contracts will be completed over the next six years, with projects from public and private sectors worldwide.

site_title: Huawei's H1 revenue up 30% at 175.9b yuan
summary: Huawei reported a 30% increase in first-half revenue to 175.9 billion yuan, exceeding its target of 20% growth. The company posted an operating margin of 18% and expressed confidence in maintaining effective growth in 2015. This marks a stable and healthy growth in its telecom, consumer device, and enterprise business segments. Huawei aims to achieve overall revenue of US$70 billion by 2018, with a projected 10% annual growth.

site_title: Fifa presidential election to be held on Feb 26: Fifa Twitter feed
summary: FIFA's presidential election is scheduled for February 26 in Zurich, with a news conference to be held at 3 pm CET.

site_title: New Zealand drone makers target Hollywood
summary: New Zealand-based drone maker Aeronavics is targeting the fast-growing market for unmanned aerial vehicles in the film and television industry, capitalizing on the US relaxation of commercial drone rules. The company aims to develop sophisticated, purpose-built aircraft to capture high-quality aerial shots, priced significantly lower than helicopter rentals. With backing from James Cameron and a competition for film industry drone developers, Aeronavics plans to launch a series of aircraft later this year, poised to revolutionize the industry.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB Group appoints new directors
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group appointed two new directors, Mohd Nasir Ahmad and Lee Kok Kwan, effective immediately. The appointments were made by Zafrul Aziz, chief executive, citing their experience in finance and governance. Lee, who was previously adviser to the CEO, will relinquish all executive positions. The new directors bring specialized expertise in conventional finance and accounting.

site_title: Morgan Stanley profit falls on compensation costs, tax provision
summary: Morgan Stanley reported an 8.5% fall in quarterly profit to $1.67 billion, or 85 cents per share, due to rising compensation costs and increased tax provisions. The bank's consolidated net revenue rose 13% to $9.74 billion, with wealth management revenue increasing 4.7% to $3.88 billion. Morgan Stanley is focusing on stable businesses like wealth management to free up capital and comply with stricter regulations.

site_title: China's Spring Airlines aims to raise US$725m to fund expansion
summary: China's Spring Airlines plans to raise up to 4.5 billion yuan (S$994.2 million) through private share placements to fund internet projects and aircraft purchases. The budget carrier reported a significant jump in half-year earnings, with net earnings rising 130-150% from last year. Spring Airlines aims to buy 21 Airbus A320 jets and maintain its Northeast Asian strategy. The company's efforts follow Shenzhen Airlines' US$4.3 billion deal to buy Boeing 737s, as both airlines seek to capitalize on China's booming air travel market.

site_title: HLH buys US$2.2m equipment to set up new cassava starch production line
summary: HLH Group has signed a deal with Tidecom Technology Co to purchase US$2.23 million worth of equipment to set up a new cassava starch production line in Cambodia. The production line, capable of producing up to 120 tonnes of cassava starch per day, is expected to be operational by the next quarter. The line will be operated by Zhong Fu International Investment (Cambodia) and will generate new revenue streams for HLH, with the company expecting to recoup its investment in less than five years.

site_title: Former Chinese presidential aide faces graft prosecution: Xinhua
summary: A former senior Chinese Communist Party official, Ling Jihua, is facing prosecution for corruption and trading power for sex. Expelled from the party, he is accused of accepting huge bribes, using his position to commit adultery, and benefiting his wife's business. The prosecution comes as part of President Xi Jinping's crackdown on graft, which has deposed several senior officials. Ling's career was marred by his son's fatal Ferrari crash in 2012, and his family faces further accusations of corruption. A trial is almost guaranteed, with a guilty sentence and jail term likely to follow.

site_title: Gold hits five-year low under US$1,100 on Chinese selling
summary: Gold prices plummeted to a five-year low, falling US$45.55 to US$1,088.05 an ounce, amid Chinese selling and a strengthening dollar ahead of potential US interest rate hikes. Investors lost confidence in gold as a risk hedge, while oversupply and weaker prices fueled speculative selling. Spot platinum also fell 5% to a six-and-a-half-year low, and platinum prices declined.

site_title: Cheating website Ashley Madison hacked for user data
summary: The adultery website Ashley Madison has been hacked, with hackers gaining unauthorized access to customers' data through various vulnerabilities on the site. The breach was briefly exposed online before being taken down, with hackers claiming responsibility as "The Impact Team." Ashley Madison, which boasts 37 million users, apologized for the intrusion and said it had secured its sites and closed the unauthorized access points. The company had stringent security measures in place but was unable to prevent the attack, which affected users in 46 countries.

site_title: Regulatory changes in Asia pose challenges for global banks
summary: Global banks face increased costs and challenges in accessing Asia's domestic markets due to regulatory changes. Fines for foreign staff providing services to onshore clients in Taiwan and reorganisations in Asia by banks like Societe Generale and Deutsche Bank signal a need for local presence. This shift will force banks to be more selective and cost-conscious, focusing on smaller markets. Banks like Societe Generale are reinforcing local presence in key markets like Japan, Korea, and Greater China to tap into growth drivers like structured products and derivatives.

site_title: Lockheed to buy UTC's Sikorsky for US$9b
summary: Lockheed Martin Corp agreed to buy Sikorsky Aircraft, the helicopter unit of United Technologies Corp, for $9 billion, or $7.1 billion after tax benefits. Lockheed CEO Marillyn Hewson said Sikorsky complements Lockheed's portfolio of aerospace and defense products. The transaction is expected to close by late 2015 or early 2016, pending regulatory approvals.

site_title: US: Stocks up as Lockheed Martin seals Sikorsky deal
summary: US stocks rose on Monday as Lockheed Martin announced its $9 billion purchase of Sikorsky Aircraft from United Technologies, adding to its aerospace and defense portfolio. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.06%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes rose 0.03% and 0.12%, respectively. Lockheed Martin and Morgan Stanley also saw gains, while United Technologies declined. The news followed solid earnings from Morgan Stanley, which beat analyst expectations.

site_title: Echo beats Packer's Crown to win Brisbane casino licence
summary: Australian gaming firm Echo Entertainment Group has won a licence to build a casino in Brisbane's Queen's Wharf, edging out rival Crown Resorts. The decision comes as Chinese high rollers seek new locations amid a corruption crackdown in Macau. Echo's win marks a victory against its rival following a failed bid to build a US$2 billion casino in Sydney. The licence is expected to benefit from an influx of wealthy Asian customers, with record revenue levels reported at Echo's casino in Sydney and Crown's Melbourne casino.

site_title: Russia proving to be best BRICS bet this year
summary: Russia has proven to be the best bet among BRICS countries in 2015, with risk-adjusted returns surpassing China and other BRICS nations. According to data compiled by Bloomberg, Russia's fast-growing economy and world-beating stock market outperformed its peers, making it a more attractive investment option at the start of 2015. This conclusion is based on a comparison of Russia's economic performance against that of China and other BRICS countries in 2015.

site_title: M1 posts S$44.3m earnings for Q2
summary: M1 announced a net profit of S$44.3 million for Q2 2015, with revenue growing 15.5% to S$276.8 million. Earnings per share remained unchanged at 4.7 Singapore cents. For the six months, net profit rose 3.8% to S$90 million, driven by service revenue of S$408.6 million. The company declared an interim dividend of 7 Singapore cents per share and expects moderate growth in net profit after tax for the year.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust's Q1 DPU dips 2.6%
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust reported a 2.6% year-on-year dip in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.85 Singapore cents for the first quarter, despite a 5% increase in gross revenue to S$85.1 million. Net property income gained 3.1% to S$71.1 million, driven by acquisitions and stronger performance from existing properties in Hong Kong. However, lower contributions from Singapore properties and increased property expenses due to multi-tenant conversions partially offset these gains. The Reit's share price rose 0.5 cents to close at S$1.155.

site_title: China: Stocks close 0.88% higher
summary: Chinese stocks closed 0.88% higher on Monday, with the Shanghai Composite Index reaching 3,992.11 after earlier gains. The Shenzhen Composite Index rose 1.82% to 2,230.29. Market sentiment improved following government measures to halt a month-long rout.

site_title: Japan's Uniqlo closes JD.com store citing China online strategy mismatch
summary: Uniqlo has closed its online store on JD.com in China, citing a mismatch between its online strategy and the Chinese market. The store was launched in April after a three-month trial run, but Uniqlo decided it wasn't aligned with its China e-commerce strategy. Despite JD.com reporting strong sales, Uniqlo will continue to operate in China, both online and offline, with plans to expand to 1,000 stores in the region by 2020. This decision contrasts with Uniqlo's successful presence on Alibaba's Tmall platform.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Monday
