This rapid increase in debt poses risks to the financial stability of the world's second-largest economy. Despite the country's economic expansion beating analysts' forecasts, the debt issue threatens to delay efforts to reduce debt levels. Non-performing loans also climbed by a record 140 billion yuan in the first quarter, and experts warn that the debt-to-GDP ratio will continue to rise. China's government is prioritizing growth stability over debt reduction.

site_title: China corporate debt burden climbs, defaults to rise: S&P
summary: China's corporate debt burden has worsened, with the corporate debt to GDP ratio reaching 160% in 2014, exceeding twice that of the US. Defaults are expected to increase, and the Chinese central government's support for state-owned enterprises is uncertain. S&P estimates that China will consume 40% of global demand for corporate debt over 2015-2019, with outstanding corporate debt globally expected to grow 40% to $71 trillion by 2019. This poses a risk to financial markets and highlights China's reliance on debt to fuel economic growth.

site_title: Sabana Reit Q2 DPU dips on larger base of units
summary: Sabana Reit reported a 3.2% dip in distribution per unit (DPU) for the second quarter to 1.8 Singapore cents due to a larger base of units. Distributable income rose 1.2% to S$13.2 million, and net property income increased 0.5%. The Reit's multi-tenanted occupancy improved to 78.3%, and its overall occupancy level rose to 90.9%. Despite a challenging market, Sabana Reit's manager plans to manage lease expiries, acquire yield-accretive assets, and diversify funding sources to strengthen the trust's capital structure.

site_title: US economy keeps up momentum: Beige Book
summary: The US economy continued its growth momentum in May and June, with 12 Federal Reserve districts reporting expansion. Consumer spending showed a mixed picture, with low energy prices boosting spending in some areas and a stronger dollar curbing exports. Manufacturing activity was uneven, with lower oil prices hurting the oil and gas industry and a strong dollar dampening exports. Fed Chair Janet Yellen indicated that interest rates may be raised later this year to normalize monetary policy.

site_title: Enjoyable romp through Marvel land
summary: Ant-Man, directed by Peyton Reed, is an enjoyable Marvel film that balances drama, action, and humor. The story follows Dr. Hank Pym, a particle scientist who invents a suit that allows a person to shrink to the size of an insect, as he teams up with thief Scott Lang to stop the villainous CEO Darren Cross from misusing the technology. The film features a low-key approach, adding to its fun factor and making it a snappy improvement over standard blockbusters. With a talented cast, including Michael Douglas, Paul Rudd, and Evangeline Lilly, Ant-Man is a well-crafted addition to the Marvel universe.

site_title: Talk of NOL sale makes the rounds in the market again
summary: Temasek Holdings is reportedly selling off Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) to prospective buyers, according to people familiar with the matter, as cited by The Wall Street Journal. The container liner has been in financial trouble, and this sale may be a way for Temasek to recoup losses. The sale has been in the works for several months, with NOL being "shopped around" to various buyers. The outcome of the sale is still uncertain, but it marks a significant development in NOL's financial struggles.

site_title: Japan investors expected to help Nikkei outdo peers, say traders
summary: Japan's domestic investors, including the Bank of Japan, are expected to help the Nikkei outperform global peers by buying on dips, offsetting any retreat by foreign investors. After hitting a near-three-month low, the Nikkei recovered to 20,569.76, driven by aggressive buying from Japanese investors and government support. The sector most vulnerable to international risks is financials and exporters, but long-term foreign investors expect Japanese stocks to rise further due to reasonable valuations. Japanese companies are also paying out record dividends and improving return on equity.

site_title: Private club-gym
summary: Gravity, a high-end private club-gym, is launching in Singapore to cater to the needs of high-powered executives. Developed from a survey of 2,500 senior executives, Gravity offers a personalized fitness and wellness program with premium services. CEO Simon Flint states that 95% of respondents were interested in exclusive propositions, willing to pay a premium for personalized fitness and healthcare. The concept aims to be a prototype for other cities worldwide, addressing the growing demand for holistic fitness and wellness programs.

site_title: Global slowdown could reveal other untenable debt burdens: IIF
summary: The Institute of International Finance (IIF) warns that the global slowdown could expose further unsustainable debt burdens, similar to the Greek crisis. The IIF suggests that countries facing high debt and low nominal growth should draw lessons from Greece, Ukraine, and Puerto Rico to develop an appropriate framework for debt restructurings. The organization emphasizes the need for governments to promote sustainable growth, considering the composition and structure of debt, and ensuring country "ownership" of adjustment programs.

images.alt_text: FLAGGING SPIRITS: The international financial community should employ a broader concept of debt sustainability, said the IIF, instead of fixating on measuring debt sustainability as a ratio of nominal debt to GDP.

site_title: Retailers need to move with shoppers
summary: The Great Singapore Sale, a two-month retail event, has ended with declining interest from consumers and a rise in e-commerce. Retailers are struggling to compete with online competitors such as Alibaba's Taobao and Amazon, which offer comparable prices and convenience. E-commerce has become a mainstream option in Singapore, with 58% of Singaporeans making online purchases monthly. To survive, retailers must rethink their strategies and establish a stronger online presence to meet consumer expectations of price and convenience.

site_title: Seoul focuses on loan quality after curbs on household debt fail
summary: South Korea's government has shifted its focus from curbing household debt to reducing riskier loan types as its economy struggles. The goal to cut household debt to 155% of disposable income by 2017 is no longer feasible, with the ratio already at 164% and expected to rise. The government plans to lower the target and strengthen lender screening, aiming to curb "bullet" loans and improve debt quality. This move prioritizes economic growth over debt reduction, amid concerns that rising debt levels could hinder growth once interest rates rise again.

site_title: Cash-short Greeks go on credit card-fuelled spending spree
summary: Greeks are using credit cards to drain their accounts due to concerns that their cash could be confiscated or devalued, following a similar experience in Cyprus two years ago. To avoid losing access to their money, Greeks are paying taxes and bills electronically or purchasing luxury goods. This spending spree is a result of the country's economic struggles, with many Greeks worried about the potential for their cash to be seized.

site_title: Shutterbug of S'pore past makes debut
summary: Singaporean photographer Loke Hong Seng, 71, has made his debut in the art world with a collection of 200 street portraits taken from 1963 to 1985. For over 30 years, he kept the negatives unprinted due to high costs, but his son persuaded him to meet gallerist Audrey Yeo, who showcased his work in a solo exhibition and published it in a book. The exhibition is now sold out, with only 500 copies of the book remaining, marking a significant recognition of Loke's contributions to Singapore's photography history.

site_title: HK to sell HK$10b inflation-linked bonds next week
summary: Hong Kong will sell up to HK$10 billion in inflation-linked bonds, with interest paid every six months based on the average change in the consumer price index. The bonds will be sold to residents from July 21 to 29, with the notes to be issued on August 7 and listed on the stock exchange on August 10. Eligible applicants must be Hong Kong citizens with valid identity cards. The government aims to boost the local debt market and help citizens preserve purchasing power.

site_title: Upping the fitness game
summary: Fitness centers in Singapore are expanding their services to cater to various needs, from executives seeking integrated health programs to seniors requiring specialized equipment. New gyms like Gravity and Active Hive offer niche experiences, such as aerial yoga and infrared elliptical workouts, to stay relevant in the market. Meanwhile, the Gym Tonic project is providing senior-focused centers with customized strength training and data analysis, aiming to use exercise as "medicine" for prevention. With growing demand and limited gym membership penetration in Singapore, the industry is poised for continued growth.

site_title: Art Apart returns with Filipino focus
summary: The Art Apart hotel art fair returns to Parkroyal on Pickering with a focus on Filipino artists, featuring over 50 emerging artists, including Aleah Angeles and JM Saycon. The fair also showcases works from 100 artists from Japan, China, and other countries. A video highlighting the art collection of Singapore-based Argentinian architect Ernesto Bedmar will be screened at the fair, with a select few invited to view his collection at his home in October and January. Only 300 people will be chosen for the home viewing, with reserve prices starting at S$50,000.

site_title: Bullion prices at a low ahead of US rate hike
summary: Bullion prices have plummeted to their lowest in eight months as the US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates later this year, according to Fed Chair Janet Yellen. Gold prices closed at $1,147.40 per troy ounce, down 0.53% from the previous day. Market participants are focusing on US interest rates and foreign exchange dynamics, rather than the Greek debt saga, which has failed to spark interest in gold. Analysts predict a September rate hike and lower gold prices, with some predicting gold could fall to $1,000 over the next 12 months.

site_title: NZ central bank seen slashing rates
summary: New Zealand's central bank is expected to cut interest rates aggressively to support the country's flagging economy. Analysts predict a potential 125 basis point rate drop to 2% by year-end, with some forecasting a 50 basis point cut in the coming week. The economy is facing challenges, including low inflation, crumbling dairy prices, and sliding consumer sentiment. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand's cash rate has already been cut by 25 basis points, and a Reuters poll suggests a rate cut on July 23 is likely, with a consensus view of a 2.5% rate by the first quarter of next year.

site_title: Greek bailout news lifts Singapore market
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore rose 14.59 points to 3,353.45 following news that Greece's parliament has voted to accept its bailout terms. The market lifted despite volatility in Hong Kong, where the Hang Seng Index first fell before closing with a triple-digit gain. US Federal Reserve Chairman Janet Yellen's testimony also suggested interest rate hikes this year. Petrochemical firm CEFC International outperformed, while DBS Bank and CapitaLand rose on positive analyst forecasts. Deutsche Bank scaled back growth forecasts for several Asian markets, citing disappointing data.

site_title: City buzz
summary: Singapore musicians showcased their talents on stage. No specific details about the event or musicians were provided. The article does not offer further information about the event.

site_title: US mortgage rates increase with 30-year at a nine-month high
summary: US mortgage rates surged to a nine-month high, with the average 30-year fixed mortgage rate reaching 4.09%, up from 4.04% last week. The increase is attributed to Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's plans to raise borrowing costs this year and the fading likelihood of a Greek exit from the euro region. The 15-year rate also rose to 3.25%. The Fed's forecast of stronger growth and lower unemployment contributed to the boost in mortgage rates.

site_title: Eurozone is imperfect, fragile: ECB
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) president Mario Draghi stated that the eurozone is "imperfect, fragile, and vulnerable" and needs stronger integration within the currency bloc. Draghi emphasized the need for decisive steps on further integration following the Greek debt crisis. He confirmed that Greece's debt relief is "uncontroversial" and the ECB "substantially accommodated" the Bank of Greece's funding request. Draghi also maintained that the ECB will continue to focus on inflation and price stability, and the region's economy is showing signs of growth.

site_title: Eden Hall vacant land could go on market
summary: Singapore's Eden Hall, a British conservation bungalow, may be sold in the next several months. The vacant freehold land could be carved out into two plots for sale, with the minimum land area required for a Good Class Bungalow (GCB) being 1,400 square meters. Industry estimates suggest the front plot could fetch at least S$2,500 per square foot, while the rear plot could sell for S$2,250 per square foot. The sale of the land would be subject to strict planning rules to preserve exclusivity and low-rise character of GCB areas.

site_title: US home builder sentiment holds at highest since 2005: NAHB
summary: US homebuilder sentiment remains at its strongest level in almost a decade, with the NAHB/Wells Fargo Housing Market index standing at 60 in July, unchanged from June. This is the highest level since November 2005. Despite rising mortgage rates, economists predict a continued recovery of the housing market. Home builder optimism increased across all four regions, but challenges such as lot and labor shortages persist.

site_title: June exports rebound, but caution remains
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rebounded 4.7% in June, exceeding expectations of a 2% gain, as improvements were seen in almost every sector. The increase was led by electronic products, with personal computers, integrated circuits, and telecommunications equipment experiencing significant growth. Despite the better-than-expected data, economists remain cautious, citing a sequential decline in June's NODX and concerns over the electronics recovery. This has led to a small upward revision in Q2 GDP growth, but the outlook remains uncertain.

site_title: Greece may hold snap elections in September or October: minister
summary: Greece's interior minister, Nikos Voutsis, suggests that snap elections may take place in September or October due to a revolt by lawmakers from the ruling Syriza party, which forced the government to rely on opposition votes to pass a vital bailout bill. The government aims to adopt its program, including commitments from the bailout deal, in the elections. A comprehensive review will determine the exact timing and outcome of the elections.

site_title: ECB says Greek crisis has shown eurozone is imperfect, fragile
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi stated that the Greek debt crisis has exposed the eurozone's fragility and need for stronger integration within the currency bloc. Draghi emphasized the union's imperfection and urged decisive steps towards further integration. He reiterated that he considers the euro "irreversible" and that discussions on Greece's participation in the eurozone do not weaken the bloc.

site_title: ECB presses ahead with quantitative easing, promises more action if necessary
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has reaffirmed its quantitative easing program, which will continue until September 2016 or inflation reaches its target of 2% by 2017. ECB President Mario Draghi stated that the bank will respond to any change in the economic outlook by using all available instruments. The decision comes as inflation remains below target, and the ECB aims to stimulate the economy and prevent deflation.

site_title: Rake to stay on Barclays board until CEO is found
summary: Barclays deputy chairman Michael Rake will remain on the bank's board until a new CEO is appointed to replace Antony Jenkins, who was fired in a boardroom revolt. Rake, 67, will continue in his roles as deputy chairman and senior independent director until a replacement is found. A search for a new deputy chairman and senior independent director will start shortly, considering both internal and external candidates. Rake will also step down from his position as chairman of payment processor WorldPay Ltd in September due to the limit on directorships under European rules.

site_title: Toshiba CEO seen stepping down
summary: Toshiba's CEO, Hisao Tanaka, is expected to step down amid an accounting scandal that could result in 300-400 billion yen in charges, following an investigation into improper accounting practices. The probe found that profits were overstated by over 170 billion yen, and top officials may have knowingly encouraged wrongdoing. The company has hired a third-party committee to investigate and is likely to replace half of its board, including Tanaka, with outside directors. Toshiba's shares have slumped 29% since the initial disclosure of irregularities in April.

site_title: Getting to know all about coffee
summary: Coffee was discovered in Ethiopia by an Ethiopian shepherd who noticed his sheep's increased energy after eating from a particular tree, believed to be a coffee tree. The exhibition "Espresso Italiano" at Scotts Square explores the history and culture of Italian coffee, despite coffee beans not being native to Italy. The curator, Luciano Calosso, discovered that coffee's social aspect and ability to stimulate the mind contribute to its widespread consumption, with 1.6 billion cups consumed daily. The exhibition showcases coffee artefacts and reproductions of paintings, highlighting the evolution of coffee from its origins to its Italian cultural significance.

site_title: India turns up heat on 'shadow' market
summary: India's regulators are cracking down on the country's "shadow" market, dubbed dabba trading, which is estimated to be 8-10 times the regulated derivatives market. Dabba trading involves unlicensed traders making high-stakes bets on shares and commodities, often avoiding taxes and market rules. The practice poses a risk to the broader financial system and has been linked to unusual market moves. Regulators have set up a team to revise its dabba policy and have established 16 regional offices to monitor the black market.

images.alt_text: KEEPING WATCH: Sebi officials say that they are worried about contagion if markets turn volatile, particularly if dabba traders are using both on-market and off-market trades to hedge their exposures.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on strong quarterly results
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by Greek parliamentary approval of a bailout plan and strong quarterly reports from US bluechip companies. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.38%, the S&P 500 gained 0.51%, and the Nasdaq composite added 0.73%. These gains followed previous record highs, which were threatened by tariff concerns.

site_title: SMRT hastening NSEWL power network upgrade
summary: SMRT is speeding up its efforts to upgrade the power network on Singapore's North-South East-West Lines (NSEWL) after a July 7 power fault disrupted 250,000 commuters. The likely cause of the disruption has been narrowed down to the insulation of the third rail. SMRT will work with the Land Transport Authority to segment the network of cables, making it less likely for a power fault to disrupt travel on other parts or lines. The company has engaged in independent consultation and is conducting concurrent investigative and mitigation efforts.

site_title: Eurogroup agrees in principle to start new bailout talks with Greece
summary: Eurozone finance ministers agreed "in principle" to start new 3-year bailout talks with Greece after the Greek parliament voted through requested reforms. The decision requires approval from several eurozone parliaments, including Germany's Bundestag, and for Athens to adopt a second set of reforms by July 22. The Eurogroup will provide stability support to Greece subject to the completion of relevant national procedures.

site_title: Iran will augment Opec's clout
summary: Iran's nuclear deal with six global powers is expected to increase Opec's oil clout in an oversupplied market. Iran's production capacity, previously at six million barrels per day, is expected to rise, adding to Opec's arsenal and leading to a price fall. The Energy Information Administration predicts a slump of up to $15 per barrel. As demand growth accelerates, conventional crude production has stagnated, and non-Opec producers face challenges, making Opec's cheap supplies a crucial factor in the market.

site_title: Eurozone to give 7b-euro loan to Greece
summary: The European Union has agreed to provide Greece with a 7 billion-euro loan as part of a 86 billion-euro bailout deal. Following the Greek Parliament's acceptance of the deal, the European Central Bank has decided to allow Greek banks to draw down more emergency funding. The loan will come from the European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism, with a portion going to the International Monetary Fund for debt forgiveness. Greece must now implement severe austerity measures, including steep pension and tax cuts, in order to receive the bailout.

images.alt_text: MR TSIPRAS: 'I acknowledge the fiscal measures are harsh, that they won't benefit the Greek economy, but I'm forced to accept them.'

site_title: Qian Hu Q2 profit takes a plunge
summary: Qian Hu Corp reported a 45.5% drop in net profit to S$12,000 in the second quarter due to uncertainty in Europe's Greek crisis affecting ornamental fish sales. Revenue slipped 5% year-on-year to S$20.03 million. The company attributed the decline to European customers' decreased purchasing sentiments and a decline in fish exports to Russia. Qian Hu plans to diversify its export customers and countries to sustain its business.

site_title: Eurozone turmoil hits Qian Hu's Q2 bottom line
summary: Qian Hu Corporation, a Singapore-based ornamental fish group, reported a 45.5% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$12,000 for the second quarter due to the eurozone turmoil. Ornamental fish sales dropped 15.4% and revenue fell 5% to S$20.03 million. The crisis in Greece and economic sanctions in Russia affected the company's European customers. Despite this, Qian Hu aims to diversify its customers and export ornamental fish from Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, and Indonesia to sustain its business.

images.alt_text: The political turmoil in the eurozone stemming from the Greek financial crisis has taken its toll on Qian Hu Corporation, with the ornamental fish group posting a 45.5 per cent year-on-year fall in net profit to S$12,000 for the second quarter.

site_title: Putin tells Dutch PM MH17 tribunal would be counterproductive: Kremlin
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin told Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte that establishing an international tribunal to prosecute those behind the downing of Flight MH17 would be counterproductive. Putin explained Russia's position regarding the tribunal as premature and counterproductive. The Kremlin stated that Putin had a phone conversation with Rutte to discuss the issue.

site_title: Delta ditches plans for new jets
summary: Delta Air Lines has abandoned plans to acquire Boeing and Embraer jets worth at least $4 billion after union pilots rejected the contract necessary to trigger the deal. The decision comes after Delta posted a second-quarter profit that beat analysts' estimates and slowed growth in seating capacity. CEO Richard Anderson stated that the orders will be cancelled without elaborating further.

site_title: LifeBrandz to undergo S$100m reverse takeover to go into healthcare
summary: LifeBrandz, a Singaporean lifestyle group, has agreed to acquire shares in four healthcare companies in a S$100 million reverse takeover deal. The deal, subject to shareholder approval, will see LifeBrandz issue 10 billion new shares at S$0.01 each. The four target firms offer medical aesthetics, cosmetic surgery, and specialist services through 12 medical clinics in Asia. The deal aims to transform LifeBrandz into a regional healthcare enterprise, with plans for business growth, hospital development, and innovative medical technology businesses.

site_title: EBay sells enterprise unit ahead of PayPal split
summary: eBay is selling its enterprise business to a consortium led by Permira for $925 million, streamlining operations ahead of the separation from PayPal. The deal leaves eBay with its slow-growing marketplace business, which faces stiff competition. Despite this, analysts are bullish on eBay's prospects as a standalone company, citing its profitability and cash generation. The sale comes as eBay reported a 7% jump in net revenue in its second-quarter results, driven by higher demand in the PayPal business.

site_title: Goldman profit halves on weak bond trading, legal provisions
summary: Goldman Sachs' profit more than halved in the second quarter, reaching $916 million, or $1.98 per share, due to weak bond trading and increased litigation provisions. The bank's net revenue from fixed-income trading fell 28% to $1.60 billion. Despite this, revenue from equity underwriting rose 9% and investment banking revenue increased 13%. Goldman ranked No. 1 in global mergers and acquisitions and equity underwriting in the first half of 2015.

site_title: ECB holds key rates steady, Greek banks in focus
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) held its key interest rates steady at 0.05%, 0.30%, and -0.20%, as expected. The decision was made despite concerns over Greece's financial stability, particularly with Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras winning parliamentary approval for austerity measures. The ECB's Emergency Liquidity Assistance (ELA) to Greek banks remains a topic of scrutiny, with analysts questioning the solvency of many Greek lenders.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports rose 4.7% year-on-year to S$14.2 billion in June 2015, driven by electronic and non-electronic exports. Temasek Holdings put Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) up for sale. A locally-made cancer drug candidate advanced into Phase 1 clinical trials. US insurer MetLife launched a new innovation centre in Singapore. The Straits Times Index closed 14.59 points higher at 3,353.45 on Thursday, despite low turnover.

site_title: ECB to delay Greek funding boost as Europe mulls bridge loan
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is delaying an increase in emergency funding to Greek banks, which would have allowed them to partially reopen, as it waits for European leaders to finalize a financial backstop. The ECB needs to ensure Greece has the temporary financing to repay a 3.5 billion euro payment due to the ECB on Monday. A temporary 7 billion euro loan has been agreed in principle, but technical details will be finalized on Friday. The ECB's decision comes amid concerns about Greece's commitment to its bailout deal and the possibility of the country leaving the euro.

site_title: MH17 families sue Ukraine rebel for US$900m
summary: Malaysia Airlines relatives have filed a nearly $900 million lawsuit against Igor Strelkov, a former Ukrainian rebel leader, for the downing of MH17. The lawsuit claims Strelkov acted with Vladimir Putin's government authority and is seeking $50 million for each of the 17 victims' families. The case comes as Ukraine and the West accuse separatists of using a Russian-supplied missile to shoot down the plane. Russia denies involvement, and Putin opposes an international tribunal for those behind the disaster.

images.alt_text: Relatives of MH17 crash victims have filed a nearly US$900 million suit against a one-time leader of Ukranian insurgents over the shooting down of the jet over the rebel-held east of the country last year.

site_title: EU Commission says Greece could get short-term funds rapidly
summary: The European Commission expressed confidence that Greece could receive short-term financing soon after the Greek parliament overwhelmingly supported measures demanded by the eurozone in exchange for aid. The commission's spokeswoman, Annika Breidthardt, said 229 MPs voted in favor of the measures, indicating a significant step towards rebuilding trust. The commission believes a compromise is within reach, with funds potentially being disbursed rapidly once the measures are adopted. This development comes after the commission expressed encouragement for the Greek parliament's actions.

site_title: ERA eyeing another 10 Asia-Pacific markets
summary: ERA Franchise System plans to expand its presence in the Asia-Pacific region from 8 to 18 markets within 3 years, with 10 new markets to be added. The new markets include Australia, New Zealand, and several Southeast Asian countries. ERA is seeking partners to develop the ERA brand in these markets, with the goal of doubling its current presence in the region.

images.alt_text: BULLISH: ERA Franchise System LLC president and chief executive Charlie Young says the Singapore market is primed for continued growth.

site_title: Citigroup profit beats estimates as Corbat shows cost discipline
summary: Citigroup reported a second-quarter net income of $4.85 billion, or $1.51 a share, beating analyst estimates. CEO Michael Corbat showed cost discipline, with operating expenses falling 7.2% to $10.9 billion. Total revenue excluding accounting adjustments fell 1.5% to $19.2 billion. Corbat has made progress in transforming the firm, selling businesses and focusing on its best customers. He aims to achieve a return on assets of 90-110 basis points by year-end and an efficiency ratio of mid-50% for the core business.

site_title: Greek bank rescue fund to name Xenofos as new CEO: banking source
summary: Greece's bank bailout fund, HFSF, will name Aris Xenofos as its new CEO, replacing Anastasia Sakellariou who resigned in May. Xenofos, a former Eurobank executive, will oversee the fund's recapitalization of Greece's banking sector and wind down non-viable lenders. The Hellenic Financial Stability Fund is funded by Greece's 240 billion euro EU-IMF bailout.

site_title: Temasek putting NOL up for sale: WSJ
summary: Temasek Holdings has put Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) up for sale, citing the shipping company's poor performance in recent years. NOL has recorded pre-tax losses for four consecutive years, with a net loss of US$260 million in 2014. The company's group president warned of persistent over-capacity and uncertain global economic prospects. A prospective buyer has been "shopped to" but negotiations failed to agree on price. This comes after NOL sold its logistics business to Kintetsu World Express for US$1.2 billion earlier this year.

site_title: China's Li says Beijing can deal with risks to economy
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang expressed confidence in the country's ability to handle economic risks and ensure market stability, stating that China can properly deal with challenges and promote long-term economic growth. The country's economy grew 7% in the second quarter, beating analysts' forecasts. Li's comments come amid concerns over the recent stock market crash, but he did not specifically mention it. He also emphasized the need for stability and healthy development.

site_title: Switzerland says has extradited official to US in Fifa case
summary: Switzerland has extradited a Fifa official to the US to face corruption charges. The official, whose name was not disclosed, was handed over to US authorities in Zurich on July 15 and flown to New York. This is the first of seven Fifa officials being held in custody in Switzerland to be extradited. The move comes as part of a US investigation into corruption within the governing body of world soccer.

site_title: US jobless claims resume downward trend
summary: US jobless claims fell 15,000 to 281,000 in the week ended July 11, reversing a three-week increase. The four-week moving average of claims increased to 282,500, but remains below 300,000 for the 16th straight week. The current unemployment rate is 5.3%, within the range considered consistent with full employment by Federal Reserve officials. The number of people receiving jobless benefits declined 112,000 to 2.22 million, with the unemployment rate for those receiving benefits falling to 1.6%.

images.alt_text: The number of Americans filing new applications for unemployment benefits fell more than expected last week, pointing to a solid labour market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Thursday, closing at 1,726.73 after a trading volume of 841.03 million lots valued at RM1.03 billion. The market saw 314 gains and 330 losses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close up 0.43%
summary: Hong Kong equities closed 0.43% higher on Thursday, driven by movements in Shanghai. The Hang Seng Index rose 107.02 points to 25,162.78, with turnover of HK$91.59 billion. This follows several firms being removed from suspension in Shanghai last week to prevent a market meltdown. The gains are attributed to traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Hong Kong to sell HK$10b inflation-linked bonds next week
summary: Hong Kong will sell up to HK$10 billion of inflation-linked bonds from July 21 to 29, with interest paid every six months at a floating rate equivalent to the average change in the consumer-price index or a one per cent fixed rate. The bonds, the fifth offering since 2011, are eligible to Hong Kong citizens with valid identity cards. The sale is expected to be well-received, following good performance and interest rates in previous years.

site_title: BT could be broken up to improve Britain's broadband networks
summary: Britain's telecoms provider BT could be broken up to improve broadband networks, according to regulator Ofcom's proposal. Rivals Sky and TalkTalk accused BT of abusing its market position and failing to invest in broadband networks. BT responded that its investment in a fibre network led to higher speeds and lower prices for customers. The regulator's plan would create an independent operator to manage the Openreach network, a move seen as a response to BT's dominance in the UK market.

site_title: Thai central bank chief sees downside risk to 3% GDP growth estimate
summary: Thailand's central bank chief, Prasarn Trairatvorakul, has expressed concerns over a downside risk to the country's 3% GDP growth estimate due to a drought in parts of the country. The baht has depreciated to its lowest in over six years, at 34.2 against the dollar, which is in line with the currencies of trade partners. Despite this, Trairatvorakul still expects 3% growth for the year.

site_title: Developing nations give up on global tax plan
summary: Developing nations have abandoned their push for a global tax authority, a UN-managed intergovernmental body to oversee global fiscal regulations, due to opposition from richer countries. The proposal aimed to address profit-shifting by multinationals, costing poorer countries an estimated $100 billion annually. The decision was made during the United Nations global development summit in Ethiopia, where developing nations dropped their demands in favor of a subsidiary committee of the UN's Economic and Social Council with a consultative role.

site_title: Volcano shuts major Indonesian airport during holiday rush
summary: Indonesia's Juanda Airport near Surabaya was closed on July 16, 2015, due to increased ash activity from Mount Raung, a volcano erupting violently in recent weeks. The airport, serving the second-biggest city in Indonesia, was shut down from 1:30 pm to 8:30 pm local time, affecting millions of travelers ahead of the Eid holiday. This comes days after the airport on the nearby island of Bali was also closed due to ash from the same volcano.

site_title: Hong Kong sees deeper retail rent cut as global brands cool off
summary: Hong Kong's retail sector is experiencing a slowdown due to decreased visitor numbers, particularly from mainland Chinese tourists. Rents in Causeway Bay, once the world's most expensive retail street, are expected to fall by up to 40% this year, with some landlords seeking 40% reductions. Retailers, such as Burberry and Chow Sang Sang Holdings, have reported declining sales and are considering lower rents if sales weakness persists. The decline in tourist arrivals, partly due to tighter visa rules and lower import taxes, has led to a drop in retail sales and forced some retailers to hold early summer sales.

site_title: EU agrees to billion-euro bridge loan to shield Greek deal
summary: Euro-area finance ministers have authorized a 7 billion-euro bridge loan to Greece, paving the way for a third bailout and potentially allowing the country to remain in the euro currency. The short-term financing is needed to meet a 3.5 billion-euro payment to the European Central Bank, and will be used to negotiate a three-year bailout package worth up to 86 billion euros. The deal comes after Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras pushed through a bailout accord in his legislature, which now needs to be approved by national parliaments.

site_title: Singapore stocks close higher on news from Greece
summary: Singapore stocks closed higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index rising 14.59 points to 3,353.45, driven by news that Greece's parliament had voted to accept bailout terms from creditors. US Federal Reserve chairperson Janey Yellen's testimony that the US economy remains strong also contributed to the gain. Petrochemical firm CEFC International topped the actives list with a 19% rise, while Singtel was the only other top 20 stock to close above S$0.70.

site_title: India tweaks foreign investment restrictions: finance minister
summary: India has introduced composite caps to simplify foreign direct investments, effectively treating foreign capital equally, regardless of type. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley announced this move, combining foreign direct investment, foreign portfolio investment, and investments by non-resident Indians under a single cap. This decision aims to simplify and streamline the investment process, providing equal treatment to foreign capital in the country's economy.

site_title: Grexit averted but eurozone debt problems still a headache
summary: Greece's eurozone bailout package, valued at 86 billion euros, is less than 10% of Italy and Spain's borrowing needs by 2017. Despite averting Grexit, eurozone debt problems persist, with sovereign debt bankers focusing on refinancing needs in other indebted states. Investors may demand higher interest rates for Spain and Italy, which are struggling to get their debts on a sustainable path, as the central bank bond-buying crutch is set to be removed in 2026. The debt crisis remains a significant concern for the eurozone.

site_title: China firm reins in platform blamed for stock chaos
summary: China's Hundsun Technologies, linked to Alibaba, has implemented new limits on its financing platform HOMS amid allegations it facilitated margin trading contributing to China's stock market boom and bust. The platform, used to connect companies with lenders, was reportedly used for unauthorized margin trading. Hundsun has shut down certain functions and warned investors that the issue will affect its first-half-year results. The move comes after a China Securities Regulatory Commission investigation and denies any role in recent market turmoil. Hundsun's stock fell 9.94% on the day.

site_title: China Jan-June outbound investment up nearly 30% year-on-year: state radio
summary: China's outbound investment rose nearly 30% year-on-year in the first six months of 2015, according to state radio, exceeding the full-year target. This growth indicates China's confidence in its economic performance this year.

site_title: First Singapore-made cancer drug enters clinical trials
summary: Singapore's first locally-made cancer drug, ETC-159, has advanced into Phase 1 clinical trials targeting colorectal, ovarian, and pancreatic cancers. Developed through a collaboration between A*STAR and Duke-NUS, the drug will be tested on up to 58 patients at National Cancer Centre Singapore and National University Hospital. The Phase I trials aim to evaluate the safety and tolerability of ETC-159, with trials set to progress in the US. This milestone marks a significant step forward in Singapore's efforts to develop innovative cancer treatments, with Prof David Virshup calling it a major achievement in addressing unmet medical needs.

site_title: Unpopular Japan security bills approved by lower house
summary: Japan's lower house approved security bills loosening military constraints, despite massive protests and a decline in Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's ratings. The legislation aims to address rising China and is welcomed by the US. Opponents claim it violates Japan's pacifist Article Nine and could entangle the country in global conflicts. The move is seen as a significant shift in Japan's defense policy, with implications for regional stability and US-Japan relations.

site_title: Swatch expects strong second half as earnings beat estimates
summary: Swatch Group AG forecast a strong second half after beating earnings estimates with a 8.3% decline in first-half operating profit. The company attributes the growth to consumer demand for Swiss watches remaining high, particularly in the greater China region. New products such as mobile payment-enabled timepieces and James Bond Omega watches are expected to boost sales. Despite the Swiss franc's surge against the euro, revenue in the euro region increased by a double-digit percentage in euro terms. The stock rose 5.8% as of the publication date.

site_title: Seoul: Won hits 2-yr low after Yellen talk; shares close at 2-wk high
summary: The South Korean won hit a two-year low against the dollar after Federal Reserve Chief Janet Yellen hinted at a US rate hike this year. The won closed at 1,143.6, down 0.5% from its previous close, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 0.7% to its highest close in two weeks. The gains were largely driven by Samsung Electronics Co Ltd, a market heavyweight.

site_title: Germany's Schaeuble casts doubt on chance of Greek bailout success
summary: Germany's Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble expressed doubt about the success of a third Greek bailout program, amid efforts by senior conservatives to secure support for aid-for-reforms negotiations. Greece's parliament passed stringent measures, paving the way for negotiations on a third multi-billion euro bailout. Chancellor Angela Merkel is expected to receive the mandate from the Bundestag to start negotiations on Friday, with support from her coalition partners and some opposition parties. Schaeuble's comments cast a skeptical tone on the prospects of a successful bailout.

site_title: Insulation of third rail was likely cause of July 7 MRT disruption: SMRT
summary: SMRT has determined that the likely cause of the July 7 MRT disruption was the insulation of the third rail, which supplies power to trains. The insulation, part of the trackside infrastructure, may have affected the supply of traction power, leading to a nearly 2-hour disruption during the evening rush hour on the North-South and East-West networks. SMRT's investigations, including intensive re-enactments, point to the insulation as the probable cause of the breakdown.

images.alt_text: The insulation of the MRT system's third rail, which supplies power to trains, is the likely cause of last Tuesday's massive breakdown, SMRT said in a media release on Thursday.

site_title: China: Shares end up but trading volatility remains high
summary: China stocks rebounded 0.8% to 3,997.36, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.5% to 3,823.18, after a sharp correction. Trading volatility remains high despite Beijing's rescue measures, with index futures contracts trading below their underlying indexes. The CSI300 bank index lost 1.7%, while the defense sector recovered and cyclical sectors like transport, real estate, and infrastructure started to gain favor. Investors remain cautious, with many betting on further falls in mainland stocks.

site_title: ECB to weigh funding boost for Greece
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is considering increasing Emergency Liquidity Assistance (ELA) for Greece, potentially easing its funding squeeze and allowing banks to reopen. A bailout deal has been approved, and the ECB's Governing Council may increase ELA as early as Thursday, but the move is uncertain and may be limited. The Greek parliament's approval of a reform deal and a temporary "bridge" finance facility are also crucial for the funding increase to occur.

site_title: Ringgit forwards point to further weakness weighed by oil, 1MDB
summary: The Malaysian ringgit is expected to weaken further in the next 12 months, weighed down by a 50% slump in Brent crude prices and a looming US interest-rate increase. The currency has already fallen to its lowest this month since the Asian financial crisis and is the region's worst-performing currency in 2015. A probe into funds linked to 1Malaysia Development Bhd. has also eroded investor sentiment, with some analysts predicting the ringgit will depreciate to 4.0 by June 2016.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher for a third day, banks in demand
summary: Australian shares rose for a third day, driven by gains in the financial sector, particularly Commonwealth Bank, which reached a two-month high. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 33.4 points higher, or 0.6%, at 5,669.6. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: Swatch says first-half profit falls nearly 20%, outlook upbeat
summary: Swatch Group reported a nearly 20% decline in first-half net profit to 548 million Swiss francs due to a strong franc and negative interest rates. Despite this, the company remains upbeat about its full-year outlook, citing a "very good" outlook in all regions and segments. Swatch plans to maintain its long-term strategy of defensive price adjustment policy and will not hike prices swiftly to protect profits. The company's strategy to manufacture in Switzerland and expand its retail network remains unchanged.

site_title: EU opens anti-trust probe into Qualcomm
summary: The European Commission launched an anti-trust probe into Qualcomm, a US computer chip giant, on Thursday. The probe focuses on possible price rigging and abuse of its dominant market position in baseband chipsets used in mobile phones and tablet computers. The investigation aims to ensure that high-tech suppliers can compete on the merits of their products and that customers receive value for money. Qualcomm may face fines of up to 10% of its annual sales if found at fault. This is the latest in a series of EU investigations into top American companies, including Google, MasterCard, and Amazon.

site_title: Cybersecurity firms eye India as attacks on world's IT hub rise
summary: Global cybersecurity firm TaaSera launched its India business, joining others in the growing market amid expected doubling of online crimes in the country. India's growing economic progress, increasing smartphone use, and government's "Digital India" initiative make it vulnerable to cybercrimes. The number of cybercrimes in India is expected to reach 300,000 in 2015, almost double the level of last year. Industry experts say the lack of public disclosure laws in India hinders comparison with developed nations.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit 6-week high on Greece, Alfa Laval surges
summary: European shares reached a six-week high on July 16, 2015, after Greece passed austerity measures, paving the way for a new multibillion-euro bailout package. Alfa Laval surged 10% and Swatch Group rose 4.8% on positive earnings reports. The STOXX Europe 600 Automobile and Parts index gained 1.4%, driven by strong demand for mid-market brands and luxury autos. The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index rose 0.6% to its highest level in over six weeks.

site_title: China stock boom boosted GDP, raising sustainability questions
summary: China's stock market boom contributed to a 7% GDP growth rate in the first half of the year, driven by a 17.4% surge in the financial sector. The sector's growth was fueled by record trading volume and revenue surges in exchanges and brokerages. However, the boom's fragility raises concerns about the economy's growth prospects in the second half, as the sector's decline in the second half of June wiped almost $4 trillion in equity values. This may dent hopes for a economic pickup. The sector's performance underlines the challenges facing policymakers.

site_title: Europe's auto upturn firms in June as mid-market, luxury brands gain
summary: Europe's auto market experienced its highest monthly growth rate in five and a half years in June, with new car sales rising 14.8% year-over-year to 1.41 million. Mid-market and luxury brands, including Volkswagen, Peugeot, and Porsche, saw double-digit gains, contributing to the region's auto-market recovery.

site_title: Japan architect calls for 2020 Olympic stadium cost cuts
summary: Award-winning Japanese architect Tadao Ando calls for cost cuts for Tokyo's 2020 Olympic stadium, which is expected to exceed $1.6 billion. Construction costs have ballooned to 252 billion yen, sparking concerns over the project's feasibility. Ando suggests contractors should prioritize the public's interest over profitability. The government may review the plan, with over 80% of voters supporting a review, amid mounting criticism of the stadium's design and soaring costs.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 0.67% higher on Greek vote, Yellen comments
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.67% on July 16, 2015, after Greek MPs passed unpopular eurozone reforms. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 20,600.12, while the Topix index climbed 0.88%. The dollar strengthened against the yen following Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's comments on a potential interest rate hike by year-end.

site_title: Fifa needs independent commission to end corruption: watchdog
summary: Transparency International calls for an independent commission to end corruption within FIFA, citing a "culture of corruption" that has plagued the world governing body for years. The watchdog group recommends reforms such as increased transparency on pay and term limits for executives, and proposes limiting executives to two four-year terms. The call comes as US senators scrutinize FIFA over allegations of widespread corruption and ahead of a meeting to elect Blatter's successor, following a resolution from the European Parliament condemning systemic corruption within the organization.

site_title: China meat smuggling crackdown stokes risky underground trade
summary: China's crackdown on meat smuggling has driven the illicit trade deeper underground, with smugglers taking greater risks to evade authorities. Smugglers are now using smaller routes, including motorbikes and sampan boats, to transport frozen meat from Vietnam to China, where it is sold in wholesale markets and eventually reaches supermarkets. The trade has led to seizures of over 100,000 tonnes of smuggled meat this year, with some shipments dating back up to 40 years. Authorities have raised concerns over food safety, with some smuggled meat being sold at 30-60% cheaper prices due to high import duties.

site_title: Greeks spend their locked-away euros
summary: Greeks are rushing to spend their euros amid fears of a potential "Grexit" and deposit confiscation, leading to a surge in luxury goods sales. Between June 27 and July 10, sales of high-end items such as watches and electronics increased 30% compared to the same period last year. The government has assured depositors that their savings are secure, and tax payments have also increased, with over €1 billion flowing into state coffers. However, retail sales have declined 70% during the same period, highlighting the economic crisis.

site_title: Quick take: Analysts remain cautious over Singapore's export outlook
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 4.7% in June to S$14.2 billion, driven by growth in electronic and non-electronic exports. However, economists remain cautious about the export outlook, citing a weak economic environment, lower confidence among trading partners, and pressure on petrochemical exports due to oil price weakness. Despite a better-than-expected year-on-year growth, sequential decline and supply-side constraints are concerns, with electronics exports stuck in a slump and facing competition from emerging manufacturers like Vietnam. The 2015 NODX forecast is expected to contract by 1%.

site_title: ITE to strengthen controls after Singapore Auditor-General finds lapses
summary: The Institute of Technical Education (ITE) has accepted the Auditor-General's findings of various lapses, including an improper procurement method and irregular contract payments. The auditor-general's office identified S$16.78 million in irregularities, prompting ITE to strengthen controls and mechanisms to ensure accountability and transparency. The institute will also enhance financial systems to mitigate risks.

site_title: Seoul: Won falls to 2-year low after Yellen; shares edge up
summary: The South Korean won fell to a 2-year low against the dollar, dropping 0.4% to 1,148.2 per dollar, following US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's statement that the central bank may increase interest rates as early as September. The dollar firmed due to growing expectations of a rate hike. Meanwhile, Seoul shares edged up 0.3% as investors offset concerns over Greece's austerity measures with expectations of a potential interest rate increase.

site_title: United Airlines awards hackers millions of miles for revealing risks
summary: United Airlines has awarded millions of frequent flier miles to hackers who discovered security vulnerabilities in the airline's website, in a first for the US airline industry. The airline paid out two awards worth one million miles each, equivalent to dozens of free domestic flights. The move aims to bolster security by offering "bug bounties" to researchers who flag cyber risks before malicious hackers can exploit them.

site_title: China's Huawei gets security clearance to manufacture in India for booming market
summary: China's Huawei has won security clearance to manufacture telecoms equipment in India, allowing it to supply locally made products to the country's booming mobile phone market. This clears the way for Huawei to become the first major Chinese brand to manufacture in India, a significant boost for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's 'Make in India' campaign. Huawei aims to become a top three brand in India within three years, capitalizing on India's growing mobile market, which has over 975 million mobile phone subscriptions.

images.alt_text: Chinese telecoms giant Huawei Technologies Co has won security clearance to manufacture telecoms equipment in India, paving the way for it to become the first major Chinese brand to supply locally made products for one of the world's biggest markets for mobile phones.

site_title: Gold holds near 4-month low as US rate hike looms
summary: Gold prices hovered near a 4-month low as US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen reiterated that a US interest rate increase is likely this year, boosting the dollar and reducing demand for gold. Spot gold fell 0.3% to $1,145.85 an ounce, its weakest since March 17. Yellen's comments were in line with the Federal Open Market Committee's recent policy statement, which suggests gold's reaction to a rate hike may be muted or short-lived, potentially keeping prices above $1,100/oz.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.32% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.32% on Thursday, extending losses from the previous day, amid reduced likelihood of Beijing unveiling fresh economy-boosting measures. The Hang Seng Index dropped 79.68 points to 24,976.08. The move follows upbeat Chinese growth data, which may have alleviated concerns about Beijing's economic stimulus.

site_title: Honda used air-bag inflators by second maker under NHTSA probe
summary: Honda has used air-bag inflators made by ARC Automotive Inc., a second company under investigation by the US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, in some vehicles produced between 2000 and 2001. The inflators, which were supplied to Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and Kia Motors, were involved in two incidents warranting further investigation. Honda is checking the number of affected vehicles and considering a recall, following the global safety crisis involving defective air bags made by Takata Corp. Eight people have died in Honda cars due to the Takata air bag flaws.

images.alt_text: Honda Motor, the automaker worst affected by the global safety crisis involving defective air bags, said it had used inflators made by a second company under investigation in the US for suspected flaws.

site_title: China: Stocks lower in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares fell 1.24% in morning trade on July 16, 2015, despite a better-than-expected second quarter economic growth announcement. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 47.20 points to 3,758.50, and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 38.12 points to 2,020.72.

site_title: New Zealand primed for aggressive rate cuts as inflation and economy fade
summary: New Zealand's central bank is expected to cut interest rates aggressively to support a struggling economy, with some analysts predicting a 125 basis point drop to a record-low 2% by year-end. The country's dairy prices have plummeted to a six-year low, and inflation rose only 0.3% in the year to June 30, while consumer sentiment has dipped to its lowest in three years. The economy, which was once touted as a "rock-star" among developed nations, is facing significant headwinds, with the US$160 billion economy showing signs of decline.

site_title: China defaults to rise as corporate debt burden climbs: S&P
summary: China's corporate debt market continues to worsen, with the world's second-largest economy slowing, leading to increased defaults. The corporate debt burden is eight times government debt, reaching 160% of GDP in 2014. S&P predicts the debt will rise to $28.5 trillion in 2019, potentially destabilizing financial markets. Despite a slowing credit cycle, China's credit growth rate remains faster than most countries, and the country is expected to consume 40% of global corporate debt demand over 2015-2019.

site_title: Indonesia: Markets closed on Thursday
summary: Indonesia's financial markets are closed on Thursday for a public holiday. Meanwhile, global stock markets are experiencing volatility, with European stocks down due to bank and healthcare sector drag, and US stocks edging down from record highs amid tariff threats. In Asia, traders are brushing off new US threats, extending the recent rally in stocks. Key stocks to watch include Singtel, Sinarmas Land, and PSC, amidst ongoing US-EU trade talks and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Oil prices rebound in Asia
summary: Oil prices rebounded in Asia on July 16, 2015, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rising 39 cents to $51.80 a barrel and Brent crude advancing 45 cents to $57.50 a barrel. The price rebound came after a sharp decline the previous day, as traders reacted to the implications of Iran's landmark nuclear deal with major powers. The price increases were seen as a response to market uncertainty, with investors weighing the impact of tariffs, sanctions, and market outlook.

site_title: Asia: Stocks up after Greece deal, Yellen boosts dollar
summary: Asian markets rose on July 16, 2015, after Greek MPs voted in favor of a bailout package. The dollar strengthened after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's interest rate hike forecast. Tokyo, Sydney, and Seoul increased, while Singapore and Taipei also rose. However, volatility returned to Shanghai and Hong Kong due to reduced chances of economy-boosting measures from Beijing.

site_title: Court dismisses US hedge fund appeal against Samsung merger
summary: A South Korean appeals court rejected a US hedge fund's appeal against a $8.0 billion merger of two Samsung affiliates. The ruling clears the way for a shareholders' meeting to vote on the proposed takeover, which would consolidate Samsung's grip on the conglomerate. The hedge fund, Elliott Associates, opposes the takeover, citing undervaluation of the company's stock. The outcome of the vote remains uncertain, with Samsung needing a two-thirds majority to approve the merger.

images.alt_text: A South Korean appeals court on Thursday rejected the latest effort by US hedge fund Elliott Associates to block the US$8.0 billion merger of two Samsung affiliates.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher after Greek Parliament approves bailout
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index opened 15.17 points higher at 3,354.03 points, up 0.45%, after the Greek Parliament approved a new set of austerity measures for a bailout. This marks a week of consecutive positive opens, driven by the Greek deal. The top stocks by value traded were DBS, Singtel, OCBC, UOB, and SGX.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Oxley, CMT, Keppel DC Reit
summary: Singapore developer Oxley Group acquired 20% of London developer Galliard Group for £50 million (S$107 million). CapitaLand Mall Trust Management is exploring options for Funan DigitaLife Mall, including disposal or redevelopment. Keppel DC Reit's DPU for the second quarter exceeded expectations at 1.62 Singapore cents, a 1.9% increase.

site_title: S'pore's banking system outlook stable, as property market eases, credit growth moderates: Moody's
summary: Moody's has revised its outlook for Singapore's banking system to stable, citing the domestic property market's soft landing and moderating credit growth. The rating agency expects moderate credit growth for Singapore banks in the next 12-18 months, with problem loans increasing from foreign loans. Capital buffers remain strong, and systemic support for large banks is high. Moody's rates Singapore's three major banking groups with stable ratings, and expects loan-to-deposit ratios to remain stable at around 90% in 2015-16.

site_title: New Zealand inflation picks up but rate cuts still loom
summary: New Zealand's inflation rate rose 0.4% in the second quarter, driven by a 8.8% increase in petrol prices. Despite this, underlying inflation pressures remain muted, leaving the central bank room to cut rates further. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to cut rates again, potentially to 2.5% by October, as the economy slows. Analysts forecast another rate cut next week and a third in September.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.61% higher after Fed chief testimony
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.61% higher on Thursday after US Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen reiterated a likely interest rate hike this year as the economy improves. The Nikkei 225 index rose 125.65 points to 20,588.98. Yellen repeated her stance from the last Fed meeting, stating a rate hike "at some point this year" if the economy "evolves as we expect".

site_title: Update: Singapore's non-oil domestic export up 4.7% year-on-year in June
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 4.7% year-on-year in June to S$14.2 billion, driven by an expansion in electronic and non-electronic exports. Electronic exports grew 7.6% to S$4 billion, led by PCs, ICs, and telecommunications equipment. Non-electronic exports grew 75% in electrical machinery, 35.8% in printed matter, and 281.8% in non-electric engines and motors. NODX to the US, China, and Thailand increased in June, while emerging markets contracted 6.6% year-on-year.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks edge down tracking weakness in Chinese shares; TSMC up
summary: Taiwan's stocks edged down 0.1% on Thursday, following weakness in Chinese equities. The main TAIEX index closed at 9,046.08. TSMC, the world's largest contract chipmaker, rose 0.7% ahead of its second-quarter results, with forecasts predicting a net profit of T$72.2 billion. The electronics subindex and financials subindex declined 0.1% each.

site_title: NZ's Fonterra to cut 500 jobs, warns more redundancies to come
summary: New Zealand's Fonterra is cutting 523 jobs in operations, resulting in payroll savings of up to NZ$60 million a year, amid a 60% decline in global dairy prices since 2014. The job losses come as the company struggles to deliver its strategy and increase cash flow. More redundancies are expected in roles including ingredients, consumer, and marketing. Fonterra aims to focus on delivering food services and specialized ingredients in emerging markets, particularly in China. The company's profits have been falling for nearly two years due to volatile dairy prices.

site_title: Abe's security bills set for vote in face of Japan's pacifism
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's security bills are set to pass the parliament's lower house, despite protests against a potential expansion of the military role. The move risks eroding Abe's public support amidst concerns over Japan's 70-year-old post-war pacifism. Activists demonstrated against the bills, citing a lack of democratic process. The bills' passage marks a significant shift in Japan's security policy, which could impact its relations with neighboring countries, particularly China.

site_title: 1MDB Malaysia's Tenaga shares fall 3.1% on interest to buy 1MDB's power assets
summary: Tenaga Nasional Bhd, Malaysia's national power group, saw its shares drop 3.1% after announcing a plan to buy almost all of 1Malaysia Development's (1MDB) power assets. The acquisition, valued at up to 18 billion ringgit (S$6.47 billion), includes 14 power assets. The move comes as 1MDB faces debt issues, and the assets could provide a significant boost to Tenaga's portfolio. The proposal, submitted by Tenaga, is non-binding and indicative, with the company's major shareholder, Khazanah Nasional Bhd, also involved in the acquisition.

images.alt_text: Shares of Tenaga Nasional Bhd, Malaysia national power group, dropped as much as 3.16 per cent in early trade on Thursday after it said it wants to buy almost all of debt-laden state fund 1Malaysia Development's (1MDB) power assets.

site_title: Carl Icahn calls BlackRock a 'dangerous' company, cites ETF concerns
summary: Billionaire activist investor Carl Icahn criticized BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, as an "extremely dangerous company" due to the illiquidity of its exchange-traded fund products. Icahn expressed concerns over the high-yield ETF market, calling them "overpriced." BlackRock CEO Larry Fink countered Icahn's claims, stating that ETFs provide price transparency and are a tool for buying exposure. Fink also acknowledged the existence of "bad" activist investors, while emphasizing BlackRock's commitment to dialogue with companies it has issues with.

site_title: Bank of Canada cuts key lending rate as economy contracts
summary: The Bank of Canada cut its key lending rate by a quarter-point to 0.5% to stimulate an economy in recession, with Finance Minister Joe Oliver earlier dismissing the idea of a recession. The central bank downgraded its growth estimate, projecting a modest contraction in the first half of 2015 and higher excess capacity. The move aims to revive the economy, which has been affected by lower oil prices and slowing growth in China.

site_title: Google to offer free internet service in White House programme
summary: Google and other companies will offer free or low-cost internet to over 275,000 low-income households as part of President Obama's ConnectHome program, aiming to bridge the digital divide. Google will provide free Google Fiber subscriptions, while Sprint and CenturyLink will offer free plans or $9.95/month. The program, backed by $70 million from companies and a $50 million federal grant, will start in 27 cities and the Choctaw Nation, with digital literacy classes and HUD support.

site_title: Australia: Stocks up 0.57% after Greece approves reforms
summary: Australian stocks rose 0.57% at the open on July 16, 2015, after Greece approved austerity measures in a new bailout deal. The S&P/ASX200 index increased 32.1 points to 5,668.3. Analysts pointed to the potential for a US interest rate rise later this year as a key driver of market sentiment, with the Australian dollar hitting fresh six-year lows.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropped 2.72 points to 1,724.54, opening lower on Thursday. The market saw 44.81 million lots traded worth RM21.63 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 88 to 77.

site_title: New Zealand manufacturing activity rises in June
summary: New Zealand's manufacturing activity increased in June, according to a survey, rising to 55.2 from 52.0 in the previous month. The increase, above the 50 threshold, indicates an expansion in activity. This is a positive sign for the country's manufacturing sector, which had been showing some weakness.

site_title: Amazon's Prime Day draws big virtual crowd, frustrates some shoppers
summary: Amazon's Prime Day sale drew an 80% rise in US sales, with 50% of social media sentiment focused on disappointment due to lack of blockbuster deals. Some shoppers expressed frustration over deals selling out quickly and the lack of attractive prices. Despite this, Amazon reported that orders per minute during the peak surpassed Black Friday sales. The event also saw a 40% rise in sales in Europe, and rival retailers such as Wal-Mart and Target launched their own online sales.

site_title: Oxley buys 20% stake in London developer Galliard for £50m
summary: Oxley Group, a Singapore developer, acquired a 20% stake in London developer Galliard Group for £50m (S$107m). Galliard Group has £1.6 billion worth of forward sales and nearly 6,000 units under construction. The partnership aims to leverage expertise in both Singapore and London markets, supporting future developments in London and complementing Galliard's presence in Singapore.

site_title: British firms' confidence falls, but marketing spend rises
summary: British companies' confidence in their financial prospects has fallen to its lowest level since 2013, according to a survey. Despite this, marketing budgets have increased for the 11th consecutive quarter, with a net balance of 12.2% of companies increasing their advertising budgets. The growth in marketing budgets was most focused on events, while internet budgets slowed to a two-and-a-half-year low. The survey, which polled 300 companies, also found that only 25.3% of firms felt optimistic about their financial prospects, down from 37.8% in the previous quarter.

site_title: Toy emporium FAO Schwarz shutters famed New York store
summary: FAO Schwarz, a 143-year-old iconic toy emporium, closed its doors on July 15, 2015, due to rising real estate costs in New York City. The store, immortalized in films like "Big," will not close permanently, as owner Toys "R" Us plans to reopen it at an unspecified location in Manhattan. Thousands of customers visited the store for its final day, with many nostalgic New Yorkers and tourists seeking to make a last purchase. The store's iconic 43,000 square feet of merchandise was largely sold, with some aisles nearly empty.

images.alt_text: Famed toy emporium FAO Schwarz, a household name for its aisles crammed with games and pricey playthings, shuttered its doors on Wednesday, a casualty of New York's skyrocketing real estate prices.

site_title: Dollar strengthens as Yellen reaffirms 2015 rate hike
summary: The US dollar strengthened against major currencies due to Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's reaffirmation of a likely interest rate hike this year as the economy improves. Yellen stated that a rate hike is "at some point this year" if the economy evolves as expected. The US June data showed better-than-expected producer price and industrial production increases, supporting the Fed's rate hike plan. This boost to the dollar was welcomed by dollar bulls, with analysts predicting a faster pace of rate hikes if the Fed waits too long.

site_title: Europe: Shares near three-week high, with focus on Greek vote
summary: European shares reached a three-week high on Wednesday, driven by a Dutch firm's forecast and Greek vote uncertainty. The FTSEurofirst 300 index rose 0.4% to 1,586.50 points, with Italy's FTSE MIB and Spain's IBEX also gaining. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras faces a rebellion in his Syriza party as he pushes for a new bailout deal. Investors remain cautious, with some analysts predicting a successful vote despite uncertainty.

site_title: Oil sinks on outlook for more Iran crude exports
summary: Oil prices dropped on Wednesday as traders anticipated increased global oversupply from Iran's nuclear deal, which is expected to lift sanctions and boost oil exports. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell $1.63 to $51.41 a barrel, while Brent North Sea crude declined $1.65 to $56.86 a barrel. The rebounding dollar also contributed to the price drop, with Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's remarks indicating a possible interest rate hike this year. Analysts expect Iran's oil exports to increase, prolonging the current surplus.

site_title: Maintaining quality standards
summary: The Hatten Group of Companies, a Malaysian hospitality firm, is expanding its brand to new territories, focusing on maintaining quality standards. The company, which has established a strong presence in Malaysia, particularly in Melaka, plans to venture into China, Cambodia, and Vietnam in the next few years. Hatten has a reputation for delivering high-end hotels, with its flagship hotel in Melaka, Hatten Hotel Melaka, boasting 704 deluxe suites and multiple awards. The company has also partnered with international giants Hilton Worldwide, Marriott International, and Hyatt Hotels Corporation to ensure quality standards.

site_title: 'We have been betrayed!' Protest turns violent as Greece votes
summary: Protesters in Athens, Greece, turned violent after the country's parliament voted on a new bailout deal, which many see as an austerity measure. Firebombs were thrown at parliament, and police used tear gas to disperse crowds. The deal, worth up to $128.6 billion, was agreed upon by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and eurozone counterparts to unlock a rescue package. The government, led by Tsipras, is expected to pass the reforms, despite opposition from his own party and many Greeks who voted against similar austerity measures in a referendum on July 5.

site_title: Euro weaker, US futures rise as Greeks endorse deal
summary: The euro slipped 0.5% to $1.0952, while US stock futures gained 0.2% amid Greek lawmakers endorsing new bailout demands, temporarily easing concerns over the currency union. New Zealand's dollar hit a five-year low, and US oil remained near a three-month low. The Canadian dollar was also affected by a central bank rate cut, while copper futures dropped 0.2%. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen reiterated that borrowing costs will be raised gradually this year.

images.alt_text: Greece's parliament endorsed the bailout without the support of Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras's Syriza bloc, as riot police tussled with protesters outside.

site_title: Hard truths of World War II history
summary: China is capitalizing on the 70th anniversary of World War II's end to show off its status as a world power by staging a military parade on September 3. Beijing has invited Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to attend, putting him in a difficult position. If he accepts, he'll face criticism for attending a public event marking Japan's defeat, but if he declines, he'll be seen as unwilling to face Japan's wartime past. The move aims to depict China as a victor, despite the Communists not gaining power until four years after the war ended.

site_title: Pushing boundaries
summary: Singapore entrepreneur Jun Low, a former SIA stewardess, has built a successful career navigating the country's changing landscape. Her restaurant, Black Society, was initially rejected due to its triad-themed name, but she persisted. Low's career parallels key events in Singapore's history, including the tourism industry's growth and foreign worker quotas. She has successfully expanded her business, BreadStory, and Central Hong Kong Cafe, and now employs over 120 staff and generates S$20 million in revenue annually. Low advocates for the government to ease foreign worker controls to support the food and beverage industry's growth.

site_title: PM Lee on ST's role as observer, reporter, influencer
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of The Straits Times maintaining its "credible, balanced and objective reporting" as Singapore's "newspaper of record." He stressed the need for the publication to balance reporting with its influence on public opinion and events, while upholding Singapore's national interest and avoiding personal or corporate agendas. Lee also acknowledged the evolving media landscape, calling on The Straits Times to adapt and innovate while retaining experienced hands in the newsroom.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower as Greek protests rattle investors
summary: US stocks ended lower on Wednesday, snapping a four-day winning streak, amid violent protests outside the Greek parliament, which revived eurozone anxiety. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dipped 3.41 points to 18,050.17, while the S&P 500 lost 1.55 points to 2,107.40. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen maintained her forecast for a rate hike later this year, citing an improving US economy.

site_title: Greek parliament approves bailout measures as Syriza fragments
summary: The Greek parliament approved a sweeping austerity package worth up to €86 billion, demanded by lenders to keep Greece in the eurozone. The package includes significant pension adjustments, increased taxes, and reforms to the economy and labor system. The approval came after Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras made a last-ditch appeal for support, but dozens of Syriza lawmakers deserted him, including former Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis. The move clears the way for bailout talks and funding, but its long-term success is uncertain, with doubts surrounding the ability of the Greek economy to sustain the burden of the austerity measures.

site_title: Eurogroup to hold conference call on Greece on Thursday
summary: Eurozone finance ministers will hold a conference call on Thursday to discuss Greece's latest developments, following the country's vote on tough reforms. The reforms, demanded by European partners, will be voted on in parliament despite opposition from radical left party Syriza. A deal is expected to be reached, with eurozone governments contributing 40-50 billion euros, the IMF contributing another chunk, and the rest coming from asset sales and financial markets.
