The talks are expected to take much of the summer, with Germany's Bundestag voting on the plan on Friday.

site_title: China Q2 GDP stabilises, but analysts say challenges remain (Amended)
summary: China's GDP growth in the second quarter stabilized at 7% above analysts' predictions, with Beijing's support measures kicking in. The economy expanded 1.7% on a quarterly basis, driven by a stronger services sector and state-led activity. However, challenges remain, including weak fundamentals, a reliance on private investment, and the potential for stock market weakness to undermine investment plans. Analysts expect further interest and RRR cuts from the central bank in the second half to support the economy.

site_title: Customers as gods in Japan keep productivity at lowest in G-7
summary: Japan's service sector, which accounts for 70% of the country's economy, has struggled with low productivity, ranking the nation lowest among G-7 countries for nearly 30 years. Despite efforts to boost productivity through technology, the sector has failed to adopt automation, and companies are hesitant to invest due to costs and cultural factors. To address this, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe aims to double productivity growth in the service sector by 2020, with a focus on introducing technology and reducing labor costs.

site_title: Federal Reserve's likelihood of raising rates is sign of US strength: Williams
summary: Federal Reserve President John Williams stated that the likelihood of raising interest rates this year is a sign of the US economy's strength. He believes the economy has enough strength to survive higher interest rates and is close to achieving its full employment goal. Williams also expects inflation to reach the Fed's 2% goal by the end of next year, leading to interest rate hikes later this year. His assessment is considered optimistic, with Williams saying it's "about as optimistic as you ever will hear a Fed person be."

site_title: More China importers to get subsidised govt loans
summary: China plans to provide subsidized loans to more importers as part of efforts to boost the trade sector, citing anaemic foreign and domestic demand. The move aims to increase imports of advanced technology equipment and components to boost domestic demand. The government also reiterated its currency policy, keeping the yuan stable to minimize foreign exchange risks. To support exporters, more credit guarantees will be given, and local companies will have more opportunities to raise yuan funds abroad. The goal is to shore up China's trade sector and support the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: 'Vulture' versus chaebol in Korea
summary: A merger plan between Cheil Industries and Samsung C&T in South Korea has sparked controversy, with minority shareholders claiming unfair treatment. Elliott Associates, an activist hedge fund, opposes the merger, citing concerns over leadership succession and undervaluation. However, the merger's success has resulted in significant gains for Elliott, with its stake in Samsung C&T increasing by 2.17% and its estimated one-month profit reaching $100 million. Analysts attribute the market's positive reaction to the "premium" attached to Cheil Industries, but Elliott continues to argue that Samsung C&T is undervalued, potentially using holdout tactics to maximize profits.

images.alt_text: Elliott says minority shareholders of Samsung C&T were unfairly treated due to Samsung's "exclusive concerns" with the leadership succession.

site_title: Apple tunes iPod as it pushes into streaming music
summary: Apple released a new iPod touch with improved cameras, graphics, and fitness tracking capabilities, priced at $199. The device runs on iOS and provides access to Apple Music, the App Store, and iOS features. This update comes just weeks after Apple launched its streaming music service. The iPod touch is essentially an iPhone without cellular connections, offering customers a cost-effective alternative.

images.alt_text: Apple's first iPod touch refresh in almost 3 years comes hot on the heels of the launch of the Apple Music streaming service.

site_title: South Korean delegates head for talks on Kaesong wage row
summary: A South Korean government delegation departed for North Korea for talks on a wage dispute at the Kaesong industrial zone. The issue has been ongoing for months, with Pyongyang insisting on a unilateral pay rise for its workers, while Seoul demands a joint decision. The talks aim to resolve the protracted row, which has hindered operations at the jointly operated zone.

images.alt_text: Lee Sang-min (third-right), chief of a South Korean delegation to a joint committee in charge of running the Kaesong Industrial Complex, speaks to reporters before leaving the Inter-Korean Dialogue Office in Seoul, South Korea, July 16, 2015, for the western North Korean border town of Kaesong.

site_title: Supplying a nation's household needs
summary: TOYOGO, a Singaporean company, has grown into a market leader in household and industrial plastic products over 30 years, with a staff strength of 300 and a production capacity of over 3,000 products. Founded by Chua Kee Tee, who sought to rival Japanese quality with local branding, TOYOGO has overcome initial challenges to become a leading plastic manufacturer. The company now distributes products in over 30 countries, focusing on eco-friendly and modern designs, and aims to continue creating useful, durable, and affordable products.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore listed companies repurchased nearly S$43 million worth of shares in the first half of July, a 84% increase from the same period last year. The top 5 companies with the largest share buybacks were Genting Singapore, Pacific Century Regional Developments, Noble Group, Singapore Technologies Engineering, and Straco Corp.

site_title: Spreading the good news of natural therapy
summary: Singaporean business consultant Peter Lim, 72, left his lucrative job to start an organic food company, Nature's Glory, 24 years ago. Lim, who battled health issues as a child, credits organic food and supplements for improving his health and is now a proponent of natural therapies. He has diversified his business into nano-energy boosters, which use technology to boost energy and immune systems. Lim aims to promote a mindset shift towards natural healing, believing it's essential for Singapore's success, and is concerned about the growing rental costs and manpower shortage affecting his business.

site_title: SGX should identify overseas firms and risks of investing in them
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has been criticized for not identifying overseas firms and potential risks of investing in them. Noble Group, a listed company, was found to have no independent directors resident in Singapore, despite being required to have at least two under SGX rule 221. The SGX has since appointed a new independent director, David Yeow, who is resident in Singapore, in response to a query about the lack of compliance. This move aims to address concerns about Noble's corporate governance and adherence to Singapore's Code of Corporate Governance.

site_title: Market closes marginally higher
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 22.36 points to 3,338.86 on Wednesday, driven by gains in three banks and property giant CapitaLand. Despite a subdued session with low volume, 231 stocks rose against 209 falls. Key factors influencing the market include the Greek debt crisis, China's economic outlook, and US interest rates. Analysts predict a trading range for the STI, with some brokers recommending buys on CapitaLand due to its joint venture with the Qatar Investment Authority and potential asset monetization.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Soilbuild Business Space Reit reported Q2 FY2015 results within expectations, with a 0.2% decrease in occupancy rate to 99.8% and rental reversions of 5% and 1.6% for renewal and new leases, respectively. Sembcorp Marine was downgraded to 'Reduce' by CIMB Research due to a $1 billion contract to build a DP3 semi-submersible crane, which could result in higher costs and lower earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) margins.

site_title: Starbucks to enter sub-Saharan Africa in partnership deal
summary: Starbucks has partnered with Taste Holdings Ltd, a Johannesburg-based franchiser, to develop its coffee shops in sub-Saharan Africa. The deal includes the rights to open outlets in South Africa and potentially other African countries for up to 25 years. The partnership aims to capitalize on the growing coffee market in the region, where the number of middle-class households is expected to reach 40 million by 2030. Starbucks sources high-quality coffee from farms in sub-Saharan Africa, and the partnership is seen as a strategic move to expand its presence in the region.

site_title: Everton squeaks past Stoke to reach Barclays final
summary: Everton soccer team defeated Stoke City 5-4 in a penalty shootout after a goalless draw in the Barclays Asia Trophy tournament. The match, played at the National Stadium in Singapore, marked the first day of the tournament featuring English Premier League teams. Everton will play in Saturday's final against either Arsenal or the Singapore Selection. The match was notable for a missed opportunity by Everton's Romelu Lukaku in the final seconds, and Arsenal did not debut their new goalkeeper Petr Cech.

site_title: Annual audit highlights several public sector lapses
summary: Singapore's Auditor-General's Office has completed the annual audit of the public sector, uncovering irregularities and lapses in various ministries and statutory boards. The audit found issues with procurement and tendering, poor management of contracts, and lack of oversight and financial administration. Four areas were identified for improvement, including grant administration, tendering and revenue contract management, contract variations, and related-party transactions. The audit also found instances of funds being used without proper approval and over-disbursements of government grants. The Auditor-General expressed concern over the lack of documentation on significant financial decisions.

site_title: Indonesia uses drones, apps to tackle holiday traffic chaos
summary: Indonesia is using drones and smartphone apps to mitigate holiday traffic chaos during the Eid holiday, when millions of people travel to rural areas. The country's narrow, ageing roads on Java Island become congested, leading to accidents and long journeys. New technologies include drones monitoring traffic, a police app tracking traffic conditions, and specialized apps helping drivers locate mosques, rest stops, and carpooling spots. Despite these innovations, major investment in public transport and infrastructure is still needed to reduce the chaos.

site_title: Steel output in China shrinks in first half as demand stumbles
summary: China's steel production declined 1.3% to 410 million tonnes in the first half of 2015, compared to the same period in 2014. This marks a second consecutive year of decline, with June's output falling 0.8% from last year. The drop is attributed to dwindling demand, with China's steel output expected to continue shrinking in the coming years.

site_title: Producer prices rise for second straight month in June
summary: US producer prices rose 0.4% in June, the second straight month, driven by a 0.7% increase in goods prices. The 12-month decrease in the producer price index (PPI) narrowed to 0.7% from 1.1% in May. Factory production, however, remained unchanged in June, marking the second consecutive month of no growth. The increase in producer prices is attributed to rising petrol and food costs, which may filter through to the June consumer price index.

site_title: Daewoo Shipbuilding heading for lowest close in almost 7 yrs
summary: Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering Co, South Korea's second-largest shipbuilder, is on track to become the first major company to plummet 30% in almost seven years amid concerns of reporting losses and restructuring debt. The company's shares slumped 30% to 8,750 won, its lowest intraday price since October 2008, following the doubling of daily stock fluctuations limits. Daewoo Ship may report an operating loss of up to three trillion won in the second quarter, according to reports.

site_title: Shortage of experienced workers may have prolonged NYSE outage
summary: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) experienced a prolonged outage last week, lasting over three hours, amid concerns about the lack of experienced workers. ICE, the parent company, has cut hundreds of workers since its acquisition in 2012, including most of the top ranks. The cuts have left the exchange with a reduced workforce, making it difficult to manage a crisis. Critics argue that the outage was an indictment of the exchange's technical abilities and the loss of senior workers who served as go-betweens with traders.

site_title: Mexico conducts landmark oil auction
summary: Mexico holds its first oil auction since nearly 80 years, offering 14 blocks in the Gulf of Mexico worth an estimated US$17 billion. The auction, part of President Enrique Pena Nieto's energy reform, allows foreign investors to bid on the blocks. Seven consortiums and 18 individual companies, including US giants ExxonMobil and Chevron, are participating. The government predicts between a third and half of the blocks will be awarded, aiming to avoid overselling the nation's oil resources. The auction comes amid a global oil price slump and potential impact from Iran's nuclear deal on oil exports.

site_title: Religare trust sells S$60m bonds; small deals dominate July's issues
summary: Religare Trust sold SGD 60m bonds, marking another small deal in July's issues as investors' appetite for local debt from small companies remains strong despite the Singapore dollar's decline following weak Q2 growth numbers. Demand for these sales is measured, and investors holding SGD assets minimize the impact of currency weakness. However, the secondary market for under SGD 100m bond issues is likely illiquid.

images.alt_text: Fortis Healthcare Bannerghatta is one of two hospitals operated and managed by Religare Health Trust.

site_title: China New Town upbeat on turnaround
summary: China New Town Development (CNTD), a Singapore-listed company backed by China's largest policy bank, China Development Bank (CDB), is optimistic about a turnaround after two years of losses. The company plans to launch up to five new town development projects in China over the next 12 months, fueled by a new business model that guarantees a steady income stream. CNTD has secured funding through a 1.3 billion yuan bond and a 10 billion yuan credit line, and is exploring public-private partnership projects, including a flood control project and an industrial park project.

site_title: Weak residential leasing persists in Singapore
summary: Singapore's residential leasing market remained weak in June, with condo rents down 0.5% and HDB rents up 0.1%. This trend is attributed to a large supply of condo units competing for a limited pool of tenants. Consultants predict this trend will continue, with a record number of condo projects set to be completed. Rents have fallen 6.5% year-over-year, while rental volume rose 15.4% compared to June 2014. Tenants are moving for better-quality or lower rents, and landlords are struggling to keep them.

site_title: ISDN gets approval for 20MW hydropower plant in Indonesia
summary: ISDN Holdings has received approval from the Indonesian government to develop a 20-megawatt hydropower plant in Central Sulawesi. The project, estimated to cost US$40 million, will be funded by debt and equity financing and is expected to generate US$10 million in annual revenue. The plant, which will take 40 months to complete, will provide electricity to the Sigi District, supporting local industries and residents. ISDN will manage the project, with PT Laa Energy owning 90% of the plant.

site_title: Indonesia's trade surplus narrows to US$477m in June
summary: Indonesia's trade surplus narrowed to US$477 million in June, with imports falling 17.42% and exports slowing. This marks the third consecutive monthly trade surplus since December 2014, indicating concerns over South-east Asia's largest economy's growth. Weaker imports and exports underscore the weakening economic conditions in the region.

site_title: Tsinghua's expected bid for Micron faces many hurdles
summary: A Chinese state-backed company, Tsinghua Unigroup Ltd, plans to buy US chipmaker Micron Technology for $23 billion. The deal faces numerous hurdles, including concerns about the price, potential impact on the Defense Department, and a close review by the National Security Agency. Analysts argue the proposed price is too low, while critics on Capitol Hill worry about the deal's implications. Any deal would likely face a thorough vetting process to address national security concerns.

site_title: Flash blocked on Firefox over security issues
summary: Mozilla has blocked Flash on its Firefox browser due to security issues, citing that the plug-in is vulnerable and compromises Firefox security. A message now appears on Firefox users, stating that Mozilla reserves the right to block software that "seriously compromises Firefox security". This move may mark the writing on the wall for Flash, potentially signaling its decline.

site_title: HK regulator orders continued suspension of Hanergy shares
summary: Hong Kong's Securities & Futures Commission has ordered the continued suspension of Hanergy Thin Film Power Group Ltd shares, citing misleading information in documents and statements. The suspension, requested by the company after a 47% price plunge, marks a rare step by regulators. If found guilty, Hanergy chairman Li Hejun could face a possible two-year prison sentence and the company could be fined up to HK$1 million. This is the first step in a potential criminal prosecution, with the regulator's investigation into Hanergy's alleged misleading statements ongoing.

site_title: FAA imposes safety limits on SkyWest after April incident
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has imposed safety limits on SkyWest Inc, a regional airline, after one of its planes temporarily plummeted out of control in April. The airline's regional jets can now fly no higher than 35,000 feet and must maintain minimum speeds. The FAA action comes after an incident in April where the plane briefly lost altitude control. The restrictions are intended to ensure the safety of passengers and crew.

site_title: Wage growth in Britain accelerates even as jobless rate rises
summary: Britain's wage growth accelerated to a 3.2% annual increase in the three months ending May, the fastest pace in over five years, while the jobless rate rose to 5.6%, its first increase since 2013. The data, released by the Office for National Statistics, has sparked concerns about the timing of a potential interest rate hike by the Bank of England. Policymakers, including Governor Mark Carney, say the labor market is showing signs of price pressures, but a gradual rate increase is expected to be necessary to manage inflation.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit's Q2 results exceed forecasts
summary: Keppel DC Reit, a Singapore-based data centre landlord, exceeded its Q2 forecasts with higher income, driven by better variable rents from its Singapore data centres. The Reit reported a 1.9% increase in distributable income and 3.4% higher net property income. It also announced plans to acquire more assets in Asia-Pacific and Europe, with its first acquisition expected to be completed in Q3. The Reit's units closed flat at S$1.06 on Wednesday.

site_title: People power
summary: Singapore's success is attributed to its hardworking, adaptable, and resilient population, despite lacking natural resources. The country has been ranked as the world's best workers since 1980 by a risk consultancy agency, and education is a top priority. The government, under Lee Kuan Yew, has invested heavily in developing human capital, contributing to Singapore's domestic and international success.

site_title: Iran's no Qatar even with its bigger gas reserves
summary: Iran, despite holding 18% of the world's gas reserves, will struggle to follow Qatar's path due to its high domestic gas demand. The country's population of 78 million consumes most of its production, and its oil industry injects gas into fields to boost productivity. Iran's gas exports account for less than 1% of trade, and the development of its South Pars field will likely take longer than expected. To keep up with demand, production must rise at a faster rate, but the revenue from exporting gas is likely to be lower than injecting fuel to maintain oil fields.

site_title: Australia consumer confidence hit by global gloom: poll
summary: Australia's consumer confidence index fell 3.2% in July, its second consecutive decline, amid global gloom over events in China and Greece. The survey of 1,200 people found households spooked by media coverage of economic downturns. The drop in confidence follows a similar decline in June and highlights the volatile mood of Australian consumers. The Melbourne Institute and Westpac Bank conducted the survey.

site_title: Web giants challenge menu aggregator Just Eat's success
summary: Just Eat plc, a UK-based food-delivery company, is facing challenges from established web giants seeking a share of the market. The company's stock has risen 60% since its debut 15 months ago, valuing it at £2.8 billion. Just Eat's multiple of 72 times projected profit is higher than rival GrubHub Inc's 56 times. This increased valuation raises concerns about the company's growth potential and ability to compete with larger players in the market.

site_title: 2014 tax deductible donations up 13% at S$1.1b
summary: Tax deductible donations to Singapore Institutions of a Public Character (IPC) rose 13% to S$1.1 billion in 2014, from S$970 million in 2013, with a matching programme and Cultural Matching Fund contributing to the increase. The government offers a 250% tax relief, and this year's tax relief is 300% to encourage giving. New measures to enhance transparency and accountability have been introduced, including the Charity Transparency Framework and Charity Transparency Awards.

site_title: Recovery in China's home sales yet to revive investment in sector
summary: China's home sales have shown a recovery, with property sales jumping 10% by value in the first six months, but this has not translated into a revival for real estate investment. Investment in property development slowed to 4.6% in the same period, about a third of the pace last year. Demand for construction workers has also slumped, and developers are not yet accelerating projects, indicating that the sector remains sluggish. A property recovery is seen as crucial for policy easing in the second half, with the National Bureau of Statistics forecasting a stabilisation of the sector through accelerated destocking of housing.

site_title: EMA completes joint effort with Cambodia to raise electrical wiring standards
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) of Singapore has completed a 16-month joint initiative with Cambodia to improve electrical wiring practices in the country. Technical standards for electrical wiring and safety standards for buildings and households were developed, with the standards set to become the first technical document for managing electrical requirements. The training of 55 senior energy officials was also completed, with plans for further human capacity building in the energy sector. The initiative was funded by the Temasek Foundation and aims to enhance Cambodia's electricity and energy industry, following frequent fires in Phnom Penh due to unlicensed electrical work.

site_title: Netherlands remembers MH17 victims
summary: The Netherlands holds a private ceremony to remember the 2,000 grieving relatives of MH17 victims, a year after the Malaysia Airlines flight was shot down over eastern Ukraine, killing all 298 on board. The focus shifts to tracking down the perpetrators and putting them on trial, with the Netherlands leading the retrieval of victims' remains and investigating the cause of the crash. A joint investigation team is underway, and a UN-backed tribunal is proposed, but Russia opposes the idea. Relatives seek closure and justice, with some families still waiting for the remains of their loved ones to be found.

site_title: When it comes to the China bourse, it's still better to tread with caution
summary: China's central government intervened to stem a stock market rout, which wiped out over US$3 trillion in value, but the move has drawn mostly negative reactions from observers. The domestic equity market has plummeted by over 30% since its peak in June due to perceived overvaluation and easy margin financing. The government's intervention raises questions about the potential economic fallout, credibility, and the pace of internationalization of the stock market. The move has sparked concerns about the government's control over the economy and its ability to manage risks.

site_title: New home sales down 42% in June; analysts paring 2015 forecasts
summary: New home sales in Singapore plummeted 42% in June to 375 units, a significant drop from May and a 21% decline from the same period last year. Analysts now expect a lower sales range for private homes this year, with forecasts ranging from 6,000 to 7,500 units. The slowdown is attributed to the ongoing property cooling measures and weak economic growth, with developers focusing on clearing existing inventory rather than launching new projects. The EC market also saw a decline in sales, with 446 units sold in Q2, taking the preliminary first-half tally to 772.

site_title: China Sky replacing auditor; cites difficult working relationship
summary: China Sky Chemical Fibre is replacing its auditor, Baker Tilly TFW LLP, due to a difficult working relationship and proposed fee increase. The company has completed 90% of outstanding accounting matters and will review and verify accounts receivables and payables. China Sky's board has identified RT LLP as the new auditors and aims to complete the audit for 2014 financial statements by August 31, 2015. The company's share trading suspension, which began in 2011, will be lifted once the outstanding matters are resolved.

site_title: 18,500 SIA staff to receive S$500 SG50 hongbao
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is giving a one-off payment of S$500 to 18,500 employees below the rank of senior vice-president to celebrate Singapore's Golden Jubilee year. This payment, due in August, is part of a larger trend of local firms offering similar incentives to celebrate SG50. Other companies, such as DBS Bank, SMRT, and NTUC FairPrice, have also announced similar payments or vouchers. SIA has also planned various initiatives, including opening its training centre to the public and decorating two of its Airbus A380s with a Singapore flag-themed design.

site_title: Treating back and neck pain
summary: In Singapore, the number of office jobs and prolonged sitting have led to a rise in back and neck pain cases, with the Neuro Spine and Pain Center at Mount Elizabeth Hospital seeing an increase in patients. The center's medical director, Prem Pillay, attributes the trend to poor posture, frequent business travel, and computer use. Advanced treatments, including spine injections and precision radiosurgery, are available to provide relief and help patients recover quickly. The center has contributed to Singapore's reputation as a world-class medical destination and works with other disciplines to educate patients on prevention and management of backache and neck pain.

site_title: A 'Singapore' within Singapore
summary: T32 Dental Centre, a Singapore-based dental group, aims to differentiate itself in the competitive market by providing top-notch dental care and services. Founded by Wong Keng Mun, the group has achieved success with its T32 Junior programme, which aims to familiarize children with dental clinics. T32 is also investing in cutting-edge technology, including 3D printing and CAD-CAM technology, to reduce treatment time. Despite facing challenges such as a shortage of manpower and increasing costs, Wong remains optimistic about the city-state's future, aiming to become a regional medical hub and "a small Singapore within Singapore".

site_title: Poor Ramadan sales distress M'sian retailers
summary: Malaysian retailers are experiencing a 20% decline in Ramadan sales, the worst in years, due to cautious consumers and economic concerns. The decline is attributed to recent tax and subsidy decisions, which have worsened consumer sentiment to its lowest in six years. Private consumption accounts for over half of Malaysia's GDP, and a slowdown in consumption threatens the government's growth target of 4.5-5.5% for this year. The decline in Ramadan sales adds to the economic challenges faced by Prime Minister Najib Razak's government, which is already battling weak exports.

site_title: Finding a new use for century-old Bronx courthouse
summary: The Bronx Borough Courthouse, a century-old landmark, has opened its doors to the public for the first time in nearly four decades, hosting a free art exhibition organized by non-profit organization No Longer Empty. The show, which ran through Sunday, featured 26 artists using the building as their canvas, and sparked an outpouring of responses on a wooden table asking what visitors wanted the building to become. The building, which was once the center of civic life in the South Bronx, will undergo a $10 million renovation and is expected to reopen permanently by 2017.

site_title: Keeping a nation fit
summary: AIBI, a Singapore-based fitness equipment retailer, has been a leading brand in the country's consumer fitness industry for 30 years. Founded by Alice Teo in 1985, the company has expanded to over 120 outlets and agents in Singapore, Indonesia, Taiwan, China, Myanmar, and India, with a market share of over 75%. AIBI sources high-quality products globally and invests heavily in after-sales service, which has contributed to its success. The company continues to innovate with new products, including the AIBI EZ Tone Desk, and is aggressively expanding into the commercial gym market.

site_title: Chinese doubling down on Aussie property
summary: Chinese investors are increasing their presence in Australia's property market, with a bulk of recent deals sealed after the Shanghai Composite Index started tumbling in June. Chinese developers snapped up 15 sites in and around Melbourne, with the bulk of the deals occurring after the index began to fall. This influx of Chinese cash risks inflating Sydney and Melbourne house prices, which could make it harder for the central bank to cut interest rates to stimulate a slowing economy.

site_title: Iran nuclear accord is that big a deal
summary: Iran and the P5+1 have reached a final, comprehensive deal to curb Tehran's nuclear program, easing international sanctions. The 18-month talks process was marked by a significant investment of effort by US Secretary of State John Kerry. The deal is seen as a major foreign policy victory for President Barack Obama, who believes it will "take a big piece of business off the table" and change the relationship between Iran and the world. The agreement will grant Iran phased relief from EU, US, and UN sanctions, potentially revitalizing its economy and bolstering reformists ahead of next year's Iranian parliamentary elections.

images.alt_text: For the Iranians, the deal is a key stepping stone towards revitalising Iran's economy which has been hit hard by years of international sanctions.

site_title: QT Vascular gets US nod on four key patents
summary: QT Vascular, a Singapore-based medical supplies group, has received US Patent and Trademark Office allowances for four key patents related to its specialty balloons for vascular disease treatment. The patents cover the company's flagship platform, Chocolate, and its Glider family of products. The company's CEO, Eitan Konstantino, described the achievement as "exceptional" and emphasized the potential benefits of its next-generation product, Chocolate Touch, which could improve treatment outcomes and reduce trauma. The company is optimistic about its chances of approval for Chocolate Touch in the US market.

site_title: French wine barrels fetch top dollar
summary: French wine barrels, crafted from high-quality oak, are in high demand abroad, with exports making up 70% of the market. Only 2-4% of the world's most expensive wines ferment in these prized oak containers. The barrel-making process can take several years and involves selecting the perfect wood, with sessile oak being a highly sought-after option. The industry is still growing, with the market reaching maturity, according to the French Federation of Coopers.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust completes acquisition in Vietnam
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) has completed the acquisition of Mapletree Logistics Park Bac Ninh Phase 1 in Vietnam for 339.4 billion Vietnamese dong (S$21 million). The acquisition, announced in May, was finalized on July 15, 2015. As an interested party transaction, the 3.4 billion-dong acquisition fee will be paid in MLT units to MLTM.

site_title: Will Millennials get tired of sharing?
summary: Millennials, the largest generation in the US workforce, are growing up financially and moving into their own homes, contrary to previous assumptions that they would prefer urban apartments. According to Zillow's chief economist, the delay in homebuying is due to delayed marriage and childbearing, not a lack of interest in homeownership. A recent survey found that 70% of Millennials prefer to own a home due to protection from rent increases, not a desire to avoid ownership. This shift could be positive for the US economy as Millennials' increasing financial stability leads to more spending.

site_title: Doing good and doing well
summary: B9 Dental Centre, a two-year-old clinic in Singapore, has made a significant impact by providing high-quality dental care at fair and transparent prices. The clinic offers free treatment to the elderly and low-income families, and absorbs all GST charges. Its patients-first approach includes investing in infection-free environments, technology, and smart clinic designs. With revenue growth of 30% year-on-year, B9 has proven that businesses can do good and still do well. CEO Raymond Lim's commitment to treating patients with kindness and fairness has earned the clinic a loyal following, and plans for expansion into Malaysia and Indonesia are underway.

site_title: Apple Pay launches in Britain as hold-out Barclays signs up
summary: Apple Pay has launched in Britain, with 250,000 outlets offering the mobile payment service, surpassing the US debut. The service allows customers to make tap-and-go payments using their iPhone, iPad, or Apple Watch, with 70% of credit and debit cards accepting it. Barclays, the last hold-out, has signed up, and other major banks, including HSBC, will offer Apple Pay later this month and in the autumn. The service offers convenience and security, with no credit card information stored within and multiple levels of user identification.

site_title: Asia ready to buy more Iranian oil when sanctions lifted
summary: Asian refiners are poised to buy more Iranian oil once sanctions are lifted, with top buyers China, India, Japan, and South Korea expected to increase imports. The deal, signed on Tuesday, paves the way for the lifting of sanctions in exchange for curbs on Iran's nuclear program. Asian refiners are eager to take advantage of lower prices and competitive pricing by Iran, but will need to wait for insurance and shipping arrangements to be finalized. Exports are expected to increase in early 2016, but will face competition from cheaper and better grades available in the oversupplied market.

site_title: Taking a journey into the unknown with Iran
summary: US President Barack Obama signed a historic nuclear deal with Iran, ending 17 days of negotiations and 12 years of deadlock. The deal, reached with the US, UK, France, China, Russia, and Germany, requires Iran to curb its nuclear program in exchange for sanctions relief. The agreement aims to create conditions for Iran to become a responsible regional power, potentially easing tensions with the US and other Middle Eastern countries. Critics warn that the deal lacks sufficient safeguards against Iranian cheating, while proponents see it as a cost-effective way to handle the nuclear program without military confrontation.

site_title: Yellen: Economy on track for hike in interest rates this year
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that the economy is on track to raise interest rates this year due to steady improvements in labor markets, despite turmoil abroad. Labour markets are not yet consistent with maximum employment, and Greece and China face challenges. Yellen defended the Fed's transparency and accountability, despite Republican-led criticism. The Fed's policy-setting committee will likely raise rates after six years at a near-zero level, which may impact the value of the US dollar and exports.

site_title: Going casual for launch of New York Men's Fashion Week
summary: New York Fashion Week: Men's officially launched on Monday night with a casual, low-key event at Amazon Imaging Studio in Brooklyn. Fashion designers Dao-Yi Chow and Maxwell Osborne of Public School showcased their designs, along with celebrities like Joe Jonas. Victor Cruz, a Giants player, wore a stylish outfit he found in his closet, sparking a conversation about the growing interest in fashion among men, including those in rural areas. Designer Billy Reid believes younger men are driving this trend and notes that even in rural parts of the world, fashion knowledge is increasing.

images.alt_text: Football player Victor Cruz had an "aha" moment before he attended the opening event for the NY Fashion Week.

site_title: Google unveils buy button on ads in mobile-commerce push
summary: Google unveils "Purchases on Google," a feature allowing consumers to buy products by clicking on select search ads on mobile devices. The service, currently available with a "limited number of retailers," will also alert users to in-store sales and loyalty programs, and simplify ad usage to drive consumers to shopping apps.

site_title: China IPO freeze paves way for more M&As
summary: China's freeze on new IPOs is creating opportunities for private equity firms, hedge funds, and sovereign wealth funds to fill funding gaps in private companies. This move follows a significant decline in share prices that wiped out over $3 trillion in market value. The halt in new listings may lead to increased merger and acquisition (M&A) activity as companies seek alternative financing options.

site_title: Tokyo trims growth outlook for fiscal 2015
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) revised its forecast for Japan's economic growth for fiscal 2015, trimming the growth outlook to 1.7% due to global developments such as the US economy's temporary slowdown and the ongoing slowdown in China. The BOJ also lowered its forecast for consumer price inflation to 1.9%, down from 2%. These revisions reflect the bank's response to global uncertainties, including the Greek debt crisis.

images.alt_text: The downward revision of the country's economic numbers is being made in the light of the temporary slowing of the US economy, China's ongoing slowdown and uncertainties caused by the Greek debt crisis.

site_title: India government spending drives borrowing costs down
summary: India's government has loosened spending, swelling cash at banks and driving down short-term borrowing costs to a five-year low. One-year commercial-paper rates fell to 8.54% and overnight interbank rates averaged the lowest in four years. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) now has an average daily lending of 18 billion rupees, with lenders parking money with the central bank. This move is seen as a step to kick-start the investment cycle and boost economic expansion, driven by increased tax revenue and lower oil prices.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust mulls disposal or redevelopment of Funan mall
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust is considering the disposal or redevelopment of its Funan DigitaLife Mall in Singapore, in line with its strategy to continually evaluate its portfolio and maximize asset value. The decision has no certainty and no agreement has been entered into. This move comes as the company evaluates its options to enhance the value of its assets, including Plaza Singapura and Raffles City malls.

site_title: Equipping a nation's development
summary: Singapore-based equipment and machinery supplier JP Nelson is set to play a crucial role in the country's development, particularly in its mega infrastructure projects. The company has supplied construction equipment to Changi Airport's Terminal 5, Resorts World Sentosa, and the Marina Coastal Expressway, among others. With a focus on customization and innovation, JP Nelson aims to become a globally trusted partner in equipment rental services, with plans to expand its influence in the Asean region and Asia. The company's chairman, Nelson Lim, hopes to grow the nation's infrastructure, citing ongoing projects such as the new runway and Terminal 4 at Changi Airport and the Thomson Line.

site_title: Choo Chiang Holdings launches Catalist IPO (Amended)
summary: Choo Chiang Holdings Ltd, a Singapore-based electrical products distributor, is launching a Catalist IPO offering 33.28 million shares at S$0.35 apiece. The company, led by executive chairman and CEO Thomas Lim, aims to raise S$72.8 million in its IPO, which opens on July 15 and closes on July 27. Choo Chiang has 13 investment properties and recorded revenues of S$70.95 million in FY2012, FY2013, and FY2014. The company plans to distribute dividends of at least 30% of its net profits to shareholders.

site_title: Human hand may be more primitive than chimpanzee's: study
summary: Scientists in the US and Spain claim the human hand is more primitive than previously thought, contrary to the widely-held assumption that it evolved from a chimpanzee-like ancestor. A study analyzing hand-length proportions of humans and apes found that the human "thumb-to-digits ratio" required little change since the last common ancestor. This suggests that human hands evolved to be more similar to those of our ancestors, and that neurological adaptations, not manual ones, drove the emergence of stone tool culture around 3.3 million years ago.

site_title: US: Stocks little changed as Yellen sees rate rise this year
summary: US stocks remained little changed as Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen signaled a rate hike this year, citing a strengthening US economy and waning risks from Greece and China. The S&P 500 Index slipped 0.1% to 2,107.72, despite the benchmark posting its longest winning streak since January. Analysts expect earnings to be key in the market's decision-making, particularly for a market richly valued.

images.alt_text: US stocks were little changed as Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen signalled the central bank remains on track to raise interest rates this year.

site_title: Honda to return US$24m to minority borrowers
summary: Honda's car-financing arm, American Honda Finance Corp, agreed to return $24 million to minority borrowers to settle a Justice Department complaint that it overcharged them. The company had authorized dealers to mark up interest rates by 2.25 percentage points, but will cap markups at 1.25 points for loans of five years or less. The settlement aims to curb discriminatory lending, but car industry advocates worry it may hurt consumers. The Justice Department found minority borrowers paid between $150 and $250 more than white borrowers, with a 2013 investigation revealing discriminatory lending practices.

images.alt_text: Honda pledged to restructure its car-financing programme as part of the settlement, the company and the Justice Department said.

site_title: Can Chinese investors save American golf?
summary: Chinese investors Yiqian Funding paid cash for 22 courses in the Grand Strand, a 60-mile stretch of coastal golf courses in South Carolina, saving American golf from a debt trap. The move aims to revitalize the struggling golf industry, which has seen course values cut in half due to the boom and bust. With Yiqian Funding's involvement, the future of American golf may be secured, providing a new era of investment and growth for the sport.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty, with investors weighing tariffs, sanctions, and market outlook. In other news, European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector woes, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received a 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for the second half of the year. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Pound up, krona down as central banks take spotlight
summary: Central banks' divergent policy outlook drove currency market fluctuations, with sterling rising to its highest this month against the dollar, euro, and yen, and the Swedish krona dipping as the Riksbank prepared to pump more cash into the economy. The Bank of Japan trimmed its growth forecasts, while traders await US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's testimony, which may impact interest rate policy. Analysts expect a fading risk of an immediate Greek exit from the eurozone to shift focus to central bank expectations, potentially leading to interest rate hikes and currency market volatility.

site_title: May retail sales speed ahead on roaring car sales
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 6.1% in May, driven by a 46.6% surge in motor vehicle sales, according to the Department of Statistics. Excluding car sales, retail sales increased by 0.9%. The May performance is expected not to be repeated, with analysts attributing the boost to a one-time increase in car sales. The modest increase in retail sales suggests a stable economic outlook for Singapore.

site_title: IMF demands debt sustainability for Greek bailout
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has expressed its demand for debt sustainability in Greece's bailout, stating that it will only remain involved if eurozone leaders agree on a plan that makes the country's debt manageable for decades to come. The IMF proposed that creditors consider letting Greece write off part of its huge debt or make no payments on its eurozone debt for 30 years. However, eurozone leaders have been reluctant to provide additional debt relief, and a new bailout package is uncertain, with Greece facing a significant financial shortfall and struggling to pay its debts.

site_title: The economic miracle
summary: The article discusses various economic and business news from around the world. Key points include the US seeing a drop in weekly jobless claims, China unveiling new employment aid measures, and Chinese property shares surging on unverified reports of a sector revival. Reliance Jio, backed by Ambani, has also delayed its India IPO beyond this year. Meanwhile, Asean has agreed that Myanmar's election is not a priority, and China is urging South-east Asian countries to back openness amid US tariffs. These developments highlight ongoing economic tensions and efforts to stimulate growth.

site_title: El Nino tightens grip in Asia
summary: El Nino is tightening its grip in Asia, with drought and typhoons affecting crops such as Thailand's main rice harvest, Indian soya beans, and Australian wheat. Thailand's rice output may slump 14% to its lowest in nine years, while India's monsoon is heading for its first back-to-back shortfall in three decades. The global economy is also at risk due to the inflation-boosting effect of El Nino, with food costs potentially spiking. The weather pattern is expected to last until 2016 and may impact global rice output, with the UN predicting less than previously forecast.

site_title: New York state factory activity recovers in July: NY Fed
summary: Manufacturing activity in New York state improved in July, with the Empire State general business conditions index rising to 3.86 from -1.98 in June, its lowest level since January 2013. This modest pickup in business outlook rebounded from a two-plus year low. A reading above zero indicates expansion, exceeding economists' expectations of a 3.0 reading. The improvement suggests a recovery in factory activity in the state.

site_title: Sembmarine secures US$1b vessel order
summary: Sembcorp Marine secured a US$1 billion order from Heerema Offshore Services to build the world's largest semi-submersible crane vessel. The vessel, scheduled for delivery in Q4 2018, will be used for installation and decommissioning of major offshore facilities worldwide. The contract value is lower than estimated by Nomura analysts, and the order will give Sembmarine a significant boost to its net order book. The win marks one of the group's largest contracts this year, despite a dearth of rig orders for both Sembmarine and Keppel Corp.

site_title: Bank of America profit more than doubles on lower legal costs
summary: Bank of America's quarterly profit more than doubled to $4.99 billion, or 45 US cents per share, due to lower legal costs. The year-earlier quarter was impacted by $4 billion in legal expenses related to mortgage disputes from the financial crisis. This marked a significant improvement from the previous period.

site_title: Yellen sticks to 2015 timeline for first US rate hike
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen reaffirmed her forecast for the first US interest rate hike in 2015, citing a still-strong labor market despite a 5.3% unemployment rate. Yellen warned that economic risks persist due to Greece and China's economic uncertainty. Despite this, she expects the economy to improve in the coming months, potentially supporting a rate hike. The Fed has kept interest rates at zero since 2008, and a rate increase is expected later this year or possibly in December.

site_title: Singapore shares close marginally up despite STI's 22-point gain
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 22.36 points to 3,338.86, driven by a handful of counter activity, despite a subdued trading session. Low-priced stocks accounted for 65% of overall dollar value traded, with Keppel Corp being a notable exception, finishing S$0.04 lower after a 20% share price rebound. The STI's performance was attributed to a trading range, with most counters not following the index up. The market awaits Keppel Corp's earnings report on July 23.

site_title: JEP Holdings to acquire supplier JEP Industrades
summary: JEP Holdings has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to acquire supplier JEP Industrades (JEPI) for 120 million shares. The acquisition aims to diversify earnings and cut costs, with JEPI's subsequent net profit to be paid back to its original shareholders up to S$4 million over FY2016-2018. The deal will allow JEP Holdings to reduce costs in order fulfillment and eliminate leasing costs for JEPI's facilities, strengthening its position in the competitive global market.

site_title: Religare Health Trust sells bonds, in yet another small-cap issue
summary: Religare Health Trust sold SGD 60 million three-year bonds at 4.5% in the latest small-cap issue. The sale follows other recent issues, totaling SGD 340 million this month, despite the Singapore dollar's weakness due to weak Q2 growth numbers. Investors are seeking higher-yielding assets, and demand for these sales is measured, with orders exceeding SGD 70 million. The secondary market for small issues is considered illiquid, making it difficult for investors to sell these bonds.

site_title: Greek civil servants, pharmacists strike against bailout reforms
summary: Greek civil servants and pharmacists have gone on strike in protest against a new bailout deal that imposes austerity measures, including tax hikes and pension reforms. The strike follows an opinion poll showing over 70% of people oppose the deal. The deal is seen as too harsh for a country struggling with high unemployment and economic shrinkage. Lawmakers are set to vote on the measures, which could unlock international aid for Greece. Protests have been limited, with only a few thousand people participating in early rallies, and unions and lawmakers within Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' party are also opposed to the deal.

site_title: Wholesale prices in US increased in June as fuel climbed
summary: US wholesale prices rose 0.4% in June, exceeding forecasts, driven by a 2.4% increase in energy costs and a 0.6% rise in food prices. Fuel prices contributed to the increase, with gasoline costs rising 2.4% last month. The data supports the case for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates this year, as Chair Janet Yellen has indicated could be appropriate. Projections suggest inflation will climb, making it easier for the Fed to communicate the need for rate hikes.

site_title: US factory output flat in June
summary: US factory output remained unchanged in June, marking the second consecutive month of no growth, contradicting economists' expectations of a 0.2% increase. The auto sector saw a 3.7% decline, while the overall industrial output rose 0.3% after a 0.2% decline in May. Mining output jumped 1.0% and utilities production gained 1.5%, leading to an increase in industrial capacity utilization to 78.4%. This reading may bolster concerns the economy lost steam towards the end of the second quarter.

site_title: Oil falls on prospect of higher Iranian exports
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday as investors considered the potential impact of increased Iranian fuel exports, which could lead to a 500,000-600,000 barrel per day increase in supply. A landmark nuclear deal between Iran and six world powers is expected to lift sanctions limiting oil sales in early 2016. Goldman Sachs analysts view this as a growing downside risk to their oil price forecast, citing a potential increase of 200,000-400,000 barrels per day in 2016. As a result, Brent crude fell 50 cents to $58.01 a barrel, while US crude fell 35 cents to $52.69.

site_title: Hong Kong regulator orders suspension of all Hanergy trading
summary: Hong Kong's Securities & Futures Commission has ordered the suspension of all Hanergy Thin Film Power Group Ltd trading, citing misleading information in documents and statements. The regulator's rare move comes after Hanergy halted trading in May due to a significant share price drop. The suspension raises the prospect that trading will remain suspended indefinitely, with FTSE dropping Hanergy from its indexes. Eric Seto, a partner at Morley, Chow, Seto Solicitors, believes this is the first step in a potential criminal prosecution.

site_title: China's Huawei gets green light to make handsets in India for booming market
summary: Huawei Technologies Co has received a manufacturing license from India's Ministry of Home Affairs, allowing it to produce handsets in the country. This marks a significant boost to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's 'Make in India' campaign and comes after 19 months of application. Huawei aims to become a top-three brand in India within three years, citing the country's growing market of 975 million mobile phone subscriptions. The move is seen as a key step for Chinese firms to offer top-end features at lower costs to India's price-sensitive consumers.

site_title: As tech firms track consumers' locations, advertisers swoop in for the sale
summary: Tech firms Facebook and Google are using advanced mapping technology to track consumers' locations, making it easier for advertisers to target shoppers by location. This has led to a significant increase in mobile ad spending, with major retailers investing up to 40% of their budgets on mobile ads. However, privacy advocates raise concerns about the intrusive nature of location tracking and the lack of regulation. Despite these concerns, Facebook and Google report early signs of success, with mobile ad revenue expected to reach $28.7 billion this year.

site_title: SIA, Tigerair saw weaker passenger revenue in June
summary: Singapore Airlines reported weaker passenger revenue in June, with 1.58 million passengers carried, a 0.9% decline year-over-year, and a load factor of 79.9%, down from 81.5% in the same period last year.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB says welcomes Tenaga interest in its power assets
summary: Malaysia's state fund 1MDB has welcomed Tenaga Nasional's interest in its power assets, including five domestic and eight international assets. The firm, Malaysia's national power company, submitted an indicative non-binding proposal to acquire the assets. 1MDB, which has faced criticism for its debt and investment strategy, had previously scrapped plans for a $3 billion IPO of its power unit. The move comes as the firm seeks to offload assets amid financial struggles.

site_title: Lower Asian prices boosts diesel, jet fuel flow to Europe
summary: Lower Asian prices for diesel and jet fuel are boosting flows to Europe as traders seek to get rid of high inventory. At least four vessels have been provisionally booked to ship diesel or jet fuel from South Korea or Singapore to Europe in July. The arbitrage between Asian and European cargoes has widened to more than minus $30 a tonne, driven by the start of monsoon season and changes in sulphur specifications. However, expensive freight rates are limiting some shipments, and distillates stocks in Europe are also building, making it uncertain how long the arbitrage will remain open.

site_title: German economy benefiting from weaker euro, IMF says
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) stated that Germany's economy is benefiting from a weaker euro and lower energy prices, allowing Berlin to bolster medium-term growth and reduce external imbalances. German exports rose at their fastest pace this year in May, reaching a record high of 22.8 billion euros. The IMF confirmed its growth forecast for Germany at 1.6% this year and 1.7% next year, slightly less than the government's forecast. The IMF also warned of potential financial vulnerabilities in the housing market and life insurance sector due to low interest rates.

site_title: SIA to give one-off, S$500 payment to employees for SG50
summary: Singapore Airlines is giving a one-off payment of S$500 to all its Singapore-based employees, below the rank of senior vice-president, to celebrate Singapore's Golden Jubilee year. The company expressed its gratitude to its staff and unions for their support over the years. The payment will be disbursed in August. This gesture aims to thank employees for their contributions to the airline's success.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines is giving a special one-off payment of S$500 to all its Singapore-based employees in celebration of Singapore's Golden Jubilee year.

site_title: Malaysian minister claims seen video confession of person involved in plot to topple PM Najib
summary: Malaysian Minister Datuk Abdul Rahman Dahlan claims to have seen a video confession from an individual involved in falsifying information about 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB). The individual, who made a police report, allegedly implicated someone in the plot to topple Prime Minister Najib. Dahlan's statement is a significant development in the ongoing investigation into 1MDB's activities. The incident highlights the potential for corruption and manipulation in the country's high-profile economic development projects.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise for second day on boost from China data
summary: Australian shares rose 1.1% on Wednesday, led by strong data from China, a major export market for Australian manufacturers. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 58.8 points to 5,636.2, its second consecutive day of gains. This follows a 1.9% increase in the previous session.

site_title: EU publishes Greece assessment, sees debt reprofiling
summary: The European Commission published an assessment of Greece's bailout request, differing from the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) assessment that Greece would require extensive debt relief. The EU assessment suggests that Greece's debt-to-GDP ratio could be reduced through reprofiling, but no write-offs, if the country implements reform measures demanded by creditors. The EU's projected debt-to-GDP ratio for 2020 and 2022 is 165% and 150%, respectively, with the IMF projecting 170% in 2022. Reprofiling, including loan extensions and interest deferrals, is seen as a possible solution.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Wednesday, adding 6.16 points to 1,727.26. A total of 1.31 billion lots were traded, with 376 gainers and 353 losers.

site_title: Greek deputy finance minister resigns over bailout deal
summary: Greek Deputy Finance Minister Nadia Valavani resigned ahead of a crucial vote on reforms demanded by creditors for a third bailout. In her letter to Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, Valavani stated that austerity measures would set the country on a "moribund path." Her resignation comes amid growing opposition to the proposed reforms within the left-wing government. The vote is expected to determine Greece's path forward in securing a third bailout package.

site_title: Greek banks to remain shut through to July 16
summary: Greek banks remain closed through July 16, with Economy Minister George Stathakis stating that banks won't reopen until the European Central Bank restores funding. The closure is tied to a parliamentary vote on austerity measures demanded by creditors for a third bailout. Passing reforms is seen as a prerequisite for further funding.

site_title: Thai finance minister sees weaker economic growth in H2
summary: Thai Finance Minister Sommai Phasee expects the country's economy to grow 2.6% in the second half of 2015, slower than the first half. Exports are forecast to contract 1.7% for the third straight year, down from a 0.2% rise in April. This slower growth is attributed to various factors, including economic instability and declining exports. Thailand is due to release second-quarter GDP data on August 17.

site_title: Greek deal skepticism has bond market showing lack of conviction
summary: Greek bond markets show lack of conviction following a six-month aid agreement with creditors. Despite initial relief, gains were short-lived as markets realized the deal was not the final solution. Investors are now taking small positions, following headlines and uncertain about the agreement's success. Traders view the market as "political" and lack confidence in the deal's implementation.

site_title: Share buybacks in first half of July jump to almost S$43 million
summary: Singapore listed companies repurchased nearly S$43 million worth of shares in the first half of July, with 63.34 million shares repurchased by 22 stocks. This is a significant increase from the S$23.3 million in the same period last year. The top five stocks with the largest buybacks were Genting Singapore, Pacific Century Regional Developments, Noble Group, Singapore Technologies Engineering, and Straco Corp.

site_title: Auditor-General flags lapses in public sector
summary: The Auditor-General's Office in Singapore has released a 72-page report highlighting irregularities and lapses in the public sector, including the administration of grants, tendering and management of revenue contracts, contract variations, and related party transactions. The report identified issues with the Infocomm Development Authority and the Workforce Development Agency, including the misuse of funds and over-disbursements of grants. The Auditor-General expressed "concern" over the lack of documentation on decisions and actions, but noted that the audits provide assurance on the proper accounting and use of public resources.

images.alt_text: The Auditor-General's Office has completed its annual audit of the country's public sector, uncovering another slew of irregularities and lapses in various ministries and statutory boards.

site_title: ISDN gets green light for hydropower plant in Central Sulawesi
summary: ISDN Holdings has received approval from the Indonesian government to develop a 20-megawatt hydropower plant in Central Sulawesi. The US$40 million project, funded by debt and equity, is expected to take 40 months to complete and generate annual revenue of US$10 million. The hydropower plant will benefit residents and industries in the Sigi District, with an estimated population of 231,000.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit Q2 DPU comes in 1.9% above forecast
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 1.9% increase in its second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.62 Singapore cents, exceeding its forecast. The Reit's gross revenue and net property income also rose 4% and 3.4%, respectively, driven by higher variable rental income from its Singapore properties and other income. The increase was attributed to higher variable rental income and recovery of power costs and ad hoc service fees. The Reit's total distributable income was S$14.27 million.

site_title: Asia ready to buy more Iranian oil when sanctions lifted
summary: Asian refiners are expected to increase oil purchases from Iran once sanctions are lifted, with the country aiming to regain market share in an oversupplied market. A deal between world powers and Iran has been reached, paving the way for sanctions on Iranian oil exports to be lifted in exchange for nuclear curbs. Iran's largest customers, China, India, Japan, and South Korea, are prioritizing the country as a crude oil supplier, having been its main customers since sanctions were tightened in 2012.

site_title: Gold marks time ahead of testimony from Fed's Yellen
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,154.67 per ounce ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's congressional testimony, as investors awaited clues on the timing of a US interest rate increase this year. Economic growth in top gold consumer China held steady at 7% in the second quarter, above expectations. US retail sales slipped 0.3% in June, renewing concerns about a slowing US economy, which may impact gold prices. Yellen is likely to reiterate her stance on raising interest rates later this year, further influencing gold prices.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip at open, before Greece vote
summary: Europe's main stock markets declined at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index dropping 0.11% to 6,746.01 points. The decline was attributed to Greece's upcoming vote on its new bailout deal, with traders reacting to the prospect of austerity measures. The Greek parliament is set to vote on the deal, which includes reforms demanded by eurozone creditors in exchange for a new bailout worth up to €86 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall after China data fails to impress
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.3% to 25,055.76 points, while the China Enterprises Index dropped 1.3% to 11,681.20 points. China's better-than-expected economic data failed to boost mainland markets, with a recent rebound appearing to lose steam. The decline was attributed to investor skepticism about the sustainability of the rebound.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise after Iran deal, won flat
summary: Seoul shares rose 0.7% to 2,072.91 points on Wednesday, driven by expectations of increasing orders from Iran following a nuclear deal. Foreigners purchased a net 230.2 billion won, and the won closed at 1,143.6 against the dollar. The gains were bolstered by foreign buying in the main board.

site_title: Greek bailout math in question as Tsipras starts sales pitch
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras began pitching a bailout deal to the international community, but faces opposition from his own party and questions about the country's finances. The deal aims to prevent Greece from defaulting on the European Central Bank and its citizens, but critics argue it has a "heavy toll" on the economy. Tsipras has vowed to finalize the deal despite criticism from German lawmakers, and opposition lawmakers are likely to back the package in a parliamentary vote on Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: Singapore's private home sales plummeted to 375 units in June, down from May's 643 units and June last year's 482 units. The decline is attributed to various global economic concerns, including US tariffs and China's slowing GDP growth. Meanwhile, other news includes Vietnam's surprise reaction to US tariffs, Malaysia's plan to seize Daim Zainuddin's assets, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month in a row. These events are expected to impact various sectors, including real estate and global markets.

images.alt_text: Developers sold 375 private homes in Singapore in June this year, down from 643 units in May this year and 482 units in June last year.

site_title: Greek parliament speaker says lawmakers must resist "blackmail"
summary: Greek parliament speaker Zoe Constantopoulou urged lawmakers to reject a package of austerity measures demanded by creditors in exchange for a third bailout. She described the measures as "blackmail" and emphasized the parliament's duty not to let it materialize. The vote on the measures is crucial, and Constantopoulou's comments reflect the Syriza party's opposition to the austerity package, which is part of Greece's bailout agreement with the European Union and International Monetary Fund.

site_title: Asia: Shares extend gains on reassuring China data
summary: Asian stocks extended gains on Wednesday after China's second-quarter GDP growth rate of 7.0% met expectations, beating forecasts and suggesting growth may have bottomed out. The MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares added 0.4% as Chinese shares fell 1.4%, while Japan's Nikkei index rose 0.5%. Investors await Bank of Japan policy decisions and US Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's congressional testimony for further market direction.

site_title: UK unemployment rate rises for 1st time in over two years, earnings growth faster
summary: Britain's unemployment rate unexpectedly rose to 5.6% in the three months to May, the first increase in over two years, due to a 67,000 decline in employment. However, total earnings showed the strongest gain in over five years, driven by bonuses.

site_title: Developer sales in Singapore fall to 375 private homes in June
summary: Developer sales in Singapore fell to 375 private homes in June, down from 643 units in May and 482 units in June last year. This marks a decline from the second quarter of last year, when 2,665 private homes were sold. Excluding executive condominiums, developers sold 2,185 private homes in the second quarter, while including ECs, they sold 485 units. The figures are lower than the previous quarter and year, indicating a decline in demand for private homes in Singapore.

site_title: Tax deductible donations up 13% to S$1.1b in 2014
summary: Tax deductible donations to Singapore Institutions of a Public Character (IPC) increased by 13% in 2014 to S$1.1 billion, up from S$970 million in 2013. This upward trend reflects strong public support for local charitable causes, according to the Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth (MCCY).

site_title: Vietnam ran US$140m trade deficit in June-customs
summary: Vietnam posted a trade deficit of US$140 million in June, lower than the estimated US$700 million. Exports rose 4.6% to US$14.3 billion, while imports fell 3.2% to US$14.46 billion. The country's trade deficit for the first half of 2015 was US$3.07 billion, with exports increasing 9.3% and imports rising 16.7% compared to the same period last year.

site_title: Singapore's retail sales up 6.1% in May on exuberant car sales
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 6.1% in May, driven by a 46.6% increase in motor vehicle sales. Excluding cars, sales would have increased 0.9%. Other sectors, such as medical goods and department stores, also saw growth. On a seasonally-adjusted basis, retail sales rose 2.4% month-over-month. The surge in car sales helped offset declines in petrol services, recreational goods, and optical goods.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end 0.38% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.38% on Wednesday, driven by a weaker yen after the Bank of Japan cut its annual inflation and growth forecasts, boosting the chance of more monetary easing this year. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 20,463.33, while the Topix index climbed 0.47%. The move is seen as a positive sign for the market, but investors remain cautious due to ongoing US-EU trade tensions and global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Indonesia's trade surplus narrowed to US$477m in June
summary: Indonesia's trade surplus narrowed to US$477 million in June from a revised US$1.08 billion in May, missing analyst expectations. Exports fell 12.78% to US$13.44 billion and imports dropped 17.42% to US$12.96 billion. This was Indonesia's seventh consecutive monthly surplus.

site_title: Yen dips after Bank of Japan cuts growth, inflation forecasts
summary: The yen fell against the dollar and euro after the Bank of Japan cut growth and inflation forecasts, boosting the likelihood of further monetary easing. The Bank of Japan's downgrade suggested weak second-quarter growth and increased the chances of expanding its asset-buying plan. The dollar rebounded as investors await Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's appearance at Congress, with expectations of an interest rate hike by September.

site_title: Oil prices edge up as Iran export surge to take time after deal
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday as investors recognized it would take time for Iran to ramp up oil exports after its nuclear deal with six world powers. Brent crude increased by 27 cents to $58.78 a barrel, while US futures rose 18 cents to $53.22 a barrel. Analysts estimate that new Iranian oil supply will not flow until 2016, with a possible 300,000-500,000 barrels per day. Despite this, oil prices are expected to remain low, with Goldman Sachs forecasting Brent to average $58 in 2015 and $62 in 2016.

site_title: Spending by tourists using MasterCard up 10% in first month of Great Singapore Sale
summary: Tourist spending by MasterCard users in Singapore increased 10% in the first month of the Great Singapore Sale, reaching S$350.6 million. Transactions rose 17.8% to 2.01 million, with Australia spending the most at S$39.5 million. China ranked third with S$26.9 million spent, while the US displaced Japan for fourth place with S$21 million spent. Local MasterCard users spent almost double that of inbound tourists, with S$684.9 million spent domestically, down 12.7% year-over-year.

site_title: EMA concludes joint project on electrical wiring practices in Cambodia (Amended)
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) in Singapore has completed a 16-month joint project with the Cambodian Ministry of Mines and Energy to improve electrical wiring practices in the country. The project developed technical standards for electrical wiring and safety standards for buildings and households. 55 senior energy officials were trained on electrical safety systems and regulatory frameworks. The standards will be the first technical document for Cambodia to manage electrical requirements for buildings and households.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise, aided by banks, China Q2 growth number
summary: Australian shares rose 0.9% on Wednesday, led by banks and a better-than-expected growth report from China, which saw second-quarter annual growth of 7.0%. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 48.3 points to 5,625.7. Banks such as Commonwealth Bank, National Australia Bank, and Westpac Bank also gained, while energy stocks like Woodside Petroleum and Santos rose due to rising oil prices. Other strong performers included telecommunications company Spark and power companies Meridian Energy and Genesis.

site_title: China state revenue jumps in June, aided by property taxes
summary: China's government revenue in June jumped 13.9% from the previous year, driven by higher property tax payments and stronger corporate earnings. The 1.53 trillion yuan in revenue supported a 13.9% spike in state spending, exceeding market expectations. The data suggests China's economy is stabilizing after a difficult half-year, with annual growth of 7% in April-June. Property-related tax income rose 3.7% and corporate income tax increased 17.5% in June. The gains lifted hopes for economic recovery and could inform government spending decisions.

site_title: Troubled developer Kaisa plans to resume Shenzhen property sales
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd, a Chinese developer facing debt restructuring, plans to resume property sales at three projects in Shenzhen as early as this month. The company is in talks with creditors to resolve blocked sales and hopes to sign a framework agreement to ease financial woes. The resumption of sales follows a liquidity crunch caused by the Shenzhen government's blockage of local project sales amid an anti-corruption probe. Kaisa's debt restructuring efforts aim to address the company's financial struggles, which were exacerbated by the failed acquisition of the company by Sunac China Holdings Ltd.

site_title: India rate swaps at two-week high as inflation concern mounts
summary: India's one-year interest-rate swaps rose to a two-week high amid concerns of faster inflation, which may deter the central bank from easing monetary policy further. The surplus in monsoon rains has turned into a deficit, sparking fears of reduced crop output and higher food costs. Consumer inflation rose 5.4% in June, the fastest pace in nine months. The fixed payment for one-year borrowing costs reached 7.49%, matching Tuesday's closing level, and the rupee remained steady. The Reserve Bank of India is likely to keep rates unchanged, with the central bank's Governor Raghuram Rajan linking policy action to monsoon strength.

site_title: Greek parliament to vote on controversial bailout
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras faces a crucial parliamentary vote on a controversial bailout deal, which includes sweeping reforms demanded by eurozone creditors in exchange for a three-year, €86 billion bailout. The deal, which Tsipras has described as a "humiliating climb down," must be approved before negotiations with other eurozone leaders can begin. The IMF has warned that Greece needs far more debt relief to stabilize its finances, and the country's creditors are divided over options to help Greece meet its short-term cash needs. The outcome of the vote could determine Tsipras's political survival.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise on building sector gains; won edges up
summary: Seoul shares rose 0.3% midday Wednesday as builders led gains due to expectations of increased orders from Iran after a nuclear deal. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose to 2,065.06 points. Builders, including Daelim Industrial Co Ltd and SK Innovation Co Ltd, outperformed the broader market. Foreigners purchased a net 109 billion won worth of KOSPI shares.
