The South Korean won edged up 0.2% against the dollar as the US Federal Reserve rate hike expectations eased following disappointing retail sales data.

site_title: Battle over Samsung merger holds potential for change
summary: A shareholder vote on a proposed merger between Samsung affiliates is set to take place, potentially leading to a shift in corporate governance practices among South Korea's family-run conglomerates. The US hedge fund Elliott Associates is spearheading opposition to the merger, arguing it undervalues Samsung C&T, a construction company. The outcome of the vote could prompt Samsung to improve transparency and consider shareholder interests, marking a new phase in investor-corporate interaction in South Korea.

site_title: Billionaire Lim may help Valencia finances, S&P Capital says
summary: Singapore billionaire Peter Lim's takeover of Valencia soccer club may improve the team's financial standing, according to S&P Capital IQ. Valencia has struggled financially, leading to the sale of star players like David Silva and David Villa. Lim's investment could help turn the team around, as billionaire investors have historically improved club finances. This trend is reflected in recent sales of team shares, with Manchester United and AS Roma raising $572.3 million in May.

site_title: QT Vascular gets green light for four patents
summary: QT Vascular Ltd received allowance letters for four fundamental patents from the US Patent and Trademark Office, covering its specialty balloons for treating vascular disease in coronary and peripheral vessels. The patents include three for its flagship platform, Chocolate, and one for its Glider family of products. The company, based in Singapore, is focused on executing operational milestones, particularly its drug coating programme. CEO Dr. Eitan Konstantino described the patent allowances as an "exceptional experience" for a start-up company.

site_title: Quake-hit Nepal to train 50,000 workers for reconstruction
summary: Nepal plans to train 50,000 workers for reconstruction efforts after devastating twin earthquakes in April and May that killed almost 9,000 people. The government aims to rebuild infrastructure and homes, with an estimated cost of $6.6 billion. Finance Minister Ram Sharan Mahat said the reconstruction will boost economic growth to 6% by next year, despite a projected 3% growth rate this fiscal year. The program is the country's largest skill development initiative, addressing a labor shortage caused by millions of Nepalis traveling abroad for work.

site_title: Drones and phones to tackle Indonesian holiday road chaos
summary: Indonesia is using drones and smartphone apps to alleviate traffic chaos during the annual Eid holiday, when millions of cars clog the roads of overpopulated Java. Hundreds of new vehicles hit the road daily, but narrow, ageing roads remain. New technology tools include drones monitoring traffic, a police app to access CCTV and check conditions, and specialized "mudik" apps offering navigation, rest stops, and meet-up spots. Despite these innovations, major investment in public transport and infrastructure is needed to reduce chaos, which has claimed scores of lives in recent years.

site_title: Update: BOJ keeps policy steady, trims GDP forecast
summary: The Bank of Japan maintained its monetary policy steady, cutting its economic growth forecast to 1.7% for the year ending in March 2016. The central bank reiterated its pledge to increase base money at an annual pace of 80 trillion yen through purchases of government bonds and risky assets. This decision comes as soft exports and household spending forced the BOJ to trim its growth projection. The decision was largely expected, following a review of its long-term estimates in January.

site_title: Stable stock market crucial for China economy: stats agency
summary: China's statistics bureau says a stable stock market is crucial for the country's economy. Recent measures to contain the market's meltdown are showing results, with the economy growing 7% between April and June, slightly ahead of expectations. This growth is attributed to the stability in the stock market, which has contributed to the country's overall economic performance.

site_title: Update: China's growth steady at 7% as investment rebounds
summary: China's economy grew 7.0% in the second quarter, steady with the previous quarter and slightly better than forecast. Despite a stock market crash, the economy showed signs of a rebound, with fixed-asset investment rising 11.4% and industrial output growth quickening to 6.8%. However, further stimulus is still expected, as the government seeks to consolidate the economic recovery and address deflationary pressures and high financing costs.

site_title: South Korea to build LNG bunkering terminals, wants to dominate duel-fuel tanker building
summary: South Korea plans to construct liquefied natural gas bunkering terminals at its ports to dominate the duel-fuel tanker market. The energy ministry aims to secure 70% of global orders for duel-fuel tankers by 2025. The growth of LNG-fuelled tankers and bunkering markets in Europe and China, driven by greenhouse gas emissions restrictions, is expected to boost demand for duel-fuel ships.

site_title: Bank of Japan cuts annual economic growth, inflation forecasts
summary: The Bank of Japan (BoJ) cut its annual economic growth forecast to 1.7% for the fiscal year to March 2016, down from 2.0%, while inflation is now expected at 0.7% compared to 0.8%. The BoJ held fire on further easing measures, citing a recovery still underway.

site_title: Private condo rents down 0.5% in June, HDB rents up 0.1%: SRX
summary: Singapore's private condo rents decreased 0.5% in June, with city and suburban areas experiencing drops of 0.8% and 0.7% respectively. Rents in city fringe areas remained unchanged. Year-over-year, private condo rents fell 6.5% and reached a 12.4% drop from their peak in January 2013. In contrast, HDB rents rose 0.1% in June, with some flats experiencing increases and others decreases. Rental volume for private condos rose 1% and for HDB flats increased 14.2% year-over-year.

site_title: ABS seeks feedback on responsibilities of banks under PDPA
summary: The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) released a Code of Banking Practices outlining the responsibilities of banks under the Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA). The code aims to assure individuals that their personal data will be handled according to high standards set by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Personal Data Protection Commission. The public can access the code on ABS' website and provide feedback until August 7, 2015.

site_title: Toshiba CEO, most other board members to step down: sources
summary: Toshiba CEO Hisao Tanaka and other board members, including Vice Chairman Norio Sasaki, will step down in September to take responsibility for accounting irregularities. An independent investigation into top officials' roles has led to a potential management overhaul. The resignation announcement is expected to be made after the investigative committee releases its report next week.

site_title: China's Q2 GDP growth flat at 7.0% y-o-y: govt
summary: China's Q2 GDP growth remains steady at 7.0% year-on-year, matching the first quarter's expansion and exceeding economists' median forecast of 6.9%. The slowdown in investment and trade weighed on growth, indicating continued economic challenges. The data provides little relief for policymakers, who face pressure to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.39% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.39% to 25,219.45 after opening, awaiting Chinese economic growth figures. The Hang Seng Index added 98.54 points. The move comes amid US-EU trade talks and other global market fluctuations.

site_title: From wood to wine: France dominates oak barrel trade
summary: France dominates the global oak barrel trade, with exports making up 70% of the market, as the country's high-quality oak barrels are in high demand for premium wines. The barrels are crafted by skilled artisans using centuries-old techniques, and the selection of wood is crucial in determining the flavor of the wine. Only a small percentage of the wood used is actually used to make barrels, with the rest being sold to paper mills or used for other purposes, and the process of making barrels can take several years.

site_title: Shanghai: Shares lower in morning ahead of growth data
summary: Chinese shares were mixed in morning trading, with Shanghai lower by 1.26% due to anticipation of second-quarter economic growth data. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 49.52 points to 3,874.97, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.42% to 2,158.56. The mixed performance was attributed to the upcoming data release, which is expected to provide insight into China's economic health.

site_title: Won rises from two-year low as dollar flounders on retail sales
summary: South Korea's won rose 0.2% to 1,140.30 a dollar, rebounding from a two-year low, as a technical indicator signaled the end of the dollar's biggest rally in a month. The US retail sales unexpectedly contracted, and investors await Chinese data due Wednesday to assess the world's second-largest economy. The won's drop was attributed to concern over China's economic slowdown and South Korea's economic dependency. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's testimony before Congress may provide clarity on US interest rate hikes this year.

site_title: Asia: Stocks up with copper before China data; oil extends gains
summary: Asian stocks rose ahead of Chinese economic data, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index up 0.3% as oil and copper gained. The region is set for its longest run of gains since April, driven by a rebound in global equities and a halt in the equity rout in China. Oil rose on speculation the nuclear deal won't spur Iranian crude exports, while copper added 0.3%. Chinese GDP data is expected to paint a muted picture, with retail sales and factory output reports due on Wednesday.

site_title: Australia consumer confidence hit by global gloom: survey
summary: Australia's consumer confidence fell 3.2% in July, the second consecutive decline, due to global economic concerns. The Melbourne Institute and Westpac Bank survey of 1,200 people showed a seasonally adjusted index reading of 92.2, 2.8% lower than in June 2014. Despite economic instability in Europe and concerns over China, businesses reported improved sales and profits, with confidence at its highest in nearly two years. Experts expect sentiment to bounce back as shares in China stabilize and Greece makes progress on a debt deal.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise slightly in cautious trade ahead of China data
summary: Taiwan's main stock index rose 0.5% to 9,088.92 on Wednesday, driven by gains in the electronics and financials subindices. The move comes ahead of China's economic data release, which is expected to show its weakest growth since the global financial crisis, raising pressure on authorities to stimulate the economy. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$31.023 per US dollar, while shares in Inotera Memories rose 0.4% following a reported offer by China's Tsinghua Unigroup Ltd to buy Micron Technology.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, CMT, Sembcorp Marine
summary: Singapore stocks to watch on Wednesday include CapitaLand Limited, which is selling Bedok Mall to CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) for S$783.1 million. Sembcorp Marine has entered into a US$1 billion engineering and construction contract. No other stocks are mentioned in this article.

site_title: BHP Billiton takes US$2.8b pre-tax writedown as oil price tumbles
summary: BHP Billiton is taking a US$2.8 billion pre-tax writedown on its US onshore assets due to plunging oil prices and shale gas. The majority of the charge comes from the Hawkville field in south Texas. The company expects a US$2 billion post-tax writedown. Despite this, BHP remains optimistic about its onshore US business, investing US$1.5 billion in 2016 to develop 10 operated rigs. The writedown reflects the impact of a 60% decline in world oil prices since 2014.

images.alt_text: Mining giant BHP Billiton on Wednesday said it was taking a US$2.8 billion pre-tax writedown on its onshore assets in the United States as plunging oil prices hit shale gas.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher ahead of China data
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened higher at 3,326.07 points, up 9.57 points or 0.29% ahead of China's GDP, retail sales, and factory output data. Gainers outnumbered losers 88 to 54, with top stocks including DBS, Global Logistic Properties, and Singtel.

site_title: New Shanghai Disneyland plans Star Wars, Marvel attractions
summary: Walt Disney Co announced its new Shanghai Disneyland theme park, set to open in spring 2016, will feature six themed lands with attractions based on the Star Wars and Marvel Universe. The $5.5 billion park, developed with Shanghai Shendi Group, aims to appeal to Chinese visitors. Disney previously delayed the opening from 2015 to accommodate expanded plans.

site_title: SingPost unit buys 80% of Dutch firm for S$12.6m
summary: SingPost's subsidiary, Famous Holdings Pte Ltd, acquired an 80% stake in Rotterdam Harbour Holding BV (FPS Rotterdam) for S$12.6 million. FPS provides services to companies in Rotterdam harbour and is now an indirect subsidiary of SingPost. The stake purchase was made from Etc Etcetera Beheer BV and Rubus Beheer BV, with an additional S$5.4 million potentially paid if performance targets are met.

site_title: Oil prices finish higher after Iran deal
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday after Iran reached a historic deal with six world powers, potentially lifting international sanctions on the country's oil exports. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate gained 84 cents at $53.04 a barrel, while European benchmark Brent oil added 66 cents at $58.51 a barrel. Analysts expect the return of Iranian oil exports to keep oil prices low, with some predicting Brent crude to trade around $60 per barrel for the remainder of the year.

site_title: China H1 property investments grow at slowest pace in 6 years
summary: China's real estate investment in the first half of 2015 grew at its slowest pace in 6 years, reaching 4.6% from a year earlier, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. The slowdown is attributed to persistent weakness in the property market, with unsold homes totaling 657.4 million square meters by the end of June. Despite this, sales volume data suggests the market may be bottoming out, with a 3.9% increase in the January-June period and a 16% rise in property sales in June alone. Economists warn that weak property investment poses a risk to China's economy.

site_title: Iran will never get nuclear weapon if I'm president: Clinton
summary: Hillary Clinton, a Democratic presidential contender, stated that Iran will never acquire a nuclear weapon if she is elected president. She criticized the Iran nuclear deal, saying critics' concerns about it providing Iran with a "glide path" toward a nuclear weapon are valid. Clinton vowed to use "every tool in our arsenal" to compel rigorous Iranian compliance and ensure the deal's effective enforcement. She supports the agreement, believing it can prevent Iran from getting a nuclear weapon, and emphasized that signing the accord is just the first step.

images.alt_text: Democratic presidential contender Hillary Clinton, in a tough statement on the Iran nuclear deal, vowed on Tuesday that Tehran will never be able to acquire atomic weapons if she is elected to the White House.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.79 points to 1,722.89. The gains were driven by a gainers-to-losers ratio of 104 to 47. Volume reached 18.42 million lots worth RM8.89 million.

site_title: Australia new vehicle sales jump in June
summary: Australia's new vehicle sales surged in June, reaching the second-highest ever, with a 3.8% seasonally adjusted increase from May. Total sales of 97,620 new vehicles rose 4.0% from June last year, the highest since September 2012. The jump is attributed to record low interest rates and a government tax break on small business investment.

site_title: Twitter confirms purported Bloomberg story is false
summary: Twitter has confirmed that a report claiming the company received a $31 billion acquisition offer from Bloomberg LP is false. The report, which was distributed online and resembled Bloomberg's website, was found on a fake site and originated from an unknown source. Twitter shares rose following the report, which was widely disseminated on the internet. Twitter did not provide additional comment.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.46% higher ahead of Fed testimony
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.46% higher on July 15, 2015, ahead of US Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's testimony to US lawmakers. The Nikkei 225 index rose 93.52 points to 20,478.85. Investors await Yellen's remarks on monetary policy and the US economy, seeking insight into the Fed's plan to raise its zero-level federal funds rate. This comes after Wall Street stocks rose Tuesday, with the Nasdaq gaining 0.66% and the Dow Jones climbing 0.42%.

site_title: Japan's Abe set to push through security bills in summer of discontent
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to push through unpopular security bills despite voter doubts, which would allow Japanese troops to fight abroad for the first time since World War Two. The legislation has sparked opposition due to concerns it violates Japan's pacifist constitution. Abe's ratings have slipped, with a recent poll showing a nine-point disapproval rate. The bills are expected to be approved in the lower house and then move to the upper chamber, with some predicting Abe may achieve his goal but have to resign.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine enters into US$1b contract to build vessel
summary: Sembcorp Marine has entered into a US$1 billion contract to build a semi-submersible crane vessel for marine contractor Heerema, scheduled for delivery in the fourth quarter of 2018. The ship will be designed for installation and decommissioning of major offshore facilities worldwide, featuring two 10,000-tonne cranes. The contract follows a letter of intent signed in March this year.

site_title: S&P cuts Puerto Rico rating to 'imminent default'
summary: Standard & Poor's lowered Puerto Rico's rating to "imminent default" due to the US territory's intention to pay creditors less than face value on its $73 billion debt. The rating cut reflects a "virtual certainty" of default by the Government Development Bank, according to S&P analyst Brendan Browne. This move follows the Puerto Rican government's push to negotiate with creditors to lighten the burden.

site_title: IMF says Greece needs much larger debt relief from EU
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that Greece needs significantly more debt relief from the EU to stabilize its finances. The EU's existing estimates of 85 billion euros may not be sufficient, and the IMF warns of "considerable" downside risks to Greece's economic situation. The IMF suggests that Greece could require a debt "haircut" or writedown, direct cash payments, or a dramatic extension of payment periods to avoid financial instability.

site_title: Uber settles wrongful death lawsuit in San Francisco crash
summary: Uber has reached a settlement in a wrongful death lawsuit filed by the family of 6-year-old Sofia Liu, who died in a San Francisco car accident in 2013 after being hit by a car while riding in an Uber X vehicle. The terms of the settlement were kept confidential due to the family's request for privacy. This comes as Uber faces controversy over its business model, with Democratic presidential contender Hillary Clinton questioning the company's impact on workers. The lawsuit was one of several ongoing cases related to Uber's classification of drivers as independent contractors.

site_title: IMF says EU needs clear plan for Greece sustainability
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) requires Greece to have a clear plan for debt sustainability before participating in a third bailout. The EU's proposed plan, which includes reforms and up to $128.8 billion in financial aid, needs more details on short-term and long-term stability. The IMF wants a comprehensive and credible agreement, with a focus on debt relief measures, such as debt restructuring or forgiveness. Greece's arrears must be cleared before the IMF can engage in talks, and the Fund's executive board will weigh joining the new bailout with a concrete and ambitious solution to Greece's debt problem.

images.alt_text: The International Monetary Fund can only participate in a third bailout of Greece if its EU creditors produce a clear plan for debt sustainability, a senior official said Tuesday.

site_title: Thai Oil burns bright amid slim China pickings
summary: Thai Oil, a state-run oil company, is considering its first dollar-denominated note in over a year, offering a respite from China's deluge of bonds amid a stock-market collapse. Investors are warming to the company's first dollar-denominated offering, citing a desire for diversification from the concentrated supply of Chinese bonds. This move could end Thailand's 21-month drought in offshore debt issuance, with investors seeking alternative issuers, particularly from Southeast Asia.

site_title: UK government sets out plans to toughen strike laws
summary: The UK government plans to introduce stricter strike laws, requiring a 50% turnout and 40% of eligible voters to support strikes in key sectors like healthcare, transportation, and education. The proposed changes aim to reduce the impact of strikes on public services, with Prime Minister David Cameron describing a 24-hour London Underground stoppage as "unacceptable and unjustified." The measures are likely to face opposition from trade unions, with one warning that they could bankrupt the opposition Labour Party. The changes are seen as part of the government's re-election campaign.

site_title: China June industrial output up 6.8% y-o-y: govt
summary: China's industrial output increased 6.8% year-over-year in June, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. Retail sales rose 10.6% and fixed asset investment expanded 11.4% in the first half of the year.

images.alt_text: China's industrial output, which measures production at factories, workshops and mines, rose 6.8 per cent year-on-year in June, the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) said Wednesday.

site_title: June retail sales dip dampens consumer spending optimism
summary: US retail sales unexpectedly dropped 0.3% in June, contradicting optimism about consumer spending strength in the second quarter. This decline was attributed to eight of 13 major retail categories showing a decrease in demand. The May sales increase of 1% was also revised downward. These figures signal a slowdown in consumer spending, which may have implications for the overall economy.

site_title: Bigger may not be better for China's "super hospitals"
summary: China's largest hospital, the First Affiliated Hospital of Zhengzhou University, with 7,000 beds, still struggles with overcrowding and long waiting times. Relatives of patients often have to share beds or sleep on the floor due to the hospital's limited capacity. The hospital's overcrowding has led to a two-day wait for a bed for patients like Ma Wenxiao, who had to travel from Wuhan for chemotherapy. Despite its massive size, the hospital is not equipped to handle the demand, highlighting the need for more hospital beds and improved healthcare infrastructure in China.

images.alt_text: Just before midnight, the pavement outside the glowing high-rise towers of the First Affiliated Hospital of Zhengzhou University is littered with slumbering bodies. Splayed on colourful mats or tucked into folding cots, these are patients' relatives.

site_title: Shaping S'pore into a smarter nation
summary: Schneider Electric aims to help Singapore become a more liveable city by improving its infrastructure. The company, which has been present in Singapore since the 1970s, has implemented numerous smart city projects globally, including over 300 projects in cities worldwide. Schneider Electric's Singapore team, led by President Saulo Spaolanse, works with city planners to implement smart mobility, energy management, and public services. The company has also established a global logistics hub in Singapore and has partnered with local universities to develop innovative technologies. Schneider Electric's goal is to make Singapore a more efficient, liveable, and sustainable city.

site_title: Over 60 firms join off-peak travel scheme
summary: Over 60 firms with 160,000 employees have joined the Travel Smart Network, a Singapore government programme encouraging off-peak travel and sustainable modes of transport. The programme, launched last August, aims to reduce peak-hour travel demand. Employers receive funding for initiatives such as flexible work arrangements and sustainable commute options, while employees earn cash rewards for using off-peak travel. The programme has gained momentum, with companies recognizing the benefits of supporting flexible work arrangements and sustainable commuting.

site_title: US: Stocks rise on reports of big Micron bid
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq leading the way after reports of a possible $23 billion acquisition of chipmaker Micron. The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 75.90 points, while the S&P 500 advanced 9.35 points. Other chipmakers, including SanDisk and STMicroelectronics, also rose following the Micron news. Google climbed 2.7% after a report on its spending cuts, and Amazon advanced 2.2% after an upgrade.

site_title: Reforms, debt repayment could pave way for ECB to help Greece
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) may ease a funding squeeze on Greece this week if Greek lawmakers pass reforms and agree to make debt payments to the ECB. A favorable vote could prompt Europe to agree to temporary or "bridge" finance, allowing Greece to clear its debt to the ECB and potentially free up the ECB to provide extra emergency funding. This could give Greece's shuttered banks a small lift and allow them to reopen, although capital controls are likely to remain in place.

site_title: China Sky replaces auditor, cites difficult working relationship and fee hike
summary: China Sky Chemical Fibre has replaced its auditor, Baker Tilly TFW LLP, due to a difficult working relationship and proposed fee hike. The company cited a directive from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in 2011 to appoint a special auditor, which China Sky refused to comply with, leading to the suspension of its shares. China Sky has started the process of appointing new auditors and aims to complete its audit for 2014 financial statements by August 31, 2015. The company will also hold an extraordinary general meeting to seek approval for 2014 accounts.

site_title: Greece bans export of 25 drugs after pharmacists' supply warnings
summary: Greece has banned the export of 25 types of drugs following warnings from pharmacists about possible shortages that could lead to a humanitarian crisis. The ban was imposed after a significant increase in re-exports of imported medicines was discovered. The Greek Health Ministry will closely check exports and re-exports and file complaints abroad where abuse is suspected. The move comes as Greece faces economic crisis and capital controls limiting bank withdrawals, exacerbating difficulties in securing drug supplies.

site_title: The Straits Times launches 170th anniversary e-book as gift to the nation
summary: The Straits Times is launching an e-book to celebrate its 170th anniversary, featuring key moments from the nation's past, including the Great Depression, World War II, and Singapore's Independence. The e-book, titled "Living History: 170 years of The Straits Times," is a compilation of stories, pictures, and videos from successive generations of ST journalists. It is available for download through the Straits Times STAR app, supported by the National Heritage Board.

site_title: World leaders voice relief at Iran nuclear deal
summary: World leaders expressed relief over the Iran nuclear deal, with US President Barack Obama seeing a "new direction" and Vladimir Putin voicing a "global sigh of relief". The deal aims to reset relations with Iran, while Israel criticized it as a "historic mistake". Despite Republican concerns that the deal could "embolden" Iran, the international powers involved hope Iran will build on the opportunity to come in from the cold.

site_title: Dollar edges lower after poor data signal rate hike delay
summary: The US dollar fell slightly after disappointing data on American consumer spending, which suggested the Federal Reserve may delay an interest rate hike. Retail sales fell 0.3% in June, lower than the expected 0.3% increase, clouding forecasts for a solid second-quarter rebound. The data's impact on interest rate expectations led to a dollar decline.

site_title: Greek banks in need of a bailout too
summary: Greek banks are in need of a bailout, according to a new agreement between Greece and its European creditors. The accord calls for an overhaul of Greece's banking system, including replenishing capital and closing insolvent lenders. The European Central Bank has declined to provide additional cash, leaving Greek banks at risk of running out of cash, with banks potentially staying closed until at least Wednesday. Analysts expect a more thorough bank cleanup, including restrictions on international money transfers, to remain in place until then.

site_title: CapitaLand sells Bedok Mall to CMT for S$783.1m
summary: CapitaLand Limited sold Bedok Mall to CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) for S$783.1 million, strengthening CMT's position as Singapore's largest Reit. The deal involves CMT acquiring the entire unitholding interest in Brilliance Mall Trust, which owns Bedok Mall, and includes the repayment of an existing bank loan. The property yield of Bedok Mall is approximately 5.1%, in line with CMT's distribution yield.

images.alt_text: Opened in December 2013, Bedok Mall is the first major mall in Bedok Town Centre. The mall was valued at S$775 million as at June 30.

site_title: Global mutual funds sell more of Singapore stocks
summary: Global mutual funds sold more Singapore stocks than they bought in the three months to July 8, with net sells of S$805.7 outweighing net buys of S$613.3. The top stocks among buys were Yoma Strategic Holdings and top stocks among sells were Ascendas Hospitality Trust. The data was provided by ShareInvestor and Ipreo, and highlights the bearish sentiment on Singapore stocks among global mutual funds.

site_title: Market intelligence delays can cost companies dearly
summary: Business managers in Singapore admit to experiencing delays in decision-making due to a lack of information, with 31% admitting to such delays. The lack of benchmarks for measuring the effectiveness of corporate market intelligence is a significant issue, as superior market intelligence can improve business performance directly. Companies with world-class market intelligence programs can grow shareholder value twice as fast as the global average. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's recent announcement on digital innovations is expected to spur the growth of the digital economy, creating more competition and opportunities for existing players and startups.

site_title: Europe: Stocks pause for Greek developments
summary: European stocks paused on Tuesday due to uncertainty surrounding Greece's bailout agreement, with investors awaiting Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' domestic support for reforms. Despite disappointing economic data, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index rose 0.28%, while Paris' CAC 40 climbed 0.69%. European equities had surged on Monday following the bailout agreement, but concerns about its implementation and potential opposition in the Greek parliament kept markets steady. The euro edged up to $1.1014 against the US dollar, while most Asian markets rose, except for Shanghai and Hong Kong, which fell.

site_title: Countries must invest more in mental health, especially during economic crises: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) emphasizes the need for countries to invest more in mental health care, particularly during economic crises when rates of depression and suicide rise. One in 10 people worldwide has a mental health disorder, but only 1% of the global health workforce treats such illnesses. WHO Director Dr. Shekhar Saxena notes that countries facing socio-economic challenges are at a higher risk of mental health problems, and that resources devoted to mental health care are extremely small globally. Inequities in mental health care also persist, with nearly half of the world's population lacking access to psychiatrists.

site_title: S&P halves its global sukuk sales forecast
summary: Standard & Poor's has halved its forecast for global sukuk issuance due to a decline in sales by Bank Negara Malaysia, the world's largest Islamic debt market. The central bank has cut back on sukuk sales, instead focusing on shorter-dated maturities in both Syariah-compliant and conventional money markets to manage cash flows. This move is expected to reduce the market's growth prospects.

site_title: Transforming dentistry through branding
summary: Smile Inc., a Singapore-based dental firm, is expanding its overseas presence following its success in transforming the public perception of dentistry in the country. Established in 1997, the company has revolutionized the dental experience through its use of the latest technologies, state-of-the-art facilities, and a patient-friendly setting. Smile Inc has received numerous accolades, including the Singapore Prestige Brand Award, and has introduced innovative procedures such as chair-side teeth whitening and computerized operations. The company plans to capitalize on its strong brand and reputation to grow its business overseas, driven by a keen CEO, Grace Chong-Tan, who emphasizes the need for liberalized healthcare regulations to remain competitive.

site_title: FedEx to buy 25 Boeing 767 cargo jets, say sources
summary: FedEx is in talks to acquire at least 25 Boeing 767 cargo jets, valued at approximately $5 billion, according to sources. The deal, which was discussed by FedEx directors in the Seattle area, would further expand the company's twin-engine freighter fleet. This acquisition would support FedEx's growing demand for cargo transportation services.

site_title: Home lotteries being reconsidered in Boston's affordability squeeze
summary: Boston's inclusionary zoning policy, requiring 13% of new rental units to be affordable, is being reevaluated amid a luxury construction boom. While the policy has helped some low-income residents, experts argue it limits the construction of middle-income housing and fails to address the city's housing crisis. The city is considering changes to the policy, including allowing developers to build affordable properties elsewhere or pay into a housing fund instead of including cheaper units onsite. The goal is to balance economic inclusion with the need for affordable housing, with some developers suggesting that donating to a housing fund could be a more efficient way to build affordable units.

images.alt_text: The luxury project on the Upper West Side in Manhattan that gained attention last year for having an income- restricted rental component with a second entrance that became known as a "poor door".

site_title: China chip maker prepares US$23b bid for Micron: WSJ
summary: China's state-backed technology conglomerate Tsinghua Unigroup is preparing a $23 billion bid for US memory chip maker Micron Technology, the largest Chinese takeover of a US company. The bid, valued at $21 per share, is a 19.3% premium to Micron's closing price on Monday. A successful bid would consolidate Tsinghua Unigroup's position in China's technological development and acquire Micron's cutting-edge memory manufacturing technology. The deal must pass review by the US Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States for national security implications.

site_title: Challenges for new SGX CEO to boldly tackle
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) CEO Loh Boon Chye faces significant challenges to transform the local bourse, including increasing investor participation, improving liquidity, and enhancing market integrity. The new CEO must address concerns about the market's lack of investor confidence, the need for better advisory services, and the lack of transparency in regulatory matters. To boost growth, SGX should consider a commercial model, facilitating mergers and acquisitions, and exploring opportunities in emerging markets like India and Africa. Discontinuing its regulatory role could also help the exchange focus on its own growth and balance the needs of all stakeholders.

site_title: Surpassing expectations
summary: The Hatten Group of Companies, led by Colin Tan June Teng, has launched an Investment Tour program to allow potential clients in Singapore to visit and experience its core developments in Melaka, Johor, and Negeri Sembilan. The free tour aims to give buyers an up-close look at the project sites and interact with the target market, understanding their goals and concerns. The company plans to consider listing within the next few years, following the tour's success.

site_title: Lian Beng: IDs quit over computation of exec directors' performance bonus
summary: Two independent directors at Lian Beng, including MP Sitoh Yih Pin, have resigned due to disagreements over the computation of their executive directors' performance bonuses. The directors wanted the bonuses to be calculated based on the group profit after minority interests, while the company has historically used the pre-minority interest basis. Lian Beng has confirmed that its external auditor has verified the computation of the 2014 bonus, and the company will engage an independent professional party to review the matter.

site_title: Handphones in operating theatres pose danger in US hospitals
summary: US hospitals are facing a growing concern about cellphone use in operating rooms, with experts warning that distractions can lead to medical errors and patient safety issues. Despite no federal regulations or industry-wide quality measures, some physicians and medical groups are calling for clear rules on phone use in the OR. Incidents, such as a 2011 case where an anesthesiologist's inattention led to a patient's death, have highlighted the risks. As more hospitals develop policies, experts emphasize the need for specific, enforceable directives to ensure patient safety.

site_title: Growing with the nation
summary: Singapore-based property agency OrangeTee has built a reputation for trust and innovation, leveraging the country's reputation as a trustworthy nation to expand its business globally. The company, which employs over 2,100 associates, prioritizes trust over commercial gain and has implemented various technologies to support its sales force. With a diversified business strategy, OrangeTee aims to provide comprehensive services to its customers and business partners, both in Singapore and Southeast Asia. The company's commitment to innovation and trust has paid dividends, with a low number of complaint cases and complimentary letters for good service.

site_title: The economic miracle
summary: The article discusses various economic and business news. The US saw a drop in weekly jobless claims, while China announced new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Reliance Jio, led by Ambani, delayed its India IPO beyond this year. China urged South-east Asian countries to support openness as US tariffs loom, and Myanmar's election was deemed non-priority by ASEAN. These developments highlight the ongoing economic and trade tensions in the region.

site_title: Greek debt deja vu looming in Puerto Rico
summary: Puerto Rico's US$72 billion debt is deemed "not payable" by Governor Alejandro Garcia Padilla, drawing parallels with Greece's financial crisis. However, unlike Greece, Puerto Rico's status as a US Commonwealth may not be affected by its financial problems. Both islands face similar structural issues, including excessive borrowing, bloated welfare systems, and human flight, leading to economic contraction and high unemployment. Puerto Rico's politicians are seeking federal bankruptcy protection, but will need to implement major reforms to restructure its financial obligations and economic systems.

site_title: Noble appoints David Yeow as independent non-exec director
summary: NOBLE Group has appointed David Yeow as an independent non-executive director with immediate effect. Yeow, an independent non-executive director of Bund Center Investment, brings extensive experience in Singapore's financial sector, including as a primary external legal adviser to the Singapore International Monetary Exchange Ltd. His appointment comes as Noble Group faces criticism over its accounting practices and lack of transparency, and the company has set up an independent board committee to oversee its operations. The appointment is seen as a positive step for the commodities trader.

site_title: M'sia visitor arrivals down 9% in Q1 despite weak ringgit
summary: Malaysia's tourism sector is expected to contract this year, with visitor arrivals down 9% in the first quarter to 6.48 million, despite a weaker ringgit. The decline is attributed to several factors, including aviation tragedies and a shrinking ringgit, which has made imported goods expensive. Arrivals from top markets China, Australia, and Singapore were significantly lower, while South Korea saw an 11% rise. The national carrier Malaysia Airlines has cut routes and reduced frequency, and a recent riot in Kuala Lumpur's main tourist belt may further deter visitors.

site_title: Grexit averted for now, but Greece faces political woes
summary: Greece has reached a deal with eurozone leaders on a new financial package, worth 62 billion euros, in exchange for significant austerity measures. The agreement, which was agreed upon after a 17-hour meeting, may cap off a five-month period of brinkmanship between the Syriza-led government and its creditors. However, the deal's passage remains uncertain, and the Greek government faces a turbulent period ahead, with potential for a government collapse or a second general election. The deal's implications are unclear, and the Greek economy remains in intensive care, with significant debt deadlines and financial turmoil.

site_title: Trump's golf empire gets hit as bigwigs keep safe distance
summary: Donald Trump's golf empire is facing backlash after he made negative comments about Mexican immigrants, leading to the PGA of America canceling a major golf tournament at one of his courses. The LPGA has also considered moving the Women's British Open from a Trump-owned course in Scotland. Singer Ricky Martin canceled a charity event at a Trump-licensed course in Puerto Rico, which filed for bankruptcy. Industry analysts warn that Trump's comments may deter weekend golfers from playing at his courses, potentially damaging his brand and net worth.

site_title: Building the economy
summary: Singapore's strong manufacturing base has enabled rapid industrialization, accounting for about a fifth of the country's GDP. The sector has broadened across multiple industries, with about one in six labor force members working in manufacturing. The Economic Development Board (EDB) played a crucial role in establishing Jurong Industrial Estate, transforming the area into a hub for factories producing various goods. This led to the growth of related businesses, with companies such as Vibrant Group and Tat Hong Holdings experiencing success, and the sector showing healthy growth in 2014, with a 0.9% increase in the manufacturing sector.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Airport of Thailand plans to complete airport expansion and development works within the next two years. IPS Securex may participate in tenders for US TSA-certified baggage and cargo scanners, potentially worth US$250 million, boosting its earnings. The company's PepperBall non-lethal countermeasure technology has been validated by several countries, expected to trigger larger orders and boost earnings. Tiger Airways Holdings is poised to see its earnings recover firmly this year, driven by higher yields and lower jet fuel costs, with projected full-year profits of S$39 million and S$55 million in FY16 and FY17 respectively.

site_title: Euro rebounds but it's still near 6-week lows
summary: The euro rebounded 0.3% against the dollar to US$1.10275, but remains near six-week lows, following a sharp decline on Monday after Greece agreed to a bailout deal. Oil prices rose, and the Canadian dollar hit a four-month low. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike is expected later this year, driving the euro lower, according to strategists. The euro's recovery may be short-lived unless the Greek bailout deal is approved or the Fed's expectations are revised.

site_title: Greek default: No financial impact on Singapore
summary: Singapore has not experienced any financial impact from Greece's default on a US$1.7 billion IMF loan, with the country's financial exposure being to the IMF, not to Greece. Monetary Authority of Singapore board member Lawrence Wong stated that Singapore's loan commitment under the IMF's 2012 Borrowing Arrangements has not been activated, as the IMF has sufficient financial resources. The crisis is expected to have a small impact on Singapore's trade and banking system assets, but there is a risk of broader economic consequences if Greece exits the eurozone.

site_title: Crude slides as Iran clinches historic nuclear deal
summary: Iran and six global powers have reached a historic nuclear deal, easing sanctions against Tehran and paving the way for a gradual increase in its oil exports. This agreement is expected to lead to a rise in global crude supply, causing oil prices to drop. Crude futures fell 35 cents to $57.50 per barrel, while US crude prices declined 8 cents to $52.12 per barrel. Analysts predict it will take Iran months to ramp up its export capacity, but a modest initial increase could further lower oil prices, which are already oversupplied due to Saudi Arabia's record-high output.

site_title: GIC invests US$42m in Brazil mall
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, GIC, has invested US$41.89 million in a minority stake in Via Parque Shopping, a mall in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The 35% equity stake is part of GIC's push into Latin America's largest economy, following investments in a Brazilian hospital chain and education company. This investment aims to increase real estate assets in its portfolio, currently at 7% of its US$100 billion assets, to 9-13%.

site_title: Uber out of the running to buy Nokia mapping unit: sources
summary: Uber has dropped out of talks to acquire Nokia's mapping unit, Here, due to a lack of interest from other potential buyers. The Finnish company had submitted an offer of up to $3 billion, but negotiations have focused on a deal between Nokia and a consortium of German carmakers, including BMW, Audi, and Mercedes-Benz. The carmakers, which rely on Here's digital mapping division, want to acquire the unit for less than $4 billion, a sticking point in the negotiations. The sale may push back until August, and the deal could still fall through or Uber could jump back in.

site_title: Use painkillers sparingly, US doctors urge
summary: US doctors urge Americans to use painkillers like Motrin IB, Aleve, and Celebrex sparingly due to growing evidence of increased risk of heart attack, stroke, and heart failure. The FDA warns that even small amounts of these non-aspirin pain relievers, or NSAIDs, pose a risk. Experts estimate the increased risk varies from 10% to 50% depending on the dose and individual factors, with people over 65 and those with heart disease being especially cautious.

site_title: India wholesale prices fall for 8 straight months
summary: India's wholesale inflation rate fell 2.4% in June, its eighth consecutive decline, due to weak global oil prices and above-average monsoon rains. The Wholesale Price Index (WPI) measure indicates a decrease from a year earlier, with the government statistics ministry reporting the result. This marks a steady drop in inflation, which has been driven down by external factors.

site_title: London shipping week draws more interest
summary: Singapore's shipping week has seen another successful year, with a focus on clustering conferences and maritime-related events. The event has been compared to other successful shipping events such as Posidonia and Nor-Shipping. This format appears to be effective in contributing to the sector's development. Keynote speaker Singapore Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew will speak at LISW15 Conference on September 10.

site_title: Vietnam coffee growers hoarding most beans in 5 yrs
summary: Vietnam coffee growers are storing the most beans in at least five years, holding 28% of the world's largest robusta crop. Unsold inventories total 440,000 tonnes, with prices rising 9.3% in June and reaching a two-month high in Vietnam. However, surging stockpiles may drive prices lower when the next harvest starts in October. Farmers are waiting for higher prices, with local prices needing to reach 40,000 dong to encourage selling, down from 36,800 dong in June.

site_title: Pop composer who penned hits for Diana Ross, Whitney Houston dies at 74
summary: Michael Masser, a renowned pop composer who penned hits for Whitney Houston, Diana Ross, and other top vocalists, has died at 74 due to complications from a stroke. Masser's career took off after he switched from being a stockbroker to pursuing music, with his first major success coming in 1973 with the song "Touch Me in the Morning," which revitalized Diana Ross's career. He went on to collaborate with Whitney Houston, producing chart-topping singles such as "The Greatest Love of All" and "Didn't We Almost Have It All." Masser was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 2007.

site_title: Stocks finish mixed in quiet trading
summary: Stocks in Singapore closed mixed on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) ending with a net gain of 5.28 points at 3,316.50, despite initial gains. Trading was quiet, with low turnover of 1.2 billion units worth S$892 million. Key movers included Singtel and DBS Group, while CEFC International surged 76.5% on Monday but declined on Tuesday. The market is awaiting developments on Greece's austerity measures, with Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras set to face Parliament on Wednesday. Analysts predict a possible 20% correction in global markets, driven by price-earnings retracement, but believe China is undergoing a correction rather than a systemic bear phase.

site_title: Indonesia holds rate steady to prop falling rupiah
summary: Indonesia's central bank kept its main interest rate steady at 7.5% for a fifth month, citing inflation above 7% and a current-account deficit, making monetary easing difficult. The decision aims to keep inflation within the 3-5% target range. The rupiah fell 0.3% to 13,338 against the dollar, while the benchmark stock index rose 0.2%. The central bank expects to achieve its inflation target in 2015, despite predicting a slow growth pace in the second quarter.

site_title: NauticAWT launches IPO for Catalist listing
summary: NauticAWT, an oil & gas engineering solutions provider, has launched an initial public offering (IPO) for a Catalist listing to raise S$2.8 million. The company aims to use the funds for expansion, capital expenditure, and working capital. NauticAWT offers a range of engineering services and contracting solutions for the upstream oil & gas sector, with a focus on mature field developments and abandonment projects. The IPO is the fourth Catalist listing this year, and the company expects to be listed on the Catalist board on July 23.

images.alt_text: NauticAWT is well-positioned to be a beneficiary of the South-east Asian market, says founder and CEO John Gronbech.

site_title: Mobius stepping down as chief of Templeton fund
summary: Mark Mobius, a pioneer in emerging-market investing, will step down as lead manager of the Templeton Emerging Markets Investment Trust on October 1. Carlos Hardenberg will take over, supporting Mobius as portfolio manager. Mobius, 78, will remain chairman of the Templeton Emerging Markets Group. The fund has trailed its benchmarks in recent years, with a 0.3% annual decline over the past five years. Mobius has been credited with using value-driven and long-term investment strategies, but the fund's performance has slipped.

site_title: Scene set for Tiger Airways' decisive turnaround: CEO
summary: Tiger Airways' CEO, Lee Lik Hsin, sees the integration with Singapore Airlines (SIA) as key to the budget carrier's turnaround and future growth. SIA has taken a 55.8% stake in Tiger, providing scale and connectivity. Despite registering a loss of S$264 million in FY15, Tiger plans to form partnerships, including with Scoot, to drive growth. The airline aims to leverage synergies in commercial, operational, and other areas with SIA, with potential cost efficiencies and revenue synergies.

site_title: Premier League has no say in how pay-TV operators price broadcasts: EPL chief
summary: English Premier League (EPL) executive chairman Richard Scudamore stated that the league has no control over how pay-TV operators price broadcasts, despite the high cost of watching EPL matches on pay-TV. The EPL spent nearly S$400 million to secure exclusive broadcast rights in Singapore in 2010, and UK broadcasters Sky and BT recently paid over £5.1 billion (S$10.6 billion) for a record British TV rights deal. Scudamore attributed the high costs to the rights holders, saying they have no say in how much they charge for the broadcasts.

images.alt_text: Arsenal players (left to right) Santi Cazorla, Olivier Giroud and Mesut Oezil are playing in the Barclays Asia Trophy, a tournament which is among the Premier League's many plans to expand its reach and brand in Asia.

site_title: Resale prices of private apartments, condos inch up again in June
summary: Resale prices of private apartments and condos in Singapore have increased for the second straight month, according to SRX Property. The price index for such homes in June was 1.6% lower year-on-year, with non-landed private residential resale prices dropping 7.1% in Core Central Region and 2.3% in Outside Central Region. However, prices in the city fringe region rose 6%.

site_title: Worst-case outcomes still possible after marathon Greek talks
summary: Greek marathon talks have ended with no deal, exposing deep fissures between euro area debtors and creditors. The harsh terms imposed by the EU on Greece, including austerity measures and increased privatization, have raised concerns about the country's ability to meet its debt obligations. The situation has led to increased tensions between Germany, France, and the US, with some calling for a more lenient approach to Greece. The Greek government faces a high risk of collapse, with the possibility of a parallel currency or departure from the euro.

site_title: Japan carmakers sticking to Indonesia sales targets
summary: Japan's top carmakers, Honda, Nissan, and Mazda, are sticking to sales targets in Indonesia despite a 6-year low sales decline, offering steep discounts to entice consumers. Sales have fallen 18% in 2015, with car sales serving as a key indicator of consumption in the country, where the economy is growing at its slowest since 2009. To boost sales, carmakers are offering discounts on down payments, low-interest loans, and extended instalment periods, with Honda aiming for a 10% sales increase.

site_title: HK developer offers £230m for stake in UK landlord
summary: Hong Kong real estate developer Samuel Tak Lee has offered £230m to buy a 9.3% stake in UK landlord Shaftesbury Plc, which owns over 580 restaurants and stores in London's West End. The offer is valued at almost £230m and would give the Lee family a 13.2% stake in the company. The bid comes as rents in the West End are expected to rise due to increased competition from overseas retailers and the upcoming opening of Crossrail in 2018.

site_title: China forecast to tip world into recession
summary: China's slowdown is predicted to drag global growth below 2%, potentially tipping the world into a recession, according to Morgan Stanley executive Ruchir Sharma. China's economy will continue to slow due to its struggle to reduce debt, with a 2 percentage-point slowdown sufficient to cause a global recession. This would be the first global slump without the US contracting in 50 years. The International Monetary Fund has also cut its forecast for global growth to 3.3% this year, citing weakness in the US and challenges in China's transition to a new growth model.

site_title: Infamous Japan activist makes comeback
summary: Yoshiaki Murakami, Japan's infamous activist shareholder, is making a comeback after being convicted of insider trading in 2007. He is teaming up with his 27-year-old daughter to push for Kuroda Electric Co to return more to shareholders. They aim to install four outside directors, including Murakami, on the board. The proposal is set to be voted on at an Aug 28 extraordinary meeting, with one former president already expressing support.

site_title: The laziness dogma
summary: US workers put in nearly 30% more hours than their German counterparts, largely due to fewer weeks of paid leave. Jeb Bush claims Americans need to work longer hours to double economic growth, echoing the "laziness dogma" prevalent among conservatives, which blames a large number of Americans for not working due to government programs. This dogma was also behind Mitt Romney's 47% remark and attacks on unemployment benefits and food stamps. Critics argue that many disability recipients are genuinely ill, with Senator Rand Paul stating that over half are anxious or hurt.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SOILBUILD Business Space Reit reported a 7.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.615 Singapore cents for Q2, up 6.1% for the six months. Net property income rose 19.0% to S$16.7 million in Q2 and 15.1% to S$32.5 million for the half year period. GREAT Eastern Holdings' subsidiary subscribed for an additional S$22.38 million in LGlobal Funds. VIVA Industrial Trust signed an MOU to acquire 30 Pioneer Road, pending corporate approvals.

site_title: Regulations a top concern among local insurance industry players: survey
summary: Singapore's insurance industry is most concerned about the country's regulatory environment, according to a survey by the Centre for the Study of Financial Innovation and PwC. This is the top risk in the global insurance sector, according to the "Insurance Banana Skins 2015" survey. The survey was conducted in March and April 2015.

site_title: Hard to find silver lining for EM currencies: Bank of Singapore report
summary: Bank of Singapore reports that lower carry costs and the battle against low inflation will weaken the Singapore dollar, Korean won, and New Taiwan dollar. Policymakers may introduce measures to limit currency strength, citing recent moves in Korea and Thailand. This comes as inflation remains below central banks' targets and the external outlook remains sluggish.

site_title: Blackstone unit selling 1,300 Atlanta houses amid shift in strategy
summary: Blackstone's Invitation Homes is selling approximately 1,300 Atlanta-area houses, marking the largest bulk sale for the 3-year-old company. The sale is part of a shift in strategy, focusing on higher-rent communities and quality schools, as the company seeks to fine-tune its portfolio and increase profitability. Invitation Homes will retain around 48,000 properties, with most of the sold homes valued under $200,000. The sale is expected to help the company prepare for a potential initial public offering, which Blackstone has said could happen within the next two years.

site_title: Lower oil prices to slightly boost global growth: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) reports that lower oil prices are expected to modestly boost global growth by about 0.5 percentage points in 2015-2016. The IMF attributes the decline in oil prices to increased production rather than weakening demand. While the positive effect of lower oil prices is expected to support global growth, other shocks, such as a slowdown in emerging-market economies, are expected to offset this effect. The IMF also notes that a substantial part of the price decline is expected to persist in the medium term.

site_title: Retail investors more upbeat about markets but stay hesitant
summary: Singapore retail investors show a more positive outlook for the global economy and markets, with a 3-point increase in the JP Morgan Investor Confidence Index to 116. Despite this, 52% of respondents plan to maintain or decrease their investment amount, citing concerns over the stock market and US interest rates. 53% of investors expect the Straits Times Index to rise, while 77% of income-seekers aim for a 4% yield. Investors are shifting towards multi-asset and balanced funds to diversify risks, and are increasing allocations to equity funds and bonds.

site_title: Riding on a wave of urbanisation
summary: Tat Hong Holdings, a 60-year-old Singapore-based heavy equipment supplier, is restructuring its business to capitalize on Asia's infrastructure development amid a slowdown in the global economy. The company, which serves customers in industries such as construction, engineering, and infrastructure, has a fleet of over 1,500 cranes and operates in 10 countries. Tat Hong is looking to reduce capital expenditure, streamline operations, and hire the right talent to ensure long-term success. The company's managing director, Roland Ng, sees opportunities in Asia's rapid urbanization and infrastructure development, particularly with the establishment of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank.

site_title: US carmakers' wage talks with union start on high note
summary: US carmakers General Motors, Ford, and Fiat Chrysler have begun contract talks with the United Auto Workers union, starting on a positive note amid rising sales and profits. The talks aim to address wage disparities between veteran workers and entry-level jobs, as well as healthcare costs and production shifts to lower-wage nations. Industry executives expect the companies to avoid wage hikes, but analysts predict a contract that may result in mild wage inflation. The union seeks wage increases, greater job security, and a closer pay gap between veteran workers and new hires.

site_title: Varoufakis says he quit because he felt marginalised
summary: Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis resigned after feeling marginalized within his own government during talks with eurozone creditors over a debt rescue. He cited a lack of engagement from his peers, saying they responded to his economic arguments with "blank stares." Varoufakis proposed a plan to fight back against the European Central Bank, but Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras failed to support it. The resignation came after Greece won a referendum on rejecting creditors' bailout terms, leading to a surprise agreement on a eurozone bailout deal just days later.

site_title: House briefs
summary: Singapore Parliament: 32 coffee shops have changed hands since Jan 2010, with 10 below S$5 million, 12 between S$5-10 million, and 8 between S$10-15 million. The government plans to build 62 eating houses in the next three years. The annual foreign workforce growth rate in Singapore has moderated from 19% in 2007 to 3% in 2014, with the government aiming to maintain a foreign workforce share of about a third.

site_title: Facebook sets speed record for breaching US$250b market cap
summary: Facebook has reached a market value of over $250 billion, surpassing the previous record held by Google, which took about eight years to achieve. This milestone was reached after a 2.4% climb in the company's market value, making it the first company in the Standard & Poor's 500 Index to breach this threshold.

site_title: Miserable Q2 S'pore GDP prompts shaving of full-year forecasts
summary: The Singapore economy contracted 4.6% in the second quarter, its worst performance since 2001, with a broad-based decline in manufacturing, services, and construction sectors. This resulted in a year-on-year GDP growth of 1.7%, slower than expectations. Several banks revised down their full-year GDP forecasts, with economists predicting a narrow growth range of 2-3% or even lower. The Monetary Authority of Singapore may consider easing monetary policies in October, but economists remain cautious due to external uncertainties, including China's economic slowdown and Greece's euro woes.

site_title: The art of work
summary: Chez Design, a Singapore-based interior design firm, has built a reputation for providing high-quality design services to corporate clients. Founded in 1986 by CEO Eddy Lim, the company has expanded its client base to include big and small corporates across Asia and globally. Lim's unique approach combines his work as an office interior designer with his hobby as an artist, resulting in masterpieces that are framed and hung in client offices. The company's success is attributed to its focus on quality, after-sales service, and a transparent business environment.

site_title: New ETFs evolving, but investors slow to warm to them
summary: New exchange-traded funds (ETFs) are being introduced to cater to investors' needs, but many are being ignored. Actively traded ETFs have fallen into this category, indicating investors are slow to adopt these new products. Despite the growing popularity of ETFs, it remains to be seen whether they will gain traction.

site_title: Nam Cheong, Roxy-Pacific issue bonds totalling S$135m
summary: Singapore's local bond market has seen a surge in liquidity with two deals worth S$135 million announced, as Greece struck a bailout deal and Chinese stock markets stabilized. Offshore support vessel builder Nam Cheong issued S$75 million 3-year fixed rate notes at 6.5% and property group Roxy-Pacific issued S$60 million 3-year fixed rate notes at 4.5%. The deals were well-received, with orders exceeding S$125 million, and are expected to help refinance existing borrowings. Bankers say the local bond market is looking better, but investors remain cautious due to the uncertain global economic outlook.

site_title: Reit dividend growth outlook dismal: HSBC
summary: HSBC's senior property analyst Pratik Burman Ray expects Reit dividend growth to slow down in the next few years due to unfavorable supply and demand factors across various property sub-segments, including office, retail, hospitality, and industrial sectors. The two-year distributions per unit (DPU) are projected to grow 2% from 2015-2017, compared to an average of 4.5% from 2007-2014. Consolidation among Reits is possible but uncertain due to management challenges, and the analyst suggests the ideal market cap for Reits is between $2-2.5 billion.

site_title: Microsoft plans celebratory debut of Windows 10
summary: Microsoft plans a celebratory debut of Windows 10, a new operating software designed for various devices, on July 29. The software will be available as a free upgrade for Windows 7 and 8.1 users worldwide, with pre-installed versions on compatible computers and tablets. The company aims to reach 1 billion devices installed by 2018. Special events will be held in 13 cities worldwide to celebrate the software's release and thank the 5 million Windows Insiders who participated in the test period.

site_title: Sanctions go, but Iran must wait for economic recovery
summary: Iran has lifted nuclear-related sanctions, paving the way for international companies to invest in the country. However, Iran needs billions of dollars in investment to boost its economy, which has been stagnant due to a decade of sanctions and economic difficulties. The country's market and educated workforce are attractive opportunities for investors, but the lifting of sanctions will take time, with sanctions relief expected to occur by early 2016. Iran's energy sector is a key target for investment, with the government aiming to attract $100 billion in foreign investment to modernize the sector.

site_title: No quick recovery for Singapore property market: seminar
summary: Singapore's property market is unlikely to stage a major rebound even with potential relaxation of cooling measures, according to market watchers. A "new normal" of slower growth and stagnation risks looms, with employment growth contracting and loans growth slowing. Experts warn that the private housing inventory and rising vacancy rate will not abate soon, and prices will not recover quickly. The economy's shift towards lower growth and productivity decline also supports this outlook, with interest rates expected to rise in the US, potentially impacting the Sibor.

site_title: Europe fails to shake off deflation threat
summary: Europe is struggling to overcome deflation, with prices falling in Sweden, remaining flat in Britain, and barely increasing in Germany and Italy. Central banks across the continent are failing to boost inflation despite implementing low interest rates and money-printing. This poses a challenge to policymakers as they aim to stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Hedge funds reassess China after market rout
summary: Foreign hedge funds reassess their investment in China after a market rout, with trillions of dollars in value lost over the last month. The Shanghai market plunged by more than a third, prompting the Chinese government to issue aggressive moves to prop up the market. This reversal comes after a period where foreign investors were able to buy and sell shares listed in the Shanghai market directly, marking a significant opening into China. The market's sudden downturn has led to a reevaluation of investment strategies in the country.

site_title: UK inflation slips back to zero in June
summary: UK inflation slipped back to zero in June, with food and summer clothing prices falling, according to official figures. This marks the lowest rate in more than half a century. The Bank of England had previously predicted the rate would bounce back, but the latest data suggests a continued downward trend.

site_title: Billionaire Pritzker brothers buy Starbucks coffee-sleeve maker
summary: Billionaire brothers Anthony and Jay Pritzker, heirs of the Hyatt Hotels Corp and Marmon Holdings Inc fortune, have acquired LBP Manufacturing Inc, a Chicago-based company that produces sustainable packaging, including Starbucks' coffee sleeves. The terms of the deal were not disclosed. The Pritzker Group, an investment firm, aims to acquire family-owned companies to preserve corporate legacies, a strategy that aligns with growing impact investments focused on clean energy and sustainable agriculture.

site_title: Greece needs far more relief than discussed so far: IMF study
summary: Greece needs significantly more debt relief than previously discussed, according to a leaked IMF study, which calls for a 30-year debt grace period and dramatic maturity extension. The study's warning comes as Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras struggles to secure a new bailout deal, with European countries unwilling to lend more money. Germany's Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble has suggested Athens might be forced to leave the eurozone temporarily, while the IMF estimates debt relief on a scale beyond current proposals would be needed to address Greece's debt sustainability.

images.alt_text: The Greek (left) and EU flags fluttering in front of Maximos Mansion, the Prime Minister's office, in Athens on Monday.

site_title: A dream to hit 10,000
summary: Singapore's largest property agency ERA has expanded its workforce to over 6,000 registered salespersons despite weak property market sentiments. The company aims to reach 10,000 agents, a feat made challenging by the closure of over 50 agencies and 4,000 real estate agents in the last year. ERA's adaptability, training, and technology investments have enabled it to stay ahead of the industry, with a 10.6% increase in profit after tax last year. The company's focus on providing solutions to clients' real estate needs and its commitment to community service have contributed to its success.

site_title: Smarter regulation needed for Indian aviation sector: Iata
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has urged the Indian government to reconsider cumbersome regulations and high costs affecting the country's domestic airlines, which are expected to turn in an overall loss this year. IATA chief Tony Tyler called for lighter tax burdens, reduced airport charges, and smarter regulation to make the aviation sector more competitive and profitable. The industry has long complained of crippling costs, and new players like Vistara and AirAsia India have lobbied for changes to legislation such as the 5/20 rule.

site_title: US import, export prices slip in June
summary: US import prices fell 0.1% in June, marking the 11th consecutive decline, as the strong dollar offset rising costs for petroleum products. The decline was lower than forecast and follows a 10.0% drop in the 12 months through June. Import prices excluding petroleum rose 0.2% due to the dollar's strength. Meanwhile, export prices fell 0.2% in June, with a 5.7% drop in the 12 months through June, as the US dollar gains against its trading partners.

images.alt_text: US import prices unexpectedly fell in June as the lingering effects of a strong dollar offset rising costs for petroleum products, keeping imported inflation pressure under wraps.

site_title: Investors' cash holdings highest since Lehman: BoA Merrill poll
summary: Global investors raised cash holdings to 5.5% in July, the highest since December 2008, amid China's stock market plunge and Greek crisis. They cut emerging market equity exposure and reduced eurozone stocks, while taking out more protection against stock price falls. This is seen as a bullish signal for equities, with some investors even increasing US equity allocations. However, expectations for global economic growth have decreased, with a net 42% of respondents forecasting weaker growth over the next 12 months.

site_title: Rocket Internet tumbles most since IPO on convertible-bond sale
summary: Rocket Internet shares plummet 16% to 34.03 euros after selling convertible bonds that can be converted to stock. The bonds, worth 10.2 million shares, will have a 7-year maturity and a conversion premium of 32.5-47.5%. The sale aims to raise funds for investing in companies, expanding into food delivery and fashion, and becoming the world's largest internet platform outside the US and China.

site_title: US: Stocks little changed as retail sales fall
summary: US stocks opened little changed on Tuesday, following a 0.3% drop in June retail sales and mixed bank earnings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 11.49 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index were flat and up 0.08 point and 0.13%, respectively. JPMorgan Chase rose 0.6% after a 5.2% earnings increase, while Wells Fargo advanced 0.1% on flat earnings. The decline in retail sales trimmed the Commerce Department's estimate for May's gain to 1.0%.

site_title: Americans more successful, confident seeking credit: Fed survey
summary: Americans reported higher success rates in securing credit, with 19% rejection rates for mortgages, auto loans, and higher credit card limits, down from 25% previously. Successful credit applications reached a new high, while discouraged Americans fell to record lows. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York survey found Americans more active in seeking loans over the coming year, with a focus on credit growth.

site_title: EU steps up pressure for rapid deal to revive asset-backed debt
summary: The European Union is pushing for a rapid deal to revive its asset-backed debt market, which stalled after the financial crisis. EU officials aim to propose a binding draft law by late September, which would make it easier for companies to raise cash from financial markets. A capital markets union, or CMU, is seen as a key plank of the plan, and a deal could be reached by Christmas. However, a proposal to lighten EU rules for companies listing bonds and shares is expected in November.

site_title: US retail sales unexpectedly weak in June
summary: US retail sales unexpectedly fell 0.3% in June, the weakest reading since February, as households cut back on purchases of automobiles and other goods. This data, combined with the disappointing employment report and sharp drop in small business confidence, may suggest the economy has lost momentum at the end of the second quarter. The weak retail sales data could also cast doubts on a possible September interest rate hike from the Federal Reserve.

site_title: S$20m in government projects open up for Singapore tech firms
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Development Authority (IDA) has created $20 million in government project opportunities for tech firms under its Accreditation@IDA programme within a year of its launch. The programme aims to help accredited firms build their credentials and accelerate growth. Five tech companies, including video analytics firms and secure file-sharing platforms, have secured projects with government agencies. IDA plans to expand the programme to include robotics, new sensors, and autonomous vehicles by March 2016. Meanwhile, two Singaporean startups have secured Series B funding, with fastacash raising $15 million and social dating app Paktor raising $10 million.

site_title: Adapting to the environment
summary: Vibrant Group, a Singapore-based logistics and warehousing company, has expanded into complementary property and financial services. Founded in 1981 as Freight Links Express Holdings, the company has grown to become one of the leading logistics players in Singapore, handling toxic, corrosive, and flammable chemical cargoes. The company has also ventured into real estate and financial services, including a public housing project in China and a Syariah-compliant real estate investment trust (Reit). With record revenues of S$191.4 million and net profit of S$42.7 million in its last financial year, Vibrant Group aims to stay competitive by adapting to changing market circumstances and identifying suitable people for its various business arms.

site_title: Greece faces ECB deadline Monday as EU engineers bridge fund
summary: European finance ministers are struggling to find a solution to Greece's debt crisis, with options deemed financially inadequate, politically unpalatable, or legally suspect. Greece faces a deadline to pay the European Central Bank 3.5 billion euros on Monday and has a larger bailout package of 86 billion euros in the works.
