Refinery crude runs rose by 65,000 barrels per day, but utilization rates fell. US crude imports fell by 197,000 barrels per day. The unexpected increases in stockpiles sent futures prices tumbling.

site_title: AirAsia shares tumble on fears Indonesia affiliate could be grounded
summary: AirAsia shares plummeted 15% after Indonesia's transport ministry ordered its Jakarta-based affiliate, Indonesia AirAsia, to raise at least $230 million to reverse a shareholder funds deficit by July 31. The airline faces shutdown if it fails to meet the deadline, which has already been hit in recent weeks by accounting questions. The directive has sparked concerns about AirAsia's financial stability, with analysts estimating the parent company's stock fell nearly $140 million on Wednesday.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC expects lower sales in Q2
summary: STATS ChipPAC expects Q2 net revenues to be 15-17% lower compared to the same period last year, mainly due to sluggish demand in the semiconductor industry. The company attributed this decline to weaker smartphone sales in emerging markets, product transitions in high-end smartphones, and reduced demand from the personal computer segment. STATS ChipPAC will be acquired by Jiangsu Changjiang Electronics Technology Co, a Chinese electronics packaging service provider, in a takeover aimed at taking the company private.

site_title: None of the frozen accounts belongs to Najib, says Malaysia's AG
summary: Malaysia's Attorney General Abdul Gani Patail clarified that none of the frozen bank accounts involving six accounts issued on Monday belonged to Prime Minister Najib Razak. The leak of documents related to an ongoing investigation by the special task force raised concerns about the integrity of the investigation. Patail expressed concern over the leakage and alleged insinuations linking him to certain political agendas, vowing to prosecute anyone found to have leaked confidential documents. The leak was also endorsed by Bank Negara Malaysia and other officials.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index losing 16.47 points to close at 1,695.83. Over 2 billion lots valued at RM2.26 billion were traded, with 117 gainers and 828 losers.

site_title: Centurion bond investors brave volatile markets
summary: Centurion Corp priced its S$65 million 3-year bonds at 5.25% amid volatile market conditions, with orders reaching S$130 million. The deal was the first Singapore dollar bond issue since last week, with private banks taking 70% of the deal. Despite market volatility, investors focused on fundamentals, as bonds tend to perform better in bear markets due to their fixed income and shorter lifespan. This is Centurion Corp's second bond sale, following a S$100 million issue in 2013.

site_title: AirAsia X files complaint with regulator over GMT Research report
summary: Malaysian budget airline AirAsia X has filed a complaint with the Securities Commission against Hong Kong-based GMT Research over a report questioning AirAsia X's accounting practices. The report alleged that AirAsia X shifted profits through transfer pricing, but AirAsia X denies the claims, calling them "untrue, misleading, and inaccurate." GMT Research maintains that it only conducts research and allows investors to make their own decisions. The complaint follows a decline in shares of both airlines since the report was published.

site_title: PM Lee 'very worried' that problem causing train breakdown may recur
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed concern that the root cause of the recent train breakdown may recur due to the lack of identification. The power trip that disrupted train services on the North-South and East-West Lines for over two hours has not been isolated, leaving tens of thousands of commuters stranded. Lee visited the SMRT Bishan Depot and the LTA Ops Centre to assess the situation, and hopes that the faults will be identified and resolved quickly to prevent further inconvenience.

site_title: Raising the bar to 20¢ - boon or doom?
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has introduced a minimum trading price (MTP) rule of 20 Singapore cents, effective March 2016, for companies listed on its mainboard. Firms unable to meet this requirement may be placed on the SGX watch-list for a three-year period, with those not meeting the MTP after that period facing compulsory delisting. Companies can consider share consolidation or transferring to the Catalist listing platform, which has more flexible rules and lower requirements. As of May, 26 mainboard companies had consolidated their shares, but 214 still traded below 20 Singapore cents, raising concerns about the effectiveness of the MTP rule.

images.alt_text: If SGX--listed companies are unable to meet the 20-cent minimum trading price requirement, they face being delisted.

site_title: US: Stocks drop as China equity slump deepens
summary: US stocks dropped in opening trade on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 121.79 points (0.69%) to 17,655.12. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, with losses of 13.04 (0.63%) and 36.14 (0.72%), respectively. The decline was attributed to concerns about China's economy, which saw a significant slump in its equity markets, further exacerbating global market volatility.

site_title: Australia: Shares tumble 2% on China, Greece woes
summary: Australian shares fell 2% on Wednesday due to concerns over China's equity rout and Greece's potential bailout deal. A weaker dollar and iron ore price slump also contributed to the decline. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5,469.5 points, down 111.9 points from the previous close. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index fell 0.6%. The decline marks the 4th consecutive session of volatility for the Australian market.

site_title: Singapore: China's crash hits local stocks
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.7% to 3,284.99 points on July 8, 2015, due to the 55.94-point crash of China stocks and the Hang Seng Index's near 6% drop. This led to widespread selling, with an advance-decline score of 73-426 and a record-breaking 1.8 billion units traded worth S$1.6 billion. The loss was attributed to the Chinese market's decline and the unresolved Greek situation, with brokers blaming China as the primary cause.

site_title: Greece's Tsipras 'confident' of meeting debt deal deadline
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras expressed confidence in meeting the end-of-the-week deadline to reach a bailout deal, warning of potential bankruptcy and geopolitical problems for Europe if a deal is not reached. The eurozone agreed to give Greece until Thursday to submit a new reform plan after a referendum rejected creditors' demands. Tsipras emphasized the need for a European solution to the crisis, urging all sides to work together to prevent a divided Europe, and denied that Greece's debt restructuring would burden European taxpayers.

site_title: Sunway Construction raises US$145m in IPO
summary: Sunway Construction Group Bhd raised US$145 million in its IPO, fixing the price at 1.20 ringgit per share. The offering was marketed in a range of 1.15 to 1.20 ringgit per share, with Maybank Investment Bank and RHB Investment Bank as global coordinators. This is Malaysia's second-largest IPO of the year, following Malakoff Corporation Bhd's 2.74 billion ringgit offering in May.

site_title: Barclays CEO Antony Jenkins to leave, chairman takes over
summary: Barclays CEO Antony Jenkins is leaving the bank, with new chairman John McFarlane taking over executive duties until a permanent successor is appointed. The decision follows a period of lacklustre results and uncertainty about the bank's future structure. The board believes a new approach is required to improve revenue, costs, and capital performance, and to become more externally focused. Jenkins' departure is seen as a bid to accelerate strategic change and boost shareholder returns, with McFarlane leading the search for a new CEO.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks plunge 5.84% by close
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 5.84% to a seven-month low on July 8, 2015, following a decline in Chinese markets. The Hang Seng Index fell 1,458.75 points to 23,516.56, its lowest close since January, with a turnover of HK$235.97 billion. This drop was in line with global market trends, with Europe and the US also experiencing declines. The sharp decline was attributed to concerns over US-EU trade tensions and economic uncertainty.

site_title: No more flip flops, warns Jokowi
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has warned his ministers and officials to stop making policy U-turns, which are eroding investor confidence in the country's largest economy. The flip-flops include scrapping a toll road tax, a language test for expats, and a ban on government officials meeting in hotels. Jokowi's government is under pressure to improve performance, with possible Cabinet changes expected after the Eid al-Fitr holiday in mid-July. The president's economic policies, including a fuel subsidy cut, are also being re-evaluated due to concerns about inflation and a weakening currency.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks tumble 3.14% on China equity rout
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted 3.14% on July 8, 2015, as Chinese equities experienced a rout, fueling losses and concerns over Greece's eurozone future. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 638.95 points to 19,737.64, its first fall below 20,000 in weeks. The broader Topix index also fell 3.34%.

site_title: Cabinet will not pressure PM Najib to step down
summary: Malaysia's cabinet members are not pressuring Prime Minister Najib Razak to step down amidst 1MDB fund allegations. Youth and Sports Minister Khairy Jamaluddin stated the cabinet is united in allowing the law to take due process before making further comments.

site_title: Microsoft to announce new round of job cuts
summary: Microsoft plans to announce a new round of job cuts, affecting workers in the hardware group and other areas, amid declining demand for certain devices and services. This move comes as the company continues to shift focus to personal computing, cloud platforms, and business productivity under CEO Satya Nadella. The cuts are part of a broader effort to cut costs, following previous reductions of about 18,000 workers last year. The announcement is expected to be made as early as Wednesday.

site_title: Quick Take: SBF welcomes further MOM support for PMEs, adds cautionary note
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) welcomes measures by the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) to support Singaporean professionals, managers, and executives (PMEs), particularly in a tight labour market. The new Career Support Programme (CSP) provides wage support for mid-level jobs and facilitates businesses' use of mature PMEs. However, SBF cautions against measures that may add rigidity to the labour market and impact competitiveness, emphasizing the need for a flexible and pro-business labour market.

site_title: New WDA programme to give wage support for firms hiring mature Singaporean PMEs
summary: The Workforce Development Agency (WDA) will launch a new career support programme on Oct 1, 2015, providing wage support to firms hiring mature Singaporean professionals, managers and executives (PMEs) aged 50 and above. Employers will receive 40% wage support for the first six months, capped at S$2,800, and 20% for the next six months, capped at S$1,400, for PMEs who have been looking for jobs for at least six months. The programme aims to assist PMEs in securing mid-level jobs.

site_title: Seoul: Shares extend fall to 4th session on China, Greece
summary: South Korean shares fell 1% on Wednesday, marking their fourth consecutive losing session, amid heavy foreign sales on China's stock markets and anxiety over the Greek debt crisis. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index dropped 1.18% to 2,016.21, its sharpest four-session percentage loss since June 25, 2013. Foreign investors sold 399.1 billion won worth of shares, contributing to a 0.6% decline in the won.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks slump 5.9% despite government moves
summary: China's Shanghai stock index plummeted 5.9% on Wednesday, defying government efforts to stabilize the market. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 219.93 points to 3,507.19, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 2.5% to 1,884.45. Despite new policies aimed at averting a market slide, dealers attributed the decline to investor concerns over the US-China trade tensions and economic slowdown.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rose at the start of trading on Wednesday, rebounding from the previous day's losses. London's FTSE 100 index added 0.24%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 gained 0.31%, and Paris's CAC 40 edged up 0.16%. The gains were despite heavy losses in China. The market recovery came as investors focused on US-EU trade talks and economic data.

images.alt_text: European shares rose on Wednesday after reaching 2015 lows as a bruising quarter ended, with a Chinese tax cut boosting automakers while miner Glencore rallied after saying it had no solvency issues.

site_title: Nissan says Takata air bag deployed abnormally in Japan crash
summary: Nissan reported its first case of a Takata air bag inflator deploying abnormally in Japan, where a Nissan X-Trail vehicle experienced an abnormal deployment sending high-temperature fragments into the dashboard. The driver suffered a lightly burned cheek, but it's unclear if the injury was caused by the Takata-made component. This incident is Nissan's first known abnormal deployment in Japan, and shares fell 6.8% after the announcement. Tens of millions of cars worldwide, including those made by Nissan, have been recalled due to the defect linked to eight deaths.

site_title: 1MDB confirms offices visited by task force on July 8
summary: 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) confirmed that officials from a special task force visited its offices on July 8 to investigate allegations of nearly $700 million in funds being deposited into Prime Minister Najib Razak's personal bank accounts. 1MDB expressed its full cooperation with the task force and reaffirmed its commitment to taking action if wrongdoing is found. The state investment agency stated that it provided officials with documents and materials to aid the investigations.

site_title: Korean Air 'nut rage' victim gets industrial injury recognition
summary: Korean Air chief steward Park Chang-Jin, who was ejected from a flight by senior executive Cho Hyun-Ah in a "nut rage" incident, has had his industrial injury claim approved by a state agency. Park claims post-traumatic depression and insomnia and will receive compensation for medical bills and lost wages. Cho, the airline's former vice-president, was jailed for violating aviation safety laws but was released after a reduced sentence. Park is preparing to file a $50-million lawsuit against Korean Air in US court, alleging abuse and seeking damages.

site_title: Modi faces reality check as India investment approvals slow
summary: India's investment approvals have slowed, with new project proposals announced in the three months through June being the lowest since Modi took power in 2014. Of 540 stalled projects valued at $432 billion, three-quarters are either substantially completed, unviable, or lack funding. Analysts attribute the slowdown to falling interest rates and Modi's pro-business rhetoric, suggesting it will take time for companies to invest. The data has pressured the government to pick up the slack, with financial markets dialing down expectations for growth.

site_title: Japan service sector sentiment worsens in June
summary: Japan's service sector sentiment index dropped to 51.0 in June, marking a second consecutive month of decline, according to a Cabinet Office survey. The index measures workers' confidence in current economic conditions and fell to 53.5 in June from 54.5 in May. The decline suggests worsening economic sentiment in Japan's service sector.

site_title: Cause of rail breakdown in Singapore still not known: LTA
summary: Singapore's rail breakdown, affecting both North-South and East-West Lines, remains unsolved, with the Land Transport Authority (LTA) citing the complexity of the rail system as a factor. Train services have resumed normal schedules, but the root cause of the massive breakdown, which began with a traction power trip, is still unknown. Investigations are ongoing, and the LTA and SMRT Corp have checked three key areas, including trains, tracks, and power substations, with no anomalies found so far.

site_title: Uber said to seek up to US$1b funding for Chinese market
summary: Uber is seeking up to $1 billion in funding for its Chinese business, valuing the company at $7-8 billion. Baidu, an existing Uber investor, plans to buy a new stake in the local unit. This marks the first time Uber is separating operations in a specific country to introduce outside investors. Uber plans to invest over $1 billion in China this year, competing with Didi Kuaidi, a rival backed by local giants Alibaba and Tencent.

site_title: 3 possible causes for Tuesday's train breakdown; investigations ongoing
summary: SMRT and the Land Transport Authority (LTA) are investigating three possible causes for the power trips on Tuesday evening that led to a 2-hour shutdown of the North-South and East-West lines. Insulation damage on two power cables along the North-South line was found during a walk-through of the tunnels. The causes under investigation include overheating, electrical surge, and electrical fault. The shutdown affected commuters during the evening peak period.

site_title: Passenger car COE premiums down
summary: COE premiums for passenger cars fell on Wednesday, with Category A slipping to S$58,700, Category B to S$65,501, and Category E to S$69,001. Category C for goods vehicles and buses dropped to S$50,001, while Category D for motorcycles rose to S$6,508. The decline in premiums was attributed to slower bookings for new cars.

images.alt_text: Certificate of Entitlement premiums for passenger cars continued to sag on Wednesday as bookings for new cars slowed down significantly, according to some dealers.

site_title: UBS provides alternative to bet on tanking Chinese stocks
summary: UBS is marketing structured notes tied to Chinese Class A funds, which can deliver returns if shares nosedive. The notes pay a 3-4% coupon regardless of performance, and can increase in value if the discount narrows. This strategy targets ultra-high-net-worth individuals and is seen as a good entry point for investors amid the Shanghai Composite Index's 30% decline since its peak. The offering is expected to close on July 10, with interest mainly coming from Chinese and Taiwanese offshore investors.

site_title: Banks uncooperative on Australia benchmark probe: Regulator
summary: Australian regulators say banks have been uncooperative in providing information on possible manipulation of the country's interest-rate benchmark. Chairman Greg Medcraft stated that banks are taking a defensive approach, triggering suspicion. The investigation, started in 2012, has led to the suspension of traders and voluntary contributions from several banks. At least $350 billion of Australian loans and bonds are priced off the benchmark, which is used globally. The regulator is yet to draw conclusions on the matter.

site_title: China car hailing app Didi Kuaidi raises US$2b as Uber rivalry intensifies
summary: China's Didi Kuaidi, the country's largest mobile car-ride hailing company, raised $2 billion in a fundraising round as it intensifies competition with US rival Uber. The company's cash reserves will increase to $3.5 billion, valuing it as high as $15 billion. Didi Kuaidi plans to expand into bus and chauffeur services to establish its leading position in the full-service transportation platform. The company's aggressive fundraising comes as it battles Uber, which recently announced plans to spend over $1 billion in China to gain a stronger presence.

site_title: Malaysian police raid 1MDB office in Kuala Lumpur
summary: Malaysian police raided the 1MDB office in Kuala Lumpur on July 8, 2015, as part of an investigation. The raids occurred at 11:30 am, with police present at the Menara IMC office. The exact reason for the raid is not specified, but it is related to the 1MDB scandal.

site_title: China says has limited Greek investments, little default impact
summary: China has limited investments in Greece, with $1.3 billion in shipping and telecoms, and Greek companies have invested only $96 million in China. China does not expect a huge impact from Greece's debt default, as it sees Greece as a portal for distributing Chinese products into Europe and Africa. China has repeatedly expressed support for Greece remaining in the euro zone and has urged a united European Union. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang has also stated that China will continue to buy euro zone debt.

site_title: Iron ore sinks below US$50 on fears of extended collapse
summary: Iron ore prices plummeted below US$50 a metric ton as concerns over expanded low-cost production and stagnant demand in China fueled the bear market. Analysts attribute the decline to supply outpacing demand, which may lead to significant price drops below the US$47-a-ton low set earlier this year. This is part of a broader commodities slump, with other metals and crude also experiencing declines due to weaker demand growth and surging supply.

site_title: Singapore imposes moratorium on Berau bonds due today
summary: The Singapore High Court has imposed a moratorium on Berau Capital's $450 million bonds due on July 8, allowing the issuer until January 4 to negotiate with bondholders. The 12.5% bonds are expected to be restructured, along with a $500 million issue due in 2017. This move comes after Sinarmas-backed Asia Coal Energy Ventures (ACE) won control of Berau Coal's parent company, Asia Resource Minerals, and proposed restructuring terms.

site_title: Najib lawyers challenge journal on Malaysia money trail reports
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's lawyers have sent a letter to the Wall Street Journal challenging the newspaper's reports on alleged misappropriation of funds from state investment company 1Malaysia Development Bhd. The reports claim US$700 million may have moved through government agencies and companies linked to 1MDB before appearing in Najib's personal accounts. The police have started an investigation under the computer crimes act, and a task force has ordered a freeze on six bank accounts believed linked to the money trail. Najib has called the claims part of a campaign of political sabotage, while senior government ministers have defended him and called for the probe to continue.

site_title: Barry Callebaut says 9-month sales volumes rise 2.5%
summary: Swiss chocolate maker Barry Callebaut reported a 7.6% year-on-year rise in nine-month sales revenue to 4.644 billion Swiss francs (US$4.91 billion). However, sales volume growth was 2.5%, below the group's mid-term target of 6-8% per year. Adjusted for currency effects, sales rose by 12%. The company attributed the underperformance to a surge in the Swiss franc's value and weaker cocoa supply from Ghana, which is the world's second-largest cocoa producer. Despite this, Barry Callebaut maintained its mid-term targets and saw its shares rise 2.9% so far this year.

site_title: Full train service resumes; no suspension of North-South line at 11am
summary: Full train service has resumed on both the North-South and East-West lines in Singapore after a breakdown on Tuesday night. SMRT announced the full service would resume at 10:33am on Wednesday, contrary to initial plans to suspend the North-South line from 11am-4pm.

site_title: China trade halts hit US$2.2 trillion as state intervention fails
summary: China's stock market halted trading for 1,249 companies, locking up $2.2 trillion in shares, as state intervention failed to revive confidence. The Shanghai Composite Index tumbled 7.5% in early trading, with selling by leveraged traders weighing on the market. Measures to prop up small-cap stocks, including margin requirements and share purchases, also failed to lift confidence. The market's transparency, efficiency, and fairness have been questioned, with analysts stating the market has "failed".

site_title: Asia stocks sink on Greece fear
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Wednesday due to fears of a Greek eurozone exit, with Shanghai and Hong Kong experiencing significant losses. Greece was given a deadline to submit fresh bailout reform proposals or face expulsion from the currency bloc, prompting traders to scramble for safer investments. The yen rose in response, while the euro edged lower. Despite Chinese leaders' efforts to stabilize markets, declines in Chinese stocks continued, weighing on regional markets. Asian markets declined, with Tokyo, Sydney, and Seoul experiencing losses of 1.52%, 1.26%, and 0.99%, respectively.

site_title: MAS in touch with banks on Malaysia's 1MDB-Najib probe
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is in contact with financial institutions regarding Malaysia's probe into 1MDB, a debt-laden state-owned fund. The probe alleges hundreds of millions of dollars were transferred to an account linked to Prime Minister Najib Razak. MAS will provide assistance to Malaysia and share information where legally able, following a Wall Street Journal report that traced nearly $700 million from a Singaporean bank account into accounts in Malaysia believed to belong to the prime minister. MAS is also assisting in the freezing of half a dozen bank accounts.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices hit record high despite cooling measures
summary: Hong Kong home prices reached a record high in May, with an 1.1% year-on-year increase to 298.4 points, driven by strong demand and low interest rates. The 20% year-over-year gain surpasses the previous record and comes despite government efforts to cool the market. Home prices have risen over 7% this year, prompting concerns of further tightening measures, including stricter mortgage restrictions, to curb the trend.

site_title: China stocks tumble as regulator warns of "panic"
summary: Chinese stocks plummeted 7.1% and 5.9% on the Shanghai and Shenzhen exchanges, respectively, as the country's securities regulator warned of "panic sentiment" and froze trading for 30% of listed companies. The CSI300 index has lost around 45% of its value since mid-June, with global investors fearing a destabilization of China's real economy. Beijing has unveiled new measures to support brokerages and stabilize the market, but analysts warn of a higher risk of a financial crisis and slower growth.

images.alt_text: Chinese stocks plunged on Wednesday after the country's securities regulator warned investors were in the grip of "panic sentiment" and the market showed signs of freezing up as firms scrambled to escape the rout by having their shares suspended.

site_title: Japan's May current account surplus stands at 1.88 trillion yen
summary: Japan's current account surplus in May reached 1.88 trillion yen, its 11th consecutive month of surplus, driven by a weak yen and declining imports. The surplus exceeded the median forecast of 1.54 trillion yen. The data suggests a narrow trade deficit.

site_title: JPMorgan to add 1,000 jobs, keep 2,600 in New Jersey
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co plans to create 1,000 jobs and retain over 2,600 workers in Jersey City, New Jersey, under a state tax credit program. The company will invest over $76 million in the state. This move is part of JPMorgan's expansion of its regional technology and operations hub. The state will receive a net benefit of $1.1 billion through the program.

site_title: China to start cotton reserves sale on Friday, demand seen weak
summary: China will start selling 1 million tonnes of cotton reserves on July 10, amid weak demand and high state prices. The sales will include domestic and imported cotton, with benchmark prices ranging from 13,200 yuan to 15,500 yuan per tonne. The move comes after China's top economic planner released the plan to gradually reduce its bulging reserves, which have built up to 11 million tonnes. The auctions will run until August 31, and traders warn that the sales may face challenges due to the high state prices and relatively low demand.

images.alt_text: A worker fills a vacuum pipe with cotton to clean it at a cotton processing unit in Kadi town in the western state of Gujarat, India, on Feb 9, 2015

site_title: Malaysia task force to freeze accounts in Najib money probe
summary: A Malaysian task force has ordered a freeze on six bank accounts linked to a money trail allegedly showing funds from a state investment company ending up in Prime Minister Najib Razak's personal accounts. The investigation, ongoing since July 3, is believed to be connected to the US$700 million funds linked to 1Malaysia Development Bhd. Najib has denied the claims, calling them a campaign of political sabotage, while some ministers have publicly backed him to allow the probe to run its course.

site_title: China's state margin lender plans US$12.9b bill issuance
summary: China's state margin lender, China Securities Finance Corp (CSF), plans to issue 80 billion yuan (S$17.45 billion) of short-term bills in the interbank market, the largest ever bill issuance by the company. The People's Bank of China will approve the deal, which comes days after the central bank announced liquidity support for CSF to help it expand its business and stabilize the stock market.

site_title: JPMorgan's effort to probe Time Warner Center Condo denied
summary: A federal judge denied JPMorgan Chase's effort to investigate the ownership of a Time Warner Center condo registered under NYC Real Estate Opportunities, a Delaware company with a Singapore address. The condo was purchased in 2012 for $19.4 million, raising questions about its true owner, Indian developer Kabul Chawla. Chawla's New Delhi company, BPTP, has received hundreds of complaints from consumers who claim he failed to deliver on promised apartments. The ruling highlights the difficulty of unraveling shell companies.

site_title: Oil prices down in Asia as Greece and China weigh
summary: Oil prices fell in Asia on July 8, 2015, due to concerns over Greece's future in the eurozone and the impact on global markets. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropped 14 cents to $52.19 a barrel, while Brent fell 13 cents to $56.72 a barrel. Analysts, including Bernard Aw, expressed concerns about the global commodity market outlook.

site_title: Myanmar scraps developments under pressure from monks
summary: Myanmar's government has halted five property developments near the Shwedagon pagoda due to pressure from influential monks, who deemed the projects as damaging and desecrating the site. The government worked with investors to stop the projects, ensuring they would incur no losses. The decision reflects the significant influence of monks in Myanmar's Buddhist-majority society and their role in pro-democracy protests. The government's move aims to preserve the country's cultural heritage and appease the monks' concerns.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.2 points to 1,706.1. The market saw 106 losers and 64 gainers, with a total trading volume of 20.83 million lots worth RM10.27 million.

site_title: Australia: Stocks down 1.1% after Greece given deadline
summary: Australian stocks dropped 1.1% at the open on Wednesday after European leaders gave Greece a final deadline to reach a new bailout deal, set for Sunday. The S&P/ASX200 index fell 60.5 points to 5,520.9. Investors exercised caution due to the Greek impasse, with the Australian dollar sliding to 74.53 US cents. The market had rebounded nearly 2% on Tuesday on bargain-hunting.

site_title: Singapore's LTA working on innovative fare payment systems
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) is exploring innovative fare payment systems, including near-field communication technology, wristbands, and mobile phones. The LTA aims to test these systems later this year and introduce an account-based payment system, which would eliminate the need for commuters to top up their fare cards regularly. Another system being studied is the "be-in-be-out" (BIBO) system, which would allow technology to identify smart cards without the commuter needing to pull them out. This would simplify the payment process for both commuters and transport operators.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks plunge 4.74% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 4.74% in the opening minutes of trading on July 8, 2015, following heavy losses in Shanghai and fears over Greece's future in the eurozone. The Hang Seng Index dropped 1,184.79 points to 23,790.52. This decline was part of a regional rout and was fueled by concerns over the Greek debt crisis and its potential impact on the global economy.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks plunge 6.97% at open, extending losses
summary: China's Shanghai stock index plummeted 6.97% at open on July 8, 2015, extending losses despite government efforts to stabilize the market. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 259.72 points to 3,467.40, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 4.07% to 1,854.22. The decline marked the latest in a series of market downturns in China, which has been grappling with economic slowdown and currency fluctuations.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.46% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.46% lower on Wednesday amid concerns over China's equity rout and Greece's potential exit from the eurozone. The Nikkei 225 index fell 94.1 points to 20,282.49. European leaders have given Greece a Sunday deadline to reach a new bailout deal or face expulsion from the currency union. US-listed Chinese companies fell, but US stocks rallied on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average ending up 93.33 points.

site_title: Singapore Turf Club, Singapore Pools apply to offer remote gambling services
summary: Singapore Turf Club and Singapore Pools have applied to offer remote gambling services, seeking certificates of exemption under the Remote Gambling Act. The evaluation process, expected to take 9-12 months, will assess the entities' contributions to public, social, and charitable purposes in Singapore. This move comes after the Act's implementation in February, which has blocked several hundred websites offering remote gambling services.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.39% lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 0.39% lower on Wednesday, closing at 3,327.83, after a European proposal for Greece's reforms. Top gainers included Dairy Farm International, Raffles Medical Group, GuocoLand, and Sarine Technologies. Trading saw 46.6 million shares worth S$64 million.

site_title: Stocks to Watch: SMRT, Noble, SPH Reit, Singapore telcos, Ezra
summary: Stocks to watch on July 8, 2015, include SMRT Corporation due to power faults affecting train lines, Noble Group's third-party review of mark-to-market models, and SPH Reit's unchanged DPU. Singapore telcos face potential competition with IDA paving the way for a fourth telco operator. Ezra Holdings' subsidiaries Triyards and Emas Offshore posted subdued Q3 results with new contract wins.

site_title: US corporate credit risk reaches 2015 high on Greece turmoil
summary: US corporate credit risk has reached its highest level this year due to the Greek crisis, with the Markit CDX North American Investment Grade Index rising 2.5 basis points to 74, its highest intraday level since December 2015. Investors are concerned about a potential failure of Greece's debt talks with European creditors, prompting a "frightened" response. Chief market strategist Brian Reynolds predicts the high-yield debt market will experience further growth, with investors seeking protection and potentially attracting pension funds.

site_title: Microsoft tweaks streaming music plan for Windows 10
summary: Microsoft has rebranded its music service as Groove Music, which will be built into the Windows 10 operating system. The new service offers 40 million songs, ad-free music for downloads and playlists, and costs $10/month or $99/year. The move aims to compete with Apple, Google, and Spotify. Microsoft is preparing to roll out Windows 10 starting July 29, hoping it will help the company better compete in the mobile device market.

site_title: US: Stocks rally from morning dive
summary: US stocks finished higher on Tuesday, rallying after early losses due to concerns over Greece and China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.53% to 17,776.91, while the S&P 500 jumped 0.61% to 2,081.34. Analysts attributed the rally to US investors' optimism, despite global market unease, and technical factors. Key losers included US-listed Chinese companies and banking shares, while consumer products stocks and a pharmaceutical company saw significant gains.

site_title: Global Yellow Pages, subsidiary face legal action in Singapore High Court
summary: Global Yellow Pages, a subsidiary of Leisure Empire Pte Ltd, has been served a writ in Singapore's High Court for S$150,000 in damages for the termination of a service agreement in 2012. The company claims it intends to rigorously defend its position, and the matter is not expected to impact its financial performance for the 2016 fiscal year.

site_title: London braces for 24 hour Underground strike
summary: London is bracing for a 24-hour Underground strike, expected to be the worst in years, due to a dispute over pay and plans to run an all-night service on weekends. Almost 20,000 staff, belonging to four unions, are set to walk out from 5:30 PM on Wednesday, causing travel chaos for millions. The strike, combined with a 48-hour strike on First Great Western trains, will bring disruption into Friday. A last-minute offer failed to clinch a deal, with unions accusing London Underground management of producing the proposal too late.

site_title: US-listed Chinese shares fall as home market teeters
summary: US-listed Chinese shares plummeted on Tuesday, with Alibaba falling 2.5% and Baidu 1.8%, amid worries of broader financial problems in China's economy. Small companies suffered significant drops, including Qihoo 360 Technology (-9.0%), Renren (-12.6%), and Youku Tudou (-8.6%). The decline raised concerns about China's economic stability, which has been a major factor in global markets.

site_title: US growth threatened by global political and economic upheaval, IMF warns
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that global economic growth slowdown and political upheaval in countries like Greece, the Middle East, and Ukraine could negatively impact US growth. The IMF advises delaying the Federal Reserve's rate hike until mid-2016, citing weaker global growth, reduced US exports, and decreased equity market valuations. The IMF also emphasizes the need for the US to implement the Dodd-Frank bank reform law and create an independent insurance regulator.

images.alt_text: A global slowdown in economic growth, together with political and economic upheaval in places like Greece, the Middle East and Ukraine, could hurt US growth going forward, the International Monetary Fund said on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore company, director fined S$38,000 for using unlicensed software
summary: A Singapore company, St Hua Private School, and its director Sophia Song Chunwei, were fined S$38,000 for using unlicensed software. The fine was upheld by the Singapore High Court after unsuccessful appeals. The Software Alliance (BSA) urged Singapore companies to ensure software is fully licensed to avoid legal and financial risks. According to the 2013 BSA Global Software Survey, 32% of PC software in Singapore was installed without proper licensing, with a record US$344 million in unlicensed software value in 2013.

site_title: Alibaba to raise stake in SingPost to 14.51% from 10.23%, subject to IDA's approval
summary: Alibaba Group will acquire a 14.51% stake in SingPost, increasing its interest in the Singapore postal group to 14.51% from 10.23%, subject to IDA's approval. Alibaba will invest up to S$92 million for a 34% stake in SingPost's subsidiary, Quantium Solutions International, which provides ecommerce logistics and fulfillment services across the Asia Pacific region. The deal aims to spur growth in ecommerce logistics across Asia and enhance SingPost's ecommerce logistics platform.

site_title: Ferrari said to pick UBS to manage New York stock listing
summary: Ferrari SpA, set to be spun off from Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV, has selected UBS Group AG to help manage its initial public offering in New York, along with JPMorgan Chase & Co and Goldman Sachs. The IPO aims to raise 10% of Ferrari's shares to fund a 48 billion-euro investment program for Fiat Chrysler's brands. Ferrari is expected to list on the New York Stock Exchange, with a valuation of "at least" 10 billion euros, and will be an independent entity from 2016.

site_title: JPMorgan to pay over US$125m to settle US credit card debt probes
summary: JPMorgan Chase has agreed to pay at least $125 million to settle US probes into allegations the bank improperly collected and sold consumer credit card debt. The settlement also includes $50 million in restitution, addressing claims of robo-signing and inaccurate information provided to debt buyers. The US Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and 47 states will split the funds, with the states receiving $95 million. This follows previous investigations and lawsuits by California and Mississippi, which are still pending.

site_title: US-listed Chinese shares fall as home market teeters
summary: US-listed Chinese shares fell on Tuesday as Chinese stock markets tumbled, raising concerns about the country's economy. E-commerce giant Alibaba, internet search company Baidu, and online retailer JD.com were among the biggest losers, with some companies experiencing drops of over 7%. The losses come after a bursting bubble in Chinese stocks that has lost an estimated $3.2 trillion in value since mid-June. Chinese officials have taken steps to stem the sell-off, but analysts say the market may have further to fall due to a lack of confidence in the government's ability to prop up the markets.

site_title: IMF faults US for inaction over shell companies
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) criticized the US for its slow action in preventing the use of shell and front companies to hide ownership. The IMF stated that US regulators have made little progress in requiring banks to know who is behind these companies, which is crucial for policing money laundering and tax evasion. This issue was first recommended by the Financial Action Task Force eight years ago.

site_title: Former IMF economist Veerathai to head Thailand's central bank
summary: Former IMF economist Veerathai Santiprabhob, 45, has been named the new governor of Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand (BOT), effective October 1. He replaces Prasarn Trairatvorakul, who steps down after a five-year term. Veerathai's appointment aims to address the country's slow economy, falling exports, and deflation, with limited policy space due to US interest rate hikes. His experience outside the central bank is seen as an asset, and investors welcome his appointment, citing his willingness to learn and make quick decisions.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip but no sign of alarm before Greece summit
summary: European shares dropped 1.6% and 2.1% in the pan-European index, with the Euro STOXX 50 closing down 2.1%, amid Greece's emergency bid to secure fresh aid from creditors at a euro zone summit. German Chancellor Angela Merkel said there were only days left to secure a deal, while Greek officials denied rejecting new proposals. Investors registered disappointment with Greece, shifting towards safe havens, and strategists believe the likelihood of Greece leaving the euro zone has increased to 70%.

site_title: Greece given Sunday debt deal deadline
summary: European leaders have given Greece a final deadline of Sunday to reach a new bailout deal and avoid crashing out of the eurozone. The deadline comes after Greek voters rejected international creditors' plans in a referendum, with 61% rejecting austerity measures in return for fresh EU-IMF bailout funds. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras must submit detailed reform plans by Thursday, and all 28 EU leaders will examine the plans on Sunday in a make-or-break summit. Failure to reach an agreement may lead to bankruptcy and insolvency of Greece's banking system.

site_title: US to cut 40,000 soldiers from Army: official
summary: The US Army plans to cut 40,000 soldiers and 17,000 civilians over the next two years to save money, resulting in a total of 450,000 soldiers by the end of the 2017 budget year. The cuts, expected to be announced this week, will affect every Army post at home and abroad. The reductions are part of broader government budget cuts set to kick in in October, which could lead to an additional 30,000 layoffs if Congress does not act.

site_title: IDA sets ball rolling for 4th telco operator
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) has set aside 60 MHz of spectrum for a new mobile network operator (MNO), paving the way for the possible entry of a fourth telco operator. The spectrum will be auctioned in early 2016, with a reserve price of S$40 million. The new MNO will be required to offer services nationwide by September 2018 and meet quality-of-service standards. The move aims to bring innovative services and competitive offerings to the market, with IDA expecting the entry of a new player to shake up the mobile-services market.

site_title: Corzine, others settle MF Global lawsuit for US$64.5m
summary: Jon Corzine and nine other former MF Global Holdings Ltd officials have settled a US$64.5 million lawsuit with investors, resolving the last major piece of litigation over the company's 2011 bankruptcy. The all-cash settlement grants preliminary approval, with a Nov 20 hearing to consider final approval. The settlement resolves claims by MF Global stock, bond, and convertible bond investors, who sought to hold Corzine and others liable for the company's financial collapse.

images.alt_text: Jon Corzine and other former MF Global Holdings Ltd officials have reached a US$64.5 million settlement of litigation brought by investors seeking to hold them liable for the now-defunct futures brokerage's 2011 bankruptcy.

site_title: US dollar rises as Greece prepares bailout proposal
summary: The US dollar rose against other major currencies except the yen as Greece prepared a bailout proposal ahead of a European Union summit. The euro pared losses to trade at $1.1007, down from a five-week low of $1.0916. Greece's debt-ridden status and potential EU debt default led investors to seek safe haven in the dollar and yen. EU president Donald Tusk warned that an inability to find an agreement may lead to Greece's bankruptcy and insolvency of its banking system, with a July 20 deadline for a debt repayment of 3.5 billion euros to the European Central Bank.

site_title: Han Solo blasts into Disney's Star Wars universe with own film
summary: Disney's Star Wars universe is expanding with a new Han Solo film, set to release on May 25, 2018. The untitled project, directed by Chris Miller and Phil Lord, will explore Han Solo's origin story, focusing on his transformation from a smuggler to a lovable scoundrel. The film, which will be the second stand-alone Star Wars anthology, will intersperse with the new trilogy, starting with December's Star Wars: The Force Awakens. The story will be written by Lawrence Kasdan and his son Jon Kasdan.

site_title: Service on the NSL suspended between 11am and 4pm for investigations: LTA
summary: Train service on Singapore's North-South line has been suspended from 11am to 4pm for further investigations into the power trip that caused a network shutdown on Tuesday. Engineers have narrowed down possible causes, but need more time to determine the situation definitively. The suspension is to allow LTA and SMRT engineers to conduct further investigations and rectify faults discovered.

site_title: Souped-up dashboards in cars good for safety? The debate rages on
summary: Automakers are producing high-tech car dashboards that resemble smartphones, but their effectiveness in improving safety is debated. While customers demand these advanced displays, some question whether they genuinely enhance safety. The article does not provide conclusive evidence to support or refute the claim, leaving the debate ongoing.

site_title: Funds are net buyers while volumes remain low
summary: Mutual funds in Singapore bought S$586.3 million worth of stocks in the three months to July 1, with net buys in the utilities and transport sector totaling S$73.9 million. SIIC Environment Holdings was the top buy, while Singapore Post was the top sell. The low volume of trades suggests that the data may not reflect the entire market activity, with alternative investors and institutional money managers potentially involved.

site_title: UBS, Morgan Stanley lead wealth managers with record $2 trillion
summary: UBS and Morgan Stanley have surpassed $2 trillion in assets managed for the world's wealthiest individuals, according to a study by Scorpio Partnership. UBS saw a 3.5% increase to $2.04 trillion, while Morgan Stanley grew 6.1% to $2.03 trillion. The top 10 wealth managers control 47% of the $20.6 trillion market, with UBS holding 9.9%. The global wealth management industry experienced solid growth in 2014 despite financial market uncertainties and currency volatility.

images.alt_text: UBS Group AG and Morgan Stanley increased the assets they manage for the world's wealthiest people to more than US$2 trillion for the first time, according to a study.

site_title: Drag on productivity growth can be fixed: OECD
summary: A new OECD report suggests that governments can help revive global productivity growth by supporting businesses and improving the match between talents and jobs. The report highlights that policy reforms can facilitate the diffusion of innovation and better utilize human talent to drive higher and more inclusive productivity growth. The OECD recommends focusing on skills development and efficient resource allocation to address the gap between high-productivity firms and the rest, which has widened over time.

site_title: M&S says merchandise sales dip but margin story intact
summary: M&S reported a dip in first-quarter underlying sales in its clothing, footwear, and homewares business, but maintained its 2015-16 guidance, citing a rise in general merchandise gross margin of 1.5-2 percentage points. The company's food business saw a 0.3% like-for-like sales rise, its 23rd consecutive quarterly increase. Despite a challenging quarter, M&S remains on track to deliver the improvement in gross margin previously guided.

site_title: Greece to make aid request soon, says Dutch minister
summary: Greece is set to make an aid request to the EU's bailout fund, with a request "imminent, possibly within the next few hours," according to Dutch Finance Minister Jeroen Dijsselbloem. Greece's voters rejected austerity measures, and the country must deliver "credible reforms" to receive aid. Euro-area finance chiefs will discuss the request on a conference call on Wednesday, which could prevent the European Central Bank from pulling the plug on Greek banks, which are struggling financially.

site_title: China's new national security law broad and vague
summary: China's new national security law, enacted by the National People's Congress, has raised concerns due to its broad and vague definition of national security, which could encompass every sphere of activity. The law identifies the Communist Party's interests with those of the Chinese state, potentially undermining democracy and allowing for a crackdown on domestic dissent and foreign interference. The law also endows itself with extraterritorial jurisdiction, raising questions about China's global influence and human rights record.

site_title: Rolls-Royce cruises Kazakh streets in ultra-luxury car frontier
summary: Rolls-Royce has expanded into Kazakhstan, a country with a growing wealthy class due to its oil and metal riches. The average person in Kazakhstan lives on about $330 a month, making it an attractive market for luxury car brands like Rolls-Royce and Bentley. Demand for upscale vehicles in frontier markets like Kazakhstan is forecast to grow 9% annually through 2020, compared to 2% in North America and Europe. Four of the six Rolls-Royce dealerships opened last year were in emerging markets, including Kazakhstan.

site_title: US trade gap grows in May as exports decline
summary: The US trade deficit widened to $41.9 billion in May, a 2.9% increase from the prior month, as exports declined by the most in three months. This decline in exports showed businesses struggled to generate sales to overseas customers. The trade deficit has grown for the first time in 2015, highlighting ongoing challenges in the US trade landscape.

site_title: Bringing a distraction, perhaps a smile, to frazzled commuters
summary: Thomas Knox, 28, has set up a pop-up booth in New York City's subways, where he engages strangers in conversation during board games like Scrabble and Connect Four. He aims to bring levity to frazzled commuters and has no intention of dating, despite the games' "Date" theme. The project, called "Date While You Wait," has gained attention online, with some copycats popping up in Berlin and other cities. Knox hopes to expand the concept into a full-time non-profit, connecting minority youths with mentors.

site_title: Temasek posts 19.2% TSR as net portfolio value rises to S$266b
summary: Temasek Holdings reported a 19.2% total shareholder return (TSR) for the year ended March 31, 2015, with a net portfolio value of S$266 billion. The company's group net profit rose to S$14.5 billion, driven by a global equity rally. Temasek made S$30 billion of new investments and S$19 billion of divestments, with a focus on consumer, financials, and life sciences. The company's exposure to Asia excluding Singapore increased to 42% and China's exposure rose to 27%. Temasek's TSR since its inception in 1974 was 16%.

site_title: Saudi petrochem giant forms research partnership with NUS (Amended)
summary: Sabic, a Saudi petrochemical giant, has formed a research partnership with the National University of Singapore (NUS) to develop sustainable materials and processes. The Master Research Agreement aims to leverage NUS's technical expertise and Sabic's global presence, technological innovation, and market understanding to address key global challenges. The partnership will focus on energy efficiency, sustainable material solutions, and process equipment design, ultimately leading to lighter, cleaner, and more efficient sustainable products. This marks Sabic's first partnership with an academic institution in South-east Asia.

site_title: Refracking offers hope to shale industry
summary: Refracking, a technique that boosts oil flow in aging shale wells, offers hope to the US shale industry. By re-stimulating wells, the lifespan of these wells can be extended, potentially lasting 50 years. This method, which involves blasting sand and water into the well, has been shown to increase oil production by 60% or more. Companies such as Marathon Oil Corp and ConocoPhillips are already incorporating refracking into their operations, and the technique is expected to become a significant part of hydraulic fracturing activity in the US by 2020, with estimates suggesting 3,000 refracks will be performed over the next two years.

site_title: Jimmy Carter says US influence waning in Middle East and globally
summary: Former US President Jimmy Carter stated that the US is experiencing an "inevitable relative decline in worldwide influence" due to the rise of China, India, and other developing economies. Carter believes the US will remain a dominant military power but its ability to shape foreign affairs is waning. He cited the lack of progress in Israeli-Palestinian peace talks as an example, stating that the US has not made sufficient efforts to orchestrate negotiations. This shift in global influence has significant implications for the US's role in international affairs.

site_title: Dancing with the Chinese market
summary: Chinese authorities and financial institutions implemented measures to stabilize the equity market, including easing monetary policy and loosening margin trading restrictions. However, the Shanghai Composite Index fell by nearly 30% over the last three weeks, and despite a short-term rebound, market sentiments remained bearish. The government's efforts to stem the bleeding were largely ineffective, with the index closing at one-third of its opening bounce after a 7.8% surge. The Chinese stock market continues to experience significant losses.

site_title: Two major train lines knocked out for hours
summary: Two major train lines in Singapore, the North-South and East-West lines, were disrupted for three hours during peak-hour traffic on Tuesday due to a power fault linked to a faulty train. The incident occurred just hours after SMRT's AGM, where CEO Desmond Kuek discussed the company's financial sustainability concerns. The train service experienced an operating loss of S$2.4 million in the last quarter of fiscal 2015. An investigation by the Land Transport Authority is underway to determine the cause of the disruption.

site_title: Eurozone's big fear is a successful Grexit
summary: The eurozone is concerned that Greece's potential exit from the euro (Grexit) could lead to a domino effect, with other peripheral economies following suit. A restored drachma would likely be pegged below the euro, causing a sharp devaluation against other currencies. This could lead to economic instability and potentially benefit Greece, but also pose risks to the eurozone as a whole. Authorities fear that a successful Grexit could undermine the eurozone's stability and create a ripple effect across the global economy.

site_title: Hoax phone call costs hedge fund £742,668 and CFO his job
summary: A hedge fund manager, Thomas Meston, lost £742,668 after a phone call from a scammer claiming to be from Coutts, the firm's bank, on December 2013. Meston was instructed to use the bank's security system to cancel payments, but the funds were transferred to accounts under various names. Meston was terminated and is being sued by the fund, which claims he breached his duty to protect assets. The incident highlights the vulnerability of online security systems to human error, with the Bank of England warning that employees are often the "weakest link" in cybersecurity.

site_title: SRX Property launches app that tracks homes' value, rent
summary: SRX Property has launched 'my Property Tracker', a free app that tracks homes' value and rent in Singapore. The app, powered by StreetSine Technology Group, provides customized updates to 1.4 million home owners and renters. It uses the X-Value, a computer-generated appraisal of a property's market value, and offers features such as rental yield, undervalued properties, and listings of nearby properties. The app aims to make Singapore's property market the most transparent in the world, with CEO Sam Baker stating that every household should receive monthly updates.

site_title: Big four US airlines conspiring on prices, fliers say in lawsuits
summary: The US Department of Justice is investigating possible collusion among the four largest US airlines - Delta, United, American, and Southwest - over ticket prices. Travellers have filed lawsuits claiming the carriers are conspiring to keep prices high despite falling fuel prices. The airlines have been accused of raising fares, imposing new fees, and reducing capacity, leaving customers with fewer choices. The DOJ has requested documents from the airlines to support its investigation.

site_title: Bank Negara defends ringgit amid political storm
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara, intervened for a third consecutive trading day to support the ringgit currency amid corruption allegations against Prime Minister Najib Razak, raising doubts over his grip on power. Despite Bank Negara's efforts, the ringgit has weakened past its old currency peg of 3.80 per US dollar, losing only 0.8% since the political storm began on Friday. The currency's value is now 0.2% lower than its pre-political storm level.

site_title: Stabilising China's stock market seen as major test for Xi
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping faces a major test in stabilizing the country's volatile stock market, which has lost US$3.2 trillion in value in three weeks. The government has introduced unprecedented measures to halt the sell-off, including suspending initial public offerings and pledging liquidity for margin trading. Xi must restore confidence in the market to prevent social unrest and potential economic disruption, as the market's collapse could damage the Communist Party's control and undermine its decades-long economic boom.

site_title: Diehards stay on floor in New York, Chicago commodity pits
summary: CME Group Inc has shut most of the futures pits in New York and Chicago, but some brokers and traders will continue to trade on the floor, albeit electronically from booths. Despite a 90% decline in open outcry deals, some traders will stay on the floor for information and to maintain relationships with long-time customers. The average daily volume has risen 6% to 13.3 million contracts, with 88% traded electronically, as the industry adapts to a shift towards electronic trading.

site_title: The big picture
summary: Singapore's OCBC Bank has announced the appointment of Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong, who will retire. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are to enhance cooperation in green and transition finance. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Meanwhile, Citigroup forecasts a 1,150 target for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026, and Chinese banks face challenges due to Beijing's consumer lending push. The moves signal significant changes in the banking and finance sectors in Asia.

site_title: Merger mania in US health insurance industry
summary: The US health insurance industry is experiencing a wave of mergers, with five largest companies - Aetna, Humana, Anthem, Cigna, and UnitedHealth Group - likely to emerge as national behemoths. The mergers aim to increase bargaining power with hospitals and doctors for lower prices. However, consumer advocates question whether consolidation will lead to fewer choices of plans and diminished competition. Regional nonprofit Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans, which have traditionally dominated local markets, face challenges in competing with larger companies.

site_title: Gavea may bid for Petrobras assets
summary: Brazilian investment firm Gavea Investimentos Ltda, controlled by JPMorgan Chase, may bid for assets of embattled oil company Petrobras, with CEO Amaury Bier stating the firm is considering partnering investors to buy assets worth $5.5 billion. Petrobras aims to sell $15.1 billion in assets this year and next, including a possible initial public offering of its fuel-distribution business. Gavea's private-equity fund has $1 billion to invest and the firm is looking to buy minority stakes, with CEO Bier noting that Brazil's economy is "very delicate" and in need of confidence.

site_title: Women's World Cup final sets record for viewership in US
summary: The US Women's World Cup final set a record for viewership in the US, with 25.4 million viewers on Fox, surpassing the previous record of 26.5 million for the 2014 men's World Cup final. The match, which saw the US defeat Japan 5-2, also drew 1.3 million viewers on Telemundo, for a total of 26.7 million. This marks a significant surge in interest in women's soccer, with the audience exceeding that of the recent NBA finals and World Series.

site_title: Plan to increase Sunday shopping hours in UK
summary: The British government plans to allow shops to open longer on Sundays, devolving the power to mayors and local authorities, to compete with online shopping and tourist destinations. Finance Minister George Osborne wants to give retailers the ability to open for more than six hours on Sundays, citing the rise of online shopping and the success of a trial during the London Olympics. However, the plan is expected to face opposition from unions and the Church of England, which defends Sunday as a common day off for "family stability and community life."

site_title: Noble bites bullet, undertakes review of accounting practices (Amended)
summary: Noble Group, a commodities trader, has commissioned PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) to review its accounting practices, following billions of dollars in market value losses. The review includes mark-to-market models, valuations, and governance framework. Market watchers welcome the move but say the proof lies in the pudding, with critics questioning the independence of the review committee. The review's findings will be reported to the board, and Noble plans to release a summary upon completion.

site_title: Who's who on Noble's independent board panel
summary: NOBLE Group, a Singapore-listed commodities firm, has set up an independent board committee to review its accounting practices amid criticism of poor governance and lack of transparency. The committee, consisting of four non-executive directors, will conduct an assurance review of mark to market models, valuations, and governance framework. The review follows allegations made by Iceberg Research and American shortseller Muddy Waters, which claimed Noble overstated asset values and inflated profits. Noble has denied the allegations and started legal action against a former employee.

site_title: Malaysia plans more subsidy cuts despite 1MDB scandal
summary: Malaysia plans to cut subsidies on petrol, liquefied petroleum gas, and cooking oil, and move billions of dollars in government employee housing loans off its balance sheets to bolster its fiscal position. Despite a 1MDB scandal threatening Prime Minister Najib Razak's ability to implement policies, the government is committed to fiscal consolidation. A Fitch Ratings decision to pull back from downgrading Malaysia is giving the country space to reinforce its fiscal credentials, allowing it to press ahead with subsidy cuts and fiscal reforms.

site_title: Conditions in Singapore's equities market have worsened despite many SGX initiatives
summary: Singapore's equities market has worsened despite the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) initiatives, with half of the Straits Times Index stocks trading at 2009-2010 levels. The market lacks continuous all-day trading, which facilitates high-frequency trading, and has become a "betting centre" rather than a platform for companies to raise capital. This has driven clients to other markets, and the SGX must reassess its strategy to attract listings and create a healthy capital market.

site_title: New, simpler 'Buy' buttons aim to entice mobile shoppers
summary: Tech companies, including Google, Facebook, and Twitter, are launching simpler "Buy" buttons to bridge the gap between mobile browsing and desktop purchasing, aiming to reduce "friction" and drive sales. The new buttons, modeled after mobile apps, allow users to log in and have their credit cards on file, making the checkout process more predictable. This move is expected to increase online sales, as mobile shoppers currently spend most of their time browsing on desktop computers.

site_title: Samsung predicts profit fall as S6 phone sales disappoint
summary: Samsung Electronics guided for weaker-than-expected second-quarter earnings due to a supply shortage and tepid demand from key markets. Operating profit likely fell 4% from a year earlier to 6.9 trillion won, marking the seventh straight period of annual decline. Revenue is expected to fall 8.3% from a year earlier to 48 trillion won. The company's annual profit is expected to rebound this year from a three-year low in 2014, but shares have languished amid doubts about sales of its Galaxy S6 smartphones.

site_title: Euro falls 1% against greenback but no panic selling
summary: The euro fell 1% against the US dollar to US$1.0946, a five-week low, due to concerns over Greece's debt crisis and potential exit from the eurozone. Despite this, there has been no panic selling, with traders expecting the European Central Bank to take action, including quantitative easing. European leaders are meeting in Brussels to discuss Greece, and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker has urged Greece's government to propose solutions to its debt crisis.

site_title: Temasek increases investments in N America, Europe and China
summary: Temasek Holdings invested S$30 billion and divested S$19 billion in the financial year ended March 31, 2015, increasing its China exposure and making its first foray into London's real estate. This marks a shift from its previous focus on mature markets in North America and Europe.

site_title: IMF urges Fed to delay rate hike till H1 of next year
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) urged the US Federal Reserve to delay raising interest rates until there are greater signs of wage or price inflation, likely in the first half of 2016. The IMF warned that a rise in US dollar strength could reignite global financial imbalances, impacting US growth and job creation. The report also highlighted the need for structural reforms to boost productivity and labor force participation, and cautioned against a government shutdown or debt ceiling standoff, which could disrupt the US economy.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings and Halcyon Agri Corporation are recommended for a "Buy" rating. Yangzijiang is positioned to benefit from post-consolidation shipbuilding market recovery, with a potential re-rating due to probable dual-listing in Hong Kong. Halcyon Agri's share price has declined 19% since a downgrade, but analysts forecast 8.4% and 17.5% net profit increases for 2015 and 2016, respectively, due to lower financing costs and a stronger US dollar.

site_title: Crowdo to launch crowdlending in Indonesia
summary: Crowdo, a Singapore-based crowdfunding platform, has announced plans to launch a crowdlending platform for SMEs and startups in Indonesia later this year. The platform, which will allow investors to lend directly to businesses in exchange for a fixed return, aims to tap into Indonesia's large unbanked segment. The move follows regulatory approval for equity crowdfunding in Malaysia, making Crowdo the first South-east Asian operator to offer reward, equity, and debt crowdfunding services. The crowdlending platform is expected to address Indonesia's significant credit gap of US$27.5 billion.

site_title: Greece crisis a teachable moment on pension reform and debt burden
summary: Greece's pension reform and debt burden crisis serves as a teachable moment for countries worldwide, including the US, China, and Singapore. The country's pension system, which relies heavily on current tax revenues to fund commitments, faces challenges due to an aging population and declining asset returns. Similar issues exist in the US, with Illinois facing a potential pension crisis, and China, where local governments have borrowed excessively to invest in unprofitable projects. The crisis highlights the importance of pension reform and responsible debt management, with lessons applicable to countries globally.

site_title: Byron will bring freedom with years of acute misery
summary: Greece's Syriza party defied expectations by winning a 61-39% referendum, with Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis successfully negotiating a left-progressive platform. This victory inspires left-wing parties in Italy and Spain, and may give the French Socialists a renewed sense of courage. Syriza's win marks a rare instance of a left-wing party achieving success in Europe, and may lead to increased influence for progressive parties across the continent.

site_title: Aussie central bank holds rates steady, eyeing a lower currency
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia held interest rates steady at 2% amid economic uncertainty, with a focus on a lower currency due to sliding commodity prices and mounting uncertainty in China. Governor Glenn Stevens emphasized the need for further depreciation, citing significant declines in key commodity prices. The decision was expected, with 22 analysts polled predicting no rate change. Interbank futures imply a 50% probability of a move by October and 80% in December.

site_title: SBI Offshore diversifies into solar energy
summary: SBI Offshore has entered into a joint venture agreement with German-based Grass Group to build and operate solar farms and systems in the Asia-Pacific region. The joint venture company, Graess Energy, will be headquartered in Singapore and aims to install 1-2GW of solar PV projects over the next two to three years, targeting markets in Japan, Kazakhstan, Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines, and the Middle East. This diversification move is in response to the downturn in the offshore sector and is expected to create a new core business for SBI Offshore.

site_title: Greece's vote to reject further austerity demands gets Cristina Fernandez's approval
summary: Greece's rejection of further austerity demands has been met with praise from Argentine President Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner, calling it an "outright victory of democracy and dignity." The move may embolden Fernandez as she faces creditors and boost her ally Daniel Scioli's presidential campaign. The Greek crisis shares similarities with Argentina's 2001 economic crisis, where austerity measures led to a recession and government resignation. The outcome may reflect the high cost of austerity policies and their unfeasibility, echoing Argentina's experience.

site_title: STI gains eight points in broadly weak session
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 7.99 points to 3,340.93 in a quiet session, driven by hopes that Greece will be bailed out and remain in the eurozone, benefiting heavyweights Singtel and banks. Despite 183 rises and 238 falls, the session was weaker than the index's movement, with low turnover of 1.2 billion units worth S$989 million. Market volatility and concerns over Greece's negotiations kept players out of the market, with some brokers expecting a 50% devaluation of Greece's new currency and a slowdown in the eurozone.

site_title: Property investment deals surge to S$5.7b in Q2
summary: Singapore's property investment deals surged to S$5.7 billion in Q2, driven by large commercial transactions, including the S$1.67 billion winning bid for Paya Lebar Central site. However, the leasing market remains soft, and borrowing costs have increased, posing headwinds for future deals. Investment sales in shophouses nearly halved to S$53 million in Q2, and residential sales were lower than expected. Experts expect core funds to return to the Singapore office market, but caution that the outlook is uncertain due to weak rental growth and increased borrowing costs.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CORDLIFE Group rejected an unsolicited offer to buy its shares and convertible notes, instead opting to sell them to Golden Meditech. DIGILAND International appointed Goh Jin Hian as CEO, while KSH Holdings won a S$34.8 million design-and-build tender in Singapore. Meanwhile, global markets were affected by tariffs, sanctions, and economic uncertainty, with oil prices rising over 2% and stocks down in Europe and the US.

site_title: Loss of Ex-Im Bank financing a competitive disadvantage: Boeing
summary: Boeing's president, Ray Conner, expressed concern over the US Export-Import Bank's charter lapse, stating it would create a "huge competitive disadvantage" for the company. Boeing relies on the bank's financing to compete with rivals like Airbus and Embraer. Conner noted that the bank's staff is working on liquidating existing obligations, but the lapse has created uncertainty among customers. Democrats and moderate Republicans aim to revive the bank by attaching charter renewal legislation to a highway funding bill, with the Obama administration expressing concern about the impact on US competitors.

images.alt_text: Mr Conner: "We absolutely need Ex-Im Bank to compete on a level playing field. The competition is not going to back away from that kind of financing."

site_title: Gloom and doom in shipping
summary: The Shipping Confidence Survey from Moore Stephens found that overall confidence levels in the shipping industry fell to its lowest rating in seven years, with respondents mainly complaining about low freight rates and overtonnaging. Charterers were the only category to record an increase in confidence, but their rating was still the lowest. The survey attributed the decline to excess liquidity in the markets, low interest rates, and the continued impact of private equity on the industry. Experts warn that the shipping industry is likely to be weaker for many years to come due to a supply of tonnage imbalance.

site_title: London luxury-home sales dip as buying season is 'wiped out'
summary: London luxury home sales have decreased significantly, with 228 existing homes sold in June compared to 325 in the same period last year. The average sale price of a home in central London fell 4.2% to £1,487 per square foot. The market is expected to remain weak until September, with prices likely to decline further due to a decline in asking prices in July. This decline is attributed to the UK election and proposals for a mansion tax and rent controls, which led to a 30% drop in sales volumes in the first half of the year.

site_title: Greek turmoil casts shadow over forex market
summary: Greece's debt turmoil is spreading to the global foreign-exchange market, with central banks in Sweden and Switzerland battling to contain an appreciation of their currencies versus the euro. The Bank of England may delay tightening monetary policy due to concerns about the impact on the UK economy. The Swiss National Bank and Sweden's Riksbank are also struggling to stoke inflation, with strengthening euros exacerbating the issue. The Bank of Japan may increase its currency weakening stimulus if the yen strengthens.

site_title: Grandma's unsold cars jumpstart a US$1b online business in Germany
summary: A German entrepreneur, Christian Bertermann, created an online business in 2012 to sell his grandmother's unsold cars. Bertermann, an internet specialist, teamed up with Hakan Koc to fill the gap in the market for used cars. The business, initially started as a side venture, quickly gained popularity and turned into a $1 billion online business. The success story showcases the potential of online marketplaces in the automotive industry, offering a convenient platform for buyers and sellers to connect.

site_title: US: Stocks dip on fears about Greece, China
