summary: US stocks declined in early trading on Tuesday due to concerns over Greece's potential exit from the eurozone and China's fragile market. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.16%, the S&P 500 lost 0.09%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index declined 0.23%. European stocks also plummeted after German Chancellor Merkel and French President Hollande took a tough stance on Greece, while China's Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.29% amid worries of a stock market bubble.

site_title: Renault's top draw in India faces heat
summary: Renault's top-selling model in India, the Duster, faces increased competition from new entrants Suzuki and Hyundai, both launching their first compact SUV models. The segment is growing at 11% annually, with sales expected to quadruple to 1.18 million units by 2024. The entry of Suzuki and Hyundai poses a threat to Renault's local revenue, with the two companies having a wider market reach and a stronger distribution network.

site_title: OEL Holdings plans to issue up to $40m in convertible bonds
summary: OEL Holdings plans to issue up to S$40 million in redeemable zero-coupon convertible bonds to Pacific Alliance Asia Opportunity Fund. The bonds, issued in 20 tranches, can be converted into ordinary shares at a minimum price of S$0.04, potentially doubling the existing share capital.

site_title: Aussie dollar's fall below 75 US cents not enough to appease RBA chief
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has kept interest rates at a record-low 2% despite the Australian dollar falling below 75 US cents, as expected by the central bank chief Glenn Stevens. The economy is growing slowly, and commodity prices have plummeted, leading to a massive terms-of-trade shock. The RBA is pushing for an ever-weaker currency to ease financial conditions and stimulate economic growth, with some predicting the Aussie dollar could drop to 70 US cents.

site_title: Number of angel investors in Silicon Valley balloon with wealth creation
summary: Young entrepreneurs in Silicon Valley are capitalizing on the growing number of angel investors, with some securing up to $2 million in just 48 hours. A recent example is Nancy Hua, who raised money from 21 angel investors, potentially receiving more if she hadn't limited the number. This trend highlights the wealth creation opportunities available to young startups, but also underscores the need for careful management and diversification to mitigate potential downsides.

site_title: US trade deficit widens to US$41.9b in May
summary: The US trade deficit widened to $41.9 billion in May, exceeding the previous month's revised $40.7 billion. Exports declined, contributing to the increase, while imports remained relatively stable. This marks the second consecutive month of widening trade deficit.

site_title: Europe: Stocks finish lower
summary: Europe's main markets closed lower on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 1.58%, and the CAC 40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX 30 also declining 2.27% and 1.96%, respectively. The decline was attributed to bank and healthcare stocks. The US stock market also saw a slight edge down from records amid US-EU tariff threats.

site_title: Builders unveil action plans to cut workplace deaths
summary: Singapore's construction industry has unveiled action plans to reduce workplace deaths to less than 1.8 per 100,000 workers by 2018. The Design for Safety (DfS) regulations, set to be gazetted in August, will require projects with a contract value of S$10 million and above to incorporate safety features from the design stage. The government aims to train 1,000 DfS professionals by 2018 and review existing courseware to expand training capacity. The industry has seen a 28% drop in construction sector fatality rate since 2010, from 8.1 to 5.5 per 100,000 workers in 2014.

site_title: SPH Reit maintains Q3 DPU as net property income rises
summary: SPH Reit maintained its Q3 distribution per unit (DPU) at 1.35 Singapore cents, unchanged from last year, due to a 4.3% increase in net property income to S$39.3 million. Gross revenue rose 1.6% to S$51.2 million, driven by higher rental income from Paragon and The Clementi Mall. The Reit's occupancy rates remain strong, with Paragon at 99.8% and The Clementi Mall fully leased. Despite a challenging retail environment, the Reit expects steady performance from its assets, with an asset enhancement programme to create additional lettable space.

site_title: Greek debt writedown against bailout rules: Schaeuble
summary: German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble stated that a debt haircut, or writedown, is not allowed under Europe's bailout rules. The comment came as Greece's finance ministers meeting was set to discuss the country's debt crisis. Schaeuble did not rule out Greece keeping the euro, but said it was a decision for the Greek government. This move may impact Greece's ability to secure a bailout and potentially exit the eurozone.

site_title: WSJ publishes documents linked to graft allegations against Najib
summary: The Wall Street Journal has released documents allegedly linked to graft allegations against Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, stemming from the government probe into state investment fund 1MDB. The documents include a diagram showing money flows to Najib's bank account and bank statements. The release of the documents is part of the ongoing probe into Najib's alleged involvement in corruption and money laundering.

site_title: Triyards, Emas Offshore bag new orders but post muted Q3 results
summary: Singapore-listed companies Triyards and Emas Offshore announced new contract wins, with Triyards securing two orders for large liftboats worth US$175 million and Emas Offshore securing three contracts worth over US$24 million. Despite these wins, both companies reported subdued third-quarter results, with Triyards' net profit down 14% to US$5.42 million and Emas Offshore's after-tax profit up 2,800% to US$5.18 million. Analysts attributed the results to higher administrative expenses and weakness in certain segments, but maintained positive long-term outlooks.

site_title: KL special task force freezes 6 bank accounts linked to 1MDB scandal
summary: Malaysia's special taskforce has frozen six bank accounts linked to the 1MDB scandal, which involves allegations of nearly $700 million being deposited into Prime Minister Najib Razak's personal accounts. The move comes as opposition lawmakers call for Najib to step aside during the probe. Documents seized from two banks relate to non-compliance with Bank Negara rules, but details are scarce. The freezing of accounts follows a raid on 1MDB-related companies and allegations that Attorney-General Abdul Gani Patail knew of the funds diversion but was dragging his feet.

site_title: Malaysian central bank defends ailing ringgit amid political storm
summary: Malaysia's central bank intervened for a third day to support the ailing ringgit currency amid corruption allegations against Prime Minister Najib Razak, which have raised doubts about his grip on power. The ringgit has lost 0.8% since the allegations surfaced, breaching its old currency peg of 3.80 per dollar. Despite Bank Negara's efforts, the ringgit remains Asia's weakest performing currency this year, and investors are selling Malaysian assets, fueling concerns about the country's economic stability.

site_title: Update: NS, EW train services may be limited on Wednesday: SMRT
summary: SMRT Corporation has advised commuters to make alternative travel plans on Wednesday due to possible limited services on the North-South and East-West rail lines. The disruption occurred on Tuesday evening, with both lines affected concurrently. Engineers are investigating a power-related equipment failure, and SMRT has mobilized staff to check the entire network and train fleet. The transport minister, Lui Tuck Yew, assured commuters that services will resume as soon as possible. SMRT also announced a new rail financing framework, where the government will own operating assets and lease them to SMRT, to address the financial sustainability of the rail business.

site_title: Proposed changes to Takeover Code welcome
summary: The Securities Industries Council (SIC) has proposed changes to the Singapore Code on Takeovers and Mergers to ensure a more balanced price for buyers and sellers in takeovers involving privatisations. The changes aim to protect minority shareholders and promote transparency in the bidding process. The proposed rules would balance the interests of majority shareholders who want to pay the lowest possible price and sellers who seek the highest possible price, in an effort to achieve a suitable middle ground.

images.alt_text: In many takeovers that involve privatisations, minority rights are usually trampled on by the actions and intent of the majority.

site_title: How to make sense of China's plummeting stock market
summary: China's stock market has plummeted 26% in four weeks, sparking concerns about the country's economy and global market impact. However, data suggests the decline may be an inevitable correction after a year of rapid price growth without corresponding earnings increases. The Shanghai composite index's price-to-earnings ratio has soared to nearly 26, indicating investors are willing to pay more for the same return. Despite China's efforts to prop up the market, the economic backdrop, including slowing growth, makes it difficult to justify the recent price surge.

site_title: Jailed former Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim admitted to hospital again
summary: Former Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim was admitted to Hospital Kuala Lumpur for further medical treatment, following a hospitalization in June. He will receive intensive physiotherapy for shoulder pain, monitor his blood pressure, and undergo a CT scan of his kidneys. This comes after a month of recovery from his initial hospitalization.

site_title: Game of Thrones 2016: the plot thickens
summary: The 2016 US presidential campaign was not a straightforward fight between Democratic Hillary Clinton and Republican Jeb Bush, as suggested by some pundits. Instead, it was a complex and evolving narrative, likened to the popular HBO series "Game of Thrones." Late-night comedians noted the unpredictability of the campaign, with various candidates emerging and fading into the background. The article highlights the dynamic nature of the campaign, which would ultimately lead to the surprise candidacy of Donald Trump.

site_title: Biggest US banks would ditch securities arms in bankruptcy
summary: US banks have submitted living wills, outlining how they would restructure and resolve themselves in the event of bankruptcy. The plans, submitted by 12 major banks, show that the firms would keep core units and shed non-essential operations, including securities arms. JPMorgan would shrink by about a third, while Citigroup would cut corporate banking and retail banking, and sell off broker-dealers. The plans aim to ensure orderly resolution without taxpayer support, but regulators have expressed concerns about the firms' progress in paring their number of subsidiaries and addressing shortcomings.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan Chase & Co says the bank's living will would resolve the firm quickly and without systemic disruption or taxpayer support.

site_title: Indonesia orders AirAsia affiliate to raise equity or risk losing licence
summary: Indonesia has threatened to suspend the operating licenses of 13 airlines, including AirAsia's affiliate PT Indonesia AirAsia, unless they raise new equity by July 31. The airlines have "negative equity" and must turn it positive to avoid license suspension. PT Indonesia AirAsia needs at least $309 million to reverse its shareholder funds deficit. The company may explore debt or new share issuance options to stay afloat. If not met, the transport ministry warned that the airlines will not ensure passenger safety.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary: Temasek Holdings reported a 19% net portfolio gain of S$43 billion to S$266 billion for FY15, its most active year since the global financial crisis. Noble Group initiated a third-party review of mark-to-market models and valuations. The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore plans to release more spectrum for mobile broadband services, paving the way for a fourth telco operator. Additionally, SBI Offshore Limited diversified into solar energy through a joint venture, and SRX Property launched a free app for tracking home values and rents.

site_title: KSH wins S$34.8m contract
summary: KSH Holdings has won a S$34.8 million design-and-build contract in Singapore for a steel structure, electrical intake station, and ancillary works. The project is expected to start in July 2015 and be completed within 16 months, boosting KSH's order book to S$400 million. The contract is expected to contribute positively to the group's performance from the financial year ending March 31, 2016.

site_title: Greece: A mess with consequences
summary: Greece is on the brink of an economic abyss after its "no" vote on needed reforms, raising concerns about its potential expulsion from the eurozone. The country's dysfunctional political economy has led to a 177% debt-to-GDP ratio, 25% unemployment, and a shrinking economy. The EU is hesitant to accept a "no" vote, which could lead to a Greek exit, causing economic disruption and setting a bad precedent. The crisis is further complicated by the global economic slowdown, China's rising influence, and the potential for a UK exit from the EU.

site_title: Greek aid proposal not expected on Tuesday: eurozone source
summary: Greece is expected to submit a new aid proposal to European creditors on Wednesday, following emergency talks in Brussels. A eurozone official stated that the proposal may outline Athens' plans for economic reforms, but did not confirm the exact timing. The move comes as Greece faces financial struggles and its European partners seek to address the crisis. The official's comments suggest that Greece's aid proposal may be submitted "maybe tomorrow," indicating uncertainty over the timing.

site_title: Hoax phone call costs hedge fund US$1.2 million and CFO's job
summary: A Fortelus Capital Management hedge fund executive, Thomas Meston, was conned by a scammer who impersonated a Coutts bank representative, resulting in a loss of $1.56 million. Meston agreed to provide codes to cancel suspicious payments, but the funds were later withdrawn. Fortelus terminated Meston and is suing him for breach of duty. The incident highlights the vulnerability of online security systems to human error and the growing threat of cybercrime to financial stability.

site_title: Average monthly Orchard Rd gross retail rent may slip by up to 5% in 2015: Colliers
summary: Average monthly gross retail rent in Orchard Road may decrease by up to 5% in 2015, according to a report by Colliers International. The decline follows a quarter-on-quarter drop of 1.6% in Q2, attributed to labour and occupational cost pressures, and competition from new malls in suburban regional centres. This brings the current rental to 3.9% higher than regional centres, down from a 6.9% difference last year. Tepid tourist numbers and new store openings in decentralised areas are also contributing factors.

site_title: Bloomberg's granddaughter gets hybrid surname
summary: Former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg's 36-year-old daughter Emma has given birth to a daughter, Zelda Violet Frissberg, combining her surname with her husband Chris Frissora's. The name Frissberg represents a portmanteau of the couple's surnames. Bloomberg has made no public mention of the birth, but expressed excitement to be a grandfather. This marks his second grandchild, with his younger daughter Georgina's son Jasper also being a grandchild.

site_title: Issuance of Islamic bonds to drop sharply in 2015: S&P
summary: Islamic sukuk issuance is expected to drop sharply in 2015, with Standard & Poor's forecasting a decline of 50-60 billion US dollars. This is largely due to Malaysia's Central Bank stopping sukuk issuance, which accounted for 42.5% of global sukuk issuance in the first half of 2015. The bank's decision was made due to sukuk being subscribed to by a broad range of investors, preventing them from reaching their intended end-users. Despite this, the sukuk market performed relatively well, with the global value of outstanding sukuk at US$269.4 billion at the end of 2013.

site_title: Japan's Aeon interested in buying Tesco's Malaysia unit: sources
summary: Japan's Aeon Co Ltd is interested in buying Tesco's Malaysian operations, valued at around $1.88 billion, as the retailer seeks to expand its presence in Southeast Asia. Aeon, which has 28 hypermarkets in Malaysia, plans to open 100 more stores by 2020. Tesco is currently seeking buyers for its South Korean business and data-gathering arm to fund a turnaround in its home market. The sale of Tesco's Malaysian unit would give Aeon its largest hypermarkets group, but negotiations are still in the early stage.

site_title: 4th telco operator to be allocated spectrum at lower price: IDA
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) plans to release 225 MHz of spectrum for mobile broadband services by next year, making it available for a fourth telco operator. The selected company will receive a lower indicative reserve package price of S$40 million, recognizing the entry barriers faced by new entrants in a mature market. The new operator must deploy its own network and achieve nationwide rollout by end-September 2018. IDA's proposal is open for public consultation until August 12.

site_title: Singapore: STI rises 8 points in broadly weak session
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 7.99 points to 3,340.93, driven by gains in Singtel and banks, despite a broadly weak session. Turnover was 1.2 billion units worth S$989 million. Concerns over Greek negotiations and extreme volatility in China and Hong Kong kept some players out of the market. Noble Group shares ended unchanged after setting up an independent board committee to address concerns over its mark-to-market models and governance framework.

site_title: China's IPO curbs risk US$32 billion of US take-private deals
summary: China's securities regulator has curbed initial public offerings (IPOs) to contain a stock market meltdown, which may endanger US$32 billion of US take-private deals. The regulator announced there would be "no new IPOs in the near-term" and reduced deals in the future. Chinese companies planning to list on US exchanges and return home are re-evaluating their plans, as the market has slumped 30% since mid-June. This move may impact nearly US$32 billion worth of deals announced this year.

site_title: SPH Reit posts unchanged Q3 DPU of 1.35 cents
summary: SPH Reit reported unchanged Q3 DPU of 1.35 cents, matching the previous year's quarter. Net property income grew 4.3% to S$39.3 million, while gross revenue rose 1.6% to S$51.2 million. The Reit attributed the growth to higher rental income from Paragon and The Clementi Mall. However, the retail environment remains challenging, with a 3.4% decline in March's retail sales index and forecasted 0-3% growth in international visitor arrivals and 0-2% growth in tourist receipts for 2015.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks close down 1.29%
summary: China's Shanghai stock index closed down 1.29% on Tuesday, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 48.79 points to 3,727.12 on turnover of 776.1 billion yuan. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, down 5.34% to 1,932.83 on turnover of 301.4 billion yuan. Despite recent government efforts to boost the market, the losses narrowed from earlier drops.

site_title: China joins Greece, Puerto Rico on top of biggest US investors' worry lists
summary: US investors, including Jeffrey Gundlach, Bill Gross, and Mohamed El-Erian, have China at the top of their worry lists due to severe market volatility and concerns about a potential economic bubble. Chinese markets have tumbled over 20% since June 12, with Shanghai's benchmark share index plunging below 4,000 points for the first time since April. Investors are warning of a risk of a "run on the new US shadow banking system" and advising a "barbell" approach of holding cash and illiquid assets. China's economic growth has slowed to 7% in the first three months of 2015, its slowest quarterly pace in six years.

site_title: SRX Property launches free app for tracking value, rent of homes
summary: SRX Property launched a free app called "my Property Tracker" to provide subscribers with customized monthly updates on home values, rents, and rental yields. The app features three sections: Home figures & facts, neighbourhood listings, and neighbourhood transactions, offering real-time data on listings and sales. Homeowners and renters can subscribe to the app on SRX.com.sg/tracker, receiving a personalized webpage with a unique URL tied to their home's postal code.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 1.31% after Greek vote dive
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.31% on Tuesday, following Greece's austerity vote, which analysts deemed overdone. The Nikkei 225 index rose 264.47 points to 20,376.59, while the Topix index climbed 1.04% to 1,637.23. The gains reversed previous day's losses.

site_title: More than 200 Chinese firms say to halt trading
summary: More than 200 Chinese-listed firms have halted trading in their shares, citing China's plunging stock markets. This follows a week where 560 companies, or 23% of the 2,808 A-share listed firms on the Shanghai and Shenzhen Exchanges, suspended trading. The move aims to shield these companies from market volatility.

site_title: Temasek says CEO Ho Ching to return after sabbatical ends
summary: Singapore state investor Temasek Holdings announced that CEO Ho Ching will return to her role after a three-month sabbatical ends later this month. The decision comes as the board reviews succession policies annually. Ho Ching took leave following the death of her father-in-law, Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's first prime minister, in March. No details were provided on her long-term plans or potential changes to leadership.

site_title: Temasek portfolio up 19% to S$266b in FY15
summary: Temasek Holdings reported a 19% net portfolio gain to S$266 billion for FY15, the largest since the global financial crisis. The firm's group net profit rose to S$14.5 billion, with a 19.2% total shareholder return. New investments focused on consumer, financials, and life sciences, with half in Asia, North America, and Europe. Exposure to Asia excluding Singapore increased to 42%, while China exposure rose to 27%. Divestments included paring its stake in China Construction Bank and exiting several investments, including Alibaba.

site_title: Oil prices stabilise after massive selloff, but outlook remains weak
summary: Crude oil prices stabilized on Tuesday, rising 40 cents to US$52.93 per barrel for front-month US crude futures, and 45 cents to US$56.99 per barrel for Brent crude. Despite the slight increases, analysts remain bearish, citing macroeconomic headwinds and a structurally oversupplied market, with prices potentially capped below US$70 per barrel. The outlook for oil demand is grim due to economic uncertainty in Greece and China, while some analysts see longer-term supply/demand fundamentals as bullish.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysian shares ended lower on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index losing 4.75 points to close at 1,712.30. 1.69 billion lots worth RM1.73 billion were traded, with 466 losers outnumbering 314 gainers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close 1.03% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 1.03% lower, extending losses from the previous day. The Hang Seng Index dropped 260.97 points to 24,975.31, following a sell-off in mainland Chinese markets. The decline was attributed to Chinese firms listed in Hong Kong tumbling. The benchmark index closed on turnover of HK$172.48 billion.

site_title: Australia: Stocks rally 1.94% despite Greece
summary: Australian stocks rose 1.94% on Tuesday, despite the ongoing Greek crisis, as investors snapped up oversold shares. The benchmark S&P/ASX200 index reclaimed losses from the previous day ahead of an emergency summit in Brussels. Investors believed the crisis was of little consequence for Australia, citing the stability of European and US markets. The Australian dollar closed at 74.89 US cents, and the benchmark index closed at 5,581.4.

site_title: SGX welcomes Noble's decision to get third-party review
summary: SGX welcomes Noble Group's decision to commission a third-party review of its mark to market models and valuations, citing increased transparency as a positive step. The exchange will continue to monitor the situation and request further clarity if necessary. SGX has been in close communication with Noble Group to meet the needs of its stakeholders, looking forward to the release of the review results. This move aims to address market concerns raised by Noble Group's accounting practices.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose slightly at the start of trading on Tuesday, recovering from heavy losses the previous day. The DAX 30 in Frankfurt gained 0.36%, the CAC 40 in Paris edged up 0.02%, and London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.10%. The gains were driven by mining and healthcare shares, as investors focus on US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Australia's central bank holds interest rate at 2.0%
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, held interest rates at 2.0% for the second consecutive month, citing subdued economic growth and the need for accommodative monetary policy. The decision was made despite a weaker Australian dollar and a recent decline in commodity prices. Governor Glenn Stevens expressed confidence in the need for a weaker exchange rate to support sustainable growth and inflation. The economy has been growing below trend, with a decade-high unemployment rate and slow wages growth. The decision was largely seen as a wait-and-see move by the RBA.

site_title: LifeBrandz in talks over a 'very substantial acquisition or RTO'
summary: LifeBrandz, a nightclub operator, is in preliminary discussions with a third party regarding a "very substantial acquisition or reverse takeover". The discussions are ongoing, and no definitive agreements have been reached. As a result, the company advises shareholders to exercise caution in trading its shares. The acquisition or takeover, if completed, would likely have significant implications for the company's future operations and share price.

site_title: EMAS Offshore bags US$24m contracts
summary: EMAS Offshore secured three contracts worth up to US$24 million, including one from an oil major in West Africa and two in Thailand. The charters, with an average duration of 1.1 years, are expected to start in Q4 2015. The company posted an after-tax profit of US$5.18 million in Q3, a 28-fold increase from the previous year, driven by a bigger contribution from associates. However, revenue declined 15% year-on-year to US$59.24 million, and the net asset value per share fell to US$1.15.

site_title: Non-listed real estate funds draw 62.5% of capital raised for Asia-Pac vehicles
summary: Non-listed real estate funds raised 62.5% of the $23.5 billion capital for Asia-Pacific vehicles in 2015, according to a report by ANREV, INREV, and NCREIF. Globally, fund managers raised $149.2 billion, a 12.6% year-over-year increase. Non-listed funds attract 53.7% of total equity, up from 49% in 2013. The survey, which received responses from 142 fund managers, predicts another increase in capital raising activity in the next two years.

site_title: Vietnam Airlines, Boeing to negotiate about 16 more airplane sales
summary: Boeing and Vietnam Airlines agreed to negotiate the sale of eight more 787-10 Dreamliners and eight 777-8X aircraft, marking a significant expansion of trade ties between the US and Vietnam. The deal reflects a growing relationship between the two nations, with US Deputy Commerce Secretary Bruce Andrews stating that it represents an "important dimension" of trade expansion. The agreement also aims to promote US companies in Vietnam through the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a key aerospace and manufacturing market. The deal is seen as a milestone in bilateral trade efforts between the US and Vietnam.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up but Shanghai tumbles again
summary: Asian markets mostly recovered Tuesday, but Shanghai tumbled again amid concerns over government measures to curb the recent sell-off. The euro held steady after Greece's weekend vote against austerity proposals, limiting contagion. Crude prices edged up after Monday's hammering due to the Greek crisis and China's stock market struggles.

site_title: China needs long-range strategic bomber: state media
summary: China needs to develop a long-range strategic bomber to strike adversaries farther away from its coast in the event of conflict, state media reported. The country's air force is considered a "strategic force" and a recent meeting deemed the need for such a bomber to attack the "second island chain" in the Pacific Ocean, including Guam and the US territory of Hawaii. This development comes as China asserts its territorial claims in the East and South China Seas, raising tensions with the US. A long-range strategic bomber would enable China to strike farther out into the Pacific without refuelling.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall to 3-week low; won slips to near 4-month low
summary: South Korean shares fell to a three-week low, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closing down 0.7% at 2,040.29 points. The won also dropped 0.3% to 1,130.2 against the dollar, its lowest level since March 17. Pharmaceutical shares plummeted 13.2%, their largest daily loss since 2001, while LG Display Co rebounded 4.1% after reaching its lowest level in over a year. Investors await the outcome of an emergency euro zone summit on Greece for clues on the euro's future.

site_title: Gold gets ignored in Greek meltdown with fewest bulls since 2006
summary: Gold prices have plummeted, falling 40% since 2011, as investors shun the metal in favor of equities and the dollar. The net-bullish wager on gold is the smallest since 2006, with over $300 million wiped from the value of gold-backed exchange-traded products in the past month. Despite Greece's euro crisis, gold demand remains steady, with physical demand from Greek customers and other countries increasing. Experts predict gold prices will drop an additional 11% by the end of 2015, reaching a five-year low.

site_title: China: Stocks extend rout despite support measures as hundreds of companies ask for trading halts
summary: Chinese stocks extended their rout, falling 4.8% in early trading on Tuesday, despite government support measures. The CSI300 index sank 3.4% as hundreds of companies asked for trading halts. Premier Li Keqiang's comments on the economy failed to reassure investors, as he didn't mention the market's recent decline. The decline marks a 30% drop in Chinese shares since mid-June, with no clear end in sight to the market's volatility.

site_title: Britain faces first Conservative budget in two decades
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron's government will unveil its first Conservative budget in nearly 20 years, targeting deep welfare cutbacks and a £12 billion spending reduction. Finance Minister George Osborne will present his plans on Wednesday, aiming to cap annual welfare payments at £23,000 per household and increase rent for subsidized council housing. The budget also seeks to lower the tax burden and address concerns about the welfare system's culture of state handouts, while tackling Britain's £1.5 trillion debt.

site_title: SBI Offshore diversifies into solar energy business
summary: SBI Offshore Limited has entered into a joint venture agreement with GSS Renewables to pursue solar photovoltaic (PV) energy business. The joint venture company, Graess Energy Private Limited, will be incorporated in Singapore with an initial paid-up capital of US$100. SBI Offshore chairman John Chan plans to invest in PV projects in Japan, Kazakhstan, Thailand, the Philippines, and the Middle East. The company will seek shareholders' approval for the diversification into this new business, and the investment's impact on earnings and net tangible assets is uncertain.

images.alt_text: SBI Offshore Limited on Tuesday announced that it has entered into a joint venture agreement with GSS Renewables to pursue solar photovoltaic (PV) energy business.

site_title: Singapore to release advance Q2 GDP data on July 14
summary: Singapore will release advance Q2 GDP data on July 14 at 8 am GMT, showing economists expect a 2.7% year-on-year expansion in the April-June quarter. The data follows a 2.6% growth in the first quarter and a 3.2% growth in the previous quarter on an annualized basis.

site_title: Oil prices rebound in Asia
summary: Oil prices rebounded in Asia on Tuesday, rising ahead of an emergency summit on Greece, following a 8.0% plunge in US closing deals Monday. West Texas Intermediate advanced 47 cents to US$53.00, while Brent crude gained 69 cents to US$57.23. Analysts attribute the rebound to bargain-hunting, with some speculating an exit from the eurozone could trigger a contagion effect. Ongoing negotiations between Western powers and Iran on Tehran's nuclear ambitions are also being closely watched.

site_title: Malaysia task force to freeze bank accounts in Najib money probe
summary: A Malaysian task force has ordered the freezing of six bank accounts linked to a money trail allegedly showing funds from a state investment company ending up in Prime Minister Najib Razak's personal accounts. The investigation, which began after a Wall Street Journal report claimed about $700 million may have moved through government agencies and companies linked to debt-ridden 1Malaysia Development Bhd, is ongoing. Najib has denied the claims, calling them part of a campaign of political sabotage.

images.alt_text: A Malaysia task force has ordered a freeze on six bank accounts believed linked to a money trail that allegedly showed funds from a state investment company ending in Prime Minister Najib Razak's personal accounts.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 0.32 points to 1716.73, with volume reaching 18.88 million lots worth RM8.07 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 84 to 51.

site_title: Habit of "giving while living" detrimental to retirement goals in Singapore: HSBC report
summary: Singaporean retirees are falling short of retirement goals due to ongoing financial support of their families, according to a HSBC report. 81% of Singaporean retirees must adjust one or more retirement goals due to budget constraints, with 66% pre-retirees planning to leave an inheritance to their children, but only 18% having received one. This phenomenon, known as "giving while living," is affecting inheritance plans and is attributed to strong family ties.

site_title: Sealed HSBC report shows US managers battling clean-up squad
summary: HSBC's US investment-banking unit resisted the bank's efforts to clean up its act, with some managers bullying and discrediting in-house watchdogs. Despite agreeing to submit to a court-appointed monitor in 2012, the US unit continued to provide banking services to clients at risk, including a Saudi bank linked to 9/11 hijackers. The report, previously unreported, highlights the challenges in implementing reforms at the bank.

site_title: Japan must consider exemptions for 2017 sales tax, Abe aide says
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe must consider exemptions when raising the sales tax again, according to Koichi Hamada, one of Abe's economic advisers. Hamada suggests exempting food and other basics to reduce the burden on poorer citizens, particularly those living on pensions. The exemptions should target necessities for people with low incomes, who will be disproportionately affected by the tax hike. The move comes after last year's recession prompted Abe to delay the tax hike, and it aims to address concerns about the nation's high debt burden.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.3% higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 0.3% higher on Tuesday, at 3,342.88, driven by gains from top gainers such as Great Eastern Holdings, Jardine Matheson Holdings, and Singapore Exchange. The market is awaiting an emergency meeting of European leaders and finance ministers on Greece. Trading volume was 50.7 million shares worth S$64.1 million, with 89 gainers outnumbering 50 losers.

site_title: Hot Stock: Noble slips 0.7% after announcing third party review
summary: Noble Group shares fell 0.7% after announcing a third-party review of mark-to-market models and valuations. The review, led by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, aims to address concerns over the company's accounting practices and lack of transparency. The independent board committee, comprising non-executive members, was set up to oversee the review. The move follows Noble's previous issues with its valuation methods and governance framework.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks slump 3.21% on opening
summary: China's benchmark Shanghai stock index dropped 3.21% on July 7, wiping out previous gains, after the government unveiled new measures to boost the slumping market. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 121.13 points to 3,654.78, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 3.50% to 1,970.38. This is the first major decline in the market since a previous day's gains. The government's new package of measures aims to stabilize the market, but the impact is yet to be seen.

site_title: Eurozone leaders to hold emergency summit on Greece
summary: Eurozone leaders will hold an emergency summit in Brussels on Tuesday to discuss the Greek crisis, following a historic "No" to austerity measures in a referendum. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras will unveil new proposals, while German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Francois Hollande urged him to make "precise" proposals to revive bailout talks. The European Central Bank has maintained emergency funding for Greek banks, but conditions for a new Greek rescue package "have not yet been met." A Grexit, or Greece's exit from the eurozone, is considered a "very high" possibility, with more than three-quarters of Greeks wanting to stay in the eurozone.

site_title: WHO urges governments to raise tobacco taxes to beat smoking
summary: The World Health Organisation (WHO) urges governments to increase tobacco taxes to combat smoking and generate funds for stronger health services. The WHO recommends that at least 75% of a pack of cigarettes be taxed to dissuade people from smoking. Tobacco-related deaths are forecast to rise to over 8 million annually by 2030 unless measures are taken to control the "tobacco epidemic." Currently, one person dies from tobacco-related disease every six seconds, equivalent to 6 million deaths per year.

site_title: Malaysia plans more subsidy cuts with 1MDB raising policy risk
summary: Malaysia plans to cut subsidies on petrol, liquefied petroleum gas, and cooking oil, and move billions of dollars in government employee housing loans off its balance sheets to bolster its fiscal position. The move comes amid a growing scandal threatening Prime Minister Najib Razak's ability to implement policies. A Fitch Ratings decision to pull back from downgrading Malaysia provides space for the country to strengthen its fiscal credentials. Despite 1MDB scandal, the government asserts the state investment firm has enough assets to pay off its debt.

site_title: So, who's who in Noble's independent board committee?
summary: Noble, a commodity group, has established an independent board committee consisting of four non-executive members to review its MTM models, valuations, and governance framework. The committee, led by Paul Brough, has appointed PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) to conduct the assurance review. This move comes in response to criticism and contentious issues raised by stakeholders. The review aims to address concerns and provide assurance on Noble's internal controls and decision-making processes.

site_title: Sheryl Sandberg joins SurveyMonkey board after husband's death
summary: Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook's COO, joined SurveyMonkey's board after her husband David Goldberg's unexpected death in May. Goldberg was SurveyMonkey's CEO for six years. Sandberg aims to "realize Dave's vision" and help build a lasting company. Facebook's former CFO David Ebersman and GoPro executive Zander Lurie also joined the board, with Lurie becoming permanent chairman.

images.alt_text: Sheryl Sandberg joined the board of SurveyMonkey, the company her husband ran until his unexpected death in May.

site_title: As China intervenes to prop up stocks, foreigners head for exits
summary: Foreign investors are selling Shanghai shares at a record pace as China steps up government intervention to combat a stock-market rout. Despite efforts to prop up the market, including stock purchases by state-run financial firms and a halt to initial public offerings, investors remain skeptical about the government's ability to manage the financial system. Foreign investors have been net sellers of mainland shares through the Hong Kong link, with options traders in the US paying near-record prices for insurance against further losses. The Shanghai Composite Index has plunged 29% since its peak, with median valuations of stocks exceeding 59 times reported earnings.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.62% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.62% higher on Tuesday, rebounding from a 3% drop in the previous session. The Hang Seng Index rose 155.48 points to 25,391.76. The gains followed a global rally, despite US-EU trade tensions and US stock market near records.

site_title: White House calls on Greece, EU to find compromise
summary: The White House urged Greece and EU leaders to find a compromise to keep Greece in the eurozone after the country's resounding rejection of an austerity-based bailout. The US called for a package of reforms and financing that would allow Greece to achieve debt sustainability and economic growth. US President Barack Obama spoke with French President Francois Hollande to emphasize the importance of finding a path forward, requiring difficult compromises from all sides. The White House and US Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew also called for multiparty talks and a constructive outcome.

site_title: Cosby admits drugging woman for sex
summary: Bill Cosby admitted in a 2005 deposition that he drugged at least one woman with Quaaludes to have sex with her, specifically mentioning an incident in 1976. Cosby obtained seven prescriptions for the powerful sedative and gave them to others, including the woman, who was referred to as "Ms. T" to preserve her anonymity. This admission was made in court documents unsealed Monday, contradicting Cosby's previous denials of any wrongdoing.

images.alt_text: Embattled US comedian Bill Cosby (centre) admitted having drugged at least one woman with Quaaludes to have sex with her, in court documents unsealed Monday.

site_title: China premier says Beijing has ability to deal with risks to economy: gov.cn
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang stated that China has the ability to deal with economic risks and challenges, citing stabilized major indicators and emerging positive signs. The economy showed basic stability, according to the statistics bureau. However, China's stock market has slumped 30% since June, with top leaders remaining silent on the issue.

images.alt_text: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang said on Monday that China had the confidence and ability to deal with the risks and challenges faced by its economy, according to a statement on the central government's website.

site_title: Hedge funds who called treasuries wrong are now getting it right
summary: Hedge funds that previously bet against US treasuries are now seeing their predictions vindicated. Last week, they reduced their short positions in 10-year notes to almost zero, and the market has since risen, driven by concerns over Greece's euro membership and tumbling Chinese shares. The 10-year US yield has increased by 0.4% in July, as investors seek safer assets. This reversal marks a significant improvement in hedge funds' track record, following a 53-basis-point decline in January and a three-month selloff in treasuries.

site_title: Asia: Stocks climb after rout as investors weigh Greek debt crisis
summary: Asian stocks rose 0.4% to a two-month high, rebounding from the biggest drop since February 2014, as investors weighed the Greek debt crisis before an emergency meeting of European leaders. Despite initial shock, markets are seen as ring-fenced and unlikely to create contagion. Other regional indexes, including Japan's Topix and South Korea's Kospi, also gained ground.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 1.20% up
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 1.20% higher on July 7, 2015, following a global decline on concerns Greece would exit the eurozone. The Nikkei 225 index rose 242.11 points to 20,354.12. Investors awaited developments in the crisis, including Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' proposals in Brussels, amid European Central Bank pressure on Athens. The euro strengthened to US$1.1041 and 135.47 yen.

site_title: Cordlife rejects third party offer for China Cord Blood stake and notes
summary: Cordlife Group has rejected an unsolicited third-party offer for its shares in China Cord Blood Corporation (CCBC) and convertible notes due 2017. Instead, it will proceed with an earlier plan to sell these assets to Hang Seng-listed healthcare company Golden Meditech for a minimum of S$146.5 million in cash. The decision was made after considering various commercial and legal factors, including a binding agreement with Golden Meditech and the terms of the offer. The transaction is subject to shareholder approval by both companies.

site_title: Stocks to Watch: Noble, mDR, AsiaPhos, healthcare stocks
summary: Noble Group initiated a third-party review of mark-to-market models and valuations. mDR Ltd is set to acquire a Japanese mobile content company for S$110-165 million. AsiaPhos acquired LY Resources' entire stake for S$36.8 million. Healthcare stocks in Singapore saw a 26.4% price gain in the first six months of the year.

site_title: Brazil unveils plan to encourage cutting hours rather than jobs
summary: Brazil's government has introduced a plan to encourage employers to cut employees' hours rather than firing them, as the country struggles with an economic slowdown. The plan, which supplements employee income, allows employers to cut regular hours by up to 30% with a corresponding reduction in wages. The government will cover half of the lost salary, up to a limit of 900.84 reais. The decree, issued by the presidency, aims to ease concerns among union allies of President Dilma Rousseff's Workers' Party-led coalition, which have criticized recent budget cuts and social security changes.

site_title: Disney seeks continued tax exemption from Anaheim, California
summary: Disney seeks a 30-year tax exemption from Anaheim, California, in exchange for a $1 billion-plus expansion of its theme park complex. The current exemption is set to expire in 2016, but the city council is expected to vote on the plan, which would reimburse Disney for any future admission tax imposed. The expansion is expected to create 2,600 local jobs per year and support 2,100 permanent jobs, with construction to begin by 2017 and finish by 2024.

site_title: Noble commissions review of mark to market models and valuations
summary: Noble Group initiates review of mark-to-market models and valuations following criticism of its accounting practices and lack of transparency. The review, led by PricewaterhouseCoopers, aims to assess the accuracy of the company's models and valuations. The board has set up an independent committee to oversee the review and ensure transparency. The move comes after Noble announced plans to redeem a US$235 million bond to cut interest costs and improve its balance sheet. The review's findings will be reported to the board and publicly released.

site_title: Buffett donates record US$2.84b to Gates, family charities
summary: Warren Buffett donated approximately US$2.84 billion to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and four family charities, his largest donation to date. This marks the 10th annual donation and increases his total contributions to over US$21.5 billion. Buffett still owns nearly 19% of Berkshire Hathaway's stock, valued at over US$64 billion, making him the fourth wealthiest individual worldwide.

site_title: Digiland appoints Goh Jin Hian as CEO
summary: Digiland International has appointed Goh Jin Hian as its CEO, effective July 7, 2015. Dr. Goh was previously appointed as an executive director on June 24, 2015.

site_title: Triyards Q3 net down 14%, announces US$175m in order wins
summary: Trijyards Holdings reported a 14% year-on-year decline in net profit to US$5.42 million for Q3 2015, driven by increased administrative expenses. Revenue rose 16% to US$63.91 million, primarily from four liftboats in advanced construction stages. The company also announced US$175 million in order wins for two liftboats and fulfilled exercise conditions for its issuance of 29.5 million warrants.

site_title: Plan to increase Sunday shopping hours in Britain
summary: The British government plans to allow shops to open longer on Sundays, devolving the power to mayors and local authorities. Finance Minister George Osborne aims to give retailers a competitive edge against online shopping and global tourist destinations. The 1994 law currently limits larger shops to six hours of Sunday trading, but Osborne's plan is expected to face opposition from unions and the Church of England, who value Sundays as a common day off. The decision will be made on a local basis, with some areas potentially opening for longer hours.

site_title: Latin America, Europe cab drivers team up against Uber
summary: Taxi drivers from Latin America and Europe formed an alliance against Uber and Cabify, citing threats to the taxi sector. The international front, announced by Mexican taxi associations, includes drivers from Brazil, France, and Spain. Protests are planned, including a July 29 demonstration in front of the Mexican embassy in Madrid. The move aims to protect taxi drivers from the "illegal operations" of ride-hailing companies, which put the sector at risk.

site_title: Samsung profit misses estimates on weaker S6 smartphone sales
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 4% decline in operating income to 6.9 trillion won (S$8.3 billion) in the second quarter, missing analyst estimates. The decline was attributed to weaker sales of the S6 smartphone, partly due to production constraints and shortages of the curved display model. Despite initial praise for the device, the sales fell short, and the company struggled to lure customers away from Apple's iPhone and cheaper handsets from China.

site_title: Google tests carpooling app in Israel with Waze traffic service
summary: Google is testing a carpooling app called RideWith in the Tel Aviv area, using its Waze traffic service. The feature connects drivers and potential riders during rush hour, with restrictions including limiting rides to two a day and reimbursing drivers only for gas and vehicle wear. This is part of Google's effort to attract users and compete with rivals like Uber and Apple, as well as integrate Waze into its mapping feature. The pilot aims to learn from user feedback and expand the service if successful.

site_title: Britain's banks urge govt to phase out industry levy
summary: Britain's banks have urged the government to phase out the bank levy, citing its damaging effect on competitiveness and causing business to be lost to overseas rivals. The levy, introduced in 2011 to raise revenue and discourage risky borrowing, now aims to generate £3.4 billion annually. The British Bankers Association has suggested reforming the tax, including capping its rate and introducing a sunset clause, to allow banks to plan for a future without the levy. The Treasury has not commented on whether the Chancellor's emergency budget will address the issue, which was a Conservative party election manifesto pledge.

site_title: New Greek finance minister is a change of style, not substance
summary: Greece's new finance minister, Euclid Tsakalotos, brings a change in style from his predecessor Yanis Varoufakis, but not in substance. A former professor and economist, Tsakalotos is a key negotiator in talks with creditors and is likely to push for debt relief. He supports European integration but rejects capitalist principles, and has proposed various solutions for debt relief, including having the European bailout fund take over Greek bonds held by the ECB. His strong negotiating qualities and calm demeanor are expected to help break the deadlock in talks with creditors.

site_title: Australia: Stocks rebound 1.1% at the open
summary: Australian stocks rose 1.11% at the open on Tuesday, driven by bargain hunting despite the crisis in Greece. The benchmark S&P/ASX200 index gained 60.8 points to 5,535.8. Strategist Evan Lucas noted the market sees Greece's risks as isolated, but remains vigilant. The rebound follows a period of volatility, with stocks previously trading amid concerns over US-EU trade tensions and global economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Australian stocks rose 1.11 per cent at the open on Tuesday, shrugging off the crisis in Greece as investors went bargain hunting.

site_title: Biggest US banks would ditch securities arms in bankruptcy
summary: US banks have pledged to dismantle non-essential units and securities arms if they fail, with JPMorgan Chase cutting its broker-dealer operations by up to two-thirds. The move follows regulator demands for clearer plans to avoid harming the broader financial system in the event of bankruptcy. The banks, including JPMorgan, Morgan Stanley, and Bank of America, have submitted revised plans under the Dodd-Frank Act, which will be evaluated by authorities over the coming months.

site_title: Facing sales slump, American Apparel to close stores
summary: American Apparel plans to close under-performing retail locations, resulting in job losses, as it fights declining sales. The company, which had 239 stores in 20 countries, aims to slash $30 million in spending over 18 months. Despite launching a redesigned fall line, American Apparel warns it may need to raise additional capital to meet funding requirements. The company's CEO says the moves are necessary to adapt to the retail industry's headwinds and return to long-term profitability.

site_title: StarHub Green sold for about S$260m
summary: Singapore-based Basil Property Trust, managed by AEPim, has acquired StarHub Green, a light industrial building, for approximately S$260 million, translating to a net yield of 5.5%. The 42-year-old asset is anchored by StarHub, with occupancy nearing 90%, offering potential for increased rental income. This is the maiden acquisition for Basil Property Trust, with AEPim aiming to own a US$600 million portfolio by the end of next year.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall on 'Grexit' jitters
summary: European stock markets fell on Monday due to concerns that Greece will crash out of the eurozone following its rejection of creditors' austerity demands in a weekend referendum. The CAC 40 in Paris fell 2.01%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 dropped 1.52%. Greek banks remain closed with limits on daily withdrawals, and analysts predict a "Grexit" if the government doesn't make concessions. The European Central Bank is set to hold a conference call to calm market panic.

site_title: Big four US airlines collude on prices, consumers say in suit
summary: The US Justice Department is investigating possible collusion among the four biggest US airlines: Delta, United, American, and Southwest. A Chicago federal court lawsuit claims the airlines conspired to keep ticket prices high, seeking unspecified damages for domestic air travel from October 2012. This is the second such claim, following requests for information from American Airlines and Southwest. The Justice Department's investigation comes as airlines report a strong travel demand outlook.

site_title: Netccentric starts ASX trading on strong note
summary: Shares of Singapore-based digital media company Netccentric surged by 17% on its first day of trading on the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX), reaching A$0.27, three Australian cents higher than its issue price of A$0.20. The counter opened at A$0.23 and traded 2.4 million shares, ending the day at A$0.23.

site_title: SGX loses year's biggest IPO on Greece fears
summary: Singapore's Manulife Reit has indefinitely postponed its IPO offer, citing weak demand and volatile capital markets. The proposed listing, which would have been the largest in almost a year, was expected to raise S$759 million. The company's decision to shelve the offer was also attributed to the offer not being compelling enough for investors.

site_title: Oil prices stabilise after massive sell-off
summary: Crude oil prices stabilized on Tuesday, July 7, 2015, after a massive sell-off the previous day due to concerns over Greece's debt bailout and China's stock market woes. Front-month US crude futures rose 38 US cents to US$52.91 per barrel, while Brent crude gained over half a dollar to US$57.07 per barrel. The slight gain followed a near eight percent fall on Monday, which was the largest this year.

site_title: ECB maintains Greek bank funding but with tougher terms
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) maintained emergency liquidity assistance (ELA) to Greek banks, but with tougher conditions, amid the country's cash crisis following a historic referendum. The ECB will continue supplying aid, but raised the bar for banks to access funds, requiring sufficient collateral. The move aims to put more pressure on Greece's debt-wracked economy, with the ECB reviewing its decision on Wednesday. Analysts believe the ECB will keep ELA levels to prevent a "Grexit" and force Greece out of the single currency, but warned that the current situation is unsustainable.

site_title: Boeing says loss of Export-Import Bank would be competitive disadvantage
summary: Boeing's president, Ray Conner, stated that the loss of US Export-Import Bank financing would create a "huge competitive disadvantage" for the company. The bank's charter lapsed at the end of June, and Boeing is seeking reauthorization. Conner emphasized the need for Ex-Im Bank to compete on a level playing field, as rivals still have access to financing support. The Obama administration and lawmakers are working to revive the bank, with Democrats and moderate Republicans hoping to attach charter renewal legislation to a highway and rail transit funding bill.

site_title: Euro slips after Greece vote rejects austerity bailout
summary: The euro slipped to US$1.1057 against the dollar after Greek voters rejected an austerity bailout plan from creditors, raising the risk Greece could exit the euro. The euro had previously plummeted to US$1.0970 after the Sunday vote, but rebounded after the surprise resignation of Greece's finance minister and the appointment of a new finance minister. The rejection of the bailout plan increases the likelihood of Greece leaving the euro, and negotiations between Greece and its EU lenders are expected to be challenging.

site_title: US oil prices sink nearly 8% on Greece, China worries
summary: US oil prices dropped nearly 8% on Monday due to concerns over slowing global growth, following Greece's rejection of a bailout offer and China's efforts to calm financial market turbulence. The West Texas Intermediate oil price fell $4.43 to $52.53 a barrel. Analysts cited fears of European economic instability and supply issues from OPEC pumping above quota as contributing factors. The Greece crisis has also strengthened the dollar, increasing the cost of crude for those using other currencies.

site_title: Tennis-Wimbledon? It's elementary, dear Watson
summary: IBM's cognitive computer Watson is being trained to master tennis at Wimbledon, a project aimed at improving the computer's cognitive abilities. Watson, designed by IBM, has previously demonstrated its capabilities in chess and Jeopardy, beating Gary Kasparov and a US$1 million Jeopardy contestant. The training is taking place at the All England Club, but seven-time Wimbledon champion Roger Federer has no cause for concern as Watson is a silicon-chipped cyborg, not a human opponent.

site_title: Managing the food, water and energy nexus
summary: Undergraduate students from seven Asian countries gathered in Singapore to discuss managing the nexus of food, water, and energy. The UN projects 9.6 billion people by 2050, requiring additional resources for 2.3 billion. Currently, 805 million people suffer from undernourishment, 1.1 billion lack electricity, and 3.5 billion lack clean water. The summit aims to develop coordinated policies to address these challenges and ensure adequate resources for the growing global population.

site_title: Germany, France press Greece to make fast, credible proposals
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Francois Hollande urged Greece to make credible proposals to restart financial aid talks, a day after Greeks rejected more austerity measures. Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is under pressure to bring a new proposal to the euro zone summit on Tuesday. The European Central Bank has kept a tight grip on funding to Greek banks, and talks to avert a Greek exit from the euro zone are becoming increasingly unlikely. Greece's finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis, resigned, and the country's banks will remain closed until further notice.

site_title: Amid crisis, Frankfurt's landmark euro sculpture gets pricey makeover
summary: Frankfurt's 14-metre euro sculpture, considered an eyesore by many, is undergoing its largest makeover in 13 years. The non-profit Frankfurter Kultur Komitee has spent up to 60,000 euros to repair the structure, which was damaged by protests and years of wear and tear. The renovation, expected to be completed by Friday, aims to restore the sculpture to its former glory with fashionable LED lighting and new panels. The project was financed by donations from the European Central Bank, Bundesbank, and private individuals, coinciding with the currency facing its biggest test amid Greece's potential exit from the bloc.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence slumps to 3-year low in Q2: survey
summary: New Zealand business confidence plummeted to a three-year low in Q2, with a net 5% of firms expecting general business conditions to improve, the lowest since June 2012. This suggests annual growth will remain below 3% in the next year. The New Zealand Institute of Economic Research expects the economy to grow 2.6% in the second quarter, down from 3.5% growth late last year. The decline points to retailers and companies cutting investment plans amid easing economic growth.

site_title: US: Stocks fall after Greek vote
summary: US stocks fell moderately on Monday after Greece voted against further austerity measures, raising fears of a potential eurozone exit. The Dow Jones declined 46.53 (0.26%) to 17,683.58, while the S&P 500 fell 8.02 (0.39%) to 2,068.76. French and German leaders called for Greek proposals, and US oil prices dropped nearly 8%. Bond prices rose, with the 10-year Treasury yield falling to 2.29%.

site_title: Greek 'No' vote implies an uncertain future
summary: Greek citizens voted "no" in a Sunday referendum on a package of reforms and fiscal measures proposed by creditors, potentially leading to Greece's exit from the eurozone. The result has sent shockwaves across the European Union and has raised concerns about the country's economic future. The Greek government now faces a difficult position to navigate, with growing signs of potential calamity and a need for substantial debt relief. The country's public finances are unsustainable, with a debt burden of over 175% of GDP, and the government is expected to return to Brussels to meet with creditors.

site_title: Varoufakis, scourge of Greece's int'l creditors, steps aside
summary: Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis has stepped aside following the country's "No" victory in a referendum on bailout terms. Varoufakis, known for his blunt negotiating tactics and unconventional style, accused creditors of "terrorism" and sought drastic revisions to Greece's massive debt. He cited a preference by creditors for his absence from future negotiations, which he believed would aid Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras in talks with creditors. Varoufakis' departure follows a five-month stalemate between Athens and its creditors.

site_title: Expensive steaks here to stay as drought cuts Canada cattle herd
summary: A severe drought in Canada's major beef-producing provinces has led to the country's smallest cattle herd in 22 years, with ranchers struggling to feed their animals. As a result, meat supplies are at a seven-year low, causing prices to rise. Canadian beef exports to the US are increasing, but this has led to higher prices in Canada, where processors are paying a premium for animals. The drought is expected to last for four to six years, with tight supplies impacting both Canadian and US markets.

site_title: Greek 'no' vote places EU leaders on the back foot
summary: Greek voters overwhelmingly rejected EU creditor austerity demands, with 61.3% backing Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras's Syriza party. Tsipras stated the "no" vote was against austerity, not a referendum on leaving the euro. EU leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel, asked Tsipras to propose reforms. Market participants reacted positively, and the Greek government accepted most creditor proposals with minor changes. However, economists warn that debt forgiveness or restructuring will require significant reforms, and the IMF is unlikely to propose a third bailout without economic reforms and debt relief.

site_title: AsiaPhos to acquire LY Resources for S$36.8m
summary: AsiaPhos is acquiring LY Resources for S$36.8 million to boost operating cash flows and expand its resource base. The acquisition, valued at S$58 million, follows an independent valuation report by Jones Lang LaSalle Corporate Appraisal and Advisory. AsiaPhos CEO Ong Hian Eng said the deal will allow the company to acquire economic benefits from an existing cooperation arrangement and expand its ownership of a Chinese exploration licence. The acquisition is expected to facilitate longer-term output growth and enhance the company's resource base.

site_title: Markets muted as Greek crisis seen quarantined
summary: Greek voters rejected creditors' austerity demands in a referendum, resulting in the euro dropping less than 1% and stock volatility easing. European and US stocks fell, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index down 1.3% and the Standard & Poor's 500 Index down 0.7%. Treasury 10-year yields also fell, while Shanghai shares rose amid efforts to counter a $3.2 trillion sell-off. The reaction is seen as muted, with investors viewing the crisis as "quarantined" for now.

site_title: Global stocks fall on 'Grexit' jitters
summary: Global stock markets plummeted on Monday, with European bourses taking the hardest hits, after Greece rejected more austerity measures in a referendum. The Eurostoxx 50 index sank 2.22%, while the CAC 40 in Paris fell 2.01%. The Dow Jones Industrial average and S&P 500 also declined, with the euro continuing to erode against the dollar. The European Central Bank tightened collateral conditions for Greece's commercial banks, heightening fears of a "Grexit." Analysts warn that Greece's banks could run out of money, threatening the country's economic stability.

site_title: Six reasons why innovations require errors
summary: Innovations and errors are closely linked, as errors facilitate exploration, discovery, and serendipity in the creative process. Having an effective error management culture can improve an organization's capacity for innovation by embracing errors as necessary for experimentation, exploration, and new idea generation. Errors can lead to new areas of inquiry, and a closed mind can discard valuable results, while an open mind can turn accidental discoveries into innovations, ultimately driving growth and progress.

site_title: US triumph caps truly global Women's World Cup
summary: The US women's soccer team won the 2015 Women's World Cup, defeating Japan 5-2 in the final. Carli Lloyd scored a hat-trick, including a goal from the half-way line, in a 16-minute span, leading the US to a 4-0 lead. The tournament marked a significant milestone for women's soccer, with global interest and participation on the rise. The US team's victory solidified their position as a top-tier team, while other nations, such as England, Australia, and Colombia, also demonstrated growth and promise in the sport.

site_title: TPP to reshape stock portfolios: fund managers
summary: The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) is nearing completion, with 12 nations expected to wrap up an agreement in coming weeks. The deal is expected to deliver $295 billion in annual global economic gains and has long-term implications for Pacific Rim companies. Fund managers are positioning themselves for the benefits, with Japan, Vietnam, and US media stocks expected to rise. Japan is likely to be the biggest winner, with textiles and transport equipment expected to see significant growth. South-east Asian nations, particularly Vietnam and Malaysia, are also expected to benefit, with the US yarn and textile industry hoping for protections.

site_title: mDR unveils move to acquire Japan firm in RTO deal
summary: Singapore-listed company mDR Ltd is set to acquire a Japan-based mobile content developer in a "very substantial acquisition" or RTO deal. The expected consideration is between S$110 million and S$165 million, made in cash, shares, and convertible debt. The target company is profitable and expected to contribute to mDR's bottom line, with its product offerings seen as synergistic with mDR's mobile devices business. The vendors will own between 35-40% of mDR's post-completion capital and between 45-50% upon conversion of convertible debt.

images.alt_text: Philip Eng, chairman of mDR Limited.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Genting Singapore's share price remains around S$0.90 due to a lackluster VIP business outlook and the MERS outbreak. Analysts believe the pessimism has already been priced in, with the stock being a 2017 story with strong overseas angles. In contrast, Pacific Radiance is expected to recover with stable oil prices, while Perennial Real Estate Holdings is seen as a strategic investment with potential to realize S$4.2 billion from its land bank. Analysts maintain "Buy" ratings for the companies.

site_title: Heineken, Carlsberg have their eyes on Myanmar market
summary: Heineken and Carlsberg are expanding their presence in Myanmar, a South-east Asian nation with a large population and growing middle-class consumers. Both brewers have invested in local breweries, with Heineken opening a US$60 million facility on July 12 and Carlsberg's US$75 million brewery already operational. The move aims to capitalize on the country's increasing beer sales, which rose 14% between 2009 and 2013 and are forecast to reach US$675 million by 2018. Both companies are working with local partners to build a presence in the country, marking a new attempt at growth in Myanmar after previous efforts in the 1990s were hindered by Western sanctions.

site_title: Demand, drought drive up almond prices
summary: US almond prices have surged to record levels due to high demand and drought in California, where 80% of the world's almonds are grown. Americans are consuming about 2 pounds of almonds per person annually, driving up sales of specialty nut butters, including almond butter, which now exceeds peanut butter in popularity. However, the high cost of almonds is making it difficult for companies to maintain profitability, with some suppliers raising prices by only 15% to avoid scaring off customers.

site_title: Singapore's direct exposure to Greece 'negligible'; impact being closely watched: MAS
summary: Singapore's direct exposure to Greece is "negligible", according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), despite the global market volatility following Greece's rejection of an international bailout. The MAS maintains a close watch on eurozone and global financial markets, but notes that the impact on Singapore's economy is minimal.

site_title: China blames short sellers, foreigners for stock-market rout
summary: China's state-run media blames short sellers and foreign investors for the stock-market rout, which erased $3.2 trillion in value in three weeks. However, analysts say the market's unsustainable valuations are to blame. Short positions on the Shanghai Stock Exchange totalled just 0.03% of the market capitalization, and foreign money managers own less than 3% of Chinese shares, which they've been increasing. The true cause of the selloff remains unclear, with regulators pledging to crack down on "vicious" short selling.

site_title: Iran nuclear talks could go either way: Kerry
summary: Foreign ministers from the US, Britain, China, France, Germany, and Russia are set to meet in Vienna on Monday to finalize a nuclear deal with Iran, with a deadline looming. US Secretary of State John Kerry warned that the talks could go either way, while French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius said the atmosphere is "constructive and positive." The deal aims to limit Iran's nuclear capabilities in exchange for lifting sanctions, with experts suggesting key issues have been resolved. The talks have been ongoing since 2013, and a collapse would be a major setback.

site_title: Beijing's emergency moves bring some relief to stocks
summary: China's emergency measures to prop up its stock market brought relief on Monday, with the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 2.4% and the CSI300 index rising 2.9%. The government's support includes brokerages and fund managers buying massive stocks, aided by a direct line of liquidity from the central bank. The market had fallen 30% from its peak in mid-June, sparking fears about the economy's stability. The rebound, however, remains uncertain, with some analysts questioning whether the gains can be sustained.

site_title: The long and rocky road to the TPP
summary: The US trade policy has taken a significant turn after President Obama's efforts to win a "fast track" authority to conclude trade deals were blocked by Democrats in the House of Representatives. Despite this, the White House succeeded in passing the Trade Promotion Authority (TPA) bill, allowing President Obama to sign it into law. However, the passage of the TPA does not guarantee the approval of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) deal, which requires at least 61 senators to pass. The recent vote against the TPA by Senators Ted Cruz and Rand Paul has sparked concerns that the TPP may not pass, potentially delaying its conclusion and sparking a heated debate in Congress.

site_title: 10 most active healthcare stocks average 26% H1 price gain
summary: Singapore Exchange reported that the 10 most active healthcare stocks averaged a 26.4% price gain in the first six months of 2015, with an average turnover velocity of 178%. The sector showed high liquidity, with International Healthway Corporation being the most actively traded stock. The SGX Healthcare Index, comprising healthcare stocks and real estate investment trusts, showed a total return of 21.4% in the first half-year.

images.alt_text: The 10 most active healthcare stocks averaged a price gain of 26.4 per cent in the first six months of this year

site_title: Disruption models a reality in insurance, says PwC report
summary: A report by PwC predicts an acceleration in new business models in the global insurance industry, driven by digital developments and new market entrants. Innovations include advanced profiling techniques, cost-efficient digital distribution, and usage-based insurance. Companies such as Friendsurance and Bought By Many are leading the way with crowd-sourced insurance and personalized policies. However, the industry faces a looming threat from increasing tax burdens, with 64% of insurance CEOs identifying tax as a threat to growth.

site_title: Serena is first to book WTA Finals berth
summary: Serena Williams is the first player to qualify for the WTA Finals, a record for being the earliest in a season to do so, at the age of 33. She will defend her title in Singapore from October 23 to November 1, marking her 10th appearance at the tournament. Williams has had a dominant first half of 2015, winning the Australian Open and French Open, and has held the world No. 1 ranking for 124 consecutive weeks. Tickets for the tournament are already on sale, with prices starting at S$16.90.

site_title: Investors upbeat on Japan, H-shares in Asia
summary: Investors remain optimistic on Japan and Hong Kong-listed China stocks for the second half of the year, despite short-term concerns over the US interest rate hike and Greece-related uncertainties. Large investors expect Europe to recover economically, with the European Central Bank supporting the euro. Some analysts have turned cautious on stocks as an asset class, citing potential contagion risks from a possible Grexit.

site_title: Govt buys unsold homes to help China builders
summary: The Chinese government has purchased thousands of unsold homes at discounted prices to alleviate the country's real estate glut. The properties are being converted into public housing in six provinces, providing affordable housing for low-income households. While this measure may help alleviate the issue, it is unclear whether it will completely eliminate the surplus of unsold homes, which has been a major concern for the government.

site_title: Reddit CEO under fire as users protest sacking of executive
summary: Reddit CEO Ellen Pao faces backlash after firing Victoria Taylor, the director of talent, and censoring online message boards. Over 130,000 users signed a Change.org petition calling for her removal. Despite an apology, the petition gained over 100,000 signatures and continued to grow. The incident led to a blackout of most message boards on July 3, with moderators protesting the dismissal. Pao's handling of the situation has sparked concerns about censorship and employee treatment at Reddit.

site_title: Carmakers gear up to transform vehicles into full-service tools
summary: Carmakers are transforming vehicles into full-service tools, with potential revenue from data streams and connectivity components projected to reach 180 billion euros by 2020. BMW, Volkswagen, and Daimler are competing to acquire Nokia's Here digital map business, which could fetch up to $4 billion, to ensure access to fine-grained location data and compete with Google.
