The digital-car age is expected to generate valuable data, with 90% of new vehicles in western Europe connected by 2020, and carmakers are preparing to monetize this information through services such as coffee ordering and automated vehicle guidance.

images.alt_text: Cars in the next few years will be able to find the fastest route for the morning commute as well as order coffee, pay for it and guide the driver to pick it up.

site_title: Ringgit's dive expected to boost travel to Malaysia
summary: The Malaysian ringgit has hit a fresh low of RM 2.81 against the Singapore dollar, boosting travel to Malaysia. The currency's depreciation is attributed to domestic concerns and the recent fall in oil prices, as well as intensifying political uncertainty in Malaysia. Travel agents expect higher bookings for Malaysia, with a 25-30% increase in enquiries from leisure and business travelers. However, the lower ringgit may also weigh on Singapore's tourism industry, which has seen a five percent year-on-year decline in visitor arrivals.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Najib crisis savages the ringgit
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak faces a severe political crisis amid allegations that nearly $700 million in state funds were transferred to his personal bank accounts. The ringgit currency hit a 16-year low against the US dollar, and Najib has maintained he would not keep the funds in his accounts if he had planned to steal them. Despite this, he has not denied the alleged deposit, and his reputation has taken a hit due to his party's perceived ties to government institutions. Najib's popularity has been slipping, and critics are calling for him to clarify the situation and take responsibility.

site_title: Grexit jitters hit regional markets
summary: The Greek public's "no" vote against austerity terms has sent regional markets into a tailspin, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dipping 0.3% and the Hang Seng plummeting 3%. China stocks bucked the trend, advancing 2.4% after Beijing's market-friendly measures. The move has raised concerns over Greece's economic stability and potential contagion within the eurozone, but analysts believe it's unlikely to trigger a global crisis like the 2008 Lehman moment.

images.alt_text: A pedestrian holding an umbrella looks at an electronic board showing the stock market indices of various countries outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan.

site_title: How accepting and managing errors can raise a firm's performance
summary: Embracing and managing errors is crucial to a firm's performance, as numerous successful innovations were born from mistakes. A study of medium-sized firms in Europe found that those with a systematic approach to error management embedded in their organization outperform those without, with a 20% higher return on assets. Firms that view errors as opportunities for growth and learning, rather than as shameful mistakes, can minimize negative impacts, increase innovation, and improve productivity. By accepting and managing errors, firms can create a culture that encourages open discussion, quick analysis, and recovery, ultimately leading to improved profitability and competitiveness.

site_title: Taiwan aims to set up US dollar bond exchange
summary: Taiwan aims to establish its first US dollar-denominated bond exchange, a move to boost its capital markets and align with global trends. The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) is studying proposals to allow insurers to trade US-denominated bonds, with a goal of reaching a conclusion by late this year. This follows efforts to ease financial regulations and attract foreign investors, including Chinese banks and insurance firms. The move is part of Taiwan's strategy to build itself into a wealth management hub in Asia.

site_title: Municipal Services Office to partner six more town councils
summary: Singapore's Municipal Services Office (MSO) plans to partner six more town councils to expand its scope in improving municipal services. The MSO, launched last October, has already seen a 20% reduction in response time for multi-agency cases, from 8 working days to 6.5 days. The office aims to partner all 16 town councils within the next 12 months, with town councils retaining autonomy and authority in service delivery. The MSO's One Service mobile app has received over 9,000 pieces of feedback since its launch in January.

site_title: O Fournier to sell vineyard plots in Spain to wine buffs
summary: O Fournier, a winery founded by Jose Manuel Ortega, is selling managed vineyard plots in Spain's Ribera del Duero to wine collectors and enthusiasts. The 22 lots, spanning 34 hectares, will be sold at approximately £120,000 (S$252,000) per hectare. The proceeds will fund expansion plans in Chile, Argentina, and Spain, allowing investors to own the land and produce their own wine. This unique investment opportunity differs from traditional wine industry models, offering investors a chance to own the land and receive their own wine.

site_title: Longtime champ dethroned at New York hot dog eating contest
summary: Joey "Jaws" Chestnut, the 8-time hot dog eating contest champion, was defeated by Matt "Megatoad" Stonie at the 2015 Nathan's hot dog eating contest in New York. Stonie, 23, consumed 62 hot dogs in 10 minutes, surpassing Chestnut's total. Miki Sudo won the women's contest, and Chestnut vowed to return next year to reclaim his title. The contest, held on the Coney Island boardwalk, drew a national audience and thousands of spectators, with Stonie winning a $10,000 prize and the coveted mustard yellow winner's belt.

site_title: Polaroid Swinger: changing the market in an instant
summary: The article marks the 50th anniversary of the Polaroid Swinger, the world's first low-priced, mass-market "instant" camera, introduced in 1965. The Swinger was a groundbreaking device that foreshadowed modern technology like the Apple iPhone, capturing images and sharing them instantly. Founded by Edwin Land, the camera was initially met with skepticism but went on to sell over one million units within eight years. Its impact on the photography industry was significant, with Polaroid eventually becoming a major player in the market, and its legacy continues to be celebrated today.

site_title: India launches ambitious plan for a robust digital future
summary: India's government has launched a "Digital India week" with Prime Minister Narendra Modi announcing plans for a robust digital future, including greater Internet connectivity and services for more people. The goal is to cut electronics imports by 2020 and jump-start Indian manufacturing in electronics. Modi compared the country's transition to the use of technology, likening it to a child growing from wearing glasses to a mobile phone. The initiative aims to harness technology to drive economic growth and improve the lives of Indians.

images.alt_text: Mr Modi wants greater Internet connectivity and services for more of the country's people and jump-start electronics manufacturing.

site_title: A rose among the thorns in male-dominated world of pilots
summary: Eva Maria Thien, a 50-year-old Austrian pilot, has become the only woman to fly widebody planes for Singapore's Scoot airline. She broke into the male-dominated industry through determination and hard work, overcoming rejection and obstacles to become a captain. Thien's journey, which began with flying lessons as a toddler, serves as a rare example of a woman succeeding in the aviation industry. Her goal is to inspire other women to follow in her path and break down barriers in the cockpit.

site_title: Euro holding well despite Greek 'no'
summary: The euro held steady despite Greece's "No" vote to further austerity, with the currency down 0.6% at US$1.1035. The vote led to a brief drop below US$1.10, but the euro recovered as Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis resigned. Forex players remain uncertain about the impact of a Greek exit on the euro, but some see it as a balanced risk. The euro's resilience was partly due to a positive outlook for core European government debt, drawing investors to safe-haven assets. A deal to avert a Greek departure is still seen as possible, with German Chancellor Merkel's intentions a key factor.

images.alt_text: Foreign exchange markets reserved judgement on Greece's place in the euro and the overall solidity of the common currency project on Monday.

site_title: Greek economic crisis is deja vu to Argentinians
summary: Argentinians are drawing parallels between Greece's current economic crisis and their own country's 2001 crisis, which led to a default of $102 billion and widespread social unrest. Greece's referendum on an austerity-driven bailout proposal ended with a "no" vote, prompting the government to close banks and stock exchanges until Monday to prevent capital flight. Experts warn of a potential domino effect throughout the eurozone, citing similarities in Greece's economic situation to Argentina's in 2001, including a 25% decline in GDP and similar unemployment rates.

site_title: S-E Asia's rail boom may be a boon for Japan
summary: South-east Asia's urban rail projects are expected to ease traffic congestion, with Thai government plans to extend Bangkok's urban railways to 515 km by 2029. Japanese firms are well-positioned to capitalize on the boom, given their reputation for safety and precision, but Chinese companies are also entering the market. The Thai government aims to raise public transit usage to 40% by 2029, with Japanese companies involved in several projects, including a 26.3-km-long Red Line elevated railway project in Bangkok.

site_title: Shipping sentiment worsens: annual survey
summary: Shipping industry sentiment worsens due to a growing vessel glut, with confidence among respondents declining to 33% in the latest annual survey. The dry bulk sector, which transports commodities such as iron ore and coal, is experiencing one of its worst downturns. The survey attributed this to massive fleet growth and weaker activity from top importers like China. Shipping faces a multi-billion dollar funding hole due to European banks' retreat from the sector, and the industry is closely watching developments in the eurozone, particularly Greece.

site_title: Singapore, Myanmar central banks sign banking supervision MOU
summary: Singapore and Myanmar's central banks signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to cooperate in banking supervision and capacity building. The agreement, made during the 5th Singapore-Myanmar Joint Ministerial Working Committee (JMWC) meeting, aims to develop an interbank funding market and deepen technical cooperation in banking and capital markets supervision. The meeting also discussed cooperation in the legal sector and other areas such as urban solutions, transport, and logistics. The bilateral trade between Singapore and Myanmar rose 6.6% in 2014 to S$3.23 billion.

site_title: SIC proposes changes to Singapore Code of Takeovers and Mergers
summary: The Securities Industry Council (SIC) has proposed changes to the Singapore Code on Takeovers and Mergers in response to market developments and international practices since its last review in 2012. Key proposals include clarifying procedures and timelines for competing offers and encouraging offeree company boards to prioritize shareholder interests. The SIC aims to provide greater certainty and safeguard shareholders' rights. A consultation paper outlining the proposed amendments has been issued for feedback.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close down on fears of 'Grexit'
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell on Monday after Greece rejected creditors' austerity demands, raising fears of a potential 'Grexit' and a possible exit from the eurozone. The CAC 40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX 30 indexes dropped 2.01% and 1.52% respectively. The FTSE 100 index lost 0.76% outside the eurozone. The decline was attributed to bank and healthcare sectors, with investors focusing on US-EU trade talks and potential tariffs.

site_title: Tsipras, Merkel agree to discuss Greece's proposals at summit
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and German Chancellor Angela Merkel agreed to discuss Greece's proposals at a eurozone summit on Tuesday, following a referendum in which 61.31% of Greeks rejected creditor demands for further austerity. Tsipras also spoke with European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi and Russian President Vladimir Putin. The ECB is seen as key to calming market panic and preventing the Greek economy from collapsing.

site_title: Working up the value chain
summary: Wong Fong Engineering, a 50-year-old Singaporean company, is undergoing a mid-life crisis, driven by an aging workforce and land constraints. The second-generation family business is shifting its focus from integration to product development under its own brand name. The company has established a research and innovation centre (WFRIC) and is working on several projects, including a waste-to-energy digester, an automated robot waste collecting system, and electric vehicles. Wong Fong aims to commercialize its products and become a brand owner, with China as its main target market, to increase margins and expand globally.

site_title: Greek default has very small Asia impact: DBS
summary: DBS Group Holdings' CEO Piyush Gupta stated that a Greek default would have a limited impact on the European economy and a very small impact on the Asian economy. The European private sector and Asia's exposure to Greek liabilities are close to zero, with the European Central Bank bearing most of the exposure. Gupta also expressed confidence in China's stock market, stating that the recent 80-100% increase was justified due to the country's robust economic growth.

site_title: Vanke to buy back up to 10b yuan A shares
summary: China's largest residential homebuilder, Vanke Co, has approved a plan to repurchase up to 10 billion yuan (S$2.17 billion) of its A shares, signaling a price bottom. The repurchase aims to protect investors' interests amid the recent instability of the A-share market. This move follows government measures to stem the stock-market rout, including halting initial public offerings (IPOs) and brokerages pledging to buy shares. The repurchase will account for at least 6.6% of Vanke's total issued stock.

site_title: Norway's decision in oilfield stake case baffles analysts
summary: Norway's Petroleum and Energy Ministry has made a decision in the Johan Sverdrup oilfield stake case, taking away 15 million barrels of oil from state-owned Petoro AS. Det Norske Oljeselskap, a partner in the field, had disagreed with the other partners, including Statoil ASA, Lundin Petroleum, and A P Moeller-Maersk. The decision was made after months of deliberation and has left analysts baffled.

site_title: UOBAM 'neutral' on four asset classes in Q3
summary: UOB Asset Management has taken a "neutral" stance on four major asset classes for Q3, citing increased uncertainties. The fund manager is cautious on the global economy, but not bearish, and expects investors to gain confidence in the US economy despite potential rate hikes. It maintains a positive outlook for consumer staples, real estate, and healthcare in Singapore, while being "underweight" on industrials and telecommunication services. The fund also favors emerging market bonds over developed market bonds.

site_title: US: Stocks open down 0.8% after Greek vote
summary: US stocks opened down 0.8% on Monday after Greek voters rejected a creditor austerity package, throwing Greece and the eurozone into turmoil. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index were all affected, with the US stocks continuing a trend of edging down from record highs amid tariff threats.

site_title: Fruits of victory will turn sour; creditors and debtors alike will be punished
summary: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has won a decisive 61% "No" vote in the referendum, allowing him to implement the "Oxi" plan, which has outmanoeuvred creditors and divided the surplus states. The plan's success is attributed to the Greek government's unorthodox tactics, including constant re-engagement and surprise demands. However, Greece faces a challenging period of infighting and pain, including devaluation of banknotes, rationing, and exchange controls, which will punish both creditors and debtors.

site_title: China-listed firms rush to file trading halts as markets slump
summary: China-listed firms have surged to over 700 requests to halt trading or extend halts since the country's stock market began its 30% plunge in mid-June, equivalent to around a quarter of the firms on Shanghai and Shenzhen exchanges. The number of requests is double that of April, raising concerns that firms can easily suspend shares to avoid market downturns. Regulators have been criticized for only having one eye open, and firms face fines if they request halts without good reason, with some analysts suggesting that trading halts may actually create market stability.

site_title: Greece's Tsakalotos to be sworn in as finance minister: source
summary: Greece's top negotiator Euclid Tsakalotos will be sworn in as finance minister after Yanis Varoufakis' shock resignation. The move comes as Greece continues its aid talks with creditors. The exact timing of Tsakalotos' swearing-in is not specified, but it is expected to take place on Monday.

site_title: Sabic, SK Global Chemical in US$640m Singapore venture
summary: Sabic and SK Global Chemical have formed a 50-50 joint venture in Singapore to operate a chain of manufacturing plants worldwide. The venture will produce high-performance plastic products using Nexlene technology, valued at US$640 million, and will have an annual capacity of 230,000 tonnes. The partnership marks Sabic's push into the Far East and gives it access to the most complete polyethylene platforms in the petrochemical industry. The joint venture is seen as mutually beneficial, with both parties aiming to expand their global presence and offer a wider portfolio of products.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Monday
summary: Singapore's Manulife US Reit IPO has been delayed due to market volatility. AsiaPhos will acquire LY Resources for S$36.8m, while Noble Group will redeem senior notes worth US$235m early. Singapore and Myanmar's central banks signed a MOU on banking supervision and capacity building. Local shares closed 0.3% lower, weighed down by concerns over Greece's rejection of bailout terms.

site_title: JPMorgan, Barclays see Greek exit as likeliest scenario after referendum
summary: Greek economists from JPMorgan and Barclays predict a Greek exit from the euro as the most likely scenario after the country's referendum rejection of austerity measures. The economists say the situation could come under chaotic circumstances. The probability of Greece leaving the euro has been increased to 75% by Teneo Intelligence and 85% by Oxford Economics, making it a base case scenario for some analysts. The Greek government has just weeks to negotiate a new aid deal, with capital controls in place and banks running out of euros.

site_title: Brent crude slumps below US$60 as Greece, China put demand at risk
summary: Brent crude oil prices dropped below $60 a barrel for the first time in almost 12 weeks due to concerns over economic stability in Europe and Asia. Greece rejected creditors' bailout terms, prompting European leaders to hold an emergency summit, while China sought to restore investor confidence after its stock market plummeted. US Secretary of State John Kerry tempered expectations for a deal with Iran, which is estimated to double crude exports if sanctions are lifted. The decline in oil prices is seen as a result of investors seeking safer assets amid the global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Well-off investors see S$1.38m as ideal retirement nest egg: survey
summary: Singaporean investors estimate an average retirement nest egg of S$1.38 million, with 66% feeling financially insecure or financially savvy. The survey, conducted by Friends Provident International, found that saving for retirement is the top priority for 72% of respondents. Many rely on professionals for financial advice, with 55% seeking input before investing. Experts warn that 25% of respondents are underestimating the amount needed for retirement, citing high costs of living, inflation, and increasing medical bills.

images.alt_text: Well-off investors in Singapore estimate their ideal retirement nest egg at an average of S$1.38 million, based on a survey by insurance company Friends Provident International (FPI).

site_title: HK: Shares suffer biggest fall in 3 yrs on Greek crisis fears
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark index fell 3.2% to a three-month low, its largest drop in three years, amid concerns over the Greek debt crisis. Global and regional markets also declined, with stocks in Hong Kong and other markets plummeting. The Hang Seng index closed at 25,236.28, and the Growth Enterprise Market slumped 14%. The decline was driven by worries that the Greek crisis could deepen, with investors selling stocks across the board.

site_title: Indonesia to impose coal export tax next month: govt official
summary: Indonesia plans to impose a 1.5% tax on coal exports starting August 8 for firms with newer mining licenses. The tax aims to boost state revenue and keep more coal for domestic power demand. Around 900 of 960 coal firms in production will be affected, contributing 20% of total output. The move is part of President Joko Widodo's administration's plan to build 70 gigawatts of new power stations by the end of the decade.

site_title: Ntegrator says Thai unit sued in Bangkok
summary: Ntegrator International's Thai subsidiary has been sued by Telewave Communication Co Ltd for 28.55 million baht (S$1.14 million) allegedly owed for fibre optic connection systems. The directors and subsidiary have denied the claim, with preliminary views that it is without merit. Ntegrator International has made arrangements to obtain legal advice.

site_title: 1MDB does not pose systemic risk to govt finances: Moody's
summary: Moody's downplays concerns, stating 1MDB's developments do not pose a systemic risk to Malaysia's government finances. The rating agency notes that the rise in political friction has not affected the government's stance on fiscal reforms. However, stocks declined and the ringgit plummeted to a fresh low following a Wall Street Journal report that investigators linked nearly $700 million to Prime Minister Najib Razak's bank accounts. Two opposition parties called for an emergency parliament sitting to discuss the prime minister's future amid escalating tensions.

site_title: Singapore's direct exposure to Greece negligible, says MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) stated that the country's direct exposure to Greece is "negligible", accounting for only 0.2% of total trade and 0.1% of total banking system assets. Despite this, MAS is closely monitoring the ongoing Greek crisis and its potential impact on the global economy and Singapore's domestic markets.

site_title: Malaysia deserves support on probe into crash of flight MH17
summary: Malaysia is pushing for a UN-backed trial for those responsible for the downing of MH17, a year after the tragic incident. Despite initial claims that Ukrainian rebels shot the plane down with a Russian-supplied BUK missile, Malaysia expressed skepticism and demanded to know why it was left out of the investigation. Malaysian diplomats briefed UN Security Council members on their intention to present a resolution, seeking justice for the 43 Malaysian victims. The move comes after years of skepticism about the official narrative, and may finally reveal what really happened to the Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide at start of trading
summary: European stock markets slid at the start of trading on Monday after Greece rejected creditors' austerity demands in a weekend referendum. Frankfurt's DAX 30 fell 2.11% and the CAC 40 in Paris fell 2.06%, while the FTSE 100 index lost 1.07%. The decline was attributed to bank and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Singapore, Myanmar sign MOU on banking supervision, capacity building
summary: Singapore and Myanmar's central banks signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on banking supervision and capacity building. The agreement aims to develop an inter-bank funding market and deepen technical cooperation in banking and capital markets supervision. The two countries also agreed on cooperation in the legal sector, including joint legal workshops and seminars. This cooperation is seen as a step to deepen bilateral economic ties between the two nations, including areas such as urban solutions, transport, and logistics. The MOU is expected to foster stronger economic relations between Singapore and Myanmar.

site_title: China: Shares close higher
summary: China's benchmark stock index closed up 2.41% on Monday after authorities unveiled a package of measures to shore up a plunging market. The Shanghai Composite Index surged 88.99 points to 3,775.91, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 2.70%. Analysts question the sustainability of the gains, which follow a huge run-up in Chinese shares over the past year. The government's intervention aims to protect the broader economy from the market slump.

site_title: Greece to extend bank holiday for at least a few more days: bankers
summary: Greece's government plans to extend the bank holiday by at least a few more days, replacing the current decree that expires on Monday. The decision comes after the European Central Bank froze a vital financial lifeline following the breakdown of bailout talks between Athens and its foreign creditors. A new decree is expected to be issued, with one banker speculating that the bank holiday will be extended until Friday or next Monday. This move aims to stabilize the country's financial system amidst ongoing economic uncertainty.

site_title: Amos Yee sentenced to 4 weeks jail, sentence backdated
summary: Singaporean teenager Amos Yee, a 16-year-old blogger, was sentenced to 4 weeks in prison on July 6, 2015, with his sentence backdated. He has spent over 50 days in remand to date. The sentence was handed down after Yee was found guilty of insulting his former teacher, Maria Hoon.

site_title: DBS bank chief says Greek default would have limited impact
summary: DBS Group Holdings CEO Piyush Gupta stated that a Greek default would have limited impact on the European economy and a very small impact on the Asian economy. The European private sector and Asia's exposure to Greek liabilities are close to zero, with the ECB and other official bodies bearing most of the exposure to Greek debt. This suggests that the effects of a potential Greek exit from the eurozone would be contained.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Noble Group announced the redemption of its outstanding 6.625% senior notes due 2020, worth US$235 million, on August 5, 2025, at a 100% redemption price. Meanwhile, global markets saw oil rise over 2% amid market uncertainty, while US stocks edged down from records due to tariff threats. In other news, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case.

site_title: German industrial orders fall less than expected in May
summary: German industrial orders fell 0.2% in May, beating expectations of a 0.4% drop. Foreign demand rose 0.2%, while domestic demand declined 0.6%. The Economy Ministry reported a 2.7% increase in bookings for April and May, citing strong foreign demand. This suggests economic growth may pick up in the April-June period, despite a 0.3% growth rate in the first quarter. The outcome may be influenced by the Greek debt crisis, with economists warning of uncertainty.

site_title: Infinio Group ends web portal business, stuck in financing limbo
summary: Infinio Group has ended its web portal business, MagicOverload, after a 10-year license expired, resulting in the loss of revenue. The company, listed on the Singapore Exchange, is now stuck in financing limbo, unable to proceed with its gold mining plans in Australia until it raises more funding. Infinio had collected S$45,000 in revenue from the portal in 2015 and will revert the license to MOL Access Portal. The company is considering an application to the exchange for an extension on its compliance reports for mineral, oil and gas companies.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower on Greek debt worries
summary: Singapore's stock market closed 0.3% lower on Monday, July 6, 2015, due to concerns over Greece's rejection of harsh bailout terms in a referendum. The local bourse fell 9.79 points to 3,332.94, with 1.17 billion shares worth S$833.1 million traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 315 to 114.

site_title: China's economy shows positive changes
summary: China's economy is showing positive changes with recent government measures gaining traction, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. Economic growth remains within a "reasonable range" and is basically stable, with growth expected to dip below 7% in the second quarter, the weakest performance since the global financial crisis. The government is set to release second-quarter GDP data on July 15, and economists are closely watching for signs of economic slowdown, which could put pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Eurogroup ministers expect 'new proposals' from Greece
summary: Eurogroup ministers are set to discuss new proposals from Greece following the country's rejection of creditor terms in a referendum. The ministers, who meet on Tuesday, expect fresh reform ideas from the Greek government amid concerns over the country's future in the eurozone. The Eurogroup, led by Dutch Finance Minister Jeroen Dijsselbloem, described the "No" vote result as "very regrettable" and urged the Greek government to come up with new ideas. The outcome leaves the path forward uncertain, with the eurozone nations set to meet in an extraordinary summit later this week.

images.alt_text: Eurogroup ministers expect fresh reform proposals from the Greek government in talks on Tuesday, a statement said on Monday, a day after Greeks overwhelmingly rejected terms demanded by creditors.

site_title: Beijing names preferred chief for China-led bank
summary: Beijing has named Jin Liqun, a former vice minister of finance, as its preferred candidate to head the China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB). As the largest shareholder, Beijing will have veto power over the choice of president, which requires a 75% majority. Jin, who has worked for the World Bank, Asian Development Bank, and China's sovereign wealth fund, has "abundant experiences in leading and managing government agencies, international organisations, and private companies." Nominations close this month, with the president to be elected at the bank's inaugural meeting later this year.

site_title: For Chicago futures traders, one final round in the ring
summary: Chicago's open-outcry futures trading, a tradition spanning 167 years, is set to end on Monday with CME Group Inc. closing most operations after the closing bell. The US Commodity Futures Trading Commission has a 90-day review to decide if to delay the closures, which have been met with resistance from floor brokers and traders. The CME, the birthplace of futures trading, has held off on switching to an all-digital platform longer than most other exchanges, but electronic trading is increasingly replacing open-outcry operations.

site_title: China auto sales flat in June despite broad price cuts
summary: China's auto sales remained flat in June, with General Motors Co selling 246,066 cars, unchanged from the same month last year. Despite price cuts on 40 models, demand failed to boost, with sales down 4% in May and 0.4% in April. The market's slowest start since 2012, with overall sales up only 2.1% from last year.

images.alt_text: General Motors Co vehicle sales in China were roughly flat for June as broad price cuts introduced earlier in the year failed to boost demand.

site_title: ECB's Greek debt cannot be restructured: Noyer
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) governing council member Christian Noyer stated that Greek debt held by the Eurosystem cannot be restructured, as it would amount to monetary financing of a state, violating EU rules. This decision was made to prevent the ECB from financing the Greek government. Noyer declined to comment further on Greece's debt situation, awaiting a decision on the matter.

site_title: Broker's Take: UOBAM overweight on consumer staples, real estate, healthcare, IT
summary: UOB Asset Management (UOBAM) has upgraded its Singapore equity strategy to overweight in consumer staples, real estate, healthcare, and IT sectors, while being neutral in the financial sector. The bank's Q3 strategy also underweights consumer discretionary, industrials, and telecommunication services. UOBAM has taken a cautious approach globally, recommending a neutral stance on equities, fixed income, commodities, and cash due to unexciting corporate earnings and relatively supportive valuations.

site_title: Malaysia's Sunway Construction closes IPO to institutions early
summary: Malaysia's Sunway Construction Group Bhd has closed the institutional portion of its 478 million ringgit (US$125.59 million) IPO ahead of schedule. The company was selling 191.8 million shares through the bookbuilding process, which was five times over-subscribed. The retail portion of the IPO is set to close on Monday. Sunway Construction is expected to price the offer at the top end of its indicative range of 1.15 ringgit to 1.20 ringgit per share.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed at 1,717.05, down 17.19 points on Monday, with 1.54 billion lots valued at RM1.41 billion traded. The market saw 158 gains and 646 losses.

site_title: Greek FM Varoufakis says he is resigning
summary: Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis announced his resignation on Monday, a day after Greeks rejected the conditions of a rescue package. Varoufakis stated he was leaving due to being considered unwelcome by some euro zone finance ministers, an idea deemed potentially helpful by the prime minister. This move comes after a resounding 'No' from Greeks to the rescue package conditions.

site_title: Australia: Stocks end 1.14% lower after Greek vote
summary: Australian stocks fell 1.14% on Monday after Greece rejected fresh austerity demands, but recovered from their lows. The S&P/ASX200 index closed 63.3 points down at 5,475.0. Despite market concerns, Asian traders remained calm, waiting for European confirmation before making trading moves. The Australian dollar recovered to 74.69 US cents, its lowest level in six years, after dipping to 74.52 US cents earlier.

site_title: China equity deals surged through market chaos
summary: China saw a surge in equity deals despite market volatility, with $20.6 billion in new share offerings in the past three weeks. This defies expectations of a slowdown, highlighting the resilience of domestic institutions and the growing influence of Chinese institutional investors. The deals were largely targeted at mainland funds, which are less likely to be affected by overseas market fluctuations. While secondary share sales are expected to slow, Hong Kong IPOs remain on track, with some deals unaffected by the measures to curb IPOs.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index drops after Greek 'No' vote
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 2.08% on Monday following Greece's rejection of austerity measures, leading to concerns the country may exit the eurozone. The Nikkei 225 fell 427.67 points to close at 20,112.12. The broader Topix index also declined 1.92%, as investors digested the vote results. The news boosted the odds of Greece leaving the eurozone, affecting global markets.

site_title: Euro picks up after Greek finance minister resigns
summary: The euro rose to US$1.1088 after Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis resigned, following the rejection of creditors' austerity demands in a landmark referendum. Varoufakis clashed with creditors and announced his resignation on his blog, citing a desire to help the Prime Minister reach an agreement. The move was seen as a positive development for the euro, which had dropped after the referendum. The resignation is a significant shift in Greece's debt negotiations, and its implications for the country's economic future remain to be seen.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post biggest daily losses in 3 years; won down
summary: South Korean shares plummeted 2.4% on Monday, the largest daily loss in over three years, amid concerns Greece might exit the European common currency. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 2,053.93 points. Foreign investors sold 287.5 billion won worth of shares, contributing to the losses. The won also fell 0.3% against the dollar, its lowest since March 18.

site_title: Taiwan aims to set up first US dollar bond exchange
summary: Taiwan aims to set up its first US dollar bond exchange, a move aimed at boosting its capital markets and aligning with global trends. The Financial Supervisory Commission has proposed a secondary market for trading US dollar-denominated bonds issued by foreign firms, with Morgan Stanley and AT&T among those that have sold bonds in Taiwan. The plan, set to be finalized late this year, is part of efforts to make Taiwan a wealth management hub in Asia and increase foreign investment.

site_title: Brent slumps below US$60 as Greek vote prompts stability concern
summary: Brent oil prices fell below $60 a barrel for the first time since April due to speculation that Greece's rejection of austerity measures may lead to its exit from the euro area, sparking concerns over Europe's economic stability. The Greek vote prompted a 1.6% decline in London futures, with US Secretary of State John Kerry tempering expectations for a nuclear deal with Iran. Oil prices have slumped amid concerns about a significant increase in supply from Iran, which could double its crude exports within six months of sanctions being lifted.

site_title: BOJ keeps rosy view of regional Japan
summary: The Bank of Japan maintained its optimistic view of regional Japan, citing moderate economic recoveries in all 9 regions, despite soft exports and output. The BOJ raised its assessment for Hokkaido and left views intact for the remaining regions. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expressed confidence in a moderate recovery, but noted the bank is watching market developments due to the Greek referendum's uncertainty. The BOJ is set to review its economic forecasts at its next meeting on July 14-15, with many analysts expecting no expansion of monetary stimulus.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan on Monday maintained its upbeat assessment on regional sectors of the economy, saying they are recovering thanks to a pick-up in output and tightening job markets.

site_title: Oil, steel, base metals fall on Greek 'No' vote
summary: Greece's rejection of bailout terms sent commodity prices plummeting, with oil falling below $60 per barrel, steel prices at their lowest since 2009, and iron ore down 15% since mid-June. China's market turmoil, fueled by a slowdown in its economy, further exacerbated the declines. Gold, however, rose as investors sought safe-haven assets amid economic uncertainty. The global economy's outlook remains uncertain, with oversupply pressures on oil, steel, and other commodities.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.71% up
summary: Hong Kong shares opened 0.71% higher on Monday, following China's measures to support mainland markets after three weeks of heavy losses. Greece's rejection of creditors' bailout reforms was offset by this move. The Hang Seng Index added 186.01 points to 26,250.12.

site_title: Rolls-Royce downgrades 2015, 2016 profit forecasts
summary: Rolls-Royce downgraded its 2015 and 2016 profit forecasts, citing weak oil and gas markets and lower demand for some aero-engine programmes. The company now expects 2015 profit to be between £1.325 billion and £1.475 billion, a 5% decrease from its previous guidance. The downgrade comes four days after new CEO Warren East took the helm, and affects sales of marine engines.

images.alt_text: British engineering company Rolls-Royce downgraded its profit forecasts for this year and next, citing continued weakness in oil and gas markets plus lower demand for some of its aero-engine programmes.

site_title: Interruption in launch of enhanced SingPass due to system maintenance
summary: The launch of an enhanced SingPass in Singapore was interrupted by a maintenance due to high traffic, leaving users unable to sign up a day later. The Infocomm Development Authority stated that the team is working to resolve the issue.

site_title: HK Exchanges sinks most in 6 years as Goldman says sell
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd plummeted 13% to HK$226, its largest decline in 6 years, after Goldman Sachs advised selling shares due to concerns over weakening earnings and volumes. The stock's price estimate was lowered by 26% and recommendation changed to sell from neutral. Analysts attribute the decline to slowing earnings growth despite solid revenue growth, with the gap between forecasted and current prices at its widest since 2008.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd is on course for its steepest slump since Oct 2008 after Goldman Sachs Group Inc advised selling shares of the world's largest bourse operator amid concern weaker volumes will curb earnings.

site_title: Quick Takes: Greferendum - what the 'no' vote means
summary: Greece's 61% "no" vote on creditors' bailout terms has sent markets into "risk off" mode, with economists warning of a potential Grexit. The "no" vote does not automatically mean Greece will exit the euro, but economists predict a high risk of a Grexit and its consequences. The European Central Bank's upcoming emergency liquidity assistance decision will be crucial in determining the outcome, and economists are divided on the potential impact on the global financial system and eurozone growth.

site_title: Honda chief downplays sales target, pledges better communication
summary: Honda's new president, Takahiro Hachigo, downplays the importance of meeting sales targets, instead focusing on developing unique products that align with the company's vision. He pledged to improve communication with the "real people in the field" and treat all suppliers equally, regardless of nationality. Hachigo also stated that a sales target of 6 million vehicles annually by 2017 was not the right focus for Honda, instead emphasizing the need to bring out the best in the company's engineers.

images.alt_text: Honda Motor Co's new president pledged to improve communication, while downplaying the importance of chasing sales that was widely seen as contributing to quality problems at the automaker.

site_title: Asia: Markets sink after Greece votes 'No' to austerity
summary: Asian markets sank on Monday after Greece voted "No" to austerity demands, fuelling fears of a potential eurozone exit. Despite European leaders' calls for respect, Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' decision is seen as a significant setback in bailout talks. Analysts warn of a high chance of Greece exiting the eurozone, potentially destabilizing the single currency. Shanghai shares surged, while Hong Kong and Tokyo also saw gains, as investors await further developments.

site_title: Yuan drops to one-week low on weaker PBOC fixing, Euro decline
summary: China's yuan dropped to a one-week low due to a weaker People's Bank of China (PBOC) fixing and a decline in the euro after Greek voters rejected further austerity measures. The euro's drop boosted demand for the dollar, which advanced 0.3% and spurred demand for the currency. The PBOC will provide liquidity for margin trading and stabilize the stock market. The yuan fell 0.03% to 6.2078 a dollar, and the PBOC's fixing was the weakest level since June 10.

site_title: Oxley sells rights to rents in London project for £34.5m
summary: Oxley Holdings sold its rights to ground rents for phases one and two of its London development, Royal Wharf, to Adriatic Land East Limited for £34.5m. The sale is expected to positively impact Oxley's net tangible assets and earnings per share for 2016 and 2017. Royal Wharf, a 999-year leasehold land parcel along the River Thames, will accommodate 3,400 homes and various amenities when completed, with the first phase expected to be finished in summer 2016.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 6.79 points to 1728.43, with losers outnumbering gainers 167 to 55. Volume was 62.4 million lots worth RM15.8 million.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.77% lower on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.77% to 3,316.96, opening weaker on Monday, following a 61% "no" vote in Greece on creditors' bailout terms. Top gainers included Jardine Strategic Holdings and Yeo Hiap Seng. Losers outnumbered gainers 100 to 41, with 43.4 million shares changing hands worth S$100.1 million.

site_title: Greeks reject austerity, setting up showdown on Euro membership
summary: Greece rejected a proposed austerity package demanded by creditors, with 61% of voters backing Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras's rejection of further spending cuts and tax increases. The result sets up a showdown on Greece's Euro membership, potentially leading to a financial rescue or a Greek exit from the single currency. The euro fell to a four-week low, and European leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Francois Hollande, called for an emergency leaders' summit on July 7. The outcome raises the chances of a Greek exit from the euro zone, with the country's banks running out of cash and its economy in a state of collapse.

site_title: Surging luxury car demand vaults Mercedes-Benz past Volkswagen in Japan
summary: Mercedes-Benz is poised to surpass Volkswagen as Japan's top-selling import auto brand, driven by a surge in luxury car demand. Through June, Mercedes-Benz delivered 32,680 vehicles, a 19% increase, while Volkswagen's sales fell 17% to 29,666. The trend reflects Japan's booming luxury car market, which has seen the Nikkei 225 Stock Average nearly double since 2013. This success contrasts with a recent slowdown in China, driven by a government crackdown on graft and conspicuous consumption.

site_title: BMWs that can buy morning coffee lure Apple, Google to the road
summary: BMW, Volkswagen, and Daimler are teaming up to acquire Nokia's HERE digital map business, potentially worth $4 billion, to gain control over location data crucial for autonomous vehicles and in-car services. The goal is to create a full-service mobile device, allowing cars to order coffee, pay for it, and guide drivers to pick it up. This move aims to disrupt the transportation industry and tap into a $180 billion market by 2020, as McKinsey estimates.

site_title: Ringgit tumbles to weakest since 3.8 dollar peg scrapped in 2005
summary: Malaysia's ringgit currency dropped 0.7% to 3.8045 against the US dollar, its weakest level since 2005, amid heightened risk of Greece exiting the euro and a 48% drop in Brent crude prices. The currency has been Asia's worst-performing exchange rate this year, partly due to a political debate surrounding Prime Minister Najib Razak and deteriorating finances. Fitch Ratings raised the outlook on Malaysia's A- rating to stable from negative, but warned of a downgrade due to the country's net oil exporter status.

site_title: China's "shadow lenders" line pockets even as bourses bomb
summary: China's "shadow lenders" have profited from lending up to 10 times a borrower's capital to buy stocks, despite the market's slump, resulting in heavy losses for customers. The grey market network, involving state-owned banks, trust companies, and fund managers, has generated significant profits through annualized interest rates of up to 17%. However, excessive leverage can lead to a vicious cycle of selling shares to meet margin calls, driving prices down further. Beijing is struggling to regulate the system while protecting retail investors, who comprise 80% of the stock market.

site_title: Noble to redeem senior notes worth US$235m early
summary: NOBLE Group announced it will redeem its outstanding 6.625% senior notes worth US$235m early, with the redemption price set at 100% of the principal amount. The redemption is scheduled for August 5, 2025.

site_title: Philippines confirms second Mers case
summary: The Philippines has confirmed its second case of the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) corona virus, a 36-year-old foreigner who arrived in Manila on June 19 from Dubai. The man is in a government hospital and his condition is improving, with no known transmission to the community. Contact tracing is underway to prevent the spread of the disease, which is the second reported case in the country, following a Filipino nurse who survived the disease in January.

site_title: AsiaPhos to acquire LY Resources for S$36.8m
summary: AsiaPhos to acquire LY Resources for S$36.8 million, expanding its 55% equity interest in Deyang Fengtai Mining Co Ltd, which holds a barite exploration licence in China's Sichuan province. The acquisition aims to improve operating cash flows and increase resource base, with potential economies of scale and cost savings. The deal is valued at S$57.56 million based on an independent valuation report by Jones Lang LaSalle.

images.alt_text: AsiaPhos CEO Dr Ong Hian Eng.

site_title: China: Stocks rocket 8% at open after weekend rescue moves
summary: China's stocks surged 8% at open on Monday, driven by Beijing's weekend policy moves to support the market. The CSI300 index rose 7.7% to 4,186.24 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 7.0%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index added 0.7%, and China Enterprises Index rose 1.9%. These moves followed a weekend of unprecedented policy support, as Beijing aims to stabilize the market amid concerns about economic growth.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Otto Marine, Miyoshi, Noble
summary: Otto Marine secured a $26 million term loan facility, with loan conditions tied to the ownership of its controlling shareholder. Miyoshi reported a net profit of $777,000 for its third quarter, reversing a $520,000 loss last year, with revenue rising 5.4% to $13.5 million. Noble Group will redeem its $235 million senior notes in August.

site_title: Malaysia ringgit hits 16-year low on PM graft allegations
summary: Malaysia's ringgit plummeted to a 16-year low on Monday, falling 0.8% to 3.8070 per dollar, amid allegations of Prime Minister Najib Razak's involvement in corruption linked to state fund 1MDB. A Wall Street Journal report claimed nearly $700 million was traced to accounts believed to belong to the prime minister. Najib has denied any wrongdoing. Two opposition parties demanded an emergency parliament sitting to discuss his future. The report sparked widespread political tensions and economic instability in Malaysia.

site_title: Australia inflation gauge stays benign in June: gauge
summary: Australia's private inflation gauge remained subdued in June, increasing 0.1% from May, below the Reserve Bank of Australia's 2-3% target band. The annual pace ticked up to 1.5%, offering scope for lower interest rates if needed. Despite this, investors suspect further easing may be required to offset economic uncertainty and weakness in business investment. The central bank is expected to keep interest rates steady at its upcoming meeting, with a potential rate cut by December.

site_title: Investors lower Samsung Elec Q2 expectations amid S6 doubts
summary: Samsung Electronics' Q2 expectations have been lowered amid doubts over the sales prospects of its new Galaxy S6 models, citing supply shortages and economic headwinds. The company's stock price has declined nearly six percent for the year, and analysts now forecast operating profit of 7.2 trillion won for the second quarter, down from initial estimates of 7 trillion won. Despite this, Samsung's overall profit is expected to recover to 27.8 trillion won in 2015, with the new S6 phones projected to be its best-selling devices to date.

site_title: Britain's banks call on government to phase out industry levy
summary: Britain's banks have called on the government to phase out the bank levy, citing its damaging impact on competitiveness and loss of business to overseas rivals. The levy, introduced in 2011, aims to raise revenue and discourage risky borrowing. Finance Minister George Osborne has emphasized the need for banks to contribute to repairing the country's finances. The banks' request is part of a broader push to address the UK's economic challenges.

site_title: Manulife US Reit IPO delayed: source
summary: The initial public offering (IPO) of Manulife US Reit has been delayed due to increased volatility in the equity capital market. The IPO, set to launch in Singapore in the second half of 2015, is expected to proceed at a later date depending on market conditions. Manulife US Reit had lodged its preliminary prospectus with the Monetary Authority of Singapore earlier. The exact delay is not specified, but the company is working to reschedule the IPO.

site_title: Asia: Stocks slide as Greece 'no' vote raises risk of Euro exit
summary: Asian stocks fell 0.5% as Greece voted against accepting further austerity, increasing the likelihood of the country's euro exit. The 'no' vote, backed by 61% of voters, puts Greece on the brink of financial collapse. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index slid to 145.65, while Japan's Topix index sank 1.5%. The European Union is set to hold a summit on Tuesday, and the European Central Bank is expected to discuss supporting Greece's lenders. The outcome is uncertain, with unpredictable outcomes and a potential for a prolonged period of limbo for risk sentiment.

site_title: When a selfie is not enough: India abuzz over 'velfie' craze
summary: India is embracing the "velfie" craze, with Bollywood stars, sports heroes, and politicians using mobile apps to create and share video selfies. The trend, which involves lip-synching to pre-recorded audio, has been popularized by apps like Velfie and Dubsmash, which have been downloaded millions of times globally. Indian tech firms are betting on the velfie craze, with plans to expand into a "video social network" and use it for advertising. The trend has also been used to engage with audiences and promote businesses, with some politicians and celebrities using it to respond to voter queries and promote their work.

images.alt_text: Move over selfie, India is embracing the "velfie" with Bollywood stars, sporting heroes and even politicians taking and posting videos of themselves online using a range of new mobile apps.

site_title: Temasek surfs worldwide equity rally as assets to reach new high
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore state-owned investor, reported a significant increase in assets, potentially reaching a record S$263 billion, driven by a global equity rally, particularly in developed markets. The firm's assets may have increased 16-18% in the year to March 31, surpassing last year's all-time high. Temasek's focus on mature markets, such as the US and Europe, and its aggressive investment style contributed to the growth.

site_title: Despite crisis, few Greeks ready to give up their coffee
summary: In Greece, despite an economic crisis, cafes remain packed with customers, including those seeking to discuss a crucial referendum that may impact their future in Europe. Greeks have cut back on consumption, but their love for traditional coffee, including iced coffees and frappes, remains strong. Many believe that if Greece leaves the euro, imported coffee prices may rise, potentially leading to a shift back to traditional Greek coffee. Opinion polls show a near-even split on the referendum, with some Greeks deliberating over coffee before making a decision.

site_title: Shipping industry gloomiest since 2009 in survey as glut endures
summary: The shipping industry is experiencing its most pessimistic outlook since 2009, according to a survey by Norton Rose Fulbright. Two-thirds of respondents expressed pessimism about the industry's prospects, citing excess fleet capacity as the main concern. Despite some surging markets, such as oil hauling, others are slumping, with rates for delivering Saudi Arabian crude to Japan reaching a 2009 high. The Baltic Dry Index, measuring coal and iron ore freight, has also seen its worst first six months on record. Excess capacity and new ship orders have fueled increased pessimism.

site_title: Eurozone summit on Greece confirmed for Tuesday: Tusk
summary: Eurozone nations will hold a summit on Tuesday to discuss the Greek referendum result, following a 'No' vote against creditor demands for further austerity in return for bailout funds. EU President Donald Tusk confirmed the meeting, which will be preceded by a Eurogroup of eurozone finance ministers on Tuesday. The summit aims to address the situation after the Greek referendum.

site_title: Euro edges up as investors weigh risks of Greek exit
summary: The euro edged up against the dollar in Asia, despite a jump in the odds of a Greek exit from the eurozone following a weekend referendum. The euro was at US$1.1025, up from US$1.0963, as investors assessed the risks of a Greek exit. The referendum saw over 61% of Greek voters reject austerity demands, increasing the likelihood of a "Grexit" to 70-80%, according to analysts.

A "Yes" vote may bring more austerity measures, while a "No" vote could lead to economic instability.

site_title: Distributors rue parallel import advantage
summary: Parallel importers in Singapore are enjoying a resurgence in popularity, with their market share rising to 11.3% in the first quarter of 2015, compared to 5.2% in 2013. The main reasons for this growth are lower prices due to lower registration taxes and CEVS surcharges, as well as the use of fixed Evolution Coefficient values for carbon emissions. This has led to complaints from authorised distributors, who claim to be unfairly competing with parallel importers. The affected brands, including Toyota, Honda, and Mercedes-Benz, are seeing a significant proportion of their sales come from parallel imports, with some models accounting for over 50% of their total sales.

site_title: Iran nuclear talks: dispute remains over UN sanctions
summary: Iran and world powers made progress in nuclear talks, agreeing on a mechanism for suspending US and EU sanctions, but remaining divided on lifting UN sanctions and developing advanced centrifuges. Diplomats said a final agreement is within reach, but issues such as a stalled UN investigation and Iran's demand to continue research on advanced centrifuges need to be resolved. A deal would require cooperation from Iran to ease sanctions, including on low-enriched uranium stockpiles. Foreign ministers are expected to rejoin negotiations on Sunday.

site_title: Gold rebounds as dollar dips, focus on Greek vote
summary: Gold prices rebounded 0.2% to $1,167.73 an ounce as the US dollar softened ahead of Greece's referendum on an international bailout deal. Despite uncertainty over the timing of a potential interest rate hike, which could boost the dollar and dent gold demand, investors remained cautious. The metal was still expected to fall 0.5% on the week, largely due to gains in the dollar against the euro. The outcome of the Greek referendum and potential European Central Bank actions could trigger buying on gold, analysts said.

site_title: Reddit restores most of site after moderator-led blackouts
summary: Reddit has restored most of its online message boards after moderators led a blackout in protest of the firing of Victoria Taylor, the company's director of talent. Almost 300 discussion areas were marked private and required moderator approval to view. The blackout appeared after Taylor's dismissal on Thursday, and the closures started appearing on Friday. The move was a response to the moderators' dissatisfaction with the company's management. Reddit has since restored most of its service.

site_title: Mers cases keep coming from Samsung hospital
summary: A 25-year-old female doctor at Samsung Medical Centre in Seoul has contracted Mers, bringing the total number of infected medics to 13. The hospital, a major epicentre of the outbreak, now accounts for 90 out of 185 confirmed cases. Two nurses were confirmed infected, prompting the transfer of 12 patients to other facilities, but the death toll remains unchanged at 33. 41 patients are still hospitalized, with 11 in critical condition.

site_title: Europe tensely awaits Greek voters' decision
summary: European leaders, particularly German Chancellor Angela Merkel, anxiously await the outcome of Greece's referendum, which could shape the country's future and impact the EU. The vote, scheduled for Sunday, will determine whether to support Greece's left-led government in its anti-austerity stance, potentially leading to a "Grexit" and a re-evaluation of European integration. The outcome will also have significant economic and political implications, with fears of unforeseen consequences and a boost for anti-euro groups.

site_title: Greece: Grimbo or Grexit?
summary: Greece is at risk of a "Grimbo" or a prolonged period of economic limbo before potentially exiting the eurozone. A currency law, "lex monetae," would create a new currency, and the government would specify official conversion rates. This could lead to a gradual process of issuing scrip or IOUs, rather than a sudden Grexit. The implications for the economy and markets are uncertain, and investors should be prepared for potential volatility. The Greek government's decision on a new currency would have significant consequences for the country's debt, banking system, and overall economy.

site_title: Greek deposits may be seized to save banks: FT
summary: Greek savers may face a 30% haircut on their bank deposits, with those over €8,000 potentially losing their savings, to help shore up the country's banking system amid fears of financial collapse. This could happen as part of an overall restructuring of the bank sector after Greece returns to a bailout program. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has called a referendum on tougher austerity measures in exchange for bailout funds from international creditors. The Greek banking system is at risk of collapse if the ECB declares the banks insolvent and Greece fails to pay back its debts.

site_title: Canadian economy not heading for recession: minister
summary: Canada's finance minister, Joe Oliver, denied the country is heading for recession, contradicting predictions from major banks. The economy shrank 0.6% in the first quarter, but Oliver expects robust growth in the second quarter and beyond. A recession would be defined by two consecutive quarters of contraction, and the government is concerned about the impact on the Conservative government ahead of general elections in October. Second quarter GDP estimates are expected July 15, with final figures confirmed in September.

site_title: Hong Kong stock exchange to introduce volatility controls from mid-2016
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange, HKEX, plans to introduce new controls to rein-in volatility, including a closing auction and price band restrictions, starting mid-2016. The move comes after a series of wild price swings in Chinese shares listed in Hong Kong, with some stocks losing up to 50% of their value in less than two hours. The controls aim to bring the market in line with international peers and mitigate price swings, which can be up to six times greater than in other developed markets.

site_title: Japan pledges US$6b to Mekong nations as China prepares new bank
summary: Japan pledged US$6 billion in development aid to Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Thailand, and Vietnam over three years, as China prepares to launch a new institutional lender. The move aims to boost infrastructure projects in the region, with a focus on railway systems and power plants. The aid follows a previous pledge of 600 billion yen and contrasts with China's AIIB, which the US has expressed concerns over. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Mekong region leaders discussed regional tension, including China's South China Sea expansion, during a Tokyo summit.

site_title: Row breaks out over Greek medicine supplies
summary: Greek medicine suppliers face criticism from wholesalers trading medicines across European borders over proposed restrictions to prevent life-saving drug shortages in the country. The European Association of Euro Pharmaceutical Companies argues that manufacturers' suggestion is a "commercial ploy" to exploit Greece's potential crisis, while the EU Health Commissioner is under pressure to take emergency action. The wholesalers claim that the proposed restrictions would not prevent shortages, despite the potential for prices to fall sharply if Greece leaves the euro.

site_title: UK private-sector growth falls to six-month low in June: CBI
summary: The UK private sector experienced its lowest growth in six months, according to the Confederation of British Industry. The growth indicator fell to +14 in June, its lowest since December, from +33 in May. While manufacturing growth increased, services companies saw a slowdown from a nine-year high in May. This marks a fresh blow to UK economy, with the economy shrinking for the second month in a row.

site_title: Hundreds of flights canceled in Toronto fuel strike
summary: Hundreds of flights were canceled and hundreds delayed at Toronto Pearson International Airport on July 3 after staff refueling planes went on strike. The strike, led by Consolidated Aviation Fueling of Toronto, was in protest of an airline consortium's decision to cut ties with the fueling provider. The airport reported 185 canceled flights and over 30 additional cancellations, causing travel disruptions for many passengers. The Greater Toronto Airports Authority is urging the air carrier consortium to address the situation immediately and ensure passenger needs are met.

site_title: Stop the guacamole madness now
summary: US President Barack Obama and Republican presidential contender Jeb Bush weighed in on a national debate over adding peas to guacamole, with Obama calling the idea "radical" and Bush declaring "You don't put peas in guacamole." The New York Times published a recipe featuring peas, but most Americans, including Obama and Bush, disagreed. The avocado farmers' trade group also endorsed the president's view, saying "Stop the #guacamole madness now, Peas out!" The debate highlights the strong opinions on traditional vs. innovative recipes in the US.

site_title: Malaysian PM says referred "wild allegations" against him to lawyers
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak referred "wild allegations" of stealing US$700 million to his lawyers, saying he will decide on legal action in a few days. The allegations, made by a Wall Street Journal report, claim nearly US$700 million was traced to bank accounts believed to belong to Najib. Najib has previously denied any wrongdoing, stating he will take action against the accusations. Reuters could not independently verify the report.

site_title: IMF gives Greece something to mull over
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged European countries to provide more financial assistance to Greece to ease its debt burden, recommending a restructuring of the country's debt. The IMF estimates Greece needs at least 50 billion euros over the next three years. The proposal, released just days before a referendum on accepting new bailout terms, has been met with resistance from European leaders, particularly Germany, which claims the figures are outdated. The IMF's recommendations have the potential to divide Greece's main creditors, including the EU and ECB, and raise concerns about the sustainability of the Greek debt.

images.alt_text: Reviled in Greece for pushing the bitter medicine of austerity, the IMF has nonetheless thrown Athens a bone by urging European countries to cough up more money to ease Greece's titanic debt load.

site_title: Report Greek deposits may be seized is 'malicious rumour': minister
summary: Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis has dismissed a Financial Times report that Greek savers could lose 30% of their bank deposits to shore up the country's banking system, calling it a "malicious rumour". The report, quoting unidentified bankers, suggested that depositors with over €8,000 could face a "haircut" similar to those taken by Cypriot account holders in 2013. Greek banks remain shut and the system faces collapse if the European Central Bank declares them insolvent. A referendum is set for Sunday to determine Greece's willingness to accept tougher austerity measures in exchange for bail-out funds.

site_title: Cash-strapped O&M firms caught in a bind
summary: Cash-strapped offshore and marine (O&M) companies are facing difficulties in raising funds due to investor sentiment remaining dampened despite oil prices recovering from their lows. Traditional capital markets and private equity are hesitant to invest, with banks advising O&M firms to restructure or sell assets to raise funds. Some companies are exploring alternative options, such as convertible bonds and rights issues, while private equity funds are waiting for more attractive valuations before investing. Analysts expect more cash calls from smaller O&M firms, particularly those with high debt levels and upcoming debt repayments.

site_title: Oil slides in thin trade on rising US rig count
summary: Oil prices dropped on Friday as a rising US rig count fueled concerns about global oversupply, despite a brief rise earlier in the week. The US increased oil drilling for the first time in 29 weeks, indicating producers are responding to higher prices. The market was also unsettled by an investigation into suspected stock market manipulation by Chinese regulators. Thin liquidity, with many US market participants off for the US July Fourth holiday, exacerbated the price drop.

site_title: New Credit Suisse CEO promises "ruthlessly selective" review: FT
summary: Credit Suisse AG's new CEO, Tidjane Thiam, has promised a "ruthlessly selective" review of the bank's businesses, aiming to cut staff by 15% in its investment banking arm. Executives will compete for capital allocations based on unit profitability, but those without performance issues will have no concerns. Thiam may focus on private banking in Asia and pursue growth through international expansion in emerging markets, the US, and Switzerland. His strategic review may not follow investor expectations, which anticipate scaling back investment banking operations.

site_title: Reit rule changes to have little impact on sector: analysts
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) consultation paper on real estate investment trusts (Reits) has introduced rule changes that are expected to bear little impact on the sector. Analysts had anticipated changes but were surprised by the limited scope, with some expressing disappointment over the decision not to address performance fees. The changes include a 45% single-tier leverage limit for all Reits, with some analysts warning that Reits with high debt levels may face backlash from investors. However, the MAS has clarified that internal management and consolidation of Reits are allowed, potentially leading to consolidation and merger-and-acquisition activities in the sector.

site_title: Toshiba accounting errors may be over US$1 billion: report
summary: Toshiba Corp may need to restate past earnings by over $1.64 billion due to accounting errors related to computer parts procurement. The company previously estimated an overstatement of profits by nearly $550 million, but a new investigation found more irregularities. The errors are believed to be related to procurement practices for computer parts used in various Toshiba business segments, including highway electronic toll collection systems and semiconductors. The company has not commented on the new estimate.

site_title: Brazil targets 15 banks including Citi, HSBC in forex fixing probe
summary: Brazil's antitrust body Cade announced a probe into 15 banks, including Citigroup and HSBC, for alleged foreign exchange market rigging. The alleged cartel-like behavior, involving price fixing and coordination of trades, occurred from 2007 to 2013. Authorities claim the banks formed a secret cartel to impede other market operators. The probe aims to determine if these practices are anticompetitive and have harmed the Brazilian market.

site_title: Brazil govt expects Petrobras to lose key oil rights: source
summary: Brazil's government expects a bill to pass Congress that will end state-run Petrobras' dominant role in key offshore oil areas, reversing President Dilma Rousseff's signature policy. The bill, which will amend a 2010 law, will allow companies like Exxon Mobil Corp and BP plc to invest in the subsalt without being required to partner with Petrobras. The move is seen as a response to the slowing oil industry and Petrobras' crippling debt, with the government pushing for an amendment giving Petrobras the right of first refusal.

site_title: Crying Greek pensioner: The human story behind the Greek crisis
summary: A 77-year-old Greek pensioner, Giorgos Chatzifotiadis, broke down in tears after being unable to withdraw his wife's pension due to Greece's debt crisis. He had queued at four banks in Thessaloniki, but was told he couldn't withdraw the €120. The crisis has left ordinary Greeks struggling, with many facing financial difficulties and even suicidal thoughts. The situation has sparked widespread despair, with Chatzifotiadis feeling powerless to change the situation.

site_title: What Greece needs is Grunorthodoxy
summary: Greece faces a critical juncture as the country teeters on the edge of a financial crisis. The government's austerity measures and potential Grexit have been deemed insufficient, leaving the country with a daunting debt of 1.6 billion euros. Alternative solutions, such as crowdfunding, charity, and selling naming rights to landmarks, have been proposed, but may not be enough to alleviate the crisis. A more drastic approach, including using a Trojan Horse virus to infiltrate IMF headquarters, has been suggested, but its feasibility and ethics are unclear.

site_title: India's NSE explores listing shares
summary: The National Stock Exchange of India Ltd (NSE) plans to seek board approval for an initial share sale, with chairman Sunil Behari Mathur stating the board will take "conscious calls" about the timing. This move comes amid pressure from shareholders and intense competition from other Indian bourses. The NSE, which handles twice the volume of its competitor BSE Ltd in the cash segment, aims to list its shares once the nation's securities regulator issues revised guidelines for new applications.

site_title: Technology and progress bypass Chicago's pit traders
summary: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME Group) plans to close most of its open-outcry futures pits on July 6, marking the end of an era for human brokers. Electronic trading has been the driving force behind the decline, with floor-based volumes falling to 1% of total business. The historic pits, where traders used hand signals and body language to gain an edge, will be replaced by all-electronic trading systems, which have already boosted volumes and revenue. The closure is seen as a natural progression, given the rise of electronic trading and the eventual demise of similar exchanges in London and Paris.

site_title: China security law causes jitters in tech world
summary: China has enacted its national security law, which includes a "national security review" of the technology industry, including foreign investment, and calls for technology to be "secure and controllable". The law's vagueness has raised concerns that it could lead to forced back doors, encryption key sharing, or source code handovers, sparking a new front in the US-China clash over online security and technology policy. The law's enforcement unclearness may increase lobbying pressure on the US, particularly with the upcoming counter-terrorism law, which could include stronger restrictions on foreign technologies.

site_title: China bargain-hunters snap up Japan homes
summary: Chinese investors are snapping up homes in Japan, driving up prices, particularly in Tokyo. Busloads of buyers from China are visiting Tokyo and Osaka, buying apartments and pushing prices higher. The yen's decline to 22-year lows has prompted the trend, with Tokyo apartment prices reaching the highest levels since the early 1990s. Chinese buyers are mainly purchasing in the 1 million to 2 million yuan bracket, and some developers have put quotas on the number of new apartments sold to foreigners. The trend is expected to continue, with thousands more mainland Chinese coming to Tokyo to buy properties.

site_title: Oil glut meets rising demand in quietest market since 2013
summary: Oil prices remain stable in the US$5 range, the narrowest in 19 months, as demand and supply remain balanced. Crude traded around US$59 in the third quarter and US$63 in the fourth, according to analyst forecasts. Despite increased petrol demand, record Opec production and rising US shale output have capped price rebounds. Investors remain cautious, with some expecting oil to move higher if US production slows or an Iran deal is signed.

site_title: Total unveils its largest lubricant plant in S'pore
summary: TOTAL Oil Asia-Pacific has launched its largest lubricant plant in Singapore, increasing regional capacity by 30% and doubling local lubricant production. The new facility, located at the Singapore Lube Park at Tuas South, has an annual production capacity of 310,000 tonnes and employs 104 workers. The move is expected to boost the company's lubricants sales in Asia, which is projected to reach 40% of Total's overall lubricant sales by 2025. The plant is fully operational by year-end and marks Total's strategic expansion in the region.

site_title: Qing bling
summary: Hong Kong jewellery designer Dickson Yewn is challenging the status quo in the luxury jewellery industry by showcasing his contemporary Chinese designs, which draw inspiration from Chinese history and culture. Despite being a pioneer in this field, Yewn's creations have been largely influenced by Western designers. His new 60-piece collection, "Dream and Reality," features intricate designs inspired by Chinese literature, such as the Taoist story of Chuang Tzu Becomes a Butterfly. Yewn aims to revive traditional Chinese imperial jewellery-making techniques and promote Chinese culture through his work.

site_title: Odd-shaped melons herald Japan summer
summary: Japanese consumers are paying high prices for unusual, ornamental watermelons, with some selling for up to 12,960 yen (S$142) for a cube-shaped model. The fruit is grown in acrylic containers to achieve the desired shape, which is meant to be displayed as an ornament rather than eaten.
