This luxury fruit trend is part of Japan's tradition of exchanging expensive gifts, with prices rivaling those of high-end strawberries and cantaloupes. The trend is expected to continue, with some farmers already planting young watermelons for the purpose.

images.alt_text: FEAST FOR THE EYES: Mr Nishimura of Tokyo's Shibuya Nishimura luxury fruit shop displaying square and heart-shaped watermelons. Farmers plant young watermelons inside acrylic containers to get the desired shape.

site_title: Iceland decriminalises blasphemy after Charlie Hebdo attack
summary: Iceland's parliament voted 43-1 in favor of decriminalizing blasphemy, following the Charlie Hebdo attacks in Paris. The bill, proposed by the Pirate Party, abolishes Article 125 of Iceland's penal law, which penalized public mockery of a legal religious group. The move aims to promote freedom of expression and was supported by the Lutheran Church of Iceland, which represents 75% of Icelanders. The Pirate Party hailed the vote as a message that freedom will not be intimidated by attacks.

site_title: Citigroup, HSBC among banks named in Brazil currency probe
summary: Brazil's antitrust agency, Cade, is investigating Citigroup, HSBC, Morgan Stanley, and 12 other banks for alleged anti-competitive price-fixing practices in the foreign-exchange market. The probe found "strong signs" of coordinated currency transactions and blocked competitors from operating freely, similar to cases in the US and Europe that resulted in multibillion-dollar settlements. The accused banks have 30 days to respond, and penalties could amount to up to 20% of revenue from operations involved.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate expands into China healthcare sector
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings (PREH) has expanded into China's healthcare sector through a 40% stake in a joint venture with Guangdong Boai Medical Group. The venture will acquire and develop medical facilities, including Modern Hospital Guangzhou, and reposition Dongzhan Mall in Chengdu into a health and medical hub. PREH aims to build 30-50 hospitals in the next 5-7 years, complementing its existing integrated projects. The move is seen as a natural extension of the company's real estate business, with rental yields expected to be comparable to its retail space.

site_title: Out of the box
summary:
Singaporean architects are pushing boundaries with innovative designs, as seen in the upcoming World Architecture Festival. Three notable projects include:

* Multiply Architects' Mahabodhi Monastery, a contemporary Buddhist temple featuring onyx tiles and subtle elements inspired by traditional Buddhist and Chinese designs.
* LAUD Architects' DECK, a modular art space made from refurbished shipping containers, designed to minimize environmental impact and promote community interaction.
* SCDA Architects' SkyTerrace @ Dawson, a public housing development that combines modern design with lush landscaping and communal spaces, redefining the concept of public housing.
* Ministry of Design's 100PP, an office building with a unique "stepped" balcony design that blurs the boundaries between industrial and commercial spaces.
* DP Architects' Connexion, a mixed-use complex that connects various functions and responds to its surroundings, featuring a colorful façade and harmonious design elements.

These projects showcase the creativity and innovation of Singaporean architects, as they strive to create spaces that are not only functional but also beautiful and sustainable.

site_title: Destiny says it's Chile's time at last
summary: Chile is poised to make history in the Copa America final against Argentina, with the host nation seeking its first championship title. The sold-out match at the National Stadium in Santiago will be a fitting conclusion to the three-week tournament, with Argentina desperate to end its 22-year drought without a major trophy. Lionel Messi, the star forward for Argentina, is seeking to add an international honor to his collection, but Chile's talented team, led by Arturo Vidal, Alexis Sanchez, and Claudio Bravo, is expected to give the favored Argentines a run for their money, with destiny firmly on Chile's side.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Two Singaporean stocks, Mapletree Logistics Trust and Ezion Holdings, received upgrades from analysts. Mapletree Logistics Trust was upgraded to a "Buy" with a target price of S$1.31, driven by recent acquisitions and attractive yields. Ezion Holdings was also upgraded to a "Buy" with a target price of S$2.10, following a successful non-deal roadshow and growth prospects in the oil and gas sector.

site_title: SGX Healthcare Index outperforms STI
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) Healthcare Index outperformed the Straits Times Index (STI) by 20.2 percentage points, with a total return of 21.4% in the January to June period, compared to the STI's 0.1376%.

site_title: From partners to 'friendly' rivals
summary: Blackstone CEO Steve Schwarzman and BlackRock CEO Larry Fink, former partners, are intensifying their competition in the business and finance world. In April, Blackstone secured a $14 billion real estate deal, solidifying its position as the world's largest landlord. Meanwhile, BlackRock, now the largest traditional money management firm, issued a warning letter to S&P 500 companies about the dangers of short-term thinking and the growing influence of activist shareholders. Both firms, with assets totaling $4.8 trillion and $US$14 billion respectively, are vying for attention as they expand into new activities.

site_title: BP's spill deal is 'catalyst' for acquirers as uncertainty ends
summary: BP's $18.7 billion US legal settlement has ended five years of financial uncertainty, making the company a more attractive takeover target. The settlement's removal of unquantifiable liabilities related to the 2010 Gulf of Mexico spill has increased investor confidence. BP's slimmed-down profile, with a low enterprise value-to-production ratio, has also made it more appealing to potential buyers. Analysts believe Exxon Mobil Corp is the most likely buyer due to shared assets and business ties, but other acquirers may still be attracted to BP's deep-water prospects and trading outfit.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler taken to task over recalls
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has convened a hearing over Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) for mishandling recalls affecting over 10 million vehicles. The recalls included fixing a defective nut in Ram trucks, a broken tie-rod in Ram owners, faulty ignition switches, and exposed gas tanks in Jeep Grand Cherokees. FCA has only repaired 6% of affected Jeep Grand Cherokees with exposed gas tanks. The NHTSA's investigation aims to address the company's slow response to the recalls, putting drivers' safety at risk.

site_title: Aetna to acquire rival Humana for US$37b in cash and stock
summary: Aetna agreed to acquire Humana for $37 billion in cash and stock, combining two of the largest US health insurers. The deal would create a company with estimated operating revenue of $115 billion and over 33 million consumers. The merger signals the start of potential consolidation in the US health insurance sector, driven by rising medical costs and pressure to grow pricing power. The transaction is subject to shareholder and regulatory approval and expected to close in the second half of 2016.

site_title: MOM arrests 41 in foreign-worker syndicate bust
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower (MOM) arrested 41 individuals, including an alleged mastermind, in a foreign-worker syndicate bust. The syndicate set up shell companies to bring in foreign workers, earning profits from kickbacks, with no actual employment involved. The operation is part of MOM's enforcement strategy to ensure a level playing field in employment. The syndicate's actions deny Singaporeans job opportunities and put law-abiding employers at a disadvantage. Those involved face fines of up to S$6,000 and/or imprisonment of 6 months to 2 years.

site_title: Rakuten acquires S'pore- and Japan-based startup Voyagin
summary: Rakuten, Japan's leading e-commerce site, has acquired a majority stake in Singapore- and Japan-based travel booking platform Voyagin for over $3.48 million. The acquisition will allow Rakuten to strengthen in-bound tourism services in Japan ahead of the 2020 Olympic and Paralympic Games. Voyagin, co-founded in 2012, will continue to operate with its own brand identity and expand its team to hire for various positions. The deal is seen as beneficial for Voyagin, which doesn't need to fund-raise again, and for Rakuten, which gains access to the travel space and market knowledge.

site_title: The handsome Hyundai
summary: The new Hyundai Tucson boasts improved design, refinement, and features. The third-generation compact crossover has a larger body, bolder styling, and a more supportive and comfortable interior. The new platform provides better ride quality, with improved insulation and reduced noise, vibration, and harshness. The Tucson also features a new 2.0L petrol engine, advanced safety features, and a more user-friendly dashboard design. With a starting price of S$142,999, the Tucson offers a higher level of equipment and refinement, solidifying its position as a bigger, better, and bolder compact SUV.

site_title: Regulatory resistance could force GE to seek other deals
summary: US and European regulatory resistance may force General Electric to seek alternative buyers for its appliances business and explore different expansion strategies. GE's CEO, Jeff Immelt, is focusing on higher-margin industrial products like jet engines and power-generating turbines, but regulatory concerns over acquisitions are hindering progress. The US government is suing to block GE's sale to Electrolux, and European regulators are questioning the impact of GE's acquisition of Alstom's power equipment business. Investors are considering alternative paths for GE, including other acquisitions or buybacks.

site_title: Minority PM inevitable, but Tharman rules himself out
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam predicts Singapore will have a minority-race prime minister in the future, but he rules himself out due to his preference for playing a supporting role. He credits PM Lee Hsien Loong's strong leadership and the presence of younger candidates for the country's future leadership. Tharman emphasizes the importance of competition and accountability in Singapore's political system, rejecting the idea that the country is a one-party state.

site_title: Singapore's new PMI
summary: Singapore's new Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has taken office, succeeding Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew. The government has set up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific and aims to make Singapore a global hub for advanced chip packaging. The country is also exploring opportunities for trade talks with the US, particularly for businesses hit by tariffs. Meanwhile, graduates are advised to stay calm with better employment rates, and the government is offering a grant of up to SGD 100,000 to support affected businesses. The government is also promoting workforce development through initiatives like SBF.

site_title: New PMI may help plug gap in services sector data
summary: Singapore has launched a new Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) gauge that covers the whole economy, aiming to fill a gap in timely information on the country's growing services sector. The Nikkei Singapore PMI, produced by Markit, covers more sectors and companies than the existing PMI compiled by the Singapore Institute of Purchasing & Materials Management. This broader measure is also used for Hong Kong, Egypt, and other countries. The new PMI is seen as a more comprehensive measure of business conditions in Singapore, providing a more accurate picture of the economy.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Otto Marine has taken a US$26 million term loan facility linked to one of its directors. The loan conditions will be breached if a controlling shareholder holds less than 51% of the company. Meanwhile, Miyoshi reported a net profit of S$777,000 for its third quarter, driven by higher revenue from its consumer electronics segment.

site_title: Moving into uncharted territory
summary: Negative interest rates in parts of Europe are creating unusual situations, with some corporate bonds paying interest to the issuer and banks threatening depositors with negative rates. This phenomenon, inspired by economist Silvio Gesell's 19th-century idea of a "Gesell tax," aims to prevent money hoarding by taxing currency notes. As interest rates drop below zero, people are increasingly using negative-interest bonds, which are seen as a secure investment. The widespread adoption of negative interest rates may lead to a reevaluation of money's function, potentially paving the way for a "free money" system, where cash loses its value as a store of wealth.

site_title: A 'No' vote by Greeks on Sunday will isolate the country
summary: Greece's citizens are set to vote on a referendum Sunday, with a "No" vote potentially isolating the country from Europe and the eurozone. A rejection of the creditors' offer would mean no to modernization, the euro, and Europe. The consequences of a "No" vote could include Greece defaulting on payments, leaving the euro, and becoming an economic pariah in international markets. If Greece votes "Yes", it could lead to a technocratic government or a unity government. The outcome of the referendum will have immeasurable economic and political implications for Greece and future generations.

site_title: Google campuses help tech startups flourish
summary: Google is building campuses around the world to support tech startups, providing spaces for entrepreneurs to meet, work, and learn. The first campus opened in London in 2012, followed by ones in Tel Aviv, Seoul, and Madrid. The campuses offer co-working desk spaces, event spaces, and partnerships with organizations such as TechHub and Seedcamp. Membership is free, with over 55,000 people worldwide participating. Google plans to open campuses in Warsaw and Sao Paulo later this year, with the goal of fostering entrepreneurship globally and supporting startups in their growth.

site_title: S Korea to inject 22 trillion won stimulus into Mers-hit economy
summary: South Korea's government has agreed to inject 22 trillion won (S$26.4 billion) into the economy, which has been hit by the MERS virus outbreak and sluggish consumption. The stimulus package aims to revitalize the economy and stabilize the livelihood of ordinary people. It is expected to raise economic growth by 0.3 percentage point in 2015 and 0.4 percentage point in 2016. The package includes additional credits for exporters and expanded investments by state companies. The move comes as the country hosts international sporting events despite lingering concerns over the MERS outbreak.

site_title: China targets stock manipulators amid rout
summary: China's securities regulator has opened an investigation into suspected market manipulation amid a 20% slump in Chinese stocks since mid-June. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) is probing investors who used stock index futures to short the market, amid Beijing's efforts to stem a potential stock market crash and support an already slowing economy. The benchmark composite index slumped below 4,000 points for the first time since April, with analysts warning of a key uncertainty for the global outlook due to weak Chinese demand and expected GDP growth below 7%.

site_title: European service industry enjoys June bounce despite Greek woes
summary: The European service industry experienced a faster-than-expected growth in June, expanding at a four-year record pace despite Greece's economic uncertainty. The final composite PMI for June came in at 54.2, above the preliminary reading and May's 53.6. This growth was attributed to low inflation and the European Central Bank's bond-buying program, with retail sales also rising faster than thought. However, markets remained unchanged, awaiting the outcome of Greece's referendum, which could impact the eurozone's economic stability.

site_title: UK Tories see best chance in 18 years to cut welfare bill
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron's Conservative Party has its best chance in nearly two decades to remake Britain's economy, with their first Budget statement after an election victory set for next week. Finance Minister George Osborne aims to cut the annual welfare bill by £12 billion, aiming for a budget surplus within three years. The budget plan includes a 11% reduction in welfare spending for people under retirement age, sparking concerns about austerity measures.

site_title: Global business growth at five-month low as prices jump: PMI
summary: Global business growth slowed to a five-month low in June, according to a survey, as firms hiked prices at the fastest rate in nine months. The JPMorgan Global All-Industry Output Index fell to 53.1, below the 50 mark that divides growth from contraction. The global PMI, covering the service industry, also fell to 53.5. This marks a decline in global business growth, with prices rising at the highest rate in nine months.

site_title: US airline execs' talk of 'discipline' said to trigger antitrust probe
summary: The US Justice Department is investigating US airline executives for allegedly triggering an antitrust probe with their talk of "discipline" when adding seats on competitive routes. The probe is aimed at determining if the four largest airlines - American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, United Continental Holdings, and Southwest Airlines - are coordinating pricing and capacity through public statements. The investigation seeks e-mails and communications to show the extent of any coordination, with some analysts suggesting the goal is to reduce prices and benefit travelers.

images.alt_text: CONCERN OVER COORDINATION: The Justice Department sued in 2013 to stop US Airways from merging with American Airlines.

site_title: Chinese tycoons lose US$34b as China stock market slumps
summary: Chinese tycoons lost over US$34 billion in combined net worth in June as the Shanghai Composite Index tumbled, with 80% of the 45 wealthy individuals on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index experiencing losses. This marks the worst monthly slump in Chinese stocks in two years. The slump is attributed to various factors, including China's slowing GDP growth and Beijing's consumer lending push.

site_title: Oil heads for biggest weekly drop since March as rig count rises
summary: Oil prices are set for their largest weekly drop since March as US drilling increases, despite concerns of a prolonged surplus. The number of active rigs rose by 12 to 640, extending this week's decline to 5.2%. Oil futures in New York fell for a third day, with West Texas Intermediate for August delivery losing 53 cents to $56.40 a barrel. The US and Iran are negotiating a nuclear deal, which could restore Iran's crude exports, adding to concerns of oversupply.

site_title: Party central
summary: A Singaporean mother, Shi Xiao Wei, has transformed her 1,900 sq ft condominium into a "party central" for her preteen children, Ashley and Brandon. The home features a large 10-seater dining table, converted playroom, and colorful decor, including a mural created with washi tape. The space is designed to encourage creativity and interaction, with the family displaying their artwork, vinyl records, and antique finds throughout the home. The mother, a former marketing executive, has injected her own personality into the space, creating a unique and playful atmosphere that is "unpretentious yet stylish."

site_title: Group calls for robust world climate pact
summary: Thousands of cities, provinces, and states worldwide have urged national governments to finalize a robust, binding climate pact by December. The declaration, made in Lyon, France, calls for equitable and universal cooperation to halt global warming. Cities and states committed to their part in national and international efforts to save the planet, but did not provide details on how to achieve this goal or how much additional funding is needed for local authorities to implement their plans.

site_title: Greek banks have 1 bln euro liquidity: association
summary: Greek banks have a 1 billion euro liquidity cushion, according to the head of Greece's banking association, Louka Katseli. This liquidity will last until Monday, after which it will depend on the European Central Bank's decision. The announcement comes after Greek banks were shuttered for a week due to a government decision to call a referendum on the bailout terms.

site_title: San Francisco creates short-term rental agency
summary: San Francisco Mayor Ed Lee announced the creation of an Office of Short-Term Rental Administration and Enforcement to oversee short-term rentals like Airbnb. The agency will manage rental applications, pursue violators, and protect the city's housing supply and neighborhood character. This move comes after a city committee limited the length of stays for short-term rentals and after Lee signed an ordinance requiring short-term renters to prove residency and pay hotel taxes. The agency will address concerns that short-term rentals may drive up prices for long-term renters.

site_title: Tsipras seeks 30% haircut off Greek debt
summary: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras called for a 30% haircut on Greek debt and a 20-year grace period to ensure debt viability, ahead of a weekend referendum. The IMF analysis showing Greece's debt is unsustainable justifies the government's decision to reject an aid package with no debt relief. Greece was declared in default on Friday, with the EFSF reserving its rights to act on outstanding loans. A "no" vote in the referendum could strengthen Tsipras' position, but European leaders warn it would jeopardize Greece's eurozone membership.

images.alt_text: CLOCK IS TICKING: Stakes were already high before the EFSF announcement, with European Union leaders warning a 'no' in the plebiscite would jeopardise Greece's place in the 19-nation eurozone.

site_title: Noodles strike back
summary: A spate of new noodle shops in Singapore aims to challenge Ramen's dominance in the Japanese-obsessed food scene. These shops, such as Wanton Seng's Noodle Bar, offer alternative noodle options, potentially appealing to consumers looking for variety. While the success of these new shops is uncertain, they may help revitalize the humble noodle's presence in Singapore's food scene, offering a fresh alternative to Ramen's popularity.

site_title: Tech workplaces get makeover for cool vibe
summary: Tech companies in Singapore are investing heavily in creating "cool" office spaces, spending millions to build workplaces that resemble homes rather than traditional cubicle farms. This trend is bolstering the global office furniture market, worth $47 billion. Companies such as Amazon Web Services, Oracle, and Grab are setting up innovation hubs to foster creativity and pride among employees. Research suggests that these modern workspaces inspire innovation and improve employee satisfaction, making them a key aspect of the tech industry's future.

site_title: PM's defamation damages: Written submissions by Aug 31
summary: Singaporean blogger Roy Ngerng broke down in tears in the High Court, claiming persecution for questioning the management of Central Provident Fund (CPF) savings and silencing by the government. Senior Counsel Davinder Singh argued Ngerng was deceitful despite repeated apologies for defaming Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. A written submission deadline for PM Lee's defamation damages is set for August 31.

site_title: Najib: Mahathir behind 1MDB lies
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has accused former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of colluding with foreign parties to create the 1MDB crisis, after Mahathir refused his personal demands. Najib denied allegations that he siphoned funds from 1MDB, citing audited debts and assets. He warned that those who continue to mount attacks against him will face consequences, and accused Mahathir of creating a crisis to topple a democratically elected government. Najib's office cited 1MDB's statement that it never provided funds to him, and accused media outlets of spreading false information.

site_title: Greek chaos brings valuations headache for fund firms
summary: Fund firms with Greek exposure face a headache as the Athens Stock Exchange remains closed due to the country's crisis. Without accurate valuations, managers must estimate share prices, which can lead to mispricing of units. The closure has forced some funds to suspend NAV calculations or use "stale" prices, potentially affecting investors. Industry experts warn that managers may over- or underestimate the impact, highlighting the need for transparent valuation methods.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Friday
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam stated he's not interested in becoming Singapore's prime minister. A new PMI report showed improved business conditions in Singapore in June for the first time in three months. The Ministry of Manpower busted a labor syndicate, arresting 41 individuals. Total launched its largest global lubricant plant in Singapore. Perennial Real Estate Holdings entered a joint venture with a Guangdong medical group to enter the healthcare business in China. Singapore shares rose 0.4% amid bank rally and Greek uncertainty.

images.alt_text: IT'S just a matter of time before Singapore sees a prime minister from a minority race, said Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam on Friday - but it won't be him, as he is not interested in the job.

site_title: Update: Greek PM defends vote, demands 30% debt haircut
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras defended a weekend referendum, demanding creditors forgive 30% of Greece's debt and allow delayed repayments for the rest. Tsipras rejected EU leaders' concerns that the move risks Greece's eurozone or EU membership, stating that rejecting an unsustainable agreement does not mean a break with Europe. The referendum is seen as a bid to reset bailout negotiations and allow Greece to breathe new life into its struggling economy.

site_title: Greek referendum poll shows 'No' vote at 43%, 'Yes' vote at 42.5%
summary: A poll by Public Issue for the Syriza-published newspaper Avgi shows that 43% of Greeks would vote 'No' in Sunday's referendum on bailout terms, a 0.5 percentage-point lead over the 'Yes' vote at 42.5%. The remaining 9% are undecided. The results suggest that opponents of the bailout terms have a slight advantage going into the referendum.

site_title: STI inches up 0.45% as uncertainties loom
summary: The Singapore stock market, represented by the Straits Times Index (STI), rose 0.45% to close at 3,342.73 on Friday, despite uncertainties from the Greece crisis and a selloff in China. The index has traded within a range of 93.36 points over the past four weeks. Investors have been cautious, with a referendum in Greece potentially affecting membership in the eurozone, and China's equity markets continuing to decline despite government efforts. Singapore banks were the key gainers, with DBS Group Holdings and United Overseas Bank rising 2% and 0.4% respectively.

site_title: Europe's still a global disaster area in 21st century
summary: The European Union's economic union, established in 1957, has failed to unite the continent, with weaker economies, such as Greece, facing financial crisis and potential expulsion. The euro, introduced in 2002, has been a power grab, forcing member states to lose control over their economies. As Greece is cast aside, others may follow, and the One Nation concept will be lost. The UK's decision to opt out of the euro and maintain its financial independence has positioned it well for future economic opportunities, with the EU's collapse potentially benefiting investors.

images.alt_text: WARNING FLAGS: The voters are likely to say "non" to the EU next year, which leaves us to pick up some quite nice pieces of European investment when the euro finally collapses.

site_title: Soft US jobs data pin down dollar, euro hostage to Greek vote
summary: The US dollar fell 0.1% against a basket of currencies due to softer-than-expected employment data, with the dollar index retreating from a four-week high. The euro edged up 0.1% to $1.1100, while the Australian dollar hit a 6-year low due to disappointing retail sales data. Investors remain cautious ahead of Greece's referendum on Sunday, which could determine whether the country stays in the eurozone, with analysts expecting limited gains in the euro if a "Yes" vote is successful.

site_title: Europe: Stocks decline second day before Greek austerity vote
summary: European stocks declined for the second consecutive day, posting their worst week of the year, as investors awaited Sunday's Greek referendum on austerity. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index fell 0.5% to 383.42, with shares dropping 3.4% this week. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras called for a "no" vote, while creditors urged a "yes" to secure financial aid. The outcome will determine the path to reform and potential further political upheaval in the euro region.

site_title: Japan welcomes Mekong leaders in jostle for influence
summary: Japan is hosting the seventh annual "Japan-Mekong" summit in Tokyo, welcoming leaders of the "Mekong Five" countries (Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Thailand, and Vietnam) in a bid to boost infrastructure exports and influence in the region. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will meet with his counterparts to discuss cooperation and counterbalance China's growing presence. The summit comes as Japan seeks to expand its economic ties with the region and counter China's increasing influence in Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: LINKING UP: From left: Cambodia's PM Hun Sen, Laos' PM Thongsing Thammavong, Myanmar's President Thein Sein, Thailand's PM Prayut Chan-o-cha and Vietnam's PM Nguen Tan Dung joining hands before an economic forum hosted by the Japan External Trade Organization in Tokyo on July 3.

site_title: Eurozone rescue fund reserves right to call in Greek loans
summary: The European Financial Stability Facility (EFSF) has reserved the right to call in 130.9 billion euros in Greek debt ahead of schedule following Athens' default on an International Monetary Fund loan. This decision was made two days before a Greek referendum on bailout terms rejected by the leftist government. The move could lead to severe consequences for the Greek economy and people if the country votes "No" in the referendum. The EFSF's chief executive, Klaus Regling, described the default as a cause for deep concern, breaking Greece's commitment to honor its financial obligations.

site_title: UBS has whistleblower deal in Brazil currency investigation: paper
summary: UBS has reached a whistleblower deal with Brazilian authorities in an investigation into the suspected rigging of Brazil's currency market. The investigation, involving 15 major banks, was sparked by UBS evidence. UBS will not face punishment, according to a local newspaper report. The deal is part of a broader probe into market manipulation in Brazil's currency market.

site_title: Roy Ngerng not repentant despite apologies to PM Lee Hsien Loong, says Senior Counsel Davinder Singh
summary: Blogger Roy Ngerng, who previously apologized to PM Lee Hsien Loong, remains unrepentant, claiming he's being persecuted for questioning the management of CPF savings. Ngerng broke down in tears, stating he's being silenced by the Government. Despite this, he continues to express his views on the matter.

site_title: Dutch seek UN tribunal to investigate downing of Malaysia plane
summary: The Dutch government is seeking UN support to establish a tribunal to investigate the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17, which killed 298 people, mostly Dutch passengers, in 2014. Prime Minister Mark Rutte believes a UN tribunal would ensure cooperation from all countries in seeking justice for the victims. The move aims to hold those responsible accountable and provide closure for the families of the victims.

site_title: Roy Ngerng breaks down in tears during questioning by Senior Council Davinder Singh
summary: Blogger Roy Ngerng broke down in tears during questioning by Senior Council Davinder Singh, who accused him of using foreign organizations to apply pressure on courts to not award high damages to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. Ngerng had submitted letters from the International Commission of Jurists and Centre for International Law, Philippines, claiming that high damages would be a violation of international human rights laws. The incident occurred during the defamation trial of Ngerng, who has been found guilty of defaming the Prime Minister.

site_title: Flights cancelled, delayed amid work dispute at Toronto Pearson
summary: About 70 flights in and out of Toronto Pearson International Airport have been canceled due to a dispute between airlines and their fueling company, Consolidated Aviation Fueling Toronto. As of 10:05 am, 31 departing flights and almost 40 inbound flights were canceled. The dispute began on Friday morning, with Air Canada flights to Montreal, Ottawa, New York, and Philadelphia being affected. Additional staff have been brought in to work at the airport, and it is unclear how long the disruptions will last.

site_title: Tsipras dismisses Europe's warnings to Greece on vote
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has dismissed European warnings that Greeks will decide on their future in the eurozone in a referendum on Sunday, saying negotiations will continue for a better deal with international creditors. Tsipras rejected the European Commission's and IMF's warnings that a 'No' vote would signal Greece's exit from the eurozone, calling it a "dead end." The referendum, called at short notice, is seen as a vote on whether Greece will accept harsh austerity measures in exchange for a bailout. The outcome is uncertain, with polls showing the 'Yes' and 'No' camps neck-and-neck.

site_title: ECB signals it could loosen bank funding if Greeks vote 'Yes'
summary: European Central Bank Vice President Vitor Constancio signaled that the ECB could loosen bank funding to Greece if Greeks vote 'Yes' in a referendum on Sunday, making it more likely to reach an agreement on providing financial assistance. If Greeks vote 'No', it would be more difficult to reach an agreement, potentially affecting ECB's liquidity provisions. The ECB's policy-setting council would need to analyze the situation and make a decision, with no guarantees of assistance if Greeks reject the aid proposal.

site_title: Uber announces suspension of UberPOP in France
summary: Uber Technologies announced the suspension of its UberPOP ride-hailing service in France due to violent protests and local authorities labeling it as an illegal taxi service. France took two Uber executives into custody, who will face trial in September. This decision follows similar bans in Italy and Germany, highlighting Uber's challenges in Europe.

site_title: Greece declared in default ahead of knife-edge referendum
summary: Greece was officially declared in default on Friday, ahead of a crucial referendum on Sunday. The European Financial Stability Facility announced an event of default by Greece, but decided not to immediately demand repayment of its loans. This move has injected urgency into the referendum, with EU leaders warning a 'No' vote would jeopardize Greece's place in the eurozone. The referendum question has stumped many voters, and polls suggest the outcome is too close to call, with a 'Yes' vote seen as strengthening the government's hand but with difficult negotiations ahead.

site_title: For many Greeks abroad: "transaction cannot be approved"
summary: Thousands of Greeks abroad face financial difficulties due to a 60 euro cap on bank withdrawals imposed last weekend. Many have limited access to their money, leading to long lines at cash machines and failed transactions. Greeks abroad, such as Vassilis, who came to London with limited funds, are struggling to find work and pay bills. The situation is exacerbated by the upcoming referendum, which may impact their ability to return home or access their funds. The Greek government is urging voters to reject the creditors' offer, but many overseas Greeks feel helpless and are relying on friends and family for support.

site_title: IMF debt figures on Greece 'outdated': Dijsselbloem
summary: Eurogroup chief Jeroen Dijsselbloem criticized Greece's finance minister Yanis Varoufakis for saying a debt deal was "in the offing." Dijsselbloem stated that an IMF analysis on Greek debt restructuring was based on "outdated" figures, which predicted EU losses of 53 billion euros. The IMF forecasted Greece would need at least 50 billion euros to stabilize its finances over three years and warned of a potential 36 billion euro bailout from Brussels. Dijsselbloem disputed Varoufakis' claims of ongoing negotiations, calling them "complete wishful thinking."

site_title: ISDN to build mini-hydropower plant with Indonesian district government
summary: ISDN Holdings, a mainboard-listed company, has partnered with the Indonesian district government of Gowa to develop a 9.7 megawatt mini-hydropower plant in South Sulawesi, Indonesia. The project, valued at US$20 million, is expected to take 18-24 months to complete and generate US$5.3 million in annual revenue. The joint venture will be funded through debt and equity financing, with ISDN holding 49% of the stake and the Gowa government holding 20%. The project's completion is subject to obtaining necessary permits and approvals from the local community.

site_title: Fearing return to drachma, some Greeks use bitcoin to dodge capital controls
summary: Greeks are turning to bitcoin as a way to protect their euros from potential devaluation into drachmas. The Greek-based bitcoin exchange, BTCGreece, has seen a surge in new customers depositing at least 50 euros, with deposits quadrupling to around 700 euros. The exchange's founder, Thanos Marinos, reports a 400% increase in new customers between May and June. This move allows Greeks to bypass capital controls and transfer funds easily.

site_title: Greek PM seeks 30% debt haircut, grace period for 20 years
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras demanded a 30% haircut on Greece's debt and a 20-year grace period for the remaining debt, aiming to ensure the country's debt viability. The move comes ahead of a weekend referendum, which Tsipras hopes will strengthen his position in negotiations. Greece's debt currently stands at nearly 180% of its GDP.

site_title: Greek pro-bailout 'Yes' vote in referendum ahead: survey
summary: A survey conducted by the Alco institute indicates that more Greeks (44.8%) plan to vote 'Yes' in favor of accepting the latest bailout proposals, compared to those opting for 'No' (43.4%) and undecided voters (11.8%) ahead of Sunday's referendum.

site_title: China firms fleeing US listings leave bondholders in dark
summary: At least 25 Chinese companies listed in the US are considering going private or have already done so this year, amid speculation they plan to list in China for higher valuations. This trend threatens to worsen transparency and corporate governance for bondholders, who rely on quarterly financial results to assess financial risks. Companies delisting US exchanges no longer have to file financial results, making it harder for investors to gauge borrowers' ability to pay off obligations.

site_title: India central bank, govt in talks to scrap import curbs on gold-silver alloy: sources
summary: The Reserve Bank of India and the finance ministry are in talks to scrap import curbs on a gold-silver alloy used by domestic refiners, known as dore, which accounts for 150 tonnes of imports annually. The move comes months after relaxing curbs on gold imports, which widened the current account deficit in 2013. The RBI wants to remove all restrictions, while the finance ministry is concerned about tax evasion. If the proposal is approved, refineries may no longer need a licence to import dore, potentially preventing tax evasion.

site_title: Japan regulator urges banks to reduce cross-shareholdings
summary: Japan's financial regulator has urged the country's largest banks to reduce their cross-shareholdings, which are equivalent to nearly 50% of their core capital. The heavy exposure to the equity markets poses risks to their capital and undermines accountability and transparency. The regulator's annual report also requires banks to explain the rationale for their cross-shareholdings, as part of a corporate governance code introduced by the government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.

site_title: Australian dollar drops 1.5% to hit 6-year low
summary: The Australian dollar plummeted 1.5% to hit a 6-year low against the US dollar, reaching US$0.7511. This decline was fueled by disappointing retail sales data in Australia and weak data from China's services sector. Investors are also cautious ahead of Greece's referendum on bailout conditions, driving risk-averse behavior and favoring higher-yielding currencies. The Aussie dollar's low is its lowest level since mid-2009, underscoring the economic concerns in Australia and its reliance on China as its largest trading partner.

site_title: Some would exploit Greek 'no' to take apart Europe: Moscovici
summary: EU Commissioner Pierre Moscovici warned that a 'no' vote in Greece's debt bailout referendum on Sunday would send a negative signal, potentially allowing those who seek to dismantle Europe to exploit it. Moscovici, who campaigned for a 'yes' vote, urged Greeks to reject the bailout deal, saying it would be "a negative message to the rest of Europe." A 'no' vote would undermine the EU's efforts to maintain economic stability in the region.

site_title: China says to maintain financial cooperation with Greece
summary: China has reaffirmed its commitment to maintaining financial cooperation with Greece, despite the country's debt crisis. China sees Greece as a key market for its exports to Europe and Africa. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang expressed support for Greece's continued use of the euro and pledged to buy eurozone debt. China has already responded to Greek requests for financial assistance and will continue to promote bilateral cooperation, including in the financial sphere. China's goal is to maintain a united European Union and a strong euro.

site_title: Eurozone businesses shrug off Greek fears; growth reaches four-year high: PMI
summary: Eurozone business activity expanded at its fastest pace in four years in June, driven by a rebound in the service industry and low inflation. The Eurozone composite PMI rose to 54.2, its highest reading since May 2011, as companies cut prices to boost trade. The service industry, which accounts for the bulk of the eurozone economy, saw a 0.2-point increase in activity, while manufacturing activity remained steady. The data suggests second-quarter economic growth of 0.4%, despite concerns over Greece's economic future.

site_title: Greek PM Tsipras says IMF debt report justifies rejection of deal
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said an IMF report justifying Greece's unsustainable debt makes the rejected aid package from creditors unjustified. Tsipras renewed his appeal to Greeks to vote against the package, citing "blackmail and ultimatums" from creditors. The IMF report backs Greece's decision, as it shows the debt is unsustainable under current terms. Tsipras urged Greeks to reject the package on Sunday's referendum, emphasizing the need for a "no" vote.

images.alt_text: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras on Friday said an IMF analysis showing Greece's debt is unsustainable justifies his government's decision to reject an aid package from creditors that offered no debt relief.

site_title: Greece's Varoufakis says debt deal 'in the offing'
summary: Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis stated it's not "too late" for Athens to reach a deal with creditors ahead of Sunday's referendum on bailout terms. He said an agreement is "in the offing," whether the referendum results in a "Yes" or "No." Varoufakis claimed private talks with the European Commission and ECB have continued, and a deal could be reached as early as tomorrow. He believes a "No" vote will lead to a better agreement for Greece and Europe, with a focus on debt restructuring and profiling.

site_title: Iron ore price fall a sign China's economic might waning
summary: Iron ore prices fell to the lowest in over two months, dropping 5% to $55.80 a tonne, amid concerns that China's economic activity is slowing. China's steel consumption peaked faster than expected, with iron ore stocks at 42 ports rising 1.7% to 81.97 million tonnes. Analysts expect lower demand and higher supply to drive prices down to $54 a tonne this year and $52 in 2016, threatening the livelihoods of smaller mining producers.

site_title: Asian currencies to fall slightly with Fed set to raise rates
summary: Emerging Asian currencies are expected to weaken slightly in the months ahead due to anticipated US Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. Asian currencies such as Indonesia, Taiwan, and Singapore are forecast to decline, with the Indonesian rupiah predicted to weaken to 13,800 a dollar, while Taiwan's dollar and Singapore's dollar are expected to fall over 3% and 1% respectively. In contrast, China's yuan is expected to remain relatively strong, with forecasts suggesting it will trade at 6.20 per dollar by the end of the year.

site_title: Miyoshi back in the black in Q3
summary: Miyoshi, an engineering group, reported a net profit of S$777,000 in its third quarter ended May 31, 2015, reversing a net loss of S$520,000 from the previous year. Revenue rose 5.4% to S$13.5 million, driven by higher orders from the photo imaging business. Lower costs and improved productivity contributed to the profit. The group's operating landscape remains challenging, but its focus on cost management and product mix has yielded results. Earnings per share was 0.17 Singapore cents, compared to a loss of 0.12 cents in the previous year.

site_title: Singapore pledges new 2030 greenhouse gas targets to limit climate change
summary: Singapore has set two new environmental targets for 2030, aiming to limit climate change. The country pledges to peak its greenhouse gas emissions at 65 million tonnes of carbon dioxide, equivalent to the current emissions, even if the economy grows. This move aligns with global efforts to curb climate change. The government aims to achieve this goal by 2030, marking a significant step towards reducing its carbon footprint and contributing to a sustainable future.

site_title: China's central bank gives 250b yuan in loans to banks
summary: China's central bank extended 250 billion yuan in loans to 11 financial institutions, ensuring liquidity in the banking system and boosting support for key sectors of the economy. The new loans, with a 6-month maturity and 3.35% interest rate, matured alongside 384.5 billion yuan of existing loans to 14 institutions, with 11 requesting an extension. The move aims to provide adequate liquidity and support economic growth amid slowing GDP growth.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.4% higher on bank rally amid Greek uncertainties
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.4% on Friday, driven by a rally in the banking sector, with DBS Group Holdings up 2%. The Straits Times Index climbed 14.89 points to 3,342.73 amid uncertainty over Greece. About 1.27 billion shares worth S$779 million changed hands, with Federal International being the most actively traded stock. Losers outnumbered gainers 248 to 163, but the market's 5-day rally remains intact ahead of GDP data.

site_title: French private sector grows for fifth month in June: PMI poll
summary: France's private sector experienced its fifth consecutive month of growth in June, according to a PMI poll. The Purchasing Managers Index rose to 53.3, up from 52.0 in May, driven by a faster rise in new business and rising backlogs. The service sector also expanded, with a PMI index of 54.1. This marks a turnaround from the recession in the manufacturing sector, which had been below 50 since April 2014. The growth is attributed to increased confidence and optimism among businesses, with hiring and investment on the rise.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower on Greece caution, NZ outperforms
summary: Australian shares fell 1.1% on Friday, finishing the week with a 0.1% loss, amid investor caution ahead of a Greek referendum that could impact the euro zone. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 1.5% for the week. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,538.3.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close 0.83% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 0.83% on Friday, following a regional sell-off and losses on Wall Street ahead of the Greek bailout referendum. The Hang Seng Index fell 218.21 points to 26,064.11 on HK$148.87 billion in turnover. The decline was in line with global market trends, with European and US stocks also experiencing losses.

site_title: 'This is only our temporary home': Kong Hee on his Sentosa Cove property
summary: City Harvest Church founder Kong Hee revealed that he and his family moved into a Sentosa Cove home after selling properties to pay for legal fees. The 50-year-old pastor posted about this on Facebook in response to a report about his Sentosa Cove home being sold for $10m. Kong Hee's move comes after he had to sell properties to cover legal expenses, leaving his Sentosa Cove home as his only temporary residence.

site_title: German private sector gathers steam, points to modest Q2 growth: PMI
summary: Germany's private sector showed signs of growth in June, with Markit's composite Purchasing Managers' Index reaching 53.7, above the 50 line that divides expansion from contraction for the 26th month. This suggests modest Q2 growth, following a modest Q1 expansion. The improvement was seen in both factories and service providers, indicating a strengthening economy.

images.alt_text: Germany's private sector gained traction in June as growth improved in both factories and service providers, suggesting Europe's largest economy expanded in the second quarter after growing modestly in the first.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.36 points to close at 1,734.24 on Friday, driven by a strong trading session with 1.46 billion lots valued at RM1.39 billion. The market saw 295 gains and 459 losses.

site_title: Thailand's first Mers case to leave hospital
summary: Thailand has declared a 75-year-old Omani man, the country's first Mers case, fully recovered and ready to be discharged from hospital. The man, who was being treated for a heart condition, contracted the virus while in Bangkok. He and three relatives who traveled with him will be allowed to return home after being cleared by medical staff.

site_title: Malaysia PM slams corruption report; says part of political sabotage
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has denied allegations that nearly $700 million was wired to his personal account from the debt-laden state fund 1MDB, calling it a "continuation of political sabotage." The Wall Street Journal reported the alleged transactions, which would be the first direct link to corruption accusations against Najib. His office claims the documents are unsubstantiated and should not be accepted as genuine unless verified. The allegations come as Najib faces opposition pressure over his management of the economy and a high-profile murder scandal.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty, with investors weighing tariffs, sanctions, and market outlooks. In business news, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall. US stocks edged down from records due to tariff threats, and London's Heathrow considered raising airport fees. Additionally, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case, and Singapore ranked as the world's top port for the 12th consecutive year.

site_title: Malaysia PM says reports alleging corruption part of political sabotage
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's office stated that reports alleging corruption involving his personal account and the 1MDB state fund are part of "political sabotage." Najib had approximately $700 million in deposits from 1MDB-linked entities wired into his account, according to a government probe. The office accused certain individuals of undermining the government and attempting to remove a democratically elected prime minister. This comes as Malaysia faces economic challenges and growing pressure on the government.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's ofiice said on Friday that media reports claiming he received money in his personal account from banks, government agencies and companies linked to the 1MDB state fund were a"continuation of political sabotage."

site_title: MOM smashes syndicate involved in illegal importation of labour; 41 arrested
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore has busted a syndicate involved in illegal importation of foreign labor, arresting 41 people, including the alleged mastermind. The syndicate set up shell companies to bring in foreign workers, collecting kickbacks from them. Those found guilty can face fines, imprisonment, or caning. Employers who hire foreign workers for illegal employment can also face significant fines and imprisonment. The operation aims to ensure a level playing field in the employment landscape and protect law-abiding employers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks cast off early losses to slightly higher
summary: Tokyo stocks ended slightly higher on Friday, recovering from early losses after a mixed US jobs report. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.08% to close at 20,539.79, while the Topix index increased 0.23% to finish at 1,652.09. The gains come ahead of Greece's weekend bailout referendum, which could determine its future in the eurozone. Investors are also watching US-EU trade talks, which have been overshadowed by tariff threats.

site_title: Record Singapore fuel oil trades congest port, snarl loadings
summary: Record fuel oil volumes traded in Singapore in June have congested the port, with buyers struggling to load cargoes, leading to delays and rate spikes. The congestion, combined with nearly full land tanks and ships holding tens of millions of barrels, has resulted in at least two companies being temporarily barred from oil pricing assessments. Traders have chartered short-term tankers to store excess oil, with an estimated 10-18 tankers still loaded but unable to find buyers, easing congestion only later in July.

site_title: Japan June PMI shows services sector grows at fastest pace in 9 months
summary: Japan's services sector activity expanded at its fastest pace in 9 months in June, according to a survey, with the Markit/Nikkei Japan Services Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) rising to 51.8. This is the third consecutive month the index has remained above the 50 threshold, indicating expansion. Strong domestic demand, fueled by rising household spending and a robust jobs market, is seen as essential to the Bank of Japan's goal of lifting consumer inflation to 2% by mid-2016.

site_title: Singapore bail-in proposals make senior bond holders breathe easy
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore proposes limiting its statutory bail-in framework to subordinated debt, making senior bondholders less vulnerable to bank failures. This move would turn Singapore into a more investor-friendly nation for senior bank debt. The proposal aims to protect taxpayers and depositors, while also adding another buffer against losses. The changes are part of a set of proposed enhancements to the bank resolution regime, aimed at strengthening the country's banking system.

site_title: New Nikkei Singapore PMI shows improved business conditions in June
summary: The Nikkei Singapore PMI rose to 51.1 in June, up from 49.5 in May, marking the first improvement in three months. This indicates improved business conditions, driven by a sharp expansion in private sector output and new product development. However, client demand remained subdued, and firms remained cautious about hiring policies. The data suggests a stronger rebound in client demand is needed to sustain growth momentum and job creation.

site_title: Bargain-hunting Chinese snap up Tokyo homes in cash deals
summary: Chinese buyers are snapping up Tokyo homes in cash deals, driving up prices to 11% over two years, the highest since the early 1990s. Busloads of Chinese buyers, 40 at a time, are visiting Tokyo and Osaka for three-day property-shopping trips, seeking safe investments abroad. The yen's decline to 22-year lows and excitement over the 2020 Tokyo Olympics have fueled the trend, with thousands of mainland Chinese coming to Tokyo to buy properties. This influx has led to a surge in demand, with some developers imposing quotas on foreign buyers, and prices now outpacing income growth in the city.

site_title: China says multiple currencies can be used in cross-border fund scheme
summary: China has announced a new cross-border fund scheme that allows investments to be denominated in yuan or other currencies, marking a significant departure from existing schemes. The scheme, launched on July 1, enables funds in Hong Kong and China to be sold in each other's markets, with an initial quota of 300 billion yuan. The move is part of China's efforts to liberalize its capital account and internationalize the yuan, which is expected to facilitate more foreign investment and access to overseas markets.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 3.46 points to 1737.23. The trading volume was 33.3 million lots worth RM10.5 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 110 to 57.

site_title: Malaysia state fund 1MDB says it never provided funds to PM Najib
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB state fund has denied providing funds to Prime Minister Najib Razak, following a Wall Street Journal report claiming nearly $700 million was wired into his personal account. 1MDB stated that the company never provided funds to Najib, calling the reports "highly irresponsible" and a "deliberate attempt to undermine" the company. The fund is cooperating with authorities investigating the matter, urging parties to await the outcome of their findings before making further allegations.

site_title: Total unveils its largest global lubricant plant in Singapore
summary: Total, a French oil major, has launched its largest global lubricant plant in Singapore, with a capacity to produce 310,000 tonnes per year. The plant, located at the Tuas Industrial Complex, replaces two existing facilities and will double Total's lubricants production in Singapore, increasing regional capacity by 30%. The facility is part of the Singapore Lube Park, a joint venture with Shell and Sinopec, and aims to capitalize on the growing Asian lubricants market, expected to reach $70 billion by 2020.

site_title: Oil prices drop on rising US rig count, China stock market probe
summary: Oil prices dropped on Friday due to concerns of oversupply and a Chinese stock market probe. US crude futures fell 39 US cents to US$56.54 per barrel, below the US$57-62 price range since early May. The probe into suspected stock market manipulation also affected other commodities.

site_title: Europe: Shares set for biggest weekly drop in two months, Greece in focus
summary: European shares are poised for their biggest weekly drop in two months, with the FTSEurofirst 300 down 0.2% at 1,524.75 points. Tensions between Greece and international creditors are a major concern, with a crucial vote on debt negotiations set for Sunday. Investors are cautious ahead of the vote, which could impact the market's outlook. The market has been affected by mounting tensions since Greece announced a surprise referendum, with some analysts warning of a cautious approach over the weekend.

site_title: China to lift ban on entry of 400,000-tonne ships
summary: China has officially lifted a three-year ban on entry of 400,000-deadweight tonne ships, allowing four domestic ports to receive giant carriers that meet technical standards. The National Development & Reform Commission and Ministry of Transport announced the move, which will enable Brazilian miner Vale's giant vessels to dock at Chinese ports. This decision is seen as a significant relaxation of restrictions, following a ban imposed in 2012.

site_title: 10 more ETFs on SGX gain excluded investment product status
summary: Ten more exchange traded funds (ETFs) at Singapore Exchange (SGX) have been converted to the excluded investment product (EIP) status, bringing the total to 19. The 10 ETFs, issued by Deutsche Asset & Wealth Management, cover countries including Brazil, China, and South Korea. Retail investors can now access these ETFs without pre-qualification, offering greater investment choices. This move aims to promote ETFs as a simple and low-cost way to build diversified portfolios, particularly in uncertain market conditions.

site_title: China: Stocks pare losses as tech CEOs pledge to support shares
summary: Chinese stocks pared losses as tech CEOs pledged to support shares. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.5% before recovering, while the ChiNext gauge of technology companies rose 2.5% after a 33% decline from its June 3 peak. The pledge by at least 28 companies to buy equities or halt new share sales helped stabilize the market.

site_title: Italy service sector growth hits 12-month high in June: PMI
summary: Italy's services sector expanded at its fastest rate in 12 months in June, according to a survey, with the Markit/ADACI Business Activity Index rising to 53.4 from 52.5 in May. This marks the fourth straight month above the 50 mark, indicating growth. However, the sub-index for new work declined to a four-month low of 52.7. The improved services sector data suggests a modest economic recovery could continue in the second quarter, ending three years of recession.

site_title: Malaysia's May exports fall, but less than expected
summary: Malaysia's May exports fell 6.7% from a year earlier, less than expected, due to weak demand for liquefied natural gas, manufactured exports, and lower commodity prices. Shipments to China grew 5.7% driven by higher exports of petroleum products, palm oil, and rubber products. The trade surplus narrowed to 5.51 billion ringgit (US$1.5 billion) in May, following a 6.89 billion ringgit surplus the previous month.

site_title: Google 'campuses' give tech startups room to flourish
summary: Google is building "campuses" worldwide to support tech startups, following its own humble beginnings in a Silicon Valley garage. The fourth campus opened in Madrid, with locations in London, Tel Aviv, and Seoul, offering spaces for startups to meet, work, and learn. Membership is free, with over 55,000 people signed up, and partners provide services such as cafe facilities and mentorship. Google aims to foster entrepreneurship globally, with plans to open campuses in Warsaw and Sao Paulo later this year.

site_title: EU, IMF heap pressure on Greece days ahead of crucial vote
summary: The EU and IMF are pressuring Greece ahead of a crucial referendum on Sunday, warning of the country's perilous finances. The IMF slashed its growth forecast for Greece to zero and warned the country needs an additional 50 billion euros to stabilize its finances over the next three years. Greek leftist leaders are staking their political lives on the outcome, with the referendum determining the country's future in the eurozone. The EU and IMF are urging Greeks to reject the austerity measures proposed by the government, which they claim will worsen the economic crisis.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.38% higher on Friday
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.38% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,340.33, driven by gains despite a US stocks decline due to ongoing debt crisis in Greece. In contrast, Tokyo shares fell 0.22%. The Singapore market saw 68.1 million shares change hands, with gainers slightly outnumbering losers 79 to 64.

site_title: China money rates down on week as central bank acts to shore up market
summary: China's central bank injected 50 billion yuan into the money markets through open market operations, driving down benchmark seven-day repo rates to 2.82% by mid-afternoon Friday, the lowest since mid-May. The 14-day repo rate fell 35 basis points to 3.25%, while the one-day rate rose 20 basis points to 1.14%. The central bank's actions aim to shore up market volatility, following a series of guidance cuts in mid-March and April. Money rates remain low, with the seven-day repo rate below its 200-day moving average of 3.48%.

images.alt_text: Chinese money market rates were down the most on the week since mid-May on Friday, following a net injection of 50 billion yuan (S$10.9 billion) into the money markets through open market operations since Monday.

summary:

site_title: Qantas spends A$90m on bonus for 28,000 after wage freeze
summary: Qantas Airways will pay a A$90 million bonus to its 28,000 employees as part of its profit recovery plan, following an 18-month wage freeze. The one-off payment is equivalent to 5% of annual base salary and reflects the company's bright future. Qantas has made A$875 million in savings and is expected to release annual results on August 20. The bonus payment is a significant gesture, with CEO Alan Joyce citing the dedication and hard work of Qantas staff as key to the company's turnaround.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up 0.19% at open, mainland shares sink
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.19% at open on Friday, despite losses on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index increased 50.64 points to 26,332.96. Mainland Chinese markets, however, declined, with Shanghai's composite index dropping 3.43% to 3,778.71. The recent relaxation of margin trading rules failed to support the mainland markets.

site_title: China's services activity slows to 5-month low, jobs shed: HSBC
summary: China's services sector activity slowed to its lowest in five months in June, with the HSBC/Markit Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 51.8 from 53.5 in May. This indicates a slowdown in expansion, with business activity, new orders, and employment all expanding at slower rates. The sector has been resilient compared to the manufacturing sector, which contracted for the fourth straight month. Economists expect the central bank to ease policy further to support growth, which is seen slowing to around 7 percent in 2015, the weakest annual expansion in a quarter of a century.

site_title: China regulator to probe possible stock market manipulation
summary: China's securities market regulator announced an investigation into suspected market manipulation in the country's stocks, which have slumped around 20% since mid-June. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) established a team to probe market manipulation, particularly across markets, and will send any cases to the police for further investigation. The regulator aims to uncover clues of illegal manipulation.

images.alt_text: China's securities market regulator said it would investigate suspected market manipulation after a slump of around 20 per cent in Chinese stocks since mid-June.

site_title: China: Shares plunge more than 5 per cent
summary: Chinese shares plummeted over 5% on Friday, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 5.02% and the Shenzhen Composite Index diving 5.77%. The declines follow recent weeks of market volatility. The benchmark indices closed at 3,716.41 and 2,087.99 respectively. The plunge is attributed to ongoing market uncertainty, including US-EU trade tensions and concerns about the Chinese economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.22% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.22% lower on Friday, following a mixed US jobs report and a Greek debt crisis referendum. The Nikkei 225 index declined 45.81 points to 20,476.69. US stocks also lost ground, with the Dow Jones shedding 0.16% on Thursday. The US economy added 223,000 jobs in June, but hourly earnings remained flat. Investors await the outcome of the Greek referendum, which could impact the European Union's financial future.

site_title: Greece needs US$40b in fresh euro-area money, IMF says
summary: Greece needs an additional 36 billion euros from euro-area states over the next three years to sustain its finances, according to an IMF analysis. The report suggests that even if Greece delivers on proposed reforms, euro countries will need to provide new financing and ease the nation's debt load. The IMF's total financing needs for Greece are estimated at 50 billion euros from 2015 to 2018, and the organization may be reluctant to disburse new money unless the nation's debt is brought under control.

site_title: Hedge funds see more demand fueled by solid first half returns
summary: Hedge funds are expected to attract billions of dollars in new money in the second half of 2015, with forecasts suggesting up to $14 billion in fresh cash, driven by solid first-half returns. Investors are seeking funds with flexible trading styles to navigate market volatility, including Greece's debt drama and potential interest rate hikes. The average hedge fund has returned 1.27% in the first six months, outperforming the Standard & Poor's 500 index, with some funds delivering even stronger returns, such as Kingdon Capital's 13% gain.

site_title: Foreign investors dump Philippine shares at record speed
summary: Foreign investors dumped Philippine shares at a record speed in the second quarter, with net foreign selling reaching 31.81 billion pesos (S$2.74 billion). This surpassed outflows from major stock markets in Indonesia and Thailand. The selling was driven by disappointing corporate earnings and economic growth below forecasts. Valuations on the Manila broad index soared to 20, making it more expensive than its 10-year average. Despite this, the Philippine Stock Exchange expects investors to re-align their portfolios, with a potential boost from the country's service sector and consumer firms in the run-up to next year's presidential polls.

site_title: Venture capital firms casting a wider net
summary: Venture capital firms are shifting their focus to a broader pool of potential founders, rather than relying on referrals from established entrepreneurs. Data analysis by researchers at the University of California, Berkeley, Haas School of Business found that successful founders are often 38-year-old men with master's degrees and 16 years of work experience. However, this traditional approach may be limiting the potential for innovation. Bloomberg Beta's "Future Founders" program aims to identify and invest in a more diverse group of founders, with promising results, including identifying 20% of potential female founders and 8% of women with technology backgrounds.

site_title: Perennial in JV with Guangdong medical group to enter healthcare business in China
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings, a Singapore-listed company, has entered into a joint venture with Guangdong Boai Medical Group to acquire, develop, and manage healthcare services in China. The JV will focus on eight core medical fields and acquire Modern Hospital Guangzhou, a leading private tumour and cancer hospital. Perennial will fund its 40% stake through internal funds and bank borrowings, with the JV expected to boost its bed capacity and fund future growth plans. The move is part of Perennial's strategic expansion into China's rapidly growing medical and healthcare industry.

site_title: South Korea injects US$20b stimulus into MERS-hit economy
summary: South Korea's government agreed to inject US$20 billion into the economy, which has been impacted by the MERS virus outbreak and sluggish consumption. The 22-trillion-won (S$26.7 billion) stimulus package aims to revitalize the economy and stabilize the livelihoods of ordinary people. The move was made at a cabinet meeting, with Vice Finance Minister Bang Moon-Kyu stating that the package will help those most affected by the MERS fallout.

site_title: Tencent deal throws spotlight on Hong Kong backdoor listings
summary: Tencent's acquisition of loss-making solar-panel maker Mascotte Holdings for US$97 million has raised concerns about the use of "listed shell companies" in Hong Kong to sidestep the bourse's rigorous listing process. The deal, worth 97% of the target company's market capitalization, highlights a booming grey market for these companies. Analysts say the practice allows companies to acquire a listing without going through an IPO, potentially leaving investors in the dark.

site_title: Pop star Prince pulls music from most online streaming services
summary: Prince has removed his music from most online streaming services, including Spotify, citing his publisher's request. The sole service still carrying his music is Tidal, which was re-launched by Jay Z. This move comes after Apple launched a new streaming platform, prompting some artists to reconsider their stance on streaming. Prince's decision follows his previous criticism of the internet and his refusal to stream music, and joins other artists like Taylor Swift and AC/DC in resisting streaming platforms.

site_title: South Korea unveils US$14.3b stimulus package to support economy
summary: South Korea has proposed a US$14.3 billion stimulus package to support its economy, which is facing weak domestic and global demand. The package includes an 11.8 trillion won supplementary budget, new spending plans of 6.2 trillion won, and a 5.6 trillion won tax shortfall cover. The government aims to boost economic growth by 0.3 percentage points, targeting a 3.1% GDP growth this year. The measures are aimed at reviving the economy, which has been hit by the MERS outbreak and a decline in exports.

site_title: Malaysia tells UN Security Council of push for MH17 tribunal
summary: Malaysia has informed the UN Security Council of its intention to push for a UN-backed tribunal to prosecute those suspected of downing Malaysia Airlines flight MH17, which crashed in Ukraine in 2014, killing 298 people. Malaysia, along with Australia, the Netherlands, Belgium, and Ukraine, is seeking a mechanism to deal with criminal accountability. Russia has described the move as premature and may block the proposal, citing the need for further investigations. A joint inquiry led by the Netherlands is already underway, with Russian investigators also involved.

site_title: Facebook tests video ads in budding YouTube challenge
summary: Facebook tests video ads in a "Suggested Videos" feature, recommending clips based on user preferences. The company shares revenue with content creators, with 55% going to those providing the content. The test is part of a larger effort to compete with YouTube, which dominates the video ad market. Facebook's move is seen as a strategic expansion into video advertising, with industry trackers predicting a significant growth in US$7.77 billion spent on video ads in the US this year.

site_title: Yahoo tests using Google-powered search skills
summary: Yahoo is testing a partnership with Google to use its search skills on Yahoo's online properties, aiming to improve user experiences. The test follows a partnership update with Microsoft in April, which allowed more flexibility in searches. Yahoo's CEO Marissa Mayer had previously expressed dissatisfaction with the original 2010 partnership. The move could attract antitrust regulators due to Google's dominant position in the search market, with Google expected to control 54.5% of the global market this year.

site_title: Google apologises after photo app mislabels black couple
summary: Google has apologized for its photo app mislabeling a black couple as "gorillas" in an identification program. The company expressed "appalled" and "genuinely sorry" for the incident, which occurred on July 2, 2015.

site_title: Hotels in San Francisco are the priciest in the world
summary: San Francisco has become the world's most expensive city for hotel stays, with the average price of a hotel room jumping 88% to $397 per night, according to a Bloomberg index. This surpasses cities like Geneva and Milan, and ties with Chicago and Miami as the second-costliest US cities. This new distinction adds to the city's reputation as a pricey place for apartment renters and office space, solidifying its position as one of the most expensive US cities.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as Greek debt saga drags on
summary: US stocks declined in the week ending July 3, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1.21% to 17,730.11, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index losing 1.18% and 1.40%, respectively. The decline was driven by concerns over a potential Greek debt default, which overshadowed solid US economic data, including a mixed June jobs report and a rise in consumer confidence. Analysts predict a volatile market if Greece votes "no" in a referendum on creditors' reform plans on Sunday.

site_title: Despite Fitch upgrade, Malaysia still has a lot of hassles to resolve
summary: Fitch Ratings upgraded Malaysia's debt outlook from negative to stable, citing improving fiscal finances and favorable growth rates. Despite the positive news, Malaysia still faces significant challenges, including the 1MDB scandal, shrinking exports, and a growing household debt-to-GDP ratio. The country's economy is also vulnerable to global growth fragility and sudden capital flight. The Fitch upgrade provides a comfort window for reforms, but the Malaysian government must address its socioeconomic and political woes, including governance and accountability issues, to move forward.

images.alt_text: The heavy feeling in the air that has dogged Malaysia this year due to a confluence of internal and external factors was briefly supplanted by great relief on Wednesday when Fitch Ratings did not (as widely expected) downgrade the country's debt rating; instead, it upgraded its outlook from negative to stable.

site_title: Asia bankers not reaping fees from region's M&As
summary: Asian investment bankers are facing a decline in fees from cross-border mergers and acquisitions (M&As), despite a record-breaking US$552 billion in acquisitions involving Asia-Pacific companies excluding Japan in the first half of the year. The proportion of cross-border deals accounted for 42% of the region's deal volume, the lowest since 2004. Boutique firms are expanding in the region, threatening the bulge-bracket banks, which rely on these transactions for higher fees. The slowdown is attributed to China's focus on domestic consolidation and restructuring, and increased competition from boutique firms.

site_title: BBC plans to cut over 1,000 jobs
summary: The BBC plans to cut over 1,000 jobs as part of a long-term drive to reduce costs due to changing viewing habits and a decline in licence fee income. The cuts will be mostly in management, with a focus on simplifying support services and reducing costs by £50 million.
