The move aims to help the broadcaster meet financial challenges and deliver outstanding programmes and content. Director General Tony Hall stated that a "simpler, leaner" BBC is necessary, despite the tough choices.

site_title: OCBC favours palm over gold, copper
summary: OCBC analyst Barnabas Gan forecasts that palm oil prices will rise in the second half due to potential supply disruptions from the El Nino weather pattern, which could affect weather and harvests worldwide. Gold prices are expected to fall to US$1,050 an ounce due to higher US borrowing costs strengthening the dollar. Copper prices may slump about 5% to US$5,500 a tonne due to ample inventories. This year's El Nino poses a risk to the global economy, potentially harming crops and boosting inflation.

site_title: Wage stagnation dampens June job creation
summary: The US labor market experienced a mixed outcome in June, with 223,000 jobs added despite stagnant wages. The unemployment rate fell to a seven-year low of 5.3%, while the labor force participation rate decreased to 62.6%. Average hourly earnings remained unchanged at $24.95, and revisions to prior reports subtracted 60,000 jobs from payrolls. The job market is considered solid, but wage growth remains weak, consistent with the Federal Reserve's projected timetable to raise borrowing costs by year-end.

site_title: Chinese tycoons lose US$34b as China stock market slumps
summary: Chinese billionaires lost a combined US$34 billion in June due to the worst monthly slump in Chinese stocks in two years. The Shanghai Composite Index tumbled, wiping away fortunes of 80% of the 45 wealthy individuals on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. Notable losses included Zhang Lu's US$4.8 billion and Wang Jing's US$3.6 billion. In contrast, some billionaires like Richard Liu and Robin Li saw minimal changes in their net worth. The decline was attributed to the instability of the Chinese stock market.

site_title: BP reaches US$18.7b settlement over deadly 2010 spill
summary: BP has agreed to pay up to $18.7 billion to the US government and five states to resolve claims from its 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill. The settlement, which covers Clean Water Act fines and natural resource damages, avoids further litigation and will be paid over 18 years. The deal brings the total BP's pre-tax charge for the spill to $53.8 billion. The agreement resolves the largest liabilities remaining from the disaster, which killed 11 workers and spilled millions of barrels of oil onto US shorelines.

site_title: Reit rule changes seen as 'balanced' and less severe than expected
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has released rule changes for real estate investment trusts (Reits), seen as a balanced approach between boosting corporate governance and operational flexibility. The changes include a single-tier leverage limit of 45% and a higher development limit of 25% of deposited property. MAS has also imposed a statutory duty on Reit managers to prioritize unitholders' interests and improved independence of the manager's board of directors. However, on performance fees, MAS opted for transparency rather than prescriptive guidelines, allowing the market to decide.

site_title: AIIB set to open for business this year
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) is set to open for business by the end of this year after its Articles of Agreement were endorsed by 50 founding member countries. China will have 26% voting shares and 30% capital stock, followed by India with 7.51% voting shares and 8.5% capital stock. Russia's prominent position in the AIIB reflects its strategic convergence with China and its efforts to boost diplomatic and economic ties with Asia. The bank's mission is to foster sustainable economic development in Asia by investing in infrastructure and promoting regional cooperation.

site_title: Guillem headlines da:ns fest
summary: Legendary French ballerina Sylvie Guillem will perform at the Esplanade in Singapore on Oct 13 and 14 as part of the 10th annual da:ns festival, marking her farewell tour before retiring from dance at 50. The program will feature new works by Akram Khan and Russell Maliphant, alongside older pieces by Mats Ek and William Forsythe. This marks an extraordinary feat considering most ballerinas retire at 40 due to physical demands of dance. Guillem's performance is part of a "best of" collection of artists who have performed at the Esplanade before, celebrating the festival's 10th anniversary.

site_title: Beirut's largest green space off-limits to Lebanese
summary: Beirut's largest green space, Horsh Beirut, has been off-limits to locals for 20 years due to concerns over visitor management. The park, which accounts for two-thirds of Beirut's green space, requires permits from the city's governor and has restrictions on access for Lebanese residents. Activists claim the restrictions are enforced more strictly for locals than for foreigners, and the park's lack of resources and infrastructure makes it unsuitable for large crowds. The municipality plans to launch a tender for private management and security, but activists argue the city has the means to maintain the park.

site_title: Streets become public spaces under new URA initiative
summary: Singapore's Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched the "Streets for People" programme, aiming to transform streets and back lanes into temporary public spaces. The initiative supports community-initiated car-free zones, providing road closure essentials and up to S$5,000 of seed funding. Since its launch, car-free zones at various locations have seen success, including increased vibrancy and improved personal safety. The programme encourages community involvement and promotes a car-free environment, reflecting public appreciation for reduced car usage in land-scarce Singapore.

site_title: US antitrust officials probe airlines for price fixing
summary: US antitrust officials are investigating whether airlines are colluding to maintain pricing power amid a drop in airfares and a surge in seating. The Justice Department seeks documents on capacity reductions or growth limitations, citing a link between fares and capacity. Despite a 2% increase in domestic seating in 2014, carriers are adding capacity at a 5% clip, and average domestic coach fares have fallen 4.9% through May. Analysts argue that airlines have done too little to curb seat supply, and the investigation may be puzzling given the airlines' recent efforts to rein in capacity.

site_title: Dyson looks to hire 100 new engineers in Singapore
summary: Dyson Ltd plans to recruit 100 engineers in Singapore annually for four years to meet its growth plans and global demand for its unique technology, including bagless vacuum cleaners and bladeless fans. The company sees Singapore as a critical engineering development base, where it manufactures digital motors for its cordless products. Dyson aims to increase its production of digital motors from 4 million to 11 million units by the end of 2015, and is investing S$100 million in its Tuas manufacturing plant.

site_title: Becoming Mrs LKY
summary: Actress Sharon Au, playing Madam Kwa, the wife of Singapore's founding father Lee Kuan Yew, is preparing for the musical "The LKY Musical." Au has been taking pronunciation lessons to perfect her accent and has been working on her acting skills, despite critics questioning her ability to portray the intelligent and unassuming Madam Kwa. Au, who has survived the entertainment industry's cutthroat world, is determined to do justice to the role and make her family proud. The musical, directed by Steven Dexter, tells the story of Mr. Lee's early life and concludes with Singapore's Independence.

site_title: German court rules YouTube not liable for policing copyright
summary: A German court has ruled that YouTube is not liable for policing copyright, but must take measures to prevent future infringements. The court rejected an appeal by the German performing rights association Gema, stating that YouTube should block copyright-infringing videos upon notification. However, the court also found that YouTube had failed to act promptly enough in 7 out of 12 cases, and had no duty to remove videos in 5 cases. YouTube plans to review the ruling and may appeal certain aspects, while Gema is considering further action.

site_title: 1MDB claims it has hand in Fitch's upgrade of KL's outlook
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB has been credited with helping secure Fitch Ratings' affirmation of the country's long-term foreign currency A-rating with a stable outlook. 1MDB's president, Arul Kanda, stated that the company discussed its debt reduction plans and provided assurance to Fitch, which was instrumental in the sovereign's credit rating upgrade. Despite concerns over ballooning government debt and contingent liabilities, Fitch praised the implementation of the Goods & Services Tax and the termination of fuel subsidies as key fiscal reform measures.

site_title: US$ strengthens, Swedish unit falls on rate cut
summary: Sweden's central bank cut interest rates deeper into negative territory, citing risks from Greece, causing the Swedish crown to drop 1% against the euro and US dollar. The US dollar rose to a three-week high against a basket of major currencies, boosted by upcoming US data potentially leading to interest rate hikes. The euro ticked higher in Asia following a positive US jobs report, while the US dollar strengthened against other Asia-Pacific currencies.

site_title: Food prices set to decline but market risks to rise: OECD and FAO
summary: A joint report from the OECD and FAO forecasts a gradual decline in food prices over the next decade due to lower oil prices and strong crop yields. However, the report warns that market risks will rise due to the increasing dependence on a small group of global suppliers, particularly in dairy products and other commodities. Prices are expected to remain above those in the early 2000s, and governments are advised to develop policies to boost productivity and manage risk.

images.alt_text: Mr Gurria cautioned against complacency, saying "we cannot rule out the risk of new price spikes in the coming years".

site_title: Getting crafty
summary: Singapore's craft beer market is growing, driven by increasing demand for artisanal brews. Distributors are stocking or importing craft beers, and bars are offering a wider range of options. Craft beer drinkers prefer beers with better flavors, structures, and bodies. The global trend is catching up, with Western countries like the US and UK experiencing a surge in craft beer popularity. However, it's unlikely to overtake traditional beer in popularity, with mainstream beer still dominating the market. Local breweries like Little Island Brewing Co and 1925 Microbrewery are emerging, offering unique and exciting options, and home-brewing may become more common, leading to the production of "made-in-Singapore" beers.

site_title: Singapore needs younger leader for the longer haul: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed his desire to step down after a decade in office, citing the need for a younger leader to connect with the younger population and fight for their interests. He acknowledged Singapore's paranoia about maintaining its success, but emphasized the importance of having a government that benefits all citizens. Lee also warned of the dangers of a fractured political system and the need for a balance between respecting authority and giving people a voice.

images.alt_text: While Mr Lee acknowledged that Singapore is "paranoid" and "worries all the time" about the possibility of losing its success, he said such paranoia is necessary.

site_title: Toyota's first female executive resigns
summary: Toyota's first female executive, Julie Hamp, a 55-year-old American, resigned after just 90 days following her arrest for allegedly importing prescription painkillers in Japan. Her resignation is a setback for President Akio Toyoda's efforts to diversify management ranks and for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's goal of increasing female representation in leadership roles. Hamp's arrest and treatment by police and media have sent a chilling message to other foreign managers considering postings in Japan, highlighting the challenges of integrating outsiders into traditional Japanese management culture.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a summary of the article in 100 words or less:

Keong Hong Holdings subsidiary clinched a S$163.38 million contract to build 11 residential blocks in Singapore. SIIC Environment subsidiary secured a 63.8 million yuan project in China to build and operate a wastewater treatment plant. Sincap Group acquired Orion Energy Resources for S$7.2 million to expand its resource trading business. Geo Energy entered a sales contract to supply 1.5 million tonnes of coal to BTG Pactual in Singapore. Evergrande Real Estate Group applied to list its Alibaba-backed soccer club and entertainment group on the New Third Board to raise cash and pay debts.

site_title: Singapore June PMI up, but manufacturing recovery still uncertain
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector showed a modest expansion in June, with a PMI reading of 50.4, driven by increases in new orders, production, and inventory. However, the recovery remains uncertain due to regional contraction and external demand uncertainty. Despite this, the electronics sector, which had been in contraction, returned to growth with a 50.3 reading. Economists caution that the expansion may not be sustainable, citing the poor performance of regional PMIs and ongoing uncertainty over external demand.

site_title: US property and casualty insurer in US$28b bid for Chubb
summary: Ace Ltd, a US property and casualty insurer, announced a US$28 billion deal to acquire Chubb Corp. The acquisition is the largest in the industry since the 2008 US government bailout of American International Group Inc. Insurers are expected to drive "M&A fever" across the industry, with analysts noting that the scale gained through acquisitions is crucial for insurance providers amid increased competition. The deal values Chubb at about 1.7 times book value, a discount to typical industry valuations, and may embolden other competitors to consider acquisitions.

site_title: Call for guidelines on insurance commission rebates
summary: The Association of Financial Advisers (Singapore) has urged regulators to establish guidelines for commission rebates in life insurance policies to ensure their implementation is ethical and proper. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has agreed to work with the industry and other stakeholders to provide guidance on the use of rebates, where necessary. The MAS has also introduced new regulations under the Financial Advisory Industry Review (FAIR) to improve the remuneration structure of financial advisory firms, including the introduction of a balanced scorecard remuneration framework and the capping of first-year commissions.

site_title: Tsipras is crumbling
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is facing intense pressure from creditors as he struggles to negotiate a new bailout deal. After defaulting to the International Monetary Fund, Tsipras proposed a cash-for-reforms deal but was rejected by the eurozone. The European Central Bank has refused to supply more liquidity to banks, leading to capital controls and a referendum on the proposal. If Greeks vote "Yes" in the referendum, eurozone authorities may find ways to meet commitments, but a solution is unlikely to be straightforward due to Greece's complex politics and the creditors' skepticism of Tsipras' radical left party.

site_title: Ascott Reit buys New York hotel for US$163.5m
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (Ascott Reit) acquired a 411-room hotel in New York's Times Square for US$163.5 million. The Element New York Times Square West hotel has an Ebitda yield of 6.2% and is expected to increase Ascott Reit's distribution income in FY2014 by US$0.8 million. This marks Ascott Reit's entry into the US market, expanding its presence in Asia-Pacific and Europe.

site_title: Asian nations move up income ladder in World Bank ranking
summary: Asian nations, including Bangladesh, Myanmar, and Tajikistan, have moved up the World Bank's global rankings, with per capita Gross National Income (GNI) increasing. These countries now have incomes between $1,046 and $4,125, joining lower-middle-income countries. In contrast, countries like Malawi remain in the "low-income" category, while Norway's per capita income has more than doubled over 25 years, reflecting the significant gap between the poorest and richest nations.

site_title: A tribute to the 'little people' who built Singapore
summary: Artist May Oon urges Singaporeans to be more compassionate towards foreign laborers, who built the country's infrastructure. Despite the majority of Singaporeans being low-paid workers, they are often stigmatized. Oon calls for a more gracious attitude towards migrant workers who help improve the country's way of living. She suggests that Singaporeans should appreciate the contributions of these workers, rather than complaining about their presence.

site_title: Ted's not funny anymore
summary: Seth MacFarlane's sequel to Ted (2012) has received negative reviews, with many considering it a rehash of the original's crude humor and lack of cleverness. The film, Ted 2, follows the teddy bear and its owner, John Bennett, as they sue the state for personhood after discovering that stuffed toys don't have the same rights as people. Despite its attempts to tackle social issues, the movie is deemed a commercial failure, with critics labeling it an "abysmal" and "insensitive" comedy. The film's rating is a disappointing C.

site_title: Is there life after making music for the movies?
summary: Mumford & Sons' third album "Wilder Mind" has received critical acclaim, with a powerful mix of pop, rock, and folk influences. The album showcases the band's emotional range and tight sound, with standout tracks like "Believe" and "Monster." In contrast, Passion Pit's "Kindred" fails to recapture the magic of their previous work, with quirky but unmemorable songs. Danish indie band Mew's sixth album "+-" returns to their tight, catchy sound, with abstract lyrics and a live disc included in the deluxe version.

site_title: Tesco seeks fresh start with suppliers who survive cull
summary: Tesco is seeking new deals with suppliers who will survive a cull of thousands of products from its shelves. The supermarket chain aims to secure better deals with fewer partners on best-selling items, providing suppliers with more income clarity, increased shelf space, and potentially higher sales volumes. The plan is part of Tesco's efforts to rebuild trust with suppliers after a £263 million accounting scandal last year. Suppliers of popular brands, such as Premier Foods and AB Foods, are expected to benefit from the new agreements, while those that miss out may face reduced income.

site_title: Rihanna is recording industry's top digital singles artist
summary: Rihanna has become the first artist to surpass 100 million cumulative digital singles, according to the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA). The 27-year-old singer has topped the list of artists with the most digital singles, ahead of Taylor Swift and Katy Perry. This historic feat marks a testament to her extraordinary career, with eight Grammy awards and seven studio albums to her name.

site_title: Stocks finish mixed in quiet trading
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed 3.3 points weaker at 3,327.84, with weak trading volume and a mix of factors cited as reasons, including uncertainty over Greece's referendum and volatility in China's stock market. China's Shanghai Composite lost 3.5% and Bank of America-Merrill Lynch predicts it could fall to 2,500 before large-scale margin calls. Despite this, contagion risks appear low due to reduced private sector and foreign bank exposure to Greek debt.

images.alt_text: A new day, another nondescript session. The Straits Times Index on Thursday displayed all the verve of a patient on life support, finishing a coma-inducing session a nett 3.3 points weaker at 3,327.84.

site_title: China Fibretech on roller-coaster ride after consolidation
summary: China Fibretech's shares have experienced volatile trading after a 50-into-one consolidation in May to meet the Singapore Exchange's minimum trading price (MTP) of S$0.20. The stock initially opened at S$1.63 but plummeted 27% to S$1.18 on July 1, prompting a "Trade With Caution" from the exchange. Dealers blame the consolidation for increasing volatility, saying it's "ironic" that the goal was to reduce volatility. The company's share price closed at S$1.195, a net gain of S$0.015.

site_title: China relaxes margin rules as share prices fall
summary: China's securities regulator has relaxed margin trading rules, removing limits on investors' minimum deposit requirements. The move aims to stabilize the market after recent heavy falls in Chinese shares. Margin investors can now deposit a smaller proportion of their trades, generating bigger profits but also bigger losses. The regulator also relaxed rules for brokerages, allowing them to lend more to clients for longer. Despite the changes, markets remained volatile, with the Shanghai Composite Index dropping 1.83% on Thursday morning.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while stocks in Europe and the UK were also down due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. In other news, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, and Creative Technology warned of potentially lower H2 revenue and operating loss. Meanwhile, London's Heathrow Airport is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained an employee of Trafigura in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: India's US$100b solar push draws foreign firms as locals take backseat
summary: India's $100 billion push into solar energy over the next decade will be driven by foreign players, not local manufacturers, due to their outdated technology and inability to compete on cost. Foreign companies like Trina Solar and Softbank are investing heavily in the sector, with plans to build massive solar plants. Local firms, such as Indosolar and Moser Baer, will struggle to compete, with some looking to partner with foreign companies to access latest technology. The Indian government has dropped restrictions on equipment imports, allowing foreign players to dominate the market.

site_title: MapletreeLog: Australia a potential core market
summary: MAPLETREE Logistics Trust is acquiring Coles Chilled Distribution Centre in Sydney for A$253 million, with a 19-year lease and annual rent increments. The acquisition is seen as a springboard for further expansion into Australia, with CEO Ng Kiat stating that Australia could become a new core market for the trust. The purchase will increase MLT's portfolio weighted average lease expiry and extend its weighted average lease expiry from 4.2 years to 4.5 years.

site_title: Changing history, one trauma at a time
summary: A Singaporean theatre company, Teatro La Re-sentida, staged "The Imagination Of The Future," a play that reimagines Chile's 1973 coup d'état, where President Salvador Allende's call to the US president was censored. The play takes place in a TV station, depicting Allende's final speech as a hip-hop video, and explores the distortion of history under military dictatorship. The production was deemed controversial, with three scenes censored, but the cast's energy and the actor's personal experience under Gen Pinochet's regime added to the play's potency, mourning the loss of optimism and freedom.

site_title: John Lewis to charge for click & collect
summary: John Lewis, Britain's largest department store group, will begin charging a £2 fee for online orders under £30 for click & collect service starting July 28. The move aims to ensure the service is sustainable amid unprecedented growth. The retailer processes over 6 million click & collect orders annually, causing logistical headaches. Analysts predict other retailers may follow suit, citing the service's popularity and weight in the market.

site_title: Muscling in on the action
summary: Singapore Pro Wrestling (SPW) has become the city's premier training center for aspiring professional wrestlers. Founded by Andreuw Tang in 2012, the club now has 25 members, including working professionals who make up 75% of its members. Tang's training sessions focus on physical conditioning and bodyweight exercises, with members able to debut in the ring within 4-6 months. Unlike WWE, SPW emphasizes American-style wrestling and does not teach acting skills, instead relying on individuals to develop their own showmanship. With thousands of fans worldwide, SPW's founder, Andreuw Tang, aims to change the perception of professional wrestling as fake, highlighting the physicality and nuance of the sport.

site_title: Thailand cuts forecast for 2015 rice output by over 2m tonnes
summary: Thailand has lowered its forecast for 2015 rice output by over 2 million tonnes due to severe drought. The country now expects to produce 24.135 million tonnes, down from a previous forecast of 26.576 million tonnes. This drop could impact benchmark Thai rice prices, which are near their lowest since January 2008. Thailand has accumulated around 15.4 million tonnes of rice in storage and plans to sell 5.89 million tonnes to the industrial sector starting in July to address the surplus.

site_title: CBRE sees business park space crunch post-2016
summary: CBRE predicts a business park space crunch post-2016 due to no new developments planned. The current Q2 vacancy rate is 9.1%, down from 10.4% in Q1, driven by pharmaceutical and tech firms. With 60% of future business park space already taken up, occupiers have limited options for quality space. CBRE suggests the government should allocate land for private developers to build more multi-user projects and provide a supply of future business park space through land sales programs.

site_title: Citigroup, HSBC among banks named in new Brazil currency probe
summary: Brazil's antitrust agency, Cade, is investigating Citigroup, HSBC, and 12 other banks for alleged currency manipulation and price-fixing practices in the Brazilian foreign-exchange market. The investigation found strong signs of anticompetitive behavior, including coordinated transactions and blocked competitors. This is similar to probes in the US and Europe, which reached multibillion-dollar settlements, including guilty pleas by Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase. The accused banks have 30 days to respond, and 30 individuals are also being probed in the investigation, which spanned from 2007 to 2013.

site_title: An intriguing character sidelined - for love story
summary: Beneath the biographical focus, "Paradise Lost" prioritizes a love story between Canadian surfer Nick and Escobar's niece Maria, sidelining the charismatic performance of Benicio del Toro as the notorious drug lord Pablo Escobar. The film, directed by Andrea Di Stefano, explores the relationship between Nick and Maria as Escobar's plan unfolds, showcasing del Toro's portrayal of the anti-hero as a complex, dark character. Despite this, the film's focus on the romance detracts from its potential as a biopic about Escobar.

site_title: Investors hedging against Greece, but there's no panic
summary: Global investors have hedged against a potential Greek exit from the eurozone ahead of Sunday's referendum, but there's no panic in financial markets. Investors are trimming exposure in the eurozone, but expect a last-minute deal to be struck and a chance to buy back eurozone assets. The Greek government, led by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, is fiercely campaigning for a "No" vote, believing it will strengthen its hand in negotiations with creditors. Despite increased hedging in currency and equities, investors remain cautious, with no sense of panic, according to market participants.

site_title: Asia-Pac passenger traffic leaps 10% in May
summary: Asia-Pacific passenger traffic rose 10% year-over-year in May, outpacing global growth, with load factor reaching 77%. Despite a 7.5% increase in capacity, airlines maintained a 79.3% load factor. International markets saw a 7.1% increase in passenger traffic, while European carriers expanded 5.9% and Middle Eastern carriers grew 14%. African carriers reported a 3.9% decline due to economic downturns. Strong demand in India and China drove domestic growth, while Brazil's growth was 0.8% and Australia's declined 1.3%. IATA chief Tony Tyler warned of potential storm clouds on the horizon.

site_title: H1 Asia-Pac syndicated loans down 15%
summary: Asia-Pacific syndicated loans fell 15% in the first half of 2015 to US$214 billion, mainly due to weaker activity in Hong Kong, Australia, and Singapore. The number of transactions closed at 608, down from 870 last year. This slowdown was reflected in a decrease in volume.

site_title: US factory orders fall more than expected on transportation
summary: US factory orders fell 1.0% in May, exceeding expectations, due to weak demand for transportation and electrical equipment. This marks the ninth consecutive month of decline, with factory orders dropping 0.7% in April. Despite a stabilization in the sector, manufacturing remains mired in a soft patch, affected by a strong dollar and lower crude oil prices. A recent report showed the Institute for Supply Management's national factory activity index rose to a five-month high in June, indicating signs of stabilization.

site_title: Cash buyers pull back from US housing market
summary: US home purchases made with cash have fallen to a five-year low, with fewer than 25% of single-family home and condominium purchases being all-cash transactions in May. The share of acquisitions by institutional investors has also declined, reaching a 15-year low. The US housing market is recovering, with contracts to purchase previously owned homes rising to a nine-year high. Investors are pulling back due to rising prices, which have priced them out of the market, and a shrinking distressed market.

site_title: SGX stock pulls back as MAS issues 'trade with caution'
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) issued a "trade with caution" on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) stock on July 2, 2015, in response to an unexplained surge in its share price. The MAS stated that shareholders and investors should exercise caution when dealing with SGX's securities due to potential market disruption. The share price slipped 1.22% in response, but remained up 30 cents from two days ago. Analysts attributed the surge to institutional interest and a safe-haven asset, with some questioning the MAS's move, especially for a blue-chip stock like SGX.

site_title: Government to unveil enhanced SingPass system on Sunday
summary: The Singapore government will launch an enhanced SingPass system on Sunday, featuring improved user experience, mobile-friendly features, and two-factor authentication for enhanced security. The new system will include features such as SMS or e-mail notifications for profile changes, a two-step verification process, and the ability to customize the SingPass ID. Users will have a one-year grace period to set up two-step verification, with all transactions requiring it after July 5, 2016. The government will also conduct system testing and provide education and support for users.

site_title: UOB, OCBC make strides in Myanmar amid branch openings
summary: United Overseas Bank Group (UOB) and OCBC Bank have officially opened their branches in Yangon, Myanmar, amid growing investments. UOB expects US$300 million in investments from its clients over the next 12 months, mainly for factories, hotels, and commercial properties. OCBC Bank signed memoranda of understanding with 10 Myanmar banks to collaborate on training and capability-building. Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean attended the openings, highlighting Singapore's significant investments in the country.

site_title: IMF warns Greece needs debt extension, may require writedown
summary: The International Monetary Fund warned Greece needs an extension of its European Union loans and a large debt writeoff if the country grows slowly and economic reforms are not implemented. The IMF, part of the "troika" overseeing the bailout, said even if Greek policies come back on track, loans will need to be extended significantly and further concessional financing will be required. Greece is set to vote on a bailout deal on Sunday, with Prime Minister Alexis Tsipiras urging voters to reject it.

site_title: JES uncovers possible financial irregularities related to ex-CEO
summary: JES International, a Singapore-based Chinese shipbuilder, has uncovered possible financial irregularities related to its former CEO, Jin Xin. Unauthorized payments may have been made to Jin, and "questionable" transactions occurred between the group and companies with undeclared interests. Jin's relatives removed the company's financial records, leaving the group unable to conduct a thorough investigation. JES has started legal proceedings against a former employee and plans to engage an independent auditor to review its financials. The company also vowed to take action against Jin if the irregularities are attributed to him.

site_title: Singapore's paranoia is necessary: Lee Hsien Loong
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong acknowledged the country's "paranoid" nature, stating that constant worry about losing its accomplishments is "necessary." He expressed gratitude for the country's achievements, including its high standard of living, education, and healthcare. Lee also announced his preference to step down as Prime Minister in the next decade, citing the need for a younger leader to connect with the younger population and drive long-term change.

site_title: Performances that help to start a conversation
summary: A UK theatre company, Mind the Gap, will perform in Singapore as part of the Forum Theatre Festival, a first for the city-state. The festival features performances by international groups addressing social issues such as contract employment and child brides. The event also includes interactive role-playing and a newly-commissioned inflatable theatre, GoLi, designed to be a "moveable" space for community discussions. The festival aims to engage non-traditional theatre-goers and promote social change through the Theatre of the Oppressed model.

site_title: Romance in a different time
summary: A film adaptation of Thomas Hardy's 1874 novel "Far From the Madding Crowd" tells the story of Bathsheba Everdene, a headstrong and independent young woman in Victorian England. Bathsheba is pursued by three men, including Gabriel Oak, William Boldwood, and Francis Troy, but ultimately marries Troy, who has an unrequited love for another woman. The film features a fresh-faced charm from Carey Mulligan as Bathsheba and a standout performance from Michael Sheen as the obsessive Boldwood. The movie takes a lighthearted approach to the classic novel, with a rating of B-.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets close mixed
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed mixed on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.33% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 0.73%. The US jobs report showed 223,000 jobs added in June, beating expectations but with stagnant wage growth and a rise in unemployment claims. The euro rose to $1.1101 amid the mixed market. Greece's referendum on its bailout looms, with markets awaiting the outcome, which could determine the country's financial future and its place in the eurozone.

site_title: Nature's potent effect on the 2003 vintage
summary: A 2003 European heatwave and drought significantly impacted wine production, resulting in reduced yields, high sugar levels, and low acidity. However, the resulting wines are proving to be of high quality. The author reflects on the heatwave, recalling the summer of 2003, and notes that wine quality is ultimately determined by the people involved, particularly the growers and those who drink the wine with others.

site_title: Update: BP settles 2010 US oil spill claims for US$18.7b
summary: BP Plc has reached a $18.7 billion settlement with the US government and five states, effectively ending years of litigation over the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill. The settlement covers Clean Water Act fines and natural resources damages, with $6.8 billion going to states. The agreement resolves BP's largest liabilities from the disaster, with CEO Bob Dudley calling it a "realistic outcome" providing clarity and certainty for all parties. The settlement includes claims from 400 local government entities and covers environmental damage and human casualties caused by the spill.

site_title: US: Wall Street stocks rise as US adds 223,000 jobs
summary: US stocks rose moderately in opening trade on Thursday after the Labor Department reported the US economy added 223,000 jobs in June. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 0.20% to 17,792.75, while the S&P 500 rose 0.26% to 2,082.78. Despite the strong jobs number, average hourly earnings were flat and the Labor Department cut its estimates for job growth in April and May. Analysts believe the report keeps the US Federal Reserve on track to raise interest rates later this year.

site_title: BP said to settle 2010 Gulf oil spill claims with US, States
summary: BP Plc reached an agreement with the US and four Gulf states (Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida) to settle claims from the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill, the worst offshore spill in US history. The terms of the agreement are not yet available, and a BP spokesman declined to comment. The deal comes as a federal judge was weighing pollution fines against the oil company.

site_title: ECB to next discuss emergency Greek funding on Monday: source
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) will discuss emergency funding for Greek banks on Monday, considering whether to freeze, extend, or tighten assistance. The current cap stands at around 89 billion euros, which Greek banks depend on. The decision comes after Greece's bailout referendum.

site_title: Consumer comfort in US increases to highest level since April
summary: US consumer comfort increased to its highest level since April, with the Bloomberg Consumer Comfort Index rising 1.4 points to 44, driven by lower gasoline prices and stronger employment growth. The buying climate gauge improved to 38.9, the biggest two-week gain since March 2012, and personal finances climbed to 58.6, the highest since early April. Wealthier Americans were also more upbeat, with comfort among those earning over $100,000 rising to its highest level since May.

site_title: Traders keep bets on December for first Fed rate hike
summary: US traders expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates for the first time this year in December, with a 51% chance of a rate hike, down from 57% before a weaker-than-expected jobs report. The report showed fewer jobs added in June and May, and a drop in the unemployment rate. The Fed has kept short-term rates near zero since December 2008, and the decision is seen as a response to the economic slowdown.

site_title: Germany's Schaeuble hits new popularity high amid Greece crisis
summary: Germany's Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble has reached a new high in popularity at home, with 70% of Germans approving of his job, surpassing Chancellor Angela Merkel's 67%. This surge in popularity comes after Schaeuble's tough stance in bailout talks with Greece, where he is widely disliked. In contrast, Merkel is viewed more positively by Greeks, with 39% approval. Schaeuble's conservative media has praised him as "Euroman" for defending the eurozone, while in Greece, he is the subject of cartoons depicting him as a Nazi.

site_title: EU Commission delays euro area report due to Greek referendum
summary: The European Commission has delayed the publication of a quarterly report on the euro area due to concerns over Greece's upcoming bailout referendum. The report, which typically attracts little media attention, was put on hold until at least next week to avoid any potential interference. The report covers topics such as the euro area services sector and business cycle synchronisation. The delay comes as tensions rise over Greece's vote on a bailout deal, which could impact the eurozone.

site_title: HP's PC, printer company to assume most debt
summary: Hewlett-Packard (HP) is set to split into two entities, with HP Inc taking over the personal computer and printer businesses, and HP Enterprise focusing on corporate computers and services. HP Enterprise will have less predictable units and greater growth opportunities, while HP Inc will inherit cash-generating PC and printer businesses. The company's total debt is estimated at $21.06 billion, with HP Inc potentially liable for most of the debt. The split is expected to result in HP Inc having a more predictable balance sheet, with HP Enterprise facing challenges due to rapid cloud-computing technology adoption.

images.alt_text: Attendees looking at servers on display during the HP Discover 2015 conference in Las Vegas on Tuesday. The unified company had US$21.06 billion in long-term and short-term borrowings .

site_title: Sweden makes surprise rate cut with wary eye on strong crown
summary: Sweden's central bank, the Riksbank, cut its benchmark interest rate to -0.35% in a surprise move, expanding its asset purchase program to combat a strengthening crown and deflationary pressures. The move aims to bring inflation to 2% and signals the bank's preparedness to intervene in the foreign exchange market if needed. The decision, made amid uncertainty in Greece and a trade-weighted currency index exceeding forecasts, is the first rate cut this year and expands the Riksbank's bond buying by 45 billion Swedish crowns.

site_title: Swiss capital controls could be last resort if franc surges: UBS
summary: Switzerland may impose capital controls on cash withdrawals from banks if the Swiss franc surges, according to UBS's chief economist Daniel Kalt. This would be a last resort in severe market turbulence, and limiting cash withdrawals would signal to investors that holding francs is less attractive. The move could make the franc less desirable for both domestic and foreign investors.

site_title: The Greek crisis: wild cards and the Russian connection
summary: Greece's referendum on July 5, 2015, will determine the country's future in the Euro and European Union. A "yes" vote will keep Greece in the Euro, while a "no" vote will lead to its exit. The outcome is uncertain, with a majority of Greeks favoring the Euro, but the opposition party Syriza faces a challenge in explaining the consequences of a "no" vote. Wild cards include a surprise result in the referendum, a deal with creditors, or Russia's involvement in meeting financial commitments. If Greece accepts Russian loans, its membership in the Euro and EU will be compromised.

site_title: Sincap to buy Orion Energy Resources for S$7.2 million in shares
summary: Sincap Group is acquiring Singapore-incorporated Orion Energy Resources for S$7.2 million in shares to expand its resource trading business. Orion sources coal from Indonesia and ships it to power plants in China, with profits of US$853,000 before tax. The acquisition will leverage Orion's network and business contracts, and Sincap expects to grow its revenue and expand into the mining and resources trading industry. Sincap will issue 133 million new shares, representing 27.3% of its enlarged share capital, with potential for additional shares if Orion meets certain profit targets.

site_title: Spain raises growth forecast to 3.3% in 2015, 3% in 2016: PM
summary: Spain's Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy raised the country's economic growth forecast for 2015 to 3.3% and for 2016 to 3%, citing improved consumer spending and investment. The move contrasts with the Bank of Spain's forecast of 3.1% growth in 2015 and 2.7% in 2016. Spain officially exited recession in 2013 and experienced its first full year of growth last year, but its unemployment rate remains high at 23.8%.

site_title: Airbnb's Cuba gambit shows promise as US relations warm
summary: Airbnb is expanding its operations to Cuba, a move seen as a positive sign for US-Cuba relations. Carlos Jimenez, a Cuban resident, is awaiting the chance to list his home on the platform, despite limited internet access in his village. The move is expected to attract US tourists, with Jimenez looking forward to the opportunity. This development comes as US relations with Cuba continue to improve, offering a new revenue stream for the online home-sharing startup.

site_title: ECB worries about Greece as source of market volatility
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) expresses concerns about market volatility stemming from Greece's debt negotiations, but acknowledges its bond purchase program is bearing fruit. The ECB's monetary policies, including quantitative easing, are contributing to the eurozone's recovery, inflation, and economic growth. Despite early success, the ECB is hesitant to declare its measures a success and emphasizes the need for a steady course of monetary policy, maintaining key interest rates unchanged and implementing non-standard measures.

site_title: SIIC Environment unit clinches 63.8 million yuan wastewater treatment project in China
summary: A wholly owned subsidiary of SIIC Environment, Wuhan Huang-Pi Kaidi Water Services, has secured a 63.8 million yuan (S$13.9 million) project in China to build and operate a wastewater treatment plant with a design capacity of 25,000 tonnes a day for 30 years. The contract is expected to have minimal impact on SIIC Environment's earnings and net tangible assets per share.

site_title: Greek "no" risks place in eurozone: Dijsselbloem
summary: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' referendum on accepting international aid terms may lead to Greece being excluded from the eurozone if the outcome is negative, according to Jeroen Dijsselbloem, chair of the eurozone finance ministers. Dijsselbloem stated that a "no" vote would not result in better terms from creditors, and that far-reaching austerity measures are necessary for Greece's economy to recover. If the outcome is positive, the European side is willing to help Greece.

site_title: Techcomp appoints new executive director
summary: Techcomp Holdings has appointed Guo Bing as its new executive director, replacing Xu Guoping who resigned after reaching retirement age. Guo Bing, who holds a 14.9% stake in the company, previously served as chief executive director of the Greater China region. Xu Guoping has confirmed he has no disagreement with the board and no matters related to his resignation. The company has thanked Xu for his contribution during his tenure.

site_title: BBC says to cut more than 1,000 jobs as viewers trade TVs for Internet
summary: The BBC announced plans to cut over 1,000 jobs due to a decline in licence fee revenue, expected to fall by 150 million pounds ($234 million) in the next financial year. The decline is attributed to viewers switching from live TV to online services, with only 69% of viewing by British adults now happening through live TV. The BBC emphasizes the need to modernize the licence fee to cover digital services.

site_title: MAS implements higher development and leverage limits for Reits, while fees stay
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has implemented changes to its Reit (Real Estate Investment Trust) policies, following industry feedback. The key changes include requiring performance fees to be investor-aligned, imposing a statutory duty on Reit managers to prioritize unitholders' interests, and adopting a single-tier leverage limit of 45%. The proposed acquisition/divestment fee changes have been dropped, and the current approach to income support arrangements will remain in place, mitigating concerns on yield sustainability. These changes aim to strike a balance between investor protection and industry flexibility.

site_title: Passenger traffic for Asia-Pacific carriers up 10 per cent in May: Iata
summary: Asia-Pacific carriers saw a 10% year-on-year increase in passenger traffic in May, outpacing the global 6.9% growth. Despite a 7.5% rise in capacity, load factor reached 77%. International markets saw a 7.1% increase in passenger traffic, while Asia-Pacific carriers experienced a 9.4% growth. However, IATA chief Tony Tyler cautioned that financial crises and softening regional trade activity may impact performance in the coming months. Load factor in Asia-Pacific carriers rose to 76% due to slower capacity growth.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore implemented higher development and leverage limits for Reits, while keeping fees unchanged. The Association of Financial Advisers urged the MAS to review insurance commission rebates. The government launched an enhanced SingPass system with enhanced security features on July 5. Singapore Exchange received a "trade with caution" from the MAS due to increased traded volume and share price. OCBC Bank signed memoranda of understanding with 10 Myanmar banks and United Overseas Bank Group expects $300 million in investments in Myanmar within a year.

site_title: US economy adds 223,000 jobs in June
summary: The US economy added 223,000 net new jobs in June, resulting in a 5.3% unemployment rate, the lowest level since April 2008. There was no upward movement in wages.

site_title: EU GE meets EU regulators over Alstom power unit deal
summary: General Electric (GE) met with EU regulators on July 2 to discuss its $13.7 billion bid for Alstom's energy unit. GE hopes for a softer line on the deal, citing concerns that it would harm competition by leaving only two gas turbine companies in Europe. GE's CEO, Steve Bolze, is expected to present data and argue that the merged company's market power would not be as dominant as claimed. GE may offer concessions, including giving up intellectual property rights, and is seeking a broader assessment of the sector to consider Chinese rivals.

site_title: JES International to take possible legal action against former CEO
summary: JES International may take legal action against former CEO Jin Xin and his relatives over financial irregularities and unauthorized payments. The company discovered questionable transactions involving Jin Xin and found that his relatives removed the group's financial records. JES is also pursuing legal action against a former employee, Ju Li Li, who absconded with administrative records and seals. The company plans to conduct a special audit and take necessary action against Jin if financial irregularities are attributed to him, including making a police report and starting legal action.

site_title: Finance minister Varoufakis says will resign if Greeks vote "Yes": TV
summary: Greece's finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis, stated he will resign if Greeks vote "Yes" in a weekend referendum on bailout terms. He emphasized the need for debt restructuring and would not agree to a plan without it. Varoufakis suggested the Greek government might change its configuration if creditors approve the terms, but a "Yes" vote would lead to his resignation.

site_title: Greece says banks will open after deal with lenders
summary: Greek banks are expected to reopen as soon as the country reaches an agreement with international creditors, with a senior government official stating that the banking system will return to normal "the minute we have a clear result" after Sunday's referendum. The government has ruled out a haircut on deposits, and the reopening of banks is contingent on a clear agreement being reached.

site_title: We can't print drachmas, says Greece's finance minister
summary: Greece's finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis, stated that the country no longer has the capacity to print its own currency, the drachma, due to having smashed its printing presses in 2000. Greece's government is holding a referendum on Sunday, with Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and Varoufakis urging a 'No' vote, while leading eurozone nations suggest the plebiscite is about whether Greek citizens want to keep the euro.

site_title: European banks' capital may be hit as bonds fall: JPMorgan says
summary: European banks may see a reduction in capital ratios due to falling bond prices, particularly for southern European lenders. JPMorgan analysts warn that Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena, CaixaBank, Bank of Ireland, and UniCredit may be hit hardest, with capital ratios declining almost a quarter of a percentage point on average. The impact could be more significant if Greece exits the euro area, leading to higher bond yields and further pressure on bank capital.

site_title: ECB adds state-backed corporate bonds to its QE purchase list
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has added state-backed corporate bonds to its list of eligible assets for its quantitative easing (QE) program, aiming to inject 1.1 trillion euros into the euro area to boost lending and growth. Italian utilities Enel SpA, Snam SpA, and Terna SpA are among the borrowers whose debt may be purchased. The ECB plans to buy 60 billion euros a month of sovereign bonds and asset-backed securities through September 2016 to revive inflation. This move is seen as a step to support the economy amid the Greek crisis.

site_title: Update: Payrolls in US rose in June with little change in wages
summary: US job market showed a moderate pace of economic growth in June, with 223,000 new jobs added, slightly less than the prior month's estimate of 254,000. The jobless rate fell to a seven-year low of 5.3% as more people left the labor force. Wages were little changed, with average hourly earnings holding steady at $24.95. The improving labor market outlook suggests the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates by year-end, with Fed Chair Janet Yellen describing wage growth as "relatively subdued."

site_title: ECB decided to 'look through' market volatility, accounts show
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) concluded its June meeting, deciding not to change monetary policy despite market volatility in the first quarter. The bank attributed the sell-off in bond markets to an improved outlook for growth and inflation, as well as technical factors. ECB President Mario Draghi stated that financial markets must adapt to higher periods of volatility. The bank's policy makers agreed that volatility could subside, but also acknowledged that it may persist in a low-interest-rate environment.

site_title: Ringgit falls as US jobs in focus after Fitch inspired rally
summary: The ringgit currency fell 0.7% to a decade low of 3.7752 per dollar, as investors shifted focus to Friday's US jobs data and potential interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. A positive Fitch Ratings report earlier in the week, which lifted Malaysia's credit outlook to stable from negative, was not enough to support the currency. Weak exports and falling commodity prices, particularly Brent crude, are also contributing to the decline.

site_title: Greeks prepare landmark referendum on the future like it's 1974
summary: Greece is set to hold a landmark referendum on its future, the first since 1974, with voters facing a complex question about approving terms attached to a now-expired bailout. The referendum, held five months after the January election that brought Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras to power, will be held under the same monitors and has raised concerns about its validity and fairness. The government has urged a 40% turnout to legitimize the vote, but critics argue that the short time frame and complex question may lead to irregularities.

site_title: Greek PM says country will be united after referendum
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has reassured the nation that the country will remain united after the upcoming referendum on bailout measures. He stated that the country will overcome its "temporary difficulty" after the vote, which European leaders see as a vote on staying in the eurozone. The referendum is set to take place three days after Tsipras' statement, and he has rejected concerns that it may split the country in two.

images.alt_text: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said on Thursday his country would remain united after the upcoming referendum, rejecting concerns the vote on bailout measures is splitting the country in two.

site_title: Chinese, HK fund managers start to apply for mutual recognition
summary: Chinese and Hong Kong fund managers have started applying for the mutual recognition of funds (MRF) scheme, allowing funds to be sold across both markets from July 1. Over 20 Hong Kong-domiciled funds and 850 mainland Chinese funds are qualified for the scheme. Fund managers, such as Invesco Hong Kong and JP Morgan Asset Management, are keen to tap new clients but will enter the Chinese market slowly due to uncertain demand and logistical difficulties. The MRF scheme marks another step in liberalizing China's capital account and sets an example for the region.

site_title: Sweden cuts key interest rate to record low -0.35%
summary: Sweden's central bank, Riksbank, cut its key interest rate to a record low of -0.35% to combat inflation and a strengthening krona amid the Greek crisis. The rate cut aims to encourage spending and ensure inflation rises towards the 2.0% target. Despite the bank's expansionary policy, consumer prices are still below target, with a 0.1% increase in May. The Riksbank has also extended its bond purchasing program to further support the economy.

site_title: Greek PM urges 'No' vote to strengthen his hand
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras urged citizens to vote 'No' in a referendum on Sunday, hoping it would strengthen his hand in negotiations with international creditors. The proposal, made last week, aims to secure a bailout deal, but European leaders have ruled out further debt talks until the outcome is known. Tsipras believes a 'No' vote will give him more leverage in negotiations, which have stalled after six months of talks. The referendum's outcome is crucial for Greece's economic future.

site_title: At least 36 die in Philippine ferry sinking, 127 survive
summary: A Philippine ferry, the MBCA Kim-Nirvana, capsized off the central islands, killing at least 36 people and injuring 127 others. The 189-passenger ferry capsized minutes after leaving the port of Ormoc in heavy waves. Authorities are investigating possible causes, including human error and bad weather, but initial findings suggest manageable sea conditions. The incident highlights the Philippines' poor maritime safety record, with overcrowding and substandard vessels common in the country's archipelago of 7,100 islands.

site_title: Singapore stocks close in mixed finish after quiet session
summary: Singapore stocks closed 3.3 points weaker at 3,327.84 on Thursday, with a weak 907 million units traded worth S$912.4 million. The session was marked by a lack of trading activity, with many investors and traders seemingly disinterested. The main reasons cited for the weak trading were Greece and China, although some brokers privately acknowledged that trading has been stagnant for months.

site_title: China: Stocks fall 5% in Shanghai afternoon trading
summary: China's Shanghai Composite Index plummeted 5.02% to 3,850.08, with the Shenzhen Composite Index down 5.63% to 2,214.12 in Thursday's afternoon trading. The decline comes despite the market regulator's easing of margin trading rules following heavy losses the previous day.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares ended higher on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 5.92 points to close at 1,733.88. The index saw a trading volume of 1.46 billion lots valued at RM1.85 billion.

site_title: Spain's jobless numbers fall again in June, but still high
summary: Spain's jobless numbers fell 2.25% in June, or 94,727 people, marking the fifth consecutive month of decline. Despite the decrease, over 4 million people remained out of work. The services sector saw a 61,887 decline, while industry and construction combined for a 25,845 drop. The decrease is attributed to the start of the tourist season.

site_title: US asks Swiss to extradite 7 FIFA officials: government
summary: The US government has formally requested the extradition of seven FIFA officials arrested in May, seeking to prosecute them for corruption in football's top body. The requests were made within the timeframe set by the bilateral extradition treaty between the US and Switzerland. The officials face charges related to a wide-ranging probe into corruption and financial irregularities within FIFA.

site_title: Greek referendum on bailout too close to call, poll shows
summary: Greek voters are nearly evenly split, with 47% leaning towards a "yes" vote on the bailout and 43% towards a "no" vote, according to a poll. The referendum, set for Monday, is seen as a potential economic dark period for Greece, with European leaders warning of economic consequences if the "no" vote prevails. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is seeking to delay implementation of austerity measures and maintain a 30% discount on sales tax, but creditors are pushing for pension reforms to bring in savings of 1% of GDP by 2016.

images.alt_text: Greek voters are almost evenly split heading into a referendum in three days that European leaders said could plunge the country into economic darkness.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 0.95% higher after upbeat US jobs data
summary: Tokyo shares closed 0.95% higher on Thursday, driven by a weaker yen and upbeat US jobs data, which boosted Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index gained 193.18 points to 20,522.50. The US jobs data and hopes for a Greece debt crisis resolution also influenced the market.

site_title: Indonesia's central bank says sees 2015 H1 credit growth at about 11%
summary: Indonesia's central bank predicts credit growth of about 11% in the first half of 2015, slightly lower than the expected 13-14% for the full year. This slower growth is attributed to the country's slowing economic pace. To stimulate growth, the central bank has lowered down payments for cars and motorcycles and increased borrowing capacity for home purchases.

images.alt_text: Credit in Indonesia expanded about 11 per cent in the first half of this year, central bank deputy governor Perry Warjiyo said on Thursday.

site_title: Manufacturing deal wins China cheap supply of GSK's new HIV drug
summary: GlaxoSmithKline's HIV drug Tivicay will be supplied to China at a discounted price, following a deal with Shanghai-based Desano Pharmaceuticals to manufacture the active ingredient. The agreement, announced by ViiV Healthcare, aims to improve access to the medicine in China and other developing countries. This move comes after GSK was fined 3 billion yuan for bribing Chinese doctors and promised to boost access to its medicines in the country by expanding local production and adopting flexible pricing. The price of Tivicay in China will be competitive with that charged in poor countries.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise for third day as investors take calm view of Greece
summary: Australian shares rose 1.53% on Thursday, marking their third day of gains, as investors took a calm view of Greece's potential departure from the Euro. The S&P/ASX 200 index increased 84.136 points to 5,599.800. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index also rose 0.81%. The gains came despite concerns about US-EU trade tensions, but investors remained optimistic, brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close mixed, dragged by China shares
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.1% to 26,282.32, outperforming mainland markets, which fell 1.5% despite new regulatory measures. The Hang Seng index saw significant trading volume, with 2.3 billion shares changing hands. The price gap between Hong Kong and Shanghai shares remained at 128.35, indicating a premium for Shanghai shares. This marked a mixed day for Hong Kong stocks, driven by the performance of specific companies.

site_title: India's US$100b solar push draws foreign firms as locals take backseat
summary: India's plan to invest $100 billion in solar energy over the next decade will largely be driven by foreign companies, as local manufacturers struggle to compete due to outdated technology and high costs. Foreign players, such as China's Trina Solar and US-based SunEdison, are expected to dominate the market, with Indian companies like Indosolar and Moser Baer unable to match foreign prices. The Indian government has scrapped restrictions on importing solar panels, allowing foreign companies to compete with local manufacturers for government projects.

site_title: Indian cbank chief says govt in talks over capital for lenders
summary: Indian Reserve Bank of India Governor Raghuram Rajan stated the government is in talks with the central bank to inject capital into lenders, ensuring funding for infrastructure projects remains on track. Rajan noted India's exposure to Greece is "very, very" limited and expressed hope for foreign investors to be attracted to the country's growth prospects.

site_title: Air France's KLM cuts winter flights as sales under pressure
summary: Air France-KLM's Dutch arm, KLM, will cut 500,000 seats from its winter network, removing flights to 10 European destinations and locations in Africa, Japan, and Brazil, due to declining revenue. The move aims to improve the airline's competitive position and follows similar efforts by sister airline Air France, which faces productivity challenges. KLM's decision is part of its Perform 2020 savings program, and the company is accelerating talks to secure more competitive labor accords. The airline's shares have fallen 0.6% due to the announcement.

images.alt_text: Air France-KLM Group's Dutch arm said it will cut frequencies across a range of routes for the coming winter season as revenue comes under pressure.

site_title: Financial advisers' association pushes for guidelines on insurance commission rebates
summary: The Association of Financial Advisers (Singapore) has urged the Monetary Authority of Singapore to establish guidelines for insurance commission rebates to ensure they are carried out ethically. AFA(S) president Vincent Ee warned that improper incentives could lead to overbuying of insurance policies, while life insurance companies could create a model where commission rebates are reflected in pricing and premiums. This move aims to prevent unethical practices and promote transparency in the industry.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets edge higher at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose in opening trade on July 2, 2015, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris's CAC 40 indices advancing 0.10% and 0.31% respectively. London's FTSE 100 index edged up 0.01%. The rebound followed a volatile week, with Greek stocks rebounding on Wednesday after a proposed reworked bailout deal was closer to creditor positions. Investors focused on US jobs data and Greece's referendum on its bailout.

site_title: Google apologises after photo app tagged black couple 'gorillas'
summary: Google apologized after its photo app incorrectly labeled a picture of a black couple as "gorillas" in an identification program. The mistake was reported on Twitter and the company promptly took action to fix the issue. A Google representative expressed "appalled" regret and promised to prevent such errors in the future. The incident has raised concerns about the app's accuracy and Google's commitment to diversity and inclusion.

site_title: Indonesia to call off search for victims in deadly military plane crash
summary: Indonesian authorities have decided to call off the search for victims in a deadly military plane crash in Sumatra, killing around 140 people. The Hercules C-130B plane crashed into a residential area in Medan shortly after takeoff on Tuesday, with all on board and more on the ground killed. The incident has prompted President Joko Widodo to review Indonesia's ageing air force fleet, with the possibility of increased military spending to boost the country's ageing transport equipment.

site_title: UK construction PMI rises to 4-month high in June
summary: The UK construction sector experienced its fastest growth in four months in June, with the Markit/CIPS Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 58.1, its highest level in a year. This surge in activity and confidence is attributed to relief over the passing of pre-election uncertainty and a belief in underlying demand's recovery.

site_title: Alibaba, Evergrande-owned football club files for China IPO in Asian first
summary: Evergrande Taobao, a football club co-owned by Alibaba Group and Evergrande Real Estate Group, has filed for an initial public offering in China, potentially becoming the first Asian club listed. The team, valued at 10 billion yuan (US$1.61 billion), has already seen a valuation of nearly US$3 billion after Alibaba's US$192 million investment. The listing is pending approval by the National Equities Exchange and Quotations.

images.alt_text: Evergrande Taobao, the football team co-owned by Alibaba Group Holding Ltd and property firm Evergrande Real Estate Group Ltd, could become the first club listed in Asia after it filed for an initial public offering in China.

site_title: UK productivity is improving: BOE
summary: The Bank of England's deputy governor, Jon Cunliffe, stated that UK productivity is improving. He also expressed concerns over Greece's deepening debt crisis, describing it as "very dangerous" and stating that the BOE needs to prepare for the worst. Cunliffe emphasized that any potential move by HSBC to base itself outside the BOE's jurisdiction would be driven by business considerations, not a search for looser regulation.

images.alt_text: Bank of England governor Mark Carney had said that the BOE was ready to take whatever action was required to limit the spillover if Greece were to leave the euro zone.

site_title: SingPass system with enhanced security features to be launched on Sunday
summary: Singapore to launch enhanced SingPass system with better user experience, mobile-friendly features, and two-factor authentication (2FA) for enhanced security, starting July 5, 2015. The system will require users to update their mobile number and email address, set up security questions and answers, and choose an SMS or OneKey token for 2FA authentication. A one-year grace period will be provided for the 2-step verification process, after which all e-government transactions requiring 2FA will require a second-level authentication.

site_title: UOB sees US$300m in investments in one year from clients in Myanmar (Amended)
summary: United Overseas Bank Group (UOB) expects US$300 million in investments from clients in Myanmar within a year, mainly for building factories, hotels, and commercial properties. The bank has also inked two loan agreements, one for Cycle & Carriage Automobile Myanmar Company and another for a 200-room hotel extension in Central Yangon. UOB's Myanmar branch officially opened in Yangon, supporting clients from Europe and Asia.

site_title: Oil prices edge up after sliding on US stock build
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, partially recovering from a 2.5-4% drop the previous day, as US stockpiles increased for the first time in months. US crude futures rose 11 cents to $57.07 per barrel, while Brent crude futures gained 26 cents to $62.27 per barrel. The US stock build was attributed to strong production, particularly from the Gulf of Mexico, contributing to a global production glut. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) also reported a three-year high in supply in June.

site_title: China's planning agency won't allow enterprise bond defaults: newspaper
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) has assured that it will not allow enterprise bond defaults, according to a deputy head's private teleconference remarks. Despite corporate bond defaults in China's onshore market over the past two years, no enterprise bond has publicly defaulted on NDRC approval. This policy aims to maintain stability in China's economy, particularly for large enterprises owned by the central government.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks edge lower as Greece bewilders markets
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.2% to 9,360.61 points, bucking regional gains, due to conflicting signals from Greece on a potential international bailout. Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras urged Greeks to reject the deal, potentially delaying EU relations and a referendum on Sunday. Global uncertainties, including Europe and China, also impacted Taiwan's economy, with the Nikkei/Markit Taiwan PMI hitting a 33-month low in June.

site_title: "Wow, pulled back wrong throttle": captain of crashed TransAsia plane
summary: A TransAsia Airways plane crashed in Taiwan in February, killing 43 people. The captain, who was piloting the plane, had switched off the working engine after the other lost power, and then mistakenly pulled back the wrong throttle. The plane stalled and crashed into a river. The Aviation Safety Council has released a detailed report, which will be finalized in April 2016, but does not assign responsibility or make recommendations for improvement. The incident highlights the importance of proper engine management and crew training.

site_title: Oil prices recover as Iran talks, Greek crisis drag on
summary: Oil prices recovered on Thursday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rising 10 cents to $57.06 and Brent increasing 23 cents to $62.24, amid extended Iran nuclear talks. The extended deadline provides a breather for oversupplied markets, but uncertainty over the Greek financial crisis remains. Analysts will closely monitor the outcome of the negotiations, given Iran's significant oil reserves.

site_title: Asia: Markets climb on Greece hopes, Shanghai sinks again
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday, driven by hopes for a Greece eurozone deal and strong US data, while Shanghai sank 3.00% as investors brushed off easing trading rules. Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney gained, with Seoul adding 0.34%. European leaders dismissed Greece's bailout offer, but traders remain optimistic about a post-referendum agreement. US shares advanced, with a manufacturing gauge at its highest in five months and a private job survey at its strongest this year.

site_title: MAS issues 'trade with caution' on SGX
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued a "trade with caution" on Singapore Exchange (SGX) following a 5.62% increase in its share price on Wednesday. The MAS will investigate possible market irregularities and take necessary actions to maintain a fair and orderly market. As of Thursday morning, SGX's counter was trading down 0.244% at S$8.16, following a surge of 7.48 million shares. The MAS aims to ensure transparency and fairness in the market.

site_title: Gold languishes below US$1,170 ahead of US jobs data
summary: Gold prices fell to nearly four weeks low, trading at $1,167.40 an ounce, due to a strong dollar and anticipation of higher US interest rates. The metal was hit by strong US private employment data and a weakening euro. Analysts expect gold to decline further, citing a strong US labor market report and potential rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The Greek debt crisis remains a concern, but its impact on gold has been limited so far.

site_title: Thailand's consumer outlook slips to one-year low as recovery stalls
summary: Thai consumer confidence plummeted to a one-year low in June, falling to 74.4, as economic uncertainty, low exports, and drought continue to affect the country. This marks the sixth consecutive month of decline, with growth forecasted at 2.5-3.0% in the second quarter. The government is urged to implement measures to lift consumer sentiment and weaken the baht to boost exports. The country's economy has struggled since the 2014 coup, with growth last year at just 0.9%.

site_title: US hiring seen solid in June, keeping September rate hike in play
summary: US job growth likely cooled in June after reaching a five-month high, but still-healthy hiring suggests the labor market is strong enough to support a September interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve. Nonfarm payrolls rose 230,000 last month, above the average for the first five months of the year, and the jobless rate is forecast to fall to a seven-year low of 5.4%. The economy is expected to continue growing, with average hourly earnings expected to rise 0.2% in June, exerting moderate upward pressure on wages.

images.alt_text: US job growth likely cooled a bit in June after reaching a five-month high, but still-healthy hiring would suggest the labor market is strong enough to support a September interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Vietnam's Petrolimex and Kuwait Petroleum end diesel term contract: sources
summary: Vietnam's Petrolimex and Kuwait Petroleum Corp have ended their 1990s-long diesel term contract due to lower duties on imports from Southeast Asia. The decision follows Vietnam's implementation of the ASEAN trade deal, which lowers the import tax on diesel from ASEAN countries to 5% from 10%. The contract, which supplied 5.3 million barrels of diesel annually, will not be renewed, potentially shifting Petrolimex's supply to the spot market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.41% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.41% higher on Thursday, following advances in New York and Europe, driven by hopes of a deal to keep Greece in the eurozone. The Hang Seng Index rose 106.81 points to 26,356.84. The gains come as traders brush off new US President Trump's tariff threats, instead focusing on ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: South Korea plans overhaul of bourse structure to attract new listings
summary: South Korea's Korea Exchange plans to overhaul its bourse structure into a listed holding company, aiming to attract more new listings. The holding company will have separate subsidiaries for the main board KOSPI, tech-heavy KOSDAQ, and derivatives market. The proposals will be submitted to parliament later this year, with the goal of fostering more competition between boards.

site_title: Defiant Greek PM vows referendum will go ahead
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras vowed to proceed with a referendum on Sunday's bailout, despite European leaders' refusal to offer fresh debt talks. Tsipras urged Greeks to vote 'No' to creditors' demands, promising a 'No' vote would not signify a rupture with Europe. The referendum comes after Greece defaulted on an IMF loan and entered uncharted waters without external financial assistance. A 'No' vote is seen as a risk towards a possible exit from the eurozone, prompting concerns from EU officials and credit rating agencies, including Moody's cutting Greece's credit rating.

images.alt_text: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras vowed Wednesday to press ahead with a controversial bailout referendum as European leaders ruled out any fresh debt offer before Sunday's vote.
