A new system for resolving disputes between investors and states, proposed by European Parliament President Martin Schulz, could help overcome public resistance to the accord. The system would involve publicly appointed, independent professional judges in public hearings. The proposal aims to address concerns that US multinationals will use private arbitration to challenge European food and environmental laws. A vote on the deal is expected on July 8.

site_title: PM Lee's lawyers seek 'very high' damages in defamation case against Roy Ngerng
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's lawyers have requested "very high" damages in the defamation case against blogger Roy Ngerng, alleging that Ngerng's actions were "deeply and intensely malicious" and aimed at damaging Lee's reputation. The hearing began at the High Court, with Ngerng remaining determined to harm Lee's reputation. The case is ongoing, with the outcome yet to be determined.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: Singapore's private home prices dropped 0.9% in Q2, marking a seventh consecutive quarter of decline. The Singapore Diamond Investment Exchange (SDiX) is set to launch the world's first commodities exchange for physically settled diamonds in Singapore. Singapore Airlines proposed changing its external auditor after 43 years, while Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong testified in a defamation case against blogger Roy Ngerng. Meanwhile, a former ST Marine financial controller was fined $210,000 for abetting bogus entries, and the STI rebounded 50 points over two days.

site_title: China launches new oil and gas trading platform: Xinhua
summary: China has launched a new oil and gas trading platform, the Shanghai Petroleum and Natural Gas Exchange (SHPGX), in the Shanghai free trade zone. The platform, which is registered in Shanghai, will initially handle natural gas transactions during a test run. Trading volumes are expected to range from 5-6 billion cubic meters in 2015 and over 10 billion cubic meters in 2016. The move aims to introduce more market-oriented elements into gas pricing, which is pegged to crude oil benchmarks, as China's natural gas output fell 2% in May and demand growth has slumped.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on Greece deal hopes
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, July 1, 2015, after Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras expressed readiness to accept most of creditors' bailout terms with modifications, boosting market hopes. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 64.87 points, the S&P 500 gained 9.44 points, and the Nasdaq Composite added 41.47 points, driven by optimism over the Greek deal.

site_title: US factory activity eases; slowest pace since Oct 2013: Markit
summary: US factory activity eased in June, hitting its slowest pace since October 2013, according to Markit's final US Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index, which declined to 53.6. The index's employment component rose to 55.5, but output slowed to 53.9, the lowest level since January 2014. A slowdown in exports, attributed to the strong dollar, is largely linked to the decline. The report suggests the economy is slowing again, with the slowest rate of manufacturing expansion in over a year and a half.

site_title: US private sector adds 237,000 jobs in June: ADP
summary: US private employers added 237,000 jobs in June, the largest gain since December, according to a report by ADP. This suggests the jobs market may allow the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates later this year. The figure exceeded economists' forecast of 218,000 jobs. May's private payroll gains were revised up to 203,000 from 201,000. The ADP report comes ahead of Thursday's US Labor Department non-farm payrolls report, which is expected to show a 230,000 job gain.

site_title: BoE to hike in Q1 as wage growth surpasses its expectations: Reuters poll
summary: The Bank of England is expected to hike its benchmark interest rate in Q1 2016, according to a Reuters poll of economists. Average earnings are predicted to rise faster than the central bank's forecast of 2.5%, surpassing expectations. Economists believe Bank Rate will rise to 0.75% in the first quarter, 1.0% in the third, and end 2016 at 1.25%. The poll gave a 55% chance of a rate hike before April, unchanged from June, but none of the 59 economists polled expect a move when the Monetary Policy Committee meets on July 9.

site_title: Indonesian plane crash toll rises to 142
summary: A plane crash in Medan, Indonesia, has killed 142 people, with many believed to be military personnel and their families who paid to be on the flight despite military rules prohibiting it. The Hercules C-130 transport plane crashed into a residential neighborhood, causing severe damage and fires. The air force has revised its initial count of 12 crew members, and an investigation is underway. The incident marks the sixth deadly crash involving an Indonesian air force plane in the past decade, prompting calls for a fundamental overhaul of the military's equipment.

images.alt_text: The number of people killed when an Indonesian air force plane crashed into a residential neighbourhood rose to 142 on Wednesday, as families said their relatives had paid to be on the aircraft, in violation of military rules.

site_title: Euro dips as officials strive to head off Greek exit
summary: The euro dipped to $1.1108 due to reports of new concessions made by Greece to its European creditors, potentially preventing a Greek exit from the single currency. Despite a brief increase in European stock markets, the euro quickly returned to its losses. Traders await the weekend vote by Greeks on whether to accept bailout conditions, with strategists warning that a Greek exit would lead to a sharp fall in the euro.

site_title: Bank of America Merrill Lynch hires Martin Siah to head Asia real estate investment banking and Singapore investment banking
summary: Bank of America Merrill Lynch has hired Martin Siah as head of Asia real estate investment banking and head of Singapore investment banking, effective September. Siah will initially be based in Hong Kong. The appointment was announced in a memo seen by The Business Times.

site_title: Indonesia 1H 2015 GDP growth seen at 4.9% year-on-year: finance minister
summary: Indonesia's economy is expected to expand 4.9% in the first half of 2015, with full-year growth projected at 5.2%, according to Finance Minister Bambang Brodjonegoro. The slowest rate in six years was reported for January-March, with 4.7% growth. In the second half, growth is expected to reach 5.5%.

site_title: Oil prices drop before US inventory data
summary: Oil prices dropped on Wednesday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling 86 cents to $58.61 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude dropping 60 cents to $62.99 a barrel. The decline was attributed to concerns over the Greek debt crisis and its potential impact on the eurozone, leading to a decrease in oil demand. The release of US inventory data was also anticipated, but its impact was not yet clear.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell on Wednesday with developments over Greece providing the main direction for markets.

site_title: Ex-ST Marine group financial controller fined S$210,000, two others charged
summary: A former ST Marine financial controller, Patrick Lee Swee Ching, was fined S$210,000 for abetting bogus entries for entertainment expenses. He pleaded guilty to 38 charges involving over S$126,000 in expenses. Lee showed remorse by pleading guilty early and cooperating with investigations. Two other former senior executives were charged earlier, bringing the total implicated to seven. The court considered Lee's cooperation and lack of corruption charges in sentencing him.

site_title: Blackstone CEO says eurozone could contain Grexit contagion
summary: Blackstone CEO Stephen Schwarzman believes the eurozone can contain a potential 'Grexit' following Greece's upcoming referendum. He notes that the eurozone has undergone significant changes since 2010, making it better prepared for a possible exit. Schwarzman's comments come as Greece's economy and financial system face significant risks ahead of the referendum on Sunday. Despite these concerns, Schwarzman remains optimistic, citing the eurozone's improved preparedness.

site_title: CEE manufacturing strengthens despite Greek debt woes
summary: Central European manufacturing strengthened in June, with Poland's HSBC manufacturing PMI at 54.4 and the Czech Republic's at 56.9, beating forecasts. Demand from the euro zone, which accounts for 62% of Czech exports, 57% of Hungary's, and 54% of Poland's, has helped drive growth. Unlike Greece, Poland, the Czech Republic, and Hungary do not have significant trade or banking ties, reducing concerns of contagion. The region's transport sector has also seen signs of a gradual economic revival, with increased demand for shipping and storage.

site_title: Chinese people getting taller and fatter: govt
summary: China sees a rise in average height, with men reaching 167.1 cm and women 155.8 cm, but an increase in obesity rates, with 30.1% of over-18s considered overweight and 11.9% obese. This is a two-thirds increase over a decade, with average weights rising by 3.5 kg for men and 2.9 kg for women. Experts attribute the rise in obesity to dietary changes and lifestyle factors, including smoking, excessive drinking, and insufficient physical exercise. The obesity problem is linked to 363,000 fatalities annually in China.

site_title: Greek pensioners besiege banks to grab cash
summary: Thousands of angry Greek pensioners besieged banks on Wednesday to withdraw cash from their state pensions, amid a week-long banking shutdown. The Greek government temporarily reopened 1,000 branches to allow pensioners without cards to withdraw 120 euros. The move sparked lengthy queues and outrage from retirees who feel exposed to the economic downturn. Many pensioners, like Dyonisia Zafiropoulou, who withdrew 120 euros, expressed confidence that Greece can weather the financial crisis, while others, like a retired mariner, struggled to access essential funds.

site_title: Germany's Schaeuble says no Greece deal possible before referendum
summary: German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble stated that a deal between Greece and creditors is unlikely before the country's referendum on Sunday on bailout terms. Despite Athens sending an amended proposal, Schaeuble said there is no basis for an agreement before the referendum. He criticized the Greek government for misleading the people and accused them of making "incredibly untruthful claims." Schaeuble called for Greece to clarify its position before negotiations can resume, as the country's financial situation has become more difficult due to the end of its EU aid program and default on an IMF loan.

site_title: Four ways to change employee behaviour
summary: A new book, "Changing Employee Behavior: A Practical Guide for Managers," explores four psychological models to explain how behavior change occurs. These models include behaviorism, cognitive psychology, systemic psychotherapy, and behavioral economics. Each model offers a unique perspective on behavior change, from conditioning habits through rewards and punishments to influencing thoughts and intentions. A thorough understanding of these models can help managers choose effective interventions and evaluate their effectiveness in changing employee behavior.

site_title: 'Grexit' would benefit Greece, economist at top Indian bank says
summary: India's top economist, Soumya Kanti Ghosh, believes a "Grexit" from the euro would benefit Greece and also be good for India. In a report, Ghosh argues that Greece's reckless fiscal austerity will continue to be a non-starter, and that creditors should acknowledge fiscal austerity isn't the solution. He notes that 69 currency exits over the past century have had few negative economic consequences, and that the markets might respond in a composed manner if Greece leaves the euro. Ghosh's report suggests that extreme negativity around Greece could spread panic, but a rational view might lead to a more stable outcome.

site_title: World Bank warns China over state financial control
summary: The World Bank has warned China to accelerate reforms of its state-dominated financial sector, citing concerns over wasteful investment, overindebtedness, and a weakly regulated shadow-banking system. The institution urged the Chinese government to reduce the state's role in banking and financial institutions, which it described as "unbalanced, repressed, costly to maintain, and potentially unstable." The World Bank also expressed concern that failure to address these issues could derail China's economic growth after three decades of stellar performance.

site_title: Singapore shares close with STI rebounding a second day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 13.81 points on Wednesday to close at 3,331.14, marking its second consecutive day of gains. The STI had initially surged to an intraday high of 3,342, but volatility was fueled by heavy margin selling in China and Greece's failure to meet an IMF repayment deadline. Despite a lack of significant news, the STI has bounced about 50 points in two days, driven by short-covering momentum.

site_title: Soilbuild Construction Q2 profit up 5% at S$5.51m
summary: Soilbuild Construction's Q2 net profit rose 5% to S$5.51m, driven by a 21% jump in revenue to S$81.63m from certain projects. The company's six-month net profit was S$9.97m, up 9% from the previous year. The board declared an interim dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent per share. The group's order book stands at S$748.6m, expected to be completed in the next 24 months, following the award of its maiden overseas project in Myanmar worth approximately S$68.5m.

site_title: German industry starts to advocate Greek exit from eurozone
summary: German industry is calling for Greece to exit the eurozone, citing concerns that prolonged uncertainty could harm economic recovery in Europe. The German automotive and machinery associations, VDA and VDMA, say a Greek exit could be manageable for German businesses, despite fears of market chaos. Industry leaders believe that a stable eurozone is crucial for German companies, and that a Grexit could spoil the recovery in Spain, Portugal, Ireland, and Germany.

site_title: Tsipras offers conditional okay to bailout, creditors sceptical
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has offered a conditional approval for a bailout package, but creditors remain skeptical. Tsipras requested changes to the package, including a 29 billion euro loan to cover debt service payments, a discount on value added tax for Greek islands, and delayed defense spending cuts. Germany rejected the request, saying the letter came too late and didn't go far enough. Tsipras' amendments aim to maintain the program's credibility and robustness.

site_title: ECB set to keep Greece on tight funding leash
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is likely to maintain its existing cap on funding for Greece, keeping pressure on the country as its lenders run out of cash. The cap on emergency liquidity assistance may be tightened slightly, but not significantly, to address concerns about the risk of releasing funds to banks in a state on the brink of insolvency. Greece is set to put new proposals for a two-year loan agreement and debt rescheduling to the euro zone ministers ahead of a bailout referendum that could decide the country's future in the euro.

site_title: World Bank to lend US$650m for Indian rail project
summary: The World Bank has approved a US$650 million loan for India's Eastern Dedicated Freight Corridor, a 1,840 km rail project aimed at easing congestion on the country's freight network. The project, set to be completed by 2025, will help speed up the carrying of goods between Ludhiana and Kolkata, supporting India's growing freight traffic projected to increase 7% annually. The World Bank sees the project as crucial to meet India's freight needs.

site_title: Chinese premier confident China can reach 7% GDP growth goal
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang expressed confidence that China can achieve its 7% GDP growth target for 2015, despite a slowdown since the beginning of the year. Li attributed the slowdown to various policy options, including a streamlined administration, proper competition, and a better business environment for foreign investors. He emphasized that quantitative easing is not the only way to boost an economy, citing the need for a more comprehensive approach.

site_title: Consumer sentiment in US declines on weaker expectations
summary: US consumer confidence declined in July as Americans' expectations fell to an eight-month low, with the University of Michigan's final index of sentiment dropping to 93.1 from 96.1 in June. Consumer expectations six months from now decreased to 84.1, while a gauge of current conditions dropped to 107.2. Americans' median income increase expectations remained high, but wage growth remains modest, with worker pay rising at the slowest pace on record.

site_title: China parliament ratifies BRICS Bank agreement
summary: China's parliament ratified an agreement to create the New Development Bank, also known as the BRICS Bank, with Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa. The bank aims to provide financing for infrastructure and development projects in emerging markets. The Standing Committee of the National People's Congress approved the agreement, which is seen as an alternative to Western institutions such as the World Bank. The BRICS Bank is one of two international development banks being promoted by China.

site_title: Euro zone factory PMI at 52.5 in June
summary: Euro zone factory growth picked up to 52.5 in June, a 14-month high, despite uncertainty over Greek debt talks and potential exit from the currency union. The increase was attributed to a modest boost from manufacturing, which also saw the fastest price rise since late 2013. However, overall expansion remains insipid, and weak growth in Germany and France limited the impact. The European Central Bank's quantitative easing programme may see positive effects, as inflation rose 0.2% in June.

site_title: Toyota's top female executive steps down after arrest in Japan
summary: Toyota's top female executive, Julie Hamp, has resigned after being arrested in Japan on suspicion of illegally importing oxycodone. Hamp, a US citizen, had joined Toyota as chief communications officer in June, becoming the company's first female managing officer. She was arrested on June 18 and remains in police custody, with her detention set to end on July 8. Toyota accepted her resignation, citing concerns and inconvenience caused by the events. Senior Managing Officer Shigeru Hayakawa will take over Hamp's duties until a replacement is appointed.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor Corp said on Wednesday that Julie Hamp, its first female managing officer, had resigned following her arrest last month on suspicion of illegally importing the painkiller oxycodone into Japan.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 21.32 points to close at 1,727.96 on Wednesday, with 1.94 billion lots valued at RM2.17 billion traded. The market saw 678 gainers and 192 losers.

images.alt_text: Malaysian shares ended higher on Wednesday with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index adding 21.32 points to close at 1,727.96.

site_title: Shaping the public realm
summary: Architect Moshe Safdie's latest project, Sky Habitat, a condominium complex in Singapore, has obtained its Temporary Occupation Permit. Inspired by his iconic Habitat 67 project in Montreal, Sky Habitat features two stepped towers linked by sky bridges, providing residents with a balance of privacy and community space. The design prioritizes humanizing the megascale, with private terraces, common gardens, and community infrastructure such as swimming pools and playgrounds. The 509 units, ranging from two- to four-bedroom units, are priced from S$1,370 psf, with 137 units left for sale.

site_title: MAS may require central clearing of OTC interest rate swaps, seeks feedback
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is proposing to require central clearing of over-the-counter (OTC) interest rate swaps, affecting Singapore-dollar and US-dollar contracts booked by banks with more than S$20 billion in derivatives contracts. The contracts can be cleared through domestic or foreign central counterparties regulated by MAS. The proposal aims to enhance market stability and risk management. MAS is seeking feedback on the proposal, which will initially apply to banks meeting the specified threshold.

site_title: Charge of the Zebra
summary: Zebra Technologies CEO Anders Gustafsson has successfully acquired Motorola Solutions' enterprise unit for $3.45 billion, positioning his company to capitalize on the IoT revolution. The acquisition has enabled Zebra to expand its offerings and hit the ground running, with a 200% rise in revenue in its first full quarter as an expanded company. Gustafsson attributes the success to the lack of redundant departments and the ability to provide a complete solution to customers, who previously bought barcodes and barcode readers from both companies. The acquisition has also allowed Zebra to leverage its expertise in IoT, cloud, and mobility to deliver Enterprise Asset Intelligence (EAI) to customers, enabling smarter and more timely business decisions.

site_title: Singtel sells 30% stake in Abacus Travel Systems
summary: Singtel sold its 30% stake in Abacus Travel Systems for US$3 million in cash. The transaction marked the end of ATS as a joint venture of Singtel. ATS had a net tangible asset value of S$7.8 million as of March 31. The sale will allow Abacus International to acquire full control of the company.

site_title: Greece "not a Lehman", says Deutsche Asset and Wealth Management CIO
summary: Deutsche Asset and Wealth Management's CIO Asoka Woehrmann stated that Greece's situation will not trigger a global financial crisis, but it will create volatility that could be beneficial for investors seeking European equity positions. Woehrmann emphasized patience and described the world economy as slowly recovering. He also highlighted that the economy is moving upwards steadily, despite being in an unusual recovery cycle.

site_title: Update: Athens stock market to reopen Monday: finance ministry source
summary: Greece's main stock exchange in Athens will reopen on Monday after being closed for five weeks due to the Greek debt crisis. The decision to reopen was made by the finance ministry, which imposed capital controls on June 26. The resumption of trading will be accompanied by restrictions for investors based in Greece.

site_title: Singapore's split from M'sia made news on Swiss press
summary: On August 9, 1965, Singapore officially separated from Malaysia, making significant headlines in the Swiss press, particularly in the Zurich-based Neue Zürcher Zeitung. The event was met with mixed reactions, with Singaporeans celebrating their independence, while in Sarawak, opposition parties called for a referendum on independence. The separation was seen as a significant shift in the Cold War era, with the US intensifying bombing in North Vietnam and the Soviet Union's influence in the region. Indonesia recognized Singapore as an independent state, and the move marked a new era for the small nation.

site_title: Royal Bank of Scotland reports profits rise
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland reported a 27% increase in net profits for the second quarter, with £293 million in profit after tax, driven by the sale of US operations. This comes after the British government plans to sell its 80% stake in RBS over the coming months. The bank was bailed out with £45.5 billion in public funds following the 2008 global financial crisis.

site_title: A digital revolution and a reality check
summary: Key tech firms are exploring digital banking and financial inclusion in Southeast Asia, leveraging mobile payments and social media data to reach the unbanked population. However, concerns over data privacy, regulatory hurdles, and infrastructure demands remain. Companies like Globe Banko in the Philippines and Wing Money in Cambodia have successfully scaled up mobile banking services, but regulatory challenges and security risks persist. Meanwhile, the "Internet of things" trend is expected to continue, with companies like Samsung integrating sensors and data communication into various products, but questions remain about network capacity and data control.

site_title: Raffles Medical Group to join Mayo Clinic Care Network
summary: Raffles Medical Group, a Singapore-based integrated private-healthcare provider, announced it will join the US-based Mayo Clinic Care Network. This will be the first time an Asian healthcare provider joins the network, with services available at RMG's Singapore clinics and hospital. RMG will have access to Mayo Clinic's tools, including electronic consultations and clinical reference materials, without affecting their respective operations. The partnership is expected to provide patients with no significant extra cost.

site_title: ECB can support European markets; Grexit unlikely, says Credit Suisse Private Banking CIO
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) can support European markets by buying sovereign bonds of peripheral countries and keeping borrowing costs low, according to Credit Suisse Private Banking's CIO Michael Strobaek. Greece's formal default on a $2.25 billion debt payment to the IMF does not necessarily mean Grexit, with a 70% probability of the country staying in the eurozone. Strobaek believes a European recovery is on the way, driven by the ECB's accommodative stance, and sees a low probability of Grexit.

images.alt_text: Even though Greece has formally defaulted on a 1.5 billion euro (S$2.25 billion) debt payment to the International Monetary Fund (IMF), there is still a low probability of Grexit - that the country will exit the eurozone monetary union, said Michael Strobaek, chief investment officer of Credit Suisse Private Banking and Wealth Management.

site_title: Zero-pollution buses get moving with Silicon Valley backing
summary: Seattle is launching a fleet of zero-pollution, all-electric buses made by Proterra, backed by Silicon Valley and Warren Buffett's company. The buses, which run on renewable energy, have shown significant fuel cost savings and quieter operation compared to traditional diesel models. The trials in Seattle, Dallas, San Antonio, and Worcester, Massachusetts, demonstrate the potential of electric buses for mass transportation. With over 41% of bus fleets already using alternative technologies, cities are pushing for a greener transportation system, with electric buses expected to become the norm by 2020, according to analysts.

site_title: Passenger traffic at Changi Airport steady at 26.6m in H1
summary: Changi Airport saw nearly flat passenger traffic in the first half of 2015, reaching 26.6 million, a 0.2% year-on-year increase. Aircraft take-offs and landings decreased by 1%, while cargo volume increased by 0.2%. Thailand overtook Indonesia as the busiest route to Changi Airport, with Bangkok seeing a 30% growth in passenger movements. Other cities in the top five included Kuala Lumpur, Hong Kong, and Manila.

site_title: Hyundai Motor sets first interim dividend after land deal
summary: Hyundai Motor announced its first interim dividend of 1,000 won per share, totaling 268.7 billion won (S$316 million), following criticism over overpaying for a piece of land in central Seoul last year. The stock rose 4.2% after the announcement. The company plans to use the site for a hotel, convention center, and auto theme park, and will relocate 30 affiliates to the new site. This move aims to increase shareholder returns and offset the negative impact of the land deal on the company's shares, which fell 34% after the deal was announced last September.

site_title: Uber to deliver Xiaomi smartphones in Singapore and Malaysia
summary: Uber has partnered with Xiaomi to deliver the company's new Mi Note smartphone in Singapore and Malaysia. The partnership allows Uber users to purchase the device through the Uber app, which will be charged to their account and delivered shortly thereafter. This marks Uber's expansion into the same-day delivery business, as the company aims to utilize its hundreds of thousands of active drivers to transport both passengers and goods. The partnership is seen as a strategic move by Xiaomi to generate buzz for the product launch in Southeast Asia and India.

site_title: Ho Bee Land acquires office building in London for £144m
summary: Singapore's Ho Bee Land Limited acquired a London office building for £144m (S$308m) from British Land, marking the company's fourth commercial property in London and fifth overall in the UK. The 10-storey building, developed in 2014, is let to the Corporate Officer of the House of Commons until 2029. The acquisition aims to grow recurring income and is seen as a move to diversify overseas for profit growth.

images.alt_text: Developed by British Land in 2014, the property at Victoria Street is a 10-storey office building with retail space on the ground floor, totalling approximately 98,000 square feet.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Friday
summary: Singapore's electoral boundaries report shows 89 Members of Parliament will be elected after the next general election, two more than the current batch. HDB resale prices slipped 0.4% in Q2, while manufacturing output contracted 4.4% in June. Private home prices and rents fell 0.9% and 2.6% respectively in Q2. Singapore shares closed lower, despite gains in penny stocks. Internationally, Vietnam reacted to the US tariff announcement, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Malaysia's Daim Zainuddin's assets are set to be seized.

site_title: Japan July flash manufacturing PMI rises as domestic orders increase
summary: Japan's manufacturing activity expanded at the fastest pace in five months, according to a July flash PMI survey, as domestic orders increased. The index rose to 51.4 from 50.1 in June, indicating growth after an expected slump in the second quarter. New orders and output component of the PMI index also rose, while new export orders fell. The data suggests economic growth is picking up, with Japan's economy expected to expand 0.7% in April-June and 2.0% in the current quarter.

site_title: Australia's drought bringing the beef to McDonald's, Carl's Jr
summary: Australia's severe drought, fueled by a strengthening El Nino, is boosting beef exports to the US, with shipments reaching an all-time high. The drought has led to a surge in cattle feedlots and a near-record number of cattle being sent to slaughter, with 70% of Australian beef destined for burgers. This has benefited US hamburger chains like McDonald's and Carl's Jr, which are sourcing Australian beef to meet demand due to the US herd's low levels.

site_title: US bond investors tend to overestimate inflation
summary: US bond investors overestimate inflation, with data showing that actual inflation has been lower than expected since 1999. This disparity is crucial as it influences the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates. Despite signs of an economic upswing, inflation remains below the central bank's 2% goal, with the 10-year Treasury yield rising to 2.26% and economists predicting a 50% chance of a rate hike in September. Historically, the bond market's inflation estimates have been off the mark, suggesting investors are pricing in too high an inflation outlook.

site_title: Singapore's asset management industry shows strong growth; AUM up 30% to S$2.36 trillion in 2014
summary: Singapore's asset management industry experienced strong growth in 2014, with assets under management (AUM) increasing by 30% to S$2.36 trillion. This growth was driven by sovereign wealth funds setting up offices in the country to access Asian investment opportunities. The industry also saw significant growth in trading volumes, with average daily foreign exchange turnover rising 40% to US$478 billion and total futures and options contracts reaching a new high of 120 million. Other sectors, including corporate debt and offshore insurance, also expanded in 2014.

site_title: Payrolls rose in 31 US states in June, led by New York
summary: US payrolls rose in 31 states in June, led by New York's 25,500 job gain. The unemployment rate fell in 21 states, with Nebraska holding the lowest rate at 2.6% and West Virginia the highest at 7.4%. The national jobless rate dropped to 5.3%, while wages stagnated and the labour force shrank. The Federal Reserve is considering raising interest rates this year due to solid job growth.

site_title: Virgin Australia flight turns back to LA after window crack
summary: A Virgin Australia flight bound for Brisbane was turned back to Los Angeles after a crack was found in the aircraft's windscreen, approximately 30 minutes into its flight. The Boeing 777 was forced to return as a precautionary measure. Engineers are working to rectify the issue, and passengers are being rebooked. Passengers reported feeling anxious during the flight, but were reassured by the airline's response. The flight was eventually diverted back to Los Angeles for further inspection and repairs.

images.alt_text: A Virgin Australia flight bound for Brisbane was turned back to Los Angeles after a crack was found in the passenger jet's windscreen, the airline said Thursday.

site_title: Father of modern human resources
summary: Dave Ulrich, known as the "father of modern human resources," argues that HR units should focus on enabling business results rather than just addressing policy issues. He advocates for retaining top performers and believes that placing underperforming employees in competitors' companies can be a strategic move. Ulrich co-founded RBL Group, an HR consultancy firm that provides advisory services to multinational firms. The firm aims for impact over growth and has registered a compound annual growth rate of 8-12%. Ulrich is concerned about the "liability of success," where companies become complacent and fail to adapt to changing times, leading to decline. He emphasizes the importance of good leadership in driving change and engagement among employees.

site_title: S'pore-made cancer drug starts clinical trials
summary: A Singapore-developed cancer drug, ETC-159, has advanced into clinical trials, targeting colorectal, ovarian, and pancreatic cancers by inhibiting Wnt signalling pathways. If successful, it could be Singapore's first made-in-Singapore blockbuster cancer drug. The Phase I clinical trial will study the safety and effect of ETC-159 in 58 patients, with trials to be conducted in Singapore and the US. The drug candidate has been under development since 2009, and its development marks a major breakthrough in cancer therapeutics.

site_title: Audi cuts 2015 car sales outlook on China
summary: Audi lowered its global sales forecast due to slumping demand in China, its largest market. The company now expects deliveries to increase between 3-4% this year, down from a previous forecast of 5-9.9%. Audi attributed the decline to China's "bumpy road" in the next few months, despite posting a 9.1% gain in first-half operating profit, driven by growth in the European market. The brand maintained its revenue and operating profit margin targets.

images.alt_text: Audi lowered its global sales forecast because of slumping demand in China, the luxury-car brand's biggest market.

site_title: Australia dollar skids to 6-year low on soft China data
summary: The Australian dollar dropped to a 6-year low after disappointing China manufacturing data, with the Aussie falling to US$0.7269. The data, which showed a flash Caixin/Markit China PMI of 48.2, was a miss by over a point and put pressure on commodity prices. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand cut interest rates this week, and analysts predict further easing in September. The poor data also raised concerns about Australia's credit rating, although the triple A rating was reaffirmed with a stable outlook.

site_title: US stocks may rise as focus turns to corporate earnings
summary: US stocks may rise as investors focus on corporate earnings, following a calming of market concerns over Greece and China. Standard & Poor's 500 companies will report earnings this week, shifting attention from macroeconomic issues. Experts expect a relatively bright US economic outlook, with portfolio manager Eric Marshall stating that the focus on earnings will lead to a more stable market.

site_title: Intel sales forecasts may exceed analysts' estimates
summary: Intel forecasts third-quarter sales of $14.3 billion, exceeding analysts' estimates of $14 billion, driven by rising server demand and gains in the PC chip market share. The company expects revenue to remain little changed this year, despite a decline in the PC market, as it benefits from growing demand for data centers. Gross margin is forecast at 63%, higher than analysts' estimate of 61.2%. Intel shares rose 1.7% following the announcement.

site_title: Donald Trump as a political paradox
summary: Donald Trump, a Wall Street investor and reality TV personality, has gained popularity among Republican primary voters, leading in opinion polls despite being a non-traditional candidate. Trump's populist rhetoric and criticism of economic elites, immigrants, and foreign leaders have resonated with conservative and patriotic Americans. However, his comments disparaging war heroes, such as John McCain, have sparked criticism from the media and establishment. Despite this, Trump's growing attacks from the establishment may actually increase his popularity among Republican voters, potentially dominating the 2016 Republican presidential nomination.

site_title: Gasoline, eggs lift US consumer prices in June
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.3% in June, marking a fifth straight month of increases, driven by higher gasoline and egg prices. The core CPI, excluding food and energy, rose 0.2%, while the year-on-year CPI rate increased 0.1%. This strengthens the case for an interest rate hike, with Fed Chair Janet Yellen affirming the central bank's intent to start tightening monetary policy later this year.

site_title: US insurer MetLife launches new innovation centre in Singapore
summary: US insurer MetLife has launched its new innovation centre, LumenLab, in Singapore, focusing on health, wealth, and retirement solutions for Asian consumers. The 7,800 sq ft centre aims to anticipate the needs of the region, expected to account for half of the insurance industry's growth in the next decade. LumenLab is based on the "Asiafication of Demand" phenomenon, where Asian consumers drive the demand curve. The centre's CEO, Zia Zaman, emphasizes the importance of consumer insights in driving innovation, positioning MetLife for growth in the region.

site_title: China says H1 foreign direct investment up 8.0% year-on-year: ministry
summary: China reported a 8.0% year-on-year increase in foreign direct investment in the first six months of 2015, with investment in the services sector rising 23.0% from the previous year. Vice Commerce Minister Wang Shouwen attributed the growth to China's fast-growing services sector. The exact investment value and June figures were not disclosed by the Ministry of Commerce.

site_title: Oil prices edge up, but glut fears cap gains
summary: Oil prices rose 19 cents to $51.10 a barrel for US benchmark West Texas Intermediate and 20 cents to $57.12 for Brent crude, but gains are unlikely due to concerns about a global supply glut. The global economy's slow recovery and increasing dollar strength also weigh on prices. A historic deal between Iran and world powers easing sanctions on its oil exports and a US energy report showing rising oil stockpiles in Oklahoma also contributed to the price increase. Investors expect prices to remain stable despite solid US economic data.

site_title: China widens access to its gold market
summary: China has expanded its gold market to Hong Kong investors, allowing them to trade the precious metal using offshore yuan. The move aims to influence global gold prices and boost the yuan's global use. The Shanghai Gold Exchange now offers yuan-denominated gold products, with daily turnover averaging 9,634 kilograms in May. This is part of China's efforts to increase its influence in the global gold market and expand the use of the yuan beyond its borders.

site_title: Asia: Stocks climb after Greeks endorse bailout; kiwi tumbles
summary: Asian stocks rose 0.3% after Greece endorsed new bailout demands, easing concerns over the currency union. The kiwi dollar plummeted to a six-year low due to inflation data and dairy price slumps. Ten-year Treasury yields rebounded, while the euro lost value against the dollar. Economists predict New Zealand will cut interest rates again next week, leading commodity-linked currencies to decline. The Federal Reserve continues to forecast a gradual pace of interest rate tightening in 2015.

site_title: ECB awaits midnight Athens signal as Greek lenders in limbo
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is awaiting a Greek parliament vote at midnight to grant fresh liquidity to the country's lenders, who are in limbo after two weeks of closure and capital controls. The ECB may increase the cap on Emergency Liquidity Assistance (ELA) if Greece proceeds with a planned bailout program, including repaying debt to the central bank on July 20. The ECB's decision is conditional on Greece's government implementing reform measures, which are set to be voted on by the parliament on Wednesday.

site_title: Walmart, Amazon square off over big July sales events
summary: Walmart and Amazon are competing in a major sales event in July. Walmart will offer 2,000 products at lower prices, free shipping at $35, and discounts for 90 days. The sale starts on July 15, the same day as Amazon's "Prime Day," which promises "more deals than Black Friday." Amazon has criticized Walmart for charging higher prices in physical stores compared to online. Walmart's CEO said, "We've always believed in giving customers low prices every day," in response to Amazon's counter-attack.

site_title: Dish Network's talks for T-Mobile stalled: sources
summary: Dish Network's talks to acquire T-Mobile US Inc from Deutsche Telekom AG have stalled due to valuation and structure concerns. The halt in talks has raised doubts about a potential transaction this year or at all. T-Mobile needs more spectrum to grow, and a deal with Dish would allow it to avoid billions of dollars in government auctions. The ball is now in Dish's court, with Deutsche Telekom having told Dish what kind of offer it wants, which Dish has yet to meet.

site_title: German giants set on goal
summary: Borussia Dortmund, a German football club, is on a week-long pre-season tour in Asia to expand its fanbase. The team, led by a Singaporean, visited Singapore, Japan, and Malaysia, playing friendly matches and connecting with fans. Dortmund aims to keep ticket prices affordable, with the cheapest season ticket costing £160 (S$332), and has a high average attendance at home games. Star players Mats Hummels and Ilkay Gundogan have pledged to stay with the club, despite offers from other European sides, and are enthusiastic about the growth of the Bundesliga in Asia.

site_title: Good times for airlines rarely endure
summary: Airlines generate the slimmest returns for investors among 29 industries worldwide, according to Iata. Despite a bumper year for the industry, driven by low fuel prices and weaker competition, airlines' profits are expected to remain tight. The Bloomberg World Airlines Index has fallen 10-12% from its peak, exceeding a market correction. Experts warn that good times for airlines rarely endure, as increased capacity can lead to "irrational price competition" and a market share war.

site_title: UK austerity drive could be counter-productive: analysts
summary: The UK government's austerity drive, aiming to reduce welfare dependency and slash £12 billion from welfare costs over five years, has sparked concerns that it could be counter-productive, particularly for low-paid workers. Analysts warn that the changes, including reducing tax credits and introducing a higher minimum wage, may not mitigate the benefit cuts and could instead hit the poorest families, forcing them to choose between paying bills and missing meals. The measures have been criticized for being inconsistent and potentially worsening work disincentives.

site_title: China wealth fund buys US$1.4b of European properties
summary: China's sovereign wealth fund, China Investment Corp, has acquired US$1.4 billion worth of European retail properties, including shopping centers and malls in France and Belgium. This deal follows a trend of international investors buying retail properties in continental Europe to capitalize on the nascent economic recovery. The purchase marks a significant investment in the region, as office, shop, and logistics buildings valued at 87.3 billion euros were sold in the first quarter, a 25% increase from the previous year.

site_title: P&G to sell beauty brands portfolio to Coty
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has agreed to sell its portfolio of 43 beauty brands to Coty for $12.5 billion. The deal includes brands such as Wella, Clairol, and Gucci, and is part of P&G's efforts to shed non-core brands and focus on 10 core product lines. Coty, which already owns brands like Calvin Klein and Marc Jacobs, will enter the haircare market with the acquisition. The deal is expected to be completed through a reverse Morris trust, a tax-efficient spin-off, and is part of P&G's strategy to create value through focused growth.

images.alt_text: PRODUCT FOCUS: The deal is part of P&G's efforts to shed more than 100 brands and focus on about 10 core product lines, such as Tide.

site_title: Cool cruises to hot Cuba
summary: US-Cuba relations warming, tourists flock to the island nation as cruise ships become a popular way to experience Havana's retro vibe without hassle. Major cruise lines like Royal Caribbean, Norwegian Cruise Line, and Carnival have expressed interest in sailing to Cuba, with smaller ships offering cosy groups, personalized journeys, and bespoke service. MSC Cruises will start Caribbean cruises from Cuba in December, while AdventureSmith Explorations offers eight-day Cuba cruises on a three-masted schooner, starting at $4,999 per person. Travelers are drawn to Cuba's unique culture resulting from its isolation, and many hope to experience it before the country undergoes significant changes.

site_title: China's bid to extend economic diplomacy entangled in EU fund rules
summary: China is considering a 10 billion euro investment in the EU's new infrastructure fund, but negotiations are stalled due to EU fund rules that limit Chinese technology companies' role. China's Premier Li Keqiang initially pledged to invest in the fund but later mentioned an additional co-investment fund. The investment aims to support Europe's digitalization efforts and align with China's "One Belt, One Road" initiative. The EU's guarantees for the fund pose an obstacle, as China would need to accept the risk of project failure and have limited say in choosing projects.

site_title: Greece and China will still set the pace
summary: Greece and China continue to dominate global headlines, with Greece's referendum and potential euro exit, and China's stock market meltdown. However, experts believe the main issue lies with the deep structural problems plaguing the local stock market, particularly institutional underweighting. Singapore stocks, despite being "boring" and defensive, may offer an 8% return in the next 12 months, according to Macquarie Equities Research. Despite some optimism, concerns remain about the stability of the Greek and Chinese economies, with some warning of potential systemic risks and can-kicking.

site_title: Europe demands new Greek debt plan at crisis summit
summary: European leaders are pressuring Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras to present new bailout proposals at an emergency summit, warning that Greece risks leaving the euro if no agreement is reached. The country's economy is struggling, with banks closed until at least Thursday due to fears of an implosion. German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Francois Hollande have urged Tsipras to make "precise" proposals to rebuild trust and restart negotiations, amid a backdrop of a 'No' vote in a referendum on further austerity measures.

site_title: Beware of the global debt trap
summary: A global debt trap is forming, where high debt levels and low economic growth are intertwined, making it difficult for countries to service their debts. This phenomenon is not unique to Greece, but rather a shared problem among major countries, including the US, Japan, France, and others. High debt levels are widespread, with no clear benchmark, and economic growth has slowed in many countries, exacerbating the issue. The combination of high debt and low growth creates an unstable situation, with little room for maneuver, and a potential collapse if interest rates rise or investor sentiment worsens.

site_title: If Japan firm succeeds, jets will fly on algae fuel
summary: Japan's Euglena Co aims to commercialize algae-based bio jet fuel by 2020, partnering with ANA and Chevron. The company has developed a nutritional supplement from green algae, which it plans to use as a feedstock for biofuel production. With over 59 nutrients, Euglena has various applications, including cosmetics and medical bandages, and is expected to overtake health food as a business. Analysts see Euglena as a frontrunner in the field, with competitors struggling to catch up. The company's success could drive demand for alternative jet fuels, driven by a global CO2 emissions cap.

site_title: China service sector slows to 5-month low
summary: China's services sector slowed to a 5-month low in June, with the HSBC/Markit Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 51.8, indicating expansion for the 11th straight month. Despite this, economists warn that the economy still needs policy support due to persistent weakness in exports and the property sector, as well as high local government debt. The sector's new business sub-component and employment sub-index also showed slower growth, indicating jobs are being shed. The central bank may ease policy further to support growth, which is expected to slow to around 7% in 2015, the weakest annual expansion in a quarter of a century.

site_title: Seven-seat style
summary: The Land Rover Discovery Sport is a seven-seat, seven-seater SUV with the styling of the Range Rover Evoque but wider dimensions. It features a 2.0-litre turbocharged engine producing 240 hp and a 9-speed automatic transmission for efficiency. The vehicle has a spacious interior with a luxurious cabin, excellent visibility, and useful features like Park Assist. With a starting price of SGD 244,999, it is ideal for young families, offering a balance of performance and practicality.

site_title: Facebook's Sandberg joins SurveyMonkey board
summary: Facebook's Sheryl Sandberg joins SurveyMonkey's board, following the death of her late husband, Dave Goldberg, who was SurveyMonkey's CEO until his death in May. Goldberg's former CFO, David Ebersman, also joins the board. The company is searching for a new CEO. Sandberg expressed her support for Goldberg's vision and looked forward to helping realize it. The appointments were announced on SurveyMonkey's website and reflect the company's commitment to its mission.

site_title: Australian dollar heads for parity with Singapore dollar
summary: The Australian dollar is on track to reach parity with the Singapore dollar due to weak commodity prices and the rising US dollar. As of Wednesday, one Australian dollar was valued at approximately S$1.0019, its weakest point since the 2009 global financial crisis. This decline is attributed to a decrease in commodity prices and the US dollar's strengthening value.

site_title: China unveils 'Internet Plus' action plan to juice slow economy
summary: China has unveiled its "Internet Plus" plan to boost economic growth, aiming to rejuvenate traditional industries and manage the country's slowest pace of growth since the 2009 global recession. The plan will utilize internet technologies to optimize manufacturing, agriculture, energy, finance, and other sectors, and will upgrade infrastructure to improve data streaming ability in remote and rural areas. The government will lower market-entry barriers, build a nationwide credit system, and earmark funds for the plan, aiming to give consumers and services more prominence in the economy.

site_title: Felda eyes US$262m asset sale
summary: Felda Global Ventures Holdings Bhd plans to sell non-core assets worth over 1 billion ringgit (US$260 million) to repair investor confidence, following a contentious acquisition of PT Eagle High Plantations in Indonesia. The company aims to raise debt to finance the purchase and may monetize its plantation estates through an initial public offering. Felda's shares have declined 26% this year, and the company's CEO, Mohd Emir Mavani Abdullah, believes the company is "definitely undervalued" compared to other plantation companies.

site_title: Printing the new drachma: the messy future of a post-euro Greece
summary: Greece's potential exit from the eurozone due to a rejected international bailout referendum poses significant challenges. The country lacks the administrative capacity to quickly introduce a new currency, the drachma, and the transition would have to happen fast with little planning. The Greek banking system relies on European Central Bank support, which might be withdrawn, forcing Greece to create its own means of exchange. Introducing a new currency typically takes at least six months, and the process involves distributing new notes and coins, as well as planning for bank accounts, debts, and financial instruments.

site_title: ST Aerospace seals US$350m deal
summary: ST Aerospace has sealed a six-year, US$350 million engine maintenance contract with India's Jet Airways and its subsidiary JetLite. The contract extends an existing agreement and covers CFM56-7B engines powering Boeing 737-Next Generation aircraft. ST Aerospace will provide maintenance services at facilities in Singapore and China's Xiamen. This partnership, which began 22 years ago, is expected to have minimal impact on ST Engineering's financials.

site_title: China: Stocks plunge again as regulators hunt for bull market killer
summary: China's stocks plummeted 5.4% on Friday, taking their three-week decline to nearly 30% and wiping out most of this year's gains. The CSI300 index and Shanghai Composite Index fell 10.4% and 12.1%, respectively, amid news of investigations into suspected market manipulation by regulators. The China Securities Regulatory Commission set up a team to look into "clues of illegal manipulation" across markets, and the China Financial Futures Exchange suspended 19 accounts from short-selling for a month. The central bank and Premier Li Keqiang's comments failed to calm investors.

site_title: Doyen of money managers
summary: Capital Group Companies, led by chairman Jim Rothenberg, has maintained a stellar long-term track record despite underperforming during the 2008-2010 global financial crisis. The firm's unique approach, known as the Capital System, involves multiple managers working in portfolios, which has contributed to its success. Rothenberg argues that active management has value and can outperform passive investing, citing examples of successful active managers and the challenges of the passive theory. He emphasizes the importance of talent, research, and a well-organized approach. Rothenberg also highlights emerging trends, including the impact of aging and retirement on investment strategy, and the growing importance of global investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: 'We are not advocating that active management is better than passive management. What we are trying to say is that there is a possibility that active management has value.'

site_title: Indonesia softens tone on airlines' finances
summary: Indonesia's transport ministry has softened its stance on airlines' finances, stating it will "help and support" airlines struggling to meet a deadline to improve their finances, rather than shutting them down. This move follows concerns about the measures that sent AirAsia's shares to five-year lows. The ministry's change in tone has alleviated investor concerns, with AirAsia's shares recovering some losses and trading 1.5% lower. The move is seen as a step towards addressing regulatory uncertainty in Indonesia's aviation industry.

site_title: The physics of technology
summary: Former Applied Materials chairman Michael Splinter emphasizes the company's high-tech nature, despite its lower market capitalization compared to other tech giants like Apple. He credits Applied Materials' equipment and services as driving the semiconductor industry's advancements. Splinter attributes the company's success to its focus on R&D, hiring PhDs, and investing 15-20% of revenue in research. He predicts significant changes in device functionality, including the rise of 3D flash memory, which will enable more powerful gadgets at lower prices. Splinter also sees opportunities for innovation in areas like smart cities, transportation, and IoT, and believes that companies willing to take risks with new technologies will thrive.

site_title: Singapore can play key role in AIIB
summary: Singapore can play a key role in the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) by developing its infrastructure ecosystem to serve as a hub for innovative project development and finance in Southeast Asia and beyond. With its strong engineering capabilities, financial hub status, and good legal and regulatory system, Singapore is well-positioned to integrate these elements to benefit infrastructure projects. The country's experience and involvement in the AIIB can also help mitigate corruption and promote good governance, ensuring high-quality infrastructure standards are maintained.

site_title: Singapore's manufacturing, electronics PMIs rise in June
summary: Singapore's manufacturing and electronics sectors showed signs of improvement in June, with the main PMI rising to 50.4 and the electronics PMI increasing to 50.3. This follows a fourth consecutive month of declining industrial production in May. While the uptick in PMI suggests growth, external demand uncertainties remain, and whether the improvement can be sustained into the third quarter is uncertain.

site_title: Danske Bank warns Copenhagen property is Scandinavia's riskiest
summary: Copenhagen's property market is becoming increasingly risky, according to Danske Bank, with homebuyers seeking to borrow more than 3.5 times their annual income to afford apartments. Despite being the cheapest in Scandinavia, Copenhagen flats are priced at 35,000 kroner per square meter, making them unaffordable for many. Risks are rising faster in Copenhagen than anywhere else in the Nordic region, pricing out low-income households and fueling concerns of a housing bubble.

site_title: Ascott Reit expands into US with US$163.5m acquisition of New York hotel
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (Ascott Reit) has expanded into the US with a US$163.5 million acquisition of the 411-room Element New York Times Square West hotel in Midtown Manhattan. The acquisition is expected to increase distribution income by US$0.8 million and raise distribution per unit to 8.51 cents. The hotel has had over 90% occupancy in the last three years, and the US economy is forecasted to expand by 2.4% in 2015 and 2.5% in 2016.

site_title: Despite crisis, analysts resolute on China's copper demand growth forecasts
summary: Analysts remain optimistic about China's copper demand growth forecasts, despite the country's economic crisis. China accounts for half of the world's copper demand, with forecasts ranging between 1-5% growth for 2015. Despite a recent stock market crash, analysts see measures taken by the government as a boon for copper demand, citing infrastructure spending and construction projects. Benchmark copper prices have recovered from a six-year low, and Chinese shares have rebounded by 15% following state intervention. Experts expect Chinese end-user demand for copper to remain solid, with some predicting a 3.6% growth rate for the year.

site_title: Greece's Tsipras digs in against bailout
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has rejected an international bailout deal, urging Greeks to vote "No" in a referendum on Sunday that may decide Greece's future in Europe. The deal, which would accept most creditor demands, was proposed just hours after Tsipras had written a conciliatory letter to creditors. Tsipras claims Greece is being "blackmailed" and says a "No" vote would lead to a better agreement. European partners have warned that the referendum would effectively be a vote on whether Greece stays in the euro or returns to the drachma, with no further discussions on a new bailout package until after the vote.

images.alt_text: A defiant Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras urged Greeks on Wednesday to reject an international bailout deal, wrecking any prospect of repairing broken relations with European Union partners before a referendum on Sunday that may decide Greece's future in Europe.

site_title: New Deutsche Bank CEO warns staff will act to fix problems
summary: Deutsche Bank's new CEO, John Cryan, has warned staff that the bank will implement tough reforms to address problems, including a damaged reputation and high operating costs. Cryan, who took over on his first day, said the bank will close unprofitable business lines, narrow its scope, and delay publication of details on a strategic overhaul until October. He vowed to hold accountable those who misbehave and repair relationships with regulators. Investors are hoping for swift action to tackle issues that have depressed the bank's share price and led to a management crisis.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank's new Chief Executive John Cryan told staff to prepare for tough reforms as he shakes up a group that he said had become too diversified and complex.

site_title: SGX to MAS: Unaware of any reasons for unusual trading activity
summary: SGX shares rose 5 cents to $7.83 on Tuesday, with 3.7 million shares traded, due to unusual activity. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) stated it was unaware of any reasons for the unusual trading. The company later corrected its previous market closing day to Wednesday.

images.alt_text: THE Singapore Exchange said on Wednesday that it was unaware of any possible reasons that could explain the unusual trading activity in its share price.

site_title: No final deal in Pacific trade talks: negotiators
summary: US and 11 Pacific nations failed to reach a final deal on the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free-trade agreement after several days of talks in Hawaii, dealing a setback to President Barack Obama. Despite "significant progress," US Trade Representative Michael Froman said the remaining issues will be ironed out through bilateral discussions. The TPP, a comprehensive trade bloc covering 40% of the world's economy, faces criticism for its secrecy and potential to favor corporate interests over economic growth. The delay could jeopardize its ratification in Congress ahead of the 2016 US presidential election.

images.alt_text: Delegates negotiating a huge Pacific free-trade agreement said Friday they have failed to reach a final deal after several days of intense talks in Hawaii, in a setback to US President Barack Obama.

site_title: Not interested in being PM, says Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam stated that it's only a matter of time before Singapore sees a prime minister from a minority race, but he's not interested in the position. He believes such a move is unnecessary with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's health and a group of younger candidates waiting in the wings. Tharman made these comments at an SG50+ conference, discussing Singapore's future leadership and the country's path ahead.

images.alt_text: IT'S just a matter of time before Singapore sees a prime minister from a minority race, said Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam on Friday - but it won't be him, as he is not interested in the job.
